{"code":1,"isDone":false,"toInsertArticleList":[{"createdTime":"2020-08-17 03:23:55","updatedTime":"2020-08-17 03:23:55","title":"The Story of Us: Full Series","link":"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=7510","description":"\n<div class=\"wp-block-image-map-pro-image-map-pro\"><div id=\"image-map-pro-980\"></div></div>\n\n\n\n<p style=\"text-align: left;\"> </p>\n<p style=\"text-align: left;\">Sign up for our <strong><a class=\"ClickPico PicoRule\">email list</a></strong> and we&#8217;ll let you know when new posts are published.</p>\n<p>The post <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/08/story-of-us.html\">The Story of Us: Full Series</a> appeared first on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"http://waitbutwhy.com\">Wait But Why</a>.</p>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 26 Aug 2019 09:00:11 +0000","feedId":382,"bgimg":"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Series-Feature-Drawing-FB.png","linkMd5":"087c65c8d338547d3736754c1a7cc0ce","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn44@2020_4/2020/08/16/19-23-57-091_340b11a154d98bdb.webp","metaImg":"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Series-Feature-Drawing-FB.png","destWidth":999,"destHeight":524,"author":"Tim Urban"},{"createdTime":"2020-08-17 03:23:54","updatedTime":"2020-08-17 03:23:54","title":"Neuralink and the Brain’s Magical Future","link":"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120","description":"<p><span style=\"font-size: 10pt;\"><em><strong>Note:</strong> If you want to print this post or read it offline, the PDF is probably the way to go. You can <a href=\"https://gum.co/neuralink\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">buy it here</a>.<br /> </em></span><span style=\"font-size: 10pt;\"><em>And <a href=\"http://waitbutwhy.com/neuralink-cleanversion\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">here’s a G-rated version of the post</a>, appropriate for all ages.</em></span></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">_______________________</p> \n<p>Last month, I got a phone call.</p> \n<p><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6304\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Call-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"603\" height=\"385\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Call-1.png 1800w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Call-1-300x192.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Call-1-768x491.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Call-1-600x383.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 603px) 100vw, 603px\" /></p> \n<p>Okay maybe that’s not exactly how it happened, and maybe those weren’t his exact words. But after learning about the new company Elon Musk was starting, I’ve come to realize that that’s exactly what he’s trying to do.</p> \n<p>When I wrote about <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2015/06/how-tesla-will-change-your-life.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Tesla</a> and <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2015/08/how-and-why-spacex-will-colonize-mars.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">SpaceX</a>, I learned that you can only fully wrap your head around certain companies by zooming both way, way in <em>and</em> way, way out. In, on the technical challenges facing the engineers, out on the existential challenges facing our species. In on a snapshot of the world right now, out on the big story of how we got to this moment and what our far future could look like.</p> \n<p>Not only is Elon’s new venture—Neuralink—the same type of deal, but six weeks after first learning about the company, I’m convinced that it somehow manages to eclipse Tesla and SpaceX in both the boldness of its engineering undertaking and the grandeur of its mission. The other two companies aim to redefine what future humans will do—Neuralink wants to redefine what future humans will <em>be</em><em>.</em></p> \n<p>The mind-bending <em>bigness </em>of Neuralink’s mission, combined with the labyrinth of impossible complexity that is the human brain, made this the hardest set of concepts yet to fully wrap my head around—but it also made it the most exhilarating when, with enough time spent zoomed on both ends, it all finally <em>clicked</em>. I feel like I took a time machine to the future, and I’m here to tell you that it’s even weirder than we expect.</p> \n<p>But before I can bring you in the time machine to show you what I found, we need to get in our zoom machine—because as I learned the hard way, Elon’s wizard hat plans cannot be properly understood until your head’s in the right place.</p> \n<p>So wipe your brain clean of what it thinks it knows about itself and its future, put on soft clothes, and let’s jump into the vortex.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">___________</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\"><span style=\"text-decoration: underline; font-size: 20pt;\">Contents</span></p> \n<p><span style=\"text-align: left; font-size: 14pt;\"><strong><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#part1\">Part 1: The Human Colossus</a> </strong></span></p> \n<p><span style=\"text-align: left; font-size: 14pt;\"><strong><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#part2\">Part 2: The Brain</a> </strong></span></p> \n<p><span style=\"text-align: left; font-size: 14pt;\"><strong><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#part3\">Part 3: Brain-Machine Interfaces</a> </strong></span></p> \n<p><span style=\"text-align: left; font-size: 14pt;\"><strong><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#part4\">Part 4: Neuralink’s Challenge</a> </strong></span></p> \n<p><span style=\"text-align: left; font-size: 14pt;\"><strong><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#part5\">Part 5: The Wizard Era</a></strong></span></p> \n<p><span style=\"text-align: left; font-size: 14pt;\"><strong><a name=\"part1\"></a><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#part6\">Part 6: The Great Merger</a> </strong></span></p> \n<p><img class=\"size-full wp-image-6480 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Notes-Key.png\" alt=\"Notes key: Type 1 are fun notes for fun facts, extra thoughts, or further explanation. Type 2 are boring notes for sources and citations.\" width=\"589\" height=\"185\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Notes-Key.png 589w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Notes-Key-300x94.png 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 589px) 100vw, 589px\" /></p> \n<hr /> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 28pt;\"><strong>Part 1: The Human Colossus</strong></span></p> \n<p>600 million years ago, no one really did anything, ever.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/sponge.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"wp-image-6247 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/sponge.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"356\" height=\"360\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/sponge.png 639w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/sponge-297x300.png 297w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/sponge-593x600.png 593w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 356px) 100vw, 356px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/sponge-2.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6248\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/sponge-2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"356\" height=\"360\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/sponge-2.png 639w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/sponge-2-297x300.png 297w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/sponge-2-593x600.png 593w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 356px) 100vw, 356px\" /></a></p> \n<p>The problem is that no one had any nerves. Without nerves, you can’t move, or think, or process information of any kind. So you just had to kind of exist and wait there until you died.</p> \n<p>But then came the jellyfish.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/jellyfish-1.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6212\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/jellyfish-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"400\" height=\"336\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/jellyfish-1.png 900w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/jellyfish-1-300x252.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/jellyfish-1-768x644.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/jellyfish-1-600x503.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 400px) 100vw, 400px\" /></a></p> \n<p>The jellyfish was the first animal to figure out that nerves were an obvious thing to make sure you had, and it had the world’s first nervous system—a nerve net.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/jellyfish-3.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6213\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/jellyfish-3.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"400\" height=\"336\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/jellyfish-3.png 900w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/jellyfish-3-300x252.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/jellyfish-3-768x644.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/jellyfish-3-600x503.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 400px) 100vw, 400px\" /></a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/jellyfish-5.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6215\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/jellyfish-5.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"400\" height=\"336\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/jellyfish-5.png 900w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/jellyfish-5-768x644.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/jellyfish-5-600x503.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 400px) 100vw, 400px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/jellyfish-6.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6216\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/jellyfish-6.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"400\" height=\"336\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/jellyfish-6.png 900w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/jellyfish-6-300x252.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/jellyfish-6-768x644.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/jellyfish-6-600x503.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 400px) 100vw, 400px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/jellyfish-7.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6217\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/jellyfish-7.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"400\" height=\"336\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/jellyfish-7.png 900w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/jellyfish-7-300x252.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/jellyfish-7-768x644.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/jellyfish-7-600x503.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 400px) 100vw, 400px\" /></a><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/jellyfish-8a.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6455\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/jellyfish-8a.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"400\" height=\"336\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/jellyfish-8a.png 900w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/jellyfish-8a-300x252.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/jellyfish-8a-768x644.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/jellyfish-8a-600x503.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 400px) 100vw, 400px\" /></a></p> \n<p>The jellyfish’s nerve net allowed it to collect important information from the world around it—like where there were objects, predators, or food—and pass that information along, through a big game of telephone, to all parts of its body. Being able to receive and process information meant that the jellyfish could actually react to changes in its environment in order to increase the odds of life going well, rather than just floating aimlessly and hoping for the best.</p> \n<p>A little later, a new animal came around who had an even cooler idea.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/flatworm-1.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6249\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/flatworm-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"400\" height=\"300\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/flatworm-1.png 900w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/flatworm-1-300x225.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/flatworm-1-768x576.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/flatworm-1-600x450.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 400px) 100vw, 400px\" /></a></p> \n<p>The flatworm figured out that you could get a lot more done if there was someone in the nervous system who was in charge of everything—a nervous system boss. The boss lived in the flatworm’s head and had a rule that all nerves in the body had to report any new information directly to him. So instead of arranging themselves in a net shape, the flatworm’s nervous system all revolved around a central highway of messenger nerves that would pass messages back and forth between the boss and everyone else:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Flatworm-brain-1-2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6377\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Flatworm-brain-1-2.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"440\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Flatworm-brain-1-2.jpg 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Flatworm-brain-1-2-300x220.jpg 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Flatworm-brain-1-2-768x563.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Flatworm-brain-1-2-600x440.jpg 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Flatworm-brain-2-2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6378\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Flatworm-brain-2-2.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"440\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Flatworm-brain-2-2.jpg 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Flatworm-brain-2-2-300x220.jpg 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Flatworm-brain-2-2-768x563.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Flatworm-brain-2-2-600x440.jpg 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a></p> \n<p>The flatworm’s boss-highway system was the world’s first central nervous system, and the boss in the flatworm’s head was the world’s first brain.</p> \n<p>The idea of a nervous system boss quickly caught on with others, and soon, there were thousands of species on Earth with brains.</p> \n<p>As time passed and Earth’s animals started inventing intricate new body systems, the bosses got busier.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/frog-1-1.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\" wp-image-6320 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/frog-1-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"256\" height=\"246\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/frog-1-1.png 404w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/frog-1-1-300x288.png 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 256px) 100vw, 256px\" /></a></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Frog-brain-1-1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6368\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Frog-brain-1-1.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"440\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Frog-brain-1-1.jpg 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Frog-brain-1-1-300x220.jpg 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Frog-brain-1-1-768x563.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Frog-brain-1-1-600x440.jpg 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Frog-brain-2-2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6460\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Frog-brain-2-2.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"440\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Frog-brain-2-2.jpg 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Frog-brain-2-2-300x220.jpg 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Frog-brain-2-2-768x563.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Frog-brain-2-2-600x440.jpg 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a></p> \n<p>A little while later came the arrival of mammals. For the Millennials of the Animal Kingdom, life was complicated. Yes, their hearts needed to beat and their lungs needed to breathe, but mammals were about a lot more than survival functions—they were in touch with complex feelings like love, anger, and fear.</p> \n<p>For the reptilian brain, which had only had to deal with reptiles and other simpler creatures so far, mammals were just…a lot. So a second boss developed in mammals to pair up with the reptilian brain and take care of all of these new needs—the world’s first limbic system.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/rodent-1-1.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\" wp-image-6346 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/rodent-1-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"407\" height=\"290\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/rodent-1-1.png 604w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/rodent-1-1-300x214.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/rodent-1-1-600x427.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 407px) 100vw, 407px\" /></a></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rodent-brain-1-2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6456\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rodent-brain-1-2.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"440\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rodent-brain-1-2.jpg 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rodent-brain-1-2-300x220.jpg 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rodent-brain-1-2-768x563.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rodent-brain-1-2-600x440.jpg 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Over the next 100 million years, the lives of mammals grew more and more complex, and one day, the two bosses noticed a new resident in the cockpit with them.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/primate-1-2.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6343\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/primate-1-2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"400\" height=\"335\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/primate-1-2.png 900w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/primate-1-2-300x251.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/primate-1-2-768x643.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/primate-1-2-600x502.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 400px) 100vw, 400px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Primate-brain-1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6373\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Primate-brain-1.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"440\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Primate-brain-1.jpg 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Primate-brain-1-300x220.jpg 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Primate-brain-1-768x563.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Primate-brain-1-600x440.jpg 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a></p> \n<p>What appeared to be a random infant was actually the early version of the neocortex, and though he didn’t say much at first, as evolution gave rise to primates and then great apes and then early hominids, this new boss grew from a baby into a child and eventually into a teenager with his own idea of how things should be run.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/homonid-1-1.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\" wp-image-6323 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/homonid-1-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"355\" height=\"350\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/homonid-1-1.png 715w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/homonid-1-1-300x295.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/homonid-1-1-600x591.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 355px) 100vw, 355px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Hominid-brain-1-3.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6379\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Hominid-brain-1-3.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"440\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Hominid-brain-1-3.png 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Hominid-brain-1-3-300x220.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Hominid-brain-1-3-768x563.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Hominid-brain-1-3-600x440.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Hominid-brain-2-3.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"wp-image-6380 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Hominid-brain-2-3.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"440\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Hominid-brain-2-3.png 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Hominid-brain-2-3-300x220.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Hominid-brain-2-3-768x563.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Hominid-brain-2-3-600x440.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a></p> \n<p>The new boss’s ideas turned out to be really helpful, and he became the hominid’s go-to boss for things like tool-making, hunting strategy, and cooperation with other hominids.</p> \n<p>Over the next few million years, the new boss grew older and wiser, and his ideas kept getting better. He figured out how to not be naked. He figured out how to control fire. He learned how to make a spear.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Spear.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6251\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Spear.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"300\" height=\"312\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Spear.png 492w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Spear-288x300.png 288w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /></a></p> \n<p>But his coolest trick was <em>thinking</em>. He turned each human’s head into a little world of its own, making humans the first animal that could think complex thoughts, reason through decisions, and make long-term plans.</p> \n<p>And then, maybe about 100,000 years ago, he came up with a breakthrough.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rock-1.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6222\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rock-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"700\" height=\"514\" http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rock-17-600x440.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rock-18.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6239\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rock-18.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"440\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rock-18.png 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rock-18-300x220.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rock-18-768x563.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rock-18-600x440.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rock-19.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6240\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rock-19.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"440\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rock-19.png 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rock-19-300x220.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rock-19-768x563.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rock-19-600x440.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rock-20.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6241\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rock-20.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"440\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rock-20.png 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rock-20-300x220.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rock-20-768x563.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rock-20-600x440.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rock-21.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6242\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rock-21.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"440\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rock-21.png 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rock-21-300x220.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rock-21-768x563.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rock-21-600x440.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rock-22.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6243\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rock-22.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"440\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rock-22.png 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rock-22-300x220.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rock-22-768x563.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rock-22-600x440.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rock-23.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6244\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rock-23.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"440\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rock-23.png 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rock-23-300x220.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rock-23-768x563.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Rock-23-600x440.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a></p> \n<p>The human brain had advanced to the point where it could understand that even though the sound “rock” was not <em>itself</em> a rock, it could be used as a <em>symbol</em> of a rock—it was a sound that <em>referred</em> to a rock. The early human had invented language.</p> \n<p>Soon there were words for all kinds of things, and by 50,000 BC, humans were speaking in full, complex language with each other.</p> \n<p>The neocortex had turned humans into magicians. Not only had he made the human head a wondrous internal ocean of complex thoughts, his latest breakthrough had found a way to translate those thoughts into a symbolic set of sounds and send them vibrating through the air into the heads of other humans, who could then decode the sounds and absorb the embedded idea into their own internal thought oceans. The human neocortex had been thinking about things for a long time—and he finally had someone to talk about it all with.</p> \n<p>A neocortex party ensued. Neocortexes—fine—neocortices shared everything with each other—stories from their past, funny jokes they had thought of, opinions they had formed, plans for the future.</p> \n<p>But most useful was sharing what they had <em>learned</em>. If one human learned through trial and error that a certain type of berry led to 48 hours of your life being run by diarrhea, they could use language to share the hard-earned lesson with the rest of their tribe, like photocopying the lesson and handing it to everyone else. Tribe members would then use language to pass along that lesson to their children, and their children would pass it to their own children. Rather than the same mistake being made again and again by many different people, one person’s “stay away from that berry” wisdom could travel through space and time to protect everyone else from having their bad experience.</p> \n<p>The same thing would happen when one human figured out a new clever trick. One unusually-intelligent hunter particularly attuned to both star constellations and the annual migration patterns of wildebeest<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote-1-6120\" id=\"note-1-6120\" rel=\"footnote\">1</a> herds could share a system he devised that used the night sky to determine exactly how many days remained until the herd would return. Even though very few hunters would have been able to come up with that system on their own, through word-of-mouth, all future hunters in the tribe would now benefit from the ingenuity of one ancestor, with that one hunter’s crowning discovery serving as every future hunter’s <em>starting point</em> of knowledge.</p> \n<p>And let’s say this knowledge advancement makes the hunting season more efficient, which gives tribe members more time to work on their weapons—which allows one extra-clever hunter a few generations later to discover a method for making lighter, denser spears that can be thrown more accurately. And just like that, every present and future hunter in the tribe hunts with a more effective spear.</p> \n<p>Language allows the best epiphanies of the very smartest people, through the generations, to accumulate into a little collective tower of tribal knowledge—a “greatest hits” of their ancestors’ best “aha!” moments. Every new generation has this knowledge tower installed in their heads as their starting point in life, leading them to new, even better discoveries that build on what their ancestors learned, as the tribe’s knowledge continues to grow bigger and wiser. Language is the difference between this:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/Knowledge-growth-graph-1b.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6474\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/Knowledge-growth-graph-1b.png\" alt=\"minimal tribal knowledge growth before language\" width=\"800\" height=\"355\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/Knowledge-growth-graph-1b.png 1220w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/Knowledge-growth-graph-1b-300x133.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/Knowledge-growth-graph-1b-768x341.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/Knowledge-growth-graph-1b-600x266.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" /></a></p> \n<p>And this:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Knowledge-growth-graph-2-1.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6458\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Knowledge-growth-graph-2-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"800\" height=\"894\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Knowledge-growth-graph-2-1.png 1318w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Knowledge-growth-graph-2-1-268x300.png 268w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Knowledge-growth-graph-2-1-768x858.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Knowledge-growth-graph-2-1-537x600.png 537w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" /></a></p> \n<p>The major trajectory upgrade happens for two reasons. Each generation can learn a lot more new things when they can talk to each other, compare notes, and combine their individual learnings (that’s why the blue bars are so much higher in the second graph). And each generation can successfully pass a higher percentage of their learnings on to the next generation, so knowledge <em>sticks</em> better through time.</p> \n<p>Knowledge, when shared, becomes like a grand, collective, inter-generational collaboration. Hundreds of generations later, what started as a pro tip about a certain berry to avoid has become an intricate system of planting long rows of the stomach-friendly berry bushes and harvesting them annually. The initial stroke of genius about wildebeest migrations has turned into a system of goat domestication. The spear innovation, through hundreds of incremental tweaks over tens of thousands of years, has become the bow and arrow.</p> \n<p>Language gives a group of humans a <em>collective intelligence </em>far greater than individual human intelligence and allows each human to benefit from the collective intelligence as if he came up with it all himself. We think of the bow and arrow as a primitive technology, but raise Einstein in the woods with no existing knowledge and tell him to come up with the best hunting device he can, and he won’t be <em>nearly </em>intelligent or skilled or knowledgeable enough to invent the bow and arrow. Only a <em>collective </em>human effort can pull that off.</p> \n<p>Being able to speak to each other also allowed humans to form complex social structures which, along with advanced technologies like farming and animal domestication, led tribes over time to begin to settle into permanent locations and merge into organized super-tribes. When this happened, each tribe’s tower of accumulated knowledge could be shared with the larger super-tribe, forming a super-tower. Mass cooperation raised the quality of life for everyone, and by 10,000 BC, the first cities had formed.</p> \n<p>According to Wikipedia, there’s something called Metcalfe’s law, which states that “the value of a telecommunications network is proportional to the square of the number of connected users of the system.” And they include this little chart of old telephones:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-1-6120\" id=\"note2-1-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">1</a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/Metcalfe-Network-Effect.svg_.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6121\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/Metcalfe-Network-Effect.svg_.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"200\" height=\"460\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/Metcalfe-Network-Effect.svg_.png 476w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/Metcalfe-Network-Effect.svg_-131x300.png 131w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/Metcalfe-Network-Effect.svg_-261x600.png 261w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 200px) 100vw, 200px\" /></a></p> \n<p>But the same idea applies to people. Two people can have one conversation. Three people have four unique conversation groups (three different two-person conversations and a fourth conversation between all three as a group). Five people have 26. Twenty people have 1,048,555.</p> \n<p>So not only did the members of a city benefit from a <em>huge </em>knowledge tower as a foundation, but Metcalfe’s law means that the number of conversation possibilities now skyrocketed to an unprecedented amount of variety. More conversations meant more ideas bumping up against each other, which led to many more discoveries clicking together, and the pace of innovation soared.</p> \n<p>Humans soon mastered agriculture, which freed many people up to think about all kinds of other ideas, and it wasn’t long before they stumbled upon a new, giant breakthrough: writing.</p> \n<p>Historians think humans first started writing things down about 5 – 6,000 years ago. Up until that point, the collective knowledge tower was stored only in a network of people’s memories and accessed only through livestream word-of-mouth communication. This system worked in small tribes, but with a vastly larger body of knowledge shared among a vastly larger group of people, memories alone would have had a hard time supporting it all, and most of it would have ended up lost.</p> \n<p>If language let humans send a thought from one brain to another, writing let them stick a thought onto a physical <em>object</em>,<em> </em>like a stone, where it could live forever. When people began writing on thin sheets of parchment or paper, huge fields of knowledge that would take weeks to be conveyed by word of mouth could be compressed into a book or a scroll you could hold in your hand. The human collective knowledge tower now lived in physical form, neatly organized on the shelves of city libraries and universities.</p> \n<p>These shelves became humanity’s grand instruction manual on everything. They guided humanity toward new inventions and discoveries, and those would in turn become new books on the shelves, as the grand instruction manual built upon itself. The manual taught us the intricacies of trade and currency, of shipbuilding and architecture, of medicine and astronomy. Each generation began life with a higher floor of knowledge and technology than the last, and progress continued to accelerate.</p> \n<p>But painstakingly handwritten books were treated like treasures,<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote-2-6120\" id=\"note-2-6120\" rel=\"footnote\">2</a> and likely only accessible to the extreme elite (in the mid 15th century, there were only <a href=\"http://www.history.com/news/7-things-you-may-not-know-about-the-gutenberg-bible\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">30,000 books</a> in all of Europe). And then came another breakthrough: the printing press.</p> \n<p>In the 15th century, the <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Johannes_Gutenberg#/media/File:Gutenberg.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">beardy</a> Johannes Gutenberg came up with a way to create multiple identical copies of the same book, much more quickly and cheaply than ever before. (Or, more accurately, when Gutenberg was born, humanity had already figured out the first 95% of how to invent the printing press, and Gutenberg, with that knowledge as his starting point, invented the last 5%.) (Oh, also, Gutenberg didn’t invent the printing press, <a href=\"http://www.history.com/news/7-things-you-may-not-know-about-the-gutenberg-bible\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">the Chinese did</a> a bunch of centuries earlier. Pretty reliable rule is that everything you think was invented somewhere other than China was probably actually invented in China.) Here’s how it worked:</p> \n<div class=\"wbwAside\"> \n <p><span style=\"font-size: 14pt;\"><strong>It Turns Out Gutenberg Isn’t Actually Impressive Blue Box</strong></span></p> \n <p>To prepare to write this blue box, I found <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0ojyCDRc8uc\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">this video</a> explaining how Gutenberg’s press worked and was surprised to find myself unimpressed. I always assumed Gutenberg had made some genius machine, but it turns out he just created a bunch of stamps of letters and punctuation and manually arranged them as the page of a book and then put ink on them and pressed a piece of paper onto the letters, and that was one book page. While he had the letters all set up for that page, he’d make a bunch of copies. Then he’d spend forever manually rearranging the stamps (this is the “movable type” part) into the next page, and then do a bunch of copies of that. His first project was 180 copies of the Bible,<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote-3-6120\" id=\"note-3-6120\" rel=\"footnote\">3</a> which took him and his employees two years.</p> \n <p><em>That</em>‘<em>s </em>Gutenberg’s thing? A bunch of stamps? I feel like I could have come up with that pretty easily. Not really clear why it took humanity 5,000 years to go from figuring out how to write to creating a bunch of manual stamps. I guess it’s not that I’m unimpressed with Gutenberg—I’m neutral on Gutenberg, he’s fine—it’s that I’m unimpressed with everyone else.</p> \n</div> \n<p>Anyway, despite how disappointing Gutenberg’s press turned out to be, it was a <em>huge </em>leap forward for humanity’s ability to spread information. Over the coming centuries, printing technology rapidly improved, bringing the number of pages a machine could print in an hour from about 25 in Gutenberg’s time<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote-4-6120\" id=\"note-4-6120\" rel=\"footnote\">4</a> up 100-fold to 2,400 by the early 19th century.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-2-6120\" id=\"note2-2-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">2</a></p> \n<p>Mass-produced books allowed information to spread like wildfire, and with books being made increasingly affordable, no longer was education an elite privilege—millions now had access to books, and literacy rates shot upwards. One person’s thoughts could now reach millions of people. The era of mass communication had begun.</p> \n<p>The avalanche of books allowed knowledge to transcend borders, as the world’s regional knowledge towers finally merged into one species-wide knowledge tower that stretched into the stratosphere.</p> \n<p>The better we could communicate on a mass scale, the more our species began to function like a single organism, with humanity’s collective knowledge tower as its brain and each individual human brain like a nerve or a muscle fiber in its body. With the era of mass communication upon us, the collective human organism—the Human Colossus—rose into existence.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Human-Colossus.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6209\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Human-Colossus.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"500\" height=\"704\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Human-Colossus.png 1096w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Human-Colossus-213x300.png 213w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Human-Colossus-768x1082.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Human-Colossus-426x600.png 426w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 500px) 100vw, 500px\" /></a></p> \n<p>With the entire body of collective human knowledge in its brain, the Human Colossus began inventing things no human could have dreamed of inventing on their own—things that would have seemed like absurd science fiction to people only a few generations before.</p> \n<p>It turned our ox-drawn carts into speedy locomotives and our horse-and-buggies into shiny metal cars. It turned our lanterns into lightbulbs and written letters into telephone calls and factory workers into industrial machines. It sent us soaring through the skies and out into space. It redefined the meaning of “mass communication” by giving us radio and TV, opening up a world where a thought in someone’s head could be beamed instantly into the brains of a billion people.</p> \n<p>If an individual human’s core motivation is to pass its genes on, which keeps the species going, the forces of macroeconomics make the Human Colossus’s core motivation to create value, which means it tends to want to invent newer and better technology. Every time it does that, it becomes an even better inventor, which means it can invent new stuff even faster.</p> \n<p>And around the middle of the 20th century, the Human Colossus began working on its most ambitious invention yet.</p> \n<p>The Colossus had figured out a long time ago that the best way to create value was to invent value-creating <em>machines</em>. Machines were better than humans at doing many kinds of work, which generated a flood of new resources that could be put towards value creation. Perhaps even more importantly, machine labor freed up huge portions of human time and energy—i.e. huge portions of the Colossus itself—to focus on innovation. It had already outsourced the work of our arms to factory machines and the work of our legs to driving machines, and it had done so through the power of its brain—now what if, somehow, it could outsource the work of the brain <em>itself </em>to a machine?</p> \n<p>The first digital computers sprung up in the 1940s.</p> \n<p>One kind of brain labor computers could do was the work of information storage—they were <em>remembering</em> machines. But we already knew how to outsource our memories using books, just like we had been outsourcing our leg labor to <a href=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/06/Horse-hand.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">horses</a> long before cars provided a far better solution. Computers were simply a memory-outsourcing upgrade.</p> \n<p>Information-<em>processing </em>was a different story—a type of brain labor we had never figured out how to outsource. The Human Colossus had always had to do all of its own computing. Computers changed that.</p> \n<p>Factory machines allowed us to outsource a physical process—we put a material in, the machines physically processed it and spit out the results. Computers could do the same thing for information processing. A software program was like a factory machine for information processes.</p> \n<p>These new information-storage/organizing/processing machines proved to be useful. Computers began to play a central role in the day-to-day operation of companies and governments. By the late 1980s, it was common for individual people to own their own personal brain assistant.</p> \n<p>Then came another leap.</p> \n<p>In the early 90s, we taught millions of isolated machine-brains how to communicate with one another. They formed a worldwide computer network, and a new giant was born—the Computer Colossus.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Computer-Colossus-1.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6444\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Computer-Colossus-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"500\" height=\"684\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Computer-Colossus-1.png 1096w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Computer-Colossus-1-219x300.png 219w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Computer-Colossus-1-768x1051.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Computer-Colossus-1-438x600.png 438w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 500px) 100vw, 500px\" /></a></p> \n<p>The Computer Colossus and the great network it formed were like popeye spinach for the Human Colossus.</p> \n<p>If individual human brains are the nerves and muscle fibers of the Human Colossus, the internet gave the giant its first legit nervous system. Each of its nodes was now interconnected to all of its other nodes, and information could travel through the system with light speed. This made the Human Colossus a faster, more fluid thinker.</p> \n<p>The internet gave billions of humans instant, free, easily-searchable access to the entire human knowledge tower (which by now stretched past the moon). This made the Human Colossus a smarter, faster learner.</p> \n<p>And if individual computers had served as brain extensions for individual people, companies, or governments, the Computer Colossus was a brain extension for the entire Human Colossus itself.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/HC-3.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6443\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/HC-3.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"500\" height=\"870\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/HC-3.png 1096w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/HC-3-172x300.png 172w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/HC-3-768x1337.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/HC-3-345x600.png 345w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 500px) 100vw, 500px\" /></a></p> \n<p>With its first real nervous system, an upgraded brain, and a powerful new tool, the Human Colossus took inventing to a whole new level—and noticing how useful its new computer friend was, it focused a large portion of its efforts on advancing computer technology.</p> \n<p>It figured out how to make computers faster and cheaper. It made internet faster and wireless. It made computing chips smaller and smaller until there was a powerful computer in everyone’s pocket.</p> \n<p>Each innovation was like a new truckload of spinach for the Human Colossus.</p> \n<p>But today, the Human Colossus has its eyes set on an even bigger idea than more spinach. Computers have been a game-changer, allowing humanity to outsource many of its brain-related tasks and better function as a single organism. But there’s one kind of brain labor computers still can’t quite do. <em>Thinking.</em></p> \n<p>Computers can compute and organize and run complex software—software that can even learn on its own. But they can’t <em>think </em>in the way humans can. The Human Colossus knows that everything it’s built has originated with its ability to reason creatively and independently—and it knows that the <em>ultimate </em>brain extension tool would be one that can really, actually, legitimately <em>think</em>. It has no idea what it will be like when the Computer Colossus can think for itself—when it one day opens its eyes and becomes a <em>real </em>colossus—but with its core goal to create value and push technology to its limits, the Human Colossus is determined to find out.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">___________</p> \n<p>We’ll come back here in a bit. First, we have some learning to do.</p> \n<p>As we’ve discussed <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2015/06/how-tesla-will-change-your-life.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">before</a>, knowledge works like a tree. If you try to learn a branch or a leaf of a topic before you have a solid tree trunk foundation of understanding in your head, it won’t work. The branches and leaves will have nothing to stick to, so they’ll fall right out of your head.</p> \n<p>We’ve established that Elon Musk wants to build a wizard hat for the brain, and understanding why he wants to do that is the key to understanding Neuralink—and to understanding what our future might actually be like.</p> \n<p>But none of that will make much sense until we really get into the truly mind-blowing concept of what a wizard hat is, what it might be like to wear one, and how we get there from where we are today.</p> \n<p>The foundation for <em>that </em>discussion is an understanding of what brain-machine interfaces are, how they work, and where the technology is today.</p> \n<p>Finally, BMIs themselves are just a larger branch—not the tree’s trunk. In order to really understand BMIs and how they work, we need to understand the brain. Getting how the brain works is our tree trunk.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-tree-1.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6479\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-tree-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"800\" height=\"800\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-tree-1.png 1100w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-tree-1-150x150.png 150w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-tree-1-300x300.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-tree-1-768x768.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-tree-1-600x600.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" /></a></p> \n<p><a name=\"part2\"></a>So we’ll start with the brain, which will prepare us to learn about BMIs, which will teach us about what it’ll take to build a wizard hat, and that’ll set things up for an insane discussion about the future—which will get our heads right where they need to be to wrap themselves around why Elon thinks a wizard hat is such a critical piece of our future. And by the time we reach the end, this whole thing should click into place.</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 28pt;\"><strong>Part 2: The Brain</strong></span></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-tree-Parts-2.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6436\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-tree-Parts-2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"150\" height=\"138\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-tree-Parts-2.png 633w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-tree-Parts-2-300x277.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-tree-Parts-2-600x554.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 150px) 100vw, 150px\" /></a></p> \n<p>This post was a nice reminder of why I like working with a brain that looks nice and cute like this:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/cartoon-brain.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6253\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/cartoon-brain.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"400\" height=\"243\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/cartoon-brain.png 1100w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/cartoon-brain-300x182.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/cartoon-brain-768x466.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/cartoon-brain-600x364.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 400px) 100vw, 400px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Because the real brain is extremely uncute and upsetting-looking. People are gross.</p> \n<p>But I’ve been living in a shimmery, oozy, blood-vessel-lined Google Images hell for the past month, and now you have to deal with it too. So just settle in.</p> \n<p>We’ll start outside the head. One thing I will give to biology is that it’s sometimes very satisfying,<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote-5-6120\" id=\"note-5-6120\" rel=\"footnote\">5</a> and the brain has some satisfying things going on. The first of which is that there’s a real Russian doll situation going on with your head.</p> \n<p>You have your hair, and under that is your scalp, and then you think your skull comes next—but it’s actually like 19 things and then your skull:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-3-6120\" id=\"note2-3-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">3</a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/A270654_1_En_2_Fig3_HTML.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\" wp-image-6123 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/A270654_1_En_2_Fig3_HTML.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"537\" height=\"285\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/A270654_1_En_2_Fig3_HTML.jpg 593w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/A270654_1_En_2_Fig3_HTML-300x159.jpg 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 537px) 100vw, 537px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Then below your skull,<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote-6-6120\" id=\"note-6-6120\" rel=\"footnote\">6</a> another whole bunch of things are going on before you get to the brain<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-4-6120\" id=\"note2-4-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">4</a>:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Men1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\" wp-image-6124 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Men1.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"535\" height=\"437\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Men1.jpg 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Men1-300x245.jpg 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 535px) 100vw, 535px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Your brain has three membranes around it underneath the skull:</p> \n<p>On the outside, there’s the <strong>dura mater</strong> (which means “hard mother” in Latin), a firm, rugged, waterproof layer. The dura is flush with the skull. I’ve heard it said that the brain has no pain sensory area, but the dura actually does—it’s about as sensitive as the skin on your face—and pressure on or contusions in the dura often account for people’s bad headaches.</p> \n<p>Then below that there’s the <strong>arachnoid mater </strong>(“spider mother”), which is a layer of skin and then an open space with these stretchy-looking fibers. I always thought my brain was just floating aimlessly in my head in some kind of fluid, but actually, the only real space gap between the outside of the brain and the inner wall of the skull is this arachnoid business. Those fibers stabilize the brain in position so it can’t move too much, and they act as a shock absorber when your head bumps into something. This area is filled with spinal fluid, which keeps the brain mostly buoyant, since its density is similar to that of water.</p> \n<p>Finally you have the <strong>pia mater </strong>(“soft mother”), a fine, delicate layer of skin that’s fused with the outside of the brain. You know how when you see a brain, it’s always covered with icky blood vessels? Those aren’t actually on the brain’s surface, they’re embedded in the pia. (For the non-squeamish, <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ak1FWodg5Nw\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">here’s a video</a> of a professor peeling the pia off of a human brain.)</p> \n<p>Here’s the full overview, using the head of what looks like probably a pig:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/338317926b0c5edcd883a0ff35fa3f2b.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"size-full wp-image-6125 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/338317926b0c5edcd883a0ff35fa3f2b.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"530\" height=\"530\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/338317926b0c5edcd883a0ff35fa3f2b.jpg 530w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/338317926b0c5edcd883a0ff35fa3f2b-150x150.jpg 150w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/338317926b0c5edcd883a0ff35fa3f2b-300x300.jpg 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 530px) 100vw, 530px\" /></a></p> \n<p>From the left you have the skin (the pink), then two scalp layers, then the skull, then the dura, arachnoid, and on the far right, just the brain covered by the pia.</p> \n<p>Once we’ve stripped everything down, we’re left with this silly boy:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-5-6120\" id=\"note2-5-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">5</a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/brain1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\" wp-image-6126 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/brain1.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"618\" height=\"494\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/brain1.jpg 660w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/brain1-300x240.jpg 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/brain1-600x480.jpg 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 618px) 100vw, 618px\" /></a></p> \n<p>This ridiculous-looking thing is the most complex known object in the universe—three pounds of what neuroengineer Tim Hanson calls “<span class=\"s1\">one of the most information-dense, structured, and self-structuring matter known.”<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-6-6120\" id=\"note2-6-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">6</a> All while operating on only <a href=\"http://www.popsci.com/technology/article/2009-11/neuron-computer-chips-could-overcome-power-limitations-digital\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">20 watts</a> of power (an <a href=\"http://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-supercomputer-idUSKCN0J11VV20141117\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">equivalently powerful computer</a> runs on 24,000,000 watts).</span></p> \n<p>It’s also what MIT professor Polina Anikeeva <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6Qi5uoNYXqg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">calls</a> “soft pudding you could scoop with a spoon.” Brain surgeon Ben Rapoport described it to me more scientifically, as “somewhere between pudding and jello.” He explained that if you placed a brain on a table, gravity would make it lose its shape and flatten out a bit, kind of like a jellyfish. We often don’t think of the brain as so smooshy, because it’s normally suspended in water.</p> \n<p>But this is what we all are. You look in the mirror and see your body and your face and you think that’s you—but that’s really just the machine you’re riding in. What you actually are is a zany-looking ball of jello. I hope that’s okay.</p> \n<p>And given how weird that is, you can’t really blame Aristotle, or the ancient Egyptians, or many others, for assuming that the brain was somewhat-meaningless “cranial stuffing” (Aristotle believed the heart was the center of intelligence).<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-7-6120\" id=\"note2-7-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">7</a></p> \n<p>Eventually, humans figured out the deal. But only kind of.</p> \n<p>Professor Krishna Shenoy <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZuATvhlcUU4\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">likens</a> our understanding of the brain to humanity’s grasp on the world map <a href=\"https://www.loc.gov/loc/lcib/0309/images/maps_4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">in the early 1500s</a>.</p> \n<p>Another professor, <a href=\"http://lichtmanlab.fas.harvard.edu/people/jeff-lichtman\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Jeff Lichtman</a>, is even harsher. He starts off his courses by asking his students the question, “If everything you need to know about the brain is a mile, how far have we walked in this mile?” He says students give answers like three-quarters of a mile, half a mile, a quarter of a mile, etc.—but that he believes the real answer is “about three inches.”<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-8-6120\" id=\"note2-8-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">8</a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/How-do-you-work-4.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\" wp-image-6425 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/How-do-you-work-4.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"233\" height=\"325\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/How-do-you-work-4.png 571w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/How-do-you-work-4-215x300.png 215w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/How-do-you-work-4-431x600.png 431w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 233px) 100vw, 233px\" /></a></p> \n<p>A third professor, neuroscientist <a href=\"https://www.morancerf.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Moran Cerf</a>, shared with me an old neuroscience saying that points out why trying to master the brain is a bit of a catch-22: “If the human brain were so simple that we could understand it, we would be so simple that we couldn’t.”</p> \n<p>Maybe with the help of the great knowledge tower our species is building, we can get there at some point. For now, let’s go through what we do currently know about the jellyfish in our heads—starting with the big picture.</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 20pt;\"><strong>The brain, zoomed out</strong></span></p> \n<p>Let’s look at the major sections of the brain using a hemisphere cross section. So this is what the brain looks like in your head:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/sh202-hs.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\" wp-image-6193 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/sh202-hs.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"336\" height=\"400\" /></a></p> \n<p>Now let’s take the brain out of the head and remove the left hemisphere, which gives us a good view of the inside.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-9-6120\" id=\"note2-9-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">9</a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-cross-section.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"size-full wp-image-6299 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-cross-section.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"454\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-cross-section.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-cross-section-300x227.png 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Neurologist <a href=\"http://www.kheper.net/topics/intelligence/MacLean.htm\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Paul MacLean</a> made a simple diagram that illustrates the basic idea we talked about earlier of the reptile brain coming first in evolution, then being built upon by mammals, and finally being built upon again to give us our brain trifecta.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/triune-brain-theory.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6128\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/triune-brain-theory.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"500\" height=\"444\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/triune-brain-theory.jpg 875w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/triune-brain-theory-300x266.jpg 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/triune-brain-theory-768x682.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/triune-brain-theory-600x533.jpg 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 500px) 100vw, 500px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Here’s how this essentially maps out on our real brain:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-cross-section-LABELED.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"size-full wp-image-6300 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-cross-section-LABELED.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"454\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-cross-section-LABELED.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-cross-section-LABELED-300x227.png 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Let’s take a look at each section:</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 18pt;\"><strong>The Reptilian Brain: The Brain Stem (and Cerebellum)</strong></span></p> \n<p>This is the most ancient part of our brain:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-10-6120\" id=\"note2-10-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">10</a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/brainstem-v2.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6489\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/brainstem-v2.png\" alt=\"midbrain, pons, cerebellum, and medulla oblongata\" width=\"400\" height=\"314\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/brainstem-v2.png 1208w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/brainstem-v2-300x235.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/brainstem-v2-768x603.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/brainstem-v2-600x471.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 400px) 100vw, 400px\" /></a></p> \n<p>That’s the section of our brain cross section above that the frog boss resides over. In fact, a frog’s entire brain is similar to this lower part of our brain. Here’s a real frog brain:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-11-6120\" id=\"note2-11-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">11</a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/frogside107.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\" wp-image-6129 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/frogside107.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"505\" height=\"185\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/frogside107.jpg 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/frogside107-300x110.jpg 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 505px) 100vw, 505px\" /></a></p> \n<p>When you understand the function of these parts, the fact that they’re ancient makes sense—everything these parts do, frogs and lizards can do. These are the major sections (click any of these spinning images to see a high-res version):</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 14pt;\"><strong>The</strong> <strong>medulla oblongata</strong></span> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Medulla_oblongata-1.gif\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"size-full wp-image-6261 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Medulla_oblongata_small.gif\" alt=\"\" width=\"200\" height=\"200\" /></a></p> \n<p>The medulla oblongata really just wants you to not die. It does the thankless tasks of controlling involuntary things like your heart rate, breathing, and blood pressure, along with making you vomit when it thinks you’ve been poisoned.</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 14pt;\"><strong>The pons</strong></span> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Pons-1.gif\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"size-full wp-image-6260 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Pons_small.gif\" alt=\"\" width=\"200\" height=\"200\" /></a></p> \n<p>The pons’s thing is that it does a little bit of this and a little bit of that. It deals with swallowing, bladder control, facial expressions, chewing, saliva, tears, and posture—really just whatever it’s in the mood for.</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 14pt;\"><strong>The midbrain</strong></span> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Midbrain.gif\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"size-full wp-image-6259 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Midbrain_small.gif\" alt=\"\" width=\"200\" height=\"200\" /></a></p> \n<p>The midbrain is dealing with an even bigger identity crisis than the pons. You know a brain part is going through some shit when almost all its functions are already another brain part’s thing. In the case of the midbrain, it deals with vision, hearing, motor control, alertness, temperature control, and a bunch of other things that other people in the brain already do. The rest of the brain doesn’t seem very into the midbrain either, given that they created a ridiculously uneven “forebrain, midbrain, hindbrain” divide that intentionally isolates the midbrain all by itself while everyone else hangs out.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-12-6120\" id=\"note2-12-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">12</a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/CNX_Psych_03_04_FMHBrain.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\" wp-image-6130 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/CNX_Psych_03_04_FMHBrain.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"392\" height=\"286\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/CNX_Psych_03_04_FMHBrain.jpg 487w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/CNX_Psych_03_04_FMHBrain-300x219.jpg 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 392px) 100vw, 392px\" /></a></p> \n<p>One thing I’ll grant the pons and midbrain is that it’s the two of them that control your voluntary eye movement, which is a pretty legit job. So if right now you move your eyes around, that’s you doing something specifically with your pons and midbrain.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote-7-6120\" id=\"note-7-6120\" rel=\"footnote\">7</a></p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 14pt;\"><strong>The cerebellum</strong></span> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Cerebellum.gif\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"size-full wp-image-6258 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Cerebellum_animation_small.gif\" alt=\"\" width=\"150\" height=\"150\" /></a></p> \n<p>The odd-looking thing that looks like your brain’s scrotum is your cerebellum (Latin for “little brain”), which makes sure you stay a balanced, coordinated, and normal-moving person. <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mrt0Gq0zS4g\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Here’s that rad professor again</a> showing you what a real cerebellum looks
