like.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote-8-6120\" id=\"note-8-6120\" rel=\"footnote\">8</a></p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 18pt;\"><strong>The Paleo-Mammalian Brain: The Limbic System</strong></span></p> \n<p>Above the brain stem is the limbic system—the part of the brain that makes humans so insane.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-13-6120\" id=\"note2-13-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">13</a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/limbic.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6429\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/limbic.jpg\" alt=\"limbic system diagram\" width=\"500\" height=\"451\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/limbic.jpg 689w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/limbic-300x270.jpg 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/limbic-600x541.jpg 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 500px) 100vw, 500px\" /></a></p> \n<p>The limbic system is a survival system. A decent rule of thumb is that whenever you’re doing something that your dog might also do—eating, drinking, having sex, fighting, hiding or running away from something scary—your limbic system is probably behind the wheel. Whether it feels like it or not, when you’re doing any of those things, you’re in primitive survival mode.</p> \n<p>The limbic system is also where your emotions live, and in the end, emotions are also all about survival—they’re the more advanced mechanisms of survival, necessary for animals living in a complex social structure.</p> \n<p>In other posts, when I refer to your <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2013/10/why-procrastinators-procrastinate.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Instant Gratification Monkey</a>, your <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2014/06/taming-mammoth-let-peoples-opinions-run-life.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Social Survival Mammoth</a>, and <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2014/10/religion-for-the-nonreligious.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">all your other animals</a>—I’m usually referring to your limbic system. Anytime there’s an internal battle going on in your head, it’s likely that the limbic system’s role is urging you to do the thing you’ll later regret doing.</p> \n<p>I’m pretty sure that gaining control over your limbic system is both the definition of maturity and the core human struggle. It’s not that we would be better off without our limbic systems—limbic systems are half of what makes us distinctly human, and most of the fun of life is related to emotions and/or fulfilling your animal needs—it’s just that your limbic system doesn’t get that you live in a civilization, and if you let it run your life too much, it’ll quickly ruin your life.</p> \n<p>Anyway, let’s take a closer look at it. There are a lot of little parts of the limbic system, but we’ll keep it to the biggest celebrities:</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 14pt;\"><strong>The amygdala</strong> </span> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Amygdala.gif\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"size-full wp-image-6392 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Amygdala10.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"250\" height=\"234\" /></a></p> \n<p>The amygdala is kind of an emotional wreck of a brain structure. It deals with anxiety, sadness, and our responses to fear. There are two amygdalae, and oddly, the left one has been shown to be more balanced, sometimes producing happy feelings in addition to the usual angsty ones, while the right one is always in a bad mood.</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 14pt;\"><strong>The hippocampus</strong> </span> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Hippocampus.gif\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"size-full wp-image-6391 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/large.gif\" alt=\"\" width=\"200\" height=\"200\" /></a></p> \n<p>Your hippocampus (Greek for “seahorse” because it <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hippocampus#/media/File:Hippocampus_and_seahorse_cropped.JPG\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">looks like one</a>) is like a scratch board for memory. When rats start to memorize directions in a maze, the memory gets encoded in their hippocampus—quite literally. Different parts of the rat’s two hippocampi will fire during different parts of the maze, since each section of the maze is stored in its own section of the hippocampus. But if after learning one maze, the rat is given other tasks and is brought back to the original maze a year later, it will have a hard time remembering it, because the hippocampus scratch board has been mostly wiped of the memory so as to free itself up for new memories.</p> \n<p>The condition in the movie <em>Memento</em> is a real thing—anterograde amnesia—and it’s caused by damage to the hippocampus. Alzheimer’s also starts in the hippocampus before working its way through many parts of the brain, which is why, of the slew of devastating effects of the disease, diminished memory happens first.</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 14pt;\"><strong>The t</strong><strong>halamus</strong></span> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Thalamus.gif\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"size-full wp-image-6388 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/article_codev-2015-10-30-608d7118d8-Thalamus_small.gif\" alt=\"\" width=\"200\" height=\"200\" /></a></p> \n<p>In its central position in the brain, the thalamus also serves as a sensory middleman that receives information from your sensory organs and sends them to your cortex for processing. When you’re sleeping, the thalamus goes to sleep with you, which means the sensory middleman is off duty. That’s why in a deep sleep, some sound or light or touch often will not wake you up. If you want to wake someone up who’s in a deep sleep, you have to be aggressive enough to wake their thalamus up.</p> \n<p>The exception is your sense of smell, which is the one sense that bypasses the thalamus. That’s why smelling salts are used to wake up a passed-out person. While we’re here, cool fact: smell is the function of the <strong><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olfactory_bulb#/media/File:Head_olfactory_nerve_-_olfactory_bulb_en.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">olfactory bulb</a> </strong>and is the most ancient of the senses. Unlike the other senses, smell is located deep in the limbic system, where it works closely with the hippocampus and amygdala—which is why smell is so closely tied to memory and emotion.</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 18pt;\"><strong>The Neo-Mammalian Brain: The Cortex</strong></span></p> \n<p>Finally, we arrive at the cortex. The cerebral cortex. The neocortex. The cerebrum. The pallium.</p> \n<p>The most important part of the whole brain can’t figure out what its name is. Here’s what’s happening:</p> \n<div class=\"wbwAside\"> \n <p><span style=\"font-size: 14pt;\"><strong>The What the Hell is it Actually Called Blue Box</strong></span></p> \n <p>The<strong> cerebrum </strong>is the whole big top/outside part of the brain but it also technically includes some of the internal parts too.</p> \n <p><strong>Cortex </strong>means “bark” in Latin and is the word used for the outer layer of many organs, not just the brain. The outside of the cerebellum is the cerebellar cortex. And the outside of the cerebrum is the <strong>cerebral cortex.</strong> Only mammals have cerebral cortices. The equivalent part of the brain in reptiles is called the <strong>pallium. </strong></p> \n <p>The <strong>neocortex </strong>is often used interchangeably with “cerebral cortex,” but it’s technically the outer layers of the cerebral cortex that are especially developed in more advanced mammals. The other parts are called the allocortex.</p> \n <p>In the rest of this post, we’ll be mostly referring to the neocortex <strong>but we’ll just call it the cortex, </strong>since that’s the least annoying way to do it for everyone.</p> \n</div> \n<p>The cortex is in charge of basically everything—processing what you see, hear, and feel, along with language, movement, thinking, planning, and personality.</p> \n<p>It’s divided into four lobes:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-14-6120\" id=\"note2-14-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">14</a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/lobes2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6256\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/lobes2.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"500\" height=\"352\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/lobes2.jpg 800w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/lobes2-300x211.jpg 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/lobes2-768x540.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/lobes2-600x422.jpg 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 500px) 100vw, 500px\" /></a></p> \n<p>It’s pretty unsatisfying to describe what they each do, because they each do so many things and there’s a lot of overlap, but to oversimplify:</p> \n<p>The <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Frontal_lobe.gif\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><strong>frontal lobe </strong></a>(click the words to see a gif)<strong> </strong>handles your personality, along with a lot of what we think of as “thinking”—reasoning, planning, and executive function. In particular, a lot of your thinking takes place in the front part of the frontal lobe, called the <strong>prefrontal cortex</strong>—the adult in your head. The prefrontal cortex is the other character in those internal battles that go on in your life. The rational decision-maker trying to get you to do your work. The authentic voice trying to get you to stop worrying so much what others think and just be yourself. The higher being who wishes you’d stop sweating the small stuff.</p> \n<p>As if that’s not enough to worry about, the frontal lobe is also in charge of your body’s movement. The top strip of the frontal lobe is your <strong>primary motor cortex.</strong><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-15-6120\" id=\"note2-15-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">15</a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.getbodysmart.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/Primary-Motor-Cortex-Labeled-713x550.png\"><img class=\"alignnone \" src=\"https://www.getbodysmart.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/Primary-Motor-Cortex-Labeled-713x550.png\" width=\"363\" height=\"280\" /></a></p> \n<p>Then there’s the <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Parietal_lobe_animation.gif\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><strong>parietal lobe</strong></a> which, among other things, controls your sense of touch, particularly in the <strong>primary somatosensory cortex</strong>, the strip right next to the primary motor cortex.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-16-6120\" id=\"note2-16-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">16</a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://www.getbodysmart.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/Primary-Other-Somatosenory-Cortex-Areas-695x550.png\"><img class=\"alignnone \" src=\"https://www.getbodysmart.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/Primary-Other-Somatosenory-Cortex-Areas-695x550.png\" width=\"361\" height=\"286\" /></a></p> \n<p>The motor and somatosensory cortices are fun because they’re well-mapped. Neuroscientists know exactly which part of each strip connects to each part of your body. Which leads us to the creepiest diagram of this post: the <em>homunculus</em>.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/152-KB-Homonculus-Sensory-and-Motor-Cortex.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6134\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/152-KB-Homonculus-Sensory-and-Motor-Cortex.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"380\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/152-KB-Homonculus-Sensory-and-Motor-Cortex.png 1019w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/152-KB-Homonculus-Sensory-and-Motor-Cortex-300x152.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/152-KB-Homonculus-Sensory-and-Motor-Cortex-768x389.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/152-KB-Homonculus-Sensory-and-Motor-Cortex-600x304.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> \n<p>The homunculus, created by pioneer neurosurgeon Wilder Penfield, visually displays how the motor and somatosensory cortices are mapped. The larger the body part in the diagram, the more of the cortex is dedicated to its movement or sense of touch. A couple interesting things about this:</p> \n<p>First, it’s amazing that more of your brain is dedicated to the movement and feeling of your face and hands than to the rest of your body combined. This makes sense though—you need to make incredibly nuanced facial expressions and your hands need to be unbelievably dexterous, while the rest of your body—your shoulder, your knee, your back—can move and feel things much more crudely. This is why people can play the piano with their fingers but not with their toes.</p> \n<p>Second, it’s interesting how the two cortices are basically dedicated to the same body parts, in the same proportions. I never really thought about the fact that the same parts of your body you need to have a lot of movement control over tend to also be the most sensitive to touch.</p> \n<p>Finally, I came across this shit and I’ve been living with it ever since—so now you have to too. A 3-dimensional homunculus man.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-17-6120\" id=\"note2-17-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">17</a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Side-black.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6136\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Side-black.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"350\" height=\"407\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Side-black.jpg 1280w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Side-black-258x300.jpg 258w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Side-black-768x893.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Side-black-516x600.jpg 516w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 350px) 100vw, 350px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Moving on—</p> \n<p>The <strong><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Temporal_lobe_animation2.gif\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">temporal lobe</a> </strong>is where a lot of your memory lives, and being right next to your ears, it’s also the home of your <strong>auditory cortex</strong><strong>. </strong></p> \n<p>Last, at the back of your head is the <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Occipital_lobe.gif\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><strong>occipital lobe</strong></a><strong>, </strong>which houses your <strong>visual cortex</strong> and is almost entirely dedicated to vision.</p> \n<p>Now for a long time, I thought these major lobes were <em>chunks</em> of the brain—like, segments of the whole 3D structure. But actually, the cortex is just the outer <em>two</em><em> millimeters </em>of the brain—the thickness of a nickel—and the meat of the space underneath is mostly just wiring.</p> \n<div class=\"wbwAside\"> \n <p><span style=\"font-size: 14pt;\"><strong>The Why Brains Are So Wrinkly Blue Box</strong></span></p> \n <p>As we’ve discussed, the evolution of our brain happened by building outwards, adding newer, fancier features on top of the existing model. But building outwards has its limits, because the need for humans to emerge into the world through someone’s vagina puts a cap on how big our heads could be.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote-9-6120\" id=\"note-9-6120\" rel=\"footnote\">9</a></p> \n <p>So evolution got innovative. Because the cortex is so thin, it scales by increasing its surface area. That means that by creating lots of folds (including both sides <a href=\"https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/54/Frontal_lobe_animation.gif\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">folding down into the gap</a> between the two hemispheres), you can more than triple the area of the brain’s surface without increasing the volume too much. When the brain first develops in the womb, the cortex is smooth—the folds form mostly in the last two months of pregnancy:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-18-6120\" id=\"note2-18-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">18</a></p> \n <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/FIGURE-2-Prenatal-development-of-the-human-brain-showing-a-series-of-embryonic-and-fetal.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\" wp-image-6137 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/FIGURE-2-Prenatal-development-of-the-human-brain-showing-a-series-of-embryonic-and-fetal.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"390\" height=\"438\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/FIGURE-2-Prenatal-development-of-the-human-brain-showing-a-series-of-embryonic-and-fetal.png 475w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/FIGURE-2-Prenatal-development-of-the-human-brain-showing-a-series-of-embryonic-and-fetal-267x300.png 267w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 390px) 100vw, 390px\" /></a></p> \n <p>Cool explainer of how the folds form <a href=\"https://s-media-cache-ak0.pinimg.com/736x/03/d8/60/03d8603a8a23f473cda93722426cd9e5.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">here</a>.</p> \n</div> \n<p>If you could take the cortex off the brain, you’d end up with a 2mm-thick sheet with an area of 2,000-2,400cm<sup>2</sup>—about the size of a 48cm x 48cm (19in x 19in) square.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote-10-6120\" id=\"note-10-6120\" rel=\"footnote\">10</a> A dinner napkin. <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Guy-holding-napkin.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6404\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Guy-holding-napkin.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"300\" height=\"454\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Guy-holding-napkin.png 406w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Guy-holding-napkin-198x300.png 198w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Guy-holding-napkin-396x600.png 396w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /></a></p> \n<p>This napkin is where most of the action in your brain happens—it’s why you can think, move, feel, see, hear, remember, and speak and understand language. Best napkin ever.</p> \n<p>And remember before when I said that you were a jello ball? Well the <em>you </em>you think of when you think of yourself—it’s really mainly your cortex. Which means you’re actually a napkin.</p> \n<p>The magic of the folds in increasing the napkin’s size is clear when we put another brain on top of our stripped-off cortex:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-on-napkin.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6302\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-on-napkin.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"543\" height=\"461\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-on-napkin.png 796w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-on-napkin-300x254.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-on-napkin-768x651.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-on-napkin-600x509.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 543px) 100vw, 543px\" /></a></p> \n<p>So while it’s not perfect, modern science has a decent understanding of the big picture when it comes to the brain. We also have a decent understanding of the little picture. Let’s check it out:</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 20pt;\"><strong>The brain, zoomed in</strong></span></p> \n<p>Even though we figured out that the brain was the seat of our intelligence a long time ago, it wasn’t until pretty recently that science understood what the brain was made of. Scientists knew that the body was made of cells, but in the late 19th century, Italian physician Camillo Golgi figured out how to use a <a href=\"http://journal.frontiersin.org/article/10.3389/fnana.2016.00038/full\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">staining method</a> to see what brain cells actually looked like. The result was surprising:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/220px-GolgiStainedPyramidalCell.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\" wp-image-6138 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/220px-GolgiStainedPyramidalCell.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"338\" height=\"224\" /></a></p> \n<p>That wasn’t what a cell was supposed to look like. Without quite realizing it yet,<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote-11-6120\" id=\"note-11-6120\" rel=\"footnote\">11</a> Golgi had discovered the neuron.</p> \n<p>Scientists realized that the neuron was the core unit in the vast communication network that makes up the brains and nervous systems of nearly all animals.</p> \n<p>But it wasn’t until the 1950s that scientists worked out <em>how </em>neurons communicate with each other.</p> \n<p>An axon, the long strand of a neuron that carries information, is normally microscopic in diameter—too small for scientists to test on until recently. But in the 1930s, English zoologist J. Z. Young discovered that the squid, randomly, could change everything for our understanding, because squids have an unusually huge axon in their bodies that could be experimented on. A couple decades later, using the squid’s giant axon, scientists Alan Hodgkin and Andrew Huxley definitively figured out how neurons send information: the action potential. Here’s how it works.</p> \n<p>So there are a lot of different kinds of neurons—<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-19-6120\" id=\"note2-19-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">19</a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/neuron_types.gif\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\" wp-image-6139 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/neuron_types.gif\" alt=\"\" width=\"608\" height=\"367\" /></a></p> \n<p>—but for simplicity, we’ll discuss the cliché textbook neuron—a pyramidal cell, like one you might find in your motor cortex. To make a neuron diagram, we can start with a guy:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuron-guy-1.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\" wp-image-6337 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuron-guy-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"91\" height=\"202\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuron-guy-1.png 136w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuron-guy-1-135x300.png 135w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 91px) 100vw, 91px\" /></a></p> \n<p>And then if we just give him a few extra legs, some hair, take his arms off, and stretch him out—we have a neuron.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuron-guy-2.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6338\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuron-guy-2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"567\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuron-guy-2.png 817w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuron-guy-2-300x283.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuron-guy-2-768x726.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuron-guy-2-600x567.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a></p> \n<p>And let’s add in a few more neurons.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuron-guy-3.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\" wp-image-6339 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuron-guy-3.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"800\" height=\"676\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuron-guy-3.png 1421w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuron-guy-3-300x253.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuron-guy-3-768x649.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuron-guy-3-600x507.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Rather than launch into the full, detailed explanation for how action potentials work—which involves a lot of unnecessary and uninteresting technical information you already dealt with in 9th-grade biology—I’ll link to this great Khan Academy <a href=\"https://www.khanacademy.org/science/biology/human-biology/neuron-nervous-system/a/the-synapse\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">explainer article</a> for those who want the full story. We’ll go through the very basic ideas that are relevant for our purposes.</p> \n<p>So our guy’s body stem—the neuron’s <strong>axon</strong>—has a negative “resting potential,” which means that when it’s at rest, its electrical charge is slightly negative. At all times, a bunch of people’s feet keep touching<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote-12-6120\" id=\"note-12-6120\" rel=\"footnote\">12</a> our guy’s hair—the neuron’s <strong>dendrites</strong>—whether he likes it or not. Their feet drop chemicals called <strong>neurotransmitters</strong><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote-13-6120\" id=\"note-13-6120\" rel=\"footnote\">13</a> onto his hair—which pass through his head (the cell body, or<strong> soma</strong>) and, depending on the chemical, raise or lower the charge in his body a little bit. It’s a little unpleasant for our neuron guy, but not a huge deal—and nothing else happens.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuron-guy-4.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\" wp-image-6340 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuron-guy-4.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"800\" height=\"672\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuron-guy-4.png 1430w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuron-guy-4-300x252.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuron-guy-4-768x644.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuron-guy-4-600x503.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" /></a></p> \n<p>But if enough chemicals touch his hair to raise his charge over a certain point—the neuron’s “threshold potential”—then it triggers an <strong>action potential</strong>, and our guy is electrocuted.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuron-guy-5.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\" wp-image-6341 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuron-guy-5.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"800\" height=\"672\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuron-guy-5.png 1429w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuron-guy-5-300x252.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuron-guy-5-768x645.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuron-guy-5-600x504.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" /></a></p> \n<p>This is a binary situation—either <em>nothing </em>happens to our guy, or he’s fully electrocuted. He can’t be kind of electrocuted, or extra electrocuted—he’s either not electrocuted at all, or he’s fully electrocuted to the exact same degree every time.</p> \n<p>When this happens, a pulse of electricity (in the form of a brief reversal of his body’s normal charge from negative to positive and then rapidly back down to his normal negative) zips down his body (the axon) and into his feet—the neuron’s <strong>axon terminals</strong>—which themselves touch a bunch of other people’s hair (the points of contact are called <strong>synapses</strong>). When the action potential reaches his feet, it causes them to release chemicals onto the people’s hair they’re touching, which may or may not cause those people to be electrocuted, just like he was.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuron-guy-6.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6342\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuron-guy-6.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"759\" height=\"641\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuron-guy-6.png 1421w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuron-guy-6-300x253.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuron-guy-6-768x649.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuron-guy-6-600x507.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 759px) 100vw, 759px\" /></a></p> \n<p>This is usually how info moves through the nervous system—chemical information sent in the tiny gap between neurons triggers electrical information to pass <em>through </em>the neuron—but sometimes, in situations when the body needs to move a signal extra quickly, neuron-to-neuron connections can themselves be electric.</p> \n<p>Action potentials move at between 1 and 100 meters/second. Part of the reason for this large range is that another type of cell in the nervous system—a Schwann cell—acts like a super nurturing grandmother and constantly wraps some types of axons in layers of fat blankets called <strong>myelin sheath.</strong> Like this (takes a second to start):<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-20-6120\" id=\"note2-20-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">20</a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Myelinani.gif\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"size-full wp-image-6144 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Myelinani.gif\" alt=\"\" width=\"300\" height=\"200\" /></a></p> \n<p>On top of its protection and insulation benefits, the myelin sheath is a major factor in the pace of communication—action potentials travel <em>much </em>faster through axons when they’re covered in myelin sheath:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote-14-6120\" id=\"note-14-6120\" rel=\"footnote\">14</a><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-21-6120\" id=\"note2-21-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">21</a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/ezgif.com-optimize-2.gif\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"wp-image-6255 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/ezgif.com-optimize-2.gif\" alt=\"\" width=\"500\" height=\"500\" /></a></p> \n<p>One nice example of the speed difference created by myelin: You know how when you stub your toe, your body gives you that one second of reflection time to think about what you just did and what you’re about to feel, before the pain actually kicks in? What’s happening is you feel both the sensation of your toe hitting against something and the sharp part of the pain right away, because sharp pain information is sent to the brain via types of axons that are myelinated. It takes a second or two for the dull pain to kick in because dull pain is sent via <em>unmyelinated</em> “C fibers”—at only around one meter/second.</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 16pt;\"><strong>Neural Networks</strong></span></p> \n<p>Neurons are similar to computer transistors in one way—they also transmit information in the binary language of 1’s (action potential firing) and 0’s (no action potential firing). But unlike computer transistors, the brain’s neurons are constantly changing.</p> \n<p>You know how sometimes you learn a new skill and you get pretty good at it, and then the next day you try again and you suck again? That’s because what made you get good at the skill the day before was adjustments to the amount or concentration of the <em>chemicals</em> in the signaling between neurons. Repetition caused chemicals to adjust, which helped you improve, but the next day the chemicals were back to normal so the improvement went away.</p> \n<p>But then if you <em>keep </em>practicing, you eventually get good at something in a lasting way. What’s happened is you’ve told the brain, “this isn’t just something I need in a one-off way,” and the brain’s neural network has responded by making <em>structural changes</em> to itself that last. Neurons have shifted shape and location and strengthened or weakened various connections in a way that has built a hard-wired set of pathways that know how to do that skill.</p> \n<p>Neurons’ ability to alter themselves chemically, structurally, and even functionally, allow your brain’s neural network to optimize itself to the external world—a phenomenon called <em>neuroplasticity. </em>Babies’ brains are the most neuroplastic of all. When a baby is born, its brain has no idea if it needs to accommodate the life of a medieval warrior who will need to become incredibly adept at sword-fighting, a 17th-century musician who will need to develop fine-tuned muscle memory for playing the harpsichord, or a modern-day intellectual who will need to store and organize a tremendous amount of information and master a complex social fabric—but the baby’s brain is ready to shape itself to handle whatever life has in store for it.</p> \n<p>Babies are the neuroplasticity superstars, but neuroplasticity remains throughout our whole lives, which is why humans can grow and change and learn new things. And it’s why we can form new habits and break old ones—your habits are reflective of the existing circuitry in your brain. If you want to change your habits, you need to exert a lot of willpower to override your brain’s neural pathways, but if you can keep it going long enough, your brain will eventually get the hint and alter those pathways, and the new behavior will stop requiring willpower. Your brain will have physically built the changes into a new habit.</p> \n<p>Altogether, there are around 100 billion neurons in the brain that make up this unthinkably vast network—similar to the number of stars in the Milky Way and over 10 times the number of people in the world. Around 15 – 20 billion of those neurons are in the cortex, and the rest are in the animal parts of your brain (surprisingly, the random cerebellum has more than three times as many neurons as the cortex).</p> \n<p>Let’s zoom back out and look at another cross section of the brain—this time cut not from front to back to show a single hemisphere, but from side to side:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-22-6120\" id=\"note2-22-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">22</a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/brain-white-matter-grey-matter-cross-section.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"size-full wp-image-6262 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/brain-white-matter-grey-matter-cross-section.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"510\" height=\"384\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/brain-white-matter-grey-matter-cross-section.jpg 510w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/brain-white-matter-grey-matter-cross-section-300x226.jpg 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 510px) 100vw, 510px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Brain material can be divided into what’s called <strong>gray matter </strong>and <strong>white matter.</strong> Gray matter actually looks darker in color and is made up of the cell bodies (somas) of the brain’s neurons and their thicket of dendrites and axons—along with a lot of other stuff. White matter is made up primarily of wiring—axons carrying information from somas to other somas or to destinations in the body. White matter is white because those axons are usually wrapped in myelin sheath, which is fatty white tissue.</p> \n<p>There are two main regions of gray matter in the brain—the internal cluster of limbic system and brain stem parts we discussed above, and the nickel-thick layer of cortex around the outside. The big chunk of white matter in between is made up mostly of the axons of cortical neurons. The cortex is like a great command center, and it beams many of its orders out through the mass of axons making up the white matter beneath it.</p> \n<p>The coolest illustration of this concept that I’ve come across<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote-15-6120\" id=\"note-15-6120\" rel=\"footnote\">15</a> is a <a href=\"http://www.gregadunn.com/self-reflected/self-reflected-gallery/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">beautiful set of artistic representations</a> done by Dr. Greg A. Dunn and Dr. Brian Edwards. Check out the distinct difference between the structure of the outer layer of gray matter cortex and the white matter underneath it (click to view in high res):</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Self-Reflected-in-violets-1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6423\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Self-Reflected-in-violets.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"901\" height=\"664\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Self-Reflected-in-violets.jpg 1200w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Self-Reflected-in-violets-300x221.jpg 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Self-Reflected-in-violets-768x566.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Self-Reflected-in-violets-600x442.jpg 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 901px) 100vw, 901px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Motor-and-Parietal-cortex-2-1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6424\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Motor-and-Parietal-cortex-2.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"900\" height=\"591\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Motor-and-Parietal-cortex-2.jpg 1200w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Motor-and-Parietal-cortex-2-300x197.jpg 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Motor-and-Parietal-cortex-2-768x504.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Motor-and-Parietal-cortex-2-600x394.jpg 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Those cortical axons might be taking information to another part of the cortex, to the lower part of the brain, or through the spinal cord—the nervous system’s superhighway—and into the rest of the body.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote-16-6120\" id=\"note-16-6120\" rel=\"footnote\">16</a></p> \n<p>Let’s look at the whole nervous system:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-23-6120\" id=\"note2-23-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">23</a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/f7fa1bdddc896c2c635a1929c6578b745a6030c2.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6141\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/f7fa1bdddc896c2c635a1929c6578b745a6030c2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"400\" height=\"508\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/f7fa1bdddc896c2c635a1929c6578b745a6030c2.png 1448w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/f7fa1bdddc896c2c635a1929c6578b745a6030c2-236x300.png 236w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/f7fa1bdddc896c2c635a1929c6578b745a6030c2-768x975.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/f7fa1bdddc896c2c635a1929c6578b745a6030c2-473x600.png 473w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 400px) 100vw, 400px\" /></a></p> \n<p>The nervous system is divided into two parts: the <strong>central nervous system</strong>—your brain and spinal cord—and the <strong>peripheral nervous system</strong>—made up of the neurons that radiate outwards from the spinal cord into the rest of the body.</p> \n<p>Most types of neurons are <strong>interneurons</strong>—neurons that communicate with other neurons. When you think, it’s a bunch of interneurons talking to each other. Interneurons are mostly contained to the brain.</p> \n<p>The two other kinds of neurons are <strong>sensory neurons </strong>and <strong>motor neurons</strong>—those are the neurons that head down into your spinal cord and make up the peripheral nervous system. These neurons can be up to a <em>meter</em> long.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote-17-6120\" id=\"note-17-6120\" rel=\"footnote\">17</a> Here’s a typical structure of each type:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-24-6120\" id=\"note2-24-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">24</a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/afe8fa893b046e0dbd70425c079e2af3.511x537x1.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"size-full wp-image-6149 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/afe8fa893b046e0dbd70425c079e2af3.511x537x1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"511\" height=\"537\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/afe8fa893b046e0dbd70425c079e2af3.511x537x1.png 511w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/afe8fa893b046e0dbd70425c079e2af3.511x537x1-285x300.png 285w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 511px) 100vw, 511px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Remember our two strips?<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-25-6120\" id=\"note2-25-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">25</a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/motor-cortex-of-the-brain-1505972E27C6C96B962.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"size-full wp-image-6142 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/motor-cortex-of-the-brain-1505972E27C6C96B962.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"317\" height=\"244\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/motor-cortex-of-the-brain-1505972E27C6C96B962.png 317w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/motor-cortex-of-the-brain-1505972E27C6C96B962-300x231.png 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 317px) 100vw, 317px\" /></a></p> \n<p>These strips are where your peripheral nervous system originates. The axons of sensory neurons head down from the somatosensory cortex, through the brain’s white matter, and into the spinal cord (which is just a massive bundle of axons). From the spinal cord, they head out to all parts of your body. Each part of your skin is lined with nerves that originate in the somatosensory cortex. A <strong>nerve</strong>, by the way, is a few bundles of axons wrapped together in a little cord. Here’s a nerve up close:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-26-6120\" id=\"note2-26-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">26</a></p> \n<p><img class=\"size-full wp-image-6143 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/perner004os-1.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"400\" height=\"500\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/perner004os-1.jpg 400w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/perner004os-1-240x300.jpg 240w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 400px) 100vw, 400px\" /></p> \n<p>The nerve is the whole thing circled in purple, and those four big circles inside are bundles of many axons (here’s a helpful <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/main-qimg-3f670c6ad3bb29728c912a1abbec2d26.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">cartoony drawing</a>).</p> \n<p>So if a fly lands on your arm, here’s what happens:</p> \n<p>The fly touches your skin and stimulates a bunch of sensory nerves. The axon terminals in the nerves have a little fit and start action potential-ing, sending the signal up to the brain to tell on the fly. The signals head into the spinal cord and up to the somas in the somatosensory cortex.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote-18-6120\" id=\"note-18-6120\" rel=\"footnote\">18</a> The somatosensory cortex then taps the motor cortex on the shoulder and tells it that there’s a fly on your arm and that it needs to deal with it (lazy). The particular somas in your motor cortex that connect to the muscles in your arm then start action potential-ing, sending the signals back into the spinal cord and then out to the muscles of the arm. The axon terminals at the end of those neurons stimulate your arm muscles, which constrict to shake your arm to get the fly off (by now the fly has already <a href=\"http://www.womansday.com/food-recipes/food-drinks/news/a50683/the-disgusting-reason-you-should-never-eat-something-a-fly-landed-on/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">thrown up</a> on your arm), and the fly (whose nervous system now goes through its own whole thing) flies off.</p> \n<p>Then your amygdala looks over and realizes there was a bug on you, and it tells your motor cortex to jump embarrassingly, and if it’s a spider instead of a fly, it also tells your vocal cords to yell out involuntarily and ruin your reputation.</p> \n<p>So it seems so far like we do kind of actually understand the brain, right? But then why did that professor ask that question—<em>If everything you need to know about the brain is a mile, how far have we walked in this mile?</em>—and say the answer was <em>three inches?</em></p> \n<p>Well here’s the thing.</p> \n<p>You know how we totally get how an individual computer sends an email and we totally understand the broad concepts of the internet, like how many people are on it and what the biggest sites are and what the major trends are—but all the stuff in the middle—the inner workings of the internet—are pretty confusing?</p> \n<p>And you know how economists can tell you all about how an individual consumer functions and they can also tell you about the major concepts of macroeconomics and the overarching forces at play—but no one can really tell you all the ins and outs of how the economy works or predict what will happen with the economy next month or next year?</p> \n<p>The brain is kind of like those things. We get the little picture—we know all about how a neuron fires. And we get the big picture—we know how many neurons are in the brain and what the major lobes and structures control and how much energy the whole system uses. But the stuff in between—all that <em>middle </em>stuff about how each part of the brain actually does its thing?</p> \n<p>Yeah we don’t get that.</p> \n<p>What really makes it clear how confounded we are is hearing a neuroscientist talk about the parts of the brain we understand <em>best</em>.</p> \n<p>Like the visual cortex. We understand the visual cortex pretty well because it’s easy to <em>map</em>.</p> \n<p>Research scientist Paul Merolla described it to me:</p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><em>The visual cortex has very nice anatomical function and structure. When you look at it, you literally see a map of the world. So when something in your visual field is in a certain region of space, you’ll see a little patch in the cortex that represents that region of space, and it’ll light up. And as that thing moves over, there’s a topographic mapping where the neighboring cells will represent that. It’s almost like having Cartesian coordinates of the real world that will map to polar coordinates in the visual cortex. And you can literally trace from your retina, through your thalamus, to your visual cortex, and you’ll see an actual mapping from this point in space to this point in the visual cortex.</em></p> \n<p class=\"p1\">So far so good. But then he went on:</p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><em>So that mapping is really useful if you want to interact with certain parts of the visual cortex, but there’s many regions of vision, and as you get deeper into the visual cortex, it becomes a little bit more nebulous, and this topographic representation starts to break down. … There’s all these levels of things going on in the brain, and visual perception is a great example of that. We look at the world, and there’s just this physical 3D world out there—like you look at a cup, and you just see a cup—but what your eyes are seeing is really just a bunch of pixels. And when you look in the visual cortex, you see that there are roughly 20-40 different maps. V1 is the first area, where it’s tracking little edges and colors and things like that. And there’s other areas looking at more complicated objects, and there’s all these different visual representations on the surface of your brain, that you can see. And somehow all of that information is being bound together in this information stream that’s being coded in a way that makes you believe you’re just seeing a simple object.</em></p> \n<p class=\"p1\">And the motor cortex, another one of the best-understood areas of the brain, might be even more difficult to understand on a granular level than the visual cortex. Because even though we know which <em>general </em>areas of the motor cortex map to which areas of the body, the individual neurons in these motor cortex areas <em>aren’t</em> topographically set up, and the specific way they work together to create movement in the body is anything but clear. Here’s Paul again:</p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><em>The neural chatter in everyone’s arm movement part of the brain is a little bit different—it’s not like the neurons speak English and say “move”—it’s a pattern of electrical activity, and in everyone it’s a little bit different. … And you want to be able to seamlessly understand that it means “Move the arm this way” or “move the arm toward the target” or “move the arm to the left, move it up, grasp, grasp with a certain kind of force, reach with a certain speed,” and so on. We don’t think about these things when we move—it just happens seamlessly. So each brain has a unique code with which it talks to the muscles in the arm and hand.</em></p> \n<p class=\"p1\">The <em>neuroplasticity </em>that makes our brains so useful to us also makes them incredibly difficult to understand—because the way each of our brains works is based on how that brain has shaped itself, based on its particular environment and life experience.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\">And again, those are the areas of the brain we understand the <em>best. </em>“When it comes to more sophisticated computation, like language, memory, mathematics,” one expert told me, “we really don’t understand how the brain works.” He lamented that, for example, the concept of one’s mother is coded in a different way, and in different parts of the brain, for every person. And in the<em> </em>frontal lobe—you know, that part of the brain where <em>you </em>really live—”there’s no topography at all.”<em> </em></p> \n<p class=\"p1\">But somehow, <em>none of this </em>is why building effective brain-computer interfaces is so hard, or so daunting. What makes BMIs so hard is that the engineering challenges are <em>monumental</em>. It’s <em>physically </em>working with the brain that makes BMIs among the hardest engineering endeavors in the world.</p> \n<p><a name=\"part3\"></a></p> \n<p class=\"p1\">So with our brain background tree trunk built, we’re ready to head up to our first branch.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><span style=\"font-size: 28pt;\"><strong>Part 3: Brain-Machine Interfaces</strong></span></p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-tree-Parts-3.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6437\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-tree-Parts-3.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"200\" height=\"207\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-tree-Parts-3.png 747w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-tree-Parts-3-290x300.png 290w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-tree-Parts-3-580x600.png 580w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 200px) 100vw, 200px\" /></a></p> \n<p class=\"p1\">Let’s zip back in time for a second to 50,000 BC and kidnap someone and bring him back here to 2017.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"wp-image-6263 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"243\" height=\"361\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok.png 345w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-202x300.png 202w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 243px) 100vw, 243px\" /></a></p> \n<p class=\"p1\">This is Bok. Bok, we’re really thankful that you and your people invented language.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-2.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\" wp-image-6289 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"290\" height=\"472\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-2.png 400w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-2-185x300.png 185w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-2-369x600.png 369w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 290px) 100vw, 290px\" /></a></p> \n<p class=\"p1\">As a way to thank you, we want to show you all the amazing things we were able to build because of your invention.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-3-1.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6462\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-3-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"301\" height=\"367\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-3-1.png 500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-3-1-245x300.png 245w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-3-1-491x600.png 491w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 301px) 100vw, 301px\" /></a></p> \n<p class=\"p1\">Alright, first let’s take Bok on a plane, and into a submarine, and to the top of the Burj Khalifa. Now we’ll show him a telescope and a TV and an iPhone. And now we’ll let him play around on the internet for a while.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\">Okay that was fun. How’d it go, Bok?</p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-4.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6291\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-4.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"290\" height=\"418\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-4.png 400w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-4-208x300.png 208w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 290px) 100vw, 290px\" /></a></p> \n<p class=\"p1\">Yeah we figured that you’d be pretty surprised. To wrap up, let’s show him how we communicate with each other.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-5-1.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6405\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-5-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"528\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-5-1.png 1068w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-5-1-300x264.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-5-1-768x675.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-5-1-600x528.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-6-1.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6406\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-6-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"466\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-6-1.png 1068w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-6-1-300x233.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-6-1-768x596.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-6-1-600x466.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-7-2.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6411\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-7-2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"476\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-7-2.png 1068w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-7-2-300x238.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-7-2-768x609.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-7-2-600x476.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-8-2.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6461\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-8-2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"528\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-8-2.png 1068w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-8-2-300x264.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-8-2-768x675.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-8-2-600x528.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-9-1.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6409\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-9-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"499\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-9-1.png 1068w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-9-1-300x249.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-9-1-768x639.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-9-1-600x499.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-10-1.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6410\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-10-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"528\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-10-1.png 1068w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-10-1-300x264.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-10-1-768x675.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-10-1-600x528.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Bok would be shocked to learn that despite all the magical powers humans have gained as a result of having learned to speak to each other, when it comes to actually speaking to each other, we’re no more magical than the people of his day. When two people are together and talking, they’re using 50,000-year-old technology.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\">Bok might also be surprised that in a world run by fancy machines, the people who made all the machines are walking around with the same biological bodies that Bok and his friends walk around with. How can that be?</p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-11.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6298\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-11.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"450\" height=\"462\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-11.png 797w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-11-292x300.png 292w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-11-768x788.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Bok-11-585x600.png 585w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 450px) 100vw, 450px\" /></a></p> \n<p>This is why brain-machine interfaces—a subset of the broader field of neural engineering, which itself is a subset of biotechnology—are such a tantalizing new industry. We’ve conquered the world many times over with our technology, but when it comes to our brains—our most central tool—the tech world has for the most part been too daunted to dive in.</p> \n<p>That’s why we still communicate using technology Bok invented, it’s why I’m typing this sentence at about a 20th of the speed that I’m thinking it, and it’s why brain-related ailments still leave so many lives badly impaired or lost altogether.</p> \n<p>But 50,000 years after the brain’s great “aha!” moment, that may finally be about to change. The brain’s next great frontier may be itself.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">___________</p> \n<p>There are many kinds of potential brain-machine interface (sometimes called a brain-computer interface) that will serve many different functions. But everyone working on BMIs is grappling with either one or both of these two questions:</p> \n<p><strong>1) How do I get the right information out of the brain?</strong></p> \n<p><strong>2) How do I send the right information into the brain?</strong></p> \n<p>The first is about capturing the brain’s <em>output</em>—it’s about <strong>recording</strong> what neurons are saying.</p> \n<p>The second is about <em>inputting </em>information into the brain’s natural flow or altering that natural flow in some other way—it’s about <strong>stimulating </strong>neurons.</p> \n<p>These two things are happening naturally in your brain all the time. Right now, your eyes are making a specific set of horizontal movements that allow you to read this sentence. That’s the brain’s neurons outputting information to a machine (your eyes) and the machine receiving the command and responding. And as your eyes move in just the right way, the photons from the screen are entering your retinas and stimulating neurons in the occipital lobe of your cortex in a way that allows the image of the words to enter your mind’s eye. That image then stimulates neurons in another part of your brain that allows you to process the information embedded in the image and absorb the sentence’s meaning.</p> \n<p>Inputting and outputting information is what the brain’s neurons <em>do</em>. All the BMI industry wants to do is get in on the action.</p> \n<p>At first, this seems like maybe not <em>that </em>difficult a task? The brain is just a jello ball, right? And the cortex—the part of the brain in which we want to do most of our recording and stimulating—is just a napkin, located conveniently right on the outside of the brain where it can be easily accessed. Inside the cortex are around 20 billion firing neurons—20 billion oozy little transistors that if we can just learn to work with, will give us an entirely new level of control over our life, our health, and the world. Can’t we figure that out? Neurons are small, but we know how to split an atom. A neuron’s diameter is about 100,000 times as large as an atom’s—if an atom were a marble, a neuron would be a kilometer across—so we should probably be able to handle the smallness. Right?</p> \n<p>So what’s the issue here?</p> \n<p>Well on one hand, there’s something to that line of thinking, in that because of those facts, this <em>is </em>an industry where immense progress can happen. We <em>can </em>do this.</p> \n<p>But only when you understand what actually goes on in the brain do you realize why this is probably the hardest human endeavor in the world.</p> \n<p>So before we talk about BMIs themselves, we need to take a closer look at what the people trying to make BMIs are dealing with here. I find that the best way to illustrate things is to scale the brain up by exactly 1,000X and look at what’s going on.</p> \n<p>Remember our cortex-is-a-napkin demonstration earlier?</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-on-napkin.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6302\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-on-napkin.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"500\" height=\"424\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-on-napkin.png 796w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-on-napkin-300x254.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-on-napkin-768x651.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-on-napkin-600x509.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 500px) 100vw, 500px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Well if we scale that up by 1,000X, the cortex napkin—which was about 48cm / 19in on each side—now has a side the length of six Manhattan street blocks (or two avenue blocks). It would take you about 25 minutes to walk around the perimeter. And the brain as a whole would now fit snugly inside a two block by two block square—just about the size of Madison Square Garden (this works in length and width, but the brain would be about double the height of MSG).</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/outline-on-manhattan.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6272\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/outline-on-manhattan.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"800\" height=\"587\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/outline-on-manhattan.jpg 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/outline-on-manhattan-300x220.jpg 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/outline-on-manhattan-768x563.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/outline-on-manhattan-600x440.jpg 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" /></a></p> \n<p>So let’s lay it out in the actual city. I’m sure the few hundred thousand people who live there will understand.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/brain-on-manhattan.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6267\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/brain-on-manhattan.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"719\" height=\"570\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/brain-on-manhattan.jpg 1339w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/brain-on-manhattan-300x238.jpg 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/brain-on-manhattan-768x609.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/brain-on-manhattan-600x476.jpg 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 719px) 100vw, 719px\" /></a></p> \n<p>I chose 1,000X as our multiplier for a couple reasons. One is that we can all instantly convert the sizes in our heads. Every millimeter of the actual brain is now a meter. And in the much smaller world of neurons, every micron is now an easy-to-conceptualize millimeter. Secondly, it conveniently brings the cortex up to human size—its 2mm thickness is now two meters—the height of a tall (6’6”) man.</p> \n<p>So we could walk up to 29th street, to the edge of our giant cortex napkin, and easily look at what was going on inside those two meters of thickness. For our demonstration, let’s pull out a cubic meter of our giant cortex to examine, which will show us what goes on in a typical cubic millimeter of real cortex.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-cube-1.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6301\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-cube-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"400\" height=\"413\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-cube-1.png 1000w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-cube-1-290x300.png 290w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-cube-1-768x793.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-cube-1-581x600.png 581w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 400px) 100vw, 400px\" /></a></p> \n<p>What we’d see in that cubic meter would be a <em>mess. </em>Let’s empty it out and put it back together.</p> \n<p>First, let’s put the somas<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote-19-6120\" id=\"note-19-6120\" rel=\"footnote\">19</a> in—the little bodies of all the neurons that live in that cube.</p> \n<p>Somas range in size, but the neuroscientists I spoke with said that the somas of neurons in the cortex are often around 10 or 15µm in diameter (µm = micrometer, or micron: 1/1,000th of a millimeter). That means that if you laid out 7 or 10 of them in a line, that line would be about the diameter of a human hair (which is about 100µm). On our scale, that makes a soma 1 – 1.5cm in diameter. A marble.</p> \n<p>The volume of the whole cortex is in the ballpark of 500,000 cubic millimeters, and in that space are about 20 billion somas. That means an average cubic millimeter of cortex contains about 40,000 neurons. So there are 40,000 marbles in our cubic meter box. If we divide our box into about 40,000 cubic spaces, each with a side of 3cm (or about a cubic inch), it means each of our soma marbles is at the center of its own little 3cm cube, with other somas about 3cm away from it in all directions.</p> \n<p>With me so far? Can you visualize our meter cube with those 40,000 floating marbles in it?</p> \n<p>Here’s a microscope image of the somas in an actual cortex, using techniques that block out the other stuff around them:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-27-6120\" id=\"note2-27-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">27</a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/B9781416050094500182_f10-06-9781416050094.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\" wp-image-6146 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/B9781416050094500182_f10-06-9781416050094.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"369\" height=\"512\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/B9781416050094500182_f10-06-9781416050094.jpg 312w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/B9781416050094500182_f10-06-9781416050094-216x300.jpg 216w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 369px) 100vw, 369px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Okay not too crazy so far. But the soma is only a tiny piece of each neuron. Radiating out from each of our marble-sized somas are twisty, branchy dendrites that in our scaled-up brain can stretch out for three or four meters in many different directions, and from the other end an axon that can be over 100 meters long (when heading out laterally to another part of the cortex) or as long as a <em>kilometer</em> (when heading down into the spinal cord and body). Each of them only about a millimeter thick, these cords turn the cortex into a dense tangle of electrical spaghetti.</p> \n<p>And there’s a lot going on in that mash of spaghetti. Each neuron has synaptic connections to as many as 1,000—sometimes as high as 10,000—other neurons. With around 20 billion neurons in the cortex, that means there are over 20 <em>trillion </em>individual neural connections in the cortex (and as high as a quadrillion connections in the entire brain). In our cubic meter alone, there will be over 20 million synapses.</p> \n<p>To further complicate things, not only are there many spaghetti strands coming out of <em>each</em> of the 40,000 marbles in our cube, but there are thousands of other spaghetti strings passing through our cube from <em>other </em>parts of the cortex. That means that if we were trying to record signals or stimulate neurons in this particular cubic area, we’d have a lot of difficulty, because in the mess of spaghetti, it would be very hard to figure out which spaghetti strings belonged to <em>our </em>soma marbles (and god forbid there are <a href=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Purkinje_cell_by_Cajal.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><em>Purkinje</em> cells</a> in the mix).</p> \n<p>And of course, there’s the whole neuroplasticity thing. The voltages of each neuron would be constantly changing, as many as hundreds of times per second. And the tens of millions of synapse connections in our cube would be regularly changing sizes, disappearing, and reappearing.</p> \n<p>If only that were the end of it.</p> \n<p>It turns out there are other cells in the brain called <strong>glial cells</strong>—cells that come in many different varieties and perform many different functions, like mopping up chemicals released into synapses, wrapping axons in myelin, and serving as the brain’s immune system. Here are some common types of glial cell:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-28-6120\" id=\"note2-28-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">28</a></p> \n<p><strong><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/all_glia.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"size-full wp-image-6150 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/all_glia.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"759\" height=\"185\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/all_glia.jpg 759w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/all_glia-300x73.jpg 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/all_glia-600x146.jpg 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 759px) 100vw, 759px\" /></a></strong></p> \n<p>And how many glial cells are in the cortex? About the <em>same number as there are neurons.</em><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote-20-6120\" id=\"note-20-6120\" rel=\"footnote\">20</a> So add about 40,000 of these wacky things into our cube.</p> \n<p>Finally, there are the blood vessels. In every cubic millimeter of cortex, there’s a total of a <em>meter </em>of tiny blood vessels. On our scale, that means that in our cubic meter, there’s a <em>kilometer</em> of blood vessels. Here’s what the blood vessels in a space about that size look like:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-29-6120\" id=\"note2-29-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">29</a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/nihms-666209-f0001.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"size-full wp-image-6152 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/nihms-666209-f0001.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"472\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/nihms-666209-f0001.jpg 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/nihms-666209-f0001-300x236.jpg 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a></p> \n<div class=\"wbwAside\"> \n <p><span style=\"font-size: 14pt;\"><strong>The Connectome Blue Box</strong></span></p> \n <p>There’s an amazing project going on right now in the neuroscience world called the <a href=\"http://www.humanconnectomeproject.org/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Human Connectome Project</a> (pronounced “connec-tome”) in which scientists are trying to create a complete detailed map of the entire human brain. Nothing close to this scale of brain mapping has ever been done.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote-21-6120\" id=\"note-21-6120\" rel=\"footnote\">21</a></p> \n <p>The project entails <a href=\"http://www.nytimes.com/2010/12/28/science/28brain.html?pagewanted=all&amp;_r=0\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">slicing a human brain</a> into outrageously thin slices—around 30-<em>nano</em>meter-thick slices.
