That’s 1/33,000th of a millimeter (here’s a machine <a href=\"http://www.microscopedia.com/Content/Press/31977.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">slicing up</a> a mouse brain).</p> \n <p>Anyway, in addition to producing some <a href=\"http://www.humanconnectomeproject.org/gallery/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">gorgeous images</a> of the “ribbon” formations axons with similar functions often form inside white matter, like—</p> \n <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/White-Matter-Fibers-HCP-Dataset-side-view-720x594.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6154\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/White-Matter-Fibers-HCP-Dataset-side-view-720x594.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"479\" height=\"396\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/White-Matter-Fibers-HCP-Dataset-side-view-720x594.jpg 720w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/White-Matter-Fibers-HCP-Dataset-side-view-720x594-300x248.jpg 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/White-Matter-Fibers-HCP-Dataset-side-view-720x594-600x495.jpg 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 479px) 100vw, 479px\" /></a></p> \n <p>—the connectome project has helped people visualize just how packed the brain is with all this stuff. Here’s a breakdown of all the different things going on in one tiny snippet of mouse brain (and this doesn’t even include the blood vessels):<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-30-6120\" id=\"note2-30-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">30</a></p> \n <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/gr3.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"size-full wp-image-6153 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/gr3.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"656\" height=\"319\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/gr3.jpg 656w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/gr3-300x146.jpg 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/gr3-600x292.jpg 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 656px) 100vw, 656px\" /></a></p> \n <p>(In the image, E is the complete brain snippet, and F–N show the separate components that make up E.)</p> \n</div> \n<p>So our meter box is a jam-packed, oozy, electrified mound of dense complexity—now let’s recall that in reality, everything in our box actually fits in a cubic <em>millimeter.</em></p> \n<p>And the brain-machine interface engineers need to figure out what the microscopic somas buried in that millimeter are saying, and other times, to stimulate <em>just </em>the right somas to get them to do what the engineers want. <em>Good luck with that.</em></p> \n<p><em>We’d </em>have a super hard time doing that on our 1,000X brain. Our 1,000X brain that also happens to be a nice flat napkin. That’s not how it normally works—usually, the napkin is up on top of our Madison Square Garden brain and full of deep folds (on our scale, between five and 30 meters deep). In fact, less than a <em>third </em>of the cortex napkin is up on the surface of the brain—most is buried inside the folds.</p> \n<p>Also, engineers are not operating on a bunch of brains in a lab. The brain is covered with all those Russian doll layers, including the skull—which at 1,000X would be around seven meters thick. And since most people don’t really want you opening up their skull for very long—and ideally not at all—you have to try to work with those tiny marbles as non-invasively as possible.</p> \n<p>And this is all assuming you’re dealing with the cortex—but a lot of cool BMI ideas deal with the structures down below, which if you’re standing on top of our MSG brain, are buried 50 or 100 meters under the surface.</p> \n<p>The 1,000X game also hammers home the sheer scope of the brain. Think about how much was going on in our cube—and now remember that that’s only<em> one 500,000th of the cortex</em>. If we broke our whole giant cortex into similar meter cubes and lined them up, they’d stretch 500km / 310mi—all the way to Boston and beyond. And if you made the trek—which would take over 100 hours of brisk walking—at any point you could pause and look at the cube you happened to be passing by and it would have all of this complexity inside of it. <em>All </em>of this is currently in your brain.</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 24pt;\"><strong>Part 3A: How Happy Are You That This Isn’t Your Problem</strong></span></p> \n<p>Totes.</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 24pt;\"><strong>Back to Part 3: Brain-Machine Interfaces</strong></span></p> \n<p>So how do scientists and engineers begin to manage this situation?</p> \n<p>Well they do the best they can with the tools they currently have—tools used to record or stimulate neurons (we’ll focus on the recording side for the time being). Let’s take a look at the options:</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 20pt;\"><strong>BMI Tools</strong></span></p> \n<p>With the current work that’s being done, three broad criteria seem to stand out when evaluating a type of recording tool’s pros and cons:</p> \n<p><strong>1) Scale </strong>– how many neurons can be simultaneously recorded</p> \n<p><strong>2) Resolution </strong>– how detailed is the information the tool receives—there are two types of resolution, <strong>spatial</strong> (how closely your recordings come to telling you how individual neurons are firing) and <strong>temporal </strong>(how well you can determine <em>when </em>the activity you record happened)</p> \n<p><strong>3) Invasiveness </strong>– is surgery needed, and if so, how extensively</p> \n<p>The long-term goal is to have all three of your cakes and eat them all. But for now, it’s always a question of “which one (or two) of these criteria are you willing to completely fail?” Going from one tool to another isn’t an overall upgrade or downgrade—it’s a tradeoff.</p> \n<p>Let’s examine the types of tools currently being used:</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 16pt;\"><strong>fMRI</strong></span></p> \n<p><strong>Scale: </strong>high (it shows you information across the whole brain)</p> \n<p><strong>Resolution: </strong>medium-low spatial, very low temporal</p> \n<p><strong>Invasiveness: </strong>non-invasive</p> \n<p>fMRI isn’t typically used for BMIs, but it is a classic <em>recording </em>tool—it gives you information about what’s going on inside the brain.</p> \n<p>fMRI uses MRI—magnetic resonance imaging—technology. MRIs, invented in the 1970s, were an evolution of the x-ray-based CAT scan. Instead of using x-rays, MRIs use magnetic fields (along with radio waves and other signals) to generate images of the body and brain. Like this:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-31-6120\" id=\"note2-31-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">31</a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/f.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6155\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/f.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"500\" height=\"463\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/f.jpg 1024w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/f-300x278.jpg 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/f-768x712.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/f-600x556.jpg 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 500px) 100vw, 500px\" /></a></p> \n<p>And this full set of cross sections, allowing you to see through an entire head.</p> \n<p><iframe src=\"https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File%3AStructural_MRI_animation.ogv?embedplayer=yes\" width=\"256\" height=\"256\" frameborder=\"0\"></iframe></p> \n<p>Pretty amazing technology.</p> \n<p>fMRI (“functional” MRI) uses similar technology to track changes in <em>blood flow</em>. Why? Because when areas of the brain become more active, they use more energy, so they need more oxygen—so blood flow increases to the area to deliver that oxygen. Blood flow indirectly indicates where activity is happening. Here’s what an fMRI scan might show:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-32-6120\" id=\"note2-32-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">32</a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/7728527_f520.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"wp-image-6156 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/7728527_f520.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"323\" height=\"323\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/7728527_f520.jpg 520w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/7728527_f520-150x150.jpg 150w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/7728527_f520-300x300.jpg 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 323px) 100vw, 323px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Of course, there’s always blood throughout the brain—what this image shows is where blood flow has <em>increased</em> (red/orange/yellow) and where it has <em>decreased </em>(blue). And because fMRI can scan through the whole brain, results are 3-dimensional:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/fmriHeadCrossSection.gif\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"size-full wp-image-6157 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/fmriHeadCrossSection.gif\" alt=\"\" width=\"256\" height=\"256\" /></a></p> \n<p>fMRI has many medical uses, like informing doctors whether or not certain parts of the brain are functioning properly after a stroke, and fMRI has taught neuroscientists a ton about which regions of the brain are involved with which functions. Scans also have the benefit of providing info about what’s going on in the whole brain at any given time, and it’s safe and totally non-invasive.</p> \n<p>The big drawback is resolution. fMRI scans have a literal resolution, like a computer screen has with pixels, except the pixels are three-dimensional, cubic volume pixels—or “voxels.”</p> \n<p>fMRI voxels have gotten smaller as the technology has improved, bringing the spatial resolution up. Today’s fMRI voxels can be as small as a cubic millimeter. The brain has a volume of about 1,200,000mm<sup>3</sup>, so a high-resolution fMRI scan divides the brain into about one million little cubes. The problem is that on neuron scale, that’s still pretty huge (the same size as our scaled-up cubic meter above)—each voxel contains tens of thousands of neurons. So what the fMRI is showing you, at best, is the average blood flow drawn in by each group of 40,000 or so neurons.</p> \n<p>The even bigger problem is temporal resolution. fMRI tracks blood flow, which is both imprecise and comes with a delay of about a second—an eternity in the world of neurons.</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 16pt;\"><strong>EEG</strong></span></p> \n<p><strong>Scale: </strong>high</p> \n<p><strong>Resolution: </strong>very low spatial, medium-high temporal</p> \n<p><strong>Invasiveness: </strong>non-invasive</p> \n<p>Dating back almost a century, EEG (electroencephalography) puts an array of electrodes on your head. You know, this whole thing:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-33-6120\" id=\"note2-33-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">33</a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/EEG-cap-262x300.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"size-full wp-image-6158 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/EEG-cap-262x300.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"262\" height=\"300\" /></a></p> \n<p>EEG is definitely technology that will look hilariously primitive to a 2050 person, but for now, it’s one of the only tools that can be used with BMIs that’s totally non-invasive. EEGs record electrical activity in different regions of the brain, displaying the findings like this:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-34-6120\" id=\"note2-34-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">34</a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Human_EEG_with_prominent_alpha-rhythm.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6159\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Human_EEG_with_prominent_alpha-rhythm.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"726\" height=\"317\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Human_EEG_with_prominent_alpha-rhythm.png 1284w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Human_EEG_with_prominent_alpha-rhythm-300x131.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Human_EEG_with_prominent_alpha-rhythm-768x335.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Human_EEG_with_prominent_alpha-rhythm-600x262.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 726px) 100vw, 726px\" /></a></p> \n<p>EEG graphs can uncover information about medical issues like epilepsy, track sleep patterns, or be used to determine something like the status of a dose of anesthesia.</p> \n<p>And unlike fMRI, EEG has pretty good temporal resolution, getting electrical signals from the brain right as they happen—though the skull blurs the temporal accuracy considerably (bone is a bad conductor).</p> \n<p>The major drawback is spatial resolution. EEG has none. Each electrode only records a broad average—a vector sum of the charges from millions or billions of neurons (and a blurred one because of the skull).</p> \n<p>Imagine that the brain is a baseball stadium, its neurons are the members of the crowd, and the information we want is, instead of electrical activity, vocal cord activity. In that case, EEG would be like a group of microphones placed outside the stadium, against the stadium’s outer walls. You’d be able to hear when the crowd was cheering and maybe predict the type of thing they were cheering about. You’d be able to hear telltale signs that it was between innings and maybe whether or not it was a close game. You could probably detect when something abnormal happened. But that’s about it.</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 16pt;\"><strong>ECoG</strong></span></p> \n<p><strong>Scale: </strong>high</p> \n<p><strong>Resolution: </strong>low spatial, high temporal</p> \n<p><strong>Invasiveness: </strong>kind of invasive</p> \n<p>ECoG (electrocorticography) is a similar idea to EEG, also using surface electrodes—except they put them <em>under </em>the skull, on the surface of the brain.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-35-6120\" id=\"note2-35-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">35</a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Intracranial_electrode_grid_for_electrocorticography.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\" wp-image-6160 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Intracranial_electrode_grid_for_electrocorticography-600x600.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"350\" height=\"350\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Intracranial_electrode_grid_for_electrocorticography-600x600.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Intracranial_electrode_grid_for_electrocorticography-150x150.png 150w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Intracranial_electrode_grid_for_electrocorticography-300x300.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Intracranial_electrode_grid_for_electrocorticography-768x768.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Intracranial_electrode_grid_for_electrocorticography.png 1500w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 350px) 100vw, 350px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Ick. But effective—at least much more effective than EEG. Without the interference of the skull blurring things, ECoG picks up both higher spatial (about 1cm) and temporal resolution (5 milliseconds). ECoG electrodes can either be placed above or below the dura:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-36-6120\" id=\"note2-36-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">36</a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/layersofthebrain.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"size-large wp-image-6161 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/layersofthebrain-600x252.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"252\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/layersofthebrain-600x252.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/layersofthebrain-300x126.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/layersofthebrain-768x322.png 768w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Bringing back our stadium analogy, ECoG microphones are <em>inside </em>the stadium and a bit closer to the crowd. So the sound is much crisper than what EEG mics get from outside the stadium, and ECoG mics can better distinguish the sounds of individual sections of the crowd. But the improvement comes at a cost—it requires invasive surgery. In the scheme of invasive surgeries, though, it’s not so bad. As one neurosurgeon described to me, “You can slide stuff underneath the dura relatively non-invasively. You still have to make a hole in the head, but it’s relatively non-invasive.”</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 16pt;\"><strong>Local Field Potential</strong></span></p> \n<p><strong>Scale: </strong>low</p> \n<p><strong>Resolution: </strong>medium-low spatial, high temporal</p> \n<p><strong>Invasiveness: </strong>very invasive</p> \n<p>Okay here’s where we shift from surface electrode discs to microelectrodes—tiny needles surgeons stick into the brain.</p> \n<p>Brain surgeon Ben Rapoport described to me how his father (a neurologist) used to make microelectrodes:</p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><em>When my father was making electrodes, he’d make them by hand. He’d take a very fine wire—like a gold or platinum or iridium wire, that was 10-30 microns in diameter, and he’d insert that wire in a glass capillary tube that was maybe a millimeter in diameter. Then they’d take that piece of glass over a flame and rotate it until the glass became soft. They’d stretch out the capillary tube until it’s incredibly thin, and then take it out of the flame and break it. Now the capillary tube is flush with and pinching the wire. The glass is an insulator and the wire is a conductor. So what you end up with is a glass-insulated stiff electrode that is maybe a few 10s of microns at the tip.</em></p> \n<p class=\"p1\">Today, while some electrodes are still made by hand, newer techniques use silicon wafers and manufacturing technology borrowed from the integrated circuits industry.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\">The way local field potentials (LFP) work is simple—you take one of these super thin needles with an electrode tip and stick it one or two millimeters into the cortex. There it picks up the average of the electrical charges from all of the neurons within a certain radius of the electrode.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\">LFP gives you the not-that-bad spatial resolution of the fMRI combined with the instant temporal resolution of an ECoG. Kind of the best of all the worlds described above when it comes to resolution.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\">Unfortunately, it does badly on both other criteria.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\">Unlike fMRI, EEG, and ECoG, microelectrode LFP does not have scale—it <em>only</em> tells you what the little sphere surrounding it is doing. And it’s far more invasive, actually entering the brain.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\">In the baseball stadium, LFP is a single microphone hanging over a single section of seats, picking up a crisp feed of the sounds in that area, and maybe picking out an individual voice for a second here and there—but otherwise only getting the general vibe.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\">A more recent development is the <strong>multielectrode array, </strong>which is the same idea as the LFP except it’s about 100 LFPs all at once, in a single area of the cortex. A multielectrode array looks like this:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-37-6120\" id=\"note2-37-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">37</a></p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Focus-stack-penny_sm.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\" wp-image-6162 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Focus-stack-penny_sm-600x400.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"549\" height=\"366\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Focus-stack-penny_sm.jpg 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Focus-stack-penny_sm-300x200.jpg 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Focus-stack-penny_sm-103x70.jpg 103w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 549px) 100vw, 549px\" /></a></p> \n<p class=\"p1\">A tiny 4mm x 4mm square with 100 tiny silicon electrodes on it. Here’s another image where you can see just how sharp the electrodes are—just a few microns across at the very tip:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-38-6120\" id=\"note2-38-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">38</a></p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/jmm294120fig01.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\" wp-image-6163 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/jmm294120fig01.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"578\" height=\"258\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/jmm294120fig01.jpg 520w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/jmm294120fig01-300x134.jpg 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 578px) 100vw, 578px\" /></a></p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><strong style=\"font-size: 16pt;\">Single-Unit Recording</strong></p> \n<p><strong>Scale: </strong>tiny</p> \n<p><strong>Resolution: </strong>super high</p> \n<p><strong>Invasiveness: </strong>very invasive</p> \n<p>To record a broader LFP, the electrode tip is a bit rounded to give the electrode more surface area, and they turn the resistance down with the intent of allowing very faint signals from a wide range of locations to be picked up. The end result is the electrode picks up a chorus of activity from the local field.</p> \n<p>Single-unit recording also uses a needle electrode, but they make the tip super sharp and crank up the resistance. This wipes out most of the noise and leaves the electrode picking up almost nothing—until it finds itself <em>so </em>close to a neuron (maybe 50µm away) that the signal from that neuron is strong enough to make it past the electrode’s high resistance wall. With distinct signals from one neuron and no background noise, this electrode can now voyeur in on the private life of a single neuron. Lowest possible scale, highest possible resolution.</p> \n<p>By the way, you can listen to a neuron fire <span class=\"s1\"><span class=\"s2\"><a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8bxpz-YEuao\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">here</a> (what you’re actually hearing is the electro-chemical firing of a neuron, converted to audio).</span></span></p> \n<p>Some electrodes want to take the relationship to the next level and will go for a technique called the <strong>patch clamp</strong>, whereby it’ll get rid of its electrode tip, leaving just a tiny little tube called a glass pipette,<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote-22-6120\" id=\"note-22-6120\" rel=\"footnote\">22</a> and it’ll actually directly assault a neuron by sucking a “patch” of its membrane into the tube, allowing for even finer measurements:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-39-6120\" id=\"note2-39-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">39</a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/2009_06a.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"size-full wp-image-6164 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/2009_06a.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"325\" height=\"278\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/2009_06a.jpg 325w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/2009_06a-300x257.jpg 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 325px) 100vw, 325px\" /></a></p> \n<p>A patch clamp also has the benefit that, unlike all the other methods we’ve discussed, because it’s physically touching the neuron, it can not only record but <em>stimulate </em>the neuron,<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote-23-6120\" id=\"note-23-6120\" rel=\"footnote\">23</a> injecting current or holding voltage at a set level to do specific tests (other methods can stimulate neurons, but only entire groups together).</p> \n<p>Finally, electrodes can fully defile the neuron and actually penetrate through the membrane, which is called <strong>sharp electrode recording. </strong>If the tip is sharp enough, this won’t destroy the cell—the membrane will actually seal around the electrode, making it very easy to stimulate the neuron or record the voltage difference between the inside and outside of the neuron. But this is a short-term technique—a punctured neuron won’t survive long.</p> \n<p>In our stadium, a single unit recording is a one-directional microphone clipped to a single crowd member’s collar. A patch clamp or sharp recording is a mic in someone’s throat, registering the exact movement of their vocal cords. This is a great way to learn about that person’s experience at the game, but it also gives you no context, and you can’t really tell if the sounds and reactions of that person are representative of what’s going on in the game.</p> \n<p>And that’s about what we’ve got, at least in common usage. These tools are simultaneously unbelievably advanced and what will seem like Stone Age technology to future humans, who won’t believe you had to choose <em>either </em>high-res <em>or </em>a wide field and that you actually had to open someone’s <em>skull </em>to get high-quality brain readouts or write-ins.</p> \n<p>But given their limitations, these tools have taught us worlds about the brain and led to the creation of some amazing early BMIs. Here’s what’s already out there—</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 20pt;\"><strong>The BMIs we already have</strong></span></p> \n<p>In 1969, a researcher named Eberhard Fetz connected a single neuron in a monkey’s brain to a dial in front of the monkey’s face. The dial would move when the neuron was fired. When the monkey would think in a way that fired the neuron and the dial would move, he’d get a banana-flavored pellet. Over time, the monkey started getting <em>better </em>at the game because he wanted more delicious pellets. The monkey had learned to make the neuron fire and inadvertently became the subject of the first real brain-machine interface.</p> \n<p>Progress was slow over the next few decades, but by the mid-90s, things had started to move, and it’s been quietly accelerating ever since.</p> \n<p>Given that both our understanding of the brain and the electrode hardware we’ve built are pretty primitive, our efforts have typically focused on building straightforward interfaces to be used with the areas of the brain we understand the best, like the motor cortex and the visual cortex.</p> \n<p>And given that human experimentation is only really possible for people who are trying to use BMIs to alleviate an impairment—and because that’s currently where the market demand is—our efforts have focused so far almost entirely on restoring lost function to people with disabilities.</p> \n<p>The major BMI industries of the future that will give all humans magical superpowers and transform the world are in their fetal stage right now—and we should look at what’s being worked on as a set of clues about what the mind-boggling worlds of 2040 and 2060 and 2100 might be like.</p> \n<p>Like, check this out:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/NV_0215_Hood_alan-turing-first-computer.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\" wp-image-6175 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/NV_0215_Hood_alan-turing-first-computer.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"654\" height=\"388\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/NV_0215_Hood_alan-turing-first-computer.jpg 800w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/NV_0215_Hood_alan-turing-first-computer-300x178.jpg 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/NV_0215_Hood_alan-turing-first-computer-768x456.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/NV_0215_Hood_alan-turing-first-computer-600x356.jpg 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 654px) 100vw, 654px\" /></a></p> \n<p>That’s a computer built by Alan Turing in 1950 called the Pilot ACE. Truly cutting edge in its time.</p> \n<p>Now check this out:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/iphone-7BLACK.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"wp-image-6176 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/iphone-7BLACK.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"310\" height=\"397\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/iphone-7BLACK.png 468w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/iphone-7BLACK-234x300.png 234w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 310px) 100vw, 310px\" /></a></p> \n<p>As you read through the examples below, I want you to think about this analogy—</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span style=\"font-size: 14pt;\"><strong>Pilot ACE</strong> is to <strong>iPhone 7 </strong></span></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span style=\"font-size: 14pt;\">as </span></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><span style=\"font-size: 14pt;\"><strong>Each BMI example below</strong> is to <strong>_____</strong></span></p> \n<p>—and try to imagine what the blank looks like. And we’ll come back to the blank later in the post.</p> \n<p>Anyway, from everything I’ve read about and discussed with people in the field, there seem to be three major categories of brain-machine interface being heavily worked on right now:</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 16pt;\"><strong>Early BMI type #1: Using the motor cortex as a remote control</strong></span></p> \n<p>In case you forgot this from 9,000 words ago, the motor cortex is this guy:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/ucNSNTDc4yMxayeRNXNlpw_m.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"size-full wp-image-6133 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/ucNSNTDc4yMxayeRNXNlpw_m.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"240\" height=\"210\" /></a></p> \n<p>All areas of the brain confuse us, but the motor cortex confuses us less than almost all the other areas. And most importantly, it’s <em>well-mapped</em>, meaning specific parts of it control specific parts of the body (remember the upsetting <a href=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/152-KB-Homonculus-Sensory-and-Motor-Cortex.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"” noopener noreferrer\">homunculus?</a>).</p> \n<p>Also importantly, it’s one of the major areas of the brain in charge of our <em>output</em>. When a human <em>does </em>something, the motor cortex is almost always the one pulling the strings (at least for the physical part of the doing). So the human brain doesn’t really have to <em>learn </em>to use the motor cortex as a remote control, because the brain already uses the motor cortex as its remote control.</p> \n<p>Lift your hand up. Now put it down. See? Your hand is like a little toy drone, and your brain just picked up the motor cortex remote control and used it to make the drone fly up and then back down.</p> \n<p>The goal of motor cortex-based BMIs is to tap into the motor cortex, and then when the remote control fires a command, to <em>hear </em>that command and then send it to some kind of machine that can respond to it the way, say, your hand would. A bundle of nerves is the middleman between your motor cortex and your hand. BMIs are the middleman between your motor cortex and a computer. Simple.</p> \n<p>One barebones type of interface allows a human—often a person paralyzed from the neck down or someone who has had a limb amputated—to move a cursor on a screen with only their thoughts.</p> \n<p>This begins with a 100-pin multielectrode array being implanted in the person’s motor cortex. The motor cortex in a paralyzed person usually works just fine—it’s just that the spinal cord, which had served as the middleman between the cortex and the body, stopped doing its job. So with the electrode array implanted, researchers have the person <em>try </em>to move their arm in different directions. Even though they can’t do that, the motor cortex still fires normally, as if they can.</p> \n<p>When someone moves their arm, their motor cortex bursts into a flurry of activity—but each neuron is usually only interested in one type of movement. So one neuron might fire whenever the person moves their arm to the right—but it’s bored by other directions and is less active in those cases. That neuron alone, then, could tell a computer when the person wants to move their arm to the right and when they don’t. But that’s all. But with an electrode <em>array</em>, 100 single-unit electrodes each listen to a different neuron.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote-24-6120\" id=\"note-24-6120\" rel=\"footnote\">24</a> So when they do testing, they’ll ask the person to try to move their arm to the right, and maybe 38 of the 100 electrodes detect their neuron firing. When the person tries to go left with their arm, maybe 41 others fire. After going through a bunch of different movements and directions and speeds, a computer takes the data from the electrodes and synthesizes it into a general understanding of which firing patterns correspond to which movement intentions on an X-Y axis.</p> \n<p>Then when they link up that data to a computer screen, the person can use their mind, via “trying” to move the cursor, to really control the cursor. And this actually works. Through the work of motor-cortex-BMI pioneer company <a href=\"https://www.braingate.org/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">BrainGate</a>, here’s a guy playing a video game using only his mind.</p> \n<p><iframe src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/TJJPbpHoPWo\" width=\"560\" height=\"315\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"allowfullscreen\"></iframe></p> \n<p>And if 100 neurons can tell you where they want to move a cursor, why couldn’t they tell you when they want to pick up a mug of coffee and take a sip? That’s what this quadriplegic woman did:</p> \n<p><iframe title=\"Thought control of robotic arms using the BrainGate system\" width=\"500\" height=\"281\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/QRt8QCx3BCo?start=87&amp;feature=oembed\" frameborder=\"0\" allow=\"accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture\" allowfullscreen=\"\"></iframe></p> \n<p>Another quadriplegic woman <a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/speaking-of-science/wp/2015/03/03/a-paralyzed-woman-flew-a-f-35-fighter-jet-in-a-simulator-using-only-her-mind/?utm_term=.d76217b806c6\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">flew an F-35 fighter jet</a> in a simulation, and a monkey recently used his mind to <a href=\"https://medschool.duke.edu/about-us/news-and-communications/med-school-blog/monkeys-drive-wheelchairs-using-only-their-thoughts\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">ride around in a wheelchair</a>.</p> \n<p>And why stop with arms? Brazilian BMI pioneer <a href=\"https://www.ted.com/talks/miguel_nicolelis_brain_to_brain_communication_has_arrived_how_we_did_it\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Miguel Nicolelis</a> and his team built an entire <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?time_continue=76&amp;v=mg8TAJdQKyY\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">exoskeleton</a> that allowed a paralyzed man to make the <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=inCvbDLfXBo\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">opening kick</a> of the World Cup.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote-25-6120\" id=\"note-25-6120\" rel=\"footnote\">25</a></p> \n<div class=\"wbwAside\"> \n <p><span style=\"font-size: 14pt;\"><strong>The Proprioception Blue Box</strong></span></p> \n <p>Moving these kinds of “neuroprosthetics” is all about the recording of neurons, but for these devices to be truly effective, this needs to not be a one-way street, but a <em>loop </em>that includes recording <em>and </em>stimulation pathways. We don’t really think about this, but a huge part of your ability to pick up an object is all of the incoming sensory information your hand’s skin and muscles send back in (called “proprioception”). In one video I saw, a woman with numbed fingers tried to light a match, and it was almost impossible for her to do it, despite having no other disabilities. And the beginning of <a href=\"http://www.dailymotion.com/video/x12647t_the-man-who-lost-his-body-bbc-documentary_tech\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">this video</a> shows the physical struggles of a man with a perfectly functional motor cortex but impaired proprioception. So for something like a bionic arm to really feel like an arm, and to really be useful, it needs to be able to send sensory information back in.</p> \n <p>Stimulating neurons is even harder than recording them. As researcher Flip Sabes explained to me:</p> \n <p><em>If I record a pattern of activity, it doesn’t mean I can readily recreate that pattern of activity by just playing it back. You can compare it to the planets in the Solar System. You can watch the planets move around and record their movements. But then if you jumble them all up and later want to recreate the original motion of one of the planets, you can’t just take that one planet and put it back into its orbit, because it’ll be influenced by all the other planets. Likewise, neurons aren’t just working in isolation—so there’s a fundamental irreversibility there. On top of that, with all of the axons and dendrites, it’s hard to just stimulate the neurons you want to—because when you try, you’ll hit a whole jumble of them.</em></p> \n <p>Flip’s lab tries to deal with these challenges by getting the brain to help out. It turns out that if you reward a monkey with a succulent sip of orange juice when a single neuron fires, eventually the monkey will learn to make the neuron fire on demand. The neuron could then act as another kind of remote control. This means that normal motor cortex commands are only one possibility as a control mechanism. Likewise, until BMI technology gets good enough to perfect stimulation, you can use the brain’s neuroplasticity as a shortcut. If it’s too hard to make someone’s bionic fingertip touch something and send back information that feels just like the kind of sensation their own fingertip used to give them, the arm could instead send some <em>other </em>signal into the brain. At first, this would seem odd to the patient—but eventually the brain can learn to treat that signal as a new sense of touch. This concept is called “sensory substitution” and makes the brain a collaborator in BMI efforts.</p> \n</div> \n<p>In these developments are the seeds of other future breakthrough technologies—like brain-to-brain communication.</p> \n<p>Nicolelis created an <a href=\"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3584574/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">experiment</a> where the motor cortex of one rat in Brazil was wired, via the internet, to the motor cortex of another rat in the US. The rat in Brazil was presented with two transparent boxes, each with a lever attached to it, and inside one of the boxes would be a treat. To attempt to get the treat, the rat would press the lever of the box that held the treat. Meanwhile, the rat in the US was in a similar cage with two similar boxes, except unlike the rat in Brazil, the boxes weren’t transparent and offered him no information about which of his two levers would yield a treat and which wouldn’t. The only info the US rat had were the signals his brain received from the Brazil rat’s motor cortex. The Brazil rat had the key knowledge—but the way the experiment worked, the rats only received treats when the US rat pressed the correct lever. If he pulled the wrong one, neither would. The amazing thing is that over time, the rats got <em>better</em> at this and began to work together, almost like a single nervous system—even though neither had any idea the other rat existed. The US rat’s success rate at choosing the correct lever with no information would have been 50%. With the signals coming from the Brazil rat’s brain, the success rate jumped to 64%. (Here’s a <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m2_1dzwnNwE\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">video</a> of the rats doing their thing.)</p> \n<p>This has even worked, crudely, in people. Two people, in separate buildings, <a href=\"http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0111332\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">worked together</a> to play a video game. One could <em>see </em>the game, the other had the controller. Using simple EEG headsets, the player who could see the game would, without moving his hand, <em>think </em>about moving his hand to press the “shoot” button on a controller. Because their brains’ devices were communicating with each other, the player with the controller would then feel a twitch in his finger and press the shoot button.</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 16pt;\"><strong>Early BMI type #2: Artificial ears and eyes</strong></span></p> \n<p>There are a couple reasons giving sound to the deaf and sight to the blind is among the more manageable BMI categories.</p> \n<p>The first is that like the motor cortex, the sensory cortices are parts of the brain we tend to understand pretty well, partly because they too tend to be well-mapped.</p> \n<p>The second is that in many early applications, we don’t <em>really </em>need to deal with the brain—we can just deal with the place where ears and eyes <em>connect </em>to the brain, since that’s often where the impairment is based.</p> \n<p>And while the motor cortex stuff was mostly about <em>recording </em>neurons to get information <em>out</em> of the brain, artificial senses go the other way—<em>stimulation</em> of neurons to send information <em>in.</em></p> \n<p>On the ears side of things, recent decades have seen the development of the groundbreaking <strong>cochlear implant</strong>. <strong> </strong></p> \n<div class=\"wbwAside\"> \n <p><span style=\"font-size: 14pt;\"><strong>The How Hearing Works Blue Box</strong></span></p> \n <p>When you think you’re “hearing” “sound,” here’s what’s actually happening:</p> \n <p>What we think of as sound is actually patterns of vibrations in the air molecules around your head. When a guitar string or someone’s vocal cords or the wind or anything else makes a sound, it’s because it’s vibrating, which pushes nearby air molecules into a similar vibration and that pattern expands outward in a sphere, kind of like the surface of water expands outward in a circular ripple when something touches it.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote-26-6120\" id=\"note-26-6120\" rel=\"footnote\">26</a></p> \n <p>Your ear is a machine that converts those air vibrations into electrical impulses. Whenever air (or water, or any other medium whose molecules can vibrate) enters your ear, your ear translates the precise way it’s vibrating into an electrical code that it sends into the nerve endings that touch it. This causes those nerves to fire a pattern of action potentials that send the code into your auditory cortex for processing. Your brain receives the information, and we call the experience of receiving that particular type of information “hearing.”</p> \n <p>Most people who are deaf or hard of hearing don’t have a nerve problem or an auditory cortex problem—they usually have an ear problem. Their brain is as ready as anyone else’s to turn electrical impulses into hearing—it’s just that their auditory cortex isn’t <em>receiving</em> any electrical impulses in the first place, because the machine that converts air vibrations into those impulses isn’t doing its job.</p> \n <p>The ear has a lot of parts, but it’s the cochlea in particular that makes the key conversion. When vibrations enter the fluid in the cochlea, it causes thousands of tiny hairs lining the cochlea to vibrate, and the cells those hairs are attached to transform the mechanical energy of the vibrations into electrical signals that then excite the auditory nerve. Here’s what it all looks like:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-40-6120\" id=\"note2-40-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">40</a></p> \n <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/otitis-interna.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\" wp-image-6170 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/otitis-interna.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"577\" height=\"492\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/otitis-interna.jpg 800w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/otitis-interna-300x256.jpg 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/otitis-interna-768x655.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/otitis-interna-600x512.jpg 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 577px) 100vw, 577px\" /></a></p> \n <p>The cochlea also sorts the incoming sound by frequency. Here’s a cool chart that shows why lower sounds are processed at the end of the cochlea and high sounds are processed at the beginning (and also why there’s a minimum and maximum frequency on what the ear can hear):<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-41-6120\" id=\"note2-41-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">41</a></p> \n <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/tmp512613186340388865.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"size-large wp-image-6168 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/tmp512613186340388865-600x336.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"336\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/tmp512613186340388865.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/tmp512613186340388865-300x168.png 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a></p> \n</div> \n<p>A cochlear implant is a little computer that has a microphone coming out of one end (which sits on the ear) and a wire coming out of the other that connects to an array of electrodes that line the cochlea. <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/62036062.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6171\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/62036062.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"557\" height=\"485\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/62036062.jpg 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/62036062-300x261.jpg 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/62036062-768x669.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/62036062-600x522.jpg 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 557px) 100vw, 557px\" /></a></p> \n<p>So sound comes into the microphone (the little hook on top of the ear), and goes into the brown thing, which processes the sound to filter out the less useful frequencies. Then the brown thing transmits the information through the skin, through electrical induction, to the computer’s other component, which converts the info into electric impulses and sends them into the cochlea. The electrodes filter the impulses by frequency just like the cochlea and stimulate the auditory nerve just like the hairs on the cochlea do. This is what it looks like from the outside:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/processor-on-ear.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"size-full wp-image-6166 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/processor-on-ear.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"392\" height=\"337\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/processor-on-ear.jpg 392w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/processor-on-ear-300x258.jpg 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 392px) 100vw, 392px\" /></a></p> \n<p>In other words, an artificial ear, performing the same sound-to-impulses-to-auditory-nerve function the ear does.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://youtu.be/00WOao4kpwM?t=3m15s\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Check out what sound sounds</a> like to someone with the implant.</p> \n<p>Not great. Why? Because to send sound into the brain with the richness the ear hears with, you’d need 3,500 electrodes. Most cochlear implants have about 16.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote-27-6120\" id=\"note-27-6120\" rel=\"footnote\">27</a> Crude.</p> \n<p>But we’re in the Pilot ACE era—so of course it’s crude.</p> \n<p>Still, today’s cochlear implant allows deaf people to hear <em>speech</em> and have conversations, which is a groundbreaking development.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote-28-6120\" id=\"note-28-6120\" rel=\"footnote\">28</a></p> \n<p>Many parents of deaf babies are now having a cochlear implant put in when the baby’s about one year old. Like this baby, whose reaction to hearing for the first time is <em>cute</em>.</p> \n<p><iframe title=\"8 Month Old Deaf Baby's Reaction To Cochlear Implant Being Activated\" width=\"500\" height=\"375\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/HTzTt1VnHRM?feature=oembed\" frameborder=\"0\" allow=\"accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture\" allowfullscreen=\"\"></iframe></p> \n<p>There’s a similar revolution underway in the world of blindness, in the form of the <strong>retinal implant</strong>.</p> \n<p>Blindness is often the result of a retinal disease. When this is the case, a retinal implant can perform a similar function for sight as a cochlear implant does for hearing (though less directly). It performs the normal duties of the eye and hands things off to nerves in the form of electrical impulses, just like the eye does.</p> \n<p>A more complicated interface than the cochlear implant, the first retinal implant was approved by the FDA in 2011—the Argus II implant, made by <a href=\"http://www.secondsight.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Second Sight</a>. The retinal implant looks like this:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-42-6120\" id=\"note2-42-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">42</a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/6x6-argus-retinal-implant_2d.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\" wp-image-6172 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/6x6-argus-retinal-implant_2d.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"312\" height=\"312\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/6x6-argus-retinal-implant_2d.jpg 370w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/6x6-argus-retinal-implant_2d-150x150.jpg 150w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/6x6-argus-retinal-implant_2d-300x300.jpg 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 312px) 100vw, 312px\" /></a></p> \n<p>And it works like this:</p> \n<p><iframe title=\"Second Sight Argus II Retinal Prosthesis System (English)\" width=\"500\" height=\"281\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/Bi_HpbFKnSw?start=2&amp;feature=oembed\" frameborder=\"0\" allow=\"accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture\" allowfullscreen=\"\"></iframe></p> \n<p>The retinal implant has 60 sensors. The retina has around a million neurons. Crude. But seeing vague edges and shapes and patterns of light and dark sure beats seeing nothing at all. What’s encouraging is that you don’t need a million sensors to gain a reasonable amount of sight—simulations suggest that 600-1,000 electrodes would be enough for reading and facial recognition.</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 16pt;\"><strong>Early BMI type #3: Deep brain stimulation</strong></span></p> \n<p>Dating back to the late 1980s, deep brain stimulation is yet another crude tool that is also still pretty life-changing for a lot of people.</p> \n<p>It’s also a type of category of BMI that doesn’t involve communication with the outside world—it’s about using brain-machine interfaces to treat or enhance yourself by altering something internally.</p> \n<p>What happens here is one or two electrode wires, usually with <a href=\"http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/ieee_pilot/articles/96jproc07/96jproc07-liker/assets/img/article_1/fig_2/small.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">four separate electrode sites</a>, are inserted into the brain, often ending up somewhere in the limbic system. Then a little pacemaker computer is implanted in the upper chest and wired to the electrodes. Like this unpleasant man:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-43-6120\" id=\"note2-43-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">43</a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/StJudeMedicalDBSStory.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"size-full wp-image-6173 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/StJudeMedicalDBSStory.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"350\" height=\"400\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/StJudeMedicalDBSStory.jpg 350w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/StJudeMedicalDBSStory-263x300.jpg 263w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 350px) 100vw, 350px\" /></a></p> \n<p>The electrodes can then give a little zap when called for, which can do a variety of important things. Like:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Reduce the tremors of people with Parkinson’s Disease</li> \n <li>Reduce the severity of seizures</li> \n <li>Chill people with OCD out</li> \n</ul> \n<p>It’s also experimentally (not yet FDA approved) been able to mitigate certain kinds of chronic pain like migraines or phantom limb pain, treat anxiety or depression or PTSD, or even be combined with muscle stimulation elsewhere in the body to restore and retrain circuits that were broken down from stroke or a neurological disease.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">___________</p> \n<p><a name=\"part4\"></a>This is the state of the early BMI industry, and it’s the moment when Elon Musk is stepping into it. For him, and for Neuralink, today’s BMI industry is Point A. We’ve spent the whole post so far in the past, building up to the present moment. Now it’s time to step into the future—to figure out what Point B is and how we’re going to get there.</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 28pt;\"><strong>Part 4: Neuralink’s Challenge</strong></span></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-tree-Parts-4.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6438\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-tree-Parts-4.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"200\" height=\"228\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-tree-Parts-4.png 747w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-tree-Parts-4-263x300.png 263w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-tree-Parts-4-525x600.png 525w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 200px) 100vw, 200px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Having already written about two of Elon Musk’s companies—<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2015/06/how-tesla-will-change-your-life.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Tesla</a> and <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2015/08/how-and-why-spacex-will-colonize-mars.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">SpaceX</a>—I think I understand his formula. It looks like this:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Elon-company-formula-1.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6315\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Elon-company-formula-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"516\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Elon-company-formula-1.png 1800w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Elon-company-formula-1-300x207.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Elon-company-formula-1-768x529.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Elon-company-formula-1-600x413.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Elon-company-formula-1-103x70.png 103w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> \n<p>And his initial thinking about a new company always starts on the right and works its way left.</p> \n<p>He decides that some specific change in the world will increase the likelihood of humanity having the best possible future. He knows that large-scale world change happens quickest when the whole world—the Human Colossus—is working on it. And he knows that the Human Colossus will work toward a goal if (and only if) there’s an economic forcing function in place—if it’s a good business decision to spend resources innovating toward that goal.</p> \n<p>Often, before a booming industry starts booming, it’s like a pile of logs—it has all the ingredients of a fire and it’s ready to go—but there’s no match. There’s some technological shortcoming that’s preventing the industry from taking off.</p> \n<p>So when Elon builds a company, its core initial strategy is usually to create the match that will ignite the industry and get the Human Colossus working on the cause. This, in turn, Elon believes, will lead to developments that will change the world in the way that increases the likelihood of humanity having the best possible future. But you have to look at his companies from a zoomed-out perspective to see all of this. If you don’t, you’ll mistake what they do as their business for what they <em>do</em>—when in fact, what they do as their business is usually a mechanism to sustain the company while it innovates to try to make that critical match.</p> \n<p>Back when I was working on the Tesla and SpaceX posts, I asked Elon why he went into engineering and not science, and he explained that when it comes to progress, “engineering is the limiting factor.” In other words, the progress of science, business, and industry are all at the whim of the progress of engineering. If you look at history, this makes sense—behind each of the greatest revolutions in human progress is an engineering breakthrough. A match.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Matches-small-2.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6463\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Matches-small-2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"800\" height=\"233\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Matches-small-2.png 1483w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Matches-small-2-300x87.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Matches-small-2-768x224.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Matches-small-2-600x175.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" /></a></p> \n<p>So to understand an Elon Musk company, you need to think about the match he’s trying to create—along with three other variables:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Elon-company-formula-variables.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6316\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Elon-company-formula-variables.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"516\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Elon-company-formula-variables.png 1800w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Elon-company-formula-variables-300x207.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Elon-company-formula-variables-768x529.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Elon-company-formula-variables-600x413.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Elon-company-formula-variables-103x70.png 103w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> \n<p>I know what’s in these boxes with the other companies:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Tesla-formula-1.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6469\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Tesla-formula-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"800\" height=\"536\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Tesla-formula-1.png 1850w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Tesla-formula-1-300x201.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Tesla-formula-1-768x514.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Tesla-formula-1-600x402.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Tesla-formula-1-103x70.png 103w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" /></a><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Tesla-formula.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><br /> </a><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/SpaceX-Formula-1.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6470\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/SpaceX-Formula-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"900\" height=\"507\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/SpaceX-Formula-1.png 2200w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/SpaceX-Formula-1-300x169.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/SpaceX-Formula-1-768x433.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/SpaceX-Formula-1-600x338.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px\" /></a></p> \n<p>And when I started trying to figure out what Neuralink was all about, I knew those were the variables I needed to fill in. At the time, I had only had the chance to get a very vague idea of one of the variables—that the goal of the company was “to accelerate the advent of a whole-brain interface.” Or what I’ve come to think of as a wizard hat.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuralink-formula-1-1.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6447\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuralink-formula-1-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"800\" height=\"551\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuralink-formula-1-1.png 1800w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuralink-formula-1-1-300x207.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuralink-formula-1-1-768x529.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuralink-formula-1-1-600x413.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuralink-formula-1-1-103x70.png 103w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" /></a></p> \n<p>As I understood it, a whole-brain interface was what a brain-machine interface would be in an ideal world—a super-advanced concept where essentially all the neurons in your brain are able to communicate seamlessly with the outside world. It was a concept loosely based on the science fiction idea of a “neural lace,”<em> </em>described in Iain Banks’ <em>Culture</em> series<em>—</em>a massless, volumeless, whole-brain interface that can be teleported into the brain.</p> \n<p>I had a lot of questions.</p> \n<p>Luckily, I was on my way to San Francisco, where I had plans to sit down with half of Neuralink’s founding team and be the dumbest person in the room.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/dumbest-person-1.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6422\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/dumbest-person-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"800\" height=\"613\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/dumbest-person-1.png 1619w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/dumbest-person-1-300x230.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/dumbest-person-1-768x588.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/dumbest-person-1-600x460.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" /></a></p> \n<div class=\"wbwAside\"> \n <p><span style=\"font-size: 14pt;\"><strong>The I’m Not Being Self-Deprecating I Really Was Definitely the Dumbest Person in the Room Just Look at This Shit Blue Box</strong></span></p> \n <p>The Neuralink team:</p> \n <p><strong><a href=\"http://paulmerolla.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Paul Merolla</a></strong>, who spent the last seven years as the lead chip designer at IBM on their SyNAPSE program, where he led the development of the <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TrueNorth\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">TrueNorth chip</a>—one of the largest CMOS devices ever designed by transistor count nbd. Paul told me his field was called <em>neuromorphic, </em>where the goal is to design transistor circuits based on principles of brain architecture.</p> \n <p><a href=\"https://neurotech.llnl.gov/people/vanessa-tolosa\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\" data-saferedirecturl=\"https://www.google.com/url?hl=en&amp;q=https://neurotech.llnl.gov/people/vanessa-tolosa&amp;source=gmail&amp;ust=1494378603670000&amp;usg=AFQjCNHEr4gvUHyKt2Ri6NQEmFmA6V7nCA\"><strong>Vanessa Tolosa</strong></a>, Neuralink’s microfabrication expert and one of the world’s foremost researchers on biocompatible materials. Vanessa’s work involves designing biocompatible materials based on principles from the integrated circuits industry.</p> \n <p><strong>Max Hodak</strong>, who worked on the development of some groundbreaking BMI technology at Miguel Nicolelis’s lab at Duke while also commuting across the country twice a week in college to run <a href=\"https://www.transcriptic.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Transcriptic</a>, the “robotic cloud laboratory for the life sciences” he founded.</p> \n <p><a href=\"https://people.eecs.berkeley.edu/~djseo/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><strong>DJ Seo</strong></a>, who while at UC Berkeley in his mid-20s designed a cutting-edge new BMI concept called <a href=\"http://news.berkeley.edu/2016/08/03/sprinkling-of-neural-dust-opens-door-to-electroceuticals/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">neural dust</a>—tiny ultrasound sensors that could provide a new way to record brain activity.</p> \n <p><strong><a href=\"https://www-bsac.eecs.berkeley.edu/directory/zoom?PersonID=1376947129&amp;URLnode=70\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Tim Hanson</a></strong>, whom a colleague described as “one of the best all-around engineers on the planet” and who self-taught himself enough about materials science and microfabrication methods to develop some of the core technology that’ll be used at Neuralink.</p> \n <p><strong><a href=\"http://profiles.ucsf.edu/philip.sabes\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Flip Sabes</a></strong>, a leading researcher whose lab at UCSF<strong> </strong>has pioneered new ground in BMIs by combining “cortical physiology, computational and theoretical modeling, and human psychophysics and physiology.”</p> \n <p><strong><a href=\"https://www.bu.edu/biology/people/profiles/tim-gardner/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Tim Gardner</a></strong>, a leading researcher at BU, whose lab works on implanting BMIs in <em>birds</em>, in order to study “how complex songs are assembled from elementary neural units” and learn about “the relationships between patterns of neural activity on different time-scales.” Both Tim and Flip have left tenured positions to join the Neuralink team—pretty good testament to the promise they believe this company has.</p> \n <p>And then there’s Elon, both as their CEO/Founder and a fellow team member. Elon being CEO makes this different from other recent things he’s started and puts Neuralink on the top tier for him, where only SpaceX and Tesla have lived. When it comes to neuroscience, Elon has the least technical knowledge on the team—but he also started SpaceX without very much technical knowledge and quickly became a certifiable rocket science expert by reading and by asking questions of the experts on the team. That’ll probably happen again here. (And for good reason—he pointed out: “Without a strong technical understanding, I think it’s hard to make the right decisions.”)</p> \n</div> \n<p>I asked Elon about how he brought this team together. He said that he met with literally over 1,000 people in order to assemble this group, and that part of the challenge was the large number of totally separate areas of expertise required when you’re working on technology that involves neuroscience, brain surgery, microscopic electronics, clinical trials, etc. Because it was such a cross-disciplinary area, he looked for cross-disciplinary experts. And you can see that in those bios—everyone brings their own unique crossover combination to a group that together has the rare ability to think as a single mega-expert. Elon also wanted to find people who were totally on board with the zoomed-out mission—who were more focused on industrial results than producing white papers. Not an easy group to assemble.</p> \n<p>But there they were, sitting around the table looking at me, as it hit me 40 seconds in that I should have done a lot more research before coming here.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/dumbest-person-2.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6412\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/dumbest-person-2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"551\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/dumbest-person-2.png 1239w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/dumbest-person-2-300x275.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/dumbest-person-2-768x705.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/dumbest-person-2-600x551.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a></p> \n<p>They took the hint and dumbed it down about four notches, and as the discussion went on, I started to wrap my head around things. Throughout the next few weeks, I met with each of the remaining Neuralink team members as well, each time playing the role of the dumbest person in the room. In these meetings, I focused on trying to form a comprehensive picture of the challenges at hand and what the road to a wizard hat might look like. I really wanted to understand these two boxes:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuralink-formula-v2_02.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6450\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuralink-formula-v2_02.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"800\" height=\"551\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuralink-formula-v2_02.png 1800w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuralink-formula-v2_02-300x207.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuralink-formula-v2_02-768x529.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuralink-formula-v2_02-600x413.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuralink-formula-v2_02-103x70.png 103w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" /></a></p> \n<p>The first one was easy. The <em>business </em>side of Neuralink is a brain-machine interface development company. They want to create cutting-edge BMIs—what one of them referred to as “micron-sized devices.” Doing this will support the growth of the company while also providing a perfect vehicle for putting their innovations into practice (the same way SpaceX uses their launches both to sustain the company and experiment with their newest engineering developments).</p> \n<p>As for what kind of interface they’re planning to work on first, here’s what Elon said:</p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><em><span class=\"s1\">We are aiming to bring something to market that helps with certain severe brain injuries (stroke, cancer lesion, congenital) in about four years. </span></em></p> \n<p>The second box was a lot hazier. It seems obvious to us today that using steam engine technology to harness the power of fire was the thing that had to happen to ignite the Industrial Revolution. But if you talked to someone in 1760 about it, they would have had a lot less clarity—on exactly which hurdles they were trying to get past, what kinds of innovations would allow them to leap over those hurdles, or how long any of this would take. And that’s where we are here—trying to figure out what the match looks like that will ignite the neuro revolution and how to create it.</p> \n<p>The starting place for a discussion about innovation is a discussion about hurdles—what are you even trying to innovate <em>past? </em>In Neuralink’s case, a whole lot of things. But given that, here too, engineering will likely prove to be the limiting factor, here are some seemingly large challenges that probably <em>won’t</em> end up being the major roadblock:</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 16pt;\"><strong>Public skepticism </strong></span></p> \n<p>Pew recently conducted a <a href=\"http://www.pewinternet.org/2016/07/26/u-s-public-wary-of-biomedical-technologies-to-enhance-human-abilities/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">survey</a> asking Americans about which future biotechnologies give them the shits the most. It turns out BMIs worry Americans even more than gene editing:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-44-6120\" id=\"note2-44-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">44</a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/PS_2016.07.26_Human-Enhancement-Survey_0-01.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"size-full wp-image-6181 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/PS_2016.07.26_Human-Enhancement-Survey_0-01.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"415\" height=\"413\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/PS_2016.07.26_Human-Enhancement-Survey_0-01.png 415w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/PS_2016.07.26_Human-Enhancement-Survey_0-01-150x150.png 150w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/PS_2016.07.26_Human-Enhancement-Survey_0-01-300x300.png 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 415px) 100vw, 415px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Flip Sabes, one of Neuralink’s ground floor members, doesn’t get it.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><em>To a scientist, to think about changing the fundamental nature of life—creating viruses, eugenics, etc.—it raises a specter that many biologists find quite worrisome, whereas the neuroscientists that I know, when they think about chips in the brain, it doesn’t seem that foreign, because we already have chips in the brain. We have deep brain stimulation to alleviate the symptoms of Parkinson’s Disease, we have early trials of chips to restore vision, we have the cochlear implant—so to us it doesn’t seem like that big of a stretch to put devices into a brain to read information out and to read information back in.</em></p> \n<p class=\"p1\">And after learning all about chips in the brain, I agree—and when Americans eventually learn about it, I think they’ll change their minds.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\">History supports this prediction. People were super timid about Lasik eye surgery when it first became a thing—20 years ago, 20,000 people a year had the procedure done. Then everyone got used to it and now 2,000,000 people a year get laser eye surgery. Similar story with pacemakers. And defibrillators. And organ transplants—which people at first considered a freakish Frankenstein-esque concept. Brain implants will probably be the same story.</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 16pt;\"><strong>Our non-understanding of the brain</strong></span></p> \n<p>You know, the whole “if understanding the brain is a mile, we’re currently three inches in” thing. Flip weighed in on this topic too:</p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><em>If it were a prerequisite to understand the brain in order to interact with the brain in a substantive way, we’d have trouble. But it’s possible to decode all of those things in the brain without truly understanding the dynamics of the computation in the brain. Being able to read it out is an engineering problem.
