Being able to understand its origin and the organization of the neurons in fine detail in a way that would satisfy a neuroscientist to the core—that’s a separate problem. And we don’t need to solve all of those scientific problems in order to make progress.</em></p> \n<p class=\"p1\">If we can just use engineering to get neurons to talk to computers, we’ll have done our job, and machine learning can do much of the rest. Which then, ironically, <em>will </em>teach us about the brain. As Flip points out:</p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><em>The flip side of saying, “We don’t need to understand the brain to make engineering progress,” is that making engineering progress will almost certainly advance our scientific knowledge—kind of like the way Alpha Go ended up teaching the world’s best players better strategies for the game. Then this scientific progress can lead to more engineering progress. The engineering and the science are gonna ratchet each other up here.</em></p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><span style=\"font-size: 16pt;\"><strong>Angry giants</strong></span></p> \n<p class=\"p1\">Tesla and SpaceX are both stepping on some very big toes (like the auto industry, the oil and gas industry, and the military-industrial complex). Big toes don’t like being stepped on, so they’ll usually do whatever they can to hinder the stepper’s progress. Luckily, Neuralink doesn’t really have this problem. There aren’t any massive industries that Neuralink is disrupting (at least not in the foreseeable future—an eventual neuro revolution would disrupt almost <em>every </em>industry).</p> \n<p class=\"p1\">Neuralink’s hurdles are technology hurdles—and there are many. But two challenges stand out as the largest—challenges that, if conquered, may be impactful enough to trigger all the other hurdles to fall and totally change the trajectory of our future.</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 20pt;\"><strong>Major Hurdle 1: Bandwidth</strong></span></p> \n<p>There have never been more than a couple hundred electrodes in a human brain at once. When it comes to vision, that equals a super low-res image. When it comes to motor, that limits the possibilities to simple commands with little control. When it comes to your thoughts, a few hundred electrodes won’t be enough to communicate more than the simplest spelled-out message.</p> \n<p>We need higher bandwidth if this is gonna become a big thing. <em>Way</em> higher bandwidth.</p> \n<p>The Neuralink team threw out the number “one million simultaneously recorded neurons” when talking about an interface that could really change the world. I’ve also heard 100,000 as a number that would allow for the creation of a wide range of incredibly useful BMIs with a variety of applications.</p> \n<p>Early computers had a similar problem. Primitive transistors took up a lot of space and didn’t scale easily. Then in 1959 came the integrated circuit—the computer chip. Now there was a way to scale the number of transistors in a computer, and Moore’s Law—the concept that the number of transistors that can fit onto a computer chip doubles every 18 months—was born.</p> \n<p>Until the 90s, electrodes for BMIs were all made by hand. Then we started figuring out how to manufacture those little 100-electrode <a href=\"https://d267cvn3rvuq91.cloudfront.net/i/images/electrodex299.jpg?sw=280\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">multielectrode arrays</a> using conventional semiconductor technologies. Neurosurgeon Ben Rapoport believes that “the move from hand manufacturing to Utah Array electrodes was the first hint that BMIs were entering a realm where Moore’s Law could become relevant.”</p> \n<p>This is everything for the industry’s potential. Our maximum today is a couple hundred electrodes able to measure about 500 neurons at once—which is either super far from a million or really close, depending on the kind of growth pattern we’re in. If we add 500 more neurons to our maximum every 18 months, we’ll get to a million in the year 5017. If we <em>double </em>our total every 18 months, like we do with computer transistors, we’ll get to a million in the year 2034.</p> \n<p>Currently, we seem to be somewhere in between. Ian Stevenson and Konrad Kording published a <a href=\"http://www.nature.com/neuro/journal/v14/n2/abs/nn.2731.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">paper</a> that looked at the maximum number of neurons that could be simultaneously recorded at various points throughout the last 50 years (in <em>any </em>animal), and put the results on this graph:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-45-6120\" id=\"note2-45-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">45</a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/mooreslaw.chartx2400.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\" wp-image-6178 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/mooreslaw.chartx2400.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"555\" height=\"616\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/mooreslaw.chartx2400.jpg 1200w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/mooreslaw.chartx2400-270x300.jpg 270w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/mooreslaw.chartx2400-768x853.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/mooreslaw.chartx2400-540x600.jpg 540w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 555px) 100vw, 555px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Sometimes called Stevenson’s Law, this research suggests that the number of neurons we can simultaneously record seems to consistently double every 7.4 years. If that rate continues, it’ll take us till the end of this century to reach a million, and until 2225 to record every neuron in the brain and get our totally complete wizard hat.</p> \n<p>Whatever the equivalent of the integrated circuit is for BMIs isn’t here yet, because 7.4 years is too big a number to start a revolution. The breakthrough here isn’t the device that can record a million neurons—it’s the paradigm shift that makes the future of that graph look more like Moore’s Law and less like Stevenson’s Law. Once that happens, a million neurons will follow.</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 20pt;\"><strong>Major Hurdle 2: Implantation</strong></span></p> \n<p>BMIs won’t sweep the world as long as you need to go in for skull-opening surgery to get involved.</p> \n<p>This is a major topic at Neuralink. I think the word “non-invasive” or “non-invasively” came out of someone’s mouth like 42 times in my discussions with the team.</p> \n<p>On top of being both a major barrier to entry and a major safety issue, invasive brain surgery is expensive and in limited supply. Elon talked about an eventual BMI implantation process that could be automated: “The machine to accomplish this would need to be something like Lasik, an automated process—because otherwise you just get constrained by the limited number of neural surgeons, and the costs are very high. You’d need a Lasik-like machine ultimately to be able to do this at scale.”</p> \n<p>Making BMIs high-bandwidth alone would be a huge deal, as would developing a way to non-invasively implant devices. But doing <em>both </em>would start a revolution.</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 16pt;\"><strong>Other hurdles</strong></span></p> \n<p>Today’s BMI patients have a wire coming out of their head. In the future, that certainly won’t fly. Neuralink plans to work on devices that will be wireless. But that brings a lot of new challenges with it. You’ll now need your device to be able to send and receive a lot of data wirelessly. Which means the implant also has to take care of things like signal amplification, analog-to-digital conversion, and data compression on its own. Oh and it needs to be powered inductively.</p> \n<p>Another big one—biocompatibility. Delicate electronics tend to not do well inside a jello ball. And the human body tends to not like having foreign objects in it. But the brain interfaces of the future are intended to last forever without any problems. This means that the device will likely need to be hermetically sealed and robust enough to survive decades of the oozing and shifting of the neurons around it. And the brain—which treats today’s devices like invaders and eventually covers them in scar tissue—will need to somehow be tricked into thinking the device is just a normal brain part doing its thing.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote-29-6120\" id=\"note-29-6120\" rel=\"footnote\">29</a></p> \n<p>Then there’s the space issue. Where exactly are you gonna put your device that can interface with a million neurons in a skull that’s already dealing with making space for 100 billion neurons? A million electrodes using today’s multielectrode arrays would be the size of a baseball. So further miniaturization is another dramatic innovation to add to the list.</p> \n<p>There’s also the fact that today’s electrodes are mostly optimized for simple electrical recording or simple electrical stimulation. If we really want an effective brain interface, we’ll need something other than single-function, stiff electrodes—something with the mechanical complexity of neural circuits, that can both record and stimulate, and that can interact with neurons chemically and mechanically as well as electrically.</p> \n<p>And just say all of this comes together perfectly—a high-bandwidth, long-lasting, biocompatible, bidirectional communicative, non-invasively-implanted device. Now we can speak back and forth with a million neurons at once! Except this little thing where we actually don’t know how to talk to neurons. It’s complicated enough to decode the static-like firings of 100 neurons, but all we’re really doing is learning what a set of specific firings corresponds to and matching them up to simple commands. That won’t work with millions of signals. It’s like how Google Translate essentially uses two dictionaries to swap words from one dictionary to another—which is very different than <em>understanding language. </em>We’ll need a pretty big leap in machine learning before a computer will be able to actually know a language, and we’ll need just as big a leap for machines to understand the language of the brain—because humans certainly won’t be learning to decipher the code of millions of simultaneously chattering neurons.</p> \n<p>How easy does colonizing Mars seem right now.</p> \n<p>But I bet the telephone and the car and the moon landing would have seemed like insurmountable technological challenges to people a few decades earlier. Just like I bet this—</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/iphone-7BLACK.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\" wp-image-6176 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/iphone-7BLACK.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"317\" height=\"406\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/iphone-7BLACK.png 468w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/iphone-7BLACK-234x300.png 234w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 317px) 100vw, 317px\" /></a></p> \n<p>—would have seemed utterly inconceivable to people at the time of this:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/NV_0215_Hood_alan-turing-first-computer.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"wp-image-6175 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/NV_0215_Hood_alan-turing-first-computer.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"561\" height=\"333\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/NV_0215_Hood_alan-turing-first-computer.jpg 800w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/NV_0215_Hood_alan-turing-first-computer-300x178.jpg 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/NV_0215_Hood_alan-turing-first-computer-768x456.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/NV_0215_Hood_alan-turing-first-computer-600x356.jpg 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 561px) 100vw, 561px\" /></a></p> \n<p>And yet, there it is in your pocket. If there’s one thing we should learn from the past, it’s that there will <em>always </em>be ubiquitous technology of the future that’s inconceivable to people of the past. We don’t know <em>which </em>technologies that seem positively impossible to us will turn out to be ubiquitous later in our lives—but there will be some. People always underestimate the Human Colossus.</p> \n<p>If everyone you know in 40 years has electronics in their skull, it’ll be because a paradigm shift took place that caused a fundamental shift in this industry. That shift is what the Neuralink team will try to figure out. Other teams are working on it too, and some cool ideas are being developed:</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 16pt;\"><strong>Current BMI innovations</strong></span></p> \n<p>A team at the University of Illinois is developing an interface made of silk:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-46-6120\" id=\"note2-46-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">46</a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/brain_silk_2s-660x440.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"wp-image-6182 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/brain_silk_2s-660x440.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"456\" height=\"304\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/brain_silk_2s-660x440.jpg 660w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/brain_silk_2s-660x440-300x200.jpg 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/brain_silk_2s-660x440-600x400.jpg 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/brain_silk_2s-660x440-103x70.jpg 103w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 456px) 100vw, 456px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Silk can be rolled up into a thin bundle and inserted into the brain relatively non-invasively. There, it would theoretically spread out around the brain and melt into the contours like shrink wrap. On the silk would be flexible silicon transistor arrays.</p> \n<p>In his <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3jRNY_JcBpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">TEDx Talk</a>, Hong Yeo demonstrated an electrode array printed on his skin, like a temporary tattoo, and <a href=\"https://www.wired.com/2013/02/skin-printed-electrodes/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">researchers say</a> this kind of technique could potentially be used on the brain:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-47-6120\" id=\"note2-47-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">47</a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/3a.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"wp-image-6183 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/3a.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"451\" height=\"341\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/3a.jpg 660w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/3a-300x227.jpg 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/3a-600x454.jpg 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 451px) 100vw, 451px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Another group is working on a kind of nano-scale, electrode-lined <strong><a href=\"https://www.extremetech.com/extreme/207848-injectable-neuro-mesh-covers-the-brain-can-control-individual-neurons\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">neural mesh</a></strong> so tiny it can be injected into the brain with a syringe:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-48-6120\" id=\"note2-48-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">48</a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/1298870262105595053.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"wp-image-6185 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/1298870262105595053.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"508\" height=\"381\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/1298870262105595053.jpg 800w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/1298870262105595053-300x225.jpg 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/1298870262105595053-768x576.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/1298870262105595053-600x450.jpg 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 508px) 100vw, 508px\" /></a></p> \n<p>For scale—that red tube on the right is the tip of a syringe. <a href=\"https://www.extremetech.com/extreme/207848-injectable-neuro-mesh-covers-the-brain-can-control-individual-neurons\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Extreme Tech</a> has a nice graphic illustrating the concept:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/brainmesh-2.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"size-full wp-image-6186 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/brainmesh-2.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"850\" height=\"362\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/brainmesh-2.jpg 850w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/brainmesh-2-300x128.jpg 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/brainmesh-2-768x327.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/brainmesh-2-600x256.jpg 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 850px) 100vw, 850px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Other non-invasive techniques involve going in through veins and arteries. Elon mentioned this: “The least invasive way would be something that comes in like a hard stent like through a femoral artery and ultimately unfolds in the vascular system to interface with the neurons. Neurons use a lot of energy, so there’s basically a road network to every neuron.”</p> \n<p>DARPA, the technology innovation arm of the US military,<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote-30-6120\" id=\"note-30-6120\" rel=\"footnote\">30</a> through their recently funded <a href=\"http://www.darpa.mil/program/our-research/darpa-and-the-brain-initiative\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">BRAIN program</a>, is working on tiny, “closed-loop” neural implants that could replace medication.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-49-6120\" id=\"note2-49-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">49</a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/stanford-microimplant-mid-field.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"wp-image-6184 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/stanford-microimplant-mid-field.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"531\" height=\"293\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/stanford-microimplant-mid-field.jpg 1000w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/stanford-microimplant-mid-field-300x166.jpg 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/stanford-microimplant-mid-field-768x424.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/stanford-microimplant-mid-field-600x331.jpg 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 531px) 100vw, 531px\" /></a></p> \n<p>A second DARPA project aims to fit a million electrodes into a device the size of two nickels stacked.</p> \n<p>Another idea being worked on is transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS), in which a magnetic coil outside the head can create electrical pulses inside the brain.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-50-6120\" id=\"note2-50-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">50</a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Transcranial_magnetic_stimulation.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"size-full wp-image-6187 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Transcranial_magnetic_stimulation.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"360\" height=\"324\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Transcranial_magnetic_stimulation.jpg 360w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Transcranial_magnetic_stimulation-300x270.jpg 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 360px) 100vw, 360px\" /></a></p> \n<p>The pulses can stimulate targeted neuron areas, providing a type of deep brain stimulation that’s totally non-invasive.</p> \n<p>One of Neuralink’s ground floor members, DJ Seo, led an effort to design an even cooler interface called “<a href=\"https://arxiv.org/abs/1307.2196\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">neural dust</a>.” Neural dust refers to tiny, 100µm silicon sensors (about the same as the width of a hair) that would be sprinkled through the cortex. Right nearby, above the pia, would be a 3mm-sized device that could communicate with the dust sensors via ultrasound.</p> \n<p>This is another example of the innovation benefits that come from an interdisciplinary team. DJ explained to me that “there are technologies that are not really thought about in this domain, but we can bring in some principles of their work.” He says that neural dust is inspired both by microchip technology and RFID (the thing that allows hotel key cards to communicate with the door lock without making physical contact) principles. And you can easily see the multi-field influence in how it works:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-51-6120\" id=\"note2-51-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">51</a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/018u3meqmg2ruijpg.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\" wp-image-6188 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/018u3meqmg2ruijpg.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"519\" height=\"469\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/018u3meqmg2ruijpg.jpg 800w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/018u3meqmg2ruijpg-300x271.jpg 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/018u3meqmg2ruijpg-768x694.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/018u3meqmg2ruijpg-600x542.jpg 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 519px) 100vw, 519px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Others are working on even more out-there ideas, like <strong><a href=\"https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/optogenetics-controlling/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">optogenetics</a></strong> (where you inject a virus that attaches to a brain cell, causing it to thereafter be stimulated by light) or even using <strong><a href=\"http://news.rice.edu/2015/03/25/carbon-nanotube-fibers-make-superior-links-to-brain-2/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">carbon nanotubes</a></strong>—a million of which could be bundled together and sent to the brain via the bloodstream.</p> \n<p>These people are all working on this arrow:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuralink-formula-v2_03.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6449\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuralink-formula-v2_03.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"800\" height=\"551\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuralink-formula-v2_03.png 1800w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuralink-formula-v2_03-300x207.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuralink-formula-v2_03-768x529.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuralink-formula-v2_03-600x413.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuralink-formula-v2_03-103x70.png 103w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" /></a></p> \n<p>It’s a relatively small group right now, but when the breakthrough spark happens, that’ll quickly change. Developments will begin to happen rapidly. Brain interface bandwidth will get better and better as the procedures to implant them become simpler and cheaper. Public interest will pick up. And when public interest picks up, the Human Colossus notices an opportunity—and then the rate of development skyrockets. Just like the breakthroughs in computer hardware caused the software industry to explode, major industries will pop up working on cutting-edge machines and intelligent apps to be used in conjunction with brain interfaces, and you’ll tell some little kid in 2052 all about how when you grew up, no one could do any of the things she can do with her brain, and she’ll be bored.</p> \n<p>I tried to get the Neuralink team to talk about 2052 with me. I wanted to know what life was going to be like once this all became a thing. I wanted to know what went in the [Pilot ACE : iPhone 7 :: Early BMIs : ____] blank. But it wasn’t easy—this was a team built specifically because of their focus on concrete results, not hype, and I was doing the equivalent of talking to people in the late 1700s who were feverishly trying to create a breakthrough steam engine and prodding them about when they thought there would be airplanes.</p> \n<p>But I’d keep pulling teeth until they’d finally talk about their thoughts on the far future to get my hand off their tooth. I also focused a large portion of my talks with Elon on the far future possibilities and had other helpful discussions with Moran Cerf, a neuroscientist friend of mine who <a href=\"http://ed.ted.com/lessons/what-if-we-could-look-inside-human-brains-moran-cerf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">works on BMIs</a> and thinks a lot about the long-term outlook. Finally, one reluctant-to-talk-about-his-predictions Neuralink team member told me that of course, he and his colleagues <em>were</em> dreamers—otherwise they wouldn’t be doing what they’re doing—and that many of them were inspired to get into this industry by science fiction. He recommended I talk to Ramez Naam, writer of the popular <a href=\"http://amzn.to/2pqeLNy\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><em>Nexus Trilogy</em></a>, a series all about the future of BMIs, and also someone with a hard tech background that includes 19 software-related patents. So I had a chat with Ramez to round out the picture and ask him the 435 remaining questions I had about everything.</p> \n<p>And I came out of all of it utterly blown away. I wrote <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2015/01/artificial-intelligence-revolution-1.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">once</a> about how I think if you went back to 1750—a time when there was no electricity or motorized vehicles or telecommunication—and retrieved, say, George Washington, and brought him to today and showed him our world, he’d be so shocked by everything that he’d die. You’d have killed George Washington and messed everything up. Which got me thinking about the concept of how many years one would need to go into the future such that the ensuing shock from the level of progress would kill you. I called it a Die Progress Unit, or DPU.</p> \n<p>Ever since the Human Colossus was born, our world has had a weird property to it—it gets more <em>magical</em> as time goes on. That’s why DPUs are a thing. And because advancement begets more rapid advancement, the trend is that as time passes, the DPUs get <em>shorter</em>. For George Washington, a DPU was a couple hundred years, which is outrageously short in the scheme of human history. But we now live in a time where things are moving <em>so </em>fast that we might experience one or even multiple DPUs <em>in our lifetime</em>. The amount that changed between 1750 and 2017 might happen again between now and another time when you’re still alive. This is a <em>ridiculous</em> time to be alive—it’s just hard for us to notice because we live life so zoomed in.</p> \n<p>Anyway, I think about DPUs a lot and I always wonder what it would feel like to go forward in a time machine and experience what George would experience coming here. What kind of future could blow my mind so hard that it would kill me? We can talk about things like AI and gene editing—and I have no doubt that progress in those areas could make me die of shock—but it’s always, “Who knows what it’ll be like!” Never a descriptive picture.</p> \n<p><a name=\"part5\"></a>I think I might finally have a descriptive picture of a piece of our shocking future. Let me paint it for you.</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 28pt;\"><strong>Part 5: The Wizard Era</strong></span></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-tree-Parts-5.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6439\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-tree-Parts-5.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"238\" height=\"294\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-tree-Parts-5.png 747w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-tree-Parts-5-243x300.png 243w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-tree-Parts-5-487x600.png 487w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 238px) 100vw, 238px\" /></a></p> \n<p>The budding industry of brain-machine interfaces is the seed of a revolution that will change just about everything. But in many ways, the brain-interface future isn’t really a new <em>thing</em> that’s happening. If you take a step back, it looks more like the next big chapter in a trend that’s been going on for a long time. Language took forever to turn into writing, which then took forever to turn into printing, and that’s where things were when George Washington was around. Then came electricity and the pace picked up. Telephone. Radio. Television. Computers. And just like that, everyone’s homes became magical. Then phones became cordless. Then mobile. Computers went from being devices for work and games to windows into a digital world we all became a part of. Then phones and computers merged into an everything device that brought the magic out of our homes and put it into our hands. And on our wrists. We’re now in the early stages of a virtual and augmented reality revolution that will wrap the magic around our eyes and ears and bring our whole being into the digital world.</p> \n<p>You don’t need to be a futurist to see where this is going.</p> \n<p>Magic has worked its way from industrial facilities to our homes to our hands and soon it’ll be around our heads. And then it’ll take the next natural step. The magic is heading into our brains.</p> \n<p>It will happen by way of a “whole-brain interface,” or what I’ve been calling a wizard hat—a brain interface so complete, so smooth, so biocompatible, and so high-bandwidth that it feels as much a part of you as your cortex and limbic system. A whole-brain interface would give your brain the ability to communicate wirelessly with the cloud, with computers, and with the brains of anyone with a similar interface in their head. This flow of information between your brain and the outside world would be so effortless, it would feel similar to the thinking that goes on in your head today. And though we’ve used the term brain-machine interface so far, I kind of think of a BMI as a specific brain interface to be used for a specific purpose, and the term doesn’t quite capture the everything-of-everything concept of the whole-brain interface. So I’ll call that a wizard hat instead.</p> \n<p>Now, to fully absorb the implications of having a wizard hat installed in your head and what that would change about you, you’ll need to wrap your head around (no pun intended) two things:</p> \n<p><strong>1) The intensely <strong>mind-bending</strong> idea</strong></p> \n<p><strong>2) The super ridiculously intensely <strong>mind-bending</strong> idea</strong></p> \n<p>We’ll tackle #1 in this section and save #2 for the last section after you’ve had time to absorb #1.</p> \n<p>Elon calls the whole-brain interface and its many capabilities a “digital tertiary layer,” a term that has two levels of meaning that correspond to our two mind-bending ideas above.</p> \n<p>The first meaning gets at the idea of physical brain parts. We discussed three layers of brain parts—the brain stem (run by the frog), the limbic system (run by the monkey), and the cortex (run by the rational thinker). We were being thorough, but for the rest of this post, we’re going to leave the frog out of the discussion, since he’s entirely functional and lives mostly behind the scenes.</p> \n<p>When Elon refers to a “digital tertiary layer,” he’s considering our existing brain having two layers—our animal limbic system (which could be called our primary layer) and our advanced cortex (which could be called our secondary layer). The wizard hat interface, then, would be our tertiary layer—a new physical brain part to complement the other two.</p> \n<p>If thinking about this concept is giving you the willies, Elon has news for you:</p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><em>We already have a digital tertiary layer in a sense, in that you have your computer or your phone or your applications. You can ask a question via Google and get an answer instantly. You can access any book or any music. With a spreadsheet, you can do incredible calculations. If you had an Empire State building filled with people—even if they had calculators, let alone if they had to do it with a pencil and paper—one person with a laptop could outdo the Empire State Building filled with people with calculators. You can video chat with someone in freaking Timbuktu for free. This would’ve gotten you burnt for witchcraft in the old days. You can record as much video with sound as you want, take a zillion pictures, have them tagged with who they are and when it took place. You can broadcast communications through social media to millions of people simultaneously for free. These are incredible superpowers that the President of the United States didn’t have twenty years ago.</em></p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><em>The thing that people, I think, don’t appreciate right now is that they are already a cyborg. You’re already a different creature than you would have been twenty years ago, or even ten years ago. You’re already a different creature. You can see this when they do surveys of like, “how long do you want to be away from your phone?” and—particularly if you’re a teenager or in your 20s—even a day hurts. If you leave your phone behind, it’s like missing limb syndrome. I think people—they’re already kind of merged with their phone and their laptop and their applications and everything.</em></p> \n<p>This is a hard point to really absorb, because we don’t <em>feel </em>like cyborgs. We feel like humans who use devices to do things. But think about your digital self—you when you’re interacting with someone on the internet or over FaceTime or when you’re in a YouTube video. Digital you is fully you—as much as in-person you is you—right? The only difference is that you’re not there in person—you’re using magic powers to send yourself to somewhere far away, at light speed, through wires and satellites and electromagnetic waves. The difference is the medium.</p> \n<p>Before language, there wasn’t a good way to get a thought from your brain into my brain. Then early humans invented the technology of language, transforming vocal cords and ears into the world’s first communication devices and air as the first communication medium. We use these devices every time we talk to each other in person. It goes:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communication-Flow-1.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"size-full wp-image-6307 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communication-Flow-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"617\" height=\"104\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communication-Flow-1.png 617w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communication-Flow-1-300x51.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communication-Flow-1-600x101.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 617px) 100vw, 617px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Then we built upon that with another leap, inventing a second layer of devices, with its own medium, allowing us to talk long distance:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communication-Flow-2.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6308\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communication-Flow-2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"900\" height=\"69\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communication-Flow-2.png 1322w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communication-Flow-2-300x23.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communication-Flow-2-768x59.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communication-Flow-2-600x46.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Or maybe:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communication-Flow-3.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6309\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communication-Flow-3.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"850\" height=\"66\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communication-Flow-3.png 1242w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communication-Flow-3-300x23.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communication-Flow-3-768x60.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communication-Flow-3-600x47.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 850px) 100vw, 850px\" /></a></p> \n<p>In that sense, your phone is as much “you” as your vocal cords or your ears or your eyes. All of these things are simply tools to move thoughts from brain to brain—so who cares if the tool is held in your hand, your throat, or your eye sockets? The digital age has made us a dual entity—a physical creature who interacts with its physical environment using its biological parts and a digital creature whose digital devices—whose digital <em>parts</em>—allow it to interact with the digital world.</p> \n<p>But because we don’t think of it like that, we’d consider someone with a phone in their head or throat a cyborg and someone else with a phone in their hand, pressed up against their head, not a cyborg. Elon’s point is that the thing that makes a cyborg a cyborg is their capabilities—not from which side of the skull those capabilities are generated.</p> \n<p>We’re already a cyborg, we already have superpowers, and we already spend a huge part of our lives in the digital world. And when you think of it like that, you realize how obvious it is to want to upgrade the medium that connects us to that world. This is the change Elon believes is actually happening when the magic goes into our brains:</p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><em>You’re already digitally superhuman. The thing that would change is the interface—having a high-bandwidth interface to your digital enhancements. The thing is that today, the interface all necks down to this tiny straw, which is, particularly in terms of output, it’s like poking things with your meat sticks, or using words—either speaking or tapping things with fingers. And in fact, output has gone backwards. It used to be, in your most frequent form, output would be ten-finger typing. Now, it’s like, two-thumb typing. </em><em>That’s crazy slow communication. We should be able to improve that by many orders of magnitude with a direct neural interface.</em></p> \n<p class=\"p1\">In other words, putting our technology into our brains isn’t about whether it’s good or bad to become cyborgs. It’s that we <em>are </em>cyborgs and we will <em>continue </em>to be cyborgs—so it probably makes sense to upgrade ourselves from primitive, low-bandwidth cyborgs to modern, high-bandwidth cyborgs.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\">A whole-brain interface is that upgrade. It changes us from creatures whose primary and secondary layers live inside their heads and whose tertiary layer lives in their pocket, in their hand, or on their desk—</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Human-using-computer-1.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6264\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Human-using-computer-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"650\" height=\"477\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Human-using-computer-1.png 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Human-using-computer-1-300x220.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Human-using-computer-1-768x563.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Human-using-computer-1-600x440.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 650px) 100vw, 650px\" /></a></p> \n<p>—to creatures whose three layers all live together.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Human-brain-using-computer.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6457\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Human-brain-using-computer.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"650\" height=\"477\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Human-brain-using-computer.jpg 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Human-brain-using-computer-300x220.jpg 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Human-brain-using-computer-768x563.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Human-brain-using-computer-600x440.jpg 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 650px) 100vw, 650px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Your life is full of devices, including the one you’re currently using to read this. A wizard hat makes your <em>brain </em>into the device, allowing your thoughts to go straight from your head into the digital world.</p> \n<p>Which doesn’t only revolutionize human-<em>computer </em>communication.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\">Right now humans communicate with each other like this:</p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\" wp-image-6275 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-1.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"267\" height=\"437\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-1.jpg 444w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-1-183x300.jpg 183w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-1-366x600.jpg 366w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 267px) 100vw, 267px\" /></a></p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-2.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6417\" href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-14.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6355\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-14.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"350\" height=\"200\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-14.png 700w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-14-300x171.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-14-600x343.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 350px) 100vw, 350px\" /></a></p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-15.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6356\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-15.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"500\" height=\"286\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-15.png 700w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-15-300x171.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-15-600x343.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 500px) 100vw, 500px\" /></a></p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-16.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6357\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-16.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"500\" height=\"286\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-16.png 700w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-16-300x171.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-16-600x343.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 500px) 100vw, 500px\" /></a></p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-17.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6283\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-17.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"500\" height=\"305\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-17.jpg 574w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-17-300x183.jpg 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 500px) 100vw, 500px\" /></a></p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-18.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6284\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-18.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"500\" height=\"305\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-18.jpg 574w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-18-300x183.jpg 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 500px) 100vw, 500px\" /></a></p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-19.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6419\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-19.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"440\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-19.png 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-19-300x220.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-19-768x563.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-19-600x440.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a></p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-20-2.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6472\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-20-2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"440\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-20-2.png 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-20-2-300x220.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-20-2-768x563.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-20-2-600x440.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a></p> \n<p class=\"p1\">And that’s how it’s been ever since we could communicate. But in a wizard hat world, it would look more like this:</p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-1.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\" wp-image-6275 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-1.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"250\" height=\"409\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-1.jpg 444w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-1-183x300.jpg 183w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-1-366x600.jpg 366w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 250px) 100vw, 250px\" /></a></p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-2.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6417\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"440\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-2.png 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-2-300x220.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-2-768x563.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-2-600x440.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a></p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-22.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6287\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-22.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"900\" height=\"292\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-22.jpg 2300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-22-300x97.jpg 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-22-768x249.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-22-600x194.jpg 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px\" /></a></p> \n<p class=\"p1\">Elon always emphasizes bandwidth when he talks about Neuralink’s wizard hat goals. Interface bandwidth allows incoming images to be HD, incoming sound to be hi-fi, and motor movement commands to be tightly controlled—but it’s also a huge factor in communication. If information were a milkshake, bandwidth would be the width of the straw. Today, the bandwidth-of-communication graph looks something like this:</p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><strong><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communication-Speed-GRAPH-1.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6312\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communication-Speed-GRAPH-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"700\" height=\"523\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communication-Speed-GRAPH-1.png 1548w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communication-Speed-GRAPH-1-300x224.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communication-Speed-GRAPH-1-768x574.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communication-Speed-GRAPH-1-600x448.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px\" /></a></strong></p> \n<p class=\"p1\">So computers can suck up the milkshake through a giant pipe, a human thinking would be using a large, pleasant-to-use straw, while language would be a frustratingly tiny coffee stirrer straw and typing (let alone texting) would be like trying to drink a milkshake through a syringe needle—you might be able to get a drop out once a minute.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\">Moran Cerf has gathered data on the actual bandwidth of different parts of the nervous system and on this graph, he compares them to equivalent bandwidths in the computer world:</p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2017/04/neuralink.html/bandwidth-v2\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6499\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/Bandwidth-v2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"800\" height=\"556\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/Bandwidth-v2.png 1457w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/Bandwidth-v2-300x208.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/Bandwidth-v2-768x533.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/Bandwidth-v2-600x417.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" /></a></p> \n<p class=\"p1\">You can see here on Moran’s graph that the disparity in bandwidth between the ways we communicate and our thinking (which is at 30 bits/second on this graph) is even starker than my graph above depicts.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\">But making our brains the device cuts out those tiny straws, turning all of these:</p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communication-Flow-ALL.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6310\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communication-Flow-ALL.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"900\" height=\"304\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communication-Flow-ALL.png 1358w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communication-Flow-ALL-300x101.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communication-Flow-ALL-768x259.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communication-Flow-ALL-600x202.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px\" /></a></p> \n<p>To this:</p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communication-Flow-Condensed.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\" wp-image-6311 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communication-Flow-Condensed.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"183\" height=\"59\" /></a></p> \n<p class=\"p1\">Which preserves all the meaning with none of the fuss—and changes the graph to this:</p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communication-Speed-GRAPH-2.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6313\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communication-Speed-GRAPH-2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"700\" height=\"523\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communication-Speed-GRAPH-2.png 1548w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communication-Speed-GRAPH-2-300x224.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communication-Speed-GRAPH-2-768x574.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communication-Speed-GRAPH-2-600x448.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px\" /></a></p> \n<p class=\"p1\">We’d still be using straws, but <em>far </em>bigger, more effective ones.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\">But it’s not just about the speed of communication. As Elon points out, it’s about the <em>nuance </em>and <em>accuracy</em> of communication as well:</p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><em>There are a bunch of concepts in your head that then your brain has to try to compress into this incredibly low data rate called speech or typing. That’s what language is—your brain has executed a compression algorithm on thought, on concept transfer. And then it’s got to listen as well, and decompress what’s coming at it. And this is very lossy as well. So, then when you’re doing the decompression on those, trying to understand, you’re simultaneously trying to model the other person’s mind state to understand where they’re coming from, to recombine in your head what concepts they have in their head that they’re trying to communicate to you. … If you have two brain interfaces, you could actually do an uncompressed direct conceptual communication with another person.</em></p> \n<p class=\"p1\">This makes sense—nuance is like a <em>high-resolution thought</em>, which makes the file simply too big to transfer quickly through a coffee straw. The coffee straw gives you two bad options when it comes to nuance: take a <em>lot </em>of time saying a lot of words to really depict the nuanced thought or imagery you want to convey to me, or save time by using succinct language—but inevitably fail to transfer over the nuance. Compounding the effect is the fact that language itself is a low-resolution medium. A word is simply an <em>approximation</em> of a thought—buckets that a whole category of similar-but-distinct thoughts can all be shoved into. If I watch a horror movie and want to describe it to you in words, I’m stuck with a few simple low-res buckets—“scary” or “creepy” or “chilling” or “intense.” My actual impression of that movie is very specific and not exactly like any other movie I’ve seen—but the crude tools of language force my brain to “round to the nearest bucket” and choose the word that most closely resembles my actual impression, and that’s the information you’ll receive from me. You won’t receive the thought—you’ll receive the <em>bucket</em>—and now you’ll have to guess which of the <em>many </em>nuanced impressions that all approximate to that bucket is the most similar to my impression of the movie. You’ll decompress my description—“scary as shit”—into a high-res, nuanced thought that <em>you </em>associate with “scary as shit,” which will inevitably be based on your own experience watching other horror movies, and your own personality. The end result is that a lot has been lost in translation—which is exactly what you’d expect when you try to transfer a high-res file over a low-bandwidth medium, quickly, using low-res tools. That’s why Elon calls language data transfer “lossy.”</p> \n<p class=\"p1\">We do the best we can with these limitations—and over time, we’ve supplemented language with slightly higher-resolution formats like video to better convey nuanced imagery, or music to better convey nuanced emotion. But compared to the richness and uniqueness of the ideas in our heads, and the large-bandwidth straw our internal <em>thoughts</em> flow through, all human-to-human communication is very lossy.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\">Thinking about the phenomenon of communication as what it is—brains trying to share things with each other—you see the history of communication not as this:</p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communcation-Hacks-1.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\" wp-image-6305 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communcation-Hacks-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"405\" height=\"577\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communcation-Hacks-1.png 592w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communcation-Hacks-1-211x300.png 211w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communcation-Hacks-1-421x600.png 421w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 405px) 100vw, 405px\" /></a></p> \n<p class=\"p1\">As much as this:</p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communcation-Hacks-2.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\" wp-image-6306 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communcation-Hacks-2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"424\" height=\"294\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communcation-Hacks-2.png 592w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communcation-Hacks-2-300x208.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communcation-Hacks-2-103x70.png 103w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 424px) 100vw, 424px\" /></a></p> \n<p class=\"p1\">Or it could be put this way:</p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communcation-Hacks-3.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6465\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communcation-Hacks-3.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"424\" height=\"294\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communcation-Hacks-3.png 592w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communcation-Hacks-3-300x208.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communcation-Hacks-3-103x70.png 103w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 424px) 100vw, 424px\" /></a></p> \n<p class=\"p1\">It really may be that the second major era of communication—the 100,000-year Era of Indirect Communication—is in its very last moments. If we zoom out on the timeline, it’s possible the entire last 150 years, during which we’ve suddenly been <em>rapidly </em>improving our communication media, will look to far-future humans like one concept: the transition from Era 2 to Era 3. We might be living <em>on </em>the line that divides timeline sections.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communications-hacks-timeline.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6464\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communications-hacks-timeline.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"748\" height=\"273\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communications-hacks-timeline.png 1545w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communications-hacks-timeline-300x109.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communications-hacks-timeline-768x280.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Communications-hacks-timeline-600x219.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 748px) 100vw, 748px\" /></a></p> \n<p class=\"p1\">And because indirect communication requires third-party body parts or digital parts, the end of Era 2 may be looked back upon as the era of physical devices. In an era where your brain is the device, there will be no need to carry anything around. You’ll have your body and, if you want, clothes—and that’s it.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\">When Elon thinks about wizard hats, this is usually the stuff he’s thinking about—communication bandwidth and resolution. And we’ll explore why in Part 6 of this post.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\">First, let’s dig into the mind-boggling concept of your brain becoming a device and talk about what a wizard hat world might be like.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">___________</p> \n<p class=\"p1\">One thing to keep in mind as we think about all of this is that none of it will take you by surprise. You won’t go from having nothing in your brain to a digital tertiary layer in your head, just like people didn’t go from the Apple IIGS to using Tinder overnight. The Wizard Era will come gradually, and by the time the shift actually begins to happen, we’ll all be very used to the technology, and it’ll seem normal.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\">Supporting this point is the fact the staircase up to the Wizard Era has already started, and you haven’t even noticed. But there are thousands of people currently walking around with electrodes in their brain, like those with cochlear implants, retinal implants, and deep brain implants—all benefiting from early BMIs.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\">The next few steps on the staircase will continue to focus on restoring lost function in different parts of the body—the first people to have their lives transformed by digital brain technology will be the disabled. As specialized BMIs serve more and more forms of disability, the concept of brain implants will work its way in from the fringes and become something we’re all used to—just like no one blinks an eye when you say your friend just got Lasik surgery or your grandmother just got a pacemaker installed.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\">Elon talks about some types of people early BMIs could help:</p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><em>The first use of the technology will be to repair brain injuries as a result of stroke or cutting out a cancer lesion, where somebody’s fundamentally lost a certain cognitive element. It could help with people who are quadriplegics or paraplegics by providing a neural shunt from the motor cortex down to where the muscles are activated. It can help with people who, as they get older, have memory problems and can’t remember the names of their kids, through memory enhancement, which could allow them to function well to a much later time in life—the medically advantageous elements of this for dealing with mental disablement of one kind or another, which of course happens to all of us when we get old enough, are very significant.</em></p> \n<p class=\"p1\">As someone who lost a grandfather to dementia five years before losing him to death, I’m excited to hear this.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\">And as interface bandwidth improves, disabilities that hinder millions today will start to drop like flies. The concepts of complete blindness and deafness—whether centered in the sensory organs or in the brain<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote-31-6120\" id=\"note-31-6120\" rel=\"footnote\">31</a>—are already on the way out. And with enough time, perfect vision or hearing will be restorable.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\">Prosthetic limbs—and eventually sleek, full-body exoskeletons underneath your clothes—will work so well, providing both outgoing motor functions and an incoming sense of touch, that paralysis or amputations will only have a minor long-term effect on people’s lives.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\">In Alzheimer’s patients, memories themselves are often not lost—only the bridge to those memories. Advanced BMIs could help restore that bridge or serve as a new one.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\">While this is happening, BMIs will begin to emerge that people <em>without</em> disabilities want. The very early adopters will probably be pretty rich. But so were the early cell phone adopters.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#footnote2-52-6120\" id=\"note2-52-6120\" rel=\"footnote2\">52</a></p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/gordon-gekko-RS.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\" wp-image-6189 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/gordon-gekko-RS.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"308\" height=\"308\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/gordon-gekko-RS.jpg 405w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/gordon-gekko-RS-150x150.jpg 150w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/gordon-gekko-RS-300x300.jpg 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 308px) 100vw, 308px\" /></a></p> \n<p class=\"p1\">That’s Gordon Gekko, and that 1983, two-pound cell phone cost almost <a href=\"http://www.slate.com/blogs/browbeat/2010/09/23/gordon_gekko_s_cell_phone.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">$9,000</a> in today’s dollars. And now over half of living humans own a mobile phone—all of them far less shitty than Gordon Gekko’s.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\">As mobile phones got cheaper, and better, they went from new and fancy and futuristic to ubiquitous. As we go down the same road with brain interfaces, things are going to get <em>really </em>cool.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\">Based on what I learned from my conversations with Elon, Ramez, and a dozen neuroscientists, let’s look at what the world might look like in a few decades. The timeline is uncertain, including the order in which the below developments may become a reality. And, of course, some of the below predictions are sure to be way off the mark, just as there will be other developments in this field that won’t be mentioned here because people today literally can’t imagine them yet.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\">But some version of a lot of this stuff probably<em> will</em> happen, at <em>some </em>point, and a lot of it could be in your lifetime.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\">Looking at all the predictions I heard, they seemed to fall into two broad categories: communication capabilities and internal enhancements.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><span style=\"font-size: 20pt;\"><strong>The Wizard Era: Communication</strong></span></p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Wizard-Communication-Heading.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6473\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Wizard-Communication-Heading.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"400\" height=\"439\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Wizard-Communication-Heading.png 818w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Wizard-Communication-Heading-273x300.png 273w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Wizard-Communication-Heading-768x843.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Wizard-Communication-Heading-547x600.png 547w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 400px) 100vw, 400px\" /></a></p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><span style=\"font-size: 16pt;\"><strong>Motor communication</strong></span></p> \n<p class=\"p1\">“Communication” in this section can mean human-to-human or human-to-computer. Motor communication is all about human-to-computer—the whole “motor cortex as remote control” thing from earlier, but now the unbelievably rad version.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\">Like many future categories of brain interface possibility, motor communication will start with restoration applications for the disabled, and as those development efforts continually advance the possibilities, the technology will begin to be used to create <em>augmentation </em>applications for the non-disabled as well. The same technologies that will allow a quadriplegic to use their thoughts as a remote control to move a bionic limb can let anyone use their thoughts as a remote control…to move anything. Well not <em>anything—</em>I’m not talking about telekinesis—anything built to be used with a brain remote. But in the Wizard Era, <em>lots </em>of things will be built that way.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\">Your car (or whatever people use for transportation at that point) will pull up to your house and your mind will open the car door. You’ll walk up to the house and your mind will unlock and open the front door (all doors at that point will be built with sensors to receive motor cortex commands). You’ll think about wanting coffee and the coffee maker will get that going. As you head to the fridge the door will open and after getting what you need it’ll close as you walk away. When it’s time for bed, you’ll decide you want the heat turned down and the lights turned off, and those systems will feel you make that decision and adjust themselves.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\">None of this stuff will take any effort or thought—we’ll all get very good at it and it’ll feel as automatic and subconscious as moving your eyes to read this sentence does to you now.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\">People will play the piano with their thoughts. And do building construction. And steer vehicles. In fact, today, if you’re driving somewhere and something jumps out in the road in front of you, what neuroscientists know is that your brain sees it and begins to react well before your consciousness knows what’s going on or your arms move to steer out of the way. But when your brain is the one steering the car, you’ll have swerved out of the way before you even realize what happened.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><span style=\"font-size: 16pt;\"><strong>Thought communication</strong></span></p> \n<p class=\"p1\">This is what we discussed up above—but you have to resist the natural instinct to equate a thought conversation with a normal language conversation where you simply hear each other’s voices in your head. As we discussed, words are compressed approximations of uncompressed thoughts, so why would you ever bother with any of that, or deal with lossiness, if you didn’t have to? When you watch a movie, your head is buzzing with thoughts—but do you have a compressed spoken word dialogue going on in your head? Probably not—you’re just <em>thinking</em>. Thought conversations will be like <em>that</em>.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\">Elon says:</p> \n<p class=\"p1\"><em>If I were to communicate a concept to you, you would essentially engage in consensual telepathy. You wouldn’t need to verbalize unless you want to add a little flair to the conversation or something (laughs), but the conversation would be conceptual interaction on a level that’s difficult to conceive of right now.</em></p> \n<p class=\"p1\">That’s the thing—it’s difficult to really understand what it would be like to <em>think </em>with someone. We’ve never been able to try. We communicate with ourselves through thought and with everyone else through symbolic representations of thought, and that’s all we can imagine.</p> \n<p class=\"p1\">Even weirder is the concept of a <em>group </em>thinking together. This is what a group brainstorm could look like in the Wizard Era.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/thinking-brainstorm-1.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6359\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/thinking-brainstorm-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"500\" height=\"339\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/thinking-brainstorm-1.png 1246w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/thinking-brainstorm-1-300x203.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/thinking-brainstorm-1-768x521.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/thinking-brainstorm-1-600x407.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/thinking-brainstorm-1-782x530.png 782w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/thinking-brainstorm-1-345x234.png 345w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/thinking-brainstorm-1-103x70.png 103w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 500px) 100vw, 500px\" /></a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/thinking-brainstorm-2.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6360\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/thinking-brainstorm-2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"500\" height=\"327\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/thinking-brainstorm-2.png 1289w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/thinking-brainstorm-2-300x196.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/thinking-brainstorm-2-768x502.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/thinking-brainstorm-2-600x392.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 500px) 100vw, 500px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/thinking-brainstorm-3.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6361\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/thinking-brainstorm-3.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"500\" height=\"318\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/thinking-brainstorm-3.png 1330w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/thinking-brainstorm-3-300x191.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/thinking-brainstorm-3-768x489.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/thinking-brainstorm-3-600x382.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 500px) 100vw, 500px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/thinking-brainstorm-4.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6362\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/thinking-brainstorm-4.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"500\" height=\"341\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/thinking-brainstorm-4.png 1231w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/thinking-brainstorm-4-300x204.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/thinking-brainstorm-4-768x523.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/thinking-brainstorm-4-600x409.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/thinking-brainstorm-4-345x234.png 345w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/thinking-brainstorm-4-103x70.png 103w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 500px) 100vw, 500px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/thinking-brainstorm-5.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6363\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/thinking-brainstorm-5.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"500\" height=\"330\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/thinking-brainstorm-5.png 1292w,
