I’ll put some of the best not-that-related nuggets I found into footnotes.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#note-5-6120\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n  <!--/#footnote-5.footnote-->\n  <li id=\"footnote-6-6120\" class=\"footnote\"><p>The skull is only about 6.5mm thick in women and 7.1mm in men—like a quarter-inch. I thought it was thicker than that.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#note-6-6120\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n  <!--/#footnote-6.footnote-->\n  <li id=\"footnote-7-6120\" class=\"footnote\"><p>Delightful/upsetting tidbit: your eyes are connected directly to the brain by nerves and muscle fibers. So if you opened someone’s head and took out their brain, what would come out is their brain, their spinal cord (attached to the bottom)—and their dangling eyes.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#note-7-6120\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n  <!--/#footnote-7.footnote-->\n  <li id=\"footnote-8-6120\" class=\"footnote\"><p>One thing I learned from that video is that the two hard bumps on the lower part of the back of your head, just above your neck, are the indents in the skull where the two lobes of the cerebellum sit—so that’s right where your cerebellum is.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#note-8-6120\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n  <!--/#footnote-8.footnote-->\n  <li id=\"footnote-9-6120\" class=\"footnote\"><p>To add to the difficulties, as humans evolved, they became bipedal (upright on two legs), which reduced the size of the female pelvis (otherwise women wouldn’t have been able to run). Evolution pulled a cool trick to reconcile the situation—babies started being born while they were still fetuses. This is why newborns look like Winston Churchill for the first month or so before they become cute—they’re really supposed to still be in the womb. It’s also why newborn babies are so incredibly helpless at first.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#note-9-6120\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n  <!--/#footnote-9.footnote-->\n  <li id=\"footnote-10-6120\" class=\"footnote\"><p>That’s enough surface area, that even at only 2mm thick, the cortex has a volume of 400-500cm<sup>3</sup>, over a third of the total volume of the brain, and about the same volume as a softball.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#note-10-6120\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n  <!--/#footnote-10.footnote-->\n  <li id=\"footnote-11-6120\" class=\"footnote\"><p>Another scientist, Santiago Ramón y Cajal, made the official discovery 15 years later.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#note-11-6120\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n  <!--/#footnote-11.footnote-->\n  <li id=\"footnote-12-6120\" class=\"footnote\"><p>Not <em>quite </em>touching actually—there’s about a 20-40nm gap in between.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#note-12-6120\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n  <!--/#footnote-12.footnote-->\n  <li id=\"footnote-13-6120\" class=\"footnote\"><p>The often-discussed dopamine and serotonin are both neurotransmitters.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#note-13-6120\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n  <!--/#footnote-13.footnote-->\n  <li id=\"footnote-14-6120\" class=\"footnote\"><p>Multiple sclerosis is caused by a glitch in the body’s immune system that causes it to destroy the myelin sheaths of neurons, which as you can see from the GIF below, would seriously disrupt the body’s ability to communicate with itself. ALD, the disease in <em>Lorenzo’s Oil</em>, is also caused by myelin being destroyed.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#note-14-6120\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n  <!--/#footnote-14.footnote-->\n  <li id=\"footnote-15-6120\" class=\"footnote\"><p>Via the world’s greatest procrastination site, <a href=\"http://Kottke.org\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Kottke.org</a><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#note-15-6120\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n  <!--/#footnote-15.footnote-->\n  <li id=\"footnote-16-6120\" class=\"footnote\"><p>Tidbit: A neurosurgeon explained to me how a knockout punch works. Gray and white matter have different densities. So when your head is punched hard, or you get a really bad concussion, what can happen if your head snaps back and forth really sharply is that the gray and white matter accelerate at different velocities, which can make the gray matter of your cortex slide a bit over the white matter, or the white matter slide a bit over the gray matter of the brain stem. In the latter case, for a brief moment, your cortex is separated from being able to communicate with your brainstem. And since your consciousness resides in the brain stem, it makes you go unconscious. When either type of sliding happens, it can tear a bunch of axons. In a minor axon tear where the myelin sheath is still intact, the axon can grow back and heal. But if it’s a sharp enough blow, the myelin sheaths can tear too and the axons will never grow back—permanent brain damage. Concussions are really, really bad. This is also why an uppercut to the bottom of the chin or a blow to the back of the head can cause loss of consciousness—because those blows make the head snap back and forth sharply—while a punch to the side of the head or to the forehead won’t cause loss of consciousness.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#note-16-6120\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n  <!--/#footnote-16.footnote-->\n  <li id=\"footnote-17-6120\" class=\"footnote\"><p>If our stick guy neuron were one of those sensory neurons, drawn to scale, his torso-axon would have been about a kilometer long.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#note-17-6120\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n  <!--/#footnote-17.footnote-->\n  <li id=\"footnote-18-6120\" class=\"footnote\"><p>Sometimes, like when you step on a nail or touch a hot stove, the sensory axons will communicate with relevant motor neurons directly in the spinal cord to create an immediate reflex to pull your foot or hand away. This is called a “reflex arc.”<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#note-18-6120\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n  <!--/#footnote-18.footnote-->\n  <li id=\"footnote-19-6120\" class=\"footnote\"><p>It really feels like the plural of soma should be soma.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#note-19-6120\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n  <!--/#footnote-19.footnote-->\n  <li id=\"footnote-20-6120\" class=\"footnote\"><p>The science world used to believe there were as many as <em>ten </em>times the number of glial cells as neurons in the brain, but that number has come down with <a href=\"https://blogs.scientificamerican.com/brainwaves/know-your-neurons-what-is-the-ratio-of-glia-to-neurons-in-the-brain/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">more recent research.</a><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#note-20-6120\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n  <!--/#footnote-20.footnote-->\n  <li id=\"footnote-21-6120\" class=\"footnote\"><p>Here’s a <a href=\"http://kottke.org/17/03/a-neuroscientist-explains-a-concept-at-five-different-levels\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">silly video</a> of a scientist explaining what a connectome is five times, to five people of all different levels.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#note-21-6120\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n  <!--/#footnote-21.footnote-->\n  <li id=\"footnote-22-6120\" class=\"footnote\"><p>Really tiny—1/100th the diameter of a human hair. Here’s a <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2vI4fCsVdXc\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">delightful video</a> of one being made.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#note-22-6120\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n  <!--/#footnote-22.footnote-->\n  <li id=\"footnote-23-6120\" class=\"footnote\"><p>I’m not the one making this sexual. The patch clamp is making it sexual.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#note-23-6120\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n  <!--/#footnote-23.footnote-->\n  <li id=\"footnote-24-6120\" class=\"footnote\"><p>Researcher Andrew Schwartz <a href=\"https://www.technologyreview.com/s/528141/the-thought-experiment/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">compares</a> the number of electrodes used to a political poll, and says “the more neurons you poll, the better the result.”<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#note-24-6120\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n  <!--/#footnote-24.footnote-->\n  <li id=\"footnote-25-6120\" class=\"footnote\"><p>Though some in the BMI industry found this <a href=\"https://vimeo.com/98187386\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">less than impressive</a>.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#note-25-6120\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n  <!--/#footnote-25.footnote-->\n  <li id=\"footnote-26-6120\" class=\"footnote\"><p>Full Wait But Why explainer on sound <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2016/03/sound.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">here</a>.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#note-26-6120\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n  <!--/#footnote-26.footnote-->\n  <li id=\"footnote-27-6120\" class=\"footnote\"><p>Through using a few sound engineering tricks, cochlear implant developers have allowed 16 electrodes to actually function as if there were seven additional electrodes in between each pair, bringing the total effect to the equivalent 121 electrodes.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#note-27-6120\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n  <!--/#footnote-27.footnote-->\n  <li id=\"footnote-28-6120\" class=\"footnote\"><p>This is a <a href=\"https://www.wired.com/2005/11/bolero/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">super interesting firsthand account</a> of the experience of getting the implant.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#note-28-6120\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n  <!--/#footnote-28.footnote-->\n  <li id=\"footnote-29-6120\" class=\"footnote\"><p>One neuroscientist talked about putting devices into gaps formerly occupied by blood vessels, making the brain think the device is a blood vessel.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#note-29-6120\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n  <!--/#footnote-29.footnote-->\n  <li id=\"footnote-30-6120\" class=\"footnote\"><p>DARPA seems to be the source of a good amount of controversy. I haven’t dug into it myself, but for what it’s worth, every expert I talked to feels that DARPA is an important piece of the puzzle and is working almost entirely on projects intended to help wounded veterans.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#note-30-6120\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n  <!--/#footnote-30.footnote-->\n  <li id=\"footnote-31-6120\" class=\"footnote\"><p>The retinal implants we talked about are for people whose eyes are damaged. But blindness can take place in the brain for many people. <a href=\"https://www.wired.com/2002/09/vision/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Early work is being done</a> for this type of blindness, which involves working directly with a patient’s visual cortex.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#note-31-6120\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n  <!--/#footnote-31.footnote-->\n  <li id=\"footnote-32-6120\" class=\"footnote\"><p>Tidbit: While dogs and cats can both hear pitches beyond the human ear’s high end (hence the concept of dog whistles), apparently neither animal can hear things as low as humans—including the lowest seven keys on the piano. I only read this—people with dogs and cats and pianos should test this out.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#note-32-6120\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n  <!--/#footnote-32.footnote-->\n  <li id=\"footnote-33-6120\" class=\"footnote\"><p>Your pain pathways could be rerouted to the cloud—to your medical AI—which would either make the repairs itself by stimulating the right patterns of neurons to command some kind of repair within your body, or order the necessary medicine to be delivered to you with instructions. If you injured something like your ankle and it was important for you to keep your weight off of it, your brain could remind you of that in a lot of ways—a sound alert, another type of feeling sensation, etc.—none of which would <em>hurt</em>.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#note-33-6120\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n  <!--/#footnote-33.footnote-->\n  <li id=\"footnote-34-6120\" class=\"footnote\"><p>Classic example: the <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2014/05/fermi-paradox.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Fermi Paradox</a><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#note-34-6120\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n  <!--/#footnote-34.footnote-->\n  <li id=\"footnote-35-6120\" class=\"footnote\"><p>He added, “Or what appears to be reality” to the end of that quote. But let’s leave that can of worms for another time.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#note-35-6120\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n  <!--/#footnote-35.footnote-->\n </ol>\n</div>\n<!--/#footnotes-->\n<div class=\"footnotes2\">\n <hr />\n <ol>\n  <li id=\"footnote2-1-6120\" class=\"footnote2\"><p><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metcalfe's_law#/media/File:Metcalfe-Network-Effect.svg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Wikimedia Commons</a>.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#note2-1-6120\" class=\"footnote2-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n  <!--/#footnote2-1.footnote-->\n  <li id=\"footnote2-2-6120\" class=\"footnote2\"><p><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Printing_press#Printing_capacity\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Wikipedia</a>. Yup, this is the second time I’m referencing Wikipedia. I feel like the whole “It’s incredibly unprofessional and irresponsible to reference Wikipedia” thing is kind of outdated? At least for things like historical printed-words-per-hour data? I’m pretty sure you agree that it’s fine. Good.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6120#note2-2-6120\" class=\"footnote2-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n  <!--/#footnote2-2.footnote-->\n  <li id=\"footnote2-3-6120\" class=\"footnote2\"><p><a class=\"footnote2-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n  <!--/#footnote2-3.footnote-->\n  <li id=\"footnote2-4-6120\" class=\"footnote2\"><p><a href=\"http://vanat.cvm.umn.edu/neurHistAtls/pages/men1.html\" lking-6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn59@2020_4/2020/08/16/19-24-06-115_bd03f61de77bca42.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-7.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn20@2020_1/2020/08/16/19-23-57-136_888c77c1286eb285.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-8-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn52@2020_1/2020/08/16/19-24-26-006_669f27def2850a51.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-9.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn80@2020_3/2020/08/16/19-24-01-941_9ff30b2c352369ff.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-10-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx17/cdn79@2020_4/2020/08/16/19-24-18-818_a00b5ea8d41e1c8e.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-11-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn40@2020_5/2020/08/16/19-24-06-836_b173d81bb6861d8d.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-12.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn31@2020_6/2020/08/16/19-24-14-447_9b5a99c538c9d105.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-14.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn7@2020_2/2020/08/16/19-24-25-628_cc4cdf18a4398c8c.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-15.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn3@2020_4/2020/08/16/19-23-59-729_562ad8680e81b885.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-16.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn32@2020_1/2020/08/16/19-24-00-548_2bf2d426b428d59d.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-17.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn59@2020_3/2020/08/16/19-24-25-116_f0b9df6d91bee265.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Talking-18.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn32@2020_5/2020/08/16/19-24-26-483_415ffb420ae49622.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads dn19@2020_5/2020/08/16/19-24-20-984_8222aea1173d8835.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Brain-tree-Parts-6.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn48@2020_5/2020/08/16/19-23-59-592_5533da70931f2f05.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Exoplanets.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx20/cdn91@2020_4/2020/08/16/19-24-09-490_53f9877f90644092.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Exoplanet-4.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn40@2020_4/2020/08/16/19-24-09-975_e667ae8093d3c75e.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Computer-Colossus-tinker.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn56@2020_6/2020/08/16/19-24-18-894_2fec4315ec825773.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Human-brain-using-computer-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn24@2020_6/2020/08/16/19-24-16-970_4d33d0008070b977.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Neuralink-formula-5-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn48@2020_5/2020/08/16/19-24-10-401_c47dcfd61c3b27ba.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Human-Colossus-with-hat-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn31@2020_4/2020/08/16/19-24-05-000_db87343d59a4a9c5.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-08-17 03:23:54","updatedTime":"2020-08-17 03:23:54","title":"A Sick Giant","link":"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757","description":"<p style=\"font-size:18px\"><em>This is Chapter 10 in a blog series. If you’re new to the series, visit the </em><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/story-of-us\"><strong><em>series home page</em></strong></a><em> for the full table of contents.</em></p> \n<p><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-7518\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Notes-Key-v2.png\" alt=\"Notes key: Type 1 - fun notes. Fun facts, extra thoughts, or further explanation. Type 2 - less fun notes. Sources and citations.\" width=\"392\" height=\"123\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Notes-Key-v2.png 850w, class=\"has-text-align-center wbwFont\">Part 5: A Dangerous Trend</p> \n<div style=\"height:38px\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"wp-block-spacer\"></div> \n<p class=\"has-text-align-center\"><em>“The gentle downward slope gets steeper and imperceptibly becomes an abyss.” –&nbsp;</em>Tomas Tranströmer</p> \n<div style=\"height:38px\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"wp-block-spacer\"></div> \n<p style=\"font-size:19px\" class=\"has-text-align-center wbwFont\"><strong>Chapter 10: A Sick Giant</strong></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/FEATURE-in-post.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8843\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/FEATURE-in-post.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"400\" height=\"211\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/FEATURE-in-post.png 1424w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/FEATURE-in-post-600x316.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/FEATURE-in-post-768x405.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/FEATURE-in-post-750x396.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 400px) 100vw, 400px\" /></a></p> \n<p>In the introduction to this series, I said:</p> \n<p><em>Part of what I’ve spent three years working on is a new language we can use to think and talk about our societies and the people inside of them…full of new terms and metaphors and, of course, lots and lots of badly drawn pictures. It all amounts to a new lens. Looking through this lens out at the world, and inward at myself, things make more sense to me now. … In the early parts of the series, we’ll get familiar with the new lens, and as the series moves on, we’ll start using the lens to look at all of those topics a sane blogger isn’t supposed to write about. If I can do my job well, by the end of the journey, everything will make more sense to you too. There’s a pretty worrisome trend happening in many of our societies right now, but I’m pretty sure that if we can just see it all with clear eyes, we can fix it.</em></p> \n<p>Nine chapters later, here we are. There are a few new terms and visuals still to come, but for the most part, we now have our lens.</p> \n<p>At the heart of the lens is the notion of “seeing in 3D,” which involves two ideas:</p> \n<p><strong><span style=\"font-size: 18px;\">1) Seeing in 2D.</span></strong> Getting to know what I see as the core human struggle: the tension between our genes’ will to survive—a primal flame that burns brightly in everyone—and the human capacity to override that flame when it makes sense to do so, with rationality, self-awareness, and wisdom. I personify this tension with two characters—the Primitive Mind and the Higher Mind—whose struggle for control is a bit like a tug-of-war. Seeing in 2D means learning to consider this tug-of-war when thinking about anything human: ourselves and others, our interactions, our communities and societies and our politics, our personal and collective histories, and our prospects for the future.</p> \n<p><strong><span style=\"font-size: 18px;\">2) Seeing in 3D.</span></strong> Remembering to remember not only the Psych Spectrum tug-of-war but also <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/1.2-emergence-tower-comparison.png\">Emergence Tower</a>. Ants are cells in a giant colony “organism.” Polar bears are individual organisms in themselves. Humans are weird because we can be like ants sometimes and polar bears other times<em>, </em>making the human species kind of like a <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fractal\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">fractal</a>. The individual human is an organism, but in many ways so is a human community, and even a whole society. The reason I see humanity like a fractal is that these different-order organisms are similar in a lot of ways. Namely, I see them as all enduring the same 2D struggle. I freely alternate between psychology and sociology in this series, because in 3D, it’s all one big multi-tiered system. Psychology is just a microcosm of sociology. And sociology is higher-emergence psychology—it’s the psychology of giants.</p> \n<p>Putting the two ideas together, it’s as if the tug-of-war is itself a fractal that scales up and down. There’s a tug-of-war in every human’s head, as we struggle for self-control and try our best to think and behave wisely. That same tug-of-war takes place on a macro scale in large and small groups of humans. When couples, communities, and societies let control of the rope slip towards the Primitive Mind, they end up playing out an ancient pre-programmed skit, falling into what I call the <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/09/stories.html#cudgel\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Power Games</a>—the most primitive format of human interaction, where the only rule is: “Everyone can do whatever they want, if they have the power to pull it off.” When their collective Higher Minds regain an edge, they’re able to live within a wiser and more grown-up structure made up of consciously chosen principles. Tug-of-war shifts are also contagious. The state of each person’s tug-of-war influences both the psychology of the people around them and the collective tug-of-war of groups the person is a part of. In turn, shifts in a society’s collective mindset exert a pull on the communities and individuals within it.</p> \n<p>Which brings us to the next part of what I said in the series intro: the worrisome trend.</p> \n<p>I’ve alluded to the trend a few times in the series so far, but I didn’t want to get fully into it until our lens had been sufficiently developed. My hope is that the lens can A) help me get my point across, and B) help us all see a baggage-laden story with fresh eyes and communicate about it with fresh words. Clarity is the name of the game—if we can see a bad trend for what it is and why it is, we can put our efforts toward reversing it. If we can’t, we’ll unwittingly perpetuate it.</p> \n<p>Blogging about current events is a bad idea. It’s less fun than blogging about rockets or cryonics or Panic Monsters and much more likely to make people mad at you. But this is too important, with stakes too high, not to talk about. The fact that there are such strong social incentives to avoid the topic is itself a huge part of the problem and why it’s particularly important to talk about. For the rest of this series (this chapter and two more), we’ll discuss the worrisome trend I think is happening, the consequences at play, and how I think we can work toward changing our trajectory.</p> \n<p style=\"font-size:26px\"><strong>Sliding Downward</strong></p> \n<p>The tug-of-war in our heads ebbs and flows on a day-to-day and hour-to-hour basis. You wake up feeling fine until you log onto Twitter—i.e. Primitive Mind land—where exposure to all the low-rung-ness jolts your Primitive Mind awake, dragging your psyche downward. You head to work, which let’s say is a place with a generally high-minded, grown-up culture, and it elevates your psyche a bit. While at work, you pick up a call from your mom, who makes a subtle jab about the career path she wishes you weren’t on, which infuriates you and leaves you finishing the call sounding like a 16-year-old, lower on the Psych Spectrum than you were a few minutes ago. A minute later, with your Primitive Mind now all riled up, you snap at your boyfriend in a text conversation, only to apologize a few hours later, when the tug-of-war in your head has come back up to its default position.</p> \n<p>If there were Fitbits that could track Psych Spectrum levels, we’d each see that we have our own graph.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/1.1-wave.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8760 size-large\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/1.1-wave-750x544.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"544\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/1.1-wave-750x544.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/1.1-wave-600x435.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/1.1-wave-768x557.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/1.1-wave.png 1236w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> \n<div class=\"wbwAside\"> \n <h3><strong>The While We’re Here, My Recent Airplane Story Blue Box</strong></h3> \n <p>I recently engaged in a fun, joint Psych Spectrum roller coaster with a stranger on an airplane. We were on the runway, getting ready to take off, and I was doing my typical “I know the flight attendant said to turn all phones onto airplane mode but the whole policy is really quite inane so I’m just gonna keep texting until we take off and I lose service” thing, and a woman next to me decided I was an asshole and <em>loudly</em> <em>told on me</em> to the flight attendant, who was busy and didn’t hear her. So I did the only reasonable thing—I stealthily turned my phone onto airplane mode, re-opened my texts, and very out in the open, started typing a long text. The woman—my new eternal arch-nemesis—took the bait. She saw me texting and <em>again </em>got the flight attendant’s attention, saying, “Excuse me but he’s <em>still</em> texting.” When the flight attendant asked me to turn airplane mode on, I showed her my phone and calmly explained that airplane mode has been on this whole time and I just like to get some texting out of the way during flights—texts that don’t send until I land and re-connect to the internet. The flight attendant said, “Oh then that’s totally fine—my apologies.” I replied, “that’s okay,” and did a little “it’s amazing how awful people can be right?” sigh. Satan watched the whole thing and then just sat there silently, hopefully very embarrassed. It was an unbelievably satisfying, triumphant moment.</p> \n <p>Here’s how that interaction looks in 2D. I was hovering somewhere in the middle of the Psych Spectrum, around my default level. The woman next to me either has a particular pet peeve about people not following rules, or she was in a bad mood and low down on her Psych Spectrum and took her shit out on me. Had I remained in a Psych Spectrum middle-ground, my Higher Mind would have thought, “whoa that was aggressive…but I am kind of a cock about this kind of thing, so whatever it’s fair. Plus she’s a stranger and it would certainly be silly to take this personally.” I’d have smiled, said a little “oops, sorry about that,” and that would have been that.</p> \n <p>But that’s not what happened, because her aggressive tattletale move immediately threw my Primitive Mind into a rage, plummeting me down the Psych Spectrum. This banished my Higher Mind to the closet of my subconscious, allowing my Primitive Mind to come up with a genius-yet-psychotic plan for revenge. Which worked, and made my Primitive Mind feel deeply satisfied in a very not-grown-up way.</p> \n <p>Flash to two hours later. We’re in the air somewhere. The woman and I obviously haven’t spoken or made eye contact since the incident. Then she drops her glasses on the ground. I pick them up and hand them to her. She replies, “Thank you……hey by the way I’m sorry about before, that was totally wrong of me.” I immediately reply back, “Oh don’t worry about it, I totally understand!” For the rest of the flight, we’re best friends. She’s a lovely person and I just want her to be happy in life.</p> \n <p>In 2D: Thinking (incorrectly) that she had falsely accused me of something, she feels bad, and uses the glasses interaction as a chance to make amends. My Primitive Mind, sitting smugly in the driver’s seat of my mind, had spent the flight assuming that this woman <em>hated </em>me and in turn, she remained my lifelong nemesis. Then she apologized. In that instant, my Primitive Mind deflated like a balloon and my Higher Mind burst out of the closet, suddenly fully empowered. My hatred of this random woman evaporated as I was reminded that she is a human, not Satan, and all of my satisfied anger transformed into regret for the sneaky trick I pulled on her.</p> \n <p>Our little fight dragged both of our tugs-of-war downward, and then later, with a single positive interaction, we both snapped back upward. These kinds of Psych Spectrum roller coasters happen all the time.</p> \n</div> \n<p>Over the span of a week, your Psych Spectrum Fitbit might show you a graph like this:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/1.2-wave.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8761 size-large\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/1.2-wave-750x548.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"548\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/1.2-wave-750x548.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/1.2-wave-600x438.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/1.2-wave-768x561.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/1.2-wave.png 1227w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> \n<p>But that’s just the micro picture. To get a sense of how your life is really going, you’d want to view the graph over a longer span, like a year (by plotting each week’s average):</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/1.3-wave.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8762 size-large\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/1.3-wave-750x546.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"546\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/1.3-wave-750x546.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/1.3-wave-600x437.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/1.3-wave-768x559.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/1.3-wave.png 1234w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Or even over a full decade (by plotting each year’s average):</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/1.4-wave.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8763 size-large\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/1.4-wave-750x545.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"545\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/1.4-wave-750x545.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/1.4-wave-600x436.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/1.4-wave-768x558.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/1.4-wave.png 1237w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Over longer periods of time, the micro oscillations melt away, and we see the broader trajectories of <em>macro</em> <em>trends</em>. In most cases, I think we grow up over time, as we get a little wiser, a little more self-aware, a little kinder and less self-obsessed. This means that as the years pass, our general Psych Spectrum equilibrium rises, like a stock chart that goes up and down week to week but over the years goes up overall. But we also go through rough times in our lives where we seem to revert to old ways we thought we were done with. When a downward macro trend gets out of hand, our lives can fall apart for a while. It’s the human roller coaster that we’re all on, whether we like it or not.</p> \n<p>Macro trends happen because Psych Spectrum movement in one part of our lives can spread to others and generate a feedback spiral, helping upward and downward trends to beget more of the same. Maybe you start to lose some confidence at work, which then bleeds into your dating life. You end up in a relationship that doesn’t make you feel so great about yourself—one you probably wouldn’t have gotten into when you felt better about everything a year ago. You find yourself eating badly and exercising less. The quality of your work goes down, which makes you lose more confidence. Your lower confidence worsens your relationship, and maybe your family notices that you haven’t been calling as much as you used to. You start having a hard time being happy for friends when good things happen in their lives, which puts a distance between you and them. What started as a single negative development becomes a vicious cycle that infects all parts of your life. Years later, when things have turned around for you, you look back on those years and with hindsight, you can see them for what they were—a trough in the roller coaster of your life.</p> \n<p>If the entire U.S. giant were wearing a Psych Spectrum Fitbit, I think we might see the same kind of graph.</p> \n<p>In the U.S., election season is like a raging “Primitive Minds Gone Wild” keg party. In the months leading up to the election, the nation’s air becomes more and more saturated with toxic, contagious Primitive Mind smoke. If the two U.S. political parties are like a married couple desperately in need of couples therapy, election season is when they’re at their worst and most contemptuous. Not many of us can hold our tugs-of-war in place in that kind of environment, and on aggregate, election season causes the country to drift downward on the Psych Spectrum. The country’s giant collective Primitive Mind gets stronger and louder, pulling the national tug-of-war downward a bit on the mountain. The frozen, non-thinking spots in the collective national brain—the country’s political Echo Chambers—swell up and expand.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/2.1-Brains.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8764\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/2.1-Brains.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1200\" height=\"541\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/2.1-Brains.png 2387w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/2.1-Brains-600x270.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/2.1-Brains-768x346.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/2.1-Brains-750x338.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1200px) 100vw, 1200px\" /></a></p> \n<p>As we talked about in Chapter 9, politics is always a bit&nbsp;<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/12/political-disney-world.html#bottom-heavy\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><em>bottom-heavy</em></a>&nbsp;on the Psych Spectrum—but during election season, politics is at its bottom-heaviest.</p> \n<p>Then election season ends, a bunch of post-mortem op-eds are written, and eventually, everyone gets bored of politics and moves on, if only for a little while. Many Americans rise up a bit on the Political Ladder, leaving the low-rung giants behind and repopulating the high-rung giants. As people relax a little about politics, some communities become slightly less groupthinky, shrinking the national Echo Chambers down in size.</p> \n<p>Putting it all together, the election cycle oscillation might look something like this. Please enjoy Wait But Why’s attempt at animation:</p> \n<p></p> \n<iframe width=\"725\" height=\"560\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/Ei3H2La1svc?fs=0&amp;hd=1&amp;modestbranding=1\" frameborder=\"0\" allow=\"accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture\" allowfullscreen=\"\"></iframe> \n<div style=\"height:38px\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"wp-block-spacer\"></div> \n<p>We would expect this kind of short-term pattern in even the healthiest democracy. Like my example with an individual, to really get a sense of how a country is doing, we’d need to zoom out and try to see the longer-term macro trends.</p> \n<p>Over a period of many decades, the hope is that countries have an upward trajectory. If almost everyone in your country would agree that they’d rather live there today than 100 years ago, it may be a sign that the big, national giant has managed to move higher up the mountain throughout the century, not lower. But even the most stable, healthy countries can go through painful periods of reversion as well.</p> \n<p>The history of the U.S. has certainly been a roller coaster, with plenty of upward macro trends and some eras of negative progress too. I’m not enough of a U.S. historian to take a respectable crack at what the full graph of that roller coaster might look like (though I encourage commenters to give it a try), but when I look at recent times, here’s what I see:</p> \n<p>Over the past 30 years, the U.S. has been on a downward macro trend—a negative feedback spiral that has been accelerating in recent years. And the harder I think about what that macro trend means, about what’s causing it, and about what its consequences could be, the more worried I get.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">__________</p> \n<p>I suspect that this trend is bigger than the U.S., because it seems to be mirrored in many parts of Europe and other parts of the world. But having focused the majority of my thinking and research on the U.S., I’ll limit my analysis to what’s been going on here (though I’d love to hear from non-U.S. readers about what macro trends they see happening in their country).</p> \n<p>On its face, the downward trend I’m referring to looks like an increase in political polarization, both among voters and among politicians. Let’s take a look at both areas:</p> \n<p style=\"font-size:32px\"><strong>The Voter Polarization Story</strong></p> \n<p>Voter polarization is an old pastime in the U.S.—but over the past half century, things have devolved into a particularly nasty situation.</p> \n<p>You could probably trace the roots of the trend all the way back to 1945, when Hitler died. As we’ve discussed, nothing unites a group of humans like a common enemy—and the first half of the twentieth century was dominated by giant world wars that helped Americans to feel united. The U.S. never stopped being immersed in foreign conflicts, but Hitler’s demise marked the last time Americans were totally, uncontroversially united against a common enemy. And let’s remember <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/08/giants.html#bedouin\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">what happens</a> when the common enemy goes away.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/20.12-strangers-run-away.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-7464 size-large\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/20.12-strangers-run-away-600x310.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"310\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/20.12-strangers-run-away-600x310.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/20.12-strangers-run-away-300x155.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/20.12-strangers-run-away-768x397.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/20.12-strangers-run-away.png 1200w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/20.13-happy-cousins.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-7467 size-large\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/20.13-happy-cousins-600x343.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"343\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/20.13-happy-cousins-600x343.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/20.13-happy-cousins-300x172.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/20.13-happy-cousins-768x439.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/20.13-happy-cousins.png 1200w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/20.14-medium-cousins.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-7468 size-large\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/20.14-medium-cousins-600x310.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"310\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/20.14-medium-cousins-600x310.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/20.14-medium-cousins-300x155.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/20.14-medium-cousins-768x397.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/20.14-medium-cousins.png 851w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/20.15-angry-cousins.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-7469 size-full\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/20.15-angry-cousins.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"485\" height=\"372\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/20.15-angry-cousins.png 485w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/20.15-angry-cousins-300x230.png 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 485px) 100vw, 485px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Another key moment happened in the 1960s, when a cultural schism divided the country and never really went away.</p> \n<p>By the middle of the decade, it had been 20 years since the end of World War II, and the country was ready to start fighting with itself again.</p> \n<p>The Soviet Union was kind of a common enemy, but the country wasn’t totally united by it. A wave of pro-Communism sentiment from parts of the Left started to annoy the shit out of the Right, who felt that the Soviet Union and the spread of Communism should be viewed as pure evil, no differently than Hitler. Barry Goldwater, the 1964 Republican candidate for president, summed up this sentiment in his nomination acceptance speech, when he said:</p> \n<p><em>I would remind you that extremism in the defense of liberty is no vice. And let me remind you also that moderation in the pursuit of justice is no virtue. </em></p> \n<p>This was a rallying call against Communism, but it was also a rallying call to the American Right to dig their heels in with their stances, whether the Democrats were on board or not.</p> \n<p>Meanwhile, the Left was undergoing a shift in the other direction. In his 1997 book <a href=\"https://amzn.to/35vEKI2\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><em>Achieving Our Country</em></a><em>, </em>philosopher Richard Rorty<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#footnote-1-8757\" id=\"note-1-8757\" rel=\"footnote\">1</a> describes the mid-1960s as a period during which the Left began to transition from what he calls The Reformist Left—who were patriotic and devoted to making pragmatic progressive improvements to the traditional U.S. system—to what he calls The Cultural Left. The Cultural Left, led by students who were born after World War II ended, was less patriotic than the Left of previous decades, viewing the U.S. as somewhat of a failed experiment. This shift put them in direct conflict with the super patriotic Goldwater Right. The Cultural Left was also more politically militant and less interested in pragmatic reform than the old, Reformist Left had been, falling nicely into Goldwater’s militant “extremism over moderation on matters of virtue” camp—only on the opposite side of every issue.</p> \n<p>The renewed partisan divide was more clear-cut than it had been in decades past—and the major events of the late 1960s were viewed by both factions as binary political battlegrounds.</p> \n<p>According to Rorty, the Cultural Left, who were often critical of Capitalism and sometimes sympathetic towards the Soviet Union, despised the Vietnam War, while most of the Right fervently supported it. Anti-war Republicans and pro-war Democrats increasingly became persona non grata in their own party and either faded away or defected to the other side.</p> \n<p>The Cultural Left saw the fight for civil rights as not only necessary but as a symbol of the country’s moral bankruptcy. This really boiled the South’s potato—and Republicans jumped on the opportunity. Democrats had dominated the South in presidential elections for a century, and by solidifying in resistance to the Democrats’ 1965 Voting Rights Act (in what Nixon’s strategists called “the Southern Strategy”), the Republicans snatched the South away, and they’ve (mostly) held it <a href=\"https://www.economist.com/united-states/2010/11/11/the-long-goodbye\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">ever since</a>. What had previously been a hazier divide on race issues like segregation, with some conservative Southern Democrats and some more progressive Northern Republicans previously in support of or opposed to segregation, respectively, now sorted itself out more cleanly.</p> \n<p>The cultural gap between the parties also widened. The Cultural Left, with their drugs and their hair and their music and their rampant sex, became increasingly irritating to the more traditional Republicans. The Left had a similarly one-dimensional view of the Right, seeing them as a group of sweater-wearing, warmongering, financially predatory old white racists.</p> \n<p>It all came to a head in the 1968 election, with Richard Nixon riding into the White House on a wave of populist appeal to everyone fed up with the Cultural Left—who, in turn, saw the election result as further reason to lose hope in the country.</p> \n<p>The tumult of the 1960s sowed many of the roots for the modern Left/Right divides on foreign, fiscal, and social issues. According to a <a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Generations-Politics-Parents-Princeton-Library/dp/0691615225\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">comprehensive study</a>, people are at their most politically and ideologically impressionable between their mid-teens and mid-20s, and all of those Baby Boomers born in the 1940s and 50s—none of whom were sentient the last time the U.S. felt like a single, united front against a common enemy, and most of whom were deeply influenced by the events of the late 60s—are, by the 80s and 90s, running the country. The Greatest Generation (who fought in World War II) are by this point mostly retired, and it’s the Baby Boomers who are the politicians, the university administrators, the CEOs, the home buyers, and the media moguls.</p> \n<p>During the following decades, we see voter polarization steadily increasing. <a href=\"https://www.people-press.org/2017/10/05/the-partisan-divide-on-political-values-grows-even-wider/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Pew data</a>, collected over the past 25 years, shows us that the gap between the viewpoints of Democrats and Republicans has grown on issues across the board. <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#footnote2-1-8757\" id=\"note2-1-8757\" rel=\"footnote2\">1</a> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/128a.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8765\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/128a.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1200\" height=\"934\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/128a.png 1842w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/128a-600x467.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/128a-768x598.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/128a-750x584.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1200px) 100vw, 1200px\" /></a></p> <p>Averaging out the growth of the gap in those 10 graphs yields a smooth trend—<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#footnote2-2-8757\" id=\"note2-2-8757\" rel=\"footnote2\">2</a> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/143.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8766\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/143.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"500\" height=\"598\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/143.png 1222w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/143-502x600.png 502w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/143-768x919.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/143-627x750.png 627w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 500px) 100vw, 500px\" /></a></p> <p>—even as gaps in viewpoints between the country’s races, religions, and other types of groups have remained unchanged:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#footnote2-3-8757\" id=\"note2-3-8757\" rel=\"footnote2\">3</a> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/142.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8767\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/142.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"500\" height=\"639\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/142.png 1202w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/142-470x600.png 470w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/142-768x981.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/142-587x750.png 587w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 500px) 100vw, 500px\" /></a></p> <p>Pew helps us visualize this another way—by plotting Americans on a spectrum from consistently liberal on one end to consistently conservative on the other. So someone who holds liberal views on all 10 of the above issues is plotted on the far left, someone who answers all 10 questions conservatively is on the far right, and people who have mixed leanings are more in the middle (with those whose answers are split 5-5 in the dead center).</p> <p>The U.S. Thought Pile has gone from a steep hill to a more of a flat mesa.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#footnote2-4-8757\" id=\"note2-4-8757\" rel=\"footnote2\">4</a> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/137a.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8769 size-full\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/137a.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1890\" height=\"1120\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/137a.png 1890w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/137a-600x356.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/137a-768x455.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/137a-750x444.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1890px) 100vw, 1890px\" /></a></p> <p>A steep hill means most people have a mix of liberal and conservative views—something you’d expect in a country with 325 million unique independent thinkers. A steep hill flattening into a mesa happens when fewer people are mixed and more people are ideologically pure.</p> <p>Up on the high rungs of our <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/3.3-political-ladder-1.png\">political ladder</a>, my hunch is that you’d find people all along this spectrum—from consistently liberal to consistently conservative, to everything in between. But on the aggregate, the high rungs alone would probably form a steep hill. In the Echo Chambers, you’d be more likely to find people in lockstep, loyal to their party’s <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/19-checklist.png\">ideological checklist</a> from top to bottom. Going from a hill to a mesa is probably a sign that on the whole, America’s <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/10/idea-labs-echo-chambers.html#idea-labs\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Idea Labs</a> have gotten smaller while its <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/10/idea-labs-echo-chambers.html#echo-chambers\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Echo Chambers</a> have grown.</p> <p>Separating this graph by party helps us see what’s going on behind the scenes of this trend. Play around with <a href=\"https://www.people-press.org/interactives/political-polarization-1994-2017/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">this</a> for a minute.</p> <p>Here are three snapshots that sum up the story pretty well:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#footnote2-5-8757\" id=\"note2-5-8757\" rel=\"footnote2\">5</a> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/135-stacked.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8770 size-full\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/135-stacked.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1879\" height=\"2704\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/135-stacked.png 1879w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/135-stacked-417x600.png 417w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/135-stacked-768x1105.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/135-stacked-521x750.png 521w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1879px) 100vw, 1879px\" /></a></p> <p>Jonathan Haidt and Sam Abrams <a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2015/01/07/the-top-10-reasons-american-politics-are-worse-than-ever/?utm_term=.8aa1e606bdde\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">look at the same story</a> yet another way, using data from <a href=\"https://electionstudies.org/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><em>American National Election Studies</em></a>, which suggests that the degree of ideological purity within the two parties has about doubled over the past four decades:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/144.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8771 \" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/144-750x435.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"494\" height=\"286\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/144-750x435.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/144-600x348.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/144-768x445.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/144.png 1636w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 494px) 100vw, 494px\" /></a></p> <p>They explain: “Before the 1980s, if you knew which party an American voted for, you couldn’t predict very well whether the person held liberal or conservative views. This chart shows the degree to which identification with a party correlates with a person’s self-placement on the liberal-conservative spectrum. If there were no relationship, the “correlation coefficient” would be zero. If there were a perfect relationship, it would be 1. In 1972, it was 0.32, but it has nearly doubled since then, to 0.62 in 2012, which is considered strong.”</p> <p>2) The story shows up again when we look at presidential approval numbers. Young Americans who only know a country where half the citizens love the president and the other half hate him might be surprised to learn that it wasn’t always like this:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/134.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8772\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/134.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"500\" height=\"688\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/134.png 1072w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/134-436x600.png 436w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/134-768x1057.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/134-545x750.png 545w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 500px) 100vw, 500px\" /></a></p> <p>You can also see the story in how Americans’ feelings toward opposing voters has evolved. In stats like this—<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#footnote2-6-8757\" id=\"note2-6-8757\" rel=\"footnote2\">6</a> <p><em>In 1958, 33 percent of Democrats wanted their daughters to marry a Democrat, and 25 percent of Republicans wanted their daughters to marry a Republican. But by 2016, 60 percent of Democrats and 63 percent of Republicans felt that way.</em></p> <p>—or in graphs like this:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#footnote2-7-8757\" id=\"note2-7-8757\" rel=\"footnote2\">7</a> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/129.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8773 size-large\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/129-750x524.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"524\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/129-750x524.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/129-600x419.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/129-768x536.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/129.png 1380w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> <p>Looking at the trajectory we’re on, it’s no surprise that Americans are becoming less and less hopeful about things turning around:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/138-1.png\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8774\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/138-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"413\" height=\"353\" /></a></p> <p>As voters have polarized, a similar story has been playing out in Washington.</p> <p style=\"font-size:32px\"><strong>The Politician Polarization Story</strong></p> <p>It’s a good idea to start with some context and remind ourselves that this isn’t the first era the U.S. has descended into a polarization vortex.</p> <p>In his <a href=\"https://avalon.law.yale.edu/18th_century/washing.asp\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">farewell speech</a> at the end of his presidency, George Washington warned about the dangers of political polarization:</p> <p><em>This spirit, unfortunately, is inseparable from our nature, having its root in the strongest passions of the human mind. It exists under different shapes in all governments, more or less stifled, controlled, or repressed; but, in those of the popular form, it is seen in its greatest rankness, and is truly their worst enemy. The alternate domination of one faction over another, sharpened by the spirit of revenge, natural to party dissension, which in different ages and countries has perpetrated the most horrid enormities, is itself a frightful despotism…It serves always to distract the public councils and enfeeble the public administration. It agitates the community with ill-founded jealousies and false alarms, kindles the animosity of one part against another, foments occasionally riot and insurrection. It opens the door to foreign influence and corruption, which finds a facilitated access to the government itself through the channels of party passions…it is a spirit not to be encouraged.</em></p> <p>Everyone burst out laughing and the government has been polarized ever since.</p> <p>The John Adams–Thomas Jefferson election of 1800 was one of the <a href=\"https://www.mentalfloss.com/article/19668/election-1800-birth-negative-campaigning-us\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">dirtiest in history</a>. Jefferson then spent his presidency at fierce odds with Hamilton and the Federalists. Half a century later, the country descended into Civil War. A few decades after that, the 1890s were a hyper-polarized time<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#footnote-2-8757\" id=\"note-2-8757\" rel=\"footnote\">2</a> that in many ways resembled today’s divides.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#footnote-3-8757\" id=\"note-3-8757\" rel=\"footnote\">3</a> In the 1930s, the parties clashed again over the New Deal.</p> <p>Looking at the history seems to support the idea that a country like the U.S. goes through macro oscillations in polarization. What seems like a trajectory into hell when you only look at WWII to today looks more like just another part of a roller coaster from a more zoomed-out angle.(Though for reasons we’ll discuss later, the modern trend may be uniquely dangerous.)</p> <p>Probably the most commonly-cited metric to measure polarization levels in the U.S. House and Senate is something called the <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NOMINATE_(scaling_method)\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">DW-NOMINATE</a>,<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#footnote-4-8757\" id=\"note-4-8757\" rel=\"footnote\">4</a> which places politicians on a liberal-to-conservative scale based on data like their <a href=\"https://www.senate.gov/reference/glossary_term/roll_call_vote.htm\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">roll-call vote</a> behavior. The developers of the metric use it to <span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://voteview.com/congress/house\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">make</a></span> <span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://voteview.com/congress/senate\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">interesting</a></span> <a href=\"https://voteview.com/parties/all\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\">charts</span></a> on the site <a href=\"https://voteview.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">voteview.com</a>. One such chart shows how DW-NOMINATE averages in the U.S. House of Representatives have changed since 1880:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#footnote2-8-8757\" id=\"note2-8-8757\" rel=\"footnote2\">8</a> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/voteview-1.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8775\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/voteview-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"676\" height=\"386\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/voteview-1.png 2100w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/voteview-1-600x343.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/voteview-1-768x439.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/voteview-1-750x429.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 676px) 100vw, 676px\" /></a></p> <p>Their chart for the Senate tells a similar-looking story.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/voteview-2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8844\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/voteview-2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"689\" height=\"393\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/voteview-2.png 2100w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/voteview-2-600x343.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/voteview-2-768x439.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/voteview-2-750x429.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 689px) 100vw, 689px\" /></a></p> <p>In each chamber, both parties have gone more extreme, with the Republicans going even farther. The full trend really comes through when you plot out the&nbsp;<em>gap</em> between the parties in the two chambers:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/voteview-3.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8845\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/voteview-3.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"683\" height=\"390\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/voteview-3.png 2100w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/voteview-3-600x343.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/voteview-3-768x439.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/voteview-3-750x429.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 683px) 100vw, 683px\" /></a></p> <p>Political theorists suggest a few possibilities for the causes of the most recent polarization trend among politicians:</p> <p><a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/monkey-cage/wp/2014/01/09/american-politics-is-more-competitive-than-ever-thats-making-partisanship-worse/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">One theory</a> points to the fact that both chambers have been highly competitive over recent decades.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#footnote2-9-8757\" id=\"note2-9-8757\" rel=\"footnote2\">9</a> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/competitiveness.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8776\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/competitiveness.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"706\" height=\"533\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/competitiveness.png 1902w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/competitiveness-600x453.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/competitiveness-768x580.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/competitiveness-750x566.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 706px) 100vw, 706px\" /></a></p> <p>Political science professor Frances Lee <a href=\"https://books.google.com/books?id=dAm5BgAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PT56&amp;lpg=PT56&amp;dq=%E2%80%9CCompetition+fuels+party+conflict+by+raising+the+political+stakes+of+every+policy+dispute.+When+control+of+national+institutions+hangs+in+the+balance,+no+party+wants+to+grant+political+legitimacy+to+its+opposition+by+voting+for+the+measures+it+champions.%E2%80%9D&amp;source=bl&amp;ots=yFqIeWpoti&amp;sig=ACfU3U0lH2y46KOtpDA-Y3fQ0742rEFYAg&amp;hl=en&amp;sa=X&amp;ved=2ahUKEwiun9uBzdzmAhWniOAKHdzfCIcQ6AEwAXoECAoQAQ#v=onepage&amp;q=%E2%80%9CCompetition%20fuels%20party%20conflict%20by%20raising%20the%20political%20stakes%20of%20every%20policy%20dispute.%20When%20control%20of%20national%20institutions%20hangs%20in%20the%20balance%2C%20no%20party%20wants%20to%20grant%20political%20legitimacy%20to%20its%20opposition%20by%20voting%20for%20the%20measures%20it%20champions.%E2%80%9D&amp;f=false\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">explains</a>: “Competition fuels party conflict by raising the political stakes of every policy dispute. When control of national institutions hangs in the balance, no party wants to grant political legitimacy to its opposition by voting for the measures it champions.”</p> <p>Some theories point to the increase in campaign spending:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#footnote2-10-8757\" id=\"note2-10-8757\" rel=\"footnote2\">10</a> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Spending.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8777\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Spending.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"662\" height=\"517\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Spending.png 1134w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Spending-600x469.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Spending-768x600.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Spending-750x586.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 662px) 100vw, 662px\" /></a></p> <p>More donations means more fear of pissing off donors—which often means more candidates falling in line with their party.</p> <p>Others point the finger at redistricting—the practice of re-drawing the borders of congressional districts, which can dramatically change the voter balance in an election (usually in favor of the party who controls the state legislatures). That would certainly seem like a possible culprit in House polarization, though it wouldn’t explain the trends in the Senate (which aren’t subject to district lines).</p> <p>Then there’s Newt Gingrich. When Gingrich won his first election in 1978, the Democrats were starting their 25th straight year as the majority in Congress.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#footnote2-11-8757\" id=\"note2-11-8757\" rel=\"footnote2\">11</a> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/538.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8778 size-full\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/538.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1662\" height=\"1516\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/538.png 1662w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/538-600x547.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/538-768x701.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/538-750x684.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1662px) 100vw, 1662px\" /></a></p> <p>During this long tenure, the Democrats <a href=\"https://youtu.be/KHZTfMLGSYg?t=1118\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">didn’t always treat the Republicans so well</a>, and Gingrich and other Republicans were frustrated that between the Democrats having more money and more access privileges due to their majority position, and continual assistance from what they saw as left-leaning mainstream media, the Democrat stranglehold on Congress had no seeming end in sight. So Gingrich innovated. He wanted to reframe Congressional elections to be less about the actual people running for Congress and more about a binary tribal war between the Left and the Right. Over the following 16 years, as Gingrich gained more seniority, he emphasized a culture among Republican politicians of distrust and disgust for Democratic leadership and made it taboo to say anything to legitimize them.</p> <p>In 1994, when the Republicans finally won back Congress, Gingrich, now the Speaker of the House, doubled down on the effort to tribalize. He crunched the traditional five-day legislative schedule into three days. According to Haidt and Abrams, “he changed the legislative calendar so that all business was done Tuesday through Thursday, and he encouraged his incoming freshmen not to move to the District. He did not want them to develop personal friendships with Democrats. He did not want their spouses to serve on the same charitable boards.”<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#footnote2-12-8757\" id=\"note2-12-8757\" rel=\"footnote2\">12</a><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#footnote-5-8757\" id=\"note-5-8757\" rel=\"footnote\">5</a> He also helped to do away with the seniority system for committee chairmen, which law professor Cynthia Farina says “many now blame for enhancing extremist voices, punishing defections from the party line, and burying measures with bipartisan support.”<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#footnote2-13-8757\" id=\"note2-13-8757\" rel=\"footnote2\">13</a> <p>Whatever the cause, the shift from a standard partisan tone to a fully tribal Us-vs.-Them tone is now ubiquitous in Washington. In 2012, Chris Christie’s&nbsp;<a href=\"https://www.npr.org/2012/08/28/160213518/transcript-gov-chris-christies-convention-speech\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">entire convention speech</a> used the structure, “<strong>They </strong>believe ____; <strong>We </strong>believe ____.” In her 2015 presidential campaign announcement, Hillary Clinton made six “<strong>They</strong> [something bad]” statements in <a href=\"https://youtu.be/ZgGPMrLHRy0?t=875\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">just over a minute</a>. Just a few months ago, Kamala Harris <a href=\"https://www.brut.media/us/international/sen-kamala-harris-powerful-response-to-the-rise-in-hate-6d48b7f1-286c-4715-a8d9-4eb37098cffa\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">called on voters</a> to not “let the bad guys win.” As I write this, a visit to <a href=\"https://www.donaldjtrump.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Donald Trump’s website</a> is immediately met with this popup:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/trump-site.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8847\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/trump-site.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"576\" height=\"391\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/trump-site.png 1086w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/trump-site-600x408.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/trump-site-768x522.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/trump-site-750x510.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/trump-site-782x530.png 782w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/trump-site-345x234.png 345w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/trump-site-103x70.png 103w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 576px) 100vw, 576px\" /></a></p> <p>Voters have become more ideologically pure, and the purity in Washington is even starker. In the decades following World War II, the parties were actually pretty diverse, with lots of overlap. But in recent decades, overlap groups like the conservative “Blue Dog Democrats” and the more progressive “Rockefeller Republicans” have gone extinct. Today, the overlap has entirely vanished:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#footnote2-14-8757\" id=\"note2-14-8757\" rel=\"footnote2\">14</a> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/overlap-1.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8779\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/overlap-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"656\" height=\"458\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/overlap-1.png 1872w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/overlap-1-600x419.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/overlap-1-768x536.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/overlap-1-750x523.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 656px) 100vw, 656px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/overlap-2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8780\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/overlap-2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"656\" height=\"467\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/overlap-2.png 1806w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/overlap-2-600x427.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/overlap-2-768x547.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/overlap-2-750x534.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 656px) 100vw, 656px\" /></a></p> <p>So there’s the voter polarization story and the politician polarization story, which in many ways look similar. In both cases, polarization oscillates on a four-year cycle with elections, but each cycle, things are worse than they were in the last one.</p> <p>And the question is: why?</p> <p>As we think about that question, let’s remember not to jump to <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/12/political-disney-world.html#causation\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">causation conclusions</a> when we see a correlation. Washington polarization may be a symptom of voter polarization. Or vice versa. Maybe they’re stoking each other in a self-perpetuating loop. They could be independent phenomena, correlated only by coincidence. Or—and I think this is most likely—they could <em>both </em>be symptoms of something else.</p> <p>In <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/09/stories.html#equation\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Part 1</a>, we talked about how animal behavior works.
