It’s a <em>dependent </em>variable.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.0-bare-behavior-equation.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-7762\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.0-bare-behavior-equation.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"665\" height=\"177\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.0-bare-behavior-equation.png 1383w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.0-bare-behavior-equation-300x80.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.0-bare-behavior-equation-768x205.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.0-bare-behavior-equation-600x160.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 665px) 100vw, 665px\" /></a></p> <p>Humans are complicated animals with complicated motivations, but the basic idea holds up. If a reasonably stable human society starts falling into some kind of downward spiral, it’s probably because something about one or both of the independent variables has changed—usually, something about the environment.</p> <p>I’ve read a whole bunch of sociological theories about why we in the U.S. have been spiraling down a polarization vortex, and there are lots of interesting ideas, with little consensus. Drawing upon what I see as the most compelling theories, here’s my hypothesis:</p> <p>Due to changes in the environment over recent decades, we’ve become connected in all the wrong ways—and it’s led to a resurgence of the Power Games in the U.S.</p> <p>There are two elements of the hypothesis:</p> <p style=\"font-size:32px\"><strong>1) Geographic Bubbles</strong></p> <p>Over the past generation, Americans have become <a href=\"https://ourworldindata.org/grapher/mean-years-of-schooling-1?tab=chart&amp;country=USA\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">more educated</a>, which has made them more mobile. <em>The Economist</em> <a href=\"https://www.economist.com/united-states/2008/06/19/the-big-sort\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">cites a study</a> that found that “45% of young Americans with a college degree moved states within five years of graduating, whereas only 19% of those with only a high-school education did.”</p> <p>And here’s the thing about mobility. If lots of people have the means to choose where they settle down, and those people tend to have even a <a href=\"https://www.people-press.org/2016/06/22/4-partisan-stereotypes-views-of-republicans-and-democrats-as-neighbors/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><em>slight</em> preference</a> to live near other people like them, everyone ends up totally segregated. This phenomenon is explained in a 1971 paper called <a href=\"https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/0022250X.1971.9989794\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><em>Dynamic models of segregation</em></a>, but it’s best explored using a <a href=\"https://ncase.me/polygons/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">brilliant interactive simulation</a> by Nicky Case and Vi Hart.</p> <p>The simulation has two kinds of characters, a blue square and a yellow triangle.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/1-2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8781\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/1-2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"148\" height=\"83\" /></a></p> <p>These could represent people of different religions, different races, different socioeconomic backgrounds, or anything else. For our purposes, they’ll represent U.S. Democrats and Republicans.</p> <p>In the simulation, there’s one key metric, called “individual bias percentage”— a number that represents the minimum percentage of “sameness” (for us, ideological sameness) each shape finds acceptable among their direct neighbors. So for example, say the shapes like living in a politically diverse neighborhood, but they want at least 33% of their direct neighbors to be politically similar to them. That means they’ll only be unhappy enough to move if less than 33% of their neighbors are similar to them politically, and beyond that, they prefer diversity. To illustrate this, imagine these three tiny neighborhoods:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/2-1.png\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8782\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/2-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1736\" height=\"780\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/2-1.png 1736w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/2-1-600x270.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/2-1-768x345.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/2-1-750x337.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1736px) 100vw, 1736px\" /></a></p> <p>Given our 33% condition above, everyone in the middle neighborhood is happy, because they live in a politically diverse neighborhood while also each having at least 1/3 of their direct neighbors share their views. On the right, no one is happy because there’s no political diversity, but no one is unhappy enough to move. On the left, there’s an unhappy triangle, because their direct neighbors are 5/6 squares and only 1/6 triangles (the other triangle in the left neighborhood is fine because it has only two direct neighbors, and one of them (50%) is also a triangle). Make sense?</p> <p>Next, Case and Hart bring out a big, diverse town with an interactive slider next to it.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3-2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8783\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3-2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1200\" height=\"720\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3-2.png 2120w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3-2-600x360.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3-2-768x461.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3-2-750x450.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1200px) 100vw, 1200px\" /></a></p> <p>The slider lets you adjust the “individual bias percentage” of the shapes in the town. Above, the slider is at 0%, which means the shapes have no “acceptable minimum” requirement for ideologically similar neighbors—so no one is unhappy with the layout, and no one would feel the need to move.</p> <p>But when you move the slider up to 20%—meaning every shape now wants to move if less than 1/5 of their direct neighbors are politically like-minded—a few residents become unhappy with their locations and want to move (hard to see here, but the unhappy shapes are frowning).</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/4-2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8784\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/4-2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1200\" height=\"716\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/4-2.png 2128w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/4-2-600x358.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/4-2-768x458.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/4-2-750x448.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1200px) 100vw, 1200px\" /></a></p> <p>By clicking the “Start Movin’” button, the simulation shifts unhappy characters around randomly until everyone’s happy. Here’s how things end up:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/5-2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8785\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/5-2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1200\" height=\"720\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/5-2.png 2124w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/5-2-600x360.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/5-2-768x461.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/5-2-750x450.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1200px) 100vw, 1200px\" /></a></p> <p>Things have gotten slightly more segregated, but nothing major—according to the simulation, the region has only “18% segregation.”</p> <p>But what happens when you move the slider up from 20% to 33%? Our 18% segregated town no longer works, as there are now a few new unhappy residents.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/6-2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8786\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/6-2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1200\" height=\"723\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/6-2.png 2114w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/6-2-600x362.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/6-2-768x463.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/6-2-750x452.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1200px) 100vw, 1200px\" /></a></p> <p>Doesn’t seem like a big deal—until we hit the Start Movin’ button, and by the time no one is unhappy, we’ve ended up here:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/7-1.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8787\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/7-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1200\" height=\"721\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/7-1.png 2110w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/7-1-600x361.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/7-1-768x462.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/7-1-750x451.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1200px) 100vw, 1200px\" /></a></p> <p>In order for no one to be unhappy—even when everyone is politically open-minded enough to be fine with 2/3 of their neighbors being politically opposed to them—the town has to become 57% segregated. Suddenly, almost everyone is surrounded by people who agree with them politically.</p> <p>And how about if we up the percentage just a bit more, to 50%—meaning the shapes are still totally fine with diversity, they just don’t want to be in the political <em>minority </em>in their neighborhood? We end up with a completely segregated town.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/8-1.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8788\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/8-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1200\" height=\"725\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/8-1.png 2110w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/8-1-600x362.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/8-1-768x464.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/8-1-750x453.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1200px) 100vw, 1200px\" /></a></p> <p>This exposes a stark fact: if easily mobile people like diversity but prefer not to be the <em>minority</em> where they live, it leads to complete segregated homogeneity. Or as Case and Hart put it, “small individual bias can lead to large collective bias.” The only way areas stay diverse—racially, ethnically, politically—is if people like diversity <em>more </em>than they dislike being in the minority.</p> <p>Back to our story. The simulation suggests that if Baby Boomers were, on average, a few “individual political bias percentage” points higher than their parents, <em>and </em>they were a bit more capable of moving and choosing their location, then when the Boomers reached home-buying age, the country would quickly sort itself into politically segregated neighborhoods in politically segregated counties.</p> <p>Which is exactly what happened.</p> <p>In his book <a href=\"https://amzn.to/37EC2Bv\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><em>The Big Sort</em></a>, Bill Bishop examines how Americans have shifted geographically in relation to political leaning—and he found that Americans are far less likely to live in politically diverse areas than they used to be. Politically, Americans have formed geographical Echo Chambers. Living in a geographical Echo Chamber means people will find themselves surrounded by agreement at dinner parties, at local churches and parks and businesses, and at school, which is where children make their lifelong friends.</p> <p>The “Big Sort” shows up in poll numbers. In an election, pollsters define a “landslide county” as one in which the winning candidate beat the losing candidate by 20 percentage points or more—in other words, a very red or very blue county. In the 1976 presidential election, 27% of Americans lived in landslide counties, with the remaining 73% living in more politically balanced counties where the election margin was closer.</p> <p>By 1992, the percentage of Americans living in a landslide county had moved from 27% to 39%. That number has continued to rise every election since, with the 2016 results showing that <em>61% </em>of Americans now live in landslide counties.</p> <p>FiveThirtyEight <a href=\"https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/purple-america-has-all-but-disappeared/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">explains further</a>, writing about the 2016 presidential election:</p> <p><em>Of the nation’s 3,113 counties (or county equivalents), just 303 were decided by single-digit margins—less than 10 percent. In contrast, 1,096 counties fit that description in 1992, even though that election featured a wider national spread. During the same period, the number of </em><strong><em>extreme landslide counties</em></strong><em>—those decided by margins exceeding 50 percentage points—exploded from 93 to 1,196, or over a third of the nation’s counties. … The electorate’s move toward single-party geographic enclaves has been particularly pronounced at the extremes. Between 1992 and 2016, the share of voters living in extreme landslide counties quintupled from 4 percent to 21 percent.</em></p> <p>They sum this all up in one graph:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/122.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8789\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/122.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"475\" height=\"397\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/122.png 1150w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/122-600x501.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/122-768x641.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/122-750x626.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 475px) 100vw, 475px\" /></a></p> <p>Landslide counties are bad for progress. According to<em>&nbsp;<a href=\"https://www.economist.com/united-states/2008/06/19/the-big-sort\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">The Economist</a></em>, “Voters in landslide districts tend to elect more extreme members of Congress. Moderates who might otherwise run for office decide not to. Debates turn into shouting matches. Bitterly partisan lawmakers cannot reach the necessary consensus to fix long-term problems such as the tottering pensions and health-care systems.”</p> <p>Political writer Philip Bump illustrates the same story from a <a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2014/10/21/there-really-are-two-americas-a-urban-one-and-a-rural-one/?utm_term=.5365286598d0\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">different angle</a>, showing how the Big Sort reveals itself in an increasing urban-rural political divide.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/123.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8790\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/123.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"597\" height=\"412\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/123.png 1660w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/123-600x413.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/123-768x529.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/123-750x517.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/123-103x70.png 103w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 597px) 100vw, 597px\" /></a></p> <p>In her book <a href=\"https://amzn.to/39GmW0d\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><em>Hearing the Other Side</em></a><em>, </em>Diana Mutz surveyed people from 12 countries and <a href=\"https://books.google.com/books?id=hQLMCwAAQBAJ&amp;printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&amp;q&amp;f=false\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">found that</a> Americans “engage in political discussions slightly more than average” but are the <em>least</em> likely of all the countries “to be exposed to political beliefs and arguments that differ from their own.”</p> <p>When people are surrounded by ideologically homogenous groups, their views become more extreme. In an <a href=\"https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=911646\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">interesting study</a>, scientists studied the effects of a kind of “deliberation day,” when two groups of citizens from politically homogenous areas got together to discuss hot political issues:</p> <p><em>Groups from Boulder, a predominantly liberal city, met and discussed global warming, affirmative action, and civil unions for same-sex couples; groups from Colorado Springs, a predominately conservative city, met to discuss the same issues. </em><strong><em>The major effect of deliberation was to make group members more extreme than they were when they started to talk. Liberals became more liberal on all three issues; conservatives became more conservative.</em></strong><em> As a result, the division between the citizens of Boulder and the citizens of Colorado Springs were significantly increased as a result of intragroup deliberation. <strong>Deliberation also increased consensus, and dampened diversity, within the groups.</strong></em></p> <p>Writing about the same phenomenon, <em>The Economist </em><a href=\"https://www.economist.com/united-states/2008/06/19/the-big-sort\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">reminds</a> us that “even clever, fair-minded people are not immune,” reporting on a <a href=\"https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=1899690\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">study</a> that found that “Republican-appointed judges vote more conservatively when sitting on a panel with other Republicans than when sitting with Democrats. Democratic judges become more liberal when on the bench with fellow Democrats.”</p> <p>As worrisome as this sounds, geographic bubbles are only the tip of the worrisome iceberg here.</p> <p style=\"font-size:32px\"><strong>2) Information Bubbles</strong></p> <p>The story of politics is closely intertwined with the story of media, and several paradigm shifts in our information ecosystem have a lot to do with what’s happening politically.</p> <p>As is the theme with this series, we’ll be better able to understand these transformations, and their consequences, if we can look at them through a useful lens. Here’s one that we can use to assess news-presenting media of any kind: the Media Matrix.</p> <p style=\"font-size:28px\"><strong>The Media Matrix</strong></p> <p>The Media Matrix looks like this:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.1-media-matrix.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8791 size-medium\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.1-media-matrix-545x600.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"545\" height=\"600\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.1-media-matrix-545x600.png 545w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.1-media-matrix-768x845.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.1-media-matrix-682x750.png 682w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.1-media-matrix.png 826w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 545px) 100vw, 545px\" /></a></p> <p>Every media brand (or media personality) can be plotted somewhere in the matrix. To add a third metric, we can plot them as circles, where the size of the circle represents the size of their audience.</p> <p>At the top of the Media Matrix, in the middle, is media’s North Star. Here you have media brands that are rigorous about both accuracy and objectivity, trying their best to present the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth. These voices are like the media version of the <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/09/thinking-ladder.html#scientist\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Scientist</a> on the top rung of our <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/0-Thinking-Ladder.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Thinking Ladder</a>.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.2-media-matrix.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8792 size-medium\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.2-media-matrix-545x600.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"545\" height=\"600\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.2-media-matrix-545x600.png 545w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.2-media-matrix-768x845.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.2-media-matrix-682x750.png 682w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.2-media-matrix.png 826w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 545px) 100vw, 545px\" /></a></p> <p>Now let’s say this box represents reality:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.3-reality-box.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8793\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.3-reality-box.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"262\" height=\"303\" /></a></p> <p>Media near the North Star simply do their best to figure out what’s in that box and then convey it to their audiences.</p> <p>But as you move outwards a bit horizontally, bias begins to creep in. Brands here start to have an agenda beyond pure truth. They’ll tell most of the story, but they may omit certain especially-unhelpful-to-their-cause stories.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.8-media-matrix.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8794\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.8-media-matrix.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"545\" height=\"669\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.8-media-matrix.png 1042w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.8-media-matrix-489x600.png 489w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.8-media-matrix-768x943.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.8-media-matrix-611x750.png 611w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 545px) 100vw, 545px\" /></a></p> <p>All the way out in the upper corners, you have brands with a serious agenda—careful about accuracy but not at all about objectivity. Everything they report is carefully cherry-picked.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.9-media-matrix.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8795 size-full\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.9-media-matrix.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1689\" height=\"1269\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.9-media-matrix.png 1689w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.9-media-matrix-600x451.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.9-media-matrix-768x577.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.9-media-matrix-750x563.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1689px) 100vw, 1689px\" /></a></p> <p>As you move down in the Media Matrix, accuracy diminishes as a core value in favor of some other value more sacred to the brand—that value might be profit, entertainment, a political agenda, or something else. The goal of a news brand down here is to be a steadfast ally to their partisan audience and stay current with the latest fads and talking points in <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/12/political-disney-world.html#disney-world\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Political Disney World</a>, even if that means twisting stories, pulling quotes out of context, treating rumors as facts, or any other form of lying.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.10-media-matrix.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8796 size-full\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.10-media-matrix.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1702\" height=\"1509\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.10-media-matrix.png 1702w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.10-media-matrix-600x532.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.10-media-matrix-768x681.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.10-media-matrix-750x665.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1702px) 100vw, 1702px\" /></a></p> <p>To me, the distance between a brand’s location in the matrix and the North Star is a pretty good measure of its usefulness in the pursuit of truth. It’s inversely correlated—the longer the line, the less useful the brand is.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.12-media-matrix.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8797 size-medium\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.12-media-matrix-540x600.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"540\" height=\"600\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.12-media-matrix-540x600.png 540w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.12-media-matrix-768x853.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.12-media-matrix-675x750.png 675w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.12-media-matrix.png 809w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 540px) 100vw, 540px\" /></a></p> <p>But there’s another important metric here. So far, we’ve talked about where media brands are in the matrix. But each media brand really needs <em>two </em>circles—one for where they are and another—a yellow circle—for where they <em>claim </em>to be. The length of the yellow line connecting the two circles represents the brand’s level of <em>dishonesty</em>. So imagine two news shows are here:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.13-media-matrix.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8798 size-medium\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.13-media-matrix-545x600.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"545\" height=\"600\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.13-media-matrix-545x600.png 545w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.13-media-matrix-768x846.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.13-media-matrix-681x750.png 681w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.13-media-matrix.png 822w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 545px) 100vw, 545px\" /></a></p> <p>Now imagine that the host of Show A openly admits to their audience that they’re Democrats and make jokes about their own bias, their habit of pulling quotes out of context, etc. On the other hand, say Show B characterizes itself as serious and objective. Adding in the yellow circles, things would look like this:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.14-media-matrix.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8799 size-medium\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.14-media-matrix-542x600.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"542\" height=\"600\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.14-media-matrix-542x600.png 542w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.14-media-matrix-768x851.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.14-media-matrix-677x750.png 677w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.14-media-matrix.png 827w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 542px) 100vw, 542px\" /></a></p> <p>The black and yellow lines allow us to use the Media Matrix to grade news-presenting media voices of any kind—newspapers, TV networks, TV shows, podcasts, blogs, or individual columnists, anchors, podcasters, or bloggers—on two key criteria: usefulness and harm. In other words, positive and negative value, as it relates to what news is supposed to do: inform people of the truth.</p> <p>The shorter the black line, the more positive value a brand is providing. The <em>longer </em>the yellow line, the higher the brand’s negative value—the more harm it’s doing.</p> <p>Let’s use <a href=\"https://www.theonion.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><em>The Onion </em></a>as an example. <em>The Onion </em>offers lots of entertainment value, but it’s useless when it comes to informing people of the truth. <em>The Onion </em>is also very <em>openly</em> a satire brand. While it doesn’t do much to help its audience become more informed of reality, it doesn’t install a false sense of reality in them either, so it does <s>no</s>&nbsp;<a href=\"https://www.reddit.com/r/AteTheOnion/top/?t=all\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">little</a> harm.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.15-media-matrix.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8800 size-medium\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.15-media-matrix-542x600.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"542\" height=\"600\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.15-media-matrix-542x600.png 542w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.15-media-matrix-768x851.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.15-media-matrix-677x750.png 677w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.15-media-matrix.png 827w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 542px) 100vw, 542px\" /></a></p> <p>I use <em>The Onion </em>as a reminder that what harms society is not a brand’s Media Matrix location as much as its <em>dishonesty</em> about that location. News brands are rarely like <em>The Onion</em>—they typically claim to be squarely on the North Star. So if and when they ultimately present with bias and inaccuracy, it misleads their audience, filling them with real conviction without filling them with real knowledge.</p> <p>People will always disagree on which media brands are which level of biased/accurate, but at least the matrix can help us understand each other’s viewpoints, and the gaps between them, a bit more concretely.</p> <p>I can offer some of my own speculation. Looking broadly at the matrix, I’d guess that if you could take every presenter of news in the U.S. with a decent-sized audience and plot their actual location on the Media Matrix, you’d end up with many of them falling somewhere within an arch-shaped region—because bias and inaccuracy are probably often correlated.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.11-media-matrix-arch.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8801 size-medium\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.11-media-matrix-arch-556x600.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"556\" height=\"600\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.11-media-matrix-arch-556x600.png 556w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.11-media-matrix-arch-768x828.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.11-media-matrix-arch-695x750.png 695w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.11-media-matrix-arch.png 841w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 556px) 100vw, 556px\" /></a></p> <p><span style=\"font-size: inherit;\">I’d bet most of them claim to be entirely objective and accurate, leaving the North Star covered in yellow circles.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-size: inherit;\">I’d also bet that of the brands inside this arch, the average audience member lines up pretty well with our </span><a style=\"font-size: inherit;\" href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/09/thinking-ladder.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Thinking Ladder</a><span style=\"font-size: inherit;\">.</span></p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.11a-media-matrix-arch-ladder-V2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8866 size-medium\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.11a-media-matrix-arch-ladder-V2-556x600.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"556\" height=\"600\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.11a-media-matrix-arch-ladder-V2-556x600.png 556w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.11a-media-matrix-arch-ladder-V2-768x828.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.11a-media-matrix-arch-ladder-V2-695x750.png 695w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.11a-media-matrix-arch-ladder-V2.png 841w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 556px) 100vw, 556px\" /></a></p> <p>In any case, with this lens in mind, let’s look at two major recent media transformations:</p> <p style=\"font-size:28px\"><strong>Media Transformation #1: Broadcasting to Narrowcasting</strong></p> <p>In the 1980s, most Americans got their news from the Rather/Jennings/Brokaw trio on CBS, ABC, and NBC, and before them, from nationwide titans like Walter Cronkite. In those days, networks competed with each other for who could capture the largest share of American viewers. They were cautious to avoid seeming too politically biased and they knew that reporting a story incorrectly could lead to damaged credibility and a loss of viewers. So they had to be at least in the vicinity of the North Star.</p> <p>Some might argue that the people who ran these networks (along with those who ran the major newspapers at the time) were reasonably objective and accurate because those were the sacred values of those organizations. Those more cynical might argue that the mission was just to maximize profit, and that they presented news with reasonable objectivity and accuracy simply because they would have been penalized with a loss of viewers for not doing so. It’s hard to know for sure, because the media market was configured at the time such that the market incentives drove selfish media brands toward the North Star.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.16-media-matrix.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8856\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.16-media-matrix.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"541\" height=\"595\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.16-media-matrix.png 826w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.16-media-matrix-545x600.png 545w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.16-media-matrix-768x845.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.16-media-matrix-682x750.png 682w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 541px) 100vw, 541px\" /></a></p> <p>In recent decades, new technology has caused dramatic changes to the traditional media environment.</p> <p>First, there was <strong>the birth of cable television</strong> around 1980, and with it, the advent of cable news. CNN (which literally stands for Cable News Network) launched in 1980. Cable channels, burdened with fewer regulations and hazier expectations than mainstream networks, could be more experimental with the way they covered the news.</p> <p>Then there was <strong>the end of the</strong> <strong>Fairness Doctrine.</strong> In 1949, the FCC (the U.S. Federal Communications Commission) enacted the <a href=\"https://fas.org/sgp/crs/misc/R40009.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Fairness Doctrine</a>, which required anyone who held a broadcast license to present controversial issues of public importance in what they called an honest, equitable, and balanced manner. In 1987, in the face of arguments that the Fairness Doctrine was in direct conflict with the First Amendment’s freedom of the press clause, it was revoked.</p> <p>Not coincidentally, the demise of the Fairness Doctrine was soon followed by a sharp rise in blatantly politically biased media. Conservative talk radio exploded onto the scene in the late 1980s, most notably with <em>The Rush Limbaugh Show</em>, which debuted in 1988 and made Limbaugh the country’s most syndicated radio host by 1991. In 1996, <em>Fox News </em>and <em>MSNBC</em> were born.</p> <p>When I was in college, I went to see Ted Koppel (the anchor of ABC’s late-night news show <em>Nightline</em>) speak. I remember the host commenting that Koppel was famously secretive about his own political leanings. This was standard for a prominent anchor in the past, but by the end of the 1990s, a huge portion of Americans were getting their news from people whose political leaning was supremely out on the table.</p> <p>Then the internet sprung into our lives, and with it, sites like <em>The Drudge Report </em>(1995), <em>Slate </em>(1996)<em>, The Huffington Post </em>(2005), and <em>Breitbart</em> (2007), along with a trillion political blogs. The internet takes narrowcasting up into a new gear—full-fledged tribal media.</p> <p>Meanwhile, <em>Fox News </em>and conservative radio would continue to grow in size and influence, which was countered with a new genre of news TV on the Left—political talk shows. <em>The Daily Show </em>became a multi-decade sensation by serving as—depending on who you ask—either the voice of reason and sanity in the face of growing right-wing madness, or a show where elitist progressives would cackle as Jon Stewart relentlessly mocked their political outgroup. After Jon Stewart left, <em>The Daily Show</em> spawned, giving birth to a slew of similar “look at how awful the Right is” talk shows on even bigger stages.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#footnote-6-8757\" id=\"note-6-8757\" rel=\"footnote\">6</a> <p>Now, of course, this discussion will ruffle all kinds of feathers. People loyal to the Left will note that Fox News and conservative talk radio—which serve as the primary news outlets for a vast portion of the nation’s conservatives—are significantly more biased than their left-leaning counterparts. People loyal to the Right will argue back that what progressives think of as objective, mainstream news brands—both currently and in previous decades—are all actually quite left-leaning and the reason a brand like Fox News has to exist in the first place.</p> <p>There are <span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"http://adfontesmedia.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/01/Media-Bias-Chart_Version-3.1_Watermark-min.jpg\">all</a></span> <a href=\"https://www.adfontesmedia.com/interactive-media-bias-chart/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\">kinds</span></a> <a href=\"https://www.marketwatch.com/story/the-media-bias-chart-that-led-to-trumps-threat-to-regulate-google-2018-08-28\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\">of</span></a> <a href=\"https://i.redd.it/lmeh42e24ptz.png\"><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\">charts</span></a> online taking a crack at displaying major news brands along a political bias axis. The problem is, the people who create those charts might be biased themselves, which we know from <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/09/thinking-ladder.html#trains\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Chapter 7</a> will skew their judgment (if they’re even trying to be accurate). The closest I could find to something that seemed intent on using an objective methodology to lay things out is this chart, from a site called <a href=\"https://www.allsides.com/media-bias/media-bias-chart\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">AllSides</a> (vertical position is meaningless):</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/media-chart.jpg\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8804 \" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/media-chart-545x600.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"613\" height=\"675\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/media-chart-545x600.jpg 545w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/media-chart-768x845.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/media-chart-682x750.jpg 682w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/media-chart.jpg 1531w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 613px) 100vw, 613px\" /></a></p> <p>The difficult thing about topics where bias is both rampant and hard to quantify is that it’s hard to feel confident in anything you read. When I ran this chart by a mix of friends, a highly conservative friend (we’ll call him Bill LeMean) responded with <img src=\"https://s.w.org/images/core/emoji/12.0.0-1/72x72/1f644.png\" alt=\"🙄\" class=\"wp-smiley\" style=\"height: 1em; max-height: 1em;\" />. When I asked him for clarification, Bill went on a tirade about how absurd it is to put brands like the AP and Reuters in the center and not further left, finishing with some angry thing about “The Precious,” which is his term for how he thinks I think of Obama. So who knows. Bill LeMean certainly has his own biases—but I also haven’t read enough AP or Reuters to judge whether he’s making a good point here or not.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#footnote-7-8757\" id=\"note-7-8757\" rel=\"footnote\">7</a> <p>Part of the reason it’s so hard to figure out media bias levels is that it’s one of the areas where we’re all craziest. There’s a phenomenon called the “hostile media effect,” which says that people on both sides <a href=\"https://www.researchgate.net/publication/281191995_A_Three-Decade_Retrospective_on_the_Hostile_Media_Effect\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">tend to see</a> the media as biased against their camp, even when they’re looking at the <a href=\"https://www.ssc.wisc.edu/~jpiliavi/965/hwang.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">exact same coverage</a>.</p> <p>But there are some interesting stats out there that can offer clues. Like this chart, from <a href=\"https://www.journalism.org/2014/10/21/political-polarization-media-habits/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Pew</a>:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/media-chart-2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8805\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/media-chart-2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"702\" height=\"631\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/media-chart-2.png 640w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/media-chart-2-600x539.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 702px) 100vw, 702px\" /></a></p> <p>Or <a href=\"https://www.journalism.org/2014/10/21/political-polarization-media-habits/pj_14-10-21_mediapolarization-01/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">this one</a>:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/media-trust.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8806\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/media-trust.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"500\" height=\"966\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/media-trust.png 420w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/media-trust-310x600.png 310w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/media-trust-388x750.png 388w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 500px) 100vw, 500px\" /></a></p> <p>These don’t tell us about the bias levels of media brands, but they do tell us how the brands are viewed by the public. Looking at these charts, I can speculate how a vicious cycle could take place. Once the conservative media brands launch, many conservatives frustrated with the mainstream media would defect to them. Without those conservatives, the mainstream media has an audience that’s now overall more left-leaning than it used to be. To cater to their audience, they’ll probably start leaning a bit more left themselves—which causes more moderate conservatives to defect to the right-leaning brands. Meanwhile, with an audience made up almost entirely of conservatives, right-leaning media can move further right with little pushback, knowing that even their more moderate viewers will stick with them over the left-leaning options.</p> <p>We can also look at the people who work at the media brands. One trend that gives credence to the notion that mainstream media is moving further left is the increasing nonexistence of openly Republican journalists.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#footnote2-15-8757\" id=\"note2-15-8757\" rel=\"footnote2\">15</a> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/124.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8807\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/124.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"700\" height=\"506\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/124.png 1698w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/124-600x433.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/124-768x555.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/124-750x542.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px\" /></a></p> <p>Fortunately, we don’t need to have all the answers here. What’s important for our purposes is the bigger trend in play: broadcasting has given way to narrowcasting. And the narrowcasting market works differently than the broadcasting market. With more politically homogenous audiences, the market demand for truth goes down a little bit in favor of an increased demand for viewpoint confirmation. Likewise, unfair bias against politicians most of the audience dislikes is no longer penalized by the market—and is perhaps even rewarded with a more loyal audience. In a world of narrowcasting, the market incentives magnet is no longer located at the North Star.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.17-media-matrix-1.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8808 size-medium\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.17-media-matrix-1-545x600.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"545\" height=\"600\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.17-media-matrix-1-545x600.png 545w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.17-media-matrix-1-768x845.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.17-media-matrix-1-682x750.png 682w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.17-media-matrix-1.png 826w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 545px) 100vw, 545px\" /></a></p> <h3><span style=\"font-size: inherit;\">Political Junk Food</span></h3> <p><span style=\"font-size: inherit;\">Remember this scene from Chapter 7?</span></p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/5.1-skittles-V2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8867 size-full\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/5.1-skittles-V2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1641\" height=\"1564\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/5.1-skittles-V2.png 1641w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/5.1-skittles-V2-600x572.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/5.1-skittles-V2-768x732.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/5.1-skittles-V2-750x715.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1641px) 100vw, 1641px\" /></a></p> <p>Every business knows that the easiest way to make money is to sell directly to the simple, predictable Primitive Mind.</p> <p>To sell food to the Higher Mind, you have to worry about quality and nutrition, which is expensive and hard. Instead, you can sell Skittles to the Primitive Mind, which mistakes them for nutritious food.</p> <p>Selling magazines to the Higher Mind is also hard. Much easier to just put a young, firm, symmetrical person on the cover with the word “SEX” written in big letters next to them and market directly to the Primitive Mind.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/5.2-magazines.jpg\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8811\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/5.2-magazines.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1995\" height=\"2041\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/5.2-magazines.jpg 1995w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/5.2-magazines-586x600.jpg 586w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/5.2-magazines-768x786.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/5.2-magazines-733x750.jpg 733w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1995px) 100vw, 1995px\" /></a></p> <p>The Primitive Mind sees the same thing when it looks at a Skittles wrapper and a Cosmo cover—genetic survival.</p> <p>In the world of U.S. politics, the junk food rack looks like this:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?attachment_id=8812\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8812\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/5.3-clickbait.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1400\" height=\"2841\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/5.3-clickbait.jpg 3466w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/5.3-clickbait-296x600.jpg 296w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/5.3-clickbait-768x1559.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/5.3-clickbait-370x750.jpg 370w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1400px) 100vw, 1400px\" /></a></p> <p>The luscious confirmation promised by headlines like those looks as delectable to the Primitive Mind as the sweet sustenance promised by a Skittles wrapper. When everyone got their news from CBS, ABC, and NBC, this kind of hyper-partisan clickbait wouldn’t have worked, because when the whole country is your audience, you can’t confirm everyone’s political views at once. Narrowcast brands don’t have that same restraint. That’s how you end up with actual circles of destruction. (click for a bigger view)</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/5.4-destroy@0.5x.jpg\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8813\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/5.4-destroy@0.5x.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"2250\" height=\"2117\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/5.4-destroy@0.5x.jpg 2250w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/5.4-destroy@0.5x-600x565.jpg 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/5.4-destroy@0.5x-768x723.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/5.4-destroy@0.5x-750x706.jpg 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 2250px) 100vw, 2250px\" /></a></p> <p>Seeing “DESTROYS” next to the name of a political figure you hate is kind of like seeing “SEX” next to a picture of a person you want to have sex with. An irresistible fishhook for the Primitive Mind.</p> <p>Political junk food has nothing to do with learning—the headlines tell you from the get-go which side will win and which side will lose. Its purpose is to combine three of the Primitive Mind’s favorite things: viewpoint/identity confirmation, outgroup bashing, and gossip. Primitive Mind crack.</p> <h3>A Politics Reality Show</h3> <p>Broadcast TV news tried, at least a little, to be a show about reality. Narrowcast news tries to be a reality show. Big difference.</p> <p>Reality is interesting sometimes. Reality shows are interesting all the time. Reality shows aren’t about reality, they’re about entertainment—so reality show producers manufacture a carefully edited, fictional version of reality that’s wildly entertaining, and super addictive. And what’s the reality TV producer’s best trick? Drama and negativity. Would anyone watch <em>The Real Housewives of Beverly Hills </em>if the characters got along most of the time? Of course not. That’s why every five minutes of the show includes a conflict of some kind.</p> <p>As soon as you realize that news media is also entertainment media, the constant coverage of conflict and drama makes perfect sense.</p> <p>In the U.S., most of us are addicted to a trashy reality show called <em>The Real Politicians of Washington.</em><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#footnote-8-8757\" id=\"note-8-8757\" rel=\"footnote\">8</a> \n                 <div id=\"“eggTen”\">\n                  <div id=\"image-map-pro-6346\"></div>\n                 </div> \n                 <div style=\"height:38px\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"wp-block-spacer\"></div> <p>There are whole teams of heroes and villains, lots of ongoing storylines, and endless conflict. It’s a perfect vehicle for a dramatic, super-addictive soap opera.</p> <p>It’s not that these heavily featured politicians or the super played-up storylines are unimportant. It’s that we receive a totally <em>skewed</em> depiction of the full set of relevant political issues. The issues that make headlines day in and day out are usually overrepresented, while lots of other important political stories—like the bills being passed each week by the <a href=\"https://www.congress.gov/committees\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">52 House and Senate committees</a>—are severely underreported.</p> <p>I recently had a chance to talk with a Congressman named <a href=\"https://kilmer.house.gov/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Derek Kilmer</a>. Kilmer is the head of a House coalition called <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Democrats\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">The New Democrats</a>. Here’s how they describe themselves:</p> <p><em>The New Democrat Coalition is made up of 103 forward-thinking Democrats who are committed to pro-economic growth, pro-innovation, and fiscally responsible policies. New Democrats are a solutions oriented coalition seeking to bridge the gap between left and right by challenging outmoded partisan approaches to governing. New Democrats believe the challenges ahead are too great for Members of Congress to refuse to cooperate purely out of partisanship. </em></p> <p>Snoooooooooze. The editors of <em>Real Politicians </em>waste no airtime on this kind of shit because it’s nuanced and productive and boring as fuck. Kilmer is full of measured, well-thought-out ideas for how to make the country better and I’m falling asleep just writing this sentence.</p> <p>Actual politics, like actual reality, is boring to most people. So tribal media brands do what reality producers do—they manufacture a carefully edited, fictional version of politics that’s wildly entertaining.</p> <p>That’s why most Americans who will tell you they’re super passionate about politics can barely name ten current members of Congress. They probably can’t name all the U.S. representatives for their state, let alone members of their <em>state</em> legislatures. But they <em>can</em> tell you about the 15 or 20 politicians chosen by the media to be the main characters on <em>Real Politicians</em>, along with the 5 or 10 hot-button issues being featured on the show in any given month.</p> <p>Among many others, one reason this is bad is that there are lots of people in the U.S. who want to make the country better, and <em>The Real Politicians of Washington </em>misleads most of them on where they should be directing their efforts.</p> <p>Take a look at this data:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#footnote2-16-8757\" id=\"note2-16-8757\" rel=\"footnote2\">16</a> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/environment.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8814\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/environment.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"500\" height=\"547\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/environment.png 1224w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/environment-548x600.png 548w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/environment-768x841.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/environment-685x750.png 685w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 500px) 100vw, 500px\" /></a></p> <p>The data surprised me, as I’m sure it surprises many of you. The storyline I’ve been presented with is this:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/7.1-environment.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8815\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/7.1-environment.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"550\" height=\"373\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/7.1-environment.png 1299w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/7.1-environment-600x406.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/7.1-environment-768x520.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/7.1-environment-750x508.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/7.1-environment-782x530.png 782w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/7.1-environment-345x234.png 345w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/7.1-environment-103x70.png 103w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 550px) 100vw, 550px\" /></a></p> <p>But the actual data above looks more like this:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/7.2-environment.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8816\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/7.2-environment.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"525\" height=\"503\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/7.2-environment.png 1192w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/7.2-environment-600x575.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/7.2-environment-768x736.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/7.2-environment-750x719.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 525px) 100vw, 525px\" /></a></p> <p>Which we could rearrange like this:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/7.3-environment.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8817\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/7.3-environment.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"549\" height=\"372\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/7.3-environment.png 1299w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/7.3-environment-600x406.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/7.3-environment-768x520.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/7.3-environment-750x508.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/7.3-environment-782x530.png 782w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/7.3-environment-345x234.png 345w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/7.3-environment-103x70.png 103w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 549px) 100vw, 549px\" /></a></p> <p>Very different story. Of course it’s also true that Republican politicians, especially the current president, have often been dismissive of climate change. And “taking environmental action” is not necessarily the same as “taking action to curb emissions.” But the actual reality according to the survey makes me feel very differently about what kinds of strategies climate change activists should be using in order to build the necessarily coalition to change our trajectory. Presenting an inaccurate version of reality breeds displaced anger and division and hurts our ability to move toward important goals—all in the name of editing the politics reality show to be more entertaining with crisper, juicier storylines.</p> <p>The most dramatic events on <em>Real Politicians </em>are elections. Elections are the show’s climaxes. And the show’s editors make sure to over-dramatize the shit out of them.</p> <p>This is the past century of U.S. presidential elections.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/8-Zig-Zag-presidents-v2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8870 size-full\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/8-Zig-Zag-presidents-v2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"2084\" height=\"700\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/8-Zig-Zag-presidents-v2.png 2084w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/8-Zig-Zag-presidents-v2-600x202.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/8-Zig-Zag-presidents-v2-768x258.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/8-Zig-Zag-presidents-v2-750x252.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 2084px) 100vw, 2084px\" /></a></p> <p>It’s a clear zig-zag pattern. Which makes sense. Citizens are typically not that happy with their lives, and it’s a natural impulse to blame the government for our problems. It’s also our impulse to naively believe that our favorite new politician will be able to fix all those problems, if only they could win the presidency. So after a single party has held down the presidency for a while, the country, still unhappy, decides that it’s time to vote for the other party.</p> <p>And yet—I remember when Bush won reelection in 2004, everyone in the media was talking about how Democrats just weren’t able to win in politics anymore for a number of what-seemed-like-rock-solid sociological theories. Then the Democrats swept the midterms in 2006 and the presidency in 2008.</p> <p>I remember in 2012, when Obama won reelection, hearing people say that the country had fundamentally shifted, and there were way more Hispanic immigrants than there used to be, and the Tea Party had rendered the Republican party irrelevant, and all of this other proof that times had changed and the Democrats wouldn’t ever lose a presidential election again.</p> <p>Then Republicans swept all three branches of government in 2016, at which point I read all these articles about how the Left is more <em>culturally</em> powerful but the Right is simply more <em>politically </em>powerful. I also heard a bunch of stuff about how gerrymandering ensured that the Democrats would never win back the House again. Then the Democrats won the House in 2018.</p> <p>Media channels are for-profit businesses in a marketplace, behaving rationally. When people care about entertainment and confirmation more than truth, you end up with skewed coverage, over-dramatized storylines, and <a href=\"https://reason.com/2019/01/20/covington-catholic-nathan-phillips-video/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">lots</a> and <a href=\"https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2019/10/on-ukraine-its-hard-to-tell-fox-news-and-4chan-apart/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">lots</a> and <a href=\"https://twitter.com/juliagalef/status/894092020494381056\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">lots</a> and <a href=\"https://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2016/nov/04/conservative-daily-post/evidence-ridiculously-thin-sensational-claim-huge-/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">lots</a> and <a href=\"https://www.washingtonexaminer.com/news/new-york-times-corrects-story-on-nikki-haleys-curtains\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">lots</a> and <a href=\"https://www.infowars.com/spirit-cooking-clinton-campaign-chairman-invited-to-bizarre-satanic-performance/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">lots</a> and <a href=\"https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/donald-trump/disputed-buzzfeed-story-trump-cohen-back-limelight-after-mueller-report-n996131\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">lots</a> and <a href=\"https://www.politifact.com/punditfact/statements/2019/dec/18/tucker-carlson/carlson-falsely-claims-immigrants-are-dirtying-pot/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">lots</a> and <a href=\"https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2018/06/22/girl-time-magazine-cover-never-separated-mom-father-says/725499002/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">lots</a> and <a href=\"https://www.foxnews.com/politics/statement-on-coverage-of-seth-rich-murder-investigation\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">lots</a> and <a href=\"https://www.vox.com/2018/9/5/17821946/white-power-hand-signal-brett-kavanaugh-confirmation-hearing-zina-bash-4chan\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">lots</a> of fake news.</p> <p>In some ways, this is the return of an old story. The broadcast news era was something of an anomaly, generated by the advent of television. Before that, super partisan newspapers were common. James Baughman <a href=\"https://ethics.journalism.wisc.edu/2011/04/20/the-fall-and-rise-of-partisan-journalism/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">writes</a> about political media in the 19<sup>th</sup> century:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#footnote2-17-8757\" id=\"note2-17-8757\" rel=\"footnote2\">17</a> <p><em>“Editors,” wrote one historian, “unabashedly shaped the news and their editorial comment to partisan purposes. They sought to convert the doubters, recover the wavering, and hold the committed. ‘The power of the press,’ one journalist candidly explained, ‘consists not in its logic or eloquence, but in its ability to manufacture facts, or to give coloring to facts that have occurred.’”</em></p> <p>But in other important ways, this is a totally unprecedented media landscape.</p> <p>Most notably, we have the internet. And one special kind of internet magic would be the source of a second key transformation to the media environment.</p> <p style=\"font-size:28px\"><strong>Media Transformation #2: Algorithms</strong></p> <p>Normally, I appreciate the Google search algorithm. It filters results that are most relevant to where I live and what I’m typically interested in, and it can guess remarkably well what I want to search for after I type just a few letters, saving me the trouble of typing the whole search.</p> <p>I appreciate the YouTube algorithm, which knows my favorite channels and makes sure I never miss their latest videos.</p> <p>I appreciate the Facebook algorithm, which spares me the knowledge of what Johnny from high school 20 years ago made for dinner last night while making sure to let me know when Johnny gets engaged, so I can go look through his most recent 87 photos to see the deal with his fiancé.</p> <p>Internet algorithms are usually good things, and very helpful.</p> <p>But new technology often comes along with unintended, unanticipated consequences.</p> <p>When I’m watching a YouTube video and I glance at the thumbnails on the sidebar, I’m more likely to click on a video featuring someone explaining history or science than I am to click on a video featuring someone reviewing movies. YouTube has picked up on that, which is why I never see movie review videos on my YouTube sidebar, but I’m constantly being introduced to great new history or science explainer videos.</p> <p>But then one night last year someone sent me a funny video a driver took with their phone. The driver taking the video had pissed off another driver, who opened his window and cursed out the driver. The angry driver got so worked up that he swung his arm at the video-taking driver angrily, and in the process, punched his own side mirror off. A delight of all delights.</p> <p>Then the video ended, and YouTube offered me my choice of nine more videos in the road rage genre. I clicked on one of them and watched it. Then YouTube offered me nine more. I had a lot of work to do, so I held down the Command key and clicked on all nine, opening them in nine new tabs, and watched them all. Two<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#footnote-9-8757\" id=\"note-9-8757\" rel=\"footnote\">9</a> hours later, utterly disgusted with myself, I pulled the dramatic “punishing Chrome by holding down Command-Q and closing all eight Chrome windows and all 127 of their open tabs” move. A nightmare waste of time. But at least it was over.</p> <p>Except it wasn’t over. Somewhere out there, the YouTube algorithm was lining its Tim Urban fishhook with the best of the best road rage videos, which have reliably appeared in my YouTube sidebar ever since that regrettable night, damning me to an entire life wasted watching delightful road rage videos.</p> <p>Internet algorithms are profit-maximizing mechanisms that want to spoon feed me whatever I’m most likely to click on. This is a win-win, symbiotic relationship—until it’s not. When an algorithm is catering to your Higher Mind, it’s your friend. When it’s luring in your Primitive Mind against your Higher Mind’s will, the relationship is parasitic.</p> <p>So how does this apply to politics? What happens when your Higher Mind knows it’s important to challenge your beliefs and likes to click links representing a variety of viewpoints—but your Primitive Mind wants to click only on links that will further confirm and strengthen your existing viewpoints? Both minds will get some clicks in there—and overall, that might yield 75% clicks on confirmation links and only 25% clicks on dissent links.</p> <p>It won’t take long for the algorithms to start treating political confirmation links like my YouTube treated road rage videos. Soon, your Google searches and YouTube searches will turn up <a href=\"https://www.ted.com/talks/eli_pariser_beware_online_filter_bubbles?language=en\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">only confirmation links</a>.</p> <p>The geographic and information bubbles don’t leave much room for air. As <a href=\"http://www.thebigsort.com/home.php\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><em>The Big Sort</em></a> author Bill Bishop puts it: “We now live in a giant feedback loop, hearing our own thoughts about what’s right and wrong bounced back to us by the television shows we watch, the newspapers and books we read, the blogs we visit online, the sermons we hear and the neighbourhoods we live in.”</p> <p>On social media, the effects of the two bubbles are multiplied. Most of our newsfeeds are insular networks made up of people who get their info from the same filter bubble we do. In 2017, PNAS <a href=\"https://www.pnas.org/content/early/2017/06/20/1618923114\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">analyzed</a> over half a million tweets about three politically polarizing topics: gun control, same-sex marriage, and climate change. Using an algorithm that estimated the political leaning of each account, they examined the accounts that retweeted each tweet. The findings? Political tweets are almost entirely retweeted by those who agree with the tweet, to followers who also almost entirely agree with the tweet. They visualized these findings, which shows the tweets almost exclusively bouncing around a single Echo Chamber, with little chance to change anyone’s mind. A frenzy of confirmation:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#footnote2-18-8757\" id=\"note2-18-8757\" rel=\"footnote2\">18</a> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/retweets.jpg\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8819\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/retweets.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1280\" height=\"607\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/retweets.jpg 1280w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/retweets-600x285.jpg 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/retweets-768x364.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/retweets-750x356.jpg 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1280px) 100vw, 1280px\" /></a></p> <p>Even when there are exceptions—well-worded dissenting tweets that end up on people’s feeds—they have a hard time spreading, because social media is saturated with peer pressure to conform ideologically and shame those who dare challenge the narrative.</p> <p>On top of all that, social media provides another unfortunate filter: it dumbs down complex information. In an <a href=\"https://ncase.me/crowds/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">interactive about crowds</a>, Nicky Case explains: “Ideas don’t pass perfectly from one person to another the way a virus does. Like a game of Telephone, the message gets mutated with each re-telling…so, over time, ideas ‘evolve’ to be more catchy, copy-able, contagious.” Since complexity and catchiness are often inversely correlated, the super connectedness offered by the internet may actually <em>hinder </em>the spread of complex ideas.</p> <p>Putting this all together, the internet quickly becomes a downward magnet on your psyche. You may be a high-rung thinker interested in hearing a wide array of ideas and becoming more knowledgeable, but the internet is likely to push you in the opposite direction, even if it’s hard to see that it’s happening.</p> <p style=\"font-size:28px\"><strong>Separate Realities</strong></p> <p>When most of us hear about growing political polarization, we assume it means citizens are divided in their values. That people are unable to agree about “What Should Be”:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/7.1-3-Questions.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8442 size-medium\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/7.1-3-Questions-600x425.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"425\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/7.1-3-Questions-600x425.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/7.1-3-Questions-768x544.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/7.1-3-Questions-750x531.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/7.1-3-Questions.png 1165w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a></p> <p>But take another look at the 10 questions the Pew polarization graphs are based on:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/128a.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8765\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/128a.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"746\" height=\"581\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/128a.png 1842w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/128a-600x467.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/128a-768x598.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/128a-750x584.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 746px) 100vw, 746px\" /></a></p> <p>Only <em>one </em>of them is a philosophical question of values—a <em>What Should Be</em> question: the question about homosexuality. And that’s the question where the country has moved most closely in the same direction, as both parties follow a general national trend.</p> <p>The other nine questions above aren’t philosophical questions about values—they’re questions about <em>What Is</em>.</p> <p><em>The Wall Street Journal </em>had a great interactive feature called <a href=\"http://graphics.wsj.com/blue-feed-red-feed\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><em>Blue Feed, Red Feed</em></a> that let you see how the same topics are presented on social media to people on the Right and the Left (they stopped updating it earlier this year, but you can still see a sampling). Whether the topic is Trump, healthcare, guns, abortion, ISIS, the budget, or immigration, opposing political camps are not just seeing different slants on the same story—they’re being presented two entirely different realities.</p> <p>The Right and the Left do disagree on some values:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#footnote2-19-8757\" id=\"note2-19-8757\" rel=\"footnote2\">19</a> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/140-V2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8857\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/140-V2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"552\" height=\"787\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/140-V2.png 1042w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/140-V2-421x600.png 421w,
