http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/140-V2-768x1095.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/140-V2-526x750.png 526w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 552px) 100vw, 552px\" /></a></p> <p>They just disagree way <em>more</em> on reality:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#footnote2-20-8757\" id=\"note2-20-8757\" rel=\"footnote2\">20</a> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/128b-V2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8858\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/128b-V2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"558\" height=\"810\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/128b-V2.png 1052w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/128b-V2-413x600.png 413w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/128b-V2-768x1115.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/128b-V2-516x750.png 516w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 558px) 100vw, 558px\" /></a></p> <p>If market incentive magnets have indeed moved from the North Star region closer to the lower corners, separate realities would be a natural consequence.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.18-media-matrix-reality.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8822 size-full\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.18-media-matrix-reality.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1956\" height=\"2153\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.18-media-matrix-reality.png 1956w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.18-media-matrix-reality-545x600.png 545w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.18-media-matrix-reality-768x845.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.18-media-matrix-reality-681x750.png 681w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1956px) 100vw, 1956px\" /></a></p> <p>In today’s politics, if you forget that A) your perception of reality has probably been at least a little manipulated, and B) your opponents are behaving the way they are based on a perception of reality that’s different from your own—you’re bound to get things wrong.</p> \n                      <div class=\"wbwAside\"> \n                       <h3><strong>The Time I Was a Trump Voter Blue Box</strong></h3> \n                       <p>I had a funny experience doing research for this series. I came into it crystal clear on what people on the Left generally think, how they think, and why. So the first order of business was a deep dive into what people on the Right—especially Trump voters—were saying, and why. I dug into conservative news sites, conservative blogs, conservative YouTube channels, conservative Reddit forums.</p> \n                       <p>And a funny thing happened. The internet noticed, and it went for the full indoctrination.</p> \n                       <p>Suddenly, it didn’t matter what I was watching on YouTube—it could be <a href=\"https://youtu.be/Fend1-nnNKk?t=7\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">a group of slippery Japanese people trying to climb stairs</a>—and I’d glance at my sidebar and see this:</p> \n                       <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?attachment_id=8823\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8823\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/9-trump-sidebar.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"699\" height=\"1879\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/9-trump-sidebar.png 1773w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/9-trump-sidebar-223x600.png 223w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/9-trump-sidebar-768x2064.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/9-trump-sidebar-279x750.png 279w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 699px) 100vw, 699px\" /></a></p> \n                       <p>It wasn’t just YouTube. The algorithms were serving me the pro-Trump Bento Box. Reddit and Quora started sending me emails with links to pro-Trump threads. Twitter started recommending conservative accounts for me to follow. And it went beyond pro-Trump material. As far as the internet was concerned, these were now the Clintons:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#footnote2-21-8757\" id=\"note2-21-8757\" rel=\"footnote2\">21</a> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/hillary-witch.gif\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8824\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/hillary-witch.gif\" alt=\"\" width=\"552\" height=\"414\" /></a></p> <p>It didn’t change my views on Trump very much—but it <em>did </em>change my thoughts about his voters. Before, I had been fed a steady diet of “Trump is a huge bigot, Trump voters know he’s a huge bigot, and they voted for him because they’re huge bigots too.” But now the internet thought I was a Trump voter, and suddenly almost nothing I was seeing about Trump made him seem like a bigot. In the new depictions, he still seemed like a bit of a blowhard, but one that was unafraid to stand up to a corrupt, elite establishment and that was determined to help a losing America start winning again. The anti-Trump crowd I knew were making the mistake of looking at the version of Trump they were seeing and assuming his voters were voting for that guy. But his voters didn’t know that Trump. They knew the version of Trump <em>they </em>were seeing, and <em>that’s </em>the guy they were voting for.</p> <p>Of course, some of the most damning things that came out about Trump during the campaign were seen by everybody. Everyone in every information bubble heard Trump grab people by the pussy, criticize McCain for being captured in Vietnam, mock a disabled reporter, and stereotype illegal Mexican immigrants as rapists. But in their information bubble, they were seeing moments like these once or twice, not 20,000 times—and when compared to their bubble’s depiction of Wicked Hillary of the West, the evil treasonous criminal who threatened Bill’s sex victims and called the working class “deplorable,” I see how Trump might appear the lesser villain.</p> <p>I came out of the whole thing feeling like I understood the Trump phenomenon a little better, and the Left’s chorus of “Trump voters are all white supremacists!” began to seem over-confident, under-informed, and not very productive.</p> <p>If you’re thinking about politics without regularly asking yourself, “What does this look/feel like to the people I don’t know?”, you’re going to get a lot of things wrong. Which ultimately makes you less politically effective.</p> </p>\n                      </div> <p>Losing our grip on reality is an unnerving idea in general. But there’s one particular kind of delusion that keeps me up at night.</p> <p>Recently, I noticed <a href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2018/12/25/us/gofundme-scam-refunds-trnd/index.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">this headline</a> on CNN.com:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/127.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8825\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/127.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"502\" height=\"102\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/127.png 2052w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/127-600x122.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/127-768x156.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/127-750x153.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 502px) 100vw, 502px\" /></a></p> <p>I wanted to not click on that, but the computer and I both knew that I had no choice. So here’s what happened: a homeless man came across a woman after she had run out of gas on the side of the interstate, with no money. The homeless man told her to wait safely in her car while he walked over to a nearby gas station and, spending his last $20, bought gas and brought it back to her. The woman then went home and started a GoFundMe campaign to “pay it forward” and raise money for the homeless man.</p> <p>When we read a feel-good story like this, it poofs away the fog in our heads for a moment because it reminds us how many good people there are out there and how much generosity and kind-heartedness there is in the world. It makes our Primitive Minds feel safe, which calms them down, and it empowers our Higher Mind. <a href=\"https://www.pnas.org/content/107/12/5334\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">High-mindedness is contagious</a>,<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#footnote-10-8757\" id=\"note-10-8757\" rel=\"footnote\">10</a> and the high-mindedness of the homeless man in the story traveled through the internet and infected 14,000 people, who donated a combined $400,000 to the homeless man. It was a beautiful moment.</p> <p>Until the woman, the woman’s boyfriend, and the homeless man got caught. The homeless man (Bobbitt) really was homeless, but the whole story had been made up by the three of them as a get-rich-quick scheme. The article explains: “Bobbitt received $75,000, and within months McClure and D’Amico had ‘squandered’ their share to buy a car, high-end handbags and trips…they also used it at casinos.”</p> <p>Quite the crew.</p> <p>At the very end of the article, there was a quote from GoFundMe’s spokesman:</p> <p><em>It’s important to understand that misuse is very rare on our platform. Campaigns with misuse make up less than one tenth of one percent of all campaigns.</em></p> <p>In other words, this is reality:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/10.1-gofundme-new-V2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8860\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/10.1-gofundme-new-V2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"556\" height=\"413\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/10.1-gofundme-new-V2.png 1013w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/10.1-gofundme-new-V2-600x446.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/10.1-gofundme-new-V2-768x571.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/10.1-gofundme-new-V2-750x558.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 556px) 100vw, 556px\" /></a></p> <p>And if we knew more about the thousands of genuinely heartwarming GoFundMe stories that happen every year, it would strengthen our trust and love networks and boost kind-heartedness and generosity. Those kinds of stories are like positive viruses that, when spread, strengthen society.</p> <p>But in the reality show editing room at CNN.com, they see this:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/10.2-gofundme-new-V2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8861\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/10.2-gofundme-new-V2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"562\" height=\"442\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/10.2-gofundme-new-V2.png 958w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/10.2-gofundme-new-V2-600x472.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/10.2-gofundme-new-V2-768x604.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/10.2-gofundme-new-V2-750x590.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 562px) 100vw, 562px\" /></a></p> <p>Of all the people that saw the article’s headline, only a tiny fraction will end up reading the quote from GoFundMe at the bottom of the article. Everyone else just sees the headline, and lots of other similar headlines over the years, and they develop the intuition that things like GoFundMe are pretty “scammy”:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/10.3-gofundme-new-V2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8859\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/10.3-gofundme-new-V2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"502\" height=\"544\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/10.3-gofundme-new-V2.png 696w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/10.3-gofundme-new-V2-555x600.png 555w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/10.3-gofundme-new-V2-693x750.png 693w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 502px) 100vw, 502px\" /></a></p> <p>Trust is a society’s most precious resource, and a strong trust network does amazing things, like donating $400,000 to a homeless man. But trust takes decades to build up and is easily shattered. In the case of a scam like this, 14,000 people reached out lovingly to another member of society, and their hands were zapped by an electroshocker. Their trust was shaken and replaced by cynicism.</p> <p>On its own, this scam wouldn’t do much harm to society. Unless, of course, the news plasters the scam all over their front pages. When that happens, 14,000 people have their outreached hands painfully shocked—and 10,000,000 more people watch it happen.</p> <p>A scam is like a virus that converts trust into cynicism, but it’s the news, in the name of keeping things entertaining and addictive, that distributes the virus across the whole country.</p> <p>We can call this phenomenon—where the news cherry-picks stories that weaken society and spreads them—“destructive cherry-picking.”</p> <p>Destructive cherry-picking breeds fear, anger, and cynicism. It’s why we always think crime is getting worse even though it’s almost always getting better.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#footnote2-22-8757\" id=\"note2-22-8757\" rel=\"footnote2\">22</a> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/crime.jpg\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8829\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/crime.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1170\" height=\"1200\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/crime.jpg 1170w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/crime-585x600.jpg 585w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/crime-768x788.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/crime-731x750.jpg 731w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1170px) 100vw, 1170px\" /></a></p> <p>But to me, the most damaging form of destructive cherry-picking is the kind that spreads <em>hate</em>.</p> <p>Nicky Case made a killer simulation about this phenomenon too. It’s fun and quick—<a href=\"https://ncase.itch.io/wbwwb\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">give it a try</a>.</p> <p> </p> <p>Portraying a society where everyone is a GoFundMe scammer damages trust. Portraying a society where crime is rampant spreads fear.</p> <p>But portraying a society where everyone hates each other is the most dangerous virus of all, because it becomes a self-fulfilling prophecy.</p> <p>Geographic bubbles mean many people barely know anyone on the other political side personally, so the only information they have on what those people are like comes from information bubbles. And those bubbles have increasingly become hate-mongering machines. The right-wing information bubble floods viewers with anecdotes that make it seem like everyone on the Left positively despises them and everything they stand for. What a Republican from a small town hears from the Left is: “you’re stupid, you’re ignorant, you’re a bigot, you’re privileged, your values are wrong, your religion is bad, you’re toxic, you’re backward, you’re selfish, you’re a Nazi.” Through the left-wing information bubble, all a Mexican-American living in Los Angeles hears from the Right is: “you’re a criminal, you’re a rapist, you’re not a real American, you’re stealing our jobs, you’re inferior, you don’t belong here, and we’re coming for you.” Outrage about these messages then spreads like wildfire on social media, because as CGP Grey explains in a fun/upsetting video, <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rE3j_RHkqJc\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">nothing spreads faster than anger</a>—especially anger in the specific format, “Just <em>look </em>at how <em>awful</em> the people we hate are.”<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#footnote-11-8757\" id=\"note-11-8757\" rel=\"footnote\">11</a> <p>Vocal Primitive Minds activate other Primitive Minds. Filtering a steady stream of “they <em>hate </em>you” to people jolts awake the recipients’ Primitive Minds, filling them with reciprocal hatred, clouding their humanity, and flipping on that ancient tribal switch that makes people want to band together into giants for safety. The resulting anger is, in turn, filtered back over to the other side.</p> <p>This most troubling thing about this kind of vicious cycle is that it fosters what may be the most dangerous word in the English language.</p> <p style=\"font-size:32px\"><strong>Disgust</strong></p> <p>Like happiness, sadness, anger, and fear, disgust is a <a href=\"https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/blog/hide-and-seek/201601/what-are-basic-emotions\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">basic emotion</a>, hardwired into all humans. Travel to any country in the world and basic emotions will be expressed similarly. That’s why smiles, for example, never require translation.</p> <p>Basic emotions are the way they are because they were helpful for survival in the ancient human world. A Google Images search for “disgust” shows a bunch of people, all making the <a href=\"https://www.google.com/search?q=disgust&amp;sxsrf=ACYBGNQv-u7-iqmXdhkg1aadAcX7i6jJOg:1577494344003&amp;source=lnms&amp;tbm=isch&amp;sa=X&amp;ved=2ahUKEwjFl4mwkNfmAhXuYN8KHaOQD-kQ_AUoAXoECBMQAw&amp;biw=1837&amp;bih=1111\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">same hideous face</a>—squinting their eyes, curling up their noses, and exhaling (and if it gets really bad, exhaling turns to gagging and eventually vomiting). <a href=\"https://psycnet.apa.org/record/2008-07784-047\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Scientists believe</a> this is evolution’s way of getting us to close up our incoming passages and expel outward whatever we can, in order to protect ourselves when we’re in the presence of toxins or disease. We react this way when confronted with rotten food, blood, shit, maggots, and anything else our primitive software believes is potentially dangerous and disease-carrying. We’re so prone to feel disgust that you probably feel a bit of disgust right now just having read the last sentence.</p> <p>The strange thing is that disgust can carry over to how we view <em>people</em>. There’s a reasonable amount of <a href=\"https://www.repository.cam.ac.uk/bitstream/handle/1810/239313/Schnall,%20Haidt,%20Clore%20&amp;%20Jordan%20(2008).pdf;jsessionid=9C6B6A819ABE9155FA3801B9A1F4F868?sequence=1\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">research</a> that suggests that when people are exposed to something that brings out their disgust emotion, they become <a href=\"https://www.thejuryexpert.com/2009/03/grime-and-punishment-how-disgust-influences-moral-social-and-legal-judgments/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">harsher moral judges</a>. In <a href=\"https://www2.psych.ubc.ca/~schaller/Faulkneretal2004.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">one experiment</a>, one group of Canadians were shown disturbing-but-not-disgusting images of car accidents while another was shown photos of coughing people and other disease-related visuals. Then both groups were questioned about which countries they felt Canada should dedicate resources toward attracting immigrants from. Both groups showed a preference for immigrants from familiar countries (those who have a prominent presence in Canada), but the group that had seen images of disease felt much stronger about it.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#footnote2-23-8757\" id=\"note2-23-8757\" rel=\"footnote2\">23</a> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/disease.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8830\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/disease.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"499\" height=\"401\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/disease.png 1202w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/disease-600x482.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/disease-768x617.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/disease-750x603.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 499px) 100vw, 499px\" /></a></p> <p>In <a href=\"https://www.repository.cam.ac.uk/bitstream/handle/1810/239313/Schnall,%20Haidt,%20Clore%20&amp;%20Jordan%20(2008).pdf?sequence=1\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">another study</a>, participants sitting at a dirty desk were harsher in their judgments of a series of criminal acts than participants sitting at a clean desk. In <a href=\"https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/e9e6/6d380f4fb7d88c78a01587f5a3c65df13768.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">another</a>, a wafting odor of vomit made participants more likely to disapprove of homosexuality.</p> <p>Scientists use the term <a href=\"https://psycnet.apa.org/record/2006-20474-018\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">“behavior immune system”</a> to describe the theory that disgust is linked to concepts like xenophobia and discomfort with practices and rituals (especially sexual) that seem foreign or different to us—an ancient impulse we developed because long ago, contact with foreign people and practices often did put you at risk of disease.</p> <p>You know when you watch a horror movie and by the end, your amygdala is all up-in-arms about everything and suddenly every noise in the house makes you sure you’re about to be murdered? What’s happening is that your Primitive Mind is bad at distinguishing movies from reality and the movie actually makes it feel like it’s in danger.</p> <p>The behavioral immune system is the same idea. Once your Primitive Mind is triggered by the feeling of disgust, even just via images, it becomes <em>very </em>suspicious that life-threatening disease is afoot and wants to react accordingly. It gets all hyped up, your mind fills with smoke, and you start obeying your ancient software, even when it makes absolutely no sense. So you do the equivalent of double locking all your doors after watching a horror movie—you become super icked out by people and behavior that deviate from “your people” or their norms.</p> <p>The reason I called disgust one of the scariest words in the English language is that it’s a trigger for dehumanization, and dehumanization is the gateway drug to the worst things humans do. It’s not a coincidence that two of the most horrifying events in recent human history—the Holocaust and the Rwandan genocide—were made possible by disgust. Nazi propaganda constantly compared Jews to disgust-inducing animals like <a href=\"https://ianpace.files.wordpress.com/2015/11/das-kleine-blatt-1939.jpg?w=590\">rats</a>, <a href=\"https://i2.wp.com/der-stuermer.org/pictures/dersturmer1.jpg\">swine</a>, and <a href=\"https://alphahistory.com/nazigermany/wp-content/uploads/2012/06/spider.jpg\">insects</a>. The <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VNbUeLnxQEI\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Rwandan radio broadcasts</a> that incited the 1994 genocide referred to Tutsis as “cockroaches” repeatedly. These are just two examples of a well-worn tradition. During World War I, the Germans depicted the British as <a href=\"https://i.redd.it/1dx43bsnh5n31.jpg\">spiders</a>, while the U.S. did the <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/kaiser-spider.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">same thing</a> with the Kaiser. During World War II, Americans painted the Japanese as <a href=\"http://historymatters.gmu.edu/mpimages/mp8332.jpg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">rats</a>, while the Japanese went with <a href=\"https://cms.qz.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/propaganda5.jpg?quality=75&amp;strip=all&amp;w=620&amp;h=440&amp;crop=1\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">spiders</a> for the English.</p> <p>In a <a href=\"http://sites.oxy.edu/clint/evolution/articles/DisgustFacilitatesOutgroupDehumanization-2013-Buckels.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">2012 paper</a>, Erin Buckels and Paul Trapnell write:</p> <p><em>Once activated, feelings of disgust reliably evoke feelings of superiority over offending targets, who by virtue of their disgustingness, are expelled from the circle of moral regard. As such, disgust guards the human–animal boundary in social cognition, playing the dual role of distancing ourselves from “lower” creatures and reaffirming our own humanity. When applied to intergroup contexts, disgust inserts a psychological boundary between us and them that humanizes us at the expense of the other. … there is evidence that feelings of disgust may weaken or block perceptions of target humanity. In two social-neuroscience investigations, Harris and Fiske (2006, 2007) found that members of certain disgust-eliciting outgroups fail to be processed as fully human, social entities.</em></p> <p>Disgust fills our mind with a special kind of primitive fog—one that turns ordinary humans into psychopaths who can commit unthinkable harm without remorse. Scary shit.</p> <p>The geographic and information bubbles are a lethal combo, ripe for disgust.</p> <p>Writer Gene Knudsen Hoffman says, “An enemy is one whose story we have not heard.” It’s hard to feel dehumanizing disgust for people you know personally. Less hard when you rarely see your enemies in person. And even less hard when destructive cherry-picking teaches you only the worst of the worst about them.</p> <p>There’s a term we need to start using: <strong>political bigotry.</strong></p> <p>Political bigotry is as real as any other bigotry. In a <a href=\"http://pcl.stanford.edu/research/2014/iyengar-ajps-group-polarization.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">2014 paper</a> on political polarization in the U.S., Shanto Iyengar and Sean J. Westwood write:</p> <p><em>Hostile feelings for the opposing party are ingrained or automatic in voters’ minds, and that affective polarization based on party is just as strong as polarization based on race. We further show that party cues exert powerful effects on non-political judgments and behaviors. Partisans discriminate against opposing partisans, and do so to a degree that exceeds discrimination based on race.</em></p> <p>Their findings are corroborated by <a href=\"https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Christine_Reyna/publication/256050159_The_Ideological-Conflict_Hypothesis/links/59ee1f51a6fdcc32187dac6d/The-Ideological-Conflict-Hypothesis.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">another 2014 paper</a>, which produced this graph, suggesting that political intolerance beats other kinds of intolerance on both the left and right.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/intolerance-V2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8862\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/intolerance-V2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"716\" height=\"541\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/intolerance-V2.png 1364w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/intolerance-V2-600x453.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/intolerance-V2-768x580.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/intolerance-V2-750x566.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 716px) 100vw, 716px\" /></a></p> <p>As political Echo Chambers have gotten larger and more extreme, political opponents have gone from seeming like wrong, stupid people to seeming like evil, disgusting monsters. Feeling disgust towards a large group of people is textbook bigotry. If you heard about a country populated by two major races or ethnicities or religions, and they talked about each other the way today’s Americans talk about the opposing political tribe, you’d be very, very concerned about that country.</p> <p>But for most of us, our instinct tells us that political bigotry is not as terrible as other kinds of bigotry. Maybe because it seems like it’s disgust about ideas more than disgust about people. Or maybe because, at least in the U.S., racial and other kinds of bigotry have historically been more prominent and the cause of more strife. But the <a href=\"https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Christine_Reyna/publication/256050159_The_Ideological-Conflict_Hypothesis/links/59ee1f51a6fdcc32187dac6d/The-Ideological-Conflict-Hypothesis.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">paper</a> goes on to talk about evidence that partisanship in the U.S. has increasingly become a “<em>primal” </em>kind of bond, much like ethnicity or race, making political bigotry a lot more like other types of bigotry.</p> <p>Bigotry is at its most harmful in moments when much of society fails to recognize it as bigotry. The best tools to combat bigotry are social norms that penalize its expression, but those norms only kick in when the bigoted attitudes and behavior become widely viewed as reprehensible. In the U.S. today, political bigotry is a rare form of bigotry that is rarely ever penalized by taboo—and it’s often rewarded. Iyengar and Westwood’s research corroborates this notion:</p> <p><em>The most plausible explanation for the stronger affective response generated by partisan cues is the non-applicability of egalitarian norms. These norms, which are supported by large majorities, discourage the manifestation of behavior that may be construed as discriminatory. In contemporary America, the strength of these norms has made virtually any discussion of racial differences a taboo subject to the point that citizens suppress their true feelings. No such constraints apply to evaluations of partisan groups. While Americans are inclined to “hedge” expressions of overt animosity toward racial minorities, immigrants, gays, or other marginalized groups, they enthusiastically voice hostility for the out-party and its supporters.</em></p> <p>When society is behaving badly, politicians will too. Iyengar and Westwood also studied how rising levels of disgust amongst voters is then mimicked by politicians:</p> <p><em>Hostility for the out party among rank and file partisans sends a clear signal to elected officials; representatives who appear willing to work across party lines run the risk of being perceived as “appeasers.” For the vast majority who represent uncompetitive districts, there are strong incentives to “bash” the opposition.</em></p> <p>If they’re right, we should be seeing lots of political disgust expressed by politicians right now. Let’s see if their research holds up.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/11.1-disgusting-trump-3-column@0.5x.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8832 size-full\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/11.1-disgusting-trump-3-column@0.5x.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1798\" height=\"2588\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/11.1-disgusting-trump-3-column@0.5x.png 1798w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/11.1-disgusting-trump-3-column@0.5x-417x600.png 417w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/11.1-disgusting-trump-3-column@0.5x-768x1105.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/11.1-disgusting-trump-3-column@0.5x-521x750.png 521w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1798px) 100vw, 1798px\" /></a></p> <p>Well then. But maybe it’s just Trump?</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/11.2-disgusting-other.png\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8848\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/11.2-disgusting-other.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1400\" height=\"2000\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/11.2-disgusting-other.png 1400w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/11.2-disgusting-other-420x600.png 420w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/11.2-disgusting-other-768x1097.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/11.2-disgusting-other-525x750.png 525w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1400px) 100vw, 1400px\" /></a></p> <p>Political disgust has become so common we barely even register it.</p> <p style=\"font-size:32px\"><strong>Zooming Back Out</strong></p> <p>With all of this in mind, let’s return to this:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/135-stacked.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8770\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/135-stacked.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"732\" height=\"1053\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/135-stacked.png 1879w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/135-stacked-417x600.png 417w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/135-stacked-768x1105.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/135-stacked-521x750.png 521w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 732px) 100vw, 732px\" /></a></p> <p>When I look at this trend, I see more than a simple story of the U.S. growing more politically polarized—I see just one manifestation of a much bigger story. The U.S. giant has fallen ill, and this visual is one of the symptoms.</p> <p>We started this post looking at two well-documented trends in the U.S.: increasing polarization amongst citizens and within government. Then we looked at two major environmental changes that seem to be playing a large role in stoking and perpetuating those trends: geographic bubbles, generated by increased mobility, and information bubbles, generated by the shift from broadcast to narrowcast news and internet algorithms. These bubbles have Americans connected in all the wrong ways—no longer personally connected with people who disagree with them politically, and more connected than ever before in an online ecosystem that over-simplifies the world, encourages intellectual conformity, and spreads mistrust and hatred of the outgroup.</p> <p>Here are four reasons this scares me:</p> <p><strong>1) We’re losing our ability to gain knowledge. </strong>If our perceptions of reality are increasingly informed by media with other-than-truth motivations, we’ll increasingly lose our handle on the truth. This is like the big U.S. giant becoming schizophrenic.</p> <p><strong>2) We’re losing our ability to think together. </strong>Human giants can only think when people talk and when they’re free to say what they really think. As Echo Chambers grow larger and more intimidating, people inside them are afraid to defy the sacred narrative. And the more all-encompassing political identities become, the more topics turn from kickable machines to <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/10/idea-labs-echo-chambers.html#echo-chambers\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">precious infants</a>. Meanwhile, intergroup communication suffers even more, as opposing groups become totally unable to collaborate on ideas. As the downward trend deepens, the voices of <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/12/political-disney-world.html#high-rung\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">high-minded Progressivism and Conservativism</a>—the team that navigates the U.S. up the mountain—are growing more timid and harder to hear. The U.S. giant is losing its ability to learn.</p> <p><strong>3) We’re losing our ability to cooperate. </strong>A polarized country that isn’t capable of building broad coalitions can’t take forward steps—it can only self-inflict.</p> <p><strong>4) We’re doing that thing that people do before really, really awful things happen. </strong>Disgust should scare you as much as it scares me. If our species were a person, it would have a mix of beautiful and unadmirable qualities—but its darkest quality would be the ability to dehumanize.</p> <p>When I back up and look at all of these things at the same time—when I mentally zoom out as far as I can and try to see the downward macro trend all at once—it looks like one thing to me:</p> <p>The <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/08/fire-light.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Power Games</a>.</p> <p>Humans in a constitutional democracy aren’t quite at home. Part of us—our Higher Minds—are right in their natural habitat, like bullied nerds who finally graduated high school and moved to a place where they can be themselves. But our Primitive Minds are wild animals caged up in a zoo. The cage is made up of the constitution and laws, but even more so, it’s made of widely accepted, socially enforced liberal norms.</p> <p>The <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/09/enlightenment-kids.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Value Games</a> is a remarkable human structure and when it’s working well, it can not only cage the worst instincts of the Primitive Mind but harness them into tremendous productivity. But the Value Games aren’t really our natural way, and they’re fragile. The Power Games are always pulling on us like gravity, and whenever there’s a crack in the Value Games structure, we’re at risk of falling. The Primitive Mind may be in a cage, but it never stops pushing against the bars, searching for one it can bend, trying to break out.</p> <p>The geographic and information bubbles are relatively new. The internet especially is evolving and changing literally by the month. The U.S. was built to be incredibly robust, but such insanely rapid environmental change is pushing it to its limits.</p> <p>When I look at the downward trend, I see a resurgence of the Power Games. We’re starting to do a lot of those things humans do when they’re at their worst. We’re tossing our principles aside and glomming onto big, mindless giants who aren’t sentient enough to know that that kind of structure doesn’t make sense anymore. As the country slides its way down the mountain, we’re behaving more and more like the output of a non-living, force-of-nature software program that only wants genes to be immortal.</p> <p>This is what I mean when I say the U.S. giant has fallen ill. In the chaos of rapid environmental changes, the giant’s immune system—the thing that keeps the Power Games in check—has become weakened, and the Power Games is spreading through its body like an epidemic.</p> <p>I don’t really know what’s chicken or egg here. Maybe the two bubbles caused the political polarization. Maybe the geographic bubble is enhanced by the polarization. Maybe it’s all Newt’s fault. Or maybe Newt’s tactics only worked because the giant was already sick. Maybe Trump is an inevitable symptom of the sickness, or maybe he’s an unusually harmful exacerbator of it. Ditto for social justice bullies. Maybe all of this is business as usual and I’m over-catastrophizing what’s just another trough in an overall upward-moving roller coaster. Or maybe it would be business as usual if not for the internet, which makes this a dangerous anomaly. No one seems to know for sure. But we <em>can</em> figure out how to get ourselves onto a better trajectory.</p> <p>After the last chapter, I was accused by some readers of practicing “bothsidesism,” a suggestion that I was depicting both U.S. parties as equal and equally at fault for the state of the nation, as a kind of cop-out.</p> <p>I get it. False equivalencies are infuriating. Imagine you’re eight and you’re in an argument with your sibling. It escalates and he shoves you. You shove him back. Then he slaps you incredibly hard across the face. Then your parent says, “Both of you, stop it!” You protest that what he just did was <em>much </em>worse than anything you did, to which your parent says, “I don’t care about the details—you’re both grounded.” It would be maddeningly unfair.</p> <p>People do this kind of thing all the time with societal conflicts, whether between political parties or racial groups or any other kind of faction. The people who do it often have good intentions—they want to seem fair and they think spreading out the blame equally is the best way to diffuse things. Other times, it happens when defenders of the group who did the “face slap” want to brush over the real story. Whatever the reason, drawing a false equivalency about unequal wrongdoing is as unfair as blaming only one side when there’s equal wrongdoing.</p> <p>The problem with posting what’s clearly a book one chapter at a time is that you can’t get the entirety of your point across until the last chapter is posted. Now that another chapter has come out, I hope it’s a little clearer that “I don’t care about the details—you’re both grounded” isn’t quite my angle here. I see it more like two siblings who have caught rabies. In this particular household, the siblings always have rabies to some extent (the low-rung element of both parties), but recently, their rabies have been flaring up. More rabies makes them want to bite each other more, and the way this strain of rabies works, every time a sibling gets bitten, it causes their own rabies to ramp up a bit, making them more likely to bite the other—and it becomes a vicious cycle. Diagnosing which sibling has rabies worse right now or whose rabies flared up first, while also a worthwhile endeavor, isn’t the right focus of this series. Writing a series focused on scolding a single faction of society and riling up anger toward that side is not only unlikely to help the U.S. giant get better, it’s the exact type of thing that&nbsp;<em>exacerbates&nbsp;</em>the illness—it would just be adding another&nbsp;<em>bite</em> to the rabies war.</p> <p>What seems more pressing to me is the bigger fact that our family has an increasingly dire rabies problem—one that, in the current world of technological explosion, may have existentially scary consequences if it doesn’t get fixed quickly.</p> <p>My obsession over the past three years has been trying to figure out how our national immune system works, where it draws its strength from, and how we can get it working again. I spent so long on this because I believe a resurgence of the Power Games is <em>the </em>limiting factor of every other societal struggle I might write a post about. Every other concern I have—AI safety, climate change, war, poverty, disease, injustice, unstable institutions—hinges on that larger concern. If the U.S., and other countries in a similar predicament, can figure out how to get their immune systems back to full strength in this rapidly changing world, allowing us to think together and work together, we’ll make forward progress in <em>all</em> of those areas. If our nations continue to get sicker and fall further downward into the Power Games, each and every one of those concerns will suffer. Everybody will lose.</p> <p style=\"text-align: center;\">___________</p> <p>As bleak as this may seem, one thing makes me hopeful.</p> <p><em>Pew’s </em>findings that polarization has sharply increased were well-publicized after the release of its report. What didn’t make much news was this line:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#footnote2-24-8757\" id=\"note2-24-8757\" rel=\"footnote2\">24</a> <p><em>These sentiments are not shared by all—or even most—Americans. The majority do not have uniformly conservative or liberal views. Most do not see either party as a threat to the nation. And more believe their representatives in government should meet halfway to resolve contentious disputes rather than hold out for more of what they want.</em></p> <p>Or this line:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#footnote2-25-8757\" id=\"note2-25-8757\" rel=\"footnote2\">25</a> <p><em>But beyond the ideological wings, which make up a minority of the public, the political landscape includes a center that is large and diverse, unified by frustration with politics and little else.</em></p> <p>In the course of my research, in addition to everything I found about increased polarization, I came across a handful of stats that told a second story. Like this chart:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#footnote2-26-8757\" id=\"note2-26-8757\" rel=\"footnote2\">26</a> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/conclusion-1.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8833\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/conclusion-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"584\" height=\"357\" /></a></p> <p>And this one:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#footnote2-27-8757\" id=\"note2-27-8757\" rel=\"footnote2\">27</a> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/conclusion-4.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8834\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/conclusion-4.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"434\" height=\"799\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/conclusion-4.png 816w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/conclusion-4-326x600.png 326w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/conclusion-4-768x1414.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/conclusion-4-407x750.png 407w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 434px) 100vw, 434px\" /></a></p> <p>I’ve felt like an exception in my “I used to be a staunch Democrat, but I don’t feel that way anymore” story, but the more I dug in, the more I realized that a <em>huge</em> portion of both parties felt the same way.</p> <p>Whenever the stats went to a more granular level, everything seemed messier than the story we always hear:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#footnote2-28-8757\" id=\"note2-28-8757\" rel=\"footnote2\">28</a> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/conclusion-2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8835\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/conclusion-2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"702\" height=\"500\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/conclusion-2.png 640w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/conclusion-2-600x428.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 702px) 100vw, 702px\" /></a></p> <p>Most interesting to me was a fascinating report called <a href=\"https://hiddentribes.us/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><em>The Hidden Tribes of America</em></a>—a year-long study that collected the views of over 8,000 Americans—which found that two-thirds of Americans fall into what they call the “Exhausted Majority.”</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/conclusion-3.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8836\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/conclusion-3.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"571\" height=\"651\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/conclusion-3.png 1074w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/conclusion-3-526x600.png 526w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/conclusion-3-768x877.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/conclusion-3-657x750.png 657w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 571px) 100vw, 571px\" /></a></p> <p>While the “Wings,” as <em>Hidden Tribes </em>refers to the more politically partisan crowd, <span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/1-3.png\">tend</a></span> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/2-2.png\"><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\">to</span></a> <span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3-3.png\">hold</a></span> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/4-3.png\"><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\">extreme</span></a> <span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/5-3.png\">views</a></span>, the Exhausted Majority has “more complex views on contested issues than our polarizing public debates would suggest.” <a href=\"https://hiddentribes.us/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">According to the report</a>, the Exhausted Majority holds a wide variety of attitudes and viewpoints, but its members share four main attributes:</p> \n                              <ul> \n                               <li><em>They are&nbsp;</em><strong><em>fed up</em></strong><em>&nbsp;with the polarization plaguing American government and society</em></li> \n                               <li><em>They are often&nbsp;</em><strong><em>forgotten</em></strong><em>&nbsp;in the public discourse, overlooked because their voices are seldom heard</em></li> \n                               <li><em>They are&nbsp;</em><strong><em>flexible</em></strong><em>&nbsp;in their views, willing to endorse different policies according to the precise situation rather than sticking ideologically to a single set of beliefs</em></li> \n                               <li><em>They believe we can&nbsp;</em><strong><em>find common ground</em></strong></li> \n                              </ul> <p>Sounds a lot like…high-rung political thinking?</p> <p>If the report is to be believed, the common perception that citizens are becoming more polarized, more ideological, and more tribal about politics is an illusion.</p> <p>But where does this illusion come from? Typically, majority groups in a society are, if anything, too powerful, leaving minority groups marginalized. So why would politics work the opposite way?</p> <p><a href=\"https://www.people-press.org/2014/06/12/political-polarization-in-the-american-public/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Pew offers</a> one possibility: “The rise of ideological uniformity has been much more pronounced among those who are the most politically active.” Those with the most extreme, black-and-white views are also those most vocal about politics, most active in dictating the national dialogue, and most likely to vote:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/conclusion-5.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8842\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/conclusion-5.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"727\" height=\"430\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/conclusion-5.png 1336w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/conclusion-5-600x355.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/conclusion-5-768x454.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/conclusion-5-750x443.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 727px) 100vw, 727px\" /></a></p> <p>That’s definitely part of the explanation, but it’s also nothing new. Hardcore partisans have always been highly politically active. Something else is going on here.</p> <p>When the Value Games are working properly, people holding the most extreme views are relegated to the fringes—retaining enough of a voice to effect change when they’re right about something but unable to do too much damage when, more often, they’re wrong. But in the Power Games, it’s often the case that small groups of more extreme people end up with outsized power over others.</p> <p>Maybe instead of focusing on how politically active the most extreme people are, we should be asking ourselves why those who hold “more complex views” have become so <em>inactive</em>.</p> <p>In the series intro, I wrote:</p> <p><em>When I told people I was planning to write a post about society, and the way people are acting, and the way the media is acting, and the way the government is acting, and the way everyone else is acting, people kept saying the same thing to me.</em></p> <p><em>Don’t do it. Don’t touch it. Write about something else. <span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\">Anything</span> else. It’s just not worth it. …</em></p> <p><em>It hit me that what I really needed to write about was <span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\">that</span>—about why it’s perilous to write about society.</em></p> <p><em>I ended up going with some combination of both of these things: society’s current situation and why it’s an especially bad idea for me to write about it—and how those two things are related.</em></p> <p>This chapter focused on the first item: society’s current situation. But the second item—about how incredibly ill-advised it currently is to write about that situation—is the item we need to look hardest at.</p> <p>That’s where we’ll go in the penultimate chapter of The Story of Us.</p> <p style=\"text-align: center;\">___________</p> <p>If you like Wait But Why, sign up for the&nbsp;<strong><a class=\"ClickPico PicoRule\">email list</a></strong>&nbsp;and we’ll send you new posts right when they come out. It’s a super unannoying list I promise.</p> <p>Huge thanks to our Patreon supporters for making this series free for everyone. To support Wait But Why,&nbsp;<a href=\"https://www.patreon.com/waitbutwhy\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><strong>visit our Patreon page</strong></a>.</p> <p style=\"text-align: center;\">___________</p> \n                              <div style=\"height:38px\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"wp-block-spacer\"></div> <p style=\"font-size:24px\"><strong>More Posts:</strong></p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2015/01/artificial-intelligence-revolution-1.html\"><strong>The AI Revolution: The Road to Superintelligence</strong></a><strong>. </strong>One reason&nbsp;we need to get our shit together soon, not later.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2016/10/second-presidential-debate.html\"><strong>My transcript of the Trump / Clinton town hall debate</strong></a><strong>. </strong>The kind of silliness that happens in a polarized country.</p> <p>For everyone sick of politics, <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2016/05/mailbag-1.html\"><strong>here’s a big mailbag post</strong></a> of totally unrelated topics.</p> <p style=\"text-align: center;\">___________</p> <p style=\"font-size:24px\"><strong>Sources, Etc.</strong></p> <p>I did between one and two trillion hours of research for this chapter. The specific citations are all linked and/or footnoted in the text, which seems like a more useful place for them than in a massive list down here. Instead, the below list includes some of the core sources and data, along with some articles I think will make for good reading for anyone who wants to go on the full spiral on this topic. At the bottom, I included a group of links that were the cause of procrastination spirals because you should have to waste time on them too.</p> <p class=\"has-medium-font-size\"><strong>Data, Studies, and Reports</strong></p> <p>A lot of the data in this chapter is courtesy of <a href=\"https://www.pewresearch.org/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Pew</a>. Here’s their <a href=\"https://www.people-press.org/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">U.S. Politics homepage</a>. Their <a href=\"https://www.people-press.org/2017/10/05/the-partisan-divide-on-political-values-grows-even-wider/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">giant 2017 report</a> on polarization in the U.S. is full of interesting charts. <a href=\"https://www.people-press.org/2018/04/26/the-public-the-political-system-and-american-democracy/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Another good one</a> from 2018 with more specifics. And their report on how the country <a href=\"https://www.people-press.org/2017/10/24/political-typology-reveals-deep-fissures-on-the-right-and-left/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">may not actually be as polarized as it seems</a>.</p> <p><a href=\"https://hiddentribes.us/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><em>The Hidden Tribes of America</em></a> is a fascinating report that breaks out of the oversimplified Left/Right divide, finding it more accurate to categorize Americans into seven tribes (three of which make up the more extreme “Wings” and four of which make up the less partisan “Exhausted Majority.”) Worth flipping through.</p> <p><a href=\"https://news.gallup.com/poll/166763/record-high-americans-identify-independents.aspx\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Gallup data</a> that shows a rising percentage of Independents in the U.S. (Alan Abramowitz is skeptical, suggesting that many supposed Independents are “<a href=\"https://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2014/01/independent-voters-partisans-in-the-closet-101931#.UuGkdf30BZK\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">closet partisans</a>”).</p> <p>The <a href=\"https://www.allsides.com/media-bias/media-bias-chart\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">media bias chart</a> I included in the post, from <a href=\"https://www.allsides.com/unbiased-balanced-news\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">AllSides</a>.</p> <p><a href=\"https://www.journalism.org/2014/10/21/political-polarization-media-habits/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Interesting Pew data</a> about the ideological makeup of different media brand’s audiences, and how much each brand is trusted by people in different parts of the political spectrum.</p> <p><a href=\"https://voteview.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Voteview</a> is a useful database that shows you the results of every Congress and Senate vote, now or in history (or <a href=\"https://voteview.com/district\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">enter a zip code</a> to see who the representatives are there—if you don’t know who your own representative is, you can find out here and no one will ever know). The three “polarization over time” charts in the post can be found <a href=\"https://voteview.com/articles/party_polarization\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">here</a>. You can also look at interesting charts that illustrate the political leanings of everyone in the <a href=\"https://voteview.com/congress/house\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">House</a> and <a href=\"https://voteview.com/congress/senate\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Senate</a>, or the <a href=\"https://voteview.com/parties/all\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">history of U.S. parties</a> and their ideologies. If you want to be pretty bored, you can read about their ideological measuring metric (DW-NOMINATE) <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NOMINATE_(scaling_method)\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">here</a>.</p> <p><a href=\"https://ballotpedia.org/National_Journal_vote_ratings\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Ballotpedia</a> tallies up <a href=\"https://www.nationaljournal.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><em>National Journal’s</em></a> annual “vote rating analysis,” allowing you to <a href=\"https://ballotpedia.org/National_Journal_vote_ratings\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">pull up the data</a> on exactly how conservative or liberal each U.S. House member voted the previous year.</p> <p><a href=\"https://time.com/3534117/the-incredible-rise-in-campaign-spending/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">An interactive</a> from <em>Time </em>letting you mouse over the states and see how campaign spending has increased since the 80s. Not sure who would want this, but here’s the <a href=\"http://www.cfinst.org/data.aspx\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">raw data</a> on campaign spending (and the <a href=\"http://www.cfinst.org/pdf/federal/HistoricalTables/pdf/CFI_Federal-CF_18_Table2-01.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">cost of winning an election</a> table from the post).</p> <p><a href=\"https://cyber.harvard.edu/publications/2017/08/mediacloud\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Interesting analysis</a> of the distribution of right- vs. left-wing media during the 2016 U.S. election.</p> <p>A 2014 analysis about <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757/1,080\">the state of journalism</a>—the demographics, ideologies, and attitudes of U.S. journalists today.</p> <p>Here’s <a href=\"https://www.pnas.org/content/early/2017/06/20/1618923114\">the big analysis of political tweets</a> I referenced.</p> <p><a href=\"https://www.researchgate.net/publication/316164633_At_Least_Bias_Is_Bipartisan_A_Meta-Analytic_Comparison_of_Partisan_Bias_in_Liberals_and_Conservatives?isFromSharing=1\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">A meta-analysis</a> of 51 experimental studies, involving over 18,000 participants, on partisan bias. The findings: the Left and Right show similar levels of political bias.</p> <p><a href=\"https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Christine_Reyna/publication/256050159_The_Ideological-Conflict_Hypothesis/links/59ee1f51a6fdcc32187dac6d/The-Ideological-Conflict-Hypothesis.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">A summary of work</a> from three independent labs that suggests that the U.S. Left and Right are both pretty intolerant in their own way. The “political bigotry” graph I included in the post is on page 31.</p> <p><a href=\"https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1111/pops.12479\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">A study</a> that explores the rise of negative partisanship (the phenomenon of people voting against a party more than for one) over the past 40 years. An <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/01/opinion/negative-partisanship-democrats-republicans.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">interesting <em>New York Times</em> article</a> about the same topic.</p> <p>A <a href=\"https://www.researchgate.net/publication/281191995_A_Three-Decade_Retrospective_on_the_Hostile_Media_Effect\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">summary</a> of what we know about the “hostile media effect”—the phenomenon that all partisans tend to think the media is biased against their side.</p> <p class=\"has-medium-font-size\"><strong>Further Reading</strong></p> <p>If you want to go deeper, <a href=\"https://books.google.com/books?id=dAm5BgAAQBAJ&amp;printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&amp;q&amp;f=false\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">this collection of articles</a>, compiled by <em>The Monkey Cage</em>, is a good place to start.</p> <p>Norm Ornstein is a political scientist who has spent years researching political polarization in the U.S. His book, <a href=\"https://amzn.to/36x7QZ1\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><em>It’s Even Worse Than It Looks</em></a>, explains a lot of the history. Here’s an <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KHZTfMLGSYg\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">interesting interview</a> with him where he summarizes some of the points in the book.</p> <p>For some historical context on the modern era, Chapter 3 of <a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Red-Blue-Nation-Characteristics-Polarized/dp/0815760833\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">this collection of papers</a> (<a href=\"https://www.jstor.org/stable/10.7864/j.ctt6wpfdr\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">JSTOR link</a>, and a <a href=\"https://www.brookings.edu/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/20061208.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">summary</a> of the findings), by David Brady and Hahrie Han, tells a story of political polarization throughout U.S. history. Also: an <a href=\"https://ethics.journalism.wisc.edu/2011/04/20/the-fall-and-rise-of-partisan-journalism/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">article</a> about partisan newspapers in the 19<sup>th</sup> century.</p> <p>For a nice overarching summary, <a href=\"https://columbialawreview.org/content/congressional-polarization-terminal-constitutional-dysfunction-2/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">this essay</a>, by professor Cynthia Farina, is a well-written, balanced examination of how the U.S. got so polarized.</p> <p>For some disagreement, Alan Abramowitz believes (<a href=\"https://amzn.to/2up8aeh\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">book</a>, <a href=\"https://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2014/01/independent-voters-partisans-in-the-closet-101931#.UuGkdf30BZK\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">article</a>) U.S. polarization is bad and getting worse, while Morris Fiorina believes (<a href=\"https://amzn.to/2QVEAEE\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">book</a>, <a href=\"https://www.uniteamerica.org/fiorina_independents\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">article</a>) U.S. polarization isn’t as bad as it seems.</p> <p><a href=\"https://amzn.to/37EC2Bv\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><em>The Big Sort</em></a>, by Bill Bishop, tells the story of how so many U.S. counties became more politically homogenous in recent decades. And <a href=\"https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/purple-america-has-all-but-disappeared/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">some great visuals</a> from <em>FiveThirtyEight</em> about the same topic.</p> <p>Random extra: Seems weird today, but in the 1950s, the <em>American Political Science Association </em>urged America’s political parties to become <a href=\"https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/american-political-science-review/article/toward-a-more-responsible-twoparty-system-political-science-policy-science-or-pseudoscience/7E0C8B19699573E71C0CEDDFFC367728\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><em>more </em>distinct and divided</a>. They probably didn’t think quite hard enough about that one.</p> <p class=\"has-medium-font-size\"><strong>Fun and Procrastinatey</strong></p> <p>Nicky Case is one of my favorite creators on the internet. Nicky’s <a href=\"https://ncase.me/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">website</a> is a delightful spiral for curious people, full of brilliant interactives like the <span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://ncase.me/polygons/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">three</a></span> <span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://ncase.me/crowds/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">I</a></span> <a href=\"https://ncase.itch.io/wbwwb\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\">featured</span></a> in this post.</p> <p>Unrelated, but through Nicky’s site, I found <a href=\"https://explorabl.es/all/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">this succulent site</a>, curated by <a href=\"https://twitter.com/maartenzam?lang=en\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Maarten Lambrechts</a>. I spent a long time there.</p> <p>Also unrelated, but the <a href=\"https://ncase.me/polygons/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><em>Parable of the Polygons</em></a> interactive featured in the post was co-created by Vi Hart, whose brain Wait But Why readers will enjoy. She has a super fun <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/user/Vihart\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">YouTube channel</a> with fascinating videos like <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ahXIMUkSXX0\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">this</a>.</p> <p>Neat <em>New York Times</em> interactive displaying <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2016/11/08/us/politics/election-exit-polls.html?_r=0\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">U.S. presidential election demographic results</a> going back to 1972.</p> <p><a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2019/06/26/opinion/sunday/republican-platform-far-right.html?auth=login-smartlock\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Cool <em>New York Times</em> visuals</a> about how the U.S. parties ideologically map onto the European political scene. The U.S. Left has moved enough that it now matches Europe’s leftness. The U.S. right remains further right of most of the European Right.</p> <p>More cool visuals: See how <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2019/08/08/opinion/sunday/party-polarization-quiz.html?auth=login-smartlock\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">your demographic info predicts what your politics are</a>. Here’s the <a href=\"https://electionstudies.org/resources/anes-guide/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">raw data</a>.</p> <p><a href=\"https://www.wsj.com/graphics/red-economy-blue-economy/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Interesting visuals</a> from the <em>Wall Street Journal</em> about how the parties have moved apart in other ways beyond geography—the gap grows between the Left and Right in education and wealth levels, and they increasingly work in different industries.</p> <p>The <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rE3j_RHkqJc\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">CGP Grey video</a> I referenced. He refers to social media postings as “thought germs” and explains that no type spreads faster than anger. If you haven’t gone on a spiral on his channel yet, put it on the list.</p> <p>Eli Pariser on <a href=\"https://www.ted.com/talks/eli_pariser_beware_online_filter_bubbles?language=en\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">online “filter bubbles”</a>, his term for the bubbles of confirmation internet algorithms have us all wrapped tightly in.</p> <p>A <a href=\"http://www.trumptwitterarchive.com/archive/disgusting/ttff\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Trump Twitter search tool</a></p>\n                              <div class=\"footnotes\">\n                               <hr />\n                               <ol>\n                                <li id=\"footnote-1-8757\" class=\"footnote\"><p>I was a government major in college and <em>Achieving Our Country</em> made a big impression on me back then. In the book, he basically predicted Trump 20 years before it happened. One passage: “At that point, something will crack. The nonsuburban electorate will decide that the system has failed and start looking for a strongman to vote for—someone willing to assure them that, once he is elected, the smug bureaucrats, tricky lawyers, overpaid bond salesmen, and postmodernist professors will no longer be calling the shots.”<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#note-1-8757\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n                                <!--/#footnote-1.footnote-->\n                                <li id=\"footnote-2-8757\" class=\"footnote\"><p>Richard Walker <a href=\"https://www.brookings.edu/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/20061208.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">explains why</a>: <em>In the 1890s and early 1900s, the political parties polarized over whether government should facilitate the growth of the urban, industrial economy or protect the shrinking rural, agrarian economy. The parties also divided over what role the burgeoning country should play on the international stage.</em><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#note-2-8757\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n                                <!--/#footnote-2.footnote-->\n                                <li id=\"footnote-3-8757\" class=\"footnote\"><p>Cynthia R. Farina <a href=\"https://columbialawreview.org/content/congressional-polarization-terminal-constitutional-dysfunction-2/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">sums up</a> some of the similarities between the 1890s and today: <em>a “resurgence in religious activity,” a “melding of moral and economic issues,” and partisan debates “laden with moral overtones”; party affiliation becoming a “social as well as ideological phenomenon”; large population shifts within the country and great disparities of wealth; close electoral competition such that small voter shifts could swing control from one party to the other; and a period of tight leadership discipline that established a “highly centralized and intensely partisan House.”</em><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#note-3-8757\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n                                <!--/#footnote-3.footnote-->\n                                <li id=\"footnote-4-8757\" class=\"footnote\"><p>It stands for (<strong>D</strong>ynamic&nbsp;<strong>W</strong>eighted&nbsp;<strong>NOMINA</strong>L&nbsp;<strong>T</strong>hree-step&nbsp;<strong>E</strong>stimation), but that was such a boring fact I wanted to hide it in a footnote.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#note-4-8757\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n                                <!--/#footnote-4.footnote-->\n                                <li id=\"footnote-5-8757\" class=\"footnote\"><p>Apparently, without homes in Washington, lots of House members now <a href=\"https://www.cbsnews.com/news/one-fifth-of-house-freshmen-sleep-in-offices/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">sleep in their office</a>.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#note-5-8757\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n                                <!--/#footnote-5.footnote-->\n                                <li id=\"footnote-6-8757\" class=\"footnote\"><p>Ross Douthat’s <a href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/21/opinion/campaign-stops/clintons-samantha-bee-problem.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">view</a>: “On late-night television, it was once understood that David Letterman was beloved by coastal liberals and Jay Leno more of a Middle American taste. But neither man was prone to delivering hectoring monologues in the style of the ‘Daily Show’ alums who now dominate late night. Fallon’s apolitical shtick increasingly makes him an outlier among his peers, many of whom are less comics than propagandists—liberal ‘explanatory journalists’ with laugh lines.”<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#note-6-8757\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n                                <!--/#footnote-6.footnote-->\n                                <li id=\"footnote-7-8757\" class=\"footnote\"><p>Worth noting that AllSides specifies a “confidence level” for each publication rating. Their AP rating has Medium confidence and their Reuters rating has Low confidence.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#note-7-8757\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n                                <!--/#footnote-7.footnote-->\n                                <li id=\"footnote-8-8757\" class=\"footnote\"><p>It was around minute nine of painstakingly outlining the contours of Mitch McConnell’s neck folds that the “ya know on second thought this is not a great use of my time” thought sprung up. But the sunk cost fallacy won.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#note-8-8757\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n                                <!--/#footnote-8.footnote-->\n                                <li id=\"footnote-9-8757\" class=\"footnote\"><p>four<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#note-9-8757\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n                                <!--/#footnote-9.footnote-->\n                                <li id=\"footnote-10-8757\" class=\"footnote\"><p>The linked study examined “prosocial behavior” (like altruism) and found that it not only spread (causing the recipient of the behavior to “pay it forward”) but generated a ripple effect, whereby the “influence persists for multiple periods and spreads up to three degrees of separation (from person to person to person to person).” <a href=\"https://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0087275\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Another study</a> found that prosocial behavior spreads in two ways: beneficiaries of prosocial behavior pay it forward, and those who <em>observe </em>prosocial behavior are also more likely to exhibit prosocial behavior themselves.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#note-10-8757\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n                                <!--/#footnote-10.footnote-->\n                                <li id=\"footnote-11-8757\" class=\"footnote\"><p>Fun fact from the video (which is based on data from <a href=\"https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=1528077\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">this study</a>): sadness works the opposite way as anger. Memes or articles that make people sad are the least likely of all to spread.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8757#note-11-8757\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n                                <!--/#footnote-11.footnote-->\n                               </ol>\n                              </div>\n                              <!--/#footnotes-->\n                              <div <!--/#footnote2-11.footnote-->\n                                <li id=\"footnote2-12-8757\" class=\"footnote2\"><p><a
