itiveness.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn19@2020_3/2020/08/16/19-24-14-506_e201c277f8162c6e.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Spending.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn51@2020_6/2020/08/16/19-24-27-826_4c61f93c66fc8a3e.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/538.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx17/cdn23@2020_1/2020/08/16/19-24-28-039_24a3e15958db065e.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/trump-site.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn7@2020_1/2020/08/16/19-24-22-237_4cf61fdb7b7429c8.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/overlap-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn15@2020_3/2020/08/16/19-24-05-840_c8ac5a13c739dbb6.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/overlap-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx17/cdn23@2020_5/2020/08/16/19-24-08-772_e4dcbff3368d39d6.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.0-bare-behavior-equation.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn58@2020_6/2020/08/16/19-23-58-509_84fa22edd98b723e.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/1-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn91@2020_6/2020/08/16/19-24-13-000_bdfd0fbdb588c2bf.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/2-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn24@2020_4/2020/08/16/19-24-10-632_4d822ab92d23e6fe.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn96@2020_1/2020/08/16/19-24-12-204_d5461ed29dc6ec35.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/4-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn55@2020_3/2020/08/16/19-24-11-245_cbed733a85be204a.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/5-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn16@2020_1/2020/08/16/19-24-11-394_df511b879f0f967d.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/6-2.png":"https://c g":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn92@2020_6/2020/08/16/19-24-05-526_8c5d3bb9d49d9c08.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/5.1-skittles-V2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn44@2020_5/2020/08/16/19-24-27-408_593a8d0d093bc061.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/5.2-magazines.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn92@2020_2/2020/08/16/19-24-24-671_df8bca8ffec03c1c.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/5.3-clickbait.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn96@2020_3/2020/08/16/19-24-24-219_c6f4e6ce6aa12f5b.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/5.4-destroy@0.5x.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn100@2020_6/2020/08/16/19-24-09-083_470e9419b8f6d754.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/environment.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn84@2020_2/2020/08/16/19-24-02-782_5441b63a5590985b.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/7.1-environment.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn84@2020_5/2020/08/16/19-24-17-851_d4f1193424579840.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/7.2-environment.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn75@2020_2/2020/08/16/19-24-07-484_9de48a5ed4a4bbf2.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/7.3-environment.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn99@2020_1/2020/08/16/19-24-11-473_f9b274c33e30f5f3.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/8-Zig-Zag-presidents-v2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx20/cdn99@2020_1/2020/08/16/19-24-22-248_d267d596b7b911b8.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/retweets.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn80@2020_5/2020/08/16/19-24-04-428_bd79232657f980f7.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/7.1-3-Questions-600x425.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn55@2020_6/2020/08/16/19-24-01-452_1d8b6978f4f83e48.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/140-V2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn35@2020_2/2020/08/16/19-24-16-644_3316250ebb9bd1da.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/128b-V2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn100@2020_4/2020/08/16/19-23-58-241_719d4f76a43d3656.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/3.18-media-matrix-reality.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn64@2020_6/2020/08/16/19-24-18-386_dcaf4f02751c9527.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/9-trump-sidebar.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn48@2020_1/2020/08/16/19-24-05-577_cf1c6c9512c74f51.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/hillary-witch.gif":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn12@2020_2/2020/08/16/19-24-05-850_e71a93220af4c59a.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/127.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn44@2020_3/2020/08/16/19-23-58-422_95608bd944af8368.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/10.1-gofundme-new-V2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn24@2020_1/2020/08/16/19-24-13-738_250a8b6629cc014f.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/10.2-gofundme-new-V2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn52@2020_2/2020/08/16/19-24-10-097_f578374b6962b295.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/10.3-gofundme-new-V2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn56@2020_2/2020/08/16/19-24-21-697_0835d083ca585a0c.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/crime.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx17/cdn95@2020_1/2020/08/16/19-24-15-271_f7e934a5062730a8.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/disease.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn96@2020_2/2020/08/16/19-24-20-053_139d7256a91f17b7.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/intolerance-V2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn3@2020_3/2020/08/16/19-24-14-692_2bcfa3caf93f68c5.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/11.1-disgusting-trump-3-column@0.5x.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn72@2020_1/2020/08/16/19-24-24-210_424352c4b87b59dd.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/11.2-disgusting-other.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn28@2020_1/2020/08/16/19-24-19-576_1de3b557a15f1864.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/conclusion-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn40@2020_3/2020/08/16/19-24-20-443_6ffab08d4568ced1.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/conclusion-4.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn56@2020_6/2020/08/16/19-24-22-831_66c70114889f6526.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/conclusion-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn67@2020_4/2020/08/16/19-24-18-993_b89c422c4f586a09.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/conclusion-3.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn23@2020_6/2020/08/16/19-24-21-300_4b6ce21f3e90b26a.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/conclusion-5.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn99@2020_6/2020/08/16/19-24-25-244_50d21168152f674d.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-08-17 03:23:54","updatedTime":"2020-08-17 03:23:54","title":"Idea Labs and Echo Chambers","link":"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8229","description":"<p style=\"font-size:18px\"><em>This is Chapter 8 in a blog series. If you’re new to the series, visit the </em><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/story-of-us\"><strong><em>series home page</em></strong></a><em> for the full table of contents.</em></p> \n<p><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-7518\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Notes-Key-v2.png\" alt=\"Notes key: Type 1 - fun notes. Fun facts, extra thoughts, or further explanation. Type 2 - less fun notes. Sources and citations.\" width=\"390\" height=\"122\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Notes-Key-v2.png 850w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Notes-Key-v2-300x94.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Notes-Key-v2-768x241.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Notes-Key-v2-600x188.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 390px) 100vw, 390px\" /></p> \n<div style=\"height:38px\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"wp-block-spacer\"></div> \n<p style=\"font-size:19px\" class=\"has-text-align-center wbwFont\"><strong>Chapter 8: Idea Labs and Echo Chambers</strong></p> \n<div style=\"height:38px\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"wp-block-spacer\"></div> \n<p class=\"has-text-align-center\"><em>“Sheep wish no taste but woolly sweet conformity.”&nbsp;―&nbsp;Kevin Focke</em></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">_____________</p> \n<div style=\"height:38px\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"wp-block-spacer\"></div> \n<p>Chapter 7 began with a question: “Why do we believe what we believe?”</p> \n<p>We spent the rest of Chapter 7 thinking about thinking in 2D, exploring how our thinking process changed as we moved up and down the second dimension: the <a href=\"https://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861-wpengine.netdna-ssl.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/0.1-Psych-Spectrum.png\">Psych Spectrum</a>. At the end of the chapter, I reminded us that the entire discussion was only looking at a 2D cross section of what’s actually a 3D space of human thinking and behavior.</p> \n<p>The good news is the third dimension is something we already became familiar with early on in the series: Emergence Tower. Here it is in all its fully extended glory:</p> \n<p></p> \n<div style=\"height:38px\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"wp-block-spacer\"></div> \n<div id=\"eightTower\">\n <div id=\"image-map-pro-1427\"></div>\n</div> \n<div style=\"height:28px\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"wp-block-spacer\"></div> \n<p>We’d all be having maximum fun right now if we were about to dive into a discussion about the multiversesphere. Unfortunately, we have human concerns to deal with first. So we’ll zoom in here:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/1.2-emergence-tower-comparison-1.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8367 \" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/1.2-emergence-tower-comparison-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"589\" height=\"812\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/1.2-emergence-tower-comparison-1.png 1551w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/1.2-emergence-tower-comparison-1-435x600.png 435w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/1.2-emergence-tower-comparison-1-768x1059.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/1.2-emergence-tower-comparison-1-544x750.png 544w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 589px) 100vw, 589px\" /></a></p> \n<p class=\"has-large-font-size\"><strong>Seeing in 3D</strong></p> \n<p>The reason we need our second dimension—the Psych Spectrum—is because humans exist along a <em>span</em> of the Psych Spectrum. That’s why it’s a <em>dimension.</em></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/1.3.1-Psych-Spectrum-animal-comparison-v4.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8375 \" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/1.3.1-Psych-Spectrum-animal-comparison-v4.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"303\" height=\"506\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/1.3.1-Psych-Spectrum-animal-comparison-v4.png 900w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/1.3.1-Psych-Spectrum-animal-comparison-v4-359x600.png 359w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/1.3.1-Psych-Spectrum-animal-comparison-v4-768x1283.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/1.3.1-Psych-Spectrum-animal-comparison-v4-449x750.png 449w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 303px) 100vw, 303px\" /></a></p> \n<p>We need our third dimension for the same reason. You don’t really need a third dimension to think about the behavior of ants or polar bears, because they exist almost entirely at a single point along Emergence Tower. Ants never function as self-important individuals—they’re always cells in a colony who live entirely for the well-being of the colony. Polar bears are almost<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8229#footnote-1-8229\" id=\"note-1-8229\" rel=\"footnote\">1</a> always solitary selfish individuals, rarely sacrificing themselves for the well-being of neighboring polar bears.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/1.3.2-emergence-animal-comparison.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8241\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/1.3.2-emergence-animal-comparison.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"749\" height=\"315\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/1.3.2-emergence-animal-comparison.png 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/1.3.2-emergence-animal-comparison-600x253.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/1.3.2-emergence-animal-comparison-768x324.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/1.3.2-emergence-animal-comparison-750x316.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 749px) 100vw, 749px\" /></a></p> \n<p>But humans are more complicated. Like ants, humans often function as cells in a larger tribe giant—but unlike ants, humans are <em>also </em>complex enough to function as true individual entities the way polar bears do. Just like our relationship with the Psych Spectrum, we function at multiple points along Emergence Tower simultaneously—as I worded it in <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/08/giants.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Chapter 2</a>, we travel up and down Emergence Tower’s <em>elevator.</em></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/1.3.3-human-emergence-range-v2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8351\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/1.3.3-human-emergence-range-v2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"650\" height=\"792\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/1.3.3-human-emergence-range-v2.png 1139w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/1.3.3-human-emergence-range-v2-493x600.png 493w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/1.3.3-human-emergence-range-v2-768x935.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/1.3.3-human-emergence-range-v2-616x750.png 616w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 650px) 100vw, 650px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Every human phenomenon becomes a little clearer when we look at it in 2D with the help of our Psych Spectrum. And things start to make even more sense when we also consider Emergence Tower. Seeing in 3D allows us to consider both of these ideas simultaneously.</p> \n<p>The visuals can get a little complicated here, especially when I’m the graphic designer, but try to bear with me. Emergence Tower is kind of like a z-axis we can flip on its side and add onto our x-y graph:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.2-Z-AXIS-v2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8339\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.2-Z-AXIS-v2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"700\" height=\"838\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.2-Z-AXIS-v2.png 2164w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.2-Z-AXIS-v2-501x600.png 501w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.2-Z-AXIS-v2-768x919.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.2-Z-AXIS-v2-627x750.png 627w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px\" /></a></p> \n<p>The Psych Spectrum takes a spectrum of human thought and behavior and turns it into a square—adding Emergence Tower goes a step further and turns the story of humans into a <em>cube</em>.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.3AM-3D-loaf-no-slices-v2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8378 \" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.3AM-3D-loaf-no-slices-v2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"531\" height=\"480\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.3AM-3D-loaf-no-slices-v2.png 1369w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.3AM-3D-loaf-no-slices-v2-600x543.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.3AM-3D-loaf-no-slices-v2-768x695.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.3AM-3D-loaf-no-slices-v2-750x678.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 531px) 100vw, 531px\" /></a></p> \n<p>This is our full “loaf” of human thinking and behavior. And like a loaf of bread, we can cut it into slices.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.3AM-3D-loaf-slices-v3.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8379 \" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.3AM-3D-loaf-slices-v3.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"532\" height=\"481\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.3AM-3D-loaf-slices-v3.png 1369w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.3AM-3D-loaf-slices-v3-600x543.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.3AM-3D-loaf-slices-v3-768x695.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.3AM-3D-loaf-slices-v3-750x678.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 532px) 100vw, 532px\" /></a></p> \n<p>When we’re focusing on what goes on in our heads, we’re thinking about the very bottom of Emergence Tower—the ground-floor slice—which is the realm of individual psychology. We spent all of Chapter 7 here:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.4AM-3D-loaf-level-1-v2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8380 \" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.4AM-3D-loaf-level-1-v2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"531\" height=\"480\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.4AM-3D-loaf-level-1-v2.png 1369w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.4AM-3D-loaf-level-1-v2-600x543.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.4AM-3D-loaf-level-1-v2-768x695.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.4AM-3D-loaf-level-1-v2-750x678.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 531px) 100vw, 531px\" /></a></p> \n<p>To broaden our vision into 3D, let’s take a super oversimplified example of 500 people living as a community somewhere.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.5-500-individuals.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8244\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.5-500-individuals.png\" alt=\"500 indivi\" width=\"226\" height=\"358\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.5-500-individuals.png 1000w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.5-500-individuals-379x600.png 379w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.5-500-individuals-768x1216.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.5-500-individuals-474x750.png 474w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 226px) 100vw, 226px\" /></a></p> \n<p>And let’s say those 500 people are divided perfectly into 100 five-person families.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.6-100-families.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8245\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.6-100-families.png\" alt=\"100 families as slightly darker and larger red dots\" width=\"481\" height=\"335\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.6-100-families.png 1157w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.6-100-families-600x418.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.6-100-families-768x535.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.6-100-families-750x522.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 481px) 100vw, 481px\" /></a></p> \n<p>A five-person family is a mini giant. Now let’s imagine that each of those families is part of a small five-family community.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.7-twenty-communities.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8246\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.7-twenty-communities.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"344\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.7-twenty-communities.png 1760w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.7-twenty-communities-600x275.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.7-twenty-communities-768x352.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.7-twenty-communities-750x343.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> \n<p>And finally, those 20 communities are all part of the larger 500-person community.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.8-one-community.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8248\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.8-one-community.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1290\" height=\"436\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.8-one-community.png 2390w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.8-one-community-600x202.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.8-one-community-768x259.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.8-one-community-750x253.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1290px) 100vw, 1290px\" /></a></p> \n<p>This simple example reminds us how a 500-person community doesn’t just exist as a 500-person giant on the “hundreds of people” slice of the loaf—it permeates the entire part of the loaf below it.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.9-500-people-with-loaf-v2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8344\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.9-500-people-with-loaf-v2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1200\" height=\"1414\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.9-500-people-with-loaf-v2.png 2000w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.9-500-people-with-loaf-v2-509x600.png 509w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.9-500-people-with-loaf-v2-768x905.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.9-500-people-with-loaf-v2-637x750.png 637w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1200px) 100vw, 1200px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Likewise, that 500-person community is itself a smaller piece of the larger communities, factions, and nations that exist on the slices above it.</p> \n<p>To really understand the 500-person community and why it is the way it is, we have to examine each layer of smaller units that make it up and the larger giants that encompass it. To really understand what’s going on with a group of any size, we have to consider how it interacts with all parts of the loaf.</p> \n<p>The same goes for understanding individuals. The people within our 500-person community don’t exist as isolated minds. Each person is an individual organism, an “organ” in the mini giant of their family, a piece of tissue in the larger giant of their small community, a cell in the 500-person community giant, and an organelle, molecule, atom, and subatomic particle in the subsequent even larger giants above—all at the same time. Each of those slices plays a role in influencing the thoughts and behavior of the individuals, and in turn, each person plays a small part in influencing the giants they’re a part of.</p> \n<p>This only gets more complicated when we move out of simplified hypothetical land and into the real world—where the actual tiers of giants are messy, overlapping, and highly variable.</p> \n<p>And the thing is, every entity in the loaf—every couple, family, community, company, university, religious institution, political party, nation, even the species as a whole—is doing its own thing in the other two dimensions. Each of them moves around the first dimension—the What axis—as its thoughts and behavior shift and evolve. And each is in its very own Psych Spectrum struggle along the second dimension.</p> \n<p>To make sense of all this, we need to discuss the critical, invisible force that ties all of the loaf’s slices together: culture.</p> \n<p class=\"has-large-font-size\"><strong>Culture</strong></p> \n<p>Culture is the collection of unwritten rules, norms, and values around “how we do things here.” Every human environment—from the two-person couples to the 20-person classrooms to the 20,000-person companies—is embedded with its own culture<em>. </em>We can visualize a group’s culture as a kind of gas cloud that fills the room when the group is together.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/8.1-culture-cloud-BIG.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8250\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/8.1-culture-cloud-BIG.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"510\" height=\"512\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/8.1-culture-cloud-BIG.png 947w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/8.1-culture-cloud-BIG-150x150.png 150w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/8.1-culture-cloud-BIG-598x600.png 598w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/8.1-culture-cloud-BIG-768x770.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/8.1-culture-cloud-BIG-748x750.png 748w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 510px) 100vw, 510px\" /></a></p> \n<p>A human society is a rich tapestry of overlapping and sometimes sharply contradictory cultures, and each of us lives at our own unique cultural intersection.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/8.3-culture-overlaps.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8251\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/8.3-culture-overlaps.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"501\" height=\"591\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/8.3-culture-overlaps.png 806w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/8.3-culture-overlaps-509x600.png 509w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/8.3-culture-overlaps-768x905.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/8.3-culture-overlaps-636x750.png 636w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 501px) 100vw, 501px\" /></a></p> \n<p>On the largest scale, we’re all a part of a few vast pan-national cultural clouds—where customs like shaking hands, waving hi, New Year’s Eve, birthdays, card games, sports fandom, and tipping, to name a few, have taken on broadly shared meaning. Each nation is a smaller cloud with its own sub-culture. Americans who believe they have nothing at all in common with certain other Americans are taking for granted the rich set of specific norms, customs, and values they actually share.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8229#footnote-2-8229\" id=\"note-2-8229\" rel=\"footnote\">2</a> <p>Inside of the broadest cultures are thousands of smaller communities—each with their own cultural vibe that exerts influence on its members. Someone working in a tech startup in the Bay Area is simultaneously living inside of the broad human community, the global Western community, the American community, the U.S. West Coast community, the San Francisco community, the tech industry community, the startup community, the community of their workplace, the community of their college alumni, the community of their extended family, the community of their group of friends, a few other bizarre SF-y situations, and a dozen other communities their particular life happens to be part of (including, if they’re a regular visitor here, the Wait But Why community). Most immediate to each of us are the micro-cultures of our immediate family, closest friends, and romantic relationships. Going against the current of all the larger communities combined tends to be easier than violating the unwritten rules of the most intimate mini cultures in someone’s life.</p> <p>A culture’s rules, norms, and value systems pertain to a wide spectrum of human experience. A group of friends, for example, has a way they do birthdays, a way they do emojis, a way they do talking behind each other’s backs, a way they do bragging and self-deprecation, a way they do conflict, and so on. They even have a way they do cultural adherence for each area—one group of friends might find it delightful when a certain friend regularly appalls them with their uncharacteristic-for-the-culture bluntness while in another, the same violation might be grounds for dismissal from the community. Some cultures apply pressure to live a certain kind of lifestyle or abide by a particular structure—a culture that shames being single at 30 incentivizes people to be on the lookout for a life partner in their mid-20s, while another one might not apply that pressure at all, driving different behavior.</p> <p>Living simultaneously in multiple cultures is part of what makes being a human tricky. Do we keep our individual inner values to ourselves and just do our best to match our external behavior to whatever culture we’re currently in a room with? Or do we stay loyal to one particular culture and live by those rules everywhere, even at our social or professional peril? Or do we just go for full authenticity and let our inner values drive our behavior, unaltered, for better or worse? Do we navigate our lives so to seek out external cultures that match our own values and minimize friction? Or do we surround ourselves with a range of conflicting cultures to put some pressure on our inner minds to learn and grow? Whether you consciously realize it or not, you’re making these decisions all the time.</p> <p>And these decisions matter—because the cultures we spend time in have a major influence over us.</p> <p style=\"font-size:28px\"><strong>Cultural Incentives</strong></p> <p>Remember Moochie from <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/09/stories.html#johnsons\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Part 1</a>?</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/21.2-Moochie.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-7544\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/21.2-Moochie.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"380\" height=\"258\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/21.2-Moochie.png 415w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/21.2-Moochie-300x204.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/21.2-Moochie-345x234.png 345w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/21.2-Moochie-103x70.png 103w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 380px) 100vw, 380px\" /></a></p> <p>The Johnsons drove Moochie’s behavior in a certain direction by adding Snausage rewards and electrocution penalties into his environment. This whole thing:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/22.2-moochie-equation.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-7552\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/22.2-moochie-equation.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"210\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/22.2-moochie-equation.png 1126w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/22.2-moochie-equation-300x105.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/22.2-moochie-equation-768x269.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/22.2-moochie-equation-600x210.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/22.3-moochie-equation-2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-7553\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/22.3-moochie-equation-2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"211\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/22.3-moochie-equation-2.png 1126w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/22.3-moochie-equation-2-300x105.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/22.3-moochie-equation-2-768x269.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/22.3-moochie-equation-2-600x210.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a></p> <p>In <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/09/mute-button.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Part 2</a>, we looked at how the brutal dictator King Mustache did the same thing by imposing harsh penalties for saying the wrong thing, and how liberal democracies then turned the tables on the Power Games by writing their own set of rules that punished the violation of inalienable rights. We also looked at how free economic markets reward the creation of value with money. These are all the same idea, just with different zaps and treats.</p> <p>Cultures use incentive systems too. Instead of physical shocks or jail time as penalties, cultures enforce their values with social and psychological punishments like criticism, ridicule, shame, and ostracism. Instead of Snausages or money, they use rewards like praise, acceptance, approval, respect, and admiration.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/8.2-culture-cloud-zaps-alicia.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8253\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/8.2-culture-cloud-zaps-alicia.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"571\" height=\"573\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/8.2-culture-cloud-zaps-alicia.png 913w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/8.2-culture-cloud-zaps-alicia-150x150.png 150w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/8.2-culture-cloud-zaps-alicia-598x600.png 598w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/8.2-culture-cloud-zaps-alicia-768x771.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/8.2-culture-cloud-zaps-alicia-748x750.png 748w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 571px) 100vw, 571px\" /></a></p> <p>In other words, in a species that collectively never really leaves middle school, cultures determine what kind of behavior makes you cool or uncool. For social creatures like humans—creatures with a <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2014/06/taming-mammoth-let-peoples-opinions-run-life.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">big, fat mammoth</a> in their heads—these <em>cultural</em> zaps and treats work just as well as (and often far better than) the more tangible kinds of incentives, helping to align the behavior of people in a group.</p> <p>Which brings up an important question: why does a particular culture enforce certain values and not others?</p> <p style=\"font-size:28px\"><strong>Culture, in 2D</strong></p> <p>In your head, your Higher Mind and Primitive Mind compete for control of your psychology. On the group level, the two minds jostle for control over the group’s <em>culture.</em> When people are around other people, their Primitive and Higher Minds band together with others of their kind in a group-wide power struggle. And like a human’s personality, a group’s culture has a general Psych Spectrum equilibrium it tends to default to.</p> <p>The psych equilibrium of a culture exerts a vertical <em>pull </em>on the individuals within it—filling each culture with a kind of electrical current.</p> <p>In higher-minded culture, the pervading values are Higher-Mind driven, making it a <em>positively charged </em>culture that exerts an upward pull on the psyches of their members. The behavior rewarded or zapped by the culture align more with the Higher Mind’s values, and interactions carry a generally high-minded tone, which empowers the Higher Minds of the people within the culture.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/17-HM-grid-alicia.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8254\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/17-HM-grid-alicia.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"574\" height=\"487\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/17-HM-grid-alicia.png 1258w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/17-HM-grid-alicia-600x509.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/17-HM-grid-alicia-768x652.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/17-HM-grid-alicia-750x637.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 574px) 100vw, 574px\" /></a></p> <p>In a negatively charged culture, the Primitive Mind is on its home turf. Conversations are pettier, values are more superficial, conformity beats individuality, and things tend to feel a lot like middle school. A culture like this speaks directly to the Primitive Minds in the heads of its members, continually stoking their fires and forcing their marginalized Higher Mind counterparts to swim upstream.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/17-PM-circle-alicia.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8255\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/17-PM-circle-alicia.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"634\" height=\"494\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/17-PM-circle-alicia.png 1481w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/17-PM-circle-alicia-600x468.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/17-PM-circle-alicia-768x599.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/17-PM-circle-alicia-750x585.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 634px) 100vw, 634px\" /></a></p> <p>As always, the power struggle exists on a spectrum, not as a binary switch—and cultures, like people, can often be somewhere in the middle. But in groups, where this kind of “coalition” can form, one mind gaining control over the culture is like an extreme home-field advantage in sports. Control over the electrical charge of the air and power over the painful zaps and pleasurable rays that police cultural dissidents is such a leg up that, for the “away team,” it can be very hard to overcome.</p> <p style=\"font-size:28px\"><strong>Culture, in 3D</strong></p> <p>So far, we’ve been focusing on the relationship between culture and individuals. In that realm, culture functions as the rules of engagement. But when we move up to higher levels of emergence, where groups of people function like giant organisms, a group’s culture becomes the giant’s <em>personality. </em></p> <p>The culture cloud that surrounds us as individuals is, to a giant, a field of energy radiating through its body and coloring the way it thinks and acts.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/9-giant-culture-personality.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8256\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/9-giant-culture-personality.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"181\" height=\"441\" /></a></p> <p>A giant’s culture also affects how it interacts with the emergence levels above it, as each giant’s prevailing culture determines how it plays with other giants, and which types of other giants it will gravitate towards.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/10-giant-play-with-others.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8257\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/10-giant-play-with-others.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"703\" height=\"434\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/10-giant-play-with-others.png 1965w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/10-giant-play-with-others-600x370.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/10-giant-play-with-others-768x474.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/10-giant-play-with-others-750x463.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 703px) 100vw, 703px\" /></a></p> <p>With all of this in our mind, let’s return now to the world of human <em>beliefs</em>.</p> <p>We spent last chapter thinking about thinking here:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.4AMb-3D-loaf-level-1-w-ladder.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8381 \" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.4AMb-3D-loaf-level-1-w-ladder.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"531\" height=\"480\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.4AMb-3D-loaf-level-1-w-ladder.png 1369w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.4AMb-3D-loaf-level-1-w-ladder-600x543.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.4AMb-3D-loaf-level-1-w-ladder-768x695.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/2.4AMb-3D-loaf-level-1-w-ladder-750x678.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 531px) 100vw, 531px\" /></a></p> <p>But human thinking, like all things human, happens up and down Emergence Tower—in 3D. Where we are on the Thinking Ladder at any given moment is affected by what’s happening on the emergence slices above us—by the giants we’re a part of, and where <em>they</em> are on the Thinking Ladder.</p> <p>For the rest of this post, we’ll zoom in on one specific type of culture: <em>intellectual culture</em>. There are all kinds of intellectual cultures out there, but we can slot them into two broad categories:</p> <p>Idea Labs and Echo Chambers.</p> <p>We all know what an Echo Chamber is. An Idea Lab will be our term for the opposite. Let’s discuss:<a id=\"idea-labs\"></a></p> <p class=\"has-large-font-size\"><strong>Idea Labs</strong></p> <p>When the Higher Mind is in control of a single human’s intellect, the human becomes a high-rung thinker. When a <em>group</em> of Higher Minds band together to take over a group of people’s intellectual culture, they form what we can call an Idea Lab. An Idea Lab is an intellectual culture where high-rung thinking thrives and where it can be done well communally. Idea Lab culture abides by the Higher Mind’s intellectual goals, values, preferences, and tastes, and it sees thinking, ideas, discussion, debate, questions, answers, information, and knowledge through the Higher Mind’s lens. Any size community can be an Idea Lab if the intellectual culture in that community is Idea-Lab-like.</p> <p>We’re going to take a look at both cultures from two emergence perspectives:</p> <p><strong>1) The individual level</strong>—how the culture affects the individuals within it</p> <p><strong>2) The group level—</strong>how the culture affects the group itself, as a larger-emergence giant</p> <p style=\"font-size:28px\"><strong>How Idea Labs affect individuals</strong></p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/11.5-loaf-IL-INTRO-1-sm.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8372 \" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/11.5-loaf-IL-INTRO-1-sm.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"450\" height=\"428\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/11.5-loaf-IL-INTRO-1-sm.png 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/11.5-loaf-IL-INTRO-1-sm-600x570.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/11.5-loaf-IL-INTRO-1-sm-768x730.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/11.5-loaf-IL-INTRO-1-sm-750x713.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 450px) 100vw, 450px\" /></a></p> <p>To a person, a community is kind of like a mini nation, and as a mini nation, an Idea Lab is a lot like a liberal democracy. Both are rooted in values: a typical liberal democracy is premised on Enlightenment values like freedom and equal opportunity; an Idea Lab centers around the Enlightenment values of truth and free expression. A liberal democracy is governed by rules about the <em>way </em>things are done, not the end result—and this binding process is outlined in a constitution. An Idea Lab has a binding process too: the scientific method.</p> <p>Unlike communities of actual career scientists, most real-world communities don’t exist solely to find truth, so it’s not exactly the literal scientific method happening as much as it’s an intellectual culture that’s scientific-method-<em>esque</em>, generally abiding by the same principles.</p> <p>This makes an Idea Lab’s cultural point system pretty straightforward—the cool kids do stuff that serves truth, and those who do otherwise are lame. A few examples:</p> <p><strong><span style=\"font-size: 18px;\">Idea Labs like independent thought.</span></strong> In an Idea Lab, people are more interested in what you have to say if they think your thoughts come from a self-determined place, and they’ll begin to tune you out if they suspect you tend to just repeat what you heard from another source. This is partially because independent thinkers usually respect other independent thinkers and find low-rung dogmatics to be transparent and boring. But it’s also for practical reasons. An independent thinker, regardless of their viewpoints, is an active brain in the room, contributing something original to the system. A dogmatic who simply regurgitates the same viewpoints, without independent critical thought, contributes little.</p> <p><strong><span style=\"font-size: 18px;\">Idea Labs like intellectual diversity.</span></strong> An Idea Lab is a place of intellectual <em>pluralism</em>. It’s a miniature marketplace of ideas where multiple, varied viewpoints coexist. High-rung thinkers know that intellectual diversity is the key quality that fills a community with the rich collection of idea puzzle pieces needed to find truth. On topics where everyone seems to agree, people in an Idea Lab will have an instinct to prod that consensus with contrarian ideas and to play devil’s advocate. Thoughtful contrarianism is valued because there’s an implicit understanding that the evolution of knowledge works like the evolution of life. Only through mutations does evolution happen. In the natural world, a mutant is a biological weirdo. In an Idea Lab, bold, quirky, contrarian thinkers—intellectual weirdos—are seen as critical innovators in the lab who provide mutant ideas to the community.</p> <p style=\"font-size:18px\"><strong>Idea Labs respect thinkers who stay close to the humility sweet spot tightrope.</strong></p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/13-2x2-tightrope.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8259\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/13-2x2-tightrope.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"436\" height=\"444\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/13-2x2-tightrope.png 862w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/13-2x2-tightrope-590x600.png 590w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/13-2x2-tightrope-768x781.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/13-2x2-tightrope-737x750.png 737w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 436px) 100vw, 436px\" /></a></p> <p>In an Idea Lab, conviction is used sparingly and with caution—because conviction levels in an Idea Lab are used as “degree of certainty” stamps. The more conviction in your voice when you make a claim, the more you’re saying: “You can <em>trust </em>me that this is truth. I’ve already done the hard work to vet this information, and it’s safe to incorporate it into your beliefs without much testing.” For trusted thinkers in an Idea Lab, conviction offers fellow members a beautiful knowledge-acquisition shortcut and saves them the effort and opportunity cost of re-vetting what has already been tested.</p> <p>I’ve always been a fan of this cartoon that explains what volts, amps, and ohms are.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8229#footnote2-1-8229\" id=\"note2-1-8229\" rel=\"footnote2\">1</a> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/14.1-ohms-comic.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8260\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/14.1-ohms-comic.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"430\" height=\"432\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/14.1-ohms-comic.png 495w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/14.1-ohms-comic-150x150.png 150w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 430px) 100vw, 430px\" /></a></p> <p>In communities, info flows in a similar way. Amps are info. Volts are conviction. And ohms are skepticism.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/14.2-ohms-comic-new-labels.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8262\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/14.2-ohms-comic-new-labels.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"453\" height=\"457\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/14.2-ohms-comic-new-labels.png 900w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/14.2-ohms-comic-new-labels-150x150.png 150w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/14.2-ohms-comic-new-labels-594x600.png 594w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/14.2-ohms-comic-new-labels-768x776.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/14.2-ohms-comic-new-labels-743x750.png 743w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 453px) 100vw, 453px\" /></a></p> <p>In an Idea Lab, this system is geared around letting truth in and keeping bullshit out. In a good trust network, the Skepticism character (i.e. the Belief Bouncer) is able to trust the Conviction character, which can spare everyone a bunch of work. When a proven high-rung thinker expresses info with a lot of conviction <em>umph</em>, the listener will lower the skepticism ohms without thinking too hard about it.</p> <p>On the other hand, unearned, false conviction is a major no-no in an Idea Lab. Conviction from a trusted source opens a clear path directly into someone’s most sacred intellectual space: their beliefs. And when conviction is used carelessly, it infects those beliefs with misconceptions, slant, and inaccuracies—the Idea Lab’s toxins—like feeding someone food that will make them sick. Super uncool kid thing to do—and the Idea Lab will punish you by lowering your Rung Rating and damaging your reputation, boy-who-cried-wolf style. Getting caught abusing the use of conviction means you lose the ability to believably communicate your degree of certainty when you say something—because people will know you have a spotty history. Now, when you up the volts and express conviction, listeners will take it with a grain of salt, keep the skepticism filter tight, and feel the need to further verify it.</p> <p>For all the same reasons, humility wins you major respect in an Idea Lab—where “I don’t know” is a very cool thing to say. People in an Idea Lab are high-rung thinkers, so they know that knowledge is hard. They know the world is a foggy, incredibly complex place, and they’re well aware that no single human knows that much about it. So humility is seen as evidence of honesty and self-awareness—evidence that you “get it.” A reputation for humility makes you intellectually powerful in an Idea Lab—because when a typically humble person does express conviction, it carries a ton of meaning and everyone’s ears perk up.</p> <p><strong><span style=\"font-size: 18px;\">Idea Labs love arguments.</span></strong> Truth is a sacred value in an Idea Lab, and ideas themselves are seen as nothing more than puzzle pieces to be used in its service. Idea Labs treat all beliefs as works-in-progress, and they see an argument as not only fun, competitive, and intellectually stimulating, but also as a useful exercise for everyone involved, because they know you can only get to knowledge by rigorously testing hypotheses. That’s why Idea Labs are cultures of disconfirmation, debate, and argument. These values mean an Idea Lab doubles as a miniature <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/09/american-brain.html#mpi-gauntlet\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">marketplace-of-ideas gauntlet</a>, a place where no idea is safe. In an Idea Lab, ideas are meant to be criticized, not respected; kicked, not coddled. But the aggression never falls on the <em>thinker</em>—arguments are often heated, but they don’t get personal. As a necessary condition of truth finding, <em>people </em>in an Idea Lab are safe to express any viewpoint they want.</p> <p>Spending time as a citizen of an Idea Lab mini nation—whether it happens at dinners with your spouse, in classroom discussions, in book club get-togethers, in text conversations, on long scrolls down Reddit threads, or anywhere else—makes you smarter. It shows you where the holes in your knowledge are; it grants you access to a network of intellectual trust that floods you with new, accurate information; it introduces you to a variety of perspectives; it teaches you how to effectively judge others’ ideas and claims. It’s a constant intellectual workout that keeps you sharp.</p> <p>But even more importantly, an Idea Lab helps you fight the good fight in your own head. I don’t care how good a thinker you are, your intellect will always be in an uphill Psych Spectrum battle against gravity. Even if you get good at thinking with your Higher Mind, your Primitive Mind never gives up and is always looking for a loophole—some personal insecurity, some emotional attachment, some lingering psychological baggage from your past—to latch onto as an opportunity to re-hijack the wheel.</p> <p>No one thinks like pure top-rung Scientists all the time. More often, after a brief stint on the top rung during an especially lucid and humble period, we start to <em>like </em>the new epiphanies we gleaned up there a little too much and we quickly drop down to the Sports Fan rung. And that’s okay. It might even be optimal to be a <em>little </em>over-confident in our intellectual lives. Taking a rooting interest in our ideas—a new philosophy, a new lifestyle choice, a new business strategy—allows us to really give them a try, somewhat liberated from the constant “but are we really sure about this?” nag from the Higher Mind.</p> <p>The Sports Fan rung alone isn’t a problem—especially since, like cheering fans in a stadium who know deep down that their fandom is a little silly, somewhere behind the fog of a Sports Fan’s confidence is the self-awareness of a still-pretty-present Higher Mind. The problem is that inviting some fog into the equation is a bit like closing your eyes <em>for just another minute or two </em>after you’ve shut your alarm off for good—it’s riskier than it feels. Getting a little attached to or emotional about an idea is a small step away from drifting unconsciously into <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/09/thinking-ladder.html#unfalsifiableland\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Unfalsifiable Land</a> and into the oblivion of the intellectual slums down below. We’re programmed by evolution to be terrible thinkers, so we should never get cocky.</p> <p>Alcoholics Anonymous is a Higher Mind support network, where a bunch of people suffering from a disease—one in which the animal they live in has become fixated on using alcohol to ruin their lives—can get together and help each other fight the good fight. An Idea Lab is the same thing for our intellect—Dogmatics Anonymous.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/15-ropes-v3.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8354 \" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/15-ropes-v3.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"800\" height=\"752\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/15-ropes-v3.png 1622w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/15-ropes-v3-600x564.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/15-ropes-v3-768x722.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/15-ropes-v3-750x705.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" /></a></p> <p>People in Dogmatics Anonymous keep each other from falling too low down the Thinking Ladder.</p> <p>The social pressure helps: if it’s considered cool to think with your Higher Mind, you’re more likely to do so.</p> <p>And the intellectual pressure helps: If the people around you are good enough at thinking to notice when you’re being biased, hypocritical, conveniently gullible, or selectively unempathetic—and if they’re culturally encouraged to call you on it—you’re less likely to keep doing those things or fall into a well of false conviction. In an Idea Lab, the room is usually too well-lit for the Primitive Mind to get away with anything too sneaky.</p> <p>When you spend enough time in an Idea Lab, humility and self-awareness are <em>inflicted </em>upon you, whether you like it or not. When you float upwards on the Knowledge-Conviction graph, Idea Lab culture pulls you back down to the tightrope.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8229#footnote-3-8229\" id=\"note-3-8229\" rel=\"footnote\">3</a> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/16-2x2-IL-magnet.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8265\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/16-2x2-IL-magnet.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"500\" height=\"476\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/16-2x2-IL-magnet.png 862w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/16-2x2-IL-magnet-600x571.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/16-2x2-IL-magnet-768x731.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/16-2x2-IL-magnet-750x714.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 500px) 100vw, 500px\" /></a></p> <p>Or, depicted far more hilariously: People in an Idea Lab are like this squirrel trying to get to a bird feeder, and Idea lab culture “greases the arrogance pole.”</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/16.2-2x2-IL-magnet-alicia-v2.gif\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8266\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/16.2-2x2-IL-magnet-alicia-v2.gif\" alt=\"\" width=\"498\" height=\"474\" /></a></p> <p>All of these forces combine together to make an Idea Lab a big magnet on top of our ladder.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/18-ladder-w-magnet-1.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8268\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/18-ladder-w-magnet-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"659\" height=\"519\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/18-ladder-w-magnet-1.png 2068w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/18-ladder-w-magnet-1-600x473.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/18-ladder-w-magnet-1-768x605.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/18-ladder-w-magnet-1-750x591.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 659px) 100vw, 659px\" /></a></p> <p>And that’s just the benefits of an Idea Lab to the individuals within it. Bringing our attention upwards on Emergence Tower, a community starts to look less like a mini nation of people and more like a single giant organism—and here, we see just how powerful Idea Lab culture can be.</p> <p style=\"font-size:28px\"><strong>How Idea Labs affect groups</strong></p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/11.6-IL-INTRO-2-v2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8269\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/11.6-IL-INTRO-2-v2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"283\" height=\"401\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/11.6-IL-INTRO-2-v2.png 996w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/11.6-IL-INTRO-2-v2-424x600.png 424w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/11.6-IL-INTRO-2-v2-768x1086.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/11.6-IL-INTRO-2-v2-530x750.png 530w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 283px) 100vw, 283px\" /></a></p> <p>An Idea Lab is a giant, high-rung thinker with super-human intelligence. At its best, it’s the ultimate Scientist. The group’s mini marketplace of ideas is the giant’s brain, with the individual members’ brains as its neurons.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/20-IL-brains.png\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8270\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/20-IL-brains.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"2319\" height=\"1300\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/20-IL-brains.png 2319w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/20-IL-brains-600x336.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/20-IL-brains-768x431.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/20-IL-brains-750x420.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 2319px) 100vw, 2319px\" /></a></p> <p>This single, multi-mind thinking system is far superior to its individual members at learning new things and separating truth from fiction. If the mind of a single high-rung thinker is a truth-seeking tool, the mind of an Idea Lab giant is truth-seeking <em>factory.</em></p> <p>Instead of a single Attention Bouncer, bound by the limits of his time and the scope of his curiosity, the Idea Lab organism has a <em>team</em> of Attention Bouncers importing information.</p> <p>Instead of a single Belief Bouncer trying his hardest to judge the accuracy of info, the Idea Lab giant has a squadron of Belief Bouncers at the door of the community’s generally accepted beliefs. In order to make it past the gate, a hypothesis or piece of information has to make it past <em>each </em>of the bouncers. Even if a convincing falsehood succeeds in duping most of the community, all it takes is one person’s Belief Bouncer discovering it to be flawed and they’ll quickly expose it as fraud to everyone else. The beliefs of high-rung thinkers are readily falsifiable—so this is a fast process that leaves the bad information with little hope.</p> <p>Instead of a single Puzzler working on building hypotheses out of scattered information, the constant hum of discussion in an Idea Lab makes puzzling collaborative. With everyone mostly saying what they’re really thinking, the line between puzzling together a hypothesis and testing that hypothesis in a gauntlet of criticism blurs. When dialectic and debate are core parts of an intellectual culture, new ideas can be tested as they’re being formed, in real-time, making the step-by-step knowledge-building process of the individual high-rung thinker into a single, dynamic process.</p> <p>As a giant organism, an Idea Lab is an example of emergence at its finest: a system that is far more than the sum of its parts.</p> <p>The Idea Lab giant is an organism that takes in raw information and converts it into knowledge and wisdom. Its immune system specializes in sorting truth from fiction and rooting out falsehoods and bias—the toxins that threaten the knowledge manufacturing process.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/19.2-IL-level-2-giant-FLOW-v4.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8355 \" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/19.2-IL-level-2-giant-FLOW-v4.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"650\" height=\"531\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/19.2-IL-level-2-giant-FLOW-v4.png 1461w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/19.2-IL-level-2-giant-FLOW-v4-600x490.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/19.2-IL-level-2-giant-FLOW-v4-768x627.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/19.2-IL-level-2-giant-FLOW-v4-750x612.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 650px) 100vw, 650px\" /></a></p> <p>One of the coolest properties of an Idea Lab is its ability to play nicely with other Idea Labs and seamlessly meld together with them into larger Idea Labs. Take the simplest example: two couples.</p> <p>To continue exploiting the Johnsons from Part 1, let’s imagine that in their marriage, they have formed a strong, high-rung intellectual culture together. When they’re together, they form a tiny Idea Lab—a two-mind system that’s always working on a lifelong, collaborative mission to become a little less wrong and a little less foolish. They disagree about ideas all the time, but their intellectual arguments rarely double as <em>fights</em>. They get heated alongside smiles and jokes and light-hearted jabs at each other. Like any humans, they’re both prone to sink downwards on the ladder, but they keep each other honest, and they both have a history of changing their mind when the other makes a point so good they can’t deny the truth of it—an intellectual “offer they can’t refuse.”</p> <p>Now, let’s also imagine that they have their next-door neighbors, the Smiths, over for dinner one night.</p> \n   <div id=\"#eggEight\">\n    <div id=\"image-map-pro-1545\"></div>\n   </div> <p>The Smiths are also an Idea Lab couple. So very quickly, the dinner becomes a rich discourse, full of original ideas and critical thinking, as the four of them seamlessly merge their two-person Idea Labs into a four-person Idea Lab. The dinner table becomes a four-person marketplace of ideas, with double the knowledge, double the intellectual diversity, and double the keen-eyed Bouncers and Puzzlers at their service. The hangout goes on for hours after the food is done, and everyone leaves feeling a little bit smarter than they were before. The two couples, sharing high-rung intellectual values, both end up feeling positive about the experience, as the large amount of critical thinking that happened made the dinner super interesting and fun.</p> <p>The thing going on here is that Idea Labs are <strong>micro-divided,</strong> and <strong>macro-united. </strong>On a micro scale, Idea Labs and the people within them disagree often—that’s the intellectual diversity component.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/23.1-micro.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8271\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/23.1-micro.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"663\" height=\"509\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/23.1-micro.png 1986w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/23.1-micro-600x460.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/23.1-micro-768x589.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/23.1-micro-750x575.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 663px) 100vw, 663px\" /></a></p> <p>On a macro scale, all Idea Labs are broadly united by a common set of intellectual values—a shared understanding that they’re all ultimately on the same truth-seeking team.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/23.2-micro-macro-v2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8331 \" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/23.2-micro-macro-v2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"658\" height=\"498\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/23.2-micro-macro-v2.png 2193w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/23.2-micro-macro-v2-600x454.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/23.2-micro-macro-v2-768x582.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/23.2-micro-macro-v2-750x568.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 658px) 100vw, 658px\" /></a></p> <p>This allows Idea Labs of all sizes to combine together just as easily as the Johnsons and Smiths did. Two can become four around a dinner table. A six-college-friends Idea Lab can become part of a larger one 50 students strong when those friends walk into one of <a href=\"https://bridgeusa.org/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Bridge USA</a>’s many university clubs dedicated to ideological diversity. High-rung science departments can “team up” with other departments by criticizing each other’s findings.</p> <p>Even farther up Emergence Tower, every Idea Lab in the U.S. is a tiny piece of the grand American Idea Lab—the U.S. marketplace of ideas—each of them a little pocket of neural tissue in the giant U.S. brain. In the U.S., the joint effort of hundreds of thousands of Idea Labs of all different shapes and sizes generates that big, bright orb of light held by the collective nation’s giant Higher Mind.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/24-US-orb-2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8274\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/24-US-orb-2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"385\" height=\"370\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/24-US-orb-2.png 1248w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/24-US-orb-2-600x576.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/24-US-orb-2-768x737.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/24-US-orb-2-750x720.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 385px) 100vw, 385px\" /></a></p> <p>The U.S. marketplace of ideas is in turn a lobe of tissue in the largest Idea Lab of all—the uber-giant brain of the collective high-rung thinkers of the human race. Through a worldwide mega-web of different size Idea Labs, each individual high-rung human thinker is able to link into the giant species brain as a single tiny neuron.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/25-earth-orb.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8275\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/25-earth-orb.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"550\" height=\"491\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/25-earth-orb.png 2066w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/25-earth-orb-600x536.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/25-earth-orb-768x685.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/25-earth-orb-750x669.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 550px) 100vw, 550px\" /></a></p> <p>Idea Labs can blend together so effortlessly because the only glue needed to tie them together is a simple set of high-rung intellectual values, all centered around a common mission to get closer to the truth.</p> <p>This is what Thomas Paine was getting at when he said:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8229#footnote2-2-8229\" id=\"note2-2-8229\" rel=\"footnote2\">2</a> <p><em>Science, the partisan of no country, but the beneficent patroness of all, has liberally opened a temple where all may meet. … The philosopher of one country sees not an enemy in the philosopher of another: he takes his seat in the temple of science, and asks not who sits beside him.</em></p> <p>Idea Labs are awesome because they’re awesome at every level of emergence.</p> <p><strong>They’re great at the individual level. </strong>Individuality is valued, people are respected, and communities are safe spaces to share whatever ideas you’re thinking about, without fear of negative consequences. An Idea Lab is a good mini nation to be citizen of. Spending time in an Idea Lab makes you smarter, wiser, humbler, more realistic, and helps pull your internal battle <em>upwards.</em></p> <p><strong>Idea Labs are great at the community level.</strong> The same people encouraged to retain their full individuality at the low-emergence level also get to enjoy the benefits of being a cell in a larger, superintelligent system, with all of the social and community perks that come along with it.</p> <p><strong>Idea Labs are great at the national and pan-national level.</strong> We have Idea Labs to thank for the collective knowledge tower we’ve built as a species, for the evolution of our species’ psychological maturation, and for the development of our growing philosophical clarity.</p> <p>Perhaps most importantly, Idea Labs bring to fruition a fundamental right:</p> <p style=\"font-size:24px\"><strong>The Free Speech Puzzle</strong></p> <p>Given how naturally Idea Lab culture fits into the broader spirit of the U.S. constitution, you might assume that at least Idea Labs would be the norm in a place like the U.S.—but they’re not. The U.S. was a country built to give the underdog Higher Mind a chance, but it wasn’t built to <em>enforce</em> the Higher Mind’s ideals on any citizen. Doing so would violate the core premise of the country: freedom from authoritarian rule. The Constitution puts its citizens in an environment where neither the government, nor other citizens, are allowed to impinge on any citizen’s right to live in a high-minded environment. But like the case with power, wealth, and the pursuit of happiness—the Constitution offers only the <em>opportunity </em>to enjoy the ideals of the Enlightenment, not a guarantee of that kind of life. In the U.S., you’re so free that you’re <em>free to be unfree</em>, if you so choose.</p> <p>We can apply this to the world of discourse. The reality is that while all Americans are living under the protection of the First Amendment, many aren’t living with freedom of speech. Constitutional lawyer Greg Lukianoff highlights this distinction:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8229#footnote2-3-8229\" id=\"note2-3-8229\" rel=\"footnote2\">3</a> <p><em>Though often used interchangeably, the concept of freedom of speech and the First Amendment are not the same thing. While the First Amendment protects freedom of speech and freedom of the press as they relate to duties of the state and state power, freedom of speech is a far broader idea that includes additional cultural values. These values incorporate healthy intellectual habits, such as giving the other side a fair hearing, reserving judgment, tolerating opinions that offend or anger us, believing that everyone is entitled to his or her own opinion, and recognizing that even people whose points of view we find repugnant might be (at least partially) right. At the heart of these values is epistemic humility – a fancy way of saying that we must always keep in mind that we could be wrong or, at least, that we can always learn something from listening to the other side.</em></p> <p>Free speech, like any Value Games privilege, requires both the government <em>and</em> the culture to be on board. The U.S. Constitution makes free speech possible—but only within the right <em>culture</em> does the freedom come to fruition.</p> <p>Let’s apply this idea to t-shirts. The Constitution gives all citizens the right to walk around wearing t-shirts in public. As far as we’re concerned, there might as well be a T-Shirt Amendment that protects this right for all citizens (the right to bare arms?). But if I live in a community in which one of the unwritten cultural beliefs is that wearing t-shirts is evil—and anyone who does so will likely be permanently shunned—I’m not gonna walk around in a t-shirt. Sure, the T-Shirt Amendment means that I can’t be imprisoned by the government for wearing a t-shirt—but my entire <em>social</em> life would be destroyed by doing so, which is just a different kind of incredibly harsh penalty. Being deeply invested in a community allows the culture of that community to essentially override my constitutional rights. The actual enjoyment of a constitutional right relies on finding a community who <em>agrees with the Constitution</em> about it.</p> <p>Likewise, in cultures that impose their own harsh penalties for saying the wrong thing, freedom of speech all but vanishes, along with the presence of the marketplace of ideas. This is why Idea Labs are so important. Idea Labs are fully bought in to the value of free speech—they see it as a constitutional gift and make it a way of life.
