Idea Lab culture is the critical second piece that completes the free speech puzzle.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/27-free-speech-puzzle.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8276\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/27-free-speech-puzzle.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"336\" height=\"347\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/27-free-speech-puzzle.png 900w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/27-free-speech-puzzle-581x600.png 581w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/27-free-speech-puzzle-768x793.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/27-free-speech-puzzle-727x750.png 727w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 336px) 100vw, 336px\" /></a></p> <p>If the Idea Lab were the only intellectual culture out there, things in the human world might be simple. But Idea Labs aren’t the only human intellectual culture, because the Higher Mind isn’t the only human mind. Liberal concepts like free speech are thoroughly artificial constructions, and no matter where they exist, they’ll always be the underdog, constantly fighting against the gravity of human nature.</p> <p>Some people do manage to spend most of our time in the little pockets of Higher-Mind-run cultures that have managed to subsist inside of the broader primitive ocean. But many of us aren’t so lucky. The typical human today, around the world, and inside the U.S., is spending their life inside communities that are culturally charged the old-fashioned way.<a id=\"echo-chambers\"></a></p> <p class=\"has-large-font-size\"><strong>Echo Chambers</strong></p> <p>Imagine you’ve just had your first baby. Super exciting right?</p> <p>And every day when you look at your baby, you can’t believe how cute it is.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.1-baby.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8277\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.1-baby.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"166\" height=\"203\" /></a></p> <p>Babies have a pretty high success rate at being cute. It’s one of the only things they’re talented at.</p> <p>But the thing is, there’s also that one baby out of every five or six that manages to not pull it off. The Upsetting-Looking Baby. We all know a few.</p> <p>And I’ve noticed a funny pattern—when I talk to the parents of an Upsetting-Looking Baby, they somehow don’t seem to realize what happened.</p> <p>The reason is the Primitive Mind is pulling one of its tricks. When you have a baby, your Primitive Mind knows that, cute or upsetting, baby survival is the key to its genetic mission, and it’s critical that you as the parent are fully obsessed with it.</p> <p>So let’s just say it turns out that your baby looks like this:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.2-upsetting-baby-v2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8357\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.2-upsetting-baby-v2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"179\" height=\"209\" /></a></p> <p>You’ll never realize it—because when you look at the baby, your Primitive Mind will quickly flood your head with delusional smoke and make you see what it wants you to see.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.3-parents.png\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-8279\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.3-parents.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"250\" height=\"441\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.3-parents.png 496w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.3-parents-341x600.png 341w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.3-parents-426x750.png 426w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 250px) 100vw, 250px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.4-parents.png\"><img class=\"wp-image-8280 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.4-parents.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"283\" height=\"324\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.4-parents.png 683w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.4-parents-525x600.png 525w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.4-parents-656x750.png 656w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 283px) 100vw, 283px\" /></a></p> <p>This is why everyone thinks their baby is super cute.</p> <p>But now imagine some friends come over.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.5-friends.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8281\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.5-friends.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"499\" height=\"478\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.5-friends.png 1312w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.5-friends-600x574.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.5-friends-768x735.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.5-friends-750x717.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 499px) 100vw, 499px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.6-friends.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8282\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.6-friends.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"501\" height=\"341\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.6-friends.png 1312w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.6-friends-600x408.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.6-friends-768x523.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.6-friends-750x510.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.6-friends-782x530.png 782w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.6-friends-345x234.png 345w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.6-friends-103x70.png 103w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 501px) 100vw, 501px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.7-friends.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8283\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.7-friends.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"501\" height=\"341\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.7-friends.png 1312w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.7-friends-600x408.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.7-friends-768x523.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.7-friends-750x510.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.7-friends-782x530.png 782w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.7-friends-345x234.png 345w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.7-friends-103x70.png 103w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 501px) 100vw, 501px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.8-friends.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8284\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.8-friends.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"500\" height=\"399\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.8-friends.png 1312w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.8-friends-600x478.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.8-friends-768x612.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.8-friends-750x598.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 500px) 100vw, 500px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.9-friends.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8285\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.9-friends.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"500\" height=\"420\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.9-friends.png 1312w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.9-friends-600x504.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.9-friends-768x645.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.9-friends-750x630.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 500px) 100vw, 500px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.10-friends.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8286\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.10-friends.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"500\" height=\"443\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.10-friends.png 1312w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.10-friends-600x531.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.10-friends-768x680.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/7.10-friends-750x664.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 500px) 100vw, 500px\" /></a></p> <p>A couple’s baby is their most sacred object. And everyone who visits the house knows that—so they go with the flow and confirm the parents’ delusion, fully and unquestionably.</p> <p>When a culture holds an object to be sacred, the culture becomes embedded with an implicit set of iron-clad social rules about how that object must be treated. Praising the object becomes a very cool thing to do, while saying anything bad about the object is considered an act of unredeemable blasphemy. When something becomes uncriticizable to a culture, the culture becomes the opposite of an Idea Lab about that thing. It becomes an Echo Chamber.</p> <p>It doesn’t mean the culture is necessarily an Echo Chamber <em>in general</em>—it may be a classic Idea Lab most of the time and simply flip to the other side when the conversation turns to one particular topic.&nbsp;If you’re a sports fan (actual, not metaphorical), you’re well-accustomed to this kind of situation.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.1-packers-comic.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8288\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.1-packers-comic-600x380.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"599\" height=\"379\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.1-packers-comic-600x380.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.1-packers-comic-768x486.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.1-packers-comic-750x475.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.1-packers-comic.png 1500w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 599px) 100vw, 599px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.2-packers-comic.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8289\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.2-packers-comic.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"381\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.2-packers-comic.png 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.2-packers-comic-600x380.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.2-packers-comic-768x486.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.2-packers-comic-750x475.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.3-packers-comic.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8290\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.3-packers-comic.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"601\" height=\"380\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.3-packers-comic.png 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.3-packers-comic-600x380.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.3-packers-comic-768x486.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.3-packers-comic-750x475.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 601px) 100vw, 601px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.4-packers-comic.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8291\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.4-packers-comic.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"601\" height=\"380\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.4-packers-comic.png 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.4-packers-comic-600x380.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.4-packers-comic-768x486.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.4-packers-comic-750x475.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 601px) 100vw, 601px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.5-packers-comic.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8292\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.5-packers-comic.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"381\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.5-packers-comic.png 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.5-packers-comic-600x380.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.5-packers-comic-768x486.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.5-packers-comic-750x475.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.6-packers-comic.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8293\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.6-packers-comic.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"601\" height=\"380\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.6-packers-comic.png 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.6-packers-comic-600x380.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.6-packers-comic-768x486.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.6-packers-comic-750x475.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 601px) 100vw, 601px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.7-packers-comic.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8294\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.7-packers-comic.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"601\" height=\"380\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.7-packers-comic.png 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.7-packers-comic-600x380.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.7-packers-comic-768x486.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.7-packers-comic-750x475.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 601px) 100vw, 601px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.8-packers-comic.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8295\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.8-packers-comic.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"381\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.8-packers-comic.png 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.8-packers-comic-600x380.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.8-packers-comic-768x486.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/28.8-packers-comic-750x475.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a></p> <p>Every home that’s populated entirely by lifelong Packers fans is an immediate Echo Chamber when it comes to Packers fandom. They may happily argue about everything else, including Packer-related topics (e.g. “Are they good enough to make the playoffs this year or not?”), but on the specific topic of “who are you rooting for in this game?”, any answer other than “the Packers” is blasphemy. Packers fandom is the sacred baby in the house, and everyone damn well better call it cute.</p> <p>So why do some objects or ideas become sacred to certain humans and certain cultures?</p> <p>As we’ve discussed in previous chapters, it often has a lot to do with identity. Every human is an impossibly complex, fluid, ever-evolving unique personality—and to the Higher Mind, that’s more than enough of an identity. But the Primitive Mind doesn’t understand human complexity or uniqueness, so it sees your innermost self as a blank page. A non-identity. For the Primitive Mind to feel secure about your identity, it needs you to attach external things to it—symbols, resources, profession, family name, status, religion, ethnicity, political affiliation, nationality, hometown, college alma mater, social group, music tastes—anything really, as long as it’s crisp and clear and tangible enough for its simple programming to grasp.</p> <p>The Primitive Mind is always hungry to meld you into larger giants, so its favorite kinds of external things to stitch to your identity are those that also stitch <em>you </em>into a group. When an object can help it define both who you are and which tribe you’re in, it latches onto it.</p> <p>Sports fandom is a classic Primitive Mind identity attachment because it checks a lot of these boxes. It’s crisp and clear. It’s linked together with other identity attachments like hometown and, in the case of something like the World Cup, nationality and even ethnic group. It binds you together with everyone else who likes the same team. There are even uniforms you can wear, painting the good-guy Us colors directly on your body, as you root for them against the bad-guy Them team with their bad-guy Them fans from their bad-guy Them hometown wearing their bad-guy Them colors.</p> <p>If we didn’t understand the Primitive Mind, we might think it’s a bit odd that a group of out-of-shape people sitting in a living room in sweatpants will scream “We won!” when a bunch of professional athletes they don’t know won a game they had no part in. But to the Primitive Mind, the athletes and the game are just vehicles to do the important thing—bind you together with other people. The Primitive Mind is so well-programmed to bind together with others that using only something as superficial as sports fandom, you can seamlessly become one with a total stranger you know nothing about—like <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/29-hug.png\">the time</a> at a Red Sox playoff game when I cuddled with a big, scary, mean man I never spoke to before or since.</p> <p>Which brings me back to our Packer fan family. When the son changed his rooting interest, all he said was, “actually I’m rooting for the Vikings.” But the Primitive Minds of his family members heard a <em>cascade</em> of betrayal, up and down Emergence Tower.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/30-packers-tower-1.png\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8724\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/30-packers-tower-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1471\" height=\"1422\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/30-packers-tower-1.png 1471w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/30-packers-tower-1-600x580.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/30-packers-tower-1-768x742.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/30-packers-tower-1-750x725.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1471px) 100vw, 1471px\" /></a></p> <p>He violated a sacred object—but really, he violated the core sense of unity and safety the Primitive Minds of his family members feel. That’s why a football team became a sacred object in the first place.</p> <p>But the reason sports fandom isn’t a bad thing is that it (usually) doesn’t harm anybody—it’s a form of fake, role-play tribalism. Jonathan Haidt gets at this when he provides the analogy: “Sports is to war as pornography is to sex.”<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8229#footnote2-4-8229\" id=\"note2-4-8229\" rel=\"footnote2\">4</a> Sports fandom lets humans exercise primitive tribal drives—which you can plainly see every time triumphant fans instinctively throw <a href=\"https://live.staticflickr.com/2724/4406125299_f794cf603a_z.jpg\"><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\">their</span></a> <a href=\"https://images.axios.com/DE0OYnJGMZEV-5wgEDVOqAUz_cU=/0x580:5568x3712/1920x1080/2019/07/08/1562546788548.jpg\"><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\">arms</span></a> <span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://talksport.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/5/2015/02/454071140_1.jpg\">up</a></span> like a conquering tribe of apes, or heartbroken fans cover their <span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://larrybrownsports.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/usc-fans.jpg\">heads</a></span> <a href=\"https://i.imgflip.com/tkgiy.jpg\"><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\">and</span></a> <span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://i2-prod.irishmirror.ie/incoming/article6775531.ece/ALTERNATES/s615b/Shocked-Chelsea-fans-in-despair.jpg\">faces</a></span> like apes being attacked. But they can exercise these drives without actually going to war. Sports fans, deep down, know the whole thing is just a game, which makes sports a harmless thing to build an Echo Chamber around.</p> <p>But other Echo Chambers aren’t as harmless.</p> <p>Echo Chambers become problematic, and even dangerous, when they don’t come along with deep-down self-awareness; when the sacred object is more sacred than the well-being of people; when the tribalism they generate is more like war and less like sports. We often see this kind of Echo Chamber in the worlds of religion, ethnicity, race, nationalism, economics, and, as we’ll get fully into in the next part of this series, politics.</p> <p>Let’s head back into 3D land and take a closer look.</p> <p style=\"font-size:28px\"><strong>How Echo Chambers affect individuals</strong></p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/11.8-loaf-EC-INTRO-1.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8300\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/11.8-loaf-EC-INTRO-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"450\" height=\"434\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/11.8-loaf-EC-INTRO-1.png 1943w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/11.8-loaf-EC-INTRO-1-600x579.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/11.8-loaf-EC-INTRO-1-768x741.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/11.8-loaf-EC-INTRO-1-750x723.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 450px) 100vw, 450px\" /></a></p> <p>To understand how Echo Chambers work, just think about how Idea Labs work and then imagine the opposite. For example:</p> <p><strong>Where Idea Labs are cultures of critical thinking and debate, Echo Chambers are cultures of agreement and confirmation.</strong></p> <p>There are a few reasons for this:</p> <p>First, it comes from a core distinction between how the two cultures view ideas. Idea Labs see people and their ideas as separate entities—people are meant to be respected, ideas are not. In Echo Chambers, a person’s ideas are part of their identity, so respecting a person and respecting their ideas are one and the same. While people in an Idea lab argue with each other for fun, disagreeing with someone in a culture of agreement is seen as <em>rudeness</em>, and a heated argument about ideas in an Echo Chamber is indistinguishable from a fight. To put a visual to it, Idea Lab culture views agreement and decency as separate, unrelated axes, while Echo Chamber culture views agreement and decency as a single axis:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/31.1-agreement-decency-v2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8710 size-full\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/31.1-agreement-decency-v2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1650\" height=\"1159\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/31.1-agreement-decency-v2.png 1650w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/31.1-agreement-decency-v2-600x421.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/31.1-agreement-decency-v2-768x539.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/31.1-agreement-decency-v2-750x527.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1650px) 100vw, 1650px\" /></a></p> <p>Second, Echo Chambers are devoted to <em>specific </em>ideas. While the constitution of the Idea Lab mini nation is devoted to a <em>kind</em> of thinking, an Echo Chamber is an idea temple whose constitution is a set of sacred beliefs themselves.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/32-A-_-B.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8304\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/32-A-_-B.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"756\" height=\"219\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/32-A-_-B.png 1506w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/32-A-_-B-600x174.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/32-A-_-B-768x222.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/32-A-_-B-750x217.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 756px) 100vw, 756px\" /></a></p> <p>The Idea Lab’s quest for knowledge and truth becomes the Echo Chamber’s quest for <em>confirmation</em> of the community’s sacred story.</p> <p>Changing the goal from truth-seeking to belief-confirmation flips a bunch of other values to their opposites.</p> <p>The intellectual diversity of the Idea Lab’s pluralism is a major threat to an Echo Chamber, which replaces it by the intellectual uniformity of purism. For the same reasons, Echo Chambers don’t like intellectual mutants—inconvenient independent thought is frowned upon in an Echo Chamber, where abiding by collective groupthink tends to go over much better.</p> <p>In assigning Rung Ratings, Echo Chambers are concerned only with <em>what </em>you think, not how you got there, basing judgments not on accuracy but on <em>loyalty </em>to the sacred ideas.</p> <p>The cultural incentives follow suit. The orange, downward-charged air of an Echo Chamber, like the blue-green, upward-charged air of an Idea Lab, administers rewards of acceptance, approval, and respect, and electroshocks of criticism, ridicule, shame, and ostracism—but the criteria for the incentives is almost the exact opposite.</p> <p>In an Echo Chamber culture, which sees knowledge as easy and obvious, conviction is seen as a sign of knowledge, intelligence, and righteousness (assuming, of course, you have the right viewpoints), and it’s socially rewarded with respect and deference. Humility, on the other hand, is looked down upon in an Echo Chamber, where saying “I don’t know” just makes you sound stupid and ignorant. Changing your mind too much in an Echo Chamber gets you zapped with negative labels, like <em>wishy-washy </em>and <em>flip-flopping</em> and <em>waffling</em>.</p> <p>An Echo Chamber’s sacred ideas are the community’s newborn baby. And the best way to both express your allegiance to the community and prove your own intellectual and moral worth is to call the baby cute, as fervently as you can. Otherwise known as:</p> <p><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8305 size-large\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/32.2-virtue-signaling-750x75.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"75\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/32.2-virtue-signaling-750x75.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/32.2-virtue-signaling-600x60.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/32.2-virtue-signaling-768x77.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/32.2-virtue-signaling.png 1500w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></p> <p>Virtue signaling comes in a few forms:</p> <p>1) Talking about how cute the baby is (i.e. how correct the community’s sacred beliefs are)</p> <p>2) Talking about how uncute the rival babies are (i.e. how wrong the community’s ideological opponents are)</p> <p>3) Talking about how great the community itself is</p> <p>4) Talking about how awful the rival communities themselves are</p> <p>So some form of the statement “We are so right / knowledgeable / smart / virtuous and/or They are so wrong / ignorant / stupid / evil.”</p> <p>Virtue signaling is your Primitive Mind’s way of expressing your sheer Us-ness. While conviction in an Idea Lab expresses your degree of certainty about what you’re saying, conviction in an Echo Chamber expresses the degree of your Us-ness. The baby isn’t kind of cute. It’s not maybe cute. It’s deeply fucking cute. Period.</p> <p>When a group of people is together expressing their Us-ness at the same time, it not only makes each individual feel safe and loved and accepted and included, it provides a binding energy that unites the group. Participating in one of these sessions—as we all have—showers you with cultural reward, and it feels great in the same way eating Skittles feels great. It’s a classic form of primitive bliss.</p> <p>Positive incentives go a long way to unifying the Echo Chamber’s viewpoints—but in a community fused together by shared belief, they’re not enough. So they’re coupled with their partner in crime: <strong>taboo</strong>.</p> <p>Taboos exist in an Idea Lab, but you have to say something pretty extreme to violate one—and almost always, the offense is an attack on a person, not their idea: a mean-spirited racial slur, a degrading jab, a nasty low-blow. The only way for an otherwise-respected thinker to get culturally zapped by the sole expression of an idea itself is to express a viewpoint so inane that it totally lowers people’s opinion of their intellectual ability.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/33-inane-opinion.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8306 \" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/33-inane-opinion.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"528\" height=\"111\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/33-inane-opinion.png 1443w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/33-inane-opinion-600x126.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/33-inane-opinion-768x162.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/33-inane-opinion-750x158.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 528px) 100vw, 528px\" /></a></p> <p>The over-application of taboo is the bane of free speech, so pro-free-speech cultures use it sparingly. This frees the Idea Lab’s <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/09/mute-button.html#speech-curve\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Speech Curve</a>&nbsp;to freely line up with its <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/09/mute-button.html#thought-pile\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Thought Pile</a>.</p> <p>Echo Chamber Nation, meanwhile, is more like Hypothetica.</p> <p>In Hypothetica, the dictator, King Mustache, deemed <em>himself </em>to be the country’s sacred newborn baby, and he used his mute button to electrify any sentiments other than calling him tremendously cute.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/34-baby-king-1.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8332\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/34-baby-king-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"495\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/34-baby-king-1.png 1900w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/34-baby-king-1-600x396.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/34-baby-king-1-768x507.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/34-baby-king-1-750x495.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> <p>In a country like the U.S., the harm principle prevents Echo Chamber communities from using physical penalties, so they use taboo as their mute button instead.</p> <p>Taboo is an Echo Chamber’s censorship electric fence—a police force that slaps members with the social fines of status reduction or reputation damage, the social jail time of ostracism, and even the social execution of permanent excommunication. In your criticisms of the <em>opposing</em> viewpoints and those who hold them, you’re free in an Echo Chamber to be as personal and as vicious as you please—cutting slurs, degrading jabs, and nasty low-blows included. Not only is this kind of expression not considered taboo, it’s a sign of moral and intellectual awesomeness. But disagree with the sacred beliefs and you’ve committed blasphemy in place of worship—and you’ll be promptly electrocuted.</p> <p>The Idea Lab’s criticism gauntlet, a safe place for people and a dangerous one for ideas, provides a type of resistance that elevates truth and wisdom and pushes the whole entity, along with each of its members, toward intellectual and moral growth. An Echo Chamber’s taboo minefield makes it a safe and protected space for all ideas that confirm the sacred beliefs and a very dangerous space for ideas—and people—that don’t. This type of resistance has the opposite effect, discouraging new ideas and intellectual innovation and repressing the growth of the community and its members.</p> <p>Of course, both of these make sense, given the cultural objectives. High-rung thinkers want their perception of reality to change and get closer to reality, so they invite the productive kind of resistance. Low-rung thinkers want their perception of reality to remain untouched. They view safety not as safety <em>to</em> <em>speak </em>certain ideas but as safety <em>from hearing </em>certain ideas—making an Idea Lab a place of danger for them. So they invite the repressive kind of resistance.</p> <p>Liberal democracies were built to be bubbles of free speech in a world of censorship—bubbles where Higher Minds could band together and form high-minded giants, safe from the bullying of the Primitive Mind.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/26.2-orange-green.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8308\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/26.2-orange-green.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"580\" height=\"483\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/26.2-orange-green.png 1796w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/26.2-orange-green-600x499.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/26.2-orange-green-768x638.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/26.2-orange-green-750x623.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 580px) 100vw, 580px\" /></a></p> <p>Idea Labs are communities born of this spirit, taking full advantage of the privilege afforded to them by the liberal constitutions. But the Primitive Minds in our heads don’t understand any of this. They run on automated software, unable to see the present day or understand its liberal values. No matter what country they’re in, they want to do what they were programmed to do: play the ancient Power Games by banding together into the old-fashioned kind of giant.</p> <p>And the thing about Primitive Minds is, as simple and unthinking as they may be, they can also be highly innovative. It’s like what Jeff Goldblum said.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/26.1-life-finds-a-way.gif\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8309\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/26.1-life-finds-a-way.gif\" alt=\"\" width=\"500\" height=\"260\" /></a></p> <p>You can put as many constraints on Primitive Minds as you want to, but some of them will usually find a way to get together and play the Power Games. In a country like the U.S., the Echo Chamber is one way they do it. The Echo Chamber is a mini dictatorship—a cultural dictatorship—of Power Games inside of a liberal democracy. A non-free-speech zone inside of a free speech nation.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/26.3-orange-green-orange-1.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8311\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/26.3-orange-green-orange-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"650\" height=\"540\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/26.3-orange-green-orange-1.png 1796w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/26.3-orange-green-orange-1-600x499.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/26.3-orange-green-orange-1-768x638.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/26.3-orange-green-orange-1-750x623.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 650px) 100vw, 650px\" /></a></p> <p>This kind of mini dictatorship has the opposite effect on its citizens that an Idea Lab has. If an Idea Lab is Dogmatics Anonymous, an Echo Chamber is a dogma keg party.</p> <p>Some reasons why the dogma keg party sucks:</p> <p><strong><span style=\"font-size: 18px;\">An Echo Chamber makes you more primitive.</span></strong> Spending time in an environment full of primitive smoke gives the Primitive Mind home-field advantage in the battle inside your head. In an Echo Chamber, people are constantly releasing the human version of wolfpack pheromones—the words they use, the virtue signaling, the in-group / out-group social structure, the binary worldview. This isn’t simply the Primitive Mind’s way of thinking, it’s like gas in the air that ignites our primitive fires. Tribal language is the Primitive Mind’s way of signaling to each other: “Let’s fucking do this. Let’s band together and go to war.” Your Higher Mind is already in a serious uphill battle for sanity—but trying to tame your Primitive Mind in that kind of environment is like trying to get a shark to refrain from eating while surrounding it with the scent of blood.</p> <p><strong><span style=\"font-size: 18px;\">An Echo Chamber makes you arrogant.</span></strong> On top of the general downward pull on your psyche, an Echo Chamber pulls directly downwards on your intellect. When everyone around you believes humility is for the weak-minded and conviction is a sign of intelligence and righteousness, it’s going to have an effect on you. Even in an Idea Lab culture where humility is the ultimate intellectual virtue, we have a very hard time actually being humble. So when you take away that cultural pressure and apply the reverse pressure, <em>shaming</em>&nbsp;humility—good fucking luck.</p> <p>At the same time, the strength of your beliefs goes up. In an Idea Lab you’re always being reminded that opposing ideas have validity, that all ideas are flawed, that you and everyone else is prone to bias, and that the world is ridiculously complex. This is like an air jet that blows the fog of delusion out of the environment. In an Echo Chamber, all of those reminders have been filtered out by the system, allowing the fog to grow thick. Members of an Echo Chamber tend to share both an oversimplified conception of the world and an inflated view of their own intellect. When everyone around you shares your delusions, the communal fog strengthens delusion, which allows conviction to rise to laughable levels.</p> <p>Instead of pulling you toward the Knowledge-Conviction diagonal, the Echo Chamber pulls you upwards into the arrogant zone.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/35-2x2-EC-magnet.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8312\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/35-2x2-EC-magnet.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"500\" height=\"476\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/35-2x2-EC-magnet.png 862w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/35-2x2-EC-magnet-600x571.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/35-2x2-EC-magnet-768x731.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/35-2x2-EC-magnet-750x714.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 500px) 100vw, 500px\" /></a></p> <p>This is why people who spend too much time in an Echo Chamber end up as an intellectual contradiction—holding views that are strongly felt but weakly supported.</p> <p><strong><span style=\"font-size: 18px;\">An Echo Chamber makes you intellectually helpless.</span></strong> Those who want to become better thinkers will have a hard time in an Echo Chamber, where the constant barrage of confirmation of a single viewpoint, along with the prohibition of dissent and open debate on the sacred topics, removes all the most critical tools of knowledge-acquisition from the environment. It’s an environment where A) people think knowledge is easy, B) accuracy isn’t taken into account for ideas that confirm the dogma, C) honest new hypotheses are rarely being formed, and D) the testing of existing assumptions or new incoming confirmation, through dissent and criticism, is culturally discouraged. A + B + C + D = an environment of imposed ignorance. How could anyone learn real stuff in that environment? They couldn’t.</p> <p>And when you’ve been ignorant for too long, you don’t just lack knowledge, your learning skills dull. Learning is a skill like anything else—it takes practice—and your ability to think critically atrophies. People who surround themselves by Idea Lab cultures get constant practice at defending their ideas and challenging others. In the Echo Chamber’s safe-from-dissent-space, you remain an amateur, which makes the prospect of trying to migrate from your environment to a more argumentative one incredibly daunting.</p> <p><strong><span style=\"font-size: 18px;\">An Echo Chamber makes you more of a dick.</span></strong> When the Primitive Mind gets control of your heart, it’ll happily toggle your ability to feel empathy up and down to suit its purposes—and resisting this is all the more difficult in an environment totally isolated from the maligned group, where myths and stereotypes about them permeate every conversation, and where it’s believed that hating the right people is precisely what makes someone a good person. When you come to believe that people outside the Echo Chamber are not worth talking to, it’s easy to forget that they’re full, real people just like you.</p> <p><strong><span style=\"font-size: 18px;\">An Echo Chamber bullies you into submission.</span></strong> Those who manage to remain self-aware enough to try to improve will be met with the social aspect of the Echo Chamber’s cultural rubric. If you try to step outside the standard groupthink viewpoints, the Echo Chamber will dock your social status, and your likability, and your credibility. Your friends will talk behind your back. Your family will discuss how you’ve changed. Your co-workers will exclude you from happy hour drinks. Your fellow dogmatics have built their identities, their sense of stability, and their self-esteem around the Echo Chamber’s set of delusions—and trying to improve will be subconsciously perceived by others as a personal threat. But since self-awareness is scarce in Echo Chambers, they’ll consciously just think you’re an asshole.</p> <p>All of this adds up to an Echo Chamber culture being a big, fat magnet at the bottom of the How You Think ladder.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/36-laddder-w-magnet-EC-1.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8314\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/36-laddder-w-magnet-EC-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"671\" height=\"529\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/36-laddder-w-magnet-EC-1.png 2068w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/36-laddder-w-magnet-EC-1-600x473.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/36-laddder-w-magnet-EC-1-768x605.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/36-laddder-w-magnet-EC-1-750x591.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 671px) 100vw, 671px\" /></a></p> <p>While the pull of an Idea Lab makes you smarter, wiser, and more humble, the Echo Chamber magnet makes you ignorant, arrogant, delusional, unempathetic, and inept. Living your life in an Echo Chamber tastes as good as Skittles…and it’s just as bad for you.</p> <p>Riding up the emergence elevator, from the world of individuals to the world of giants, we’re reminded why Echo Chambers exist in the first place:</p> <p style=\"font-size:28px\"><strong>How Echo Chambers affect groups</strong></p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/11.9-loaf-EC-INTRO-2-v2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8315\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/11.9-loaf-EC-INTRO-2-v2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"274\" height=\"388\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/11.9-loaf-EC-INTRO-2-v2.png 996w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/11.9-loaf-EC-INTRO-2-v2-424x600.png 424w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/11.9-loaf-EC-INTRO-2-v2-768x1086.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/11.9-loaf-EC-INTRO-2-v2-530x750.png 530w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 274px) 100vw, 274px\" /></a></p> <p>If an Idea Lab giant looks like this:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/AM-IL-giant-v2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8333 \" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/AM-IL-giant-v2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"257\" height=\"387\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/AM-IL-giant-v2.png 900w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/AM-IL-giant-v2-398x600.png 398w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/AM-IL-giant-v2-768x1157.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/AM-IL-giant-v2-498x750.png 498w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 257px) 100vw, 257px\" /></a></p> <p>An Echo Chamber is more like the old-school kind of giant:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/37AM-giant-w-strings.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8318\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/37AM-giant-w-strings.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"296\" height=\"691\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/37AM-giant-w-strings.png 477w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/37AM-giant-w-strings-257x600.png 257w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 296px) 100vw, 296px\" /></a></p> <p>When you think about Echo Chambers not as a collection of individuals, but as a primitive human giant playing the Power Games, all of the Echo Chamber’s odd characteristics make much more sense—in the same way individual ant behavior makes the most sense when you zoom out and look at how the colony works as a whole. Revisiting the above Echo Chamber qualities from the giant organism perspective helps us see them in a new light.</p> <p>To survive, a giant needs to be glued together well, and the Echo Chamber is glued together by a shared set of beliefs. While an Idea Lab draws its strength from its intellectual diversity, the Echo Chamber thrives on intellectual uniformity:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/37-brains-EC-3.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8325\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/37-brains-EC-3.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"393\" height=\"521\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/37-brains-EC-3.png 848w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/37-brains-EC-3-452x600.png 452w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/37-brains-EC-3-768x1019.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/37-brains-EC-3-565x750.png 565w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 393px) 100vw, 393px\" /></a></p> <p>The multi-colored brain network in an Idea Lab is a marketplace of ideas that functions as a super-brain—a giant, superintelligent thinking machine. But the Echo Chamber’s network isn’t a giant brain at all. It’s a solid-colored <em>agreement network—</em>a bloc of hijacked brains, tightly glued together by shared beliefs in order to generate brute strength in numbers.</p> <p>For a giant glued together by shared beliefs, confirmation of those beliefs are like the giant’s food—the giant relies on a steady incoming stream of confirmation for sustenance and strength. So Echo Chambers are factories that specialize in confirmation manufacture.</p> <p>The Echo Chamber’s collective Attention Bouncers scour the world for bright red information cherries that support the giant’s core beliefs—anything that helps promote the “We are so right / knowledgeable / smart / virtuous and They are so wrong / ignorant / stupid / evil” manifesto. The standards for confirmation cherries aren’t high—it can be random anecdotes or statistics, strongly worded opinions, out-of-context quotes, whatever. It’s not important whether the confirmation is true or something that would pass for confirmation outside the Echo Chamber—most people in an Echo Chamber already believe, and all they need from confirmation is a nice continual flow to keep morale high and the belief glue at full strength.</p> <p>Social pressure in an Echo Chamber plays its role, lining up with the main mission. Expressing confirmation is socially rewarded in an Echo Chamber, so the giant’s circulatory system—the communication network—ends up flooded with the very ripest confirmation cherries. When new, juicy nuggets of dogma-supporting info are discovered, they spread through the system like wildfire. The confirmation factory is also great at twisting the less bright cherries to make them better—through a game of telephone, one person’s somewhat-relevant anecdote can quickly morph into a confirmed, undeniable fact about the world that members treat as further scientific proof that the sacred baby is obese and adorable. This is its own kind of market that pushes the best supporting arguments—real or manufactured—straight into the beliefs of the Echo Chamber’s members, since the Belief Bouncers of low-rung thinkers usually give an immediate free pass to friendly, confirming information.</p> <p>If the Idea Lab giant is the ultimate Scientist, the Echo Chamber is the ultimate Zealot. And like any zealot, an Echo Chamber relies not just on belief but on full <em>conviction. </em>An Echo Chamber’s conviction isn’t just a trademark quality of the Echo Chamber giant—it’s the giant’s lifeblood.</p> <p>But strength that relies on conviction is brittle, and vulnerable. In many cases, the conviction of many Echo Chamber members is entirely sourced in their trust in other members’ conviction, many of whose conviction is derived from the conviction of others still. It’s like a conviction Ponzi Scheme. In reality, the Echo Chamber’s dogma baby isn’t usually very cute at all, and the fervent belief that it is relies on the complete absence of questioning or real discussion about it. For a giant that relies on conviction to survive, doubt is deadly.</p> <p>In an Idea Lab, people know that the information stream entering the system will be full of toxins—deceptions, slant, falsehoods, bullshit surveys and studies, cherry-picked research, misleading statistics, etc.—and there needs to be a strong immune system to keep their body of knowledge healthy. Their immune system is the idea gauntlet with its culture of dissent and disconfirmation. Information and suppositions that manage to make it through the gauntlet are very likely to be non-toxic—and the continual re-examination of the Idea Lab’s accepted assumptions help to root out toxins that somehow slipped by.</p> <p>An Echo Chamber works the opposite way. The Idea Lab’s toxin—bias and misconception—is the Echo Chamber’s immune system. The Idea Lab’s immune system—doubt and dissent—is precisely the Echo Chamber’s toxin. Each immune system is made of that which the other immune system is built to guard against.</p> <p>For an Echo Chamber giant, doubt that threatens to infiltrate the system from the outside, where it can catch on and spread, is like a deadly virus. So the Echo Chamber’s immune system is a multi-layered filter system that leaves little to chance. To successfully generate doubt in an Echo Chamber’s neurons, dissent has to first make it past the cherry-picking filter. Then it has to survive the filter that specializes in misinterpreting, distorting, and re-framing inconvenient info (or, if all that fails, discrediting the source). Dissent that makes it this far has to figure out a way to spread through a social network that punishes members for sharing it. Finally, when the occasional devastating stat or damning news story or well-reasoned dissenting op-ed does manage to reach the minds of Echo Chamber members, there’s a last line of defense—denial. Most Echo Chamber members are low-rung thinkers, which means they’re unfalsifiable—they enforce Echo Chamber rules inside their own heads, and their cognitive biases provide the final blockade.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/38-EC-level-2-giant-FLOW-v2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8358 \" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/38-EC-level-2-giant-FLOW-v2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"585\" height=\"590\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/38-EC-level-2-giant-FLOW-v2.png 1304w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/38-EC-level-2-giant-FLOW-v2-150x150.png 150w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/38-EC-level-2-giant-FLOW-v2-595x600.png 595w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/38-EC-level-2-giant-FLOW-v2-768x775.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/38-EC-level-2-giant-FLOW-v2-743x750.png 743w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 585px) 100vw, 585px\" /></a></p> <p>But even with an airtight immune system in place to thwart invasion by doubt viruses, the Echo Chamber is vulnerable to an internal threat. H. L. Menken said, “The most dangerous man to any government is a man who is able to think things out for himself, and without regard for the prevailing superstitions and taboos.” Same story for Echo Chambers. In addition to the large number of Attorneys and Zealots who believe every part of the dogma, there are some people in every Echo Chamber who don’t actually believe the dogma—just like there are some people who visit new parents who are well aware that the baby isn’t actually cute. These are the most dangerous people to an Echo Chamber, because as trusted members of the Us group, dissent from their mouths can circumvent the immune system and trigger dangerous cognitive dissonance in fellow members. If dissent from the outside threatens to become a doubt virus in the body of the Echo Chamber giant, dissent from the <em>inside</em> threatens to become a doubt <em>cancer</em>. This is why Echo Chambers go beyond making it uncool to express unpopular ideas and make it <em>taboo</em>. Cancer must be nipped at the bud.</p> <p>This is the kind of intense information control you see when reality is not your friend—when ideological purity is a survival requirement.</p> <p>When we look at how giants interact with other giants, we see a final distinction between Idea Labs and Echo Chambers.&nbsp;As we discussed earlier, Idea Labs merge seamlessly together with other Idea Labs, because while micro-divided in their viewpoints, they’re macro-united by common values like civility and truth. Echo Chambers, as expected, are the reverse—micro-united in their viewpoints, macro-divided with other communities who don’t share those viewpoints.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/39-micro-macro-EC.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8334\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/39-micro-macro-EC.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"661\" height=\"638\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/39-micro-macro-EC.png 1721w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/39-micro-macro-EC-600x579.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/39-micro-macro-EC-768x741.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/39-micro-macro-EC-750x724.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 661px) 100vw, 661px\" /></a></p> <p>Since Echo Chambers are built on agreement, they can only merge with other communities who are like-minded.</p> <p>Take the Millers.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/40-millers.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8336\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/40-millers.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"550\" height=\"509\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/40-millers.png 824w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/40-millers-600x556.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/40-millers-768x711.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/40-millers-750x694.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 550px) 100vw, 550px\" /></a></p> <p>The Millers are an Echo Chamber-y couple. When they were on the dating scene, both of them judged potential suitors based on like-mindedness, and their closeness as a couple is based on how much they agree on. Today, there’s a long list of viewpoints that, if expressed by one member, would cause a huge fight. In their social life, they judge things the same way—they seek out like-minded friends and see those who disagree with them as assholes and idiots.</p> <p>Of course, all people bond with others over shared viewpoints—but for the Millers, it’s the <em>only</em> way bonding happens. When they have new potential friends over for dinner, the more agreement that happens at the table—especially around the ideas the Millers hold most sacred, like politics and child-rearing—the more they’ll like the new friends and pursue them as long-term companions. Get-togethers at their house end up feeling very different from the Johnson-Smith dinner we observed earlier.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/40.4-tables.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8360\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/40.4-tables.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"401\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/40.4-tables.png 1525w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/40.4-tables-600x321.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/40.4-tables-768x410.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/40.4-tables-750x401.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/40.4-tables-374x200.png 374w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> <p>For Echo Chamber couples, it’s pretty easy to keep things glued tightly together. But as Echo Chambers grow in size, it becomes a greater challenge to hold them together by shared ideas—so usually, the binding beliefs are honed down and simplified to the common denominator ideas that the whole community can get behind. So while Idea Labs get even smarter and more nuanced as they grow, growing Echo Chambers become even dumber and more sure of themselves.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/40.5-mirror.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8335\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/40.5-mirror.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"324\" height=\"394\" /></a></p> <p>Remember the “me against my brother; me and my brother against our cousins; me, my brother, and my cousins against the stranger” cartoon from <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/08/giants.html#bedouin\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Part 1</a> of this series? Hatred or fear of a common enemy—an opposing group of people or ideas—is often the common denominator that unites large Echo Chambers. Without a prominent Them foil, an Echo Chamber’s Us is liable to split into rival Us/Them factions. So Echo Chambers don’t usually combine all the way up to the nationwide or species-wide level the way Idea Labs do—they grow until they hit a stable two-rival situation (think political parties or economic paradigms, to name two obvious examples). The hatred/fear mechanism to unite otherwise-divided Echo Chambers means that growing Echo Chamber coalitions don’t only get more ignorant—they get meaner and scarier.</p> <p>Earlier, I said that Idea Labs are awesome because they’re awesome at every level of emergence. Well Echo Chambers suck—because they suck at every level of emergence.</p> <p><strong>At the individual level</strong>, they repress free speech with a minefield of taboos, hinder learning and growth, and foster delusional arrogance. As mini nations, they’re more like old school dictatorships than constitutional democracies, and they pull their citizens downward on the Psych Spectrum.</p> <p><strong>At the community level</strong>, Echo Chambers are more than the sum of their parts only in raw power. Intellectually, the Echo Chamber giant is less capable of finding truth than a single independent thinker.</p> <p><strong>And at the national and pan-national level</strong>, we can thank Echo Chamber coalitions for fun parts of our history like war, oppression, bigotry, and genocide. The grand, species-wide Idea Lab is why we’ve made progress. Giant Echo Chambers are why that progress hasn’t happened a lot faster.</p> <p>All of us are living in at least a few Echo Chambers right now. To discover the Echo Chambers in your life, think about the different communities you’re a part of, and ask, “Is there a sacred baby in the room when I’m with those people? Are there ideas or viewpoints that are socially off-limits?”</p> <p>Here’s one other trick:</p> <p style=\"font-size:28px\"><strong>The Asshole Litmus Test</strong></p> <p>I’m a long-time fan of Randall Munroe and his always-delightful site <a href=\"https://xkcd.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">xkcd</a>. But I have a quibble with one particular xkcd comic:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/xkcd-free_speech_2x.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8337\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/xkcd-free_speech_2x.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"609\" height=\"622\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/xkcd-free_speech_2x.png 1132w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/xkcd-free_speech_2x-588x600.png 588w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/xkcd-free_speech_2x-768x784.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/xkcd-free_speech_2x-735x750.png 735w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 609px) 100vw, 609px\" /></a></p> <p>What Randall’s trying to do here is put an end to people claiming that their First Amendment rights are being violated when in fact, they’re not.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8229#footnote-4-8229\" id=\"note-4-8229\" rel=\"footnote\">4</a> And the comic does a good job at that. My problem with the comic is that it doesn’t address the difference between the two kinds of intellectual cultures we’ve discussed—and as such, it serves as perfect justification for <em>both</em> the Idea Lab and the Echo Chamber.</p> <p>For me, the critical word in the comic is “asshole.” Both kinds of intellectual culture agree with the comic—what they disagree on is the definition of asshole.</p> <p>Communities that define asshole as “someone who in arguments attacks people, not ideas,” or “someone who expresses conviction on viewpoints where they don’t actually know very much,” or “someone who never admits when they’re wrong” are Idea Labs. They eject from the club those who turn arguments into fights and hinder the community’s ability to search for truth.</p> <p>On the other hand, communities that define asshole as “someone who disagrees with what the community believes,” or “someone who holds views that we find offensive,” or “someone who criticizes the community or defends our rival community” are Echo Chambers. By “showing the door” to anyone who doesn’t say their baby is cute, they purge their community of dissent and ensure that things remain intellectually pure.</p> <p>The xkcd comic is a comic about intolerance—but the key question it leaves open is: intolerance of <em>what?</em> When you consider your own judgments and those within your communities, think about the criteria for intolerance. Ask yourself: How exactly is “asshole” being defined?</p> <p style=\"font-size:28px\"><strong>Liberal Democracy: Cultural Coexistence</strong></p> <p>This is a post series about both psychology and sociology, because to understand what’s going on in the world around us, we need to think about both. If we view humanity in 3D, we see that psychology and sociology are really studies of the same human system, just from different vantage points along Emergence Tower.</p> <p>What Idea Labs and Echo Chambers show us is that the Higher Mind – Primitive Mind tension isn’t just happening in each of our heads—it’s raging up and down Emergence Tower, at the heart of both our psychology and sociology. It’s a <em>3D struggle.</em></p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/41-loaf-battle-NEW-v2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8390 \" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/41-loaf-battle-NEW-v2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"641\" height=\"579\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/41-loaf-battle-NEW-v2.png 1369w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/41-loaf-battle-NEW-v2-600x543.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/41-loaf-battle-NEW-v2-768x695.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/41-loaf-battle-NEW-v2-750x678.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 641px) 100vw, 641px\" /></a></p> <p>This 3D struggle is the backstory behind human history and behind everything going on in our world today. It can also help us understand why the U.S. forefathers designed the system the way they did.</p> <p>The key innovation in a country like the U.S. isn’t to force higher-minded cultures and free speech upon anyone—it’s to allow people and communities to be whoever they want to be, in peace. <span style=\"font-size: inherit;\">The important thing is that membership in any community or culture, including a mini dictatorship, is purely </span><em style=\"font-size: inherit;\">voluntary</em><span style=\"font-size: inherit;\">. If the only threat zealots have is to kick you out of their social circle—to “show you the door”—higher-minded people are free in a liberal democracy to say, “goodbye!” and head elsewhere. That’s liberal democracy’s secret sauce.</span></p> <p>In countries like the U.S., Idea Labs and Echo Chambers <em>coexist</em>. Echo Chambers may slow down the country’s progress—but they can’t forcefully hijack the whole system like they do in the Power Games. Whether the Echo Chambers like it or not (and they usually don’t), a liberal democracy’s Idea Labs, with enough tenacity, can continue to power their country’s slow, steady forward march of progress.</p> <p>At least that’s how it’s supposed to be. Remember the words of a wise man, Jeff Goldblum. <em>Life finds a way.</em> Liberal democracies do a great job of capping the power of the Primitive Mind and even harnessing that power as an engine of progress. But like an animal in a cage, the Primitive Mind yearns for its natural habitat—the Power Games. And even the best system isn’t infallible.</p> <p>I look around the U.S. and other parts of the world today and I worry that something is off—that in the chaos of rapid advances in technology and media, our worst tendencies may be quietly breaking free. In the next part of this series, we’ll hold our noses and dive into everybody’s favorite topic: politics. If we can look out at the world around us and see it in 3D, we might just be able to figure out what’s really going on.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/political-disney-world\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-7661\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/next-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"100\" height=\"55\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/next-1.png 1100w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/next-1-300x164.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/next-1-768x419.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/next-1-600x327.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/next-1-239x130.png 239w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 100px) 100vw, 100px\" /></a></p> <p class=\"has-text-align-center wbwFont\">Chapter 9: <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/12/political-disney-world.html\">Political Disney World</a></p> \n     <div style=\"height:38px\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"wp-block-spacer\"></div> <p style=\"text-align: center;\">___________</p> <p>&nbsp;</p> <p>To keep up with this series, sign up for the&nbsp;<strong><a class=\"ClickPico PicoRule\">Wait But Why email list</a></strong> and we’ll send you the new posts right when they come out. It’s a super unannoying list I promise.</p> <p>Huge thanks to our Patreon supporters for making this series free for everyone. To support Wait But Why,&nbsp;<strong><a href=\"https://www.patreon.com/waitbutwhy\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">visit our Patreon page</a></strong>.</p> <p style=\"text-align: center;\">___________</p> \n     <div style=\"height:38px\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"wp-block-spacer\"></div> <p style=\"font-size:19px\"><strong>Three places to go next:</strong></p> <p>Some thoughts on <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2014/02/pick-life-partner.html\"><strong>how to pick a life partner</strong></a> (pro tip: go for someone you can disagree with)</p> <p>The social world has a whole set of other problems: <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2014/01/the-great-perils-of-social-interaction.html\"><strong>16 comics about awkward social interactions</strong></a></p> <p>In case we’re all getting a little self-absorbed with humans here: <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2013/11/4-mind-blowing-things-about-stars.html\"><strong>4 mind-blowing things about stars</strong></a></p> \n     <div class=\"footnotes\">\n      <hr />\n      <ol>\n       <li id=\"footnote-1-8229\" class=\"footnote\"><p>I added this “almost” in during a revision, after learning that polar bears do on occasion <a href=\"http://www.arcticphoto.com/pbear.asp\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">get together to snuggle</a>.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8229#note-1-8229\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n       <!--/#footnote-1.footnote-->\n       <li id=\"footnote-2-8229\" class=\"footnote\"><p>I’m reminded of this whenever I’m in a faraway country and I run into another traveling American. There’s usually an immediate understanding of each other—one that we would never appreciate if we interacted back at home.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8229#note-2-8229\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n       <!--/#footnote-2.footnote-->\n       <li id=\"footnote-3-8229\" class=\"footnote\"><p>As a writer, I’m grateful to have an audience who lets me know how they feel—it magnetizes my humility tightrope. I can literally feel myself being humbled down to the tightrope by criticism when I drift too high, and I can feel myself being lifted up to the tightrope by positive feedback when I’m feeling insecure.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8229#note-3-8229\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n       <!--/#footnote-3.footnote-->\n       <li id=\"footnote-4-8229\" class=\"footnote\"><p>We talked about this a bit in <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/09/enlightenment-kids.html#rights-circles\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Chapter 4</a>, in the example of the red and green circles on private property.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8229#note-4-8229\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n       <!--/#footnote-4.footnote-->\n      </ol>\n     </div>\n     <!--/#footnotes-->\n     <div class=\"footnotes2\">\n      <hr />\n      <ol>\n       <li id=\"footnote2-1-8229\" class=\"footnote2\"><p>After a thorough and unsuccessful search, this seems to be one of those visuals that’s so widely circulated, it’s hard to find the original source. If anyone knows it, email us and we’ll cite it. UPDATE: A reader sent me <a href=\"https://www.reddit.com/r/electronics/comments/7hq8sv/this_ones_great/dqtqk0x/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">this Reddit thread</a>, which suggests that the image was originally part of an instruction booklet for this <a href=\"https://jaoswald.blogspot.com/2011/12/restoring-heathkit-jr-35.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">deeply random product</a>.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8229#note2-1-8229\" class=\"footnote2-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n       <!--/#footnote2-1.footnote-->\n       <li id=\"footnote2-2-8229\" class=\"footnote2\"><p><a href=\"http://thomaspaine.org/major-works/letter-to-the-abbe-raynal.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Letter to the Abbe Raynal</a>, 1782.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8229#note2-2-8229\" class=\"footnote2-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n       <!--/#footnote2-2.footnote-->\n       <li id=\"footnote2-3-8229\" class=\"footnote2\"><p>Greg Lukianoff: <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2MpA0MP\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><em>Freedom From Speech</em></a>.<a conservatives</em></a><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8229#note2-4-8229\" class=\"footnote2-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n       <!--/#footnote2-4.footnote-->\n      </ol>\n     </div>\n
