Politicians are all about principles…as long as those principles fit on the top of the country’s Thought Pile, safely inside the Overton window. But when that Thought Pile moves, like it did on the topic of gay marriage between 2008 and 2012, politicians drop everything and start <em>swimming</em>.</p> <p>This is no criticism of politicians—being a small-picture leader and a big-picture follower is the politician’s survival requirement. It’s simply a reminder that change in a country like the U.S. starts at the bottom and works its way up to the top. It starts with brave citizens willing to say unpopular things in public. With the right idea and a lot of courage, a single person can spark a mind-changing movement that gains so much momentum, it moves our beliefs and our cultural norms, which in turn moves the Overton window, which moves policy, which moves law.</p> <p>Whenever a citizen of a democracy speaks up in a classroom or town hall, writes an op-ed, makes a movie, tweets a tweet, or yells something out on the street, they’re sending an idea out into the great network—firing a little neural impulse into the workings of the larger system. Every citizen, whether they realize it or not, is a neuron in the mind of a giant organism, and what they do and say in their lifetime contributes to who that organism is, even if only a little bit.</p> <p>But all of this only works because of free speech. All of those Thought Piles only ooze along the idea spectrum with a mind of their own because they’re protected from above by the broad arc of a free and protected Speech Curve.</p> <p>It’s easy to see why free speech is often referred to as not just a right but as <em>the </em>fundamental right on which all other rights are based.</p> <p>Free speech allows the precious resource of attention to be allotted the Value Games way instead of being doled out by the powerful and high-status at their whim.</p> <p>Free speech gives citizens a way to resolve conflicts with words instead of violence. When ideas can go to battle against each other, people don’t have to.</p> <p>Free speech gives power to the powerless. It’s never easy being in the minority in any country. The rich are protected and empowered by their money, the elite by their connections, the majority by their vote. A minority population is often helpless. But free speech gives the powerless a voice—an ability to launch a mind-changing movement that wins over the majority and makes the country better for themselves.</p> <p>The free speech of individual citizens is the free <em>thought</em> of the communal citizen body, and the singular right that lets hundreds of millions of minds link together into a giant network that can learn, grow, and think as one. Society is driven by the stories we believe, and free speech hands authorship of those stories over to the people themselves.</p> <p>And it’s for all these same reasons that Power Games dictators clutch so tightly onto their mute buttons. Even today, over two centuries after the birth of the U.S., <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/58-MAP.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">almost three billion human beings</a><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=7904#footnote2-9-7904\" id=\"note2-9-7904\" rel=\"footnote2\">9</a> are still deprived of freedom of speech or other core Enlightenment freedoms.</p> <p>But dictators aren’t the only ones who use mute buttons. Given all of the obvious benefits of free speech, when a culture or a movement or an individual citizen seems threatened by free speech, the first question you should ask is: “Why? What are they so scared of?” Free speech is a tool that helps us see what’s true versus false and right versus wrong—so if you believe truth and virtue are on your side, a vibrant, open discourse is your best friend. And if someone is trying to repress free speech—that tells us something important.</p> <p>Mute buttons in any form should raise an alarm in all of our heads, though they sometimes seem to go unnoticed. When all you’ve ever known is freedom, it can be easy to forget just how precious it is.</p> <p style=\"text-align: center;\">___________</p> <p>In a world of Power Games, the American forefathers built a different kind of giant—one that didn’t need to be controlled with strings and cudgels because it could think for itself and make its own decisions. A giant human being.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/59.1-US-giant.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-7978\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/59.1-US-giant.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"356\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/59.1-US-giant.png 1221w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/59.1-US-giant-600x285.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/59.1-US-giant-768x364.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/59.1-US-giant-750x356.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> <p>In the late 1700s when the U.S. was born, it was a bit of an oddball on the global scene. But the new country quickly began to thrive. This wasn’t the first time a society replaced an iron cudgel with a constitution—but one had never been done so effectively, on so broad a scale, in modern times. Soon, countries run by constitutions, driven by minds of their own, began springing up all over the world.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=7904#footnote2-10-7904\" id=\"note2-10-7904\" rel=\"footnote2\">10</a><span style=\"color: #ffffff;\">.</span></p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/60-democracy-chart.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-7976\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/60-democracy-chart.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1200\" height=\"867\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/60-democracy-chart.png 3400w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/60-democracy-chart-600x433.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/60-democracy-chart-768x555.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/60-democracy-chart-750x542.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1200px) 100vw, 1200px\" /></a></p> <p>The founders knew that they didn’t have all the answers. They knew that over time the world would change, the citizens would change, and unpredictable things would happen. They were wise enough to know that no matter how smart they were, their country was a first draft—United States 1.0. The U.S. was a promising child who would need to grow up into a more perfect nation.</p> <p>So they built a nation that was founded on doubt, not certainty. With a mysterious, foggy future ahead, free speech would give the new nation a way to figure things out as it went: a flashlight to help see the truth, a compass that would help point it towards wisdom, and a mirror that would help an orphan child raise itself.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/61-trudging.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-7975\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/61-trudging.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"475\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/61-trudging.png 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/61-trudging-600x380.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/61-trudging-768x486.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/61-trudging-750x475.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> <p>But when you’re dealing with humans, nothing is easy.</p> <p>Taking the human out of the Power Games is one thing—taking the Power Games out of the human is quite another. Enlightenment-born constitutions put the Primitive Mind in a cage, but just how strong are those bars?</p> <p>While the Value Games may be the official way of doing business in the U.S., at the core of every U.S. citizen and government official runs a piece of primitive software that speaks a more ancient language—and in U.S. society, the shadow of a cudgel sometimes seems to loom where it’s not supposed to.</p> <p>Is the U.S. the Enlightenment come to life? Or is it the Power Games, wearing an Enlightenment disguise?</p> <p>Probably a little of both.</p> <p>The U.S. is a story of a nation’s struggle for security, for power, for progress, for wealth. But mostly, it’s a story of a nation’s struggle against itself.</p> <p>Sounds a little like each of us, doesn’t it?</p> <p>That’s the thing about building a giant human being. You get the whole package—on a giant scale.</p> <p>In this post, we got to know how the U.S. works on the surface. But to accomplish our goal in this series—to understand modern societies well enough that we can figure out how to make things better—we’ll need to go deeper. To really understand society, we’ll need to take a closer look at a miniature version of it.</p> <p>You.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/09/thinking-ladder.html\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-7661\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/next-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"103\" height=\"56\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/next-1.png 1100w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/next-1-300x164.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/next-1-768x419.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/next-1-600x327.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/next-1-374x200.png 374w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/next-1-239x130.png 239w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 103px) 100vw, 103px\" /></a></p> <p class=\"has-text-align-center wbwFont\">Chapter 7: <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/09/thinking-ladder.html\">The Thinking Ladder</a></p> <p style=\"text-align: center;\">___________</p> <p>To keep up with this series, sign up for the&nbsp;<a class=\"ClickPico PicoRule\"><strong>Wait But Why email list</strong></a> and we’ll send you the new posts right when they come out.</p> <p>Huge thanks to our Patreon supporters for making this series free for everyone. To support Wait But Why, <a href=\"https://www.patreon.com/waitbutwhy\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><strong>visit our Patreon page</strong></a><strong>.</strong></p> <p style=\"text-align: center;\">___________<span style=\"color: #ffffff;\">.</span></p> <p class=\"has-medium-font-size\">Three other places we can hang out:&nbsp; &nbsp;</p> <p><strong>1) Your odd friendships: </strong><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2014/12/10-types-odd-friendships-youre-probably-part.html\"><strong>10 types of odd friendships you’re probably a part of</strong></a></p> <p><strong>2) All the wealth in the world: </strong><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2014/03/combined-wealth-world.html\"><strong>What could you buy with $241 trillion?</strong></a></p> <p><strong>3) Creepy upsetting children in old ads: </strong><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2013/08/creepy-kids-in-creepy-vintage-ads.html\"><strong>Creepy kids in creepy vintage ads</strong></a></p> <p style=\"text-align: center;\">___________<span style=\"color: #ffffff;\">.</span></p> <p class=\"has-medium-font-size\">Sources and related reading:</p> <p><strong>John Stuart Mill, </strong><a href=\"https://socialsciences.mcmaster.ca/econ/ugcm/3ll3/mill/liberty.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><strong><em>On Liberty</em></strong></a><strong><em>.</em></strong> The old classic.</p> <p>I cited author and activist <strong>Jonathan Rauch</strong> a few times in this post. He’s one of the best at articulating why free speech matters. The long quote I included in this post is part of <a href=\"https://www.jonathanrauch.com/jrauch_articles/2013/11/hate-speech-minorities-and-moral-learning.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><strong>this excerpt</strong></a> from Rauch’s excellent book <a href=\"https://amzn.to/30d5vCQ\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><strong><em>Kindly Inquisitors</em></strong></a><strong><em>.</em></strong></p> <p>Economist <strong>Max Roser’s </strong>incredibly useful site <a href=\"https://ourworldindata.org/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><strong><em>Our World in Data</em></strong></a><strong><em>.</em> </strong>Specifically, <a href=\"https://ourworldindata.org/democracy\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><strong>the page on democracy</strong></a>.</p> <p>It’s an ongoing debate just how much a country like the U.S. is led by the citizen body vs. by politicians vs. by other components like the media. One interesting take that contradicts the idea that the people lead and politicians follow can be found in <strong>John Medearis’s </strong>book <a href=\"https://www.hup.harvard.edu/catalog.php?isbn=9780674186439\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><strong><em>Joseph Schumpeter’s Two Theories of Democracy</em></strong></a><strong>.</strong> He argues that democracy is more a mechanism that fosters competition among leaders, merely held in check by the electoral process.</p> <p>You can find the ongoing list of sources, influences, and related reading for this series <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/08/story-sources.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">here</a>.</p> \n        <div class=\"footnotes\">\n         <hr />\n         <ol>\n          <li id=\"footnote-1-7904\" class=\"footnote\"><p>The exception are people who become famous specifically by saying outlandish things—but in many of those situations, what’s actually happening is they’re saying things lots of people do agree with, but few people say. Cases like those are examples of the rule, not exceptions to it.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=7904#note-1-7904\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n          <!--/#footnote-1.footnote-->\n          <li id=\"footnote-2-7904\" class=\"footnote\"><p>For the politics-related images in this post, the colors of the idea spectrum are random—not meant to map onto the American political red and blue in any way.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=7904#note-2-7904\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n          <!--/#footnote-2.footnote-->\n          <li id=\"footnote-3-7904\" class=\"footnote\"><p>There’s a great quote about the concept of the Overton window by Anthony Trollope, in his 1868 novel <a href=\"https://amzn.to/2LAK5Y7\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><em>Phineas Finn</em></a>: <em>Many who before regarded legislation on the subject as chimerical, will now fancy that it is only dangerous, or perhaps not more than difficult. And so in time it will come to be looked on as among the things possible, then among the things probable; and so at last it will be ranged in the list of those few measures which the country requires as being absolutely needed. That is the way in which public opinion is made.</em><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=7904#note-3-7904\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n          <!--/#footnote-3.footnote-->\n         </ol>\n        </div>\n        <!--/#footnotes-->\n        <div class=\"footnotes2\">\n         <hr />\n         <ol>\n          <li id=\"footnote2-1-7904\" class=\"footnote2\"><p><a href=\"http://www.mtv.com/news/1598407/barack-obama-answers-your-questions-about-gay-marriage-paying-for-college-more/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Obama quote source</a>. <a href=\"https://www.politifact.com/truth-o-meter/statements/2015/jun/17/hillary-clinton/hillary-clinton-change-position-same-sex-marriage/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Clinton quote source</a>.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=7904#note2-1-7904\" class=\"footnote2-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n          <!--/#footnote2-1.footnote-->\n          <li id=\"footnote2-2-7904\" class=\"footnote2\"><p>Allan M. Urban","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Notes-Key-v2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn64@2020_6/2020/08/16/19-24-10-514_51492c658d30e87c.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/45.1-supply-demand-8bit.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx20/cdn19@2020_6/2020/08/16/19-24-02-100_a4f32d872ba0223d.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/45.2-supply-demand-v2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn76@2020_6/2020/08/16/19-23-59-688_9419225b4f0133c8.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/46.1a-blue-box-flat.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn83@2020_1/2020/08/16/19-24-10-472_b736bdbfa19d40ea.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/46.1-blue-box-tower.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn51@2020_2/2020/08/16/19-23-59-086_b859f95e3c39cd17.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/46.2-blue-box-humps-8bit.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn12@2020_1/2020/08/16/19-24-26-136_094a96f63d66eac9.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/46.3-blue-box-censorship-gaps-sm.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn8@2020_3/2020/08/16/19-24-14-853_2221e17b8711b469.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/47-abortion-v2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn64@2020_5/2020/08/16/19-24-00-253_dfc455b42b576b55.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/49.1-relevance-water-v2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn59@2020_3/2020/08/16/19-24-01-933_4eb04e4e64bb4e18.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/49.2-relevance-water-v3.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn91@2020_5/2020/08/16/19-24-08-865_852eb6d59ceace4a.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/50.1-ceilings.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn63@2020_1/2020/08/16/19-24-26-773_71efd024478ab21e.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/50.2-ceilings.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn80@2020_6/2020/08/16/19-24-06-781_2856a4255a3cfd06.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/51.1-overton-window-water-only-AM.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn56@2020_2/2020/08/16/19-24-12-939_dbf3dc51db2b87bf.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/51.2-overton-window-labeled.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn72@2020_6/2020/08/16/19-24-09-215_6a73df49165a5f2d.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/51.3-overton-window-drowning-v2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn44@2020_4/2020/08/16/19-24-07-127_523a8f3319d344c7.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/51.4-overton-axes-just-y.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn19@2020_5/2020/08/16/19-24-04-883_12daa9475e46c25f.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/51.5-district-piles-v3.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn28@2020_4/2020/08/16/19-24-06-984_8b0590fbabe63d87.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/51.6-gay-marriage-district-TPs.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn67@2020_2/2020/08/16/19-24-14-705_ecf2e381f1958b0c.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/51.7-gay-marriage-national-party-TPs.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn24@2020_5/2020/08/16/19-24-21-270_837a336d01b39dd5.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/51.8-gay-marriage-america-TP.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn88@2020_6/2020/08/16/19-24-00-467_6f348e79296d20ea.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/51.9-gay-marriage-america-TP-quotes-v2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn40@2020_2/2020/08/16/19-24-28-167_5963227bb0e8d878.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/52-mainstream-v2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn96@2020_3/2020/08/16/19-24-17-904_9b95512f28de2b1e.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/53.1-smoking-v2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn100@2020_2/2020/08/16/19-24-03-778_30e634bf9af042b9.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/53.2-smoking.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn68@2020_3/2020/08/16/19-23-57-088_21e8e4ba6e946d64.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/54.1-preach-vs-gauntlet.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn11@2020_1/2020/08/16/19-23-58-798_c3040074eed41a2a.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/54.2-preach-vs-gauntlet.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn76@2020_4/2020/08/16/19-24-08-406_b8c992d2a9a1eeed.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/55-smoking-poll.gif":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn15@2020_4/2020/08/16/19-24-03-216_239d81bcfea348e0.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/55.1-smoking-sumup-v2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx17/cdn47@2020_4/2020/08/16/19-24-17-118_6affc24a9f683d67.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/55.2-smoking-sumup.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn35@2020_1/2020/08/16/19-24-20-447_effc65576df11df9.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/56.1-interracial-v3.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx20/cdn35@2020_6/2020/08/16/19-24-27-581_4ee09cf32a6c927e.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/57-opinion-poll-v2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx20/cdn51@2020_6/2020/08/16/19-24-24-165_09ec8f0271afa478.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/56.2-interracial-v2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn24@2020_4/2020/08/16/19-24-03-930_06cac3df9446a712.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/56A.1-v2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn84@2020_5/2020/08/16/19-24-28-036_27729419fa96b476.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/56A.2-v3.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn68@2020_5/2020/08/16/19-24-11-239_cbfa653de177d8b1.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/56A.3.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn83@2020_2/2020/08/16/19-24-24-390_91b149209a657a35.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/58.1-gay-marriage-national-timeline.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn16@2020_3/2020/08/16/19-24-19-185_253349b032ce711a.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/58.2a-gay-marriage-national-timeline-v2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn19@2020_1/2020/08/16/19-24-25-493_10627b5b3c7a2d7f.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/59.1-US-giant.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn80@2020_4/2020/08/16/19-24-08-322_2971c59138cb5fd0.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/60-democracy-chart.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn3@2020_6/2020/08/16/19-24-08-837_c3fc2e89bfbf119c.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/61-trudging.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn48@2020_5/2020/08/16/19-24-23-990_0f9288394c0b82e6.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/next-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn43@2020_5/2020/08/16/19-24-05-418_a16f10ba94e67f6c.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-08-17 03:23:55","updatedTime":"2020-08-17 03:23:55","title":"You Won’t Believe My Morning","link":"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8917","description":"<p>You won’t believe my morning.</p>\n<p>I went out on my daily excursion to sit on the front step of my building for ten minutes holding my breath when people walked by. Normally, I spend the time diddling around my phone, but I forgot to bring my phone this morning, so I just looked around.</p>\n<p>As I was taking in the emptiness of the street, a little glint caught my eye in a patch of dirt on the sidewalk. I bent over to look closer, and there was the glint again. It wasn’t a normal glint like from a shiny rock or a piece of metal—it was a little pinprick of flashing light.</p>\n<p>Intrigued, I was now on all fours looking closer. And I saw the most surreal thing.</p>\n<p><em>Tiny houses.</em></p>\n<p>Like <em>tiny </em>houses. Each about a millimeter high, like ornately carved grains of sand.</p>\n<p>I was either dreaming or looking at the coolest, <em>cutest </em>little art project ever.</p>\n<p>As I examined the microscopic village, I noticed what looked like a scrawl of teeny letters on the dirt next to the houses. It said:</p>\n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">PUT YOUR THUMB ON THE OVAL</p>\n<p>Now fully having the time of my life, I looked around for an oval. I searched for a few minutes with no luck until I saw, a bit outside the area where the houses were, a little strip of silver, maybe two millimeters long and a millimeter wide. Careful not to damage the houses, I put my thumb on it.</p>\n<p>I won’t be able to accurately describe what happened next, but I’ll try my best. Imagine if the ground underneath you suddenly felt like a furiously spinning liquid whirlpool, combined with the feeling of freefalling, combined with your entire visual field turning into a blurry gray, combined with the worst nausea of your life.</p>\n<p>And then, just as fast as it started, it all stopped. I cowered for a few seconds trying to catch my breath, and when I opened my eyes, I wasn’t in New York anymore.</p>\n<p>I was on a pastoral ranch, surrounded by big log cabins and a bunch of people staring down at me as I looked up at them, still on all fours. One of the people said to me, “Are you okay?”</p>\n<p>“I feel okay, but I’m having <em>severe </em>hallucinations.”</p>\n<p>They all started cheering and hugging and high-fiving each other.</p>\n<p>“Are you doctors?” I asked.</p>\n<p>“He thinks he has the virus,” one of them said, and they all roared with laughter.</p>\n<p>A woman shushed the crowd and said, “Okay, back to work everyone. I’ll give him the briefing.”</p>\n<p>The others left, and the woman smiled at me. “I’m Layla.”</p>\n<p>“Hi Layla. Do I have coronavirus?” I asked.</p>\n<p>“You don’t have coronavirus,” she said. “You’re just tiny. We shrunk you to 1/10,000<sup>th</sup> of your normal size. You haven’t moved anywhere, you’ve just gotten much smaller.”</p>\n<p>“Fuck,” I explained.</p>\n<p>“Yeah, I imagine it’s a lot to take in,” she said. “Let me try to clear things up. There are different tiers of human life, not just the one you’re used to. Our tier is exactly 1/10,000<sup>th</sup> the size of yours. In yours, people are about 180 centimeters tall. Here, we’re about 0.18 millimeters tall. We’d say 180 micrometers tall, but I know in your world, micrometers don’t mean very much.”</p>\n<p>I stared at her. “You’re telling me I’m 0.18 millimeters tall right now?”</p>\n<p>“Correct,” she said. “About half the size of a dust mite, or a little taller than the width of a human hair up in your world. A person in your world with really good eyesight could <em>barely </em>see you, if they looked closely. And see that house over there?&#8221; She pointed to a large, three-story house. “In the scale you’re used to, that would be about 10 meters high. Here, it’s about the size of a cubic millimeter—the size of a grain of sand on the sidewalk. Some of our houses were actually carved from grains of sand.”</p>\n<p>“Hold on.” I stopped her. “I’m <em>very </em>scared of bugs. I wrote a whole post about it once. Are there <em>giant </em>bugs here?”</p>\n<p>“Yes and no. There are no bugs in our village because we lined the perimeter with a poison that kills any insects that come too close. But you wouldn’t want to walk too far away from the houses—about three centimeters from here, you’ll cross that barrier and run into things you won’t like.”</p>\n<p>“How about flying bugs?” I asked diligently.</p>\n<p>“Oh, I haven’t mentioned time yet. Okay so time here moves 100 times faster than it does up on your tier. Time scales up inversely with the square root of the size difference. So 1/10,000<sup>th</sup> of the size means 100X faster time. So when a flying insect starts to descend into the village, our defense crew has over a minute here to handle the situation. They fire a jet of air at the insect that deflects it away from us. Same deal for dogs. Every year or two, a dog will pee on us. The defense crew keeps track of every dog walking by. At 1/100<sup>th</sup> the speed of our world, we first see an approaching dog about ten minutes before it gets near us, and by the time a peeing dog is lifting its leg over us, we’ve had plenty of time to draw the tarps, which roll over the entire village and cover everything—the same tarps we use every time it rains or snows.”</p>\n<p>“Good to know. But why am I here?”</p>\n<p>“Right, I was about to get to that. After a heated debate in the village, we voted to bring someone from your world here, because we wanted to show you something. We’ve been trying to catch someone’s eye in your world for three of your weeks. That’s almost <em>six years </em>here. That’s why everyone was so excited to see you.”</p>\n<p>“How did you catch my attention?”</p>\n<p>“With <em>that</em>.” She pointed at a tube on the roof of one of the houses that looked like large telescope. “That’s a super-powered laser that we’ve been trying to shine in people’s eyes as they walked by on the sidewalk. But no one noticed. Until today. Way out on the horizon, we piled boulders into the shapes of letters that spelled out the instructions, and you were dicking around just hard enough that you actually bent down to read them. We’re thankful.”</p>\n<p>“What was that oval in the instructions?”</p>\n<p>“Look down.”</p>\n<p>I was standing on a metallic oval about the size of a swimming pool.</p>\n<p>“This is our trans-tier station. When you touched this with your thumb, it shrunk you down to our tier.</p>\n<p>“Wait.” I looked up at her. “Do I <em>live</em> here now?”</p>\n<p>She laughed. “Don’t worry. We’ll send you back to your world in a little bit. Now come with me.”</p>\n<p>I walked with Layla towards the other side of the village. I looked around. Everyone was staring at me. Some people waved.</p>\n<p>“What’s that?” I asked Layla, pointing up at what looked like a sheet of color stretching into the sky.</p>\n<p>“That’s your apartment building. All you can see from here is the first brick. That band of light way up in the sky is the mortar between the first and second brick in the wall.”</p>\n<p>We walked into a small building and entered a room with a long white table in the middle. Layla turned towards a wall on the side of the room, and suddenly the outline of a square formed in the wall. The square moved outwards into the room and rotated downwards until it was parallel to the floor. Layla pulled a tweezer-like tool from her pocket and carefully pinched what looked like nothing a few centimeters above the panel.</p>\n<p>She walked over to me. “Open your palm.”</p>\n<p>She put her tweezers into my hand and dropped something the size of a grain of sand. I raised up my palm to look at it. It was reddish and fuzzy.</p>\n<p>“What is it?” I asked.</p>\n<p>“SARS-CoV-2. What you&#8217;ve been calling &#8216;coronavirus.&#8217;”</p>\n<p>I flung it across the room. “What the <em>fuck</em>.”</p>\n<p>Layla laughed, touched the square, and the little object flew back across the room into its spot above the square.</p>\n<p>“It can’t hurt you here. The viruses of your world are <em>way </em>too big to do any damage in our bodies.”</p>\n<p>I stared at her, trying to process the situation. “How do you know about coronavirus? And how did you…<em>get </em>one?”</p>\n<p>“Oh we know everything about your world. Your tier moves so slowly compared to ours that your technology is eons behind ours. Our tools have allowed us to watch your world since your prehistoric days. As for how we got a coronavirus particle, we didn’t get it—we <em>made </em>it.”</p>\n<p>“<em>You </em>made the coronavirus?”</p>\n<p>“Well, with a little help. Follow me.”</p>\n<p>Again I followed Layla, again dumbfounded, this time out of the building toward a fenced-in area outside. When we got close, a door in the fence opened and inside, we stood together on the edge of what looked like a barren circle of land.</p>\n<p>Layla opened her hand. The little virus was sitting neatly on her palm. “SARS-CoV-2 is a standard sized Coronavirus—about 120 nanometers in diameter. 120 nanometers is ridiculously small in your world, but in ours, you can roll it around in your fingers.</p>\n<p>“Cool…let me think about that for a minute.”</p>\n<p>“Wait, I can explain this better. In your world, this is a perfect size analogy:</p>\n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">SARS-CoV-2 : grain of sand :: grain of sand : house</p>\n<p>In both cases, the relationship is 1-to-10,000, which is also the relationship of our world to yours. In your world, your apartment building is huge, a grain of sand is tiny, and this coronavirus is unfathomably microscopic. In ours, the virus is tiny, a grain of your sand is huge enough to live in, and your apartment building is unfathomably large.”</p>\n<p>“Makes sense.”</p>\n<p>“Now, what’s a virus made of? Atoms. And atoms are about 0.1 nanometers in diameter—about 1/1,000<sup>th</sup> of the diameter of a SARS-CoV-2 particle. That’s small even for <em>us.</em> An atom is almost as small for us as a virus is for you. Constructing a virus requires incredibly complex engineering and tools that can interact with the quantum field. We can’t do it ourselves.”</p>\n<p>“So how—”</p>\n<p>“Look down.”</p>\n<p>I looked at the ground.</p>\n<p>She pulled me toward the center of the circle of land and then pulled me to an abrupt stop.</p>\n<p>“Look closer.”</p>\n<p>I bent over as far as I could and strained my eyes. No. Fucking. Way.</p>\n<p><em>Another microscopic world</em>.</p>\n<p><em>“Is that</em>…”</p>\n<p>“Yup. That’s the tier below <em>us</em>. Give me your thumb.”</p>\n<p>She carefully placed the virus particle onto the ground. Then she guided my hand to the ground, touching both of our thumbs to a little metallic spot.</p>\n<p>Whirlpool. Falling. Gray. Nausea. Misery.</p>\n<p>I eventually got a hold of my trembling and drooling and opened my eyes. In every direction, as far as I could see, stretched a hazy blue-ish / purple-ish plane. It also began to dawn on me that I wasn’t standing or sitting on anything—I was <em>floating</em>.</p>\n<p>After about a minute of wondering what the <em>hell </em>was going on in my life, a patch of the sky darkened. The dark region became smaller and more defined until it condensed into Layla floating next to me.</p>\n<p>“Please don’t leave me again,” I said.</p>\n<p>“Sorry, my thumb hit the pad a split second later than yours did. Time moves 100 times faster here than up there, so you got to spend some reflective time here by yourself.”</p>\n<p>“Okay where are we?”</p>\n<p>“We’re outside your apartment building. Remember?”</p>\n<p>“Righttt. So what <em>size</em> are we?”</p>\n<p>“We went down the same jump you did when you transitioned from your world to ours—we shrunk to 1/10,000<sup>th</sup> of our previous size. So you’re now 18 nanometers tall. If you stood on the edge of a cross-section of a human hair, it would take you about two hours to walk across it.”</p>\n<p>“Jesus.”</p>\n<p>“Time here is now going by at 100X the speed of time in my world, which means it’s moving 10,000 times faster than the speed of time in yours. You could spend a year here and less than an hour would pass in your world.”</p>\n<p>“Kind of like Inception?”</p>\n<p>“Not really. Anyway, nothing down here works the way it does in our worlds. Like see how the ground is all eternal and purply?”</p>\n<p>“Yeah.”</p>\n<p>“That’s not really ground, and it’s not really purple. When you’re this small, there aren’t any solid objects in the sense you understand. And your eyes are too small now to perceive the visible light spectrum.”</p>\n<p>“So what the hell?”</p>\n<p>“I don’t really get it either. But the people who live here have incredibly advanced ways of manipulating the quantum field so we can feel like we’re intact humans, floating in place, seeing purple. They set it up this way because it’s something we can make sense of.”</p>\n<p>“That’s nice of them. Where are they all anyway?”</p>\n<p>“The thing is, they don’t like our world, and they <em>really </em>don’t like your world. They interact with us occasionally, when it’s necessary, but they’ll never allow you or anyone from your world to see them or know anything about how they live. This is actually the first time anyone from your world has been allowed down here, other than Andy Kaufman, who’s lived here since 1984.”</p>\n<p>“Then why am I allowed to be here?”</p>\n<p>“So I can show you this.”</p>\n<p>Layla straightened her arm in front of her, with her palm facing outwards. Her palm lit up and when it did, a bizarre-looking giant object was revealed in front of us.</p>\n<p>“This,” Layla said, “is SARS-CoV-2. Down here, it’s the size of a house.”</p>\n<p>I looked up at the vast virus in front of me. It looked nothing like it had when it was a fuzzy grain of sand in my hand. It was transparent, like a massive, intricately structured, sphere-shaped jellyfish. There was a kind of furious movement within the transparency, but I couldn’t see anything specific moving. It was confusing.</p>\n<p>Layla motioned for me to come close to the virus. She took my hand and placed my palm onto the virus’s almost invisible surface. It felt kind of like palming a grape bunch except instead of grapes it was tapioca balls like the ones in those bubble teas—if the tapioca balls were vibrating so vigorously that it felt a little like being mildly electroshocked, like when you put your finger in an electrical outlet. It was an unpleasant sensation, though not quite painful, and <em>super </em>weird and cool-feeling.</p>\n<p>“Pull one off,” Layla said.</p>\n<p>It took me a few tries to latch onto one of the atoms, because they’re “slippery” (quotes because there is no word for what it felt like, but &#8220;slippery&#8221; gets the general idea across), and when I finally got one and pulled, there was a lot of resistance. When I pulled it, it dragged the adjacent atoms along with it, and the harder I pulled, the more ferociously and unpleasantly it vibrated. Finally it <em>snapped </em>free. I looked at my fist—<em>I had an atom.</em></p>\n<p>Layla smiled. “Cool right?”</p>\n<p>“<em>So </em>cool. Can I keep it?”</p>\n<p>“Sure good luck with that.”</p>\n<p>I was so awe-struck by so many things, I had forgotten how intensely confused I was.</p>\n<p>“Wait, so why did you <em>make</em> this?”</p>\n<p>She turned towards me. “As I said, because of the way time moves—”</p>\n<p>“Your world has been around a lot longer than ours.”</p>\n<p>“Yes. And <em>this</em> world we’re in now has been around a lot longer than <em>mine</em>. They know much more about everything than we do, and they can do things we can’t even begin to understand. The stuff they can do is so over our heads they can’t even <em>explain </em>it to us. And <em>we’re</em> that far ahead of <em>your</em> world.</p>\n<p>For a long time, as advanced as this world was, it relied on us to preserve our world for its own survival. It exists on a patch of dirt in our village. If our village were destroyed, they would be destroyed with it. But a while back, they worked out the technology for how to be <em>location independent</em>, which means they can move from wherever they are to any other place in the universe instantly.</p>\n<p>We don’t have that technology yet. We tried to learn from them, but we couldn’t grasp the fundamental ideas well enough to develop it ourselves. So we’re stuck in our location.”</p>\n<p>“In New York City?”</p>\n<p>“Yup. We migrated here in the 1800s when we determined it would be a good place to interface with your world, should the need ever arise. We’re also not the only people in our world. There are lots of villages like ours in different parts of the Earth. Once we connected with you, the others stopped broadcasting their location. There’s no reason for more than one of us to be revealed to your world.</p>\n<p>For most of time, Earth was a safe and stable home for our world. But over the last century, your world has been advancing exponentially in technology but remaining stagnant in wisdom. You’re rapidly gaining tremendous powers but still behaving like short-sighted primates. The voice of wisdom is there, but it’s being trampled over by political parties, religions, and nations too mired in blind conflict to lift their heads up and see the bigger picture.”</p>\n<p>“It’s funny you say that Layla. I’m actually writing a whole thing about—”</p>\n<p>“Oh I know. We did our research on everyone who lives in your vicinity so we’d know how to communicate with the person we brought to us if we caught someone’s attention. That’s why I’m speaking English and speaking in the odd way you do. Your little series is cute, even if it took us forever to read—but it will have limited effect. Your world is stubborn about growing up. And in the process of destroying yourselves, we believe you’ll destroy us as well.”</p>\n<p>“So you’re trying to kill us off with a pandemic.”</p>\n<p>“If we wanted to kill you off, you’d all be dead right now. It’s an option we hope we don’t have to use. We were once like you and we empathize with your struggle.</p>\n<p>We created this coronavirus to fall into a certain sweet spot—not damaging enough to destroy your world, but bad enough to cause a long and scary global crisis. Short of an alien attack, it is the one thing that could make all humans in your world feel like they’re on the same team against a common enemy. The first and most crucial step on the road to a long-lasting species is the epiphany that you truly are a single team, alone in a dark and dangerous universe. We’re hoping the virus can help push you in that direction.”</p>\n<p>“I feel like there was a better way to do this.”</p>\n<p>“We probably could have thought a little harder about it.”</p>\n<p>“Yeah cause it’s going pretty badly up there is the thing.”</p>\n<p>“Totes. Anyway, we couldn’t make the virus on our own. It’s hard enough to make something that small and complex that involves atomic and subatomic construction, but we wanted the virus to be <em>precisely</em> as harmful as it is. We needed help. The tier below us is less vulnerable to your world than we are, but for reasons I’m not entirely sure about, they also believe living in a multi-tiered ecosystem may be important in the future—so they share our interests. They agreed to build the virus for us.”</p>\n<p>“How did you manage to get the virus into our world?” I asked.</p>\n<p>“It’s funny. You have to imagine it from our perspective. If you’re us, the world you’re planning to transform is a planet with nearly an <em>AU</em> diameter, full of <em>18-kilometer tall people</em>—people so tall, your world’s airplanes could accidentally fly into their belly buttons. Now imagine you’re standing on that planet, smaller than one of their dust mites, pinching between your fingers something the size of a grain of sand <em>on your scale</em>. You find your way onto one of these giants’ football-field-size teeth, and you <em>flick </em>the grain of sand into his kilometer-wide chasm of a mouth. And <em>that’s</em> supposed to change the trajectory of their future. It seems impossible.</p>\n<p>“And yet.”</p>\n<p>“And yet. With some very clever maneuvers, we flicked our little particle into the mouth of an unlucky giant, and it did the trick. By the way, we were dying when you blamed it on a <em>pangolin </em>of all things.”</p>\n<p>“He seemed guilty. I still don’t understand why you brought <em>me</em> down here.”</p>\n<p>“We weren’t originally planning to reveal any of this backstory to your world. But after watching things unfold for the first few weeks, we don’t see enough of the effect we were hoping for. Maybe if your world learns that there are other worlds out there—worlds that did manage to triumph in the wisdom game—it’ll empower the wise voices to stand up with a bit more courage in this struggle and in even greater challenges that lie ahead. It’s a long shot, but these are desperate times.”</p>\n<p>“I guess it’s worth a try. I’ll write a post explaining what I learned from you.”</p>\n<p>“And tweet out the post and send it out to your email list and stuff?”</p>\n<p>“Eh. Fine.”</p>\n<p>“Ready to go back up to your life? Only 23 seconds have passed there since you shrunk down.”</p>\n<p>“Yeah let’s do it.”</p>\n<p>Layla and I moved ourselves on top of the big metal oval.</p>\n<p>“I’m going to increase my size 10,000-fold and yours 100,000,000-fold, so you can go back home in one shot…which is a good thing because transporting up is even worse than transporting down.”</p>\n<p>“Great…”</p>\n<p>“Ready?”</p>\n<p>“I have one more question.”</p>\n<p>“Yes?”</p>\n<p>“How many tiers are there?” I asked.</p>\n<p>“No one knows for sure. The people on this atomic-level tier tell us they know of at least one tier below them, though they won’t tell us more than that. And no one seems to know about tiers above yours. Your world is thinking about that, with all your multiverse talk. We’re still working on that one too.”</p>\n<p>“If you ever figure it out, will you let me know?”</p>\n<p>“One thing at a time.”</p>\n<p>We touched our thumbs to the metal.</p>\n\n\n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">___________</p>\n<p style=\"text-align: left;\">If you like Wait But Why, sign up for the <a class=\"ClickPico\"><strong>email list</strong></a> and we’ll send you new posts right when they come out.</p>\n<p>To support Wait But Why, <a href=\"https://www.patreon.com/waitbutwhy\"><strong>visit our Patreon page</strong></a>.</p>\n\n\n\n<h3>More Posts:</h3>\n\n\n\n<p>As discussed, <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2014/02/why-bugs-ruin-everything.html\"><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><strong>why bugs ruin everything</strong></span></a>.</p>\n<p>Another time <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2014/12/what-makes-you-you.html\"><strong>we transported ourselves</strong></a>.</p>\n<p>And <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2014/04/stick-figure-puzzle.html\"><strong>a puzzle</strong></a> for your quarantine.</p>\n<p>The post <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2020/03/my-morning.html\">You Won&#8217;t Believe My Morning</a> appeared first on <a rel=\"nofollow\" href=\"http://waitbutwhy.com\">Wait But Why</a>.</p>\n","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 25 Mar 2020 21:50:20 +0000","feedId":382,"bgimg":"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/FB.jpg","linkMd5":"1de598c0ef42e27a8eea7dff4448f099","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn35@2020_1/2020/08/16/19-23-57-784_e8dd3aa5016fe644.webp","metaImg":"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/FB.jpg","destWidth":1500,"destHeight":785,"author":"Tim Urban"},{"createdTime":"2020-08-17 03:23:54","updatedTime":"2020-08-17 03:23:54","title":"The Thinking Ladder","link":"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8034","description":"<p style=\"font-size:18px\"><em>This is Chapter 7 in a blog series. If you’re new to the series, visit the </em><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/story-of-us\"><strong><em>series home page</em></strong></a><em> for the full table of contents.</em></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Notes-Key-v2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-7518\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Notes-Key-v2.png\" alt=\"Notes key: Type 1 - fun notes. Fun facts, extra thoughts, or further explanation. Type 2 - less fun notes. Sources and citations.\" width=\"373\" height=\"117\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Notes-Key-v2.png 850w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Notes-Key-v2-300x94.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Notes-Key-v2-768x241.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Notes-Key-v2-600x188.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 373px) 100vw, 373px\" /></a></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">___________</p> \n<div style=\"height:38px\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"wp-block-spacer\"></div> \n<p style=\"font-size:24px\" class=\"has-text-align-center wbwFont\"><strong>Part 3: Thinking, in 3D</strong></p> \n<p class=\"has-text-align-center\"></p> \n<div style=\"height:38px\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"wp-block-spacer\"></div> \n<p class=\"has-text-align-center\"><em>“The whole problem with the world is that fools and fanatics are always so certain of themselves and wise people so full of doubts.</em>” – Bertrand Russell</p> \n<div style=\"height:38px\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"wp-block-spacer\"></div> \n<p style=\"font-size:19px\" class=\"has-text-align-center wbwFont\"><strong>Chapter 7: The Thinking Ladder</strong></p> \n<div style=\"height:38px\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"wp-block-spacer\"></div> \n<p>Why do we believe what we believe?</p> \n<p>We’ve talked about a lot of ideas in this series so far, but a common theme that runs through most of them is human belief. Our beliefs make up our perception of reality, they drive our behavior, and they shape our life stories. History happened the way it did because of what people believed in the past, and what we believe today will write the story of our future.</p> \n<p>So it seems like an important question to ask: Why do we actually come to believe the things we end up believing?</p> \n<p>To figure that out, we have to get good at seeing human thinking in 3D. By the time you finish Part 3, you’ll understand what I mean by that.</p> \n<p>For now, let’s get used to seeing in 2D. That’s our mission in this chapter.</p> \n<p class=\"has-large-font-size\"><strong>Seeing in 2D</strong></p> \n<p>The first dimension, as we’re defining dimensions, is the <em>What</em> of life. It’s what we see around us, what goes on in society, what people say and do, what they believe.</p> \n<p>Looking at everything in one dimension just shows us what’s on the surface of all these parts of reality. But when we lift the covers off the What of life and look at what lies beneath, we’re reminded that there’s a second dimension to everything as well.</p> \n<p>To see in 2D, we’re going to need x-ray goggles:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/2-X-Ray-lens.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8035\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/2-X-Ray-lens.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"550\" height=\"569\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/2-X-Ray-lens.png 796w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/2-X-Ray-lens-580x600.png 580w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/2-X-Ray-lens-768x795.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/2-X-Ray-lens-725x750.png 725w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 550px) 100vw, 550px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Without these goggles, we’d look at a human and just see this:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/3.1-non-x-ray-human.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8037\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/3.1-non-x-ray-human.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"150\" height=\"290\" /></a></p> \n<p>That’s what a human looks like in one dimension. That’s the <em>What </em>of a human, and it includes all of the aspects of their behavior, their beliefs, and their personality.</p> \n<p>But when we put on our goggles, we look at the same human and see this:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/3.2-x-ray-human.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8038\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/3.2-x-ray-human.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"575\" height=\"319\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/3.2-x-ray-human.png 1482w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/3.2-x-ray-human-600x334.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/3.2-x-ray-human-768x427.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/3.2-x-ray-human-750x417.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 575px) 100vw, 575px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Many of the human world’s mysteries become a lot less mysterious when we put on our x-ray goggles. With x-ray vision, we can see the inner psychology that lies behind the scenes of every human What.</p> \n<p>Quick review:</p> \n<p>As we discussed in <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/08/fire-light.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Chapter 1</a>, the animal world is really a world of strands of genetic code, each in a never-ending quest for immortality. Animals are just the biological containers that genes use as temporary homes during this quest. And to control their containers, genes have their animals running on primitive automated software that I’m pretty sure looks a lot like this:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/0-PM.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8039\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/0-PM.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"400\" height=\"240\" /></a></p> \n<p>The Primitive Mind in every animal—humans included—has been optimized to near perfection at getting animals to survive long enough to pass their precious genes along to new containers.</p> \n<p>Scientists aren’t positive about the timeline, but many believe that all humans in all parts of the world lived in hunter-gatherer tribes as recently as 11,000 BC. So 13,000 years ago—or, if we call a generation 25 years, about 500 generations ago.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/4-500-generations-v2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8221\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/4-500-generations-v2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"2000\" height=\"1238\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/4-500-generations-v2.png 2000w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/4-500-generations-v2-600x371.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/4-500-generations-v2-768x475.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/4-500-generations-v2-750x464.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 2000px) 100vw, 2000px\" /></a></p> \n<p>500 generations isn’t enough time for evolution to take a shit. So the Primitive Mind—a hardwired part of us—is still stuck in the world of 11,000 BC. Which means we’re all like computers running on the highly unimpressive <em>Windows 11000 BC </em>operating system, and there’s no way to do a software update.</p> \n<p>But humans have something else going on as well—cognitive superpowers that combine together into an enhanced center of consciousness we’re calling the Higher Mind.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/0-HM.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8041\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/0-HM.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"221\" height=\"300\" /></a></p> \n<p>The Higher Mind and his magical thinking abilities helped the human species transform their typical animal hunter-gatherer world into undoubtedly the strangest of all animal habitats: an advanced civilization. The Higher Mind’s heightened awareness allows him to see the world with clear eyes, behave rationally in any environment, and adjust to changes in real time.</p> \n<p>So while our Primitive Minds are still somewhere in 11,000 BC, our Higher Minds are living right here with us in 2019. Which is why, even though both minds are just trying to do their jobs, they’re in a fight most of the time.</p> \n<p>Sometimes, the fights are about what’s best for us—a <strong>practical conflict.</strong></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/5.1-skittles.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8042\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/5.1-skittles-750x461.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"552\" height=\"340\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/5.1-skittles-750x461.png 750w, href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/5.2-skittles.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8043\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/5.2-skittles.png\" alt=\"\" href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/5.5-skittles.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8046\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/5.5-skittles.png\" alt=\"\" href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/5.7-skittles-PM.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8048\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/5.7-skittles-PM.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"550\" height=\"362\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/5.7-skittles-PM.png 1158w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/5.7-skittles-PM-750x494.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 550px) 100vw, 550px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/5.8-skittles-PM.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8049\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/5.8-skittles-PM.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"549\" height=\"413\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/5.8-skittles-PM.png 792w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/5.8-skittles-PM-600x451.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/5.8-skittles-PM-768x577.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/5.8-skittles-PM-750x563.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 549px) 100vw, 549px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/5.9-skittles.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8050\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/5.9-skittles.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"549\" height=\"360\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/5.9-skittles.png 1352w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/5.9-skittles-600x393.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/5.9-skittles-768x503.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/5.9-skittles-750x491.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 549px) 100vw, 549px\" /></a></p> \n<p>A fight like this happens when the two minds agree on what’s important—i.e. they share a common value—but they disagree on the best way to get there. When you’re torn about whether to go for it with a Skittles binge or not, your two minds are actually in total agreement that physical health is of the utmost importance. But in 11,000 BC, where your Primitive Mind lives, there was no such thing as processed food, calories were hard to come by, and anything with a texture and taste as delectable as a Skittle was sure to be high in calories. In other words, everything the Primitive Mind knows tells it that binging on Skittles is the healthiest possible decision. Your Higher Mind, living in 2019, is extremely aware that eating 145 Skittles in a sitting is not the right health decision. And thus, your inner conflict.</p> \n<p>The same kind of practical conflict can also lead to a lot of fights about our fears.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/6.1-car.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8052\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/6.1-car.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"551\" height=\"152\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/6.1-car.png 1294w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/6.1-car-600x165.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/6.1-car-768x211.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/6.1-car-750x206.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 551px) 100vw, 551px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/6.2-car.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8053\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/6.2-car-750x475.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"555\" height=\"351\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/6.2-car-750x475.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/6.2-car-600x380.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/6.2-car-768x486.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/6.2-car.png 1500w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 555px) 100vw, 555px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/6.3-car.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8054\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/6.3-car-750x475.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"550\" height=\"348\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/6.3-car-750x475.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/6.3-car-600x380.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/6.3-car-768x486.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/6.3-car.png 1500w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 550px) 100vw, 550px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Sometimes, the disagreements are more fundamental.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/7.1-coffee-shop.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8055\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/7.1-coffee-shop.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"547\" height=\"481\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/7.1-coffee-shop.png 1024w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/7.1-coffee-shop-600x527.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/7.1-coffee-shop-768x675.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/7.1-coffee-shop-750x659.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 547px) 100vw, 547px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/7.2-coffee-shop.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8056\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/7.2-coffee-shop.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"551\" height=\"299\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/7.2-coffee-shop.png 1206w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/7.2-coffee-shop-600x326.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/7.2-coffee-shop-768x417.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/7.2-coffee-shop-750x407.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/7.2-coffee-shop-239x130.png 239w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 551px) 100vw, 551px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/7.3-coffee-shop.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8057\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/7.3-coffee-shop.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"550\" height=\"382\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/7.3-coffee-shop.png 1194w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/7.3-coffee-shop-600x417.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/7.3-coffee-shop-768x534.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/7.3-coffee-shop-750x521.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 550px) 100vw, 550px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/7.4-coffee-shop.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8058\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/7.4-coffee-shop.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"551\" height=\"384\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/7.4-coffee-shop.png 1194w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/7.4-coffee-shop-600x417.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/7.4-coffee-shop-768x534.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/7.4-coffee-shop-750x521.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 551px) 100vw, 551px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/7.5-coffee-shop.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8059\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/7.5-coffee-shop.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"547\" height=\"381\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/7.5-coffee-shop.png 1194w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/7.5-coffee-shop-600x417.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/7.5-coffee-shop-768x534.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/7.5-coffee-shop-750x521.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 547px) 100vw, 547px\" /></a></p> \n<p>A disagreement like this happens when two minds disagree on what’s important in the first place—a <strong>values conflict</strong>. A values conflict happens when the Higher Mind has a moral objection to something the Primitive Mind is programmed to want. Like, say, the way the Primitive Mind is programmed to try feverishly to deliver its precious genetic cargo to as large a variety of new containers as possible, at the expense of values like kindness, civility, professionalism, or marital fidelity. An inner values conflict is in progress anytime you’re coping with a moral qualm or integrity struggle.</p> \n<p>There’s also the reverse kind of values conflict—when the Higher Mind values something that the Primitive Mind is specifically programmed to <em>resist</em>—like, say, pitching in with housework or donating to charity.</p> \n<p>Humans are so complicated for a simple reason: we’re each <em>the product of a struggle</em> between two fundamentally different, often contradictory forces.</p> \n<p>This ongoing struggle of fire and light is like a constant tug-of-war in our heads—a tug-of-war over our thoughts, our emotions, our values, our morals, our judgments, and our overall consciousness.</p> \n<p>When we look through our x-ray glasses at someone whose Higher Mind is, at the moment, running the show, we see this:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/8.1-PM-HM-leash.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8061\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/8.1-PM-HM-leash-750x719.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"347\" height=\"333\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/8.1-PM-HM-leash-750x719.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/8.1-PM-HM-leash-600x575.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/8.1-PM-HM-leash-768x736.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/8.1-PM-HM-leash.png 853w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 347px) 100vw, 347px\" /></a></p> \n<p>With a prominent Higher Mind in total control, the Primitive Mind still makes a fuss, but the Higher Mind just yanks it back like a dog owner walking his dog.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/8.2-PM-HM.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8062\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/8.2-PM-HM-750x453.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"549\" height=\"331\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/8.2-PM-HM-750x453.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/8.2-PM-HM-600x363.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/8.2-PM-HM-768x464.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/8.2-PM-HM.png 1282w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 549px) 100vw, 549px\" /></a></p> \n<p>But when the balance of power swings to the other side, the Primitive Mind is like an escaped zoo animal.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/0-PM-HM-leash-D.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8063\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/0-PM-HM-leash-D-750x475.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"507\" height=\"321\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/0-PM-HM-leash-D-750x475.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/0-PM-HM-leash-D-600x380.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/0-PM-HM-leash-D-768x486.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/0-PM-HM-leash-D.png 1500w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 507px) 100vw, 507px\" /></a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/8.3-PM-HM.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8064\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/8.3-PM-HM.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"550\" height=\"333\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/8.3-PM-HM.png 1282w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/8.3-PM-HM-600x363.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/8.3-PM-HM-768x464.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/8.3-PM-HM-750x453.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 550px) 100vw, 550px\" /></a></p> \n<p>The tug-of-war isn’t binary—it’s a spectrum. Let’s call it the <strong>Psych Spectrum. </strong></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/0.1-Psych-Spectrum.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8065\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/0.1-Psych-Spectrum.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"305\" height=\"693\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/0.1-Psych-Spectrum.png 972w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/0.1-Psych-Spectrum-264x600.png 264w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/0.1-Psych-Spectrum-768x1745.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/0.1-Psych-Spectrum-330x750.png 330w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 305px) 100vw, 305px\" /></a></p> \n<p>We can think of the Psych Spectrum like this:</p> \n<p>The Primitive Mind always lives at the very bottom of the Psych Spectrum, at the base human psychological level. The Higher Mind always lives at the top, at the pinnacle of human psychological evolved potential.</p> \n<p>Where <em>you </em>are on this spectrum at any given point is determined by the status of the internal struggle between the two minds.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/0-Psych-Spectrum-leashes.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8066\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/0-Psych-Spectrum-leashes.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"297\" height=\"675\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/0-Psych-Spectrum-leashes.png 972w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/0-Psych-Spectrum-leashes-264x600.png 264w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/0-Psych-Spectrum-leashes-768x1745.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/0-Psych-Spectrum-leashes-330x750.png 330w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 297px) 100vw, 297px\" /></a></p> \n<p>When you’re high up on the Psych Spectrum, you get the best of all worlds. The Higher Mind understands that primitive pleasures like sex, food, and all-in-good-fun tribalism like sports fandom are awesome, and often necessary, parts of a human life. And like a good pet owner, the Higher Mind is more than happy to let the Primitive Mind have its fun. Primitive bliss is great, as long as it’s being managed by the Higher Mind, who makes sure it’s done in moderation, done for the right reasons, and no one gets hurt.</p> \n<p>When we’re low on the Psych Spectrum, we’re short-sighted, we’re small-minded, we think and act with our pettiest emotions and our ego, we lack self-awareness, we’re short on compassion, high on hypocrisy—and because the Primitive Mind is an unconscious software program, we’re usually too foggy to see our own shittiness for what it is.</p> \n<p>Your Psych Spectrum position ebbs and flows throughout each day, each month, and each year of our lives, as we go through happy times and hard times, great days and terrible ones, good moods and crankiness. Even a single bad night’s sleep has the potential to lower you down the spectrum the next day. But if we could quantify all of your various states, it would yield a general average. We can call that average your “psych equilibrium.” Throughout our lives, as we grow and evolve psychologically, this equilibrium can change.<a id=\"grownups\"></a></p> \n<div class=\"wbwAside\"> \n <p style=\"font-size: 20px;\"><strong>Adults and Grown-Ups Blue Box</strong></p> \n <p>Let’s make an important language distinction: the difference between what it means to be an <em>adult </em>and what it means to be a <em>grown-up</em>. For our purposes, “adult” refers to our physical age, while “grown-up” refers to our <em>psychological </em>age. An adult is old. A grown-up is <em>wise</em>.</p> \n <p>Each of us accumulates wisdom with life experience, but only when our Higher Mind is the one doing the thinking can we tap into that wisdom. When our willpower and our consciousness succumb to ancient software, we revert to the worst version of ourselves.</p> \n <p>While the physical age pathway from child to adult is linear, steady, and the same for everyone, the pathway up this psychological spectrum is different for each of us. This is why we all know plenty of childish adults, as well as some surprisingly grown-up children.</p> \n <p>Unlike our physical age, wisdom isn’t evenly distributed inside of us—we all have parts of our lives where we’re good at being grown up, and others where we tend to struggle. Our wisdom gaps—the parts of our life where we tend to be less grown-up than we are adult—are the areas where we’re psychologically <em>stunted</em>.</p> \n <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/9.1-adult-vs-grown-up-v2-1.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8392 \" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/9.1-adult-vs-grown-up-v2-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"461\" height=\"441\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/9.1-adult-vs-grown-up-v2-1.png 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/9.1-adult-vs-grown-up-v2-1-600x574.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/9.1-adult-vs-grown-up-v2-1-768x735.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/9.1-adult-vs-grown-up-v2-1-750x718.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 461px) 100vw, 461px\" /></a></p> \n <p>So the question isn’t <em>if </em>you’re psychologically stunted—the question is <em>where?</em></p> \n <p>Of course, like everything psychological, I’m sure nature plays a big role and we’re all born already prone to certain areas of psychological stunting, based on our genetic profile. But nurture is undoubtedly behind many of our Psych Spectrum struggles. I’m no psychologist, but thinking about my own mind and the minds of the people I know well, a few likely culprits come to mind:</p> \n <p><strong><span style=\"font-size: 18px;\">1) Areas of life where your parents are stunted. </span></strong>You know how sometimes you feel like your parents are super wise about life and you admire them for it, and other times you can’t believe how unwise they can be and you feel like you have to raise <em>them? </em>This is because wisdom is unevenly distributed in your parents too—they’re stunted just like everybody else, going through the same internal struggle. And the thing is, areas of stunting often run in the family—you’re likely stunted in many of the same areas where your parents drive you crazy. It’s just harder to see in yourself because it might manifest a little differently, and because it tends to be harder to see our own flaws than the flaws of others.</p> \n <p>Part of the reason stunting runs in the family is that children aren’t raised by their parents—they’re raised by their parents’ Higher Minds <em>and </em>by their parents’ Primitive Minds. In the areas of life where your parents tend to be wise, you were probably being raised mostly by a Higher Mind.
