So you learned to approach this part of life with <em>your</em> Higher Mind doing the thinking, and the habit usually sticks.</p> \n <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/10.1-stunted-comic.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8070\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/10.1-stunted-comic.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"401\" height=\"377\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/10.1-stunted-comic.png 647w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/10.1-stunted-comic-600x564.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 401px) 100vw, 401px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/10.2-stunted-comic-1.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8223\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/10.2-stunted-comic-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"530\" height=\"530\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/10.2-stunted-comic-1.png 986w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/10.2-stunted-comic-1-150x150.png 150w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/10.2-stunted-comic-1-600x600.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/10.2-stunted-comic-1-768x768.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/10.2-stunted-comic-1-750x750.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 530px) 100vw, 530px\" /></a></p> \n <p>On the other hand, the parts of life where your parent is a baby, you were raised by…a baby. In these parts of life, your parent had yet to get ahold of their own Primitive Mind, so you were raised there by a Primitive Mind more than a Higher Mind.&nbsp;</p> \n <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/10.3-stunted-comic.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8072\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/10.3-stunted-comic.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"400\" height=\"376\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/10.3-stunted-comic.png 647w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/10.3-stunted-comic-600x564.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 400px) 100vw, 400px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/10.4-stunted-comic-1.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8224\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/10.4-stunted-comic-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"530\" height=\"530\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/10.4-stunted-comic-1.png 917w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/10.4-stunted-comic-1-150x150.png 150w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/10.4-stunted-comic-1-600x600.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/10.4-stunted-comic-1-768x768.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/10.4-stunted-comic-1-750x750.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 530px) 100vw, 530px\" /></a></p> \n <p>If there’s one thing a Primitive Mind knows how to do, it’s use primitive emotions like fear or pride to kick other people’s Primitive Minds into high gear. Thinking about an area of life through the lens of your Primitive Mind also becomes a habit—one that people can spend a lifetime trying to break, sometimes unsuccessfully. Wherever your parents were fearful, low integrity, petty, snobby, braggy, bratty, bigoted, jealous, cruel, entitled, uncompassionate, repressed, insecure, selfish, delusional, or any other form of foolish—those will be your psychological challenges in life. Those are the areas where you’ll be starting off from a psychologically primitive, unevolved place and where you’ll need to spend your energy and attention trying to grow.</p> \n <p><strong><span style=\"font-size: 18px;\">2) Areas of life where your Primitive Mind has gone through trauma. </span></strong>If at any point in your past, you were bullied, neglected, shamed, ridiculed, betrayed, out-grouped, abandoned, heartbroken, discriminated against, or profoundly let down, your Primitive Mind has gone through hell. Experiences like those are burned into the Primitive Mind’s memory, and if you never fully processed what happened, the trauma will remain an open wound in your psyche. Trauma to your Primitive Mind is a wound that only the Higher Mind can tend to, disinfect, bandage up, and begin to heal. And until that happens, the previous version of yourself—the age you were when the trauma occurred—will haunt you like a ghost. Like, say, if you were socially excluded in middle school and you never properly processed that nightmare. It’ll be 20 years later and at just the <em>hint </em>of being out-grouped in any situation, you’ll have a meltdown and find yourself acting like a child. The traumatized middle schooler will wake up and hijack your psyche, bringing your psychological age in that moment back down to middle school. The unprocessed pains of the past are vulnerable spots in your psyche where you may be prone to fall into the unconscious hands of the Primitive Mind.</p> \n <p><strong><span style=\"font-size: 18px;\">3) Areas of life where your current environment is stoking the Primitive Mind.</span> </strong>Your current environment is made up of all the places you spend time, all the people you engage with, and the river of information that enters your brain from the external world. Your environment is constantly impressing itself upon you, and vice versa: when you speak or express yourself in any way, your environment reacts. This constant friction between you and your environment can have all kinds of effects on you—ranging from very positive to neutral to very negative. And certain parts of this relationship will inevitably stoke your Primitive Mind—a gossipy workplace, a tribalism-fueling news website, an unhealthy friendship, and plenty of other elements of our environment can regularly pull us downward on the Psych Spectrum.</p> \n <p>Upbringing, trauma, and environment don’t perfectly cover all the bases, but my own life experience tells me that they map pretty well onto someone’s psychological still-working-on-it list.</p> \n</div> \n<p>The challenge of human growth is outlined, for each of us, by our personal list of Psych Spectrum trouble areas. This list is why life will be hard. It’s why we’ll hurt others. It’s why we have regrets. It’s what stands in between us and the life we know we should be living. And it’s a list we’ll install right into our children (if we haven’t already), unless we put in the continual self-reflection and hard work to “raise ourselves” in the areas where our parents couldn’t.</p> \n<p>Most of the problems with humans can be boiled down to unchecked Primitive Minds getting their way against the Higher Mind’s better judgment. This is what’s behind chronic procrastination, chronic overeating, temper outbursts, infidelity, sexual assault, and all the other terrible things humans do to themselves and others. Back in the hunter-gatherer days, the Primitive Mind was mostly on point—but in the modern world, it’s our collective mental illness. And no one is immune.</p> \n<p>Back to our dimensions. So many of our problems today stem from the oversimplification of complicated phenomena in our discussions. Thinking about the real world in one dimension is usually a bad idea.</p> \n<p>For example, wealth in one dimension looks like this.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/11.1-wealth.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8075\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/11.1-wealth.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"748\" height=\"120\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/11.1-wealth.png 1521w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/11.1-wealth-600x96.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/11.1-wealth-768x123.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/11.1-wealth-750x120.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 748px) 100vw, 748px\" /></a></p> \n<p>If you want to place blame for society’s ills, and you only have one dimension to work with, you’re left with the unnuanced option of blaming the rich, blaming the poor, blaming both, or blaming neither.</p> \n<p>But I came across this little visual recently:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/11.1a-neuterthedebt-grid.jpg\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8076\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/11.1a-neuterthedebt-grid.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"599\" height=\"329\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/11.1a-neuterthedebt-grid.jpg 599w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/11.1a-neuterthedebt-grid-239x130.jpg 239w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 599px) 100vw, 599px\" /></a></p> \n<p>This visual is imploring us to bring one-dimensional thinking into 2D. It’s taking the wealth spectrum and expanding it (with the axes switched) into something like this:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/11.2-wealth-v2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8399 \" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/11.2-wealth-v2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"702\" height=\"512\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/11.2-wealth-v2.png 1850w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/11.2-wealth-v2-600x437.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/11.2-wealth-v2-768x560.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/11.2-wealth-v2-750x546.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 702px) 100vw, 702px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Regardless of whether you agree with the specific viewpoint put forth in that other visual, adding a second dimension allows us to have a far more nuanced discussion about it.</p> \n<p>For the rest of this series, we’re going to apply one particular second dimension to everything we discuss: <strong>the Psych Spectrum. </strong></p> \n<p>The hard thing is, we’ve all been trained to think in only one dimension—in the <em>What </em>dimension. We look at people’s behavior, their words, their tendencies, their habits, their demeanor, their disposition—and we stop there. The Psych Spectrum adds the critical second dimension to the equation that asks <em>why </em>people act the way they do. When a cashier is rude to you, you can look at the situation in one dimension, judge them to be an asshole, and stop there. Or you can put your x-ray goggles on, see that their Primitive Mind is clearly pulling the strings in their head, and <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/10/cashier-1024x512.jpg\">wonder why</a>. When you look at things in 2D, it doesn’t make sense to hate people who say or do shitty things, because it doesn’t make sense to hate the ancient pre-programmed survival software causing them to do so. In 2D, you see someone acting like an asshole as being “in the hands of the demon”—a demon that you know, looking at <em>yourself</em> in 2D, you fall into the hands of too, sometimes.</p> \n<p>Once you get this second dimension into your thinking, you’ll notice yourself applying it everywhere. We’ve given it a try <span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2013/10/why-procrastinators-procrastinate.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">a</a></span> <span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2014/06/taming-mammoth-let-peoples-opinions-run-life.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">few</a></span> <span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2014/10/religion-for-the-nonreligious.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">times</a></span>&nbsp;before on this blog.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8034#footnote-1-8034\" id=\"note-1-8034\" rel=\"footnote\">1</a> Now it’s time to bring this second dimension into the world of human belief, to help us answer that key question: Why do we believe what we believe?</p> \n<p class=\"has-large-font-size\"><strong>The Battle Over Our Beliefs</strong></p> \n<p>In one dimension, our beliefs landscape looks like this:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/12.1-thinking-axes.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8078\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/12.1-thinking-axes.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"700\" height=\"76\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/12.1-thinking-axes.png 1360w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/12.1-thinking-axes-600x65.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/12.1-thinking-axes-768x83.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/12.1-thinking-axes-750x81.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px\" /></a></p> \n<p>The Idea Spectrum—the same one we spent so much time with in the last <span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/09/mute-button.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">two</a></span> <span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/09/american-brain.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">chapters</a></span>—is useful when you simply want to explore what people think. This was sufficient in Part 2, when we talked broadly about the marketplace of ideas and the way a whole nation of Americans can collectively come to a conclusion, and how that conclusion can evolve over time. But as we’ll see in this post, it’s hardly a complete picture.</p> \n<p>The Idea Spectrum is the What You Think axis. And that’s important information, but the value of <em>what</em> one thinks is entirely dependent upon <em>how</em> they came to that belief in the first place.</p> \n<p>That’s where the second dimension comes in. When it comes to the way we think and the way we form our beliefs, the Psych Spectrum is our <em>How You Think axis</em>.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/12.2-thinking-axes-v2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8397\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/12.2-thinking-axes-v2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"800\" height=\"644\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/12.2-thinking-axes-v2.png 2023w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/12.2-thinking-axes-v2-600x483.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/12.2-thinking-axes-v2-768x618.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/12.2-thinking-axes-v2-750x604.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" /></a></p> \n<p>The addition of the Psych Spectrum turns our thinking spectrum into a thinking <em>square</em>—and now our discussion can get interesting.</p> \n<p>The basic process we’re examining is belief formation, which we can notate like this:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/13-A-_-B.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8080\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/13-A-_-B.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"501\" height=\"177\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/13-A-_-B.png 1000w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/13-A-_-B-600x212.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/13-A-_-B-768x271.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/13-A-_-B-750x265.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 501px) 100vw, 501px\" /></a></p> \n<p>In our thinking square, a person’s x-axis position shows us where they landed at Point B—the output of their thinking process. Their y-axis position tells us about the kind of arrow that led them there—about the process and the rationale underlying what they believe.</p> \n<p>Where we are on this y-axis is a result of the state of our internal tug-of-war, so the first question we need to ask is: how do the two minds think?</p> \n<p style=\"font-size:18px\"><strong>How the Two Minds Think</strong></p> \n<p>In the same way our intellectual viewpoints are a function of our intellectual process, our intellectual process is a function of our intellectual <em>motivation.</em> We think the way we think in the first place mostly because it serves our purposes.</p> \n<p>Our intellectual motivation will normally reflect our values—or, more accurately, the way we <em>prioritize </em>our values. Most of us value both health and culinary pleasure—but whether or not we binge on Skittles is determined by which of those values carries the most weight in our heads in that moment. It’s as if our values are arranged in our head as a Values Stack.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/17.0-Values-Stack.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8082\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/17.0-Values-Stack.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"450\" height=\"255\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/17.0-Values-Stack.png 979w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/17.0-Values-Stack-600x340.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/17.0-Values-Stack-768x435.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/17.0-Values-Stack-750x425.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 450px) 100vw, 450px\" /></a></p> \n<p>At the very top of the stack are the values we hold sacred, and as we move down the stack, we place less and less importance on each value. Whenever two values conflict with one another, the lower one will be the one to compromise, while the higher one will stand firm.</p> \n<p>Of course, the Higher Mind and Primitive Mind totally disagree about what your Values Stack should look like.</p> \n<p>When it comes to your intellectual life, <strong>the Higher Mind values truth above all else.</strong> The Higher Mind’s intellectual mission is to steer your beliefs—your <em>perception of reality—</em>as close to <em>actual</em> reality as he can.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/14.1-perception-of-reality.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8083\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/14.1-perception-of-reality.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"474\" height=\"174\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/14.1-perception-of-reality.png 1056w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/14.1-perception-of-reality-600x220.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/14.1-perception-of-reality-768x281.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/14.1-perception-of-reality-750x275.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 474px) 100vw, 474px\" /></a></p> \n<p>This is his mission because the strength of the Higher Mind’s entire being is fed only by truth. It’s a direct correlation: the more access the Higher Mind has to truth, the brighter his light, and the wiser you are.</p> \n<p>Given that mission, and the understanding that the mission is incredibly hard and never complete—it’s only rational for the Higher Mind to be entirely humble about his perception of reality at any given moment and totally unattached to the ideas that make up that perception. He sees beliefs as nothing more than the most recent draft of an eternal work in progress, and as he lives more and learns more, nothing makes the Higher Mind happier than a chance to revise that inevitably flawed draft. Because when beliefs are being revised, it’s a signal of progress—of becoming less ignorant, less foolish, less delusional. A change of mind about something is a good sign that his light is getting brighter—and that’s all that matters to the Higher Mind.</p> \n<p>And how about the Primitive Mind?</p> \n<p>It’s intuitive why the Primitive Mind would object to marital fidelity—but what’s its problem with the Higher Mind’s approach to beliefs? Isn’t truth helpful to its genetic survival mission?</p> \n<p>Actually no, it’s not. Truth is mostly irrelevant to the Primitive Mind.</p> \n<p>The Primitive Mind’s beliefs are typically installed into its system early on in life, kind of like the way our immune system’s settings are initially configured by our environment. The “intellectual environment” that configures our Primitive Mind’s core beliefs is typically made up of the prevailing beliefs of our family and the broader community we grow up around. On the individual level, the Primitive Mind views those beliefs as a fundamental part of its person’s identity—and therefore about as sacred as the person’s arms or lungs or heart. On the group level, beliefs are the key node that wires its person into a larger giant, which—in the Primitive Mind’s ancient world—means being safe on the lifeboat. For reasons like these, the Primitive Mind puts beliefs into the same ultra-critical category as core biological needs.</p> \n<p>Given all of this, the last thing the Primitive Mind wants is for you to feel <em>humble </em>about your beliefs or interested in <em>revising</em> them. It wants you to treat your beliefs as sacred objects—as precious organs in your body or precious seats on a lifeboat. The Primitive Mind treats beliefs like it treats everything else—as nothing more than a means to the singular goal of genetic survival. To the Primitive Mind, the right beliefs are whatever will leave you with the strongest sense of identity and best fuse you with a large, powerful giant. An ever-evolving quest for truth is directly antithetical to these causes.</p> \n<p>So when it comes to beliefs, <strong>the Primitive Mind doesn’t want truth, it wants <em>confirmation</em>—of your existing beliefs.</strong></p> \n<p>So where does this inner conflict leave all of us? As fucking crazy people.</p> \n<p>To structure our little examination of our collective craziness, let’s divide the Psych Spectrum into four parts:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.1-ladder-segments.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8084\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.1-ladder-segments.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"800\" height=\"644\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.1-ladder-segments.png 2023w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.1-ladder-segments-600x483.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.1-ladder-segments-768x618.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.1-ladder-segments-750x604.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" /></a></p> \n<p>We can approximate each of these Psych Spectrum quartiles with a line—making our square into a Thinking Ladder with four rungs.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.2-ladder-rungs.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8085\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.2-ladder-rungs.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"800\" height=\"644\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.2-ladder-rungs.png 2023w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.2-ladder-rungs-600x483.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.2-ladder-rungs-768x618.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.2-ladder-rungs-750x604.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" /></a>The Thinking Ladder is my favorite lens to use to think about thinking. For any given idea spectrum, you’ll find people on each of the four rungs. People on the same rung may disagree wildly with each other about <em>what</em> they think—i.e. they’ll be at different points <em>along </em>the rung—but what they’ll all have in common is a <em>way</em> of thinking, driven by a common intellectual motivation, at least when it comes to the topic at hand. Most of us are in the habit of dividing people up by what they think—by <em>where they stand </em>on a topic. Our goal here is to shine a spotlight on <em>how</em> people think and learn to categorize people that way instead.</p> \n<p>So let’s explore each of these rungs, starting by looking at how thinking works at the top of the Psych Spectrum—where the Higher Mind is in full control—and then working our way down the rungs, until we finish up at the intellectual slums at the bottom.<a id=\"scientist\"></a></p> \n<p class=\"has-large-font-size\"><strong>Rung 1: Thinking Like a Scientist</strong></p> \n<p>Meet the Scientist:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.3-ladder-SCI.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8086\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.3-ladder-SCI.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"800\" height=\"644\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.3-ladder-SCI.png 2023w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.3-ladder-SCI-600x483.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.3-ladder-SCI-768x618.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.3-ladder-SCI-750x604.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" /></a></p> \n<p>This is who you are in moments when your Higher Mind is in charge of your thinking. Thinking like a Scientist has nothing to do with your line of work. It has to do with your thinking process.</p> \n<p>We often think of science as the study of the natural world, but in the words of Carl Sagan,&nbsp;“Science is a way of thinking much more than it is a body of knowledge.”</p> \n<p>Science is a way of thinking. A means of thinking. A&nbsp;thinking&nbsp;<em>process, </em>designed to do one thing: find truth.</p> \n<p>When you’re high up on the Psych Spectrum, the Higher Mind’s core intellectual value—truth—will be in the top section of your Values Stack. And the Primitive Mind’s core intellectual value—confirmation of your existing beliefs—will be toward the very bottom. So it’s only logical to think like a Scientist.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/17.1-Values-Stack-scientist.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8214\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/17.1-Values-Stack-scientist.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"440\" height=\"322\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/17.1-Values-Stack-scientist.png 979w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/17.1-Values-Stack-scientist-600x440.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/17.1-Values-Stack-scientist-768x563.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/17.1-Values-Stack-scientist-750x550.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 440px) 100vw, 440px\" /></a></p> \n<p>It’s a good time to bring back our nail visual from <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/09/enlightenment-kids.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Chapter 4</a>. Just like a nation, whether we consciously realize it or not, each of us has a nail in our mind that we drive through our sacred values—those values we will not compromise on. All other values, when in conflict with the sacred values, will be forced to sway to accommodate the sacred values. When you’re thinking like a Scientist, there’s little doubt where the nail goes.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/19.1-means-ends-1.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8089\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/19.1-means-ends-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"251\" height=\"333\" /></a></p> \n<p>Things are simple up on the top rung: your intellectual mission is to take your existing beliefs, or lack thereof (Point A) and use your thinking process to move towards beliefs that are a little closer to the truth (Point B). You don’t know what Point B ultimately looks like, and when you’re thinking like a Scientist, you don’t care. You just want your process to take you to the truest possible Point B.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/18.1-A-_-B-Scientist.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8091\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/18.1-A-_-B-Scientist.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"400\" height=\"383\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/18.1-A-_-B-Scientist.png 992w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/18.1-A-_-B-Scientist-600x575.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/18.1-A-_-B-Scientist-768x735.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/18.1-A-_-B-Scientist-750x718.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 400px) 100vw, 400px\" /></a></p> \n<p>To top-rung thinkers, chasing truth is like climbing through thick fog up an infinitely high mountain. It’s the pursuit of something that can never be fully achieved, but it can be approached—and their goal is simply to continue moving up the mountain. They make their way up the mountain using their sacred process—the scientific method—as their compass. They’re intellectually flexible about everything—except the process itself.</p> \n<p>The Scientist’s process looks something like this:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20-Scientific-Method.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8092\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20-Scientific-Method.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"261\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20-Scientific-Method.png 2731w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20-Scientific-Method-600x209.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20-Scientific-Method-768x267.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20-Scientific-Method-750x261.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> \n<p>To see how it works, let’s join you in one of the areas of your life where you’re good at thinking on the top rung of the ladder, and watch you work your way through this process toward a conclusion. Starting at the very beginning—Point A.</p> \n<p style=\"font-size:30px\"><strong>Point A</strong></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20.1-Scientific-Method-sci-point-A.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8094\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20.1-Scientific-Method-sci-point-A.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"261\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20.1-Scientific-Method-sci-point-A.png 2731w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20.1-Scientific-Method-sci-point-A-600x209.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20.1-Scientific-Method-sci-point-A-768x267.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20.1-Scientific-Method-sci-point-A-750x261.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> \n<p>For Scientists, Point A is almost always a loud, proud “I don’t know.” I don’t know is the top-rung thinker’s default starting place. This isn’t a righteous thing, it’s just stating the honest fact: “I don’t have knowledge about this.” When you’re honest about what you do and don’t know, knowledge and conviction are one in the same, and at Point A, you’re way down in this corner:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/21.1-2x2-Sci-starting-point.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8095\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/21.1-2x2-Sci-starting-point.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"426\" height=\"433\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/21.1-2x2-Sci-starting-point.png 862w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/21.1-2x2-Sci-starting-point-590x600.png 590w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/21.1-2x2-Sci-starting-point-768x781.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/21.1-2x2-Sci-starting-point-737x750.png 737w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 426px) 100vw, 426px\" /></a></p> \n<p>More often than not, Scientists don’t bother chasing truth—they know that with limited time, they’ll spend their whole lives not knowing when it comes to most topics. But when a Scientist <em>does</em> want to move away from A and towards B on a topic, the scientific method is the non-negotiable “due process” ideas must work their way through in order to be deemed “knowledge.”<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8034#footnote-2-8034\" id=\"note-2-8034\" rel=\"footnote\">2</a> <p>Let’s say that today, you’ve decided it’s one of those times when you want to learn more about some relevant societal topic.</p> <p>Maybe you’re thinking about society and you want to figure out what you think about trickle-down economics, or you decide it’s time you developed an original, well-thought-out stance on abortion laws. Maybe you keep hearing about charter schools or tariffs or border policies or standardized testing and want to understand the issue better. Maybe there are local elections coming up and you want to figure out who to vote for.</p> <p>Maybe you’re thinking about history and you want to get a better understanding of the causes of World War I, or maybe you’ve been reading the news and you want to know why Brexit happened and what it means for the future. Maybe you’re just wondering how scared or excited you should be about the technological explosion happening all around you.</p> <p>Whatever the topic, you’re ready to embark up the high-rung thinker’s foggy mountain in search of a truer Point B—so you get going on your first goal:</p> <p style=\"font-size:30px\"><strong>Forming a Hypothesis</strong></p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20.2-Scientific-Method-sci-hyp-formation.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8096\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20.2-Scientific-Method-sci-hyp-formation.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"261\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20.2-Scientific-Method-sci-hyp-formation.png 2731w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20.2-Scientific-Method-sci-hyp-formation-600x209.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20.2-Scientific-Method-sci-hyp-formation-768x267.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20.2-Scientific-Method-sci-hyp-formation-750x261.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a>Top-rung thinkers form hypotheses from the bottom up, <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2015/11/the-cook-and-the-chef-musks-secret-sauce.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">by reasoning from first principles</a>. When you reason from first principles, you do your best to ignore conventional wisdom and your own preconceptions, and you focus only on fundamental facts. You treat those core facts—the “first principles”—like puzzle pieces, and using only those pieces, you employ rationality to puzzle together a conclusion.</p> <p>But in order to puzzle, you need pieces, and at Point A, you don’t even have those yet. Getting the right pieces and eventually assembling them into a hypothesis is a three-part effort, carried out by these three characters:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/22.1-bouncers.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8097\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/22.1-bouncers.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"397\" height=\"274\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/22.1-bouncers.png 635w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/22.1-bouncers-600x414.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/22.1-bouncers-103x70.png 103w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 397px) 100vw, 397px\" /></a></p> <p>Here’s how they do their thing:</p> <p style=\"font-size:24px\"><strong>Forming a Hypothesis, Component 1: Gathering Information</strong></p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20.3-Scientific-Method-sci-hyp-formation-1.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8098\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20.3-Scientific-Method-sci-hyp-formation-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"314\" height=\"379\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20.3-Scientific-Method-sci-hyp-formation-1.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20.3-Scientific-Method-sci-hyp-formation-1-498x600.png 498w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20.3-Scientific-Method-sci-hyp-formation-1-622x750.png 622w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 314px) 100vw, 314px\" /></a></p> <p>When we think about how you form your viewpoints, we can think of your head as a two-region system, with a gate surrounding each region:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/23.1-Circles.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8099\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/23.1-Circles.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"401\" height=\"409\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/23.1-Circles.png 960w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/23.1-Circles-588x600.png 588w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/23.1-Circles-768x784.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/23.1-Circles-735x750.png 735w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 401px) 100vw, 401px\" /></a></p> <p>The Attention Bouncer’s job is to guard the attention gate. Each of us is flooded with information at all times, and we have severely limited attention to allot. In other words, your mind is an extremely exclusive VIP-only club. As you scan the world around you, pieces of information form a long line outside your Attention Gate, and your Attention Bouncer has no choice but to be a real dick of a bouncer and turn away almost everyone.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/24.1-Attention-Bouncer-at-door.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8101\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/24.1-Attention-Bouncer-at-door.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"475\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/24.1-Attention-Bouncer-at-door.png 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/24.1-Attention-Bouncer-at-door-600x380.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/24.1-Attention-Bouncer-at-door-768x486.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/24.1-Attention-Bouncer-at-door-750x475.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> <p>The exception is when you decide you want to learn something new and develop a viewpoint on it. When you’re thinking like a Scientist, you know how little you know, especially when you’re at Point A. So the Attention Bouncer keeps the filter very loose for any info that seems potentially relevant to the topic.</p> <p>As he mans the Attention Gate, the Attention Bouncer isn’t especially concerned with whether the puzzle pieces are reasonable or even accurate—that’s above his pay grade. He just wants to import a wide variety of pieces that seem to be representative of the full range of ideas out there on the topic at hand, from all across the idea spectrum. He knows that even a viewpoint you’re pretty sure you disagree with, from a person you’re pretty sure you don’t like, can teach you something. It may not end up changing your mind, but learning about the way that person thinks is information in itself. In this stage, even viewpoints you know are ridiculous are allowed in if they seem to be prominently represented, because the range of viewpoints that exist about the topic <em>is</em> a key facet of understanding the topic.</p> <p>Soon, the outer region of your mind—the “considerations region”—is jam-packed with eager puzzle pieces, standing in a long line of their own outside a far more exclusive VIP club—your beliefs.</p> <p style=\"font-size:24px\"><strong>Forming a Hypothesis, Component 2: Evaluating Information</strong></p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20.4-Scientific-Method-sci-hyp-formation-2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8102\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20.4-Scientific-Method-sci-hyp-formation-2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"349\" height=\"369\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20.4-Scientific-Method-sci-hyp-formation-2.png 909w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20.4-Scientific-Method-sci-hyp-formation-2-568x600.png 568w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20.4-Scientific-Method-sci-hyp-formation-2-768x812.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20.4-Scientific-Method-sci-hyp-formation-2-709x750.png 709w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 349px) 100vw, 349px\" /></a></p> <p>There are instances when a thinker has the time and the means to collect information and evidence <em>directly</em>—with their own primary observations, or by conducting their own studies. In these cases, the Belief Bouncer doesn’t have much to do—you already know that the information is reliable, because you saw it with your own eyes.</p> <p>But the vast majority of the info we use to inform ourselves is <em>indirect</em> knowledge—knowledge accumulated by others that we import into our minds and adopt as our own. Every statistic you come across, every study you learn about, everything you read in a textbook, everything you learn in school, everything you learn from your parents, every book you read, everything you see or read in the news, everything you read on social media, everything you hear a politician or celebrity say, every assumption of conventional wisdom—it’s all indirect information.</p> <p>Your Belief Bouncer’s job is to decide what’s true and what’s not.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/24.2-Belief-Bouncer-at-door.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8103\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/24.2-Belief-Bouncer-at-door.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"475\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/24.2-Belief-Bouncer-at-door.png 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/24.2-Belief-Bouncer-at-door-600x380.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/24.2-Belief-Bouncer-at-door-768x486.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/24.2-Belief-Bouncer-at-door-750x475.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> <p>Assessing an idea’s legitimacy is hard work. And if the only means of assessment is to verify the truth of it yourself, you’re not saving much time.</p> <p>That’s why perhaps the most important skill of a savvy thinker is learning how to dole out <em>trust</em>.</p> <p>Trust, when assigned wisely, is an efficient knowledge-acquisition trick. If you’re able to trust someone who actually speaks the truth, and you accept what they say as truth, you’ve taken the knowledge they worked hard for—either through their own primary research or indirectly, using their own carefully designed trust criteria—and essentially photocopied it into your own brain.</p> <p>Without trust, knowledge is limited to a tiny dataset of personal experience. Raise infant Einstein in the forest with no information and then tell him to invent the best weapon he can, and he won’t get anywhere <em>near </em>the bow and arrow. But start Einstein off standing atop a knowledge skyscraper and he can outline how general relativity works. Communication, plus trust, is a magical intellectual corner-cutting tool—and it’s the reason humanity has been able to accumulate a skyscraper of collective knowledge over the past 10,000 years that has led a species of forest primates to understand the origins of the universe.</p> <p>But trust, when applied wrongly, does the exact opposite. When we trust information to be true that isn’t, we end up with the <em>illusion </em>of knowledge—which is far worse than having no knowledge at all.</p> <p>The fact is, almost all the learning you’ve done in your life has flowed into you through a trust channel presided over by your Belief Bouncer. But what matters far more than the quantity of your cumulative learning is the <em>quality—</em>the legitimacy—of what you’ve learned. And the quality of your knowledge is a function of how good your Belief Bouncer is at assigning trust.</p> <p>In a way, learning is kind of like running a business and knowledge is like the cash you collect. Accepting bad information as truth is like accepting a customer’s payment in Monopoly money without realizing it. You can build a great business and work hard for decades running it, but if 90% of your income has been counterfeit Monopoly money, you’re still a terrible businessperson.</p> <p>It’s easy to see that Monopoly money is fake, but Monopoly knowledge often looks exactly like real knowledge to the untrained eye, so our knowledge economy is currently infested with counterfeit information.</p> <p>To do his critically important job, your Belief Bouncer needs to master the art of <em>skepticism.</em></p> <p class=\"has-medium-font-size\"><strong>The Skepticism Spectrum</strong></p> <p>The truth-seeker’s goal is to hone in on a <em>skepticism sweet spot</em>—something we can visualize on a Skepticism Spectrum.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/25.1-Skepticism-Spectrum.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8104\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/25.1-Skepticism-Spectrum.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"141\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/25.1-Skepticism-Spectrum.png 1672w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/25.1-Skepticism-Spectrum-600x113.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/25.1-Skepticism-Spectrum-768x144.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/25.1-Skepticism-Spectrum-750x141.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> <p>The Skepticism Spectrum is a filter whose settings can be adjusted to make the filter stricter or looser. The sweet spot is the filter’s optimal setting—just tight enough to consistently identify and weed out bullshit; just open enough to let in the truth and take full advantage of the magical corner-cutting of adopting the real knowledge of others as your own.</p> <p>Move to the left of the sweet spot on the spectrum, where the filter is looser, and you begin to allow some bullshit to flow into your beliefs. Move even farther left and your beliefs become packed with a jumble of falsehoods, misconceptions, and contradictions. Moving to the <em>right</em> of the sweet spot tightens the filter too much, like a business owner so worried about accidentally accepting Monopoly money that they end up turning down real money too. Go way to the right and you’ll stop believing the moon landing happened.</p> <p>To be a healthy eater, you need to find the food intake sweet spot—too lenient a “Food Bouncer” and you eat a ton of junk food, too strict a bouncer and you starve. Being a healthy thinker works the same way. Both gullibility and paranoia, especially as you move farther away from the sweet spot, cripple your ability to be a healthy thinker. When you’re being gullible, contradictions become a nightmare for you. You read Opinion A on a topic and you’re sold, adopting it into your beliefs. Then you read Opinion B, which says Opinion A is wrong, and you’re sold on <em>that</em>. With wildly contradicting viewpoints jostling over your beliefs, you end up withdrawing from the topic, feeling like you’re just not capable of understanding it. On the other side, when you’re being paranoid, everything you hear comes along with a little asterisk that says, “don’t be a chump—they’re probably trying to manipulate you.” You refrain from adding almost anything to your knowledge bank. In both cases, learning stalls.</p> <p>Both gullibility and paranoia are a sign of a lack of confidence in your own judgment of who and what is trustworthy. The key skill that’s missing is the ability to accurately separate the real from the skewed from the misleading from the totally incorrect. If you can’t judge incoming information, you can’t take advantage of the critical tool of indirect knowledge.</p> <p class=\"has-medium-font-size\"><strong>The Rung Rating: A Trust Shortcut</strong></p> <p>Effective thinkers, usually without consciously realizing it, develop an internal trust rating system for friends, journalists, politicians, media brands, institutions, and any other source of information. Like an intellectual credit score.</p> <p>We’ll call this credit score a Rung Rating—because what they’re really evaluating is which rung of our Thinking Ladder the source is “thinking from.”</p> <p>A good trust rating system adds even more efficiency to the knowledge acquisition process, saving the Belief Bouncer the heavy lifting of having to evaluate every piece of incoming info on its own merits. We have an internal trust rating system in our heads for the food we eat. If you trust a certain grocery store or food brand or restaurant, you can save the time of carefully scanning ingredients before every bite. The Rung Rating works the same way.</p> <p>On top of being an efficient time-saver for acquiring info from trusted sources, it’s a trick that allows you to gain real knowledge from <em>less</em>-than-healthy information as well. If I know that a particular source, on Topic X-Y, tends to be strongly pro-X and a bit biased against Y, but they also have shown to be reasonably concerned with truth, I can accept their views about X or Y as real information, as long as they’re taken with the proper grain of salt. Depending on the magnitude and direction of their bias, I can apply just the right size and flavor salt grain to their views. If they say something good about X, I can consider that point but know I need to verify it myself, since their historical bias in favor of X means this is just a default statement for them. Same for a negative statement about Y. On the other hand, if they say something <em>good</em> about Y, their historically anti-Y bias makes this <em>very</em> meaningful information that I can probably accept right off the bat.</p> <p>To get anywhere as a thinker, you need to start with the right puzzle pieces. The Attention Bouncer and Belief Bouncer, through a team effort, are in charge of getting you those pieces. If they’re doing their job, the super-VIP club of your beliefs ends up populated by a large array of useful information—and you’re ready to get puzzling.</p> <p style=\"font-size:24px\"><strong>Forming a Hypothesis, Component 3: Puzzling Together a Hypothesis</strong></p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20.5-Scientific-Method-sci-hyp-formation-3.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8105\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20.5-Scientific-Method-sci-hyp-formation-3.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"348\" height=\"438\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20.5-Scientific-Method-sci-hyp-formation-3.png 801w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20.5-Scientific-Method-sci-hyp-formation-3-477x600.png 477w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20.5-Scientific-Method-sci-hyp-formation-3-768x966.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20.5-Scientific-Method-sci-hyp-formation-3-596x750.png 596w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 348px) 100vw, 348px\" /></a></p> <p>In the center of the beliefs region of your mind, your Puzzler starts putting pieces of information together.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/27.1-puzzler-building.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8106\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/27.1-puzzler-building.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"540\" height=\"309\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/27.1-puzzler-building.png 914w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/27.1-puzzler-building-600x343.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/27.1-puzzler-building-768x439.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/27.1-puzzler-building-750x429.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 540px) 100vw, 540px\" /></a></p> <p>Your Puzzler knows that the two bouncers guarding his laboratory have done a ton of listening to others, and his job is to now block out all of that noise and build his puzzle using nothing other than rationality and the info already in your head.</p> <p>When you reason from first principles, you’ll often come to conclusions that conflict with your pre-existing beliefs or with conventional wisdom. It’s a challenge not to lose trust in yourself and give up on your thought process in these moments. But an experienced high-rung thinker knows how often even consensus beliefs are wrong, and their Puzzler will forge ahead confidently, knowing that in a world full of dogma and misinformation, his diligent, honest reasoning process is as valid a path to truth as any.</p> <p>Scientists, so rigid about their high-up position on the How You Think axis, start out totally agnostic about their <em>horizontal</em> position on the What You Think axis. Early on in the puzzling process, a Scientist treats their rung like a skating rink, happily gliding back and forth and flip-flopping their opinion as they explore different possible viewpoints.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/28.1-ice-skating.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8107\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/28.1-ice-skating.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"698\" height=\"562\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/28.1-ice-skating.png 2023w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/28.1-ice-skating-600x483.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/28.1-ice-skating-768x618.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/28.1-ice-skating-750x604.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 698px) 100vw, 698px\" /></a></p> <p>But as the Scientist learns and starts to puzzle info together, they increasingly hone in on a portion of the Idea Spectrum that they suspect may be where the truth lies. Their puzzle is finally taking shape—they have begun to form a <em>hypothesis</em>.</p> \n <div style=\"height:38px\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"wp-block-spacer\"></div> \n <div id=\"eggSeven\">\n  <div id=\"image-map-pro-4408\"></div>\n </div> \n <div style=\"height:38px\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"wp-block-spacer\"></div> <p>This is an exciting moment on your mission today—you’ve conquered the first section of the scientific method. You’ve learned a ton and you’ve formed an authentic take on the topic.</p> <p>Now comes the unpleasant part.<a id=\"testing\"></a></p> <p style=\"font-size:24px\"><strong>Testing the Hypothesis</strong></p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20.6-Scientific-Method-sci-testing.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8108\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20.6-Scientific-Method-sci-testing.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"261\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20.6-Scientific-Method-sci-testing.png 2731w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20.6-Scientific-Method-sci-testing-600x209.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20.6-Scientific-Method-sci-testing-768x267.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20.6-Scientific-Method-sci-testing-750x261.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> <p>Imagine I present to you this boxer.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/29.1-boxing-comic.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8109\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/29.1-boxing-comic.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"224\" height=\"413\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/29.1-boxing-comic.png 511w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/29.1-boxing-comic-325x600.png 325w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/29.1-boxing-comic-407x750.png 407w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 224px) 100vw, 224px\" /></a></p> <p>And I tell you</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/29.2-boxing-comic.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8110\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/29.2-boxing-comic.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"452\" height=\"395\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/29.2-boxing-comic.png 1127w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/29.2-boxing-comic-600x523.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/29.2-boxing-comic-768x670.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/29.2-boxing-comic-750x654.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 452px) 100vw, 452px\" /></a></p> <p>You might ask</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/29.3-boxing-comic.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8111\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/29.3-boxing-comic.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"451\" height=\"390\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/29.3-boxing-comic.png 1075w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/29.3-boxing-comic-600x519.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/29.3-boxing-comic-768x664.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/29.3-boxing-comic-750x648.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 451px) 100vw, 451px\" /></a></p> <p>If I answered</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/29.4-boxing-comic.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8112\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/29.4-boxing-comic.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"449\" height=\"410\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/29.4-boxing-comic.png 1059w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/29.4-boxing-comic-600x548.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/29.4-boxing-comic-768x702.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/29.4-boxing-comic-750x686.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 449px) 100vw, 449px\" /></a></p> <p>You’d probably ask</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/29.5-boxing-comic.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8113\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/29.5-boxing-comic.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"450\" height=\"365\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/29.5-boxing-comic.png 1163w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/29.5-boxing-comic-600x486.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/29.5-boxing-comic-768x622.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/29.5-boxing-comic-750x607.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 450px) 100vw, 450px\" /></a></p> <p>And if I answered</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/29.6-boxing-comic.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8114\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/29.6-boxing-comic.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"447\" height=\"450\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/29.6-boxing-comic.png 1030w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/29.6-boxing-comic-150x150.png 150w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/29.6-boxing-comic-596x600.png 596w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/29.6-boxing-comic-768x773.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/29.6-boxing-comic-745x750.png 745w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 447px) 100vw, 447px\" /></a></p> <p>You’d think I was insane.</p> <p>But people do this with their ideas all the time. They feel sure they’re right about an opinion they’ve never had to defend—an opinion that has never stepped into a ring.</p> <p>A belief or opinion you haven’t tested isn’t knowledge, it’s wannabe knowledge—i.e. a hypothesis. A hypothesis is a boxer with <em>potential—</em>but it’s not a champion of anything.</p> <p>In the world of ideas, the marketplace of ideas is the boxing ring, and boxing opponents come in the form of <em>dissent</em>.&nbsp;</p> <p>When you’re thinking like a Scientist, you know that there are major barriers between you and truth. No matter how fine-tuned your Rung Rating filter system is, it’s sure to mess up sometimes and let falsehood toxins find their way into your hypothesis. You’re also wary of your own biases and the inevitable stubbornness of your own worldview. This is why dissent is so critical for every Scientist. Dissent is the truth-seeker’s immune system. If your hypothesis is a machine, things like biased reasoning, oversimplification, and misleading statistics are its glitches and bugs, and a feisty dissenter to the hypothesis is like a technician searching for those flaws, which helps make it a better machine. Stuart Mill says it best:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8034#footnote2-1-8034\" id=\"note2-1-8034\" rel=\"footnote2\">1</a> <p><em>There is the greatest difference between presuming an opinion to be true, because, with every opportunity for contesting it, it has not been refuted, and assuming its truth for the purpose of not permitting its refutation.</em><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8034#footnote-3-8034\" id=\"note-3-8034\" rel=\"footnote\">3</a> <p>That’s why a Scientist views dissent as another valuable puzzle piece, critical to the completion of their understanding.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/30.1-dissent-as-puzzle-piece.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8115\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/30.1-dissent-as-puzzle-piece.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"327\" height=\"422\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/30.1-dissent-as-puzzle-piece.png 513w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/30.1-dissent-as-puzzle-piece-465x600.png 465w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 327px) 100vw, 327px\" /></a></p> <p>So you take your hypothesis out of the safety of your head—</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/31.1-hypothesis-boxing.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8116\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/31.1-hypothesis-boxing.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"540\" height=\"444\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/31.1-hypothesis-boxing.png 914w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/31.1-hypothesis-boxing-600x494.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/31.1-hypothesis-boxing-768x632.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/31.1-hypothesis-boxing-750x617.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 540px) 100vw, 540px\" /></a></p> <p>—and you toss it into the gauntlet of the marketplace of ideas. You start expressing the idea publicly, in person and online, and watch it get pelted by criticism from all angles. It’s time to see if the little guy can box.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/31.2-hypothesis-boxing.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8117\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/31.2-hypothesis-boxing.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"242\" height=\"295\" /></a></p> <p>High-rung thinkers tend to surround themselves with other high-rung thinkers—which means finding people to debate with will be no problem. When high-rung thinkers hear an idea, they reflexively look for holes to poke in it. They disagree with each other for sport.</p> <p>So you just put the idea out there and watch people flock over to try to break it.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/31.3-hypothesis-boxing.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8118\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/31.3-hypothesis-boxing.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"424\" height=\"370\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/31.3-hypothesis-boxing.png 972w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/31.3-hypothesis-boxing-600x523.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/31.3-hypothesis-boxing-768x670.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/31.3-hypothesis-boxing-750x654.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 424px) 100vw, 424px\" /></a></p> <p>Sometimes they succeed.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/31.4-hypothesis-boxing.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8119\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/31.4-hypothesis-boxing.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"449\" height=\"392\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/31.4-hypothesis-boxing.png 972w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/31.4-hypothesis-boxing-600x523.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/31.4-hypothesis-boxing-768x670.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/31.4-hypothesis-boxing-750x654.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 449px) 100vw, 449px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/31.5-hypothesis-boxing.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8120\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/31.5-hypothesis-boxing.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"444\" height=\"387\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/31.5-hypothesis-boxing.png 972w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/31.5-hypothesis-boxing-600x523.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/31.5-hypothesis-boxing-768x669.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/31.5-hypothesis-boxing-750x654.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 444px) 100vw, 444px\" /></a></p> <p>Other times your idea holds strong.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/31.6-hypothesis-boxing.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8121\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/31.6-hypothesis-boxing.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"448\" height=\"389\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/31.6-hypothesis-boxing.png 972w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/31.6-hypothesis-boxing-600x521.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/31.6-hypothesis-boxing-768x667.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/31.6-hypothesis-boxing-750x651.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 448px) 100vw, 448px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/31.7-hypothesis-boxing.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8122\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/31.7-hypothesis-boxing.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"450\" height=\"393\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/31.7-hypothesis-boxing.png 972w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/31.7-hypothesis-boxing-600x524.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/31.7-hypothesis-boxing-768x671.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/31.7-hypothesis-boxing-750x655.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 450px) 100vw, 450px\" /></a></p> <p>Watching your idea in the ring exposes flaws or misconceptions or soft spots in your ideas and helps you see where to make adjustments.&nbsp;Sometimes you engage in <em>debate</em>, playing the role of defender of your idea, arguing for its validity as hard as you can.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/32.2-boxing-ring.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8123\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/32.2-boxing-ring.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"552\" height=\"315\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/32.2-boxing-ring.png 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/32.2-boxing-ring-600x342.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/32.2-boxing-ring-768x438.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/32.2-boxing-ring-750x428.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 552px) 100vw, 552px\" /></a></p> <p>Sometimes you engage in <em>dialectic</em>, joining the dissenter in examining your idea.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/32.3-boxing-ring.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8124\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/32.3-boxing-ring.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"550\" height=\"348\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/32.3-boxing-ring.png 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/32.3-boxing-ring-600x380.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/32.3-boxing-ring-768x486.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/32.3-boxing-ring-750x475.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 550px) 100vw, 550px\" /></a></p> <p>You sometimes even try flipping sides and playing devil’s advocate, finding someone who agrees with you to debate with since looking at your conclusions through another lens enhances your clarity and reveals things you missed.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/33.1-devils-advocate.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8125\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/33.1-devils-advocate.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"430\" height=\"394\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/33.1-devils-advocate.png 669w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/33.1-devils-advocate-600x550.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 430px) 100vw, 430px\" /></a></p> <p>As your hypothesis boxes different dissenting ideas, you keep your salt shaker handy, viewing every boxing match through the lens of what you believe to be the dissenter’s Rung Rating. You also take the dissenter’s degree of conviction into account, engaging in what writer Julia Galef <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HxUxlVijZQw\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">describes</a> as “meta-updating”: if you’re arguing with someone who has previously shown that their conviction tends to carry integrity, and you’re both pretty sure you’re right in the argument, you assess which of you seems <em>more</em> sure they’re right and use that as an important piece of information.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/34.2-meta-updating.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8126\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/34.2-meta-updating.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"306\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/34.2-meta-updating.png 2861w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/34.2-meta-updating-600x245.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/34.2-meta-updating-768x313.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/34.2-meta-updating-750x306.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> <p>On the other hand, when you argue with someone who has shown you in the past that their expressed conviction is often dishonest or delusional, boy-who-cried-wolf style, you don’t view their level of certainty as meaningful information.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/34.3-meta-updating.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8127\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/34.3-meta-updating.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"601\" height=\"410\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/34.3-meta-updating.png 1705w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/34.3-meta-updating-600x409.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/34.3-meta-updating-768x524.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/34.3-meta-updating-750x512.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/34.3-meta-updating-345x234.png 345w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/34.3-meta-updating-103x70.png 103w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 601px) 100vw, 601px\" /></a></p> <p>The more boxing matches you put your hypothesis through, the more you’re able to explore the edges of your conclusions and tweak your thoughts into crisper and more confident opinions. Your hypothesis is starting to get some serious <em>gauntlet cred</em>.</p> <p>The gauntlet isn’t kind to most ideas, because most ideas are flawed. And when your hypothesis is flawed, some time in the gauntlet watching it get its ass kicked will <em>lower </em>the conviction you feel and convince you that you need to go back to the drawing board. But the times when you come up with a hypothesis that’s logically sound, thoroughly fact-based, and philosophically consistent, the marketplace of ideas will have the opposite effect: watching your idea box like a champ again and again will make you feel tremendously confident about your opinion.</p> <p>As you work your way through this process, we come across yet another important thinker skill—keeping the appropriate level of humility as your confidence grows.</p> <p>You know how I said there’s a “skepticism sweet spot”—right in between gullibility and paranoia—where your skepticism is enhancing and not hindering your ability to learn?
