Well the same thing goes for humility.</p> <p>That sweet spot falls along this dotted line:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/36.1-2x2-Sci.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8128\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/36.1-2x2-Sci.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"447\" height=\"454\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/36.1-2x2-Sci.png 862w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/36.1-2x2-Sci-590x600.png 590w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/36.1-2x2-Sci-768x781.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/36.1-2x2-Sci-737x750.png 737w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 447px) 100vw, 447px\" /></a></p> <p>At any given point on your knowledge quest, you want your conviction to be an accurate expression of how much you actually know.</p> <p>Even for the most self-aware thinkers, staying on the diagonal is easier said than done. It’s like walking on a tightrope, and it’s easy to fall off.</p> <p>When you fall off the tightrope to the lower direction, you end up in the <strong>insecure zone.</strong></p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/36.2-2x2-Sci.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8129\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/36.2-2x2-Sci.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"455\" height=\"462\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/36.2-2x2-Sci.png 862w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/36.2-2x2-Sci-590x600.png 590w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/36.2-2x2-Sci-768x781.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/36.2-2x2-Sci-737x750.png 737w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 455px) 100vw, 455px\" /></a></p> <p>The insecure zone happens when you forget a critical fact: that most people expressing conviction are full of shit. When you forget that, but you’re just self-aware enough to not feel the same BS conviction yourself, you feel stupid, and you feel ashamed of your more modest levels of knowledge.</p> <p>When you’re gullible to other people’s <em>conviction</em>—like a customer who falls prey to a snake oil salesman—<em>your</em> conviction drops below your own knowledge level. You actually do know some stuff about the topic, but you feel like you don’t. You have a confidence problem. The farther below the tightrope you are, the bigger the problem.</p> <p>When you fall off the tightrope to the other side, you land in the <strong>arrogant zone.</strong></p> <p>&nbsp;</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/36.3-2x2-Sci.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8131\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/36.3-2x2-Sci.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"482\" height=\"490\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/36.3-2x2-Sci.png 862w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/36.3-2x2-Sci-590x600.png 590w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/36.3-2x2-Sci-768x781.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/36.3-2x2-Sci-737x750.png 737w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 482px) 100vw, 482px\" /></a></p> <p>The arrogant zone happens when you’re not self-aware enough to remember your own flaws, and you forget how hard knowledge is, and you fool yourself into believing you know more than you do. The higher up you are above the tightrope, the fuller you are of shit.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/36.4-2x2-Sci.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8132\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/36.4-2x2-Sci.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"473\" height=\"481\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/36.4-2x2-Sci.png 862w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/36.4-2x2-Sci-590x600.png 590w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/36.4-2x2-Sci-768x781.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/36.4-2x2-Sci-737x750.png 737w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 473px) 100vw, 473px\" /></a></p> <p>But so far on our little journey, you’ve been doing things like a Scientist. When you’re thinking like a Scientist, it means the Higher Mind is strong in your head, and it lights you up with clarity and self-awareness. High self-awareness means that when you look in the mirror, you see yourself as you are—a flawed thinker with endless potential to learn.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/37.1-mirror-sci.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8133\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/37.1-mirror-sci.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"251\" height=\"377\" /></a></p> <p>Clear self-awareness helps you keep an eye on the Primitive Mind and stay aware of your own cognitive pitfalls—because you know that your brain was designed for survival, not truth, and it’s wise to be wary of your own intuition. As you learn and ponder, self-awareness helps you resist your brain’s urge to save mental energy and oversimplify a complex topic. It helps you remember to think in spectrums despite an instinct to think in binary black-and-white. It helps you force yourself to parse slightly different versions of similar ideas instead of more conveniently grouping ideas together and labeling them as a single thing. It helps you keep putting in the effort to search for the nuance. Because a Scientist knows that the truth is always buried somewhere in the wrinkles of nuance, and that a satisfying, clean-cut, one-sided viewpoint is almost always wrong or incomplete. Looking in the mirror helps you keep an eye on your <em>own</em> Rung Rating as you do your thinking.</p> <p>So you manage to stay pretty close to the tightrope, working your way somewhere up here:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/36.5-2x2-Sci.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8136 \" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/36.5-2x2-Sci.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"459\" height=\"467\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/36.5-2x2-Sci.png 862w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/36.5-2x2-Sci-590x600.png 590w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/36.5-2x2-Sci-768x781.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/36.5-2x2-Sci-737x750.png 737w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 459px) 100vw, 459px\" /></a></p> <p>Your little hypothesis has gone through hell and come out on the other side as <em>knowledge</em>.</p> <p>&nbsp;<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/38.2-hypothesis-_-knowledge.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8138\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/38.2-hypothesis-_-knowledge.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"431\" height=\"335\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/38.2-hypothesis-_-knowledge.png 606w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/38.2-hypothesis-_-knowledge-600x466.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 431px) 100vw, 431px\" /></a></p> <p>There’s just one more thing to do.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/38.3-hypothesis-_-knowledge.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8139\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/38.3-hypothesis-_-knowledge.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"474\" height=\"338\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/38.3-hypothesis-_-knowledge.png 684w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/38.3-hypothesis-_-knowledge-600x428.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 474px) 100vw, 474px\" /></a></p> <p>Top-rung thinkers know themselves, their peers, and history well enough to know that all human intellect is fallible. In the actual science world, even the most tried and true hypothesis will be treated not as ultimate truth, but as a&nbsp;<em>theory</em>. Scientists max out at “theory” because they know that all beliefs are falsifiable and subject to be proven wrong by changing times or new evidence. Thinking works the same way—in order to continually claim a hypothesis to be “knowledge,” it must survive continued testing and scrutiny.</p> <p style=\"text-align: center;\">___________</p> <p>If all of this sounds a bit exhausting, that’s because it is.</p> <p>The Scientist’s learning process is exhausting because knowledge is hard. Because truth is hard. Which is why people who tend to think like Scientists are more than happy to say “I don’t know” most of the time. They’re lazy like anyone else—the thing that makes them Scientists isn’t that they’re necessarily obsessive learners, but that they’re realistic about what developing real, independent, informed viewpoints entails, and they’re honest with themselves and others about what they know and what they don’t.</p> <p>But for today at least, you’ve gone hard enough at this to establish a solid, independent viewpoint that you can feel confident about—and you’ve done it the Scientist way.</p> <p style=\"text-align: center;\">___________</p> <p>I recently attended a conference for scientists (actual, science scientists). I’m not a scientist, but I’m a curious person, and I often write about science, so I had a delightful time spending the whole conference cornering scientists and grilling them on questions I’ve had but haven’t been able to answer.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8034#footnote-4-8034\" id=\"note-4-8034\" rel=\"footnote\">4</a><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8034#footnote-5-8034\" id=\"note-5-8034\" rel=\"footnote\">5</a><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8034#footnote-6-8034\" id=\"note-6-8034\" rel=\"footnote\">6</a><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8034#footnote-7-8034\" id=\"note-7-8034\" rel=\"footnote\">7</a> I also often write about how scientists <em>think</em>, and at one point, standing in a circle with about four scientists, I talked about how much I admire the way scientists think—their humility, their pure motivations, their willingness to admit they’re wrong when new evidence changes their conclusions.&nbsp;</p> <p>They all burst out laughing. One of them said, “Have you <em>met </em>scientists?”&nbsp;</p> <p>This is the thing about humans. We’re so bad at thinking like Scientists that even <em>scientists </em>are bad at thinking like Scientists. Because no matter who you are, inside your mind is a powerful little primitive fuzzball.</p> <p>Above, when you were thinking like a Scientist, the conditions in your head were pristine. The Higher Mind was doing the thinking while the Primitive Mind lay mostly dormant. We’re all there sometimes, when we’re being our best selves—when we’re thinking like pros.</p> <p>But truth is a fragile motive. And at some point, without you realizing it, something changes. It’s a bit of a chicken and egg situation. Sometimes, a topic you’re thinking about jolts your Primitive Mind awake because it believes, for some reason, that holding a certain viewpoint on this topic is important for your survival—often because the topic has become tangled up with your identity. Sometimes, the Primitive Mind has activated for some unrelated reason, which infiltrates your mind with one or more of its standard emotions—fear, pride, anger, ego—and this then affects your thinking, bringing your intellect down closer to its level.</p> <p>Whatever the cause, on our journey down the ladder today, the Primitive Mind has entered the picture. The Higher Mind is still the more powerful character, but now he’s got competition.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/0-PM-HM-leash-B.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8140\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/0-PM-HM-leash-B.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"472\" height=\"340\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/0-PM-HM-leash-B.png 1317w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/0-PM-HM-leash-B-600x433.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/0-PM-HM-leash-B-768x554.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/0-PM-HM-leash-B-750x541.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 472px) 100vw, 472px\" /></a></p> <p>The Primitive Mind’s involvement has compromised your ability to think from the very top rung—you’ve dropped down to Rung 2. You’re no longer thinking like a Scientist—you’re thinking like a <em>Sports Fan</em>.<a id=\"sports-fan\"></a></p> <p class=\"has-large-font-size\"><strong>Rung 2: Thinking Like a Sports Fan</strong></p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.4-ladder-SF.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8141\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.4-ladder-SF.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"800\" height=\"644\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.4-ladder-SF.png 2023w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.4-ladder-SF-600x483.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.4-ladder-SF-768x618.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.4-ladder-SF-750x604.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" /></a>The biggest psychos aside, most real-life sports fans want the games they watch to be played fairly. They don’t want corrupt referees, even if it helps their team win. They want their team to win fair and square. They place immense value on the integrity of the process itself.</p> <p>It’s just…that they really really want that process to yield a certain outcome. They’re not just watching the game—they’re <em>rooting.</em></p> <p>When your Primitive Mind begins to infiltrate your reasoning process, you start thinking the same way. When you head down this road—</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/13.1-A-_-B-SF.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8142\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/13.1-A-_-B-SF.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"501\" height=\"177\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/13.1-A-_-B-SF.png 1000w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/13.1-A-_-B-SF-600x212.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/13.1-A-_-B-SF-768x271.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/13.1-A-_-B-SF-750x265.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 501px) 100vw, 501px\" /></a></p> <p>—you still believe you’re starting at Point A, and you know you need to work hard to get to Point B—and you do want the Point B you ultimately arrive at to be the truth. But you’re not exactly objective about it.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/18.2-A-_-B-Sports-Fan.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8143\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/18.2-A-_-B-Sports-Fan.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"400\" height=\"383\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/18.2-A-_-B-Sports-Fan.png 992w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/18.2-A-_-B-Sports-Fan-600x575.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/18.2-A-_-B-Sports-Fan-768x735.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/18.2-A-_-B-Sports-Fan-750x718.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 400px) 100vw, 400px\" /></a></p> <p>Weird things happen to your thinking when the pure drive for truth is infected by some ulterior motive. Psychologists call it “motivated reasoning.” I like to think of as Reasoning While Motivated—the thinking equivalent of drunk driving. Sent-ts’an explains:</p> <p><em>If you want the truth to stand clear before you, never be for or against. The struggle between “for” and “against” is the mind’s worst disease.</em> – Sent-ts’an, c. 700 AD</p> <p>When you’re thinking like a Sports Fan, Sent-ts’an and his apostrophe <em>and</em> his hyphen are all mad at you, because they know what they’re about to see—the Scientist’s rigorous due process of thinking, corrupted by the truth-seeker’s most treacherous obstacle:</p> <p>Confirmation bias.</p> <p>Confirmation bias, one of the most common impairments caused by Reasoning While Motivated, is why people see perfection in their brand new romantic relationships, and why people are so often nauseated by exes they once adored. It’s why socially paranoid people <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2016/03/long-email-delay.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">freak out</a> when someone takes too long to respond to their email. It’s why overconfident artists can hear ten lukewarm reactions to their art and one effusive one and see the single exception as evidence of their greatness—and why other insecure artists do the exact opposite. It’s why conspiracy theorists see evidence of their conspiracies everywhere.</p> <p>Our x-ray goggles remind us what’s going on here: While the Higher Mind is all about the How You Think axis—about the integrity of the <em>process</em> of thinking—the Primitive Mind is the opposite: it cares only about <em>what</em> you think—about your x-axis position. Because the two minds’ intellectual goals—truth and confirmation—are in direct conflict, it’s a zero-sum situation. When the Primitive Mind enters the equation and captures a piece of your mindset, it inherently draws some of your integrity <em>away </em>from the Higher Mind’s principles. Confirmation rising up in your Values Stack also means truth moving down.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/40.1-Values-Stack-SF-v2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8144\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/40.1-Values-Stack-SF-v2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"250\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/40.1-Values-Stack-SF-v2.png 2400w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/40.1-Values-Stack-SF-v2-600x200.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/40.1-Values-Stack-SF-v2-768x256.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/40.1-Values-Stack-SF-v2-750x250.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a>Truth being lowered a bit in your Values Stack moves it out of sacred, nailed-in territory and into the important-but-not-totally-sacred area, where values are fastened in a less rock-solid way—let’s say, with a thumbtack.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/41.1-means-ends-SF.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8145\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/41.1-means-ends-SF.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"501\" height=\"170\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/41.1-means-ends-SF.png 695w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/41.1-means-ends-SF-600x204.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 501px) 100vw, 501px\" /></a></p> <p>At the same time, confirmation has moved <em>up</em> from the unimportant area of your Values Stack—where values swing freely, totally at the whim of the more important values above—to the <em>somewhat important</em> tier. Values in this tier are still secondary to the more important values, but they’re given enough weight that they don’t swing so freely anymore. They’re taped in place now.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/41.2-means-ends-SF.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8146\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/41.2-means-ends-SF.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"224\" height=\"297\" /></a></p> <p>With some effort, taped values can be moved, but there’s some friction now—a resistance to changing your mind that wasn’t there when you were on the top rung. A portion of your intellectual integrity has been supplanted by intellectual <em>loyalty.</em></p> <p>Life is simple for you when you’re dealing with only nailed-in and free-swinging values—there’s little inner conflict. Thumbtacks and tape are trickier.</p> <p>Now, as the Higher Mind tries to chase truth, confirmation bias is the invisible hand of the Primitive Mind that nudges the process in a preferred direction. And this invisible hand infects every part of the knowledge-acquisition process.</p> <p style=\"font-size:30px\"><strong>The Sports Fan’s Thinking Process</strong></p> <p>If you’re not looking closely enough, the Sports Fan’s thinking process looks a lot like the Scientist’s:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/42.1-Scientific-Method-SF.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8147\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/42.1-Scientific-Method-SF.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"261\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/42.1-Scientific-Method-SF.png 2731w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/42.1-Scientific-Method-SF-600x209.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/42.1-Scientific-Method-SF-768x267.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/42.1-Scientific-Method-SF-750x261.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> <p>But as we watch you work your way from A to B, we’ll see that a little Primitive Mind can go a long way.</p> <p>From the very start, when you’re standing at <strong>Point A</strong>, without any actual knowledge yet, the influence of your Primitive Mind’s automatic conviction has you <em>feeling </em>like you know a bit more than you do.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/43.1-2x2-SF-starting-point.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8148\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/43.1-2x2-SF-starting-point.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"479\" height=\"487\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/43.1-2x2-SF-starting-point.png 862w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/43.1-2x2-SF-starting-point-590x600.png 590w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/43.1-2x2-SF-starting-point-768x781.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/43.1-2x2-SF-starting-point-737x750.png 737w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 479px) 100vw, 479px\" /></a></p> <p>The <strong>gathering evidence phase</strong>—which the Scientist made sure to do in an even-handed and representative manner—now becomes <em>motivated gathering.</em> The Attention Bouncer now plays <em>favorites</em>.</p> <p>We all know what it’s like when a bouncer plays favorites. Back in my 20s, I suffered through a reasonable amount of <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2014/05/secretly-hate-bars.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">hellish nightlife</a>—and a common experience was waiting in line outside some dark, loud, nightmarish weekend night bar while groups of women would walk up and gain immediate entry, without waiting in line. If I were with a group that was too guy heavy, we might get all the way to the front only to not be let in at all.</p> <p>When you’re thinking like a Sports Fan, your Attention Bouncer treats information that concurs with your existing opinion like a group of young, attractive women. And he treats info that weakens your existing views like a large, unappealing group of bros. Wary of letting your mind turn into a sausage fest, he plays favorites.</p> <p>When favoritism happens in the realm of ideas, we call it <strong>cherry-picking.</strong></p> <p>According to the internet, the origin of the term has to do with actual cherry-picking. Imagine you’re a very rich person who owns a huge estate, and one day you’re bored as shit so you call your servant into the room and tell him you’d like to get a sense of what the cherry harvest is like this year in your orchard. But you’re also hungry, so you order the servant not to <em>tell </em>you how the cherries are looking but to actually bring you a<em> representative sampling</em> of the cherries in your orchard.</p> <p>If you were thinking on the Scientist rung of the ladder, you’d leave the instructions at that. Your servant would count the cherries in the orchard and collect a sampling like this:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/44.1-cherry-picking-sci.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8149\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/44.1-cherry-picking-sci.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"404\" height=\"399\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/44.1-cherry-picking-sci.png 916w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/44.1-cherry-picking-sci-600x593.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/44.1-cherry-picking-sci-768x759.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/44.1-cherry-picking-sci-750x741.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 404px) 100vw, 404px\" /></a></p> <p>But if you were thinking from the Sports Fan’s rung, you might add in one extra comment while issuing the command: “…and it will upset me greatly if my cherries aren’t having a good year. I look forward to learning how well they’re doing.”</p> <p>So now, the servant heads out to the orchard with the same plan—to pick a representative sampling. But with your last comment ringing in his ears, he finds himself not really <em>counting</em> the cherries but more <em>eyeballing</em> them. And when he picks his sampling, it comes out like this:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/44.2-cherry-picking-SF.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8151\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/44.2-cherry-picking-SF.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"400\" height=\"395\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/44.2-cherry-picking-SF.png 916w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/44.2-cherry-picking-SF-600x593.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/44.2-cherry-picking-SF-768x759.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/44.2-cherry-picking-SF-750x741.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 400px) 100vw, 400px\" /></a></p> <p>As a Rung 2 thinker, you still want to know what’s actually happening out in the world—you’re just nudging the results a little. And that’s what you did here in the info gathering phase, with your Attention Bouncer as the servant. You didn’t exactly tell the bouncer to be <em>dishonest</em> about anything—you just put him in an awkward position by providing conflicting motivations: 1) to give you a representative sampling, and 2) to hope that the results come out a certain way. So the info you end up gathering and absorbing on the topic skews a little friendly to your preferred conclusion.</p> <p>As this happens, you’re not <em>conscious</em> of doing anything weird at all. You still believe you’re thinking like a good Scientist—even if somewhere very deep down, you might feel a little worse about yourself without being quite sure why.</p> <p>And as we move on from info gathering to <strong>info assessment</strong>, the trouble continues—because when you’re thinking like a Sports Fan, the Belief Bouncer starts acting funny too.</p> <p>When presented with an idea that confirms your existing beliefs, he becomes more lax with the door, easing up on the trust filter criteria.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/45.1-Skepticism-Spectrum-SF.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8152\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/45.1-Skepticism-Spectrum-SF.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"196\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/45.1-Skepticism-Spectrum-SF.png 1672w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/45.1-Skepticism-Spectrum-SF-600x157.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/45.1-Skepticism-Spectrum-SF-768x201.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/45.1-Skepticism-Spectrum-SF-750x196.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> <p>But when a piece of evidence doesn’t seem to match your Primitive Mind’s favorite idea, that benefit of the doubt vanishes, and the Belief Bouncer looks for any reason he can find to deny entry.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/45.2-Skepticism-Spectrum-SF.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8153\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/45.2-Skepticism-Spectrum-SF.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"275\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/45.2-Skepticism-Spectrum-SF.png 1672w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/45.2-Skepticism-Spectrum-SF-600x220.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/45.2-Skepticism-Spectrum-SF-768x282.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/45.2-Skepticism-Spectrum-SF-750x275.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> <p>We talked about the problem of being either too gullible or too paranoid—but there, we were talking about genuine truth-seekers who were simply insecure about their intellectual judgment. Toggling <em>back and forth</em> on the Skepticism Meter, based on the content being evaluated, is <em>motivated skepticism</em>—a classic form of Reasoning While Motivated.<a id=\"toggle\"></a></p> <p>Social psychologist and NYU professor Jonathan Haidt sums up motivated skepticism nicely:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8034#footnote2-2-8034\" id=\"note2-2-8034\" rel=\"footnote2\">2</a> </p> <p><em>We don’t look out at the world and say, “Where’s the weight of the evidence?” We start with an original supposition and we say, </em><strong><em>“Can I believe it?”</em></strong><em> If I want to believe something, I ask: Can I believe it? Can I find the justification? But if I don’t want to believe it, I say: </em><strong><em>Must I believe it? </em></strong><em>Am I forced to believe it? Or can I escape?</em></p> <p>“<em>Can</em> I believe it?” isn’t accidental gullibility—it’s <em>motivated </em>gullibility. Likewise, “<em>must</em> I believe it?” is motivated paranoia.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/45.3-Skepticism-Spectrum-SF.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8154\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/45.3-Skepticism-Spectrum-SF.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"351\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/45.3-Skepticism-Spectrum-SF.png 1763w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/45.3-Skepticism-Spectrum-SF-600x281.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/45.3-Skepticism-Spectrum-SF-768x360.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/45.3-Skepticism-Spectrum-SF-750x351.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> <p>Haidt goes on to reference a perfect example of motivated skepticism in action:</p> <p><em>In a classic study, students come into the lab. They’re taking psychology classes, they’re learning about experimental methods, so they’re given a study. It looks like it’s from the Journal of Science. They’re asked to critique the methods. And the study seems to show that caffeine consumption is associated with breast cancer. And their job now is to read the study and say what they think of the methods.</em></p> <p><em>Well, who do you think finds a lot of flaws in that study? Who do you think? Coffee drinkers! And do you think all coffee drinkers are trying to find flaws in the study? </em>Women<em> who drink coffee are desperately saying, “Must I believe it? Must I believe it? What could possibly be wrong,” and they find all kinds of things wrong with it. The others say, “Oh gosh, okay, I didn’t know that.”</em></p> <p>Reasoning While Motivated caused the exact people who were most upset about the study’s results to reason differently, and less accurately, than the rest of the participants—because it literally changes what goes on in our brain. An MIT study used actual fMRI data to see what was going on with motivated reasoning, and they found that “motivated reasoning is qualitatively distinct from reasoning when people do not have a strong emotional stake in the conclusions reached.”<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8034#footnote2-3-8034\" id=\"note2-3-8034\" rel=\"footnote2\">3</a> Kinda like how drunk driving is qualitatively distinct from sober driving.</p> <p>We could also return to the story of smoking in the US that we discussed in Part 2 and see the same exact phenomenon. One thing I didn’t mention is that as the country slowly came around to the reality that smoking is bad for your health, no one came around more slowly than smokers.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8034#footnote2-4-8034\" id=\"note2-4-8034\" rel=\"footnote2\">4</a> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/46.1-smokers-chart.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8155\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/46.1-smokers-chart.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"548\" height=\"313\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/46.1-smokers-chart.png 974w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/46.1-smokers-chart-600x343.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/46.1-smokers-chart-768x438.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/46.1-smokers-chart-750x428.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 548px) 100vw, 548px\" /></a>When I see these stats, I see this story.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/46.2-smoker-dragged.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8157\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/46.2-smoker-dragged.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"704\" height=\"346\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/46.2-smoker-dragged.png 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/46.2-smoker-dragged-600x294.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/46.2-smoker-dragged-768x377.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/46.2-smoker-dragged-750x368.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 704px) 100vw, 704px\" /></a></p> <p>Smokers were fans of the “smoking is fine” sports team—which impaired their ability to reach truth as quickly as those without a dog in the fight.</p> <p>But neither the smokers nor the female coffee drinkers were thinking about any of this. Like a drunk driver who’s pretty sure they’re fine to drive, they assumed they were being objective. Because part of motivated reasoning’s sneakiness is that the thinker doesn’t realize that it’s happening.<a id=\"trains\"></a></p> <p>The same bias alters the way you judge info <em>sources</em>. It works kind of like adjacent trains. If you’re on a train looking out the window at another train and both trains are still, you see the other train as still.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/47.1-trains.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8159\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/47.1-trains.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"261\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/47.1-trains.png 1263w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/47.1-trains-600x209.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/47.1-trains-768x268.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/47.1-trains-750x261.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> <p>If the other train then starts moving forwards at 10mph, it appears to you as it really is—moving forwards at 10mph.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/47.2-trains-v2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8161\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/47.2-trains-v2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"261\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/47.2-trains-v2.png 1263w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/47.2-trains-v2-600x209.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/47.2-trains-v2-768x268.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/47.2-trains-v2-750x261.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a>But if <em>your</em> train is moving forwards at 10mph, then the other train, also moving forward at 10mph, looks to you like it’s stationary.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/47.3-trains.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8162\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/47.3-trains.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"261\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/47.3-trains.png 1263w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/47.3-trains-600x209.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/47.3-trains-768x268.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/47.3-trains-750x261.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> <p>And if the other train then stops moving and becomes stationary, it looks to you as if it started moving <em>backward </em>at 10mph.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/47.4-trains.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8163\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/47.4-trains.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"261\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/47.4-trains.png 1263w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/47.4-trains-600x209.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/47.4-trains-768x268.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/47.4-trains-750x261.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> <p>Humans with bias works like trains in motion. When you’re thinking clearly and objectively, like a Scientist, you’re like a stationary train. You see objectivity and bias in other thinkers for what they are. But when you’re seeing through a biased lens, you’re like a train in motion. Someone who shares your bias seems objective to you, while someone being objective seems to you to be biased the other way. And when you come across someone who is actually biased the other way, you’ll see their bias as more extreme than it is.</p> <p>The motion of your own bias skews your Rung Rating system. Instead of judging thinkers or info sources purely by the strength of their intellectual process, you’ll unconsciously inflate the rating of sources who agree with you and dock your rating of those who don’t. More motivated reasoning—this time in the form of motivated <em>judgment.</em></p> <p>This Rung Rating distortion works hand-in-hand with the Skepticism Meter toggling.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/49.1-skepticism-of-people-v2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8164\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/49.1-skepticism-of-people-v2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"351\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/49.1-skepticism-of-people-v2.png 1763w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/49.1-skepticism-of-people-v2-600x281.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/49.1-skepticism-of-people-v2-768x360.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/49.1-skepticism-of-people-v2-750x351.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> <p>A corrupt Attention Bouncer leads to a distorted picture of reality, and a corrupt Belief Bouncer means a weakened intellectual immune system against toxic falsehoods. So when we head onto the third leg of the “hypothesis formation” process—<strong>puzzling together a hypothesis</strong>—we find a room of beliefs curated by a corrupt process. The key character in that room—the Puzzler—is limited in his puzzling to the pieces he’s given, and when you’re thinking like a Sports Fan, a disproportionate number of those pieces will support your existing views.</p> <p>And that’s only half the problem, because the Primitive Mind’s motivation has infiltrated the process of all parts of your mind—including the Puzzler himself. As he puzzles, hovering somewhere in his peripheral vision is a picture of your existing viewpoint—the one your Primitive Mind wants so badly to confirm—and the Puzzler is a bit more inclined to use the pieces that match the picture.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/50.1-puzzler-building-SF.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8165\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/50.1-puzzler-building-SF.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"540\" height=\"354\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/50.1-puzzler-building-SF.png 914w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/50.1-puzzler-building-SF-600x394.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/50.1-puzzler-building-SF-768x504.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/50.1-puzzler-building-SF-750x492.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 540px) 100vw, 540px\" /></a></p> <p>By the time you arrive at your eventual hypothesis, it looks conveniently and predictably similar to what you suspected/hoped was true back when you were at Point A.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/50.2-puzzler-building-SF.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8166\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/50.2-puzzler-building-SF.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"539\" height=\"354\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/50.2-puzzler-building-SF.png 914w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/50.2-puzzler-building-SF-600x394.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/50.2-puzzler-building-SF-768x504.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/50.2-puzzler-building-SF-750x492.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 539px) 100vw, 539px\" /></a></p> <p>When you move onto the final step in the knowledge process—<strong>testing your hypothesis</strong>—your Sports Fan bias continues to rear its head.</p> <p>When you were thinking like a Scientist, you felt very little attachment to your hypothesis. But now, as you watch your little machine box, you’re watching as a <em>fan</em>. You’re wearing its jersey. It’s Your Guy in the ring. And if it wins an argument, you might even catch yourself thinking “we won!”—a classic term in the world of real sports fans that reveals their identity’s entanglement with their team.</p> <p><span style=\"font-size: inherit;\">You’re acting like a weirdo because when you’re thinking like a Sports Fan, you don’t see dissent like a helpful puzzle piece—you see it like a tennis ball coming at you during a tennis match. Something to hit back—a challenge to try to </span><em style=\"font-size: inherit;\">defeat</em><span style=\"font-size: inherit;\">.</span></p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/51.1-tennis-ball.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8167\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/51.1-tennis-ball.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"598\" height=\"234\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/51.1-tennis-ball.png 1260w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/51.1-tennis-ball-600x235.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/51.1-tennis-ball-768x300.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/51.1-tennis-ball-750x293.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 598px) 100vw, 598px\" /></a></p> <p>And as you analyze what takes place during the boxing match, there’s more motivated judgment. When a good punch is landed on your hypothesis, you’re likely to see it as a cheap shot or a lucky swing or something else that’s not really legit. And when your hypothesis lands a punch, you may have a tendency to overrate the magnitude of the blow or the high level of skill it involved. When the match is over, you usually end up feeling like your hypothesis passed the test with flying colors—even in cases when an objective observer would see it the opposite way.</p> <p>At the end of all of this, it’s no surprise when you end up right at that shiny green Point B.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/55.1-end-at-point-B.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8168\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/55.1-end-at-point-B.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"401\" height=\"384\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/55.1-end-at-point-B.png 992w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/55.1-end-at-point-B-600x575.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/55.1-end-at-point-B-768x735.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/55.1-end-at-point-B-750x718.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 401px) 100vw, 401px\" /></a></p> <p>Your road to Point B was easier this time. And even though you learned a little less to get there than you did when you were a Scientist, you feel a little more confident about your beliefs than you did then.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/56.1-2X2-SF.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8169\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/56.1-2X2-SF.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"402\" height=\"409\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/56.1-2X2-SF.png 862w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/56.1-2X2-SF-590x600.png 590w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/56.1-2X2-SF-768x781.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/56.1-2X2-SF-737x750.png 737w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 402px) 100vw, 402px\" /></a></p> <p>Your Primitive Mind’s suite of confirmation bias tricks has brought you up <em>above</em> the humility sweet spot, into the Arrogant Zone. Even though in reality, you’ve diminished as an effective thinker, when you look in the mirror you see a <em>better</em> thinker than the Scientist saw through their mirror.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/37.2-mirror-SF.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8171\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/37.2-mirror-SF.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"242\" height=\"363\" /></a></p> <p>As I said, a little Primitive Mind can have a big impact.</p> <p>But Sports Fans aren’t hopeless. The Higher Mind still has the edge in the Sports Fan’s mind, which is why the Sports Fan, motivated as they are, still goes to such great pains to try to go through all the steps of the thinking process. The Sports Fan <em>gets</em> that the scientific method is incredibly important—they’re just not great at working through it effectively.</p> <p>But the Higher Mind will be a nagging voice of self-doubt in the Sports Fan’s head, and at least some of the time, the Sports Fan can reluctantly acknowledge that they’re wrong. Watching their favorite team play, a real-life sports fan’s eye may be biased, but when a slow-motion replay clearly shows that the opposing team was in bounds and got both feet down, they will grudgingly concede that it was the right call—in the end, if the dissent is strong enough, the Sports Fan’s views are falsifiable. Deep down, when push comes to shove, the integrity of the game matters most to the Sports Fan—because underneath all the haze of cognitive bias, Sports Fans are still real thinkers.</p> <p>This is why a lot of Sports Fans end up on a <a href=\"https://rationalwiki.org/wiki/Dunning-Kruger_effect\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Dunning-Kruger</a>-type path, where the Higher Mind eventually prevails and the Sports Fan starts thinking more like a Scientist.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/56.2-2x2-SF-D-K.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8172\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/56.2-2x2-SF-D-K.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"494\" height=\"503\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/56.2-2x2-SF-D-K.png 862w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/56.2-2x2-SF-D-K-590x600.png 590w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/56.2-2x2-SF-D-K-768x781.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/56.2-2x2-SF-D-K-737x750.png 737w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 494px) 100vw, 494px\" /></a></p> <p>When the scientists I talked to at that conference laughed and asked me, “Have you <em>met </em>scientists?” I think they were probably referring to the fact that scientists, like almost all good thinkers, often drift down a rung and think like Sports Fans. Sports Fans are imperfect Scientists—Scientists who have, at least in a particular moment or on a particular topic, fallen off the thinking wagon and let their Primitive Mind get the best of them. The key is that when Rung 1 thinkers go biased, they usually go Rung-2 biased—but probably not much lower.</p> <p style=\"text-align: center;\">___________<a id=\"unfalsifiable\"></a></p> <p>As we move down the ladder from here, let’s remind ourselves that even though we’re using distinct rungs to simplify things, we’re really working on a spectrum.</p> <p>When you’re just below the Scientist rung, you’re just being a <em>little </em>bit of a Sports Fan. Yes, you’ve begun Reasoning While Motivated, but you’ve only had a couple drinks at the motivation bar and your Higher Mind is still in near-total control.</p> <p>But as you drift down the Psych Spectrum, the influence of the Primitive Mind becomes more and more prominent. Your feet get stickier on the x-axis, as it becomes increasingly difficult for even the strongest dissenting evidence to move your beliefs. As the smoke clouding your reason gets thicker, your self-awareness dulls. Your Blood Motivated Level rises higher and higher as truth and confirmation are driven closer to each other in your Values Stack.</p> <p>Eventually, you cross the mid-point.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/57.1-ladder.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8173\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/57.1-ladder.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"800\" height=\"644\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/57.1-ladder.png 2023w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/57.1-ladder-600x483.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/57.1-ladder-768x618.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/57.1-ladder-750x604.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" /></a></p> <p>This is a big moment. Because now, the Primitive Mind is the more powerful character in your mind.</p> <p> </p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/0-PM-HM-leash-C.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8174\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/0-PM-HM-leash-C.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"473\" height=\"382\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/0-PM-HM-leash-C.png 1178w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/0-PM-HM-leash-C-600x484.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/0-PM-HM-leash-C-768x619.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/0-PM-HM-leash-C-750x605.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 473px) 100vw, 473px\" /></a></p> <p>And when the Primitive Mind becomes the alpha character, confirmation becomes <em>more</em> important to you than truth.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/58.1-Values-Stack-ATT-v3.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8216 \" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/58.1-Values-Stack-ATT-v3.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"498\" height=\"287\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/58.1-Values-Stack-ATT-v3.png 1000w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/58.1-Values-Stack-ATT-v3-600x345.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/58.1-Values-Stack-ATT-v3-768x442.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/58.1-Values-Stack-ATT-v3-750x431.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 498px) 100vw, 498px\" /></a><a id=\"unfalsifiableland\"></a></p> <p>Whether you’ll admit it or not (you won’t), the desire to feel right, and appear right, has overcome your desire to <em>be </em>right. And when some other motivation overcomes your drive for truth, you leave the world of integrity, of rationality, of reality, and enter a new place—a place I call:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/59.1-Unfalsifiable-Land.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8176\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/59.1-Unfalsifiable-Land.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"800\" height=\"427\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/59.1-Unfalsifiable-Land.png 1779w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/59.1-Unfalsifiable-Land-600x320.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/59.1-Unfalsifiable-Land-768x410.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/59.1-Unfalsifiable-Land-750x401.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/59.1-Unfalsifiable-Land-374x200.png 374w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" /></a></p> <p>Unfalsifiable Land is a great world of green grass, blue sky, and a bunch of people whose beliefs are unable to be swayed by any amount of evidence. When people are here, they believe what they believe not because of independent reason, but because they are disciples of some line of thinking—that of a religion, a political ideology, a subculture—or maybe they’re simply clinging onto the conclusions of their previous self, back when that self was more of a real thinker. Either way, you can argue with them all you want, but you will achieve nothing, because their views are not falsifiable. That’s why they live here.</p> <p>Even though the vertical axis is a smooth spectrum, the mid-line is a key point along it. Having crossed it, What You Think is now more important to you than How You Think.</p> <p>When your thinking descends from Rung 2 to Rung 3, you’ve gone from a Sports Fan to a different kind of thinker entirely.<a id=\"attorney\"></a></p> <p class=\"has-large-font-size\"><strong>Rung 3: Thinking Like an Attorney</strong></p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.5-ladder-ATT.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8177\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.5-ladder-ATT.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"800\" height=\"644\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.5-ladder-ATT.png 2023w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.5-ladder-ATT-600x483.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.5-ladder-ATT-768x618.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.5-ladder-ATT-750x604.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" /></a>An Attorney and a Sports Fan have a lot in common. They both have a preferred Point B, while also still maintaining some level of dedication to the arrow that’s supposed to take them there. They’re both conflicted between the values of truth and confirmation. The critical difference is in which value, deep down, is higher in their Values Stack.</p> <p>A Sports Fan wants to win, but when pushed, they care even more about fair play than winning.</p> <p>An Attorney’s <em>job </em>is to win, and no matter how hard you push them, nothing can alter their allegiance. Because has this ever happened?</p> <p><strong><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/60.1-prosecutor.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8178\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/60.1-prosecutor.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"374\" height=\"393\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/60.1-prosecutor.png 1000w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/60.1-prosecutor-571x600.png 571w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/60.1-prosecutor-768x806.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/60.1-prosecutor-714x750.png 714w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 374px) 100vw, 374px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/60.2-prosecutor.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8179\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/60.2-prosecutor.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"650\" height=\"368\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/60.2-prosecutor.png 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/60.2-prosecutor-600x340.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/60.2-prosecutor-768x435.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/60.2-prosecutor-750x425.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 650px) 100vw, 650px\" /></a></strong></p> <p>No. That has never happened.</p> <p>Because an Attorney is <em>on a team, period.</em>&nbsp;</p> <p>Which means that while the Sports Fan starts at Point A and then kind of tries to nudge the arrow in a certain direction, when you’re thinking like an Attorney, you don’t start at Point A at all.</p> <p>You start at Point B.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/61.1-A-_-B-ATT.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8180\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/61.1-A-_-B-ATT.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"379\" height=\"218\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/61.1-A-_-B-ATT.png 655w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/61.1-A-_-B-ATT-600x345.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 379px) 100vw, 379px\" /></a></p> <p>When you’re thinking like an Attorney, the faint voice of the Higher Mind in your head means you’ll still feel the need for there to be<em>&nbsp;an</em> arrow that leads to Your Idea—but instead of Point B being the dependent variable to the arrow’s independent variable, your process renders the arrow at the whim of Point B. You’ll put your effort towards piecing together an arrow that leads right where you want it to.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/61.2-A-_-B-ATT.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8181\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/61.2-A-_-B-ATT.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"399\" height=\"377\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/61.2-A-_-B-ATT.png 688w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/61.2-A-_-B-ATT-600x567.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 399px) 100vw, 399px\" /></a></p> <p>This is how attorneys in the real world think, isn’t it? They decide to take on a case, or they’re assigned to one, and from the first moment they’re thinking about the case, they already know their overall stance—and this is where they’ll stay, regardless of what their reasoning or the evidence says.</p> <p><em>The client is not guilty. Now let’s figure out why.</em></p> <p>From there they go through their due diligence, cherry-picking evidence and piecing it together in a way that allows them to present an arrow to the jury that appears to be an objective path to their side’s Point B.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/63.1-real-life-attorneys-full-1.png\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8222\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/63.1-real-life-attorneys-full-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"845\" height=\"297\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/63.1-real-life-attorneys-full-1.png 845w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/63.1-real-life-attorneys-full-1-600x211.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/63.1-real-life-attorneys-full-1-768x270.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/63.1-real-life-attorneys-full-1-750x264.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 845px) 100vw, 845px\" /></a></p> <p>Time for the “I’m not criticizing real-life attorneys” disclaimer!</p> <p>The thing about real-world attorneys is that in an actual courtroom, the attorney way of thinking makes sense—because the attorney’s case is only <em>half </em>of what will be presented to the jury. The opposing attorney presents an opposing arrow that leads to the opposite Point B. This completes the picture, allowing the jury to decide which of the two arrows is more legit-seeming and which Point B seems more like the truth. In this way, the court process sets up a miniature marketplace of ideas, where opposing ideas can clash and truth will (hopefully) be left standing when the dust settles.</p> <p>That’s why my many criticisms of the thinking Attorney on our ladder aren’t criticisms of actual, real-world attorneys. Real-world attorneys <em>know</em> they’re one half of a two-attorney system, and they know that the best way for that <em>system</em> to yield truth is for <em>them</em> to make the best possible case they can for one side of the story.</p> <p>The problem for you when you’re <em>thinking</em> like an Attorney is that you’re not doing so as half of a complete picture, for the purpose of playing your role in a truth-finding process—you’re doing so as a thinker so flawed that winning arguments has become more important to you than truth.&nbsp;While a two-attorney courtroom is an excellent truth-finding mechanism, a courtroom with only one attorney in it is awful at truth—and when you’re thinking like an Attorney, your head is the latter kind of courtroom.<a id=\"attorney\"></a></p> <p style=\"font-size:30px\"><strong>Forming a hypothesis, Attorney style</strong></p> <p>Before any learning has begun, your starting point looks nothing like it did when you were thinking like a Scientist. With the Higher Mind’s voice now marginalized, his humble “I don’t know” is barely audible with the Primitive Mind’s more prominent “of course I know” resonating in the center of your mind.</p> <p>And as you work your way through the learning process, you treat your existing beliefs not like a revisable experiment, or even a favorite sports team, but like your <em>client</em>. The Scientist is the boss of their thinking process—but now, you’re working for your beliefs.</p> <p>Working for your beliefs means you’re not reasoning objectively and you’re not even Reasoning While Motivated—it’s more serious than that. You’re Reasoning While <em>Obligated</em>.</p> <p>When you’re Reasoning While Obligated, the three characters that make up your reasoning process are like law associates working on your case whose only job is to help build the case that will keep you at the Point B you started on—and, ideally, strengthen your conviction about it.</p> <p>Your Attention Bouncer has an updated set of instructions: only import perspectives, statistics, anecdotes, and opinions that help confirm Point B. Regardless of how cherry season is actually going, you want to see one thing: a basket full of bright, ripe cherries. Your Attention Bouncer no longer needs to put in much thought or effort to supply you with information—you’ve made his life easy.</p> <p>Attorney-style cherry-picking explains why there are so many situations where opposing sides of an argument can, simultaneously, be <em>absolutely positive </em>they’re right. When you’re low enough on the How You Think ladder, you stop being aware of the fact that cherry-picking is even a thing, so to you, it seems like <em>clearly, all the evidence shows that I’m right. </em>We see this everywhere.&nbsp;Like, for example, two ideologically opposed media platforms presenting the same exact news story but picking totally different cherries to present, so the parties presented as heroes and villains, victims and perpetrators, are literally reversed in their tellings.</p> <p>There are plenty of less-charged examples as well. Want to believe that coffee, wine, chocolate, saturated fat, or red meat are healthy? Just type into Google the name of that item, along with “surprisingly healthy.” Cherry-picking has you covered. Want to believe they’re all terrible for you? Ask Google if they’re “harmful” or “unhealthy” to eat. Either way, you’ll come out of your search even more sure of what you came in wanting to believe.&nbsp;</p> <p>Your Attention Bouncer is also less intent on collecting first principles puzzle pieces than he was on the higher rungs and more content to collect pre-packaged arguments in the form of op-eds and other external opinions. When you’re looking for confirmation first and foremost, nothing is more efficient than information in a “here is why you are right” format.</p> <p>Your Belief Bouncer’s new assignment is just as easy. When assessing which info is valid, instead of the super difficult job of checking IDs for truth, he now only has to check IDs for content.</p> <p>When a piece of imported info jibes with what you already believe, the bouncer opens the door wide.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/64.1-Skepticism-Spectrum-ATT.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8183\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/64.1-Skepticism-Spectrum-ATT.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"303\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/64.1-Skepticism-Spectrum-ATT.png 1735w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/64.1-Skepticism-Spectrum-ATT-600x242.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/64.1-Skepticism-Spectrum-ATT-768x310.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/64.1-Skepticism-Spectrum-ATT-750x303.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> <p>Info that suggests you might be wrong is seen as malicious and manipulated and consistently shut out by a skepticism filter so tight nothing could ever get through it. We have a word for that: denial.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/64.2-Skepticism-Spectrum-ATT.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8184\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/64.2-Skepticism-Spectrum-ATT.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"303\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/64.2-Skepticism-Spectrum-ATT.png 1735w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/64.2-Skepticism-Spectrum-ATT-600x242.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/64.2-Skepticism-Spectrum-ATT-768x310.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/64.2-Skepticism-Spectrum-ATT-750x303.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> <p>When your Belief Bouncer judges info<em> sources</em>, his job is just as straightforward. When you think you already know the truth, then by definition, someone who agrees with you is right and someone who doesn’t is wrong. Instead of asking, “How did they get to this idea?” your Belief Bouncer now simply asks: “Are they enlightened?”</p> <p>In such rapid “bias motion” yourself, anyone who disagrees with you, objective or biased, appears to you to be a terrible thinker. A surefire sign that you’re thinking like an Attorney is when you believe—really believe, in your heart—that the people who disagree with you are not just wrong, but wrong because of who they are—fundamentally bad thinkers—despite having a relatively small amount of experience getting to know them.</p> <p>When you’re thinking like an Attorney and Reasoning While Obligated, your two-bouncer immune system is totally disabled. Your beliefs end up filled with a combination of real information and Monopoly-money junk—and you no longer have the ability to tell one from the other.</p> <p>The good news is, it’s not important. Knowing what’s true and what’s not only matters when you’re actually trying to get to the truth—and your goal has now shifted to confirmation. So in the center of your mind, your Puzzler gets to work. The preferred conclusion at the periphery of the Sports Fan’s consciousness has now been moved front and center, and your Puzzler uses it as a guide, like the image on the box cover of a jigsaw puzzle.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/65.1-puzzler-building-ATT.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8185\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/65.1-puzzler-building-ATT.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"540\" height=\"324\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/65.1-puzzler-building-ATT.png 914w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/65.1-puzzler-building-ATT-600x360.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/65.1-puzzler-building-ATT-768x460.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/65.1-puzzler-building-ATT-750x450.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 540px) 100vw, 540px\" /></a></p> <p>Where Scientists have to painstakingly paint, Attorneys can mindlessly trace.</p> <p>Often, the main activity for your Puzzler is simple memorization. Rather than focus on raw first principles, the bouncers have imported mostly second-hand arguments by others, and memorizing them will feel to you like gaining knowledge. You simply adopt as your own viewpoints the most legit-sounding arguments made by others who agree with you, and you’re good to go.</p> <p>When you do decide to dig in a bit more and form some of your own conclusions, your Attorney process has you covered with all kinds of clever tricks involving trends and anecdotes, correlation and causation, sneakily worded statistics, and more (we’ll get into all of that in later chapters).</p> <p>If someone really wants to believe just about <em>anything—</em>that&nbsp;the Earth is flat, that 9/11 was orchestrated by Americans, that everyone hates them, that everyone loves them, that the CIA is after them—the human brain will have no problem using the large toolbox of Attorney tricks to make that belief seem perfectly clear and irrefutable.</p> <p>When you’re thinking like an Attorney, the Hypothesis Formation stage is really just a belief-strengthening process. You inevitably end up with the same viewpoints you started with, now beefed up with a refreshed set of facts and arguments that remind you just how right you are. You’ve constructed an arrow that does the trick.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/66.1-A-_-B-constructed-arrow-v2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8186\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/66.1-A-_-B-constructed-arrow-v2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"301\" height=\"297\" /></a></p> <p style=\"font-size:30px\"><strong>Testing your hypothesis, Attorney style</strong></p> <p>In the testing phase, though you’re far less eager to seek out dissent to challenge your beliefs, your manufactured arrow to Point B has you ready to argue with anyone who tries to crack your conviction. You’re ready for the testing phase, because you know you’re invincible.</p> <p>Your argument has nothing to worry about, because in order for dissent to generate doubt, you have to thoughtfully listen to and consider the dissent—and you won’t do either. For every argument that comes your way, you’ll listen only enough to pick out the best argument against it from your arsenal. Usually you’ll simply be reciting the words of one of the opinion pieces you imported. If someone does come at you with an argument you can’t seem to beat, you’ll again reach into your arsenal of dirty tricks.</p> <p>Your refusal to really listen to or consider anything a dissenter says, compounded with your bag of trump card tricks, and topped off with your unbreakable conviction that you’re right, will ensure that you’re an absolutely infuriating person to argue with. Your opponents will feel like they’re arguing against a brick wall, and by the end, it’ll be clear to them that nothing they could have said—nothing whatsoever—could have made you say “hmm that’s a good point—I need to think about that—maybe I’m wrong.” That’s what it feels like to argue with someone who lives in Unfalsifiable Land.</p> <p>The Scientist watches their ideas box as an objective spectator. The Sports Fan watches with a rooting interest. The Attorney watches boxing matches from the middle of the ring, as the corrupt ref who has fixed the match’s outcome from the moment it begun.</p> <p>Let’s bring back our scientific method of knowledge acquisition for a second.</p> <p><strong><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20-Scientific-Method.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8092\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20-Scientific-Method.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"800\" height=\"278\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20-Scientific-Method.png 2731w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20-Scientific-Method-600x209.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20-Scientific-Method-768x267.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/20-Scientific-Method-750x261.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" /></a></strong></p> <p>High-rung thinkers go through this arduous process because they know that knowledge is hard. When you’re thinking like an Attorney, this entire process is a farce—a formality to appease the faint voice of the Higher Mind bellowing from the backburner of your mind. Your knowledge process never had a chance to change your mind, and it never had a chance to build much real knowledge in your head.</p> <p>It only took you along this path:</p> <p><strong><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/67.1-2x2-ATT.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8187\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/67.1-2x2-ATT.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"481\" height=\"489\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/67.1-2x2-ATT.png 862w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/67.1-2x2-ATT-590x600.png 590w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/67.1-2x2-ATT-768x781.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/67.1-2x2-ATT-737x750.png 737w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 481px) 100vw, 481px\" /></a></strong></p> <p>But the crazy thing about humans is, when you’re thinking like an Attorney, <em>you</em> <em>still believe you’re thinking like a Scientist</em>.
