You <em>think </em>you did this:</p> <p><strong><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/67.2-2x2-ATT.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8188\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/67.2-2x2-ATT.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"464\" height=\"472\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/67.2-2x2-ATT.png 862w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/67.2-2x2-ATT-590x600.png 590w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/67.2-2x2-ATT-768x781.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/67.2-2x2-ATT-737x750.png 737w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 464px) 100vw, 464px\" /></a></strong></p> <p>You’re sure that the immense conviction you feel has been well-earned. You think your mind is full of original viewpoints based on real, hard knowledge. You come out of those fixed-match arguments believing that you crushed it. If the argument was frustrating, you probably attribute it, ironically, to your <em>opponent</em> being a brick wall to argue with, and the kind of person who just can’t admit when they’re wrong.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8034#footnote-8-8034\" id=\"note-8-8034\" rel=\"footnote\">8</a> <p>This is the power of human delusion. A delusional feat of this magnitude—to leave you filled with a level of conviction you have absolutely no ground to feel—is usually a tag-team effort between two types of delusion:</p> <p><strong>1) A distorted view of yourself. </strong>When you look in the mirror, instead of seeing a dramatically flawed thinker, the Primitive Mind’s thick smoke shows you a model intellectual.</p> <p><strong><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/37.3-mirror-ATT.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8189\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/37.3-mirror-ATT.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"253\" height=\"380\" /></a></strong></p> <p><strong>2) A distorted view of the world. </strong>When you’re clear-headed and thinking like a Scientist, you’re well aware that both the world and the people in it are impossibly complex and nuanced and messy. This fact keeps you humble about what you know, no matter how much you’ve learned. But when you’re thinking like an Attorney, the same consciousness-clouding fog that lowers your self-awareness also distorts your vision of the world around you. While the Scientist’s <em>clear </em>vision shows them a complex, foggy world, the Attorney’s <em>foggy</em> vision shows them a world that’s straightforward, full of crisp lines and black-and-white distinctions. As your intellect works its way down the ladder, fuzzy spectrums sharpen into clean, binary distinctions, and unique individual people sort themselves into easily stereotyped groups. Issues now have a right side and a wrong side, with little middle ground. People are right or wrong, well-intentioned or malicious, and that’s that. Oversimplification is the amateur thinker’s trademark.</p> <p>Arrogance is ignorance plus conviction. This is an especially deadly combo because it prevents you from improving. It not only leaves you without real knowledge, it deprives you of the humility needed to gain real knowledge or grow into a better thinker. When you think you’re already doing great, you feel like there’s no room left for improvement. We all collect life experience, but we don’t all take advantage of it. While humility is a permeable filter that absorbs life experience and converts it into knowledge and wisdom, arrogance is a rubber shield that life experience simply bounces off of.</p> <p style=\"text-align: center;\">___________</p> <p>If there’s anything you can say about Rung 3, Attorney-style thinkers, they at least understand the <em>concept</em> of an arrow. They’re unfalsifiable, but they’re not <em>that</em> big an internal shift—an intellectual “growth spurt”—away from becoming a legitimate thinker. From somewhere in the periphery of their mind, the voice of the Higher Mind still carries some weight. And if they can just learn to listen to it and value it, maybe they can change.</p> <p>But again, we’re working on a spectrum here, so the Higher Mind’s prominence in an Attorney’s head varies. The How You Think ladder works kind of like the U.S. congress. It’s a binary situation where whichever “party” has the majority is in the driver’s seat. At any point along the spectrum, either the Higher Mind or the Primitive Mind holds primary control, all determined by whether you’re below or above the ladder’s midpoint. But like congress, the margin of victory matters. When you’re thinking like an Attorney, the Primitive Mind is the majority party—but the Higher Mind is a sizable minority who still asserts influence. But as your intellect drops further down the Psych Spectrum, deeper into Unfalsifiable Land, the Higher Mind’s voice grows fainter. The Primitive Mind starts to develop a <em>super-</em>majority, eventually leaving the minority Higher Mind party with little to no influence.</p> <p>As you descend, you become an increasingly corrupt Attorney, increasingly likely to accept red-painted plastic cherries—fake news, shoddy statistics, scattered anecdotal personal experiences—as hard evidence and universal truth. You start taking things out of context or even flat-out lying when you argue with people. And less exposure to those who disagree with you means it becomes easier to fictionalize your opponents as people not even worth talking to, making you even more certain that everything you believe is correct. At the same time, your self-image and the conviction you hold about your beliefs grow even stronger than they were. You no longer concern yourself with the reasoning behind your viewpoints—you just know that those viewpoints are right.</p> <p>Eventually, your Values Stack looks like this:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/69.1-Values-Stack-ZEA-v2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8191\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/69.1-Values-Stack-ZEA-v2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"592\" height=\"341\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/69.1-Values-Stack-ZEA-v2.png 1000w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/69.1-Values-Stack-ZEA-v2-600x345.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/69.1-Values-Stack-ZEA-v2-768x442.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/69.1-Values-Stack-ZEA-v2-750x431.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 592px) 100vw, 592px\" /></a></p> <p>With confirmation having reached the sacred section of the stack, your nail is back in the picture—while truth now swings freely.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/70.1-means-ends-ZEA.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8192\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/70.1-means-ends-ZEA.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"251\" height=\"333\" /></a></p> <p>Your thinking is now entirely running on the ancient software of your Primitive Mind, with the rational, reasonable, humble, and self-aware Higher Mind completely out of the picture.</p> <p>You’ve reached the bottom rung.</p> <p class=\"has-large-font-size\"><strong>Rung 4: Thinking Like a Zealot</strong></p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.6-ladder-ZEA.png\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8193\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.6-ladder-ZEA.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"2023\" height=\"1629\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.6-ladder-ZEA.png 2023w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.6-ladder-ZEA-600x483.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.6-ladder-ZEA-768x618.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.6-ladder-ZEA-750x604.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 2023px) 100vw, 2023px\" /></a></p> <p>We all think like Zealots at times. We’re all naive in our own unique set of ways, and zealot-like thinking is sometimes a case of naivety. Sometimes we’re taught zealot-like thinking by our parents or friends. Sometimes we’re scared and zealotry is a cave we’ve found to hide in.</p> <p>I think it’s often because we’ve made the amateur error of thinking that people are ideas and ideas are people. If ideas and people are the same, it ties our self-worth to the worth of our beliefs. It ties our personal safety to the protection of those beliefs, and it makes a challenge to those beliefs feel like physical danger. It makes validation of our beliefs feel like acceptance and approval and love. This is one of the many pits we fall into when our Primitive Minds are doing our thinking.</p> <p>When you forget that people and ideas are separate, your entire thinking process is laden with a crippling burden: to protect your beliefs like you protect your body. You’ve traded in the Scientist’s horizontal flexibility for a total willingness to vertically compromise on your thinking process, and you’ve swapped the Scientist’s vertical rigidity that keeps their process on the top rung for a horizontal rigidity that nails your feet right into the Idea Spectrum, right at the point where your viewpoints live.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/71.1-ice-skating-nails.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8194\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/71.1-ice-skating-nails.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"800\" height=\"644\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/71.1-ice-skating-nails.png 2023w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/71.1-ice-skating-nails-600x483.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/71.1-ice-skating-nails-768x618.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/71.1-ice-skating-nails-750x604.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" /></a></p> <p>No longer is there a humble Point A. When you’re thinking like a Zealot, humility feels weak and shameful. You’ll never say “I don’t know,” because that sounds the same to you as saying “I don’t know who I am.” You <em>do </em>know. Your beliefs are a rock-solid reflection of the objective truth, period. Knowledge is the opposite of hard—it’s like knowing the sky is blue. Anyone with a mind and a heart knows what’s true and what’s not.</p> <p>So you don’t need any “process of thinking” arrow. Arrows are for idiots. This is what thinking like a Zealot feels like.</p> <p>In reality, you’ve taken a set of ideas to be sacred, and you’ve given up an independent truth-seeking path in order to faithfully serve those sacred ideas. Without any Higher Mind influence forcing you to engage with some kind of knowledge process, the once-rigorous scientific method has evolved to this:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/72.1-worshipping-B.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8195\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/72.1-worshipping-B.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"400\" height=\"352\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/72.1-worshipping-B.png 935w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/72.1-worshipping-B-600x528.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/72.1-worshipping-B-768x676.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/72.1-worshipping-B-750x660.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 400px) 100vw, 400px\" /></a></p> <p>Thinking, for you, is about worship, not learning.</p> <p>So aside from a deep pleasure you derive from information that praises and confirms What You Think, gathering information has little use—you already know all your cherries are perfect, so your Attention Bouncer servant can stay home.</p> <p>Your Belief Bouncer doesn’t have much to do either. Ideas that validate your ideas are good, true ideas, spoken by good, reasonable people. And those are the only ideas you want to hear.</p> <p>The three characters in your reasoning process who used to help you find truth now simply send in a never-ending stream of love, acceptance, approval, and safety in the form of anecdotes, statistics, and opinions that make you feel great.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/73.1-Attention-Bouncer-ZEA.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8196\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/73.1-Attention-Bouncer-ZEA.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"650\" height=\"371\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/73.1-Attention-Bouncer-ZEA.png 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/73.1-Attention-Bouncer-ZEA-600x342.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/73.1-Attention-Bouncer-ZEA-768x438.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/73.1-Attention-Bouncer-ZEA-750x428.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 650px) 100vw, 650px\" /></a></p> <p>In the testing ideas phase—well, there is no testing ideas phase. First of all, why would you test what you’re already sure about? It’s like testing whether the ocean is wet. But more importantly, when you think ideas and people are the same, someone challenging your ideas feels like an insult. It feels violating. It feels personally invalidating. It’s a threat. If Scientists see dissent as a puzzle piece and Sports Fans see dissent as a tennis ball, Zealots see dissent as a bucket of shit.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/73.2-dissent-shit-bucket.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8197\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/73.2-dissent-shit-bucket.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"297\" height=\"324\" /></a></p> <p>And who wants to challenge your ideas anyway? Dissenters. Dissenters are people who hold different ideas, which means they’re different kinds of people—worse kinds of people. Their entire existence, if accepted, invalidates your own existence. So they cannot be tolerated. You avoid dissenters and their disgusting ideas as much as you can—other than the time you spend mocking them and their ideas, which is just another form of self-confirmation.</p> <p>At the top of our ladder, your identity was that of a humble learner, which made you intellectually robust. So intellectual boxing matches were your friend—they made you smarter and brought you a little closer to the truth. Now that you’re thinking like a Zealot, those ideas in the ring are your naked, vulnerable body—so you don’t want to watch your ideas box, or root for them, or even fix the matches. You ban boxing altogether.</p> <p>When you’re thinking like a Zealot, there is no reasoning process, because there is no reasoning. You’re just here, always:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/74.1-2x2-ZEA.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8198\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/74.1-2x2-ZEA.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"479\" height=\"488\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/74.1-2x2-ZEA.png 862w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/74.1-2x2-ZEA-590x600.png 590w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/74.1-2x2-ZEA-768x781.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/74.1-2x2-ZEA-737x750.png 737w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 479px) 100vw, 479px\" /></a></p> <p>You’re the picture of arrogance, of unearned conviction, of total ignorance, of utter un-self-awareness. And hiding just beneath that façade is a terrifying frailty, protected only by a rigid, brittle set of simplified beliefs. It’s not a great situation.</p> <p>So there’s our ladder. Time for a big recap chart:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/75-Recap-Chart.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8199\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/75-Recap-Chart.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1250\" height=\"3621\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/75-Recap-Chart.png 2360w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/75-Recap-Chart-207x600.png 207w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/75-Recap-Chart-259x750.png 259w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1250px) 100vw, 1250px\" /></a></p> <p>Each of us is a work in progress, and as we grow in age, we also can grow up psychologically. The more we evolve psychologically, the more time we spend thinking from the high rungs and the less time we spend down below. But no matter how good we get at thinking, I’m pretty sure we never totally rid ourselves of low-rung thinking.</p> <p>This post focused entirely on individual thinking, but the intellectual life of an individual doesn’t happen in isolation. The 2D picture we’ve painted so far in this post is still an incomplete picture. It’s a 2D cross section of what’s actually a 3D system—a single slice of bread in the <em>loaf</em> of human behavior. To bring our lens into full focus, we’ll need to zoom out and look deeper into the loaf, exploring how thinking happens in communities. In the next chapter, we’ll step into the wonderful, horrible world of intellectual <em>cultures.</em></p> <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/idea-labs-echo-chambers\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-7661\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/next-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"101\" height=\"55\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/next-1.png 1100w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/next-1-300x164.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/next-1-768x419.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/next-1-600x327.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/next-1-374x200.png 374w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/next-1-239x130.png 239w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 101px) 100vw, 101px\" /></a></p> <p class=\"has-text-align-center wbwFont\">Chapter 8: <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/10/idea-labs-echo-chambers.html\">Idea Labs and Echo Chambers</a></p> <p style=\"text-align: center;\">___________</p> <p>To keep up with this series, sign up for the <strong><a class=\"ClickPico PicoRule\">Wait But Why email list</a></strong> and we’ll send you the new posts right when they come out.</p> <p>Huge thanks to our Patreon supporters for making this series free for everyone. To support Wait But Why, <a href=\"https://www.patreon.com/waitbutwhy\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><strong>visit our Patreon page</strong></a>.</p> <p style=\"text-align: center;\">___________</p> <p style=\"font-size:19px\"><strong>Three posts that are related to this one but not actually:</strong></p> <p>A post I wrote about <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2014/03/sports-fans-sports-fans.html\"><strong>actual sports fans</strong></a>.</p> <p>A post I wrote about <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2014/05/secretly-hate-bars.html\"><strong>actual bouncers and why I hate bars</strong></a>.</p> <p>A post I wrote about <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2013/10/the-primate-awards.html\"><strong>the rest of our primate relatives</strong></a>, who are even more embarrassing than we are.</p> \n     <div class=\"footnotes\">\n      <hr />\n      <ol>\n       <li id=\"footnote-1-8034\" class=\"footnote\"><p>And at <a href=\"https://www.ted.com/talks/tim_urban_inside_the_mind_of_a_master_procrastinator?language=en\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">TED</a>!<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8034#note-1-8034\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n       <!--/#footnote-1.footnote-->\n       <li id=\"footnote-2-8034\" class=\"footnote\"><p>I considered putting <a href=\"https://www.targetmarketingmag.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/3/2017/05/Screen-Shot-2017-05-04-at-9.12.45-AM.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">an image of the Dos Equis guy</a> here and putting in the speech bubble “I don’t always try to form conclusions, but when I do, I prefer the scientific method.” But I knew my wife would veto it when she did her proofread so I skipped it.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8034#note-2-8034\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n       <!--/#footnote-2.footnote-->\n       <li id=\"footnote-3-8034\" class=\"footnote\"><p>Another good one from Mill:<em> He who knows only his own side of the case knows little of that. His reasons may be good, and no one may have been able to refute them. But if he is equally unable to refute the reasons on the opposite side, if he does not so much as know what they are, he has no ground for preferring either opinion… Nor is it enough that he should hear the opinions of adversaries from his own teachers, presented as they state them, and accompanied by what they offer as refutations. He must be able to hear them from persons who actually believe them…he must know them in their most plausible and persuasive form.”</em><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8034#note-3-8034\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n       <!--/#footnote-3.footnote-->\n       <li id=\"footnote-4-8034\" class=\"footnote\"><p>Like whether two couples could decide, instead of each having their own child, to have a joint child—by each couple creating an embryo and then “mating” the two embryos in a lab by extracting a gamete from each of them and then using the two gametes to conceive the “child” of the two embryos. Then they’d implant <em>that </em>embryo in one of the two women and when she has that kid, it’s actually the <em>grandchild</em>&nbsp;of both couples. So the four of them have effectively produced a four-way child that’s equally related to each of them. Then, as my fantasy goes, 30 years later, when the two couples are in their 60s and their grandchild is in her 30s, they could return to the two original frozen embryos and birth <em>them</em>. So now you have two 60-something couples, their 30-year-old grandchild, and in her two arms, she’s holding two babies—<em>her parents</em>. And the children of the two couples. I picture a few years later her feeding the now-toddlers, being like, “Hey <em>mom</em>—do <em>not </em>hit dad. You have to <em>wait </em>for your food, you can’t just take his.” It goes on. 30 years later, the two parents are now 30, and <em>they </em>get married and have a child. And when Thanksgiving rolls around, you’ve got the original two couples—now in their 90s—their 30-year-old children, who are married, and their grandchildren, who are 60 years old and 3 months old, respectively. This is what I cornered the world-renowned stem cell researcher to ask her about.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8034#note-4-8034\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n       <!--/#footnote-4.footnote-->\n       <li id=\"footnote-5-8034\" class=\"footnote\"><p>The answer is yes, technically, this could happen. If anyone wants to join me and my wife as the other couple, let me know.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8034#note-5-8034\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n       <!--/#footnote-5.footnote-->\n       <li id=\"footnote-6-8034\" class=\"footnote\"><p>I’ve invented a new activity: footnote procrastination.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8034#note-6-8034\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n       <!--/#footnote-6.footnote-->\n       <li id=\"footnote-7-8034\" class=\"footnote\"><p>bye<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8034#note-7-8034\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n       <!--/#footnote-7.footnote-->\n       <li id=\"footnote-8-8034\" class=\"footnote\"><p>There are times when we’re actually feeling insecure about what we know and we outwardly argue like an Attorney as a kind of front. That’s a different case—more of a high-rung thinker who is embarrassed to just say “I don’t know.” The low-rung Attorney we’re talking about doesn’t have that kind of self-awareness.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8034#note-8-8034\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n       <!--/#footnote-8.footnote-->\n      </ol>\n     </div>\n     <!--/#footnotes-->\n     <div class=\"footnotes2\">\n      <hr />\n      <ol>\n       <li id=\"footnote2-1-8034\" class=\"footnote2\"><p><a href=\"https://courses.lumenlearning.com/sanjacinto-philosophy/chapter/john-stuart-mill-on-liberty-chapter-2-of-the-liberty-of-thought-and-discussion/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><em>On Liberty</em></a>, Chapter 2.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8034#note2-1-8034\" class=\"footnote2-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n       <!--/#footnote2-1.footnote-->\n       <li id=\"footnote2-2-8034\" class=\"footnote2\"><p><a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kaQ-ZF9S3uk\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Source</a><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8034#note2-2-8034\" class=\"footnote2-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n       <!--/#footnote2-2.footnote-->\n       <li id=\"footnote2-3-8034\" class=\"footnote2\"><p>MIT Press Journals: <a href=\"http://www.mitpressjournals.org/doi/10.1162/jocn.2006.18.11.1947\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><em>Neural Bases of Motivated Reasoning: An fMRI Study of Emotional Constraints on Partisan Political Judgment in the 2004 U.S. Presidential Election</em></a><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8034#note2-3-8034\" class=\"footnote2-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n       <!--/#footnote2-3.footnote-->\n       <li id=\"footnote2-4-8034\" class=\"footnote2\"><p>Source: <a href=\"https://news.gallup.com/poll/9910/tobacco-smoking.aspx\" target=\"_blank\" elivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn20@2020_1/2020/08/16/19-24-12-661_ddc4341f63383d6b.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/60.2-prosecutor.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn39@2020_6/2020/08/16/19-24-12-123_d8ee456e760280d3.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/61.1-A-_-B-ATT.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn7@2020_3/2020/08/16/19-24-09-456_2b71ccc4d6828f3e.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/61.2-A-_-B-ATT.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx20/cdn59@2020_1/2020/08/16/19-24-27-058_d84b43e03dfb3a93.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/63.1-real-life-attorneys-full-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn44@2020_2/2020/08/16/19-24-08-541_13a664adeb4727fe.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/64.1-Skepticism-Spectrum-ATT.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn80@2020_3/2020/08/16/19-24-26-068_65ae48b94754ce31.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/64.2-Skepticism-Spectrum-ATT.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn80@2020_6/2020/08/16/19-24-16-685_a726fdabc13c7442.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/65.1-puzzler-building-ATT.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn91@2020_4/2020/08/16/19-24-07-476_41701b08e543b922.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/66.1-A-_-B-constructed-arrow-v2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn16@2020_6/2020/08/16/19-24-24-169_3347e84157f24915.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/67.1-2x2-ATT.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn15@2020_6/2020/08/16/19-24-08-761_94cd067dcfe73bca.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/67.2-2x2-ATT.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn4@2020_1/2020/08/16/19-24-20-121_5ff26bd93fe15b63.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/37.3-mirror-ATT.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx17/cdn71@2020_4/2020/08/16/19-24-06-448_7caf631306923a54.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/69.1-Values-Stack-ZEA-v2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn83@2020_6/2020/08/16/19-23-59-869_7dad626cba2e7697.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/70.1-means-ends-ZEA.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn80@2020_4/2020/08/16/19-23-58-719_53bbc8adb744978e.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.6-ladder-ZEA.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn100@2020_3/2020/08/16/19-24-17-112_d50469892e26991b.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/71.1-ice-skating-nails.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn80@2020_5/2020/08/16/19-24-05-971_8c523be36412b04d.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/72.1-worshipping-B.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn47@2020_1/2020/08/16/19-24-17-498_2c60aabd7e660cdf.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/73.1-Attention-Bouncer-ZEA.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn3@2020_3/2020/08/16/19-24-13-225_60fdceee09600695.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/73.2-dissent-shit-bucket.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn48@2020_2/2020/08/16/19-24-12-720_5d4e9a7f40d6fe55.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/74.1-2x2-ZEA.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx17/cdn31@2020_6/2020/08/16/19-24-01-221_7069b9cfae6abba0.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/75-Recap-Chart.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn99@2020_2/2020/08/16/19-24-07-559_5533183df1a74c4b.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/next-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn43@2020_5/2020/08/16/19-24-05-418_a16f10ba94e67f6c.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-08-17 03:23:54","updatedTime":"2020-08-17 03:23:54","title":"How to Pick a Career (That Actually Fits You)","link":"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6721","description":"<p>Hey readers! Quick note before we jump in:</p> \n<p>This is a post about something I’ve been wanting to write about forever: careers. Society tells us a lot of things about what we should want in a career and what the possibilities are—which is weird because I’m pretty sure society knows very little about any of this. When it comes to careers, society is like your great uncle who traps you at holidays and goes on a 15-minute mostly incoherent unsolicited advice monologue, and you tune out almost the whole time because it’s super clear he has very little idea what he’s talking about and that everything he says is like 45 years outdated. Society is like that great uncle, and conventional wisdom is like his rant. Except in this case, instead of tuning it out, we pay rapt attention to every word, and then we make major career decisions based on what he says. Kind of a weird thing for us to do.</p> \n<p>This post isn’t me giving you career advice really—it’s a framework that I think can help you make career decisions that actually reflect who you are, what you want, and what our rapidly changing career landscape looks like today. You’re not a pro at this, but you’re certainly more qualified to figure out what’s best for you than our collective un-self-aware great uncle. For those of you yet to start your career who aren’t sure what you want to do with their lives, or those of you currently in the middle of your career who aren’t sure you’re on the right path, I hope this post can help you press the reset button on your thought process and get some clarity.</p> \n<p>Finally, it feels very good to put this post up. It’s been way, way too long. The last year has been pretty frustrating for me and anyone who likes Wait But Why—a lot of build-up of ideas with none of the satisfying release of those ideas on the blog (most of my last year has been spent working on another, way longer post). I’m hoping this WBW Dark Ages era is nearing its end, because I miss hanging out here. Thanks, as always, to the small group of ridiculously generous, ridiculously patient patrons who have stuck with us through such a slow period.</p> \n<p>– Tim</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 10pt;\"><em><strong>PDF:</strong> If you want to print this post or read it offline, the PDF is probably the way to go. You can <a href=\"https://gum.co/wbw-career-path\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">buy it here</a>.</em></span></p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">_______</p> \n<h5><span style=\"font-size: 16pt;\"><strong>Your Life Path So Far</strong></span></h5> \n<p>For most of us, childhood is kind of like a river, and we’re kind of like tadpoles.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/river-2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-6780\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/river-2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"761\" height=\"425\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/river-2.png 1357w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/river-2-300x168.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/river-2-768x429.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/river-2-600x335.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 761px) 100vw, 761px\" /></a></p> \n<p>We didn’t choose the river. We just woke up out of nowhere and found ourselves on some path set for us by our parents, by society, and by circumstances. We’re told the rules of the river and the way we should swim and what our goals should be. Our job isn’t to think about our path—it’s to succeed on the path we’ve been placed on, based on the way success has been defined for us.</p> \n<p>For many of us—and I suspect for a large portion of Wait But Why readers—our childhood river then feeds into a pond, called college.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6721#footnote-1-6721\" id=\"note-1-6721\" rel=\"footnote\">1</a> We may have some say in which particular pond we landed in, but in the end, most college ponds aren’t really that different from one another.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/pond-1.png\"><img class=\"wp-image-6781 aligncenter\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/pond-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"673\" height=\"488\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/pond-1.png 1518w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/pond-1-300x217.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/pond-1-768x557.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/pond-1-600x435.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 673px) 100vw, 673px\" /></a></p> \n<p>In the pond, we have a bit more breathing room and some leeway to branch out into more specific interests. We start to ponder, looking out at the pond’s shores—out there where the real world starts and where we’ll be spending the rest of our lives. This usually brings some mixed feelings.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Looking-at-shore-2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-6743\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Looking-at-shore-2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"627\" height=\"456\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Looking-at-shore-2.png 1100w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Looking-at-shore-2-300x218.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Looking-at-shore-2-768x559.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Looking-at-shore-2-600x436.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 627px) 100vw, 627px\" /></a></p> \n<p>And then, 22 years after waking up in a rushing river, we’re kicked out of the pond and told by the world to go make something of our lives.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/shore-1.jpg\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-6732\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/shore-1.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"400\" height=\"427\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/shore-1.jpg 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/shore-1-281x300.jpg 281w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/shore-1-768x819.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/shore-1-563x600.jpg 563w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 400px) 100vw, 400px\" /></a></p> \n<p>There are a few problems here. One is that at that moment, you’re kind of skill-less and knowledge-less and a lot of other things-less:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/shore-2.jpg\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-6733\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/shore-2.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"400\" height=\"427\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/shore-2.jpg 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/shore-2-281x300.jpg 281w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/shore-2-768x819.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/shore-2-563x600.jpg 563w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 400px) 100vw, 400px\" /></a></p> \n<p>But before you can even address your general uselessness, there’s an even bigger issue—your pre-set path ended. Kids in school are kind of like employees of a company where someone else is the CEO. But no one is the CEO of your life in the real world, or of your career path—except you. And you’ve spent your whole life becoming a pro student, leaving you with zero experience as the CEO of anything. Up to now, you’ve only been in charge of the micro decisions—”How do I succeed at my job as a student?”—and now you’re suddenly holding the keys to the macro cockpit as well, tasked with answering stressful macro questions like “Who am I?” and “What are the important things in life?” and “What are my options for paths and which one should I choose and how do I even make a path?” When we leave school for the last time, the macro guidance we’ve become so accustomed to is suddenly whisked away from us, leaving us standing there holding our respective dicks, with no idea how to do this.</p> \n<p>Then time happens. And we end up on a path. And that path becomes our life’s story.</p> \n<p>At the end of our life, when we look back at how things went, we can see our life’s path in its entirety, from an aerial view.</p> \n<p>When scientists study people on their deathbed and how they feel about their lives, they usually find that many of them feel some serious regrets. I think a lot of those regrets stem from the fact that most of us aren’t really taught about path-making in our childhoods, and most of us also don’t get much better at path-making as adults, which leaves many people looking back on a life path that didn’t really make sense, given who they are and the world they lived in.</p> \n<p>So this is a post about path-making. Let’s take a 30-minute pre-deathbed pause to look down at the path we’re on, and ahead at where that path seems to be going, and make sure it makes sense.</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 16pt;\"><strong>The Cook and the Chef—Revisited</strong></span></p> \n<p>In the past, <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2015/11/the-cook-and-the-chef-musks-secret-sauce.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">I’ve written about</a> the critical distinction between “reasoning from first principles” and “reasoning by analogy”—or what I called being a “chef” vs. being a “cook.” Since writing the post, I notice this distinction everywhere, and I’ve thought about it roughly 2 million times in my own life.</p> \n<p>The idea is that reasoning from first principles is reasoning like a scientist. You take core facts and observations and use them to puzzle together a conclusion, kind of like a chef playing around with raw ingredients to try to make them into something good. By doing this puzzling, a chef eventually writes a new recipe. The other kind of reasoning—reasoning by analogy—happens when you look at the way things are already done and you essentially copy it, with maybe a little personal tweak here and there—kind of like a cook following an already written recipe.</p> \n<p>A pure verbatim recipe-copying cook and a pure independently inventive chef are the two extreme ends of what is, of course, a spectrum. But for any particular part of your life that involves reasoning and decision making, wherever you happen to be on the spectrum, your reasoning process can usually be boiled down to fundamentally chef-like or fundamentally cook-like. Creating vs. copying. Originality vs. conformity.</p> \n<p>Being a chef takes a tremendous amount of time and energy—which makes sense, because you’re not trying to reinvent the wheel, you’re trying to invent it for the first time. Puzzling your way to a conclusion feels like navigating a mysterious forest while blindfolded and always involves a whole lot of failure, in the form of trial and error. Being a cook is far easier and more straightforward and less icky. In most situations, being a chef is a terrible waste of time, and comes with a high opportunity cost, since time on Earth is immensely scarce. Right now, I’m wearing J. Crew jeans and a plain t-shirt and a hoodie and Allbirds shoes, because I’m trying to conform. Throughout my life, I’ve looked around at people who seem kind of like me and I’ve bought a bunch of clothes that look like what they wear. And this makes sense—because clothes aren’t important to me, and they’re not how I choose to express my individuality. So in my case, fashion is a perfect part of life to use a reasoning shortcut and be a cook.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6721#footnote-2-6721\" id=\"note-2-6721\" rel=\"footnote\">2</a></p> \n<p>But then there are those parts of life that are really really deeply important—like where you choose to live, or the kinds of friends you choose to make, or whether you want to get married and to whom, or whether you want to have kids and how you want to raise them, or how you set your lifestyle priorities.</p> \n<p>Career-path-carving is definitely one of those really really deeply important things. Let’s spell out the obvious reasons why:</p> \n<p><strong>Time. </strong>For most of us, a career (including ancillary career time, like time spent commuting and thinking about your work) will eat up somewhere between 50,000 and 150,000 hours. At the moment, a long human life runs at about 750,000 hours. When you subtract childhood (~175,000 hours) and the portion of your adult life you’ll spend sleeping, eating, exercising, and otherwise taking care of the human pet you live in, along with errands and general life upkeep (~325,000 hours), you’re left with 250,000 “meaningful adult hours.”<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6721#footnote-3-6721\" id=\"note-3-6721\" rel=\"footnote\">3</a> So a typical career will take up somewhere between 20% and 60% of your meaningful adult time—not something to be a cook about.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Pie-Chart.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-6735\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Pie-Chart.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"713\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Pie-Chart.png 900w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Pie-Chart-253x300.png 253w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Pie-Chart-768x912.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Pie-Chart-505x600.png 505w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a></p> \n<p><strong>Quality of Life. </strong>Your career has a major effect on all the non-career hours as well. For those of us not already wealthy through past earnings, marriage, or inheritance, a career doubles as our means of support. The particulars of your career also often play a big role in determining where you live, how flexible your life is, the kinds of things you’re able to do in your free time, and sometimes even in who you end up marrying.</p> \n<p><strong>Impact. </strong>On top of your career being the way you spend much of your time and the means of support for the rest of your time, your career triples as your primary mode of impact-making. Every human life touches thousands of other lives in thousands of different ways, and all of those lives you alter then go on to touch thousands of lives of their own. We can’t test this, but I’m pretty sure that you can select any 80-year-old alive today, go back in time 80 years, find them as an infant, throw the infant in the trash, and then come back to the present day and find a countless number of things changed. All lives make a large impact on the world and on the future—but the <em>kind</em> of impact you end up making is largely within your control, depending on the values you live by and the places you direct your energy. Whatever shape your career path ends up taking, the world will be altered by it.</p> \n<p><strong>Identity. </strong>In our childhoods, people ask us about our career plans by asking us what we want to <em>be</em> when we grow up. When we grow up, we tell people about our careers by telling them what we <em>are. </em>We don’t say, “I practice law”—we say, “I am a lawyer.” This is probably an unhealthy way to think about careers, but the way many societies are right now, a person’s career quadruples as the person’s primary identity. Which is kind of a big thing.</p> \n<p>So yeah—your career path isn’t like my shitty sweatshirt. It’s really really deeply important, putting it squarely in “Definitely absolutely make sure to be a chef about it” territory.</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 16pt;\"><strong>Your Career Map</strong></span></p> \n<p>Which brings us to you. I don’t know exactly what your deal is. But there’s a good chance you’re somewhere in one of the blue regions—</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Life-path.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-6736\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Life-path.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"293\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Life-path.png 1064w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Life-path-300x117.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Life-path-768x300.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Life-path-600x235.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> \n<p>—which means your career path is a work in progress.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6721#footnote-4-6721\" id=\"note-4-6721\" rel=\"footnote\">4</a></p> \n<p>Whether you’re yet to start your career or well into it, somewhere in the back of your mind (or maybe in the very front of it) is a “Career Plans” map.</p> \n<p>We can group map holders into three broad categories—each of which is well-represented in the river, in the pond, standing on the shore, and at every stage of adult life.</p> \n<p>One group of people will look at the map and see a big, stressful question mark.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/map1.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-6737\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/map1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"349\" height=\"350\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/map1.png 488w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/map1-150x150.png 150w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/map1-300x300.png 300w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 349px) 100vw, 349px\" /></a></p> \n<p>These are people who feel indecisive about their career path. They’ve been told to follow their passion, but they don’t feel especially passionate about anything. They’ve been told to let their strengths guide them, but they’re not sure what they’re best at. They may have felt they had answers in the past, but they’ve changed and they’re no longer sure who they are or where they’re going.<strong> </strong></p> \n<p>Other people will see a nice clear arrow representing a direction they feel confident is right—but find their legs walking in a different direction. They’re living with one of the most common sources of human misery, a career path they know in their heart is wrong.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/map2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-6738\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/map2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"242\" height=\"350\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/map2.png 322w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/map2-207x300.png 207w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 242px) 100vw, 242px\" /></a></p> \n<p>The lucky ones feel they know where they want to go and believe they’re marching in that direction.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/map3.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-6739\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/map3.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"305\" height=\"350\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/map3.png 275w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/map3-261x300.png 261w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 305px) 100vw, 305px\" /></a></p> \n<p>But even these people should pause and ask themselves, “Who actually drew this arrow? Was it really me?” The answer can get confusing.</p> \n<p>I’m pretty sure all of these people would benefit from a moment of career path reflection.</p> \n<div class=\"wbwAside\"> \n <p><span style=\"font-size: 14pt;\"><strong>The Okay But Why Do You Think You Can Help Me With My Career Reflection You Draw Stick Figures for a Living Blue Box</strong></span></p> \n <p>Extremely fair question. One thing I always ask myself as I pick topics to write about is, “Am I qualified to write about this?” Here are the reasons I decided to take on this topic:</p> \n <p>1) I have spent most of the last 20 years in a perpetual state of analyzing my own career path.</p> \n <p>2) My path has taken a lot of turns—from wanting to be a movie star when I was 7 to wanting to be the president when I was 17 to wanting to write film scores when I was 22 to wanting to be an entrepreneur when I was 24 to wanting to write musicals when I was 29 to most recently wanting to be a writer-ish guy.</p> \n <p>3) After being pretty all over the place about my career path for most of my life, I actually love my job now. That’s always subject to change, but being able to look at the decision-making processes that led me to confusing or frustrating places, side by side with the decisions that led me to a more fulfilling place, has offered me some wisdom on where people tend to go wrong.</p> \n <p>4) On top of having my own story to look at, I’ve had a front-row seat for the stories of my dozen or so closest friends. My friends seem to share my career path obsessiveness, so between observing their paths and talking with them about those paths again and again along the way, I’ve broadened my views on the topic, which helps me to distinguish between the lessons that are my-life specific and those that are more universal.</p> \n <p>5) Finally, this isn’t a post about which careers are better or worse than others or which career values are more or less meaningful—there are lots of social scientists and self-help authors out there with good data on that, and I’m not one of them. It’s instead a framework that I think can help a career-path reflector better see their own situation, and what really matters to them, clearly and honestly. This framework has worked really well for me, so I think it can probably be helpful for other people too.</p> \n</div> \n<p>Now that you’ve taken a fresh look at your Career Plans map, along with whatever arrow may or may not be on it, put it down and out of sight. We’ll come back to it at the end of the post. It’s time now for a deep dive—let’s think about this from scratch. From first principles.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">___________</p> \n<p>In the <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2015/11/the-cook-and-the-chef-musks-secret-sauce.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">cook-chef post</a>, I designed a simple framework for how a chef makes major career choices. At its core is a simple Venn diagram.</p> \n<p>The first part of the diagram is the Want Box, which contains all the careers you find desirable.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Want-Box.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-6740\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Want-Box.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"300\" height=\"318\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Want-Box.png 1544w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Want-Box-283x300.png 283w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Want-Box-768x813.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Want-Box-567x600.png 567w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 300px) 100vw, 300px\" /></a></p> \n<p>The second part of the diagram is the Reality Box. The Reality Box is for the set of all careers that are realistic to potentially achieve—based on a comparison, in each case, between your level of potential in an area and the general difficulty of achieving success in that area.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Reality-Box.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-6741\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Reality-Box.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"375\" height=\"304\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Reality-Box.png 1970w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Reality-Box-300x244.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Reality-Box-768x623.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Reality-Box-600x487.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 375px) 100vw, 375px\" /></a></p> \n<p>The overlapping area contains your optimal career path choices—the set of arrows you should consider drawing on your Career Map. We can call it the Option Pool.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/venn.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-6742\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/venn.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"450\" height=\"287\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/venn.png 1586w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/venn-300x191.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/venn-768x490.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/venn-600x383.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 450px) 100vw, 450px\" /></a></p> \n<p>This is straightforward enough. But actually filling in these boxes accurately is way harder than it looks. For the diagram to work, it has to be as close to the truth as possible, and to get there, we have to lift up the hood of our subconscious and head down. Let’s start with the Want Box.</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 24pt;\"><strong>Deep Analysis, Part 1: Your Want Box</strong></span></p> \n<p>The hard thing about the Want Box is that you want a bunch of different things—or, rather, there are a bunch of different sides of you, and each of them wants—and fears—its own stuff. And since some motivations have conflicting interests with others, you cannot, by definition, have everything you want. Going for one thing you want means, by definition, not going for others, and sometimes, it’ll specifically mean going directly <em>against</em> others. The Want Box is a game of compromise.</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 16pt;\"><strong>The Yearning Octopus</strong></span></p> \n<p>To do a proper Want Box audit, you need to think about what you yearn for in a career and then unpack the shit out of it. Luckily, we have someone here who can help us. The Yearning Octopus.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Octopus-1.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-6744\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Octopus-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"514\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Octopus-1.png 1400w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Octopus-1-300x257.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Octopus-1-768x658.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Octopus-1-600x514.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a></p> \n<p>We each have our own personal Yearning Octopus<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6721#footnote-5-6721\" id=\"note-5-6721\" rel=\"footnote\">5</a> in our heads. The particulars of each person’s Yearning Octopus will vary, but people also aren’t all that different from each other, and I bet many of us feel very similar yearnings and fears (especially given that I find that Wait But Why readers tend to have a lot in common).</p> \n<p>The first thing to think about is that there are totally distinct yearning <em>worlds</em>—each living on one tentacle. These tentacles often do not get along with each other.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Octopus-2a.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-6745\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Octopus-2a.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"360\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Octopus-2a.png 1400w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Octopus-2a-300x180.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Octopus-2a-768x461.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Octopus-2a-600x360.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Octopus-2B.png\"><img class=\"aligncenter wp-image-6820\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Octopus-2B.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"682\" height=\"482\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Octopus-2B.png 1377w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Octopus-2B-300x212.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Octopus-2B-768x543.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Octopus-2B-600x424.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 682px) 100vw, 682px\" /></a></p> \n<p>It gets worse. Each tentacle is made up of a bunch of different individual yearnings and their accompanying fears—and <em>these </em>often massively conflict with each other too.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Octopus-3-segmented-1.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-6856\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Octopus-3-segmented-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"670\" height=\"574\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Octopus-3-segmented-1.png 1400w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Octopus-3-segmented-1-300x257.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Octopus-3-segmented-1-768x658.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Octopus-3-segmented-1-600x514.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 670px) 100vw, 670px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Let’s take a closer look at each tentacle to see what’s going on.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/personal-tentacle.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-6748\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/personal-tentacle.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"500\" height=\"494\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/personal-tentacle.png 1214w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/personal-tentacle-300x297.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/personal-tentacle-768x759.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/personal-tentacle-600x593.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 500px) 100vw, 500px\" /></a></p> \n<p>The Personal Yearnings tentacle is probably the hardest one to generalize here—it’s pretty particular to each of us. It’s a reflection of our specific personality and our values, and it bears the burden of probably the most complex and challenging human need: fulfillment. It’s also in the shit dealing with not only our current selves, but a bunch of our past selves too. The dreams of 7-year-old you and the idealized identity of 12-year-old you and the secret hopes of 17-year-old you and the evolving passions of your current self are all somewhere on the personal tentacle, each throwing their own little fit about getting what they want, and each fully ready to make you feel horrible about yourself with their disappointment and disgust if you fail them. On top of that, your fear of death sometimes emerges on the personal tentacle, all needy about you leaving your mark and achieving greatness and all that. The personal tentacle is why you don’t find very many billionaires content to spend the rest of their life sipping cocktails on the beach—it’s a highly needy tentacle.</p> \n<p>And yet, the personal tentacle is also one that often ends up somewhat neglected. Because in many cases, it’s the ickiest set of yearnings to really <em>go</em> for; because the fears of this tentacle aren’t scary in an immediate way—they creep in out of the background over time; and because the personal tentacle is always at risk of getting bowled over early in your career by the powerful animal emotions of the other tentacles. This neglect can leave a person with major regrets later on once the dust settles. An unfulfilled Personal Yearnings tentacle is often the explanation, for example, behind a very successful, very unhappy person—who may believe they got successful in the wrong field.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/social-tentacle.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-6749\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/social-tentacle.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"500\" height=\"459\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/social-tentacle.png 1218w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/social-tentacle-300x275.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/social-tentacle-768x704.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/social-tentacle-600x550.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 500px) 100vw, 500px\" /></a></p> \n<p>The Social Yearnings tentacle is probably our most primitive, animal side, with its core drive stemming back to our tribal evolutionary past. On the tentacle are a number of odd creatures.</p> \n<p>As we’ve discussed <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2014/06/taming-mammoth-let-peoples-opinions-run-life.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">before</a> on this blog, we all have a Social Survival Mammoth living in our heads who’s earth-shatteringly obsessed with what other people think of us. This means he craves acceptance and inclusion and being well-liked, while likewise being petrified of embarrassment, negative judgment, and disapproval. He really really really wants to be in the in-group and he really really really doesn’t want to be in the outgroup. He’s <a href=\"https://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861-wpengine.netdna-ssl.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/Mammoth1.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">quite cute</a> though.</p> \n<p>Then there’s your ego, who’s a similar character but even more needy. Your ego doesn’t just want to be accepted; it wants to be admired, desired, and fawned upon—ideally, on a mass scale. More upsetting to it than being disliked is being ignored. It wants to be relevant and important and widely known.</p> \n<p>There are other characters milling about as well. Somewhere else on the social tentacle is a little judge with a little gavel who gets very butthurt if it thinks people aren’t judging you fairly—if you’re not appropriately appreciated. It’s very important to the judge that people are aware of exactly how smart and talented you think you are. The judge is also big on holding grudges—which is the reason a lot of people are driven more than anything by a desire to <em>show</em> that person or those people who never believed in them.</p> \n<p>Finally, some of us may find a loving little dog on our social tentacle who wants more than anything in the world to please its owner, and who just cannot bear the thought of disappointing them. The one problem with this adorable creature is that its owner isn’t you. It’s a person with so much psychological power over you that, if you’re not careful, you may dedicate your whole career to trying to please them and make them proud. (It’s probably a parent.)</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/lifestyle-tentacle.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-6750\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/lifestyle-tentacle.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"500\" height=\"522\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/lifestyle-tentacle.png 1079w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/lifestyle-tentacle-287x300.png 287w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/lifestyle-tentacle-768x802.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/lifestyle-tentacle-574x600.png 574w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 500px) 100vw, 500px\" /></a></p> \n<p>The Lifestyle Yearnings tentacle mostly just wants Tuesday to be a good day. But like, a really pleasant, enjoyable day—with plenty of free time and self-care and relaxation and luxuries.</p> \n<p>It’s also concerned with your life in the big picture being as great as possible—as far as your lifestyle tentacle is concerned, you should be able to do what you want to do in life, when and how you want to do it, with the people you like most. Life should be full of fun times and rich experiences, but it should also roll by smoothly, without too much hard work and as few bumps in the road as possible.</p> \n<p>The issue is, even if you place a high priority on your lifestyle yearnings, it’s pretty difficult to keep the whole tentacle happy at the same time. The part of the tentacle that just wants to sit around and relax will hold you back from sweating to build the kind of career that offers long-term flexibility and the kind of wealth that can make life luxurious and cushy and full of toys. The part of the tentacle that only feels comfortable when the future feels predictable will reject the exact kinds of paths that may generate the long-term freedom another part of the tentacle longs for. The side of you that wants a stress-free life doesn’t get along very well with the side of you that thirsts to be hang gliding off a cliff in Namibia like Richard Branson.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/moral-tentacle-1.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-6846\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/moral-tentacle-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"847\" height=\"726\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/moral-tentacle-1.png 1400w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/moral-tentacle-1-300x257.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/moral-tentacle-1-768x658.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/moral-tentacle-1-600x514.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 847px) 100vw, 847px\" /></a></p> \n<p>The Moral Yearnings tentacle thinks the rest of the tentacles of your Yearning Octopus are a real pack of dicks—each one more self-involved and self-indulgent than the next. The parts of you on the moral tentacle look around and see a big world that needs so much fixing; they see billions of people no less worthy than you of a good life who just happened to be born into inferior circumstances; they see an uncertain future ahead that hangs in the balance between utopia and dystopia for life on Earth—a future we can actually push in the right direction if we could only get our other tentacles out of our way. While the other tentacles fantasize about what you would do with your life if you had a billion dollars in the bank, the moral tentacle fantasizes about the kind of impact you could make if you had a billion dollars to <em>deploy</em>.</p> \n<p>Needless to say, the other tentacles of your Yearning Octopus find the moral tentacle to be insufferable. They also can’t begin to understand philanthropy for philanthropy’s sake—they think, “Other people aren’t me, so why would I spend my time and energy working to help them?”—but they <em>can </em>understand philanthropy for their own motive’s sake. While the moral and lifestyle tentacles tend to be in direct conflict, others may sometimes find common ground—the social tentacle can get very into philanthropy if it’ll happen to win you respect and admiration from a highly regarded social group, and some people’s personal tentacle may find the meaning or self-worth it so craves in a philanthropic endeavor.</p> \n<p>That’s why, when you do something philanthropic—or anything altruistic, really—there are a few separate things going on in your head. The part of you <em>determined </em>to get proper public credit for the deed lives on your social tentacle; the part of you that thinks “God I’m a good person” lives on your personal tentacle; and the part of you that really loves seeing the person or group you helped be better off lives on your moral tentacle. Likewise, <em>not </em>doing anything for others can hurt you on multiple tentacles—the moral tentacle because it feels guilty and sad, the social tentacle because this may cause others to judge you as a selfish or greedy person, and the personal tentacle because it may lower your self-esteem.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/practical-tentacle.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-6752\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/practical-tentacle.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"500\" height=\"437\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/practical-tentacle.png 1214w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/practical-tentacle-300x262.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/practical-tentacle-768x672.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/practical-tentacle-600x525.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 500px) 100vw, 500px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Your Practical Yearnings tentacle thinks all of this is fine and great—but it would also like to point out that it’s March 31st and your rent is due tomorrow, and the funny thing about that is that it logged into your bank account and saw that the number of dollars in it is actually less than the number of dollars that your landlord will need from you sometime in the next 34 hours. And yeah it knows that you deposited that check on Thursday and that it’s supposed to clear tomorrow morning, but your practical tentacle also could have sworn that just last month, all the tentacles promised that they’d make some sacrifices in order to build up at least a little bank account cushion so that simply paying the rent wouldn’t have to be really fucking stressful every month. Your practical tentacle also can’t help but notice that your social tentacle offered to buy a round of drinks for all nine people you went to the bar with last Saturday so those people would think of you as a classy, generous person, and that your lifestyle tentacle chose to rent what sure seems like a pretty nice-ass apartment for someone now living check to check, and that the updates have gotten real quiet from your friend about that bagel delivery service he started six months ago that your moral tentacle happily invested $2,500 in to help it get off the ground, and oh also that meanwhile your personal tentacle has everyone sweating their dick off working at two comedy-writing internships simultaneously that somehow manage to bring in less money combined than you made dressing up as an Egyptian enchantress to wait tables at Jekyll &amp; Hyde sophomore year of college.</p> \n<p>At its basic level, your practical tentacle wants to make sure you can eat food and wear clothes and buy the medicine you need and not live outside. It doesn’t really care how these things happen—it just wants them to happen. But then everyone else on the octopus makes your practical tentacle’s life super hard by being fucky about things. Every time your income goes up, your lifestyle tentacle decides to raise the bar on what it wants and expects, leaving your practical tentacle continually in the shit trying to cover it all so you don’t have to run up your credit card debt. Your personal tentacle has all of these weird needs that take up a lot of time and more often than not aren’t exactly big money-makers. And while your practical tentacle would be totally down to just ask your rich uncle for money to help out, your social tentacle outlawed asking others for money because “it’s not a good look,” with your personal tentacle chiming in that “yeah, we’re better than that.”</p> \n<p>So that’s the situation. You’ve got this Yearning Octopus in your head with five tentacles (or however many yours has), each with their own agenda, that often conflict with each other. Then there are the distinct individual yearnings on each tentacle, often in conflict amongst themselves. And if that weren’t enough, you sometimes have furious internal conflict inside a <em>single</em> yearning. Like when your desire to pursue your passion can’t figure out what it’s most passionate about.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Passion-argument.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-6753\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Passion-argument.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"500\" height=\"482\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Passion-argument.png 999w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Passion-argument-300x289.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Passion-argument-768x741.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Passion-argument-600x579.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 500px) 100vw, 500px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Or when you want so badly to be respected, but then you remember that a career that wins the undying respect of one segment of society will always receive shrugs from other segments and even contemptuous eye rolls from other segments still.</p> \n<p>Or when you decide to satisfy your urge to help others, before realizing that the part of you that wants to dedicate your life to helping to mitigate humanity’s greatest existential risks has palpable disdain for the part of you that would rather make a tangible positive impact on your local community—while the part of you that can’t stand the thought of the millions of today’s humans without access to clean water finds both of those other yearnings to be pretty cold and heartless.</p> \n<p>So yeah, your Yearning Octopus is complicated. And no human in history has ever satisfied their entire octopus—that’s why you’ll never find it fully smiling. Human yearning is a game of choices and sacrifices and compromise.</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 16pt;\"><strong>Dissecting the Octopus</strong></span></p> \n<p>With that in mind, let’s return to your Want Box. When we think about our career goals and fears and hopes and dreams, our consciousness is just accessing the net output of the Yearning Octopus—which is usually made up of its loudest voices. Only by digging into our mind’s subconscious can we see what’s really going on.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6721#footnote-6-6721\" id=\"note-6-6721\" rel=\"footnote\">6</a></p> \n<p>The cool thing is that we all have the ability to do that. The stuff in your subconscious is like stuff in the basement of a house. It’s not off-limits to us—it’s just in the basement. We can go look at it anytime—we just have to A) remember that the house has a basement, and B) actually spend the time and energy to go down there, even though going down there might suck.</p> \n<p>So let’s head to the basement of your mind to look for the octopus. Unless you’re one of those people who’s really practiced at analyzing your subconscious, it might be dark in the basement, making it hard to see your octopus. The way to start turning the lights on is by identifying what your conscious mind currently knows about your yearnings and fears, and then unpacking it.</p> \n<p>Like if there’s a certain career path that sounds fantastic to you, unpack that. Which tentacles in particular are yearning for that career—and which specific parts of those tentacles?</p> \n<p>If you’re not currently working towards that career you supposedly yearn for, try to figure out why not.
