My goal for the future isn’t to avoid mistakes, it’s for the mistakes I do make to be my own.</p> \n<p>That’s why I went through such an excruciatingly rigorous analysis in this post. I think this is one of those few topics in life that’s worth it. Other voices will never stop fiercely trying to live your life for you—you owe it to that little insecure character in the very center of your consciousness to get this right.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">___________</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: left;\">If you’re into Wait But Why, sign up for the <strong><a class=\"ClickPico PicoRule\">Wait But Why email list</a></strong> and we’ll send you the new posts right when they come out. That’s the only thing we use the list for—and since my posting schedule isn’t exactly…regular…this is the best way to stay up-to-date with WBW posts.</p> \n<p>And if you want to download this post for printing and offline sharing, you can <a href=\"https://gum.co/wbw-career-path\">buy it here</a>.</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 14pt;\"><strong>For help analyzing your situation:</strong></span></p> \n<p><strong>Some paper to write on:</strong> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/WORKSHEET-octopus-1.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Your octopus</a>. <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/WORKSHEET-yearning-hierarchy-1.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Your priority shelf</a>. <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/WORKSHEET-A-star-1.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Some path distances</a>. <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/WORKSHEET-career-dot-map.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Your career dot map</a>.</p> \n<p><strong>For those who want to dig in even further:</strong> Alicia (WBW Manager of Lots of Things) has put together <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/WBW_Career-Path_Worksheet.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">a more involved group of worksheets</a>.</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 14pt;\"><strong>For further exploration:</strong></span></p> \n<p>The site <a href=\"https://80000hours.org/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">80,000 hours</a>—dedicated to helping young, high-potential people make big career choices—is an awesome resource. The site is run by super smart, thoughtful, forward-thinking people, and can be digested in <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iY5Vd4LH1J4&amp;list=PL-BRtcBm4Yj6ZpOG49cbHut0gtuCEVXfk&amp;index=2\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">video</a> or <a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/80-000-Hours-fulfilling-career-ebook/dp/B01M70QISP/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">book</a> format in addition to on their site.</p> \n<p>I’ve been reading <a href=\"http://sethgodin.typepad.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Seth Godin’s blog</a> for years. Seth has a lot of wisdom in his head, and he doles it out in little bite-sized nuggets each morning on his blog (which I receive by email). A lot of Seth’s advice applies to career choices. <a href=\"http://sethgodin.typepad.com/seths_blog/2013/07/people-like-us-do-stuff-like-this.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Here’s an example</a> (which I adapted into one of the cartoons in this post).</p> \n<p>Eric Barker’s <a href=\"https://www.bakadesuyo.com\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">blog</a> is full of actual data that can help with career choices, like <a href=\"https://www.bakadesuyo.com/2014/08/fulfilling-career/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">this post</a> on what makes a career fulfilling or <a href=\"https://www.bakadesuyo.com/2014/02/mentor/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">this one</a> on the importance of mentors.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">___________</p> \n<p><span style=\"font-size: 16pt;\"><strong>More Wait But Why human deep dives:</strong></span></p> \n<p><a class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n  <!--/#footnote-8.footnote-->\n  <li id=\"footnote-9-6721\" class=\"footnote\"><p>Or totally paralyze you and ruin your happiness!<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6721#note-9-6721\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n  <!--/#footnote-9.footnote-->\n  <li id=\"footnote-10-6721\" class=\"footnote\"><p><a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Venn\">John Venn</a> really pulled something off here. A Venn diagram is the most obvious possible kind of diagram, and somehow, John Venn convinced everyone he invented it. And this is despite <em>openly saying </em>he didn’t invent it<em>. </em>Venn explains: “I began at once somewhat more steady work on the subjects and books which I should have to lecture on. I now first hit upon the diagrammatical device of representing propositions by inclusive and exclusive circles. <strong>Of course the device was not new then,</strong> but it was so obviously representative of the way in which any one, who approached the subject from the mathematical side, would attempt to visualize propositions, that it was forced upon me almost at once.”<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6721#note-10-6721\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n  <!--/#footnote-10.footnote-->\n  <li id=\"footnote-11-6721\" class=\"footnote\"><p>This spectrum, of course, is also highly relevant in relationships.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=6721#note-11-6721\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n  <!--/#footnote-11.footnote-->\n Urban","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/river-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn12@2020_2/2020/08/16/19-23-59-955_a1fa73c82a295efc.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/pond-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn67@2020_3/2020/08/16/19-24-08-942_97edf08b8ec17b01.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Looking-at-shore-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn44@2020_1/2020/08/16/19-24-27-615_ed3d2a27007ad09b.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/shore-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn56@2020_6/2020/08/16/19-24-07-636_95bad97904978aa9.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/shore-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn63@2020_4/2020/08/16/19-24-21-381_08cfa5bb3f721d19.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Pie-Chart.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn71@2020_2/2020/08/16/19-23-57-165_cec0d481191882a5.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Life-path.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn15@2020_6/2020/08/16/19-24-18-240_d5117719b8a92374.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/map1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn28@2020_1/2020/08/16/19-24-11-782_01994150dcb39911.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/map2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx20/cdn43@2020_4/2020/08/16/19-24-10-764_04ab5f059992846f.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/map3.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn99@2020_5/2020/08/16/19-24-00-763_6949484982991ef7.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Want-Box.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn3@2020_5/2020/08/16/19-24-19-132_8a175a2869d712ff.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Reality-Box.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn32@2020_1/2020/08/16/19-24-04-200_118eb467ff5bbef8.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/venn.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn56@2020_6/2020/08/16/19-24-26-821_3cee2207659cff99.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Octopus-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn27@2020_6/2020/08/16/19-24-13-387_e4a53e1bf37e18be.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Octopus-2a.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn72@2020_6/2020/08/16/19-24-05-405_3d88c9f90241f78d.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Octopus-2B.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx20/cdn43@2020_4/2020/08/16/19-24-01-421_7a97236ae72a3194.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Octopus-3-segmented-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn80@2020_2/2020/08/16/19-24-15-234_34f93c282a2d0b5b.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/personal-tentacle.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn75@2020_3/2020/08/16/19-23-57-334_c79537e6b8dd8d80.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/social-tentacle.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn8@2020_2/2020/08/16/19-23-57-829_cd9f409e372482b7.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/lifestyle-tentacle.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn91@2020_6/2020/08/16/19-23-59-057_346fe25069115d5e.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/moral-tentacle-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn71@2020_1/2020/08/16/19-24-26-825_63f6bf25275d5648.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/practical-tentacle.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn96@2020_1/2020/08/16/19-24-16-823_c075c2ca119a4e83.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Passion-argument.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn12@2020_4/2020/08/16/19-24-14-903_cb8e6e23b7283543.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/mask-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn60@2020_2/2020/08/16/19-24-04-311_b954c1dde84a70cc.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/mask-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn48@2020_3/2020/08/16/19-24-02-351_ed2f1dd2d703ec29.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/mask-3.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn28@2020_6/2020/08/16/19-24-05-945_26b2962b1ae99483.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/mask-4.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn84@2020_1/2020/08/16/19-24-08-441_b3c96660b03258d0.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/mask-5-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn63@2020_6/2020/08/16/19-24-13-941_c1009d40454b59de.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/mask-6.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx20/cdn19@2020_3/2020/08/16/19-24-12-163_961b58e93577f0a9.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/mask-7.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn12@2020_5/2020/08/16/19-24-13-196_09f334a53ffcc97b.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/mask-8-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx17/cdn95@2020_4/2020/08/16/19-24-25-137_2ccaef139155034c.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/roller-coaster-1-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn87@2020_4/2020/08/16/19-24-06-987_72fcb6bc124641ac.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/denial-prison-1-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn91@2020_6/2020/08/16/19-24-17-249_d9d1f3e517dc53a4.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/denial-prison-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn28@2020_1/2020/08/16/19-24-10-753_80bcebe3ff0f87ba.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/yearning-hierarchy-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx17/cdn87@2020_1/2020/08/16/19-24-02-663_c2495df2d14598de.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/octopus-no-bones-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn87@2020_1/2020/08/16/19-24-00-796_83f0187f73d13258.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/A-star-1-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn24@2020_2/2020/08/16/19-24-26-416_d3108e18032c0428.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/A-star-2-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn64@2020_4/2020/08/16/19-24-27-679_ebe389e68a36c5c6.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/A-star-3-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn96@2020_3/2020/08/16/19-24-27-086_221a74abc1ffb8d8.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/A-star-4-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn68@2020_3/2020/08/16/19-24-25-181_78ca3d973866ab0c.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/Chef-Strategy-Loop-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx20/cdn83@2020_2/2020/08/16/19-24-26-103_44b320e7195a27f8.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/venn-1.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn88@2020_5/2020/08/16/19-23-59-107_20093899860b6856.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/roller-coaster-2-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn43@2020_1/2020/08/16/19-24-13-812_059e23fa6cc676d0.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/tunnels-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn24@2020_1/2020/08/16/19-24-19-385_a5bb19bc52adde8f.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/opportunity-cost-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn28@2020_1/2020/08/16/19-24-01-281_3cbb79b3992778f2.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/inertia-spectrum.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn91@2020_5/2020/08/16/19-23-58-259_eed0938b80ef36bf.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/venn-with-loops-small.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn95@2020_2/2020/08/16/19-24-03-945_c24620ec06da4ad5.webp","https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/04/venn-with-big-loop-small.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn79@2020_5/2020/08/16/19-24-20-733_78c2f633a3d1208d.webp"}},{"createdTime":"2020-08-17 03:23:54","updatedTime":"2020-08-17 03:23:54","title":"Political Disney World","link":"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422","description":"<p style=\"font-size:18px\"><em>This is Chapter 9 in a blog series. If you’re new to the series, visit the </em><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/story-of-us\"><strong><em>series home page</em></strong></a><em> for the full table of contents.</em></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Notes-Key-v2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-7518\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Notes-Key-v2.png\" alt=\"Notes key: Type 1 - fun notes. Fun facts, extra thoughts, or further explanation. Type 2 - less fun notes. Sources and citations.\" width=\"402\" height=\"126\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Notes-Key-v2.png 850w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Notes-Key-v2-300x94.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Notes-Key-v2-768x241.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/Notes-Key-v2-600x188.png 600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 402px) 100vw, 402px\" /></a></p> \n<p style=\"font-size:24px;text-align:center\" class=\"wbwFont\">Part 4: Politics, in 3D</p> \n<div style=\"height:38px\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"wp-block-spacer\"></div> \n<p style=\"text-align:center\"><em>“Knowledge of human nature is the beginning and end of political education.” –</em> Henry Adams</p> \n<div style=\"height:38px\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"wp-block-spacer\"></div> \n<p style=\"font-size:19px;text-align:center\" class=\"wbwFont\">Chapter 9: Political Disney World</p> \n<div style=\"height:38px\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"wp-block-spacer\"></div> \n<p>I grew up in Newton, Massachusetts in the 80s and 90s.&nbsp;Newton back then was a pretty diverse place—a 90,000-person suburb with a wide range of ethnic, religious, and socioeconomic backgrounds. To live in Newton, there were only two requirements: you had to be a Red Sox fan and you had to be a Democrat. I was both, so things were chill.</p> \n<p>When I was six, my second-grade classroom voted on the 1988 presidential election by&nbsp;circling either “Michael Dukakis” or “George Bush” on a little sheet of paper, folding it, and placing it into a shoebox on the teacher’s desk. It was the first time I had been sentient for a big political event.&nbsp;Later that day, the teacher revealed the results:</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\"><strong>Dukakis 20, Bush 1</strong></p> \n<p>Duh. Dukakis was the nice good guy candidate and Bush was the bad guy candidate. I still don’t know who the one sick fuck was who voted for the bad guy, but other than that, the results made sense. Pretty boring.</p> \n<p>Then the actual election happened and—somehow—<em>Bush won</em>.</p> \n<p>I was floored. What kind of medieval shit did my country just pull? How could so many people have gotten it so obviously wrong?</p> \n<p>I assumed when I was older and understood the world better, it would make more sense.</p> \n<p>But I got older, and the storyline stayed the same. There was the Obviously Good Party, who cared about poor people and black people and flowers and smiles—and the Obviously Bad Party, who were all these two men, teaching their sons about offshore bank accounts.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/1-watch-ad.jpg\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8427 size-medium\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/1-watch-ad-600x400.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"400\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/1-watch-ad-600x400.jpg 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/1-watch-ad-768x512.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/1-watch-ad-750x500.jpg 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/1-watch-ad-103x70.jpg 103w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/1-watch-ad.jpg 1425w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a></p> \n<p>And every election, the vote would split very near 50/50. I figured there really just were a lot of bad people in my country. Shame.</p> \n<p>Then I went to college. It was 2000. Bush-Gore year. While everyone I grew up with was obviously rooting as hard as possible for Gore to win, it began to dawn on me that I&nbsp;had made a very strange group of new friends in college. Some of them were rooting for Gore, but they hated certain things about his beliefs. Others disliked&nbsp;<em>both&nbsp;</em>candidates. And some of them were fervently rooting for&nbsp;<em>Bush,&nbsp;</em>even though they had previously seemed like reasonable people.</p> \n<p>I knew exactly where I stood, of course, and made my opinion clear. When I explained that I was unquestionably voting for Gore, instead of giving me a high five, my friends asked me why. I had all kinds of explanations, but when they’d push me to&nbsp;talk in specifics, I’d run into a problem.</p> \n<p>I didn’t really know the specifics.</p> \n<p>I knew Gore was&nbsp;the better choice, just like I knew the Democratic Party was the better party—but when pressed about my underlying reasons for liking any specific policy of Gore’s,&nbsp;I’d end up in an uncomfortable place.</p> \n<p><strong><em>Gore will be much better for the poor.</em></strong></p> \n<p><em>Why?</em></p> \n<p><strong><em>Because he&nbsp;won’t cut taxes for the rich as much and&nbsp;there will be more money for social programs.</em></strong></p> \n<p><em>Which social programs are you talking about? What about them do you think has worked well? Why are you so sure increased government spending on those programs is the best way to help the poor? And why are you so confident that tax cuts for the rich don’t end up positively affecting poor people?</em></p> \n<p><strong><em>Um well Gore will be better for the environment.&nbsp;</em></strong></p> \n<p><em>How so?</em></p> \n<p><strong><em>He talks about it more and seems to care about it more.</em></strong></p> \n<p><em>Right but what kinds of policies do you hope he’ll put in place that Bush won’t? And do you think government regulations or incentives will accomplish more than a market solution like a carbon tax?</em></p> \n<p>Well fucking shit. When continually pressed, my underlying reasoning for my positions would always seem to boil down to some combination of, “Because that’s what seems intuitive to me based on what everyone I know has always said” and “Because&nbsp;the Democrats are the good guys”.</p> \n<p>Being challenged by people who didn’t agree with me made me realize I didn’t actually <em>know</em> anything—I just strongly <em>believed</em>&nbsp;a bunch of things.</p> \n<p>I didn’t know anything because I hadn’t ever needed to know anything to feel like I had all the answers, and I hadn’t ever been interested enough in the workings of government to put in the serious effort to truly understand it. All I knew was how to articulate the beliefs I assumed were right, in a pretty surface way.</p> \n<p>I had always thought of myself as a well-educated thinker, an independent thinker, and a thinker whose opinions were based on evidence and facts—but freshman year, I was smacked over the head with the truth about myself. When it came to politics, at least, I wasn’t really a thinker at all.</p> \n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">___________</p> \n<p>If I had to describe politics in modern societies, I’d say it’s—how should I put this—it’s a fucking nightmare. It’s just awful, for basically everyone. It makes us angry. It makes us anxious. It makes us hateful. It makes us our worst selves.</p> \n<p>But why?</p> \n<p>Politics is just the domain of how people live and work and make decisions together, which on its face seems like a fascinating puzzle—a joint project each society works on together, for all of their benefit. Sure, it’s contentious and involves competition and disagreement, but there are a lot of worlds like that that aren’t a fucking nightmare and don’t consistently bring out our worst selves: science, sports, tech, entrepreneurship, and the arts, to name a few. What is it about politics that makes it so much more miserable than all of those other vibrant centers of human development?</p> \n<p>Let’s pull out our tools and discuss.</p> \n<p class=\"has-large-font-size\"><strong>Politics, in 2D</strong></p> \n<p>I don’t know about other countries, but the entire U.S. talks about politics as if it’s one-dimensional:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/2-political-spectrum.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8426\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/2-political-spectrum.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"103\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/2-political-spectrum.png 1360w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/2-political-spectrum-600x83.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/2-political-spectrum-768x106.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/2-political-spectrum-750x103.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> \n<p>In this chapter, let’s try looking at politics in 2D instead. We spent <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/09/thinking-ladder.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Chapter 7</a> talking about the <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/15.6-ladder-ZEA.png\">Thinking Ladder</a>. What would a Political Ladder look like?</p> \n<div class=\"wbwAside\"> \n <h3>The Probably Time For a Refresher Blue Box</h3> \n <p>We started this series by defining what I see as two fundamental elements of the human psyche.</p> \n <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/2.1-PM-HM.png\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8659\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/2.1-PM-HM.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"899\" height=\"736\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/2.1-PM-HM.png 899w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/2.1-PM-HM-600x491.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/2.1-PM-HM-768x629.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/2.1-PM-HM-750x614.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 899px) 100vw, 899px\" /></a></p> \n <p>I call them “minds,” but really, they just represent two states a person (or group of people) can be in. When the Primitive Mind is in control in our minds, we’re often not being our best selves, not making very good choices, and not especially self-aware about what we’re doing or why. When the Higher Mind is in control, we’re being more of a grown-up. It’s not binary though—it’s more of a tug-of-war between the two states. The tug-of-war ebbs and flows in each of us and often, we’re somewhere in the middle.</p> \n <p>The Psych Spectrum is our way of visualizing the state of this tug-of-war. When the Higher Mind has a strong presence in our heads, we’re higher up on the spectrum. When the Higher Mind’s voice gets lost in the fog of a riled up Primitive Mind, we sink lower down on the spectrum.</p> \n <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/2.2-Psych-Spectrum.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8660 \" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/2.2-Psych-Spectrum-264x600.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"292\" height=\"664\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/2.2-Psych-Spectrum-264x600.png 264w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/2.2-Psych-Spectrum-768x1745.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/2.2-Psych-Spectrum-330x750.png 330w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/2.2-Psych-Spectrum.png 972w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 292px) 100vw, 292px\" /></a></p> \n <p>I find that when I’m thinking about any What of life—what we do, what we say, what we think—things make a lot more sense once I bring the Psych Spectrum into my thought process. The ladder is our way of doing this visually. If we simplify any What of life so we can represent its possibilities on a one-dimensional, horizontal spectrum, we can then slap the Psych Spectrum onto it as a vertical y-axis. The resulting <em>square</em> forces us to add another dimension to our thinking and reconsider the What of life alongside the question, “but how is the Psych Spectrum affecting what’s happening here?”</p> \n <p>I call the square a ladder because thinking of it in terms of rungs focuses the discussion in on the Psych Spectrum, which is the skill I want us to gain in this series.</p> \n <p>To define the rungs of any ladder, we need to start by asking ourselves how the Higher and Primitive Minds “do” that part of life. This defines the y-axis’s two extremes. Each person, in thinking about their own psyche, might define it a little differently. When it comes to our intellectual lives, I see the Higher Mind as motivated to seek truth (because that’s the rational thing to want) and the Primitive Mind as motivated to confirm what it already believes (because that was the best way for a human to survive 50,000 years ago). My specific definition of each rung of the resulting Thinking Ladder is derived from those two definitions (I call the Thinking Ladder’s y-axis the “How You Think” axis for clarity—but it’s really just “the Psych Spectrum, as it applies to thinking”):</p> \n <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/2.3-thinking-ladder.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8661\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/2.3-thinking-ladder.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"850\" height=\"737\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/2.3-thinking-ladder.png 1860w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/2.3-thinking-ladder-600x520.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/2.3-thinking-ladder-768x666.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/2.3-thinking-ladder-750x650.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 850px) 100vw, 850px\" /></a></p> \n</div> \n<p>So what would a Political Ladder look like?</p> \n<p>It’s a little more complicated than the Thinking Ladder. A huge element of politics is “political thinking,” and for that element, we could just use the Thinking Ladder. But politics also involves <em>action. </em>To bring this element in, we should also ask ourselves: What would the Higher Mind and Primitive Mind’s political <em>goals</em> be?</p> \n<p>Everyone can take their own crack at this, but here’s mine: The political goal of the grown up, rational, universal-thinking Higher Mind is to build <em>a more perfect nation</em>. And the political goal of the ancient, survival-obsessed, Power-Games-playing Primitive Mind is <em>political triumph </em>against the bad guys, whomever they may be. A discussion of politics should incorporate both political thinking and political activism:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/3.2-y-axes-v4.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8674\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/3.2-y-axes-v4.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"650\" height=\"603\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/3.2-y-axes-v4.png 1400w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/3.2-y-axes-v4-600x556.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/3.2-y-axes-v4-768x712.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/3.2-y-axes-v4-750x695.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 650px) 100vw, 650px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Using two political ladders in this post would be terribly cumbersome, and also pretty redundant. I’m sure there are instances when someone is simultaneously at different y-axis positions when it comes to their political thinking and activism… but you know people—most of them will be in a similar place on both. So to simplify, we’ll combine these into a single Political Ladder.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/3.3-political-ladder-1.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8662\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/3.3-political-ladder-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1000\" height=\"831\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/3.3-political-ladder-1.png 2018w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/3.3-political-ladder-1-600x498.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/3.3-political-ladder-1-768x638.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/3.3-political-ladder-1-750x623.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px\" /></a></p> \n<p>With our view of politics now in 2D,<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#footnote-1-8422\" id=\"note-1-8422\" rel=\"footnote\">1</a> we can return to our question: Why is politics such a nightmare?</p> \n<p>The answer: The Political Ladder is <em>bottom-heavy.<a id=\"bottom-heavy\"></a></em></p> \n<p style=\"font-size:32px\"><strong>Bottom-Heavy Topics</strong></p> \n<p>Religion, like most things human, exists all up and down the Psych Spectrum. At the top, you’ll find people who think about religion as a set of cultural traditions, as a basis for community, as a moral framework, even as an enticing set of possibilities for the unknown. Every single major religious text has high-minded ideas in it, and every single major religion includes millions of high-minded members—those whose religious adherence isn’t mutually exclusive with, but right in line with, top-rung intellectual and moral thought. Religion, when done the Higher Mind’s way, is a lovely thing.</p> \n<p>And in each case, as you work your way down the Psych Spectrum, high-minded conceptions of religious culture, community, and philosophy morph into complete and utter zealotry, tribalism, delusion, and depravity, as they’re transferred from the Higher Mind’s domain into the clutches of the Primitive Mind.</p> \n<p>What makes religion a major cause of some of the largest, most intense Echo Chambers isn’t that religious thinking spans the Psych Spectrum—most topics do—it’s that the distribution is bottom-heavy. For every deeply religious person thinking about religion from the high rungs, there are even more people down below. Some reasons why:</p> \n<ul> \n <li>Religion involves beliefs about death, sex, morality, and almost every other topic the Primitive Mind cares about. Beliefs about eternal life, in particular, match up perfectly with the core end goal of animal genes.</li> \n <li>Religion is faith-based, and at least with its conceptions of what happens after death, inherently untestable—i.e. unfalsifiable.</li> \n <li>Religion is a topic that identities like to attach themselves to. People don’t <em>follow</em> Christianity or <em>believe in</em> Christianity or <em>live by the philosophies of</em> Christianity—people <em>are </em>Christians.</li> \n <li>Religion lends itself perfectly to a tribal, Us/Them worldview. Not only are you an X, but <em>other people are a Y</em>, and if Y religion is true, it would mean your religion is not true.</li> \n <li>Most religions are based on books written long ago, by people whose Higher Minds had much less access to knowledge and advanced moral wisdom than we do today.</li> \n</ul> \n<p>So it makes sense that religion would rile up our Primitive Minds and damn religion to eternal Psych Spectrum bottom-heaviness.</p> \n<p>And if I had grown up in a religious Echo Chamber—and if I were surrounded by religious dogmatists in my life today—and if my country were currently being torn apart by religion—then I might have decided to write a big post series about religion. Instead, I wrote one about politics.</p> \n<p>Like religion, politics is a pro at igniting our primitive fires.</p> \n<p>The Primitive Mind mistakes politics, like it does religion, for a life-and-death situation. This makes sense, because in the ancient world where the Primitive Mind still thinks it lives, politics <em>was</em> a life-or-death game. For almost everyone who lived before the Enlightenment, and still for many people in today’s world, being on the losing end of the game of politics put you in grave danger at the hands of your enemies. And being on the winning side meant having the power to vanquish those enemies. If politics went wrong, nothing else mattered—you were fucked.</p> \n<p>It’s not that today’s politics no longer deals with critical life factors like freedom, safety, fairness, and resources—it’s that today, in a country like the U.S., the <em>stakes</em> in each of those games are far lower than they were in ancient times. Modern politics is about whether taxes should be higher or lower—not about which people should have food during a period of low resources and which should starve to death. It’s about where the line should be drawn when certain rights butt up against other rights—not about which people will be slaves and which will be masters. Politics today is an argument about whether the criminal justice system is applied consistently—not about which citizens the written law itself will and won’t apply to. It’s about the way police do their job and police accountability—not about which citizens should be protected by the government during a genocide and which should be the subject of government genocide. It’s not that modern liberal politics doesn’t have life-or-death consequences for some people—it’s that today, those cases are the exception, not the rule.</p> \n<p>But our Primitive Minds are hardwired to see politics the old-fashioned way, regardless of how the world has changed. That many people will read the above paragraph and think, “politics is <em>still </em>all of those things, just in better disguise,” is reflective of how bad we are at thinking reasonably about politics.</p> \n<p>And politics doesn’t just rile up one part of your ancient mind—like religion, politics is a one-stop-shop for nearly every concept that lights the Primitive Mind’s fires:</p> \n<p>The Primitive Mind is obsessed with the concept of power hierarchies—and politics is literally the allotment to some humans of power they’re allowed to use against the rest of the population.</p> \n<p>The Primitive Mind is obsessed with binary moral divisions—and politics, like religion, is a prime arena for the fiercest disputes over what’s righteous and depraved, fair and unfair, pure and toxic, good and evil.</p> \n<p>The Primitive Mind is deeply concerned with defending your identity—and political alignment, like religious affiliation, consistently forms a piece of people’s core identity.</p> \n<p>Politics sometimes even overlaps with the world of religion itself, in the continual dispute over how political laws interact with religious laws.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/4-church-and-state.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8431 \" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/4-church-and-state-600x531.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"450\" height=\"398\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/4-church-and-state-600x531.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/4-church-and-state.png 626w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 450px) 100vw, 450px\" /></a></p> \n<p>And of course, there’s the way politics lends itself beautifully to tribalism, the Primitive Mind’s favorite game. The Primitive Mind sees the whole world through a Power Games lens, and it’s always looking for ways to divide its surroundings into Us people and Them people—it just needs a vehicle. And politics provides a perfect one.</p> \n<p>This all adds up to politics being a bottom-heavy thing for us. But don’t just take my word for it—</p> \n<div class=\"wbwAside\"> \n <h3><strong>The Some Actual Science Agrees That We Suck at Politics Blue Box</strong></h3> \n <p>We’re still learning about this, but there’s some interesting research that helps explain why politics so often takes place on the lower rungs of the ladder.</p> \n <p><a href=\"https://www.nature.com/articles/srep39589\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">A 2016 study</a> published in the journal <a href=\"https://www.nature.com/srep/\"><em>Scientific Reports</em></a>&nbsp;presented people with “arguments that contradicted their strongly held political and nonpolitical views.” The results were pretty stark: people were much less likely to have their minds changed when it came to their political beliefs.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#footnote2-1-8422\" id=\"note2-1-8422\" rel=\"footnote2\">1</a> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/4A.1-actual-science.png\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8433\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/4A.1-actual-science.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"850\" height=\"407\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/4A.1-actual-science.png 850w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/4A.1-actual-science-600x287.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/4A.1-actual-science-768x368.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/4A.1-actual-science-750x359.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 850px) 100vw, 850px\" /></a></p> <p>In other words, political thinking was taking place in <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/59.1-Unfalsifiable-Land.png\">Unfalsifiable Land</a>, while other thinking was not.</p> <p>Even more interesting is that while conducting this study, the scientists used an fMRI scanner to measure participants’ brain activity, revealing that people actually processed challenges to their political beliefs with different parts of their brains than they used to process nonpolitical contradictions.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#footnote2-2-8422\" id=\"note2-2-8422\" rel=\"footnote2\">2</a> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/4A.2-actual-science.jpg\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8434\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/4A.2-actual-science.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"479\" height=\"864\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/4A.2-actual-science.jpg 986w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/4A.2-actual-science-333x600.jpg 333w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/4A.2-actual-science-768x1386.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/4A.2-actual-science-416x750.jpg 416w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 479px) 100vw, 479px\" /></a></p> <p>In particular, they found that having nonpolitical beliefs challenged lit up regions of the brain like the orbitofrontal cortex that are involved in decision-making. Having political beliefs challenged, on the other hand, generated less activity in those areas and more activity in the <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Default_mode_network\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Default Mode Network</a>—a group of brain regions associated with creating a sense of self and with disengagement from the external world. The scans also showed that having a political belief challenged caused more activity in the insula and the amygdala—emotional, fight-or-flight parts of the brain—than having a nonpolitical belief challenged.</p> <p>So when the participants had one of their political views challenged, they were more likely to withdraw from the external world and go into the internally focused parts of their brains that deal with their identity, as well as the parts of their brains that deal with danger, fear, and other primal emotions. And while doing their thinking this way, their minds were far less likely to change.</p> <p>This is just one of dozens of studies I came across in my research that examine the relationship between political beliefs and the likelihood of changing one’s mind—and the findings seem to be pretty consistent.</p> <p>The study above examined people who identified with the American Left, but of course, the phenomenon spans the political spectrum. <a href=\"https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0959378014000909\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Another study</a> found that in their questioning, “people whose political identity was made salient were less likely to believe in an anthropogenic cause of climate change and less likely to support government climate change policies than those whose identity was not made salient; particularly when those people were aligned with the right-wing of politics.”</p> <p><a href=\"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/14599246\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Another</a> found that “even under conditions of effortful processing, attitudes toward a social policy depended almost exclusively upon the stated position of one’s political party.” This study also examined participants’ awareness of their own political dogmatism and found, predictably, that “participants denied having been influenced by their political group.” But of course, “they believed that other individuals, especially their ideological adversaries, would be so influenced.”</p> <p><a href=\"https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1111/j.1559-1816.2010.00588.x\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">One study</a> suggests that showing people belief-disconfirming scientific evidence not only leads them to reject the evidence but to lose faith in <em>science in general</em>—finding that “relative to those reading belief-confirming evidence, participants reading belief-disconfirming evidence indicated more belief that the topic could not be studied scientifically and more belief that a series of other unrelated topics could not be studied scientifically.”</p> <p>Then there are the studies about <a href=\"https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs11109-010-9112-2\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">the backfire effect</a> that find that not only do “corrections frequently fail to reduce misperceptions among the targeted ideological group … corrections actually increase misperceptions among the group in question.”</p> <p>The <a href=\"https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs11109-010-9112-2\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">study</a> suggests an explanation: “When confronted with counterevidence, people experience negative emotions borne of conflict between the perceived importance of their existing beliefs and the uncertainty created by the new information. In an effort to reduce these negative emotions, people may begin to think in ways that minimize the impact of the challenging evidence: discounting its source, forming counterarguments, socially validating their original attitude, or selectively avoiding the new information.”</p> <p>In case you’re assuming that well-educated people might fare better here—mountains of evidence (not to mention real-world observation) suggest that they don’t. <a href=\"http://www.pnas.org/content/early/2017/08/15/1704882114.short\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">One study</a> looked specifically at what happens when education and science knowledge butt heads with political dogmatism. It found that “more knowledgeable individuals are more likely to express beliefs consistent with their religious or political identities for issues that have become polarized along those lines (e.g. stem cell research, human evolution), but not for issues that are controversial on other grounds (e.g. genetically modified foods).” So for controversial science-related issues that were not politically polarized, more education meant less dogmatism—which seems intuitive. But when the science-related controversies were politically (or religiously) polarized, that correlation went away, and their beliefs simply lined up with their tribal alliance. In our terms: well-educated people are likely to be high-rung thinkers…until the topic is politically or religiously polarized, at which point they drop down the ladder and become obedient partisans like anybody else.</p> <p>Taking a moment to look at some research is a nice reminder that high-rung thinking is actually neurologically different than low-rung thinking. Low-rung thinking isn’t really thinking at all—it’s self-preservation. Our relationship with intellectual culture follows suit. When our psyche is up on the high rungs, we know that thinking is just thinking. This makes us interested in truth and open to changing our minds—so we like Idea Labs. When we’re lower on the ladder and confusing thinking with self-preservation, confirmation of our beliefs feels like safety—so we seek out an Echo Chamber as a protective bunker.</p> </p></p>\n</div> \n<p>The good news is that politics isn’t <em>confined </em>to the low rungs. There’s plenty of political activity up on the high rungs—it’s just that politics has an ugly high/low <em>ratio</em>. I think, with some work, we can improve that ratio. But first, we have to see the political landscape for what it is. You can’t improve upon a bottom-heavy distribution if you can’t <em>see</em> the bottom-heavy distribution, and you can’t see it if you don’t know there’s a vertical dimension to be at the bottom of in the first place.</p> \n<p>It reminds me of the whole “Inuit people have 428,085 words to describe different kinds of snow!” thing. Whether that’s true or just a fun myth (it’s a myth), it gets at an important concept: the level of nuance in our thinking is limited by the level of nuance in our language. Before I encountered the delightful term “<a href=\"https://grantland.com/features/humblebrag-hall-fame/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">humblebrag</a>,” I found it vaguely irritating when someone would humblebrag, but it was more of a subconscious irritation and one I’d have had a hard time articulating to someone if I tried. But then this term entered my thinking and my vocabulary, and suddenly, humblebragging became a distinct <em>thing</em> in my head. I clearly noticed it now, and I knew exactly why it irritated me. I also noticed myself doing it, which helped me do it less. Labeling a nuanced concept sharpens our ability to think about that concept and communicate our thoughts to others. With the right labels, nuance becomes a breeze.</p> \n<p>That’s what we’re trying to do here. Like, consider these four political thinkers:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/5.1-2x2-on-ladder.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8435\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/5.1-2x2-on-ladder.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"800\" height=\"664\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/5.1-2x2-on-ladder.png 2018w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/5.1-2x2-on-ladder-600x498.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/5.1-2x2-on-ladder-768x638.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/5.1-2x2-on-ladder-750x623.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" /></a></p> \n<p>The two thinkers on the left side, at least on the topic at hand, share a common viewpoint. Same for the two thinkers on the right.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/5.2-2x2-on-ladder.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8436\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/5.2-2x2-on-ladder.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"800\" height=\"629\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/5.2-2x2-on-ladder.png 1925w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/5.2-2x2-on-ladder-600x471.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/5.2-2x2-on-ladder-768x603.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/5.2-2x2-on-ladder-750x589.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" /></a></p> \n<p>But the two high-rung thinkers share a common <em>way </em>of thinking. They’re humbler, more nuanced, and their opinions about the topic were hard-earned. The two low-rung thinkers are more sure of themselves while knowing less than the thinkers above them—and there’s nothing you could really do to change their minds.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/5.3-2x2-on-ladder.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8437\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/5.3-2x2-on-ladder.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"800\" height=\"586\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/5.3-2x2-on-ladder.png 2150w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/5.3-2x2-on-ladder-600x440.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/5.3-2x2-on-ladder-768x563.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/5.3-2x2-on-ladder-750x549.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Our societies are great at talking about the horizontal distinction. We’re experts at identifying what people think and grouping people that way, because we’ve been trained to look at these four thinkers and see two left-wingers and two right-wingers.</p> \n<p>But we’re awful at talking about the vertical distinction. When I listen to arguments or read op-eds, I constantly hear people <em>trying </em>to make vertical distinctions in their arguments about politicians or ideas, but because A) many people forget that there is a vertical axis, and B) those who do think vertically lack a common language with which to talk about it, those attempts are usually misunderstood or missed altogether.</p> \n<p>When people notice a vertical discrepancy between thinkers, it’s like me before I learned the word “humblebrag”—they often can’t quite tell <em>what </em>it is that they’re noticing, so they’ll misattribute the qualities that distinguish the thinkers to something they do have a vocabulary for. I hear people refer to high-rung political thinkers as being more <em>centrist</em>, or more <em>moderate</em>, than low-rung thinkers. But those are What You Think words. They refer to the middle part of the <em>x-</em>axis—as if holding viewpoints in those areas is the mark of a good thinker, and vice versa. Often, high-rung thinkers <em>will</em> end up at more centrist or moderate positions than low-rung thinkers,&nbsp;but there are plenty of cases where the opposite is true. Vertical terms like <em>high-rung </em>and <em>low-rung</em> make our discussions a bit less constrained and a bit nimbler.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/5.4-2x2-on-ladder-1.png\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8621\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/5.4-2x2-on-ladder-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"2018\" height=\"1676\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/5.4-2x2-on-ladder-1.png 2018w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/5.4-2x2-on-ladder-1-600x498.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/5.4-2x2-on-ladder-1-768x638.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/5.4-2x2-on-ladder-1-750x623.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 2018px) 100vw, 2018px\" /></a></p> \n<p>So let’s try taking a breath from left-wing and right-wing politics and focusing, for the rest of this chapter, on the worlds of high-rung and low-rung politics.</p> \n<p style=\"font-size:32px\"><strong>The Political Arch</strong></p> \n<p>Every country has their own special political squabble around the What of politics—the parties, the stances, the ideologies. We’ll be using U.S. politics as our “demo system” in this discussion—because as an American, it’s the system I understand the best and will be the least wrong about. But this discussion can apply to any country, as the high-rung / low-rung distinction is something that all political systems share.</p> \n<p>If we mapped out the American political landscape in the traditional way—by bunching everyone up in one dimension, paying attention only to What people think—it might look something like this:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/0-political-1D.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8439 size-large\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/0-political-1D-750x228.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"228\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/0-political-1D-750x228.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/0-political-1D-600x183.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/0-political-1D-768x234.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/0-political-1D.png 1479w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Now let’s bring the landscape into 2D:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/0-political-2D-arch.jpg\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8633\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/0-political-2D-arch.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1000\" height=\"831\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/0-political-2D-arch.jpg 2018w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/0-political-2D-arch-600x498.jpg 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/0-political-2D-arch-768x638.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/0-political-2D-arch-750x623.jpg 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px\" /></a></p> \n<p>This tells a more interesting story. The American political distribution now forms a <a href=\"https://media.wnyc.org/i/800/0/c/85/1/shutterstock_270828248.jpg\">St. Louis Arch</a>-esque shape.</p> \n<p>Of course, since no one talks about the Psych Spectrum, there are no Gallup polls, Pew research tables, or <a href=\"https://ourworldindata.org/\">Our World in Data</a> graphs showing us the exact shape or distribution of Americans on our two-dimensional graph. All we can do is guess—and my best guess is that we’re dealing with some kind of St. Louis Arch situation.</p> \n<p>Let’s start at the top of the arch and work our way down.<a id=\"high-rung\"></a></p> \n<p class=\"has-large-font-size\"><strong>High-Rung Politics</strong></p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/0-political-2D-top-v2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8656\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/0-political-2D-top-v2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"850\" height=\"914\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/0-political-2D-top-v2.png 1412w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/0-political-2D-top-v2-558x600.png 558w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/0-political-2D-top-v2-768x826.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/0-political-2D-top-v2-697x750.png 697w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 850px) 100vw, 850px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Not everyone who participates in high-rung politics approaches politics like a <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/09/thinking-ladder.html#scientist\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Scientist</a>. Up in this realm, you’ll find some super-objective, unaffiliated top-rung thinkers. But you’ll probably find even more somewhat partisan, pretty confirmation-bias-y political <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/09/thinking-ladder.html#sports-fan\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Sports Fans</a>. You’ll even find some hopelessly partisan, highly tribal, fully unfalsifiable political <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/09/thinking-ladder.html#attorney\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Attorneys</a>.</p> \n<p>The thing that makes high-rung politics high-rung is that it takes place within high-rung political <em>culture. </em></p> \n<p>High-rung political culture is the political version of the high-rung Idea Lab cultures we discussed <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/10/idea-labs-echo-chambers.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">last chapter</a>. It subscribes to all the same high-rung intellectual values and supplements them with the high-rung political notion that the good of the country trumps the good of any political tribe. It’s a culture that makes it safe for Scientists to be Scientists, and it lets Sports Fans do their thing while keeping their worst tendencies on a leash. Attorneys who abide by the culture’s norms and don’t inhibit good conversations can stay. When Attorneys are policed by a strong high-rung culture, their one-sided arguments can provide potential truth material or serve as useful criticism of prevailing ideas. The right political culture can turn a wide collection of thinkers into a productive thinking system.</p> \n<p>In high-rung political culture, people are micro-divided in their viewpoints and macro-united, in a broader sense, in their values.</p> \n<p>They’re macro-united because they’re almost all liberals. Not “liberal” the way it’s often used in the U.S., as a synonym with “Left”—liberal the way the Enlightenment thinkers used it. Liberal meaning “committed to liberal values”—values like truth, human rights, freedom of expression, and equality of opportunity.</p> \n<p>They’re macro-united because they share a common notion of reality. Their opinions will differ wildly, but they’ll usually agree on facts or the lack thereof.</p> \n<p>They’re macro-united by a shared humility—an understanding of just how hard politics is and a self-awareness that knows it’s impossible to fully understand the values or the worldview of people who grew up in or live in circumstances different from your own.</p> \n<p>They’re macro-united because they get how democracy works. They know that a successful democracy is one where everyone gets what they want only <em>sometimes</em>—where regular and widespread frustration and disappointment means the system is working.</p> \n<p>Finally, high-rung political thinkers and activists are macro-united around the broad shared goal of a more perfect nation, along with a mutual understanding that they can move towards that goal only by being micro-divided within a vibrant marketplace of ideas. High-rung political discussions are boxing rings, where ideas get their asses kicked, but people don’t. When it’s safe for people to say what they’re thinking, <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/09/american-brain.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Speech Curves line up with Thought Piles</a>, turning high-rung thinking communities into giant superbrains.</p> \n<p>And what exactly are people micro-divided about in the high-rung political world? Their debates center around three core questions:</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/7.1-3-Questions.png\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8442\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/7.1-3-Questions.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1165\" height=\"825\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/7.1-3-Questions.png 1165w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/7.1-3-Questions-600x425.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/7.1-3-Questions-768x544.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/7.1-3-Questions-750x531.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1165px) 100vw, 1165px\" /></a></p> \n<p class=\"has-medium-font-size\"><strong>Question 1: What Is?</strong></p> \n<p>You can’t figure out how to make a more perfect nation if you don’t have a good sense of what the nation currently is. What does the population look like, and how has it evolved over time? What are the current policies, and how do they work? Which experimental programs are being attempted, and what does the data say about their efficacy? How are resources currently distributed? How is the status quo being experienced by citizens of all kinds and in all circumstances? The study of What Is is the domain of science. Embedded in What Is, and critical to its understanding, is the study of What Has Been—i.e. how did What Is become What Is? This is the domain of history.</p> \n<p>Both science and history are the search for truth—the quest to see reality as best you can. High up on the ladder, there’s disagreement around Question 1, but not too much <em>conflict</em>. Conflict happens when disagreement is accompanied by conviction, and two high-rung thinkers won’t usually both feel strongly about conflicting conceptions of reality. Conviction on the high rungs is a function of clarity, and if there’s clarity around a certain set of facts, high-rung thinkers will usually agree with each other. When things are hazier, two differing high-rung thinkers will both speak with doubt, and they’ll consider the points where their conceptions differ to be areas for joint exploration as part of a collaborative knowledge quest.</p> \n<p class=\"has-medium-font-size\"><strong>Question 2: What Should Be?</strong></p> \n<p>Unlike What Is, What Should Be is a matter of philosophy and often the subject of fierce conflict on the high rungs. High up on the arch, almost everyone’s goal is a more perfect nation, but thinkers hold different notions of what kinds of policies and systems are the fairest, the most morally right, and the most philosophically consistent. They’ll dig deep on lots of hard questions with no objectively correct answer:</p> \n<p>What should the role of government be? Which freedoms should be restricted in the name of citizen protection and which shouldn’t? When does a fetus become a human being? What are the criteria for “equal opportunity” to be considered equal? How big and how powerful should government be, and where should the boundaries be drawn between state and federal government power? What should the country’s role be in the world, and under what circumstances should it involve itself in foreign affairs? When is it appropriate for the military to use force against other countries or police to use force against citizens? Which resources are rights, and which are privileges? The list is long, and the debates are heated.</p> \n<p class=\"has-medium-font-size\"><strong>Question 3: How to Get There?</strong></p> \n<p><a id=\"pdw\"></a>What Is and What Should Be, when compared, yield the gaps between reality and the ideal. These gaps define the political objectives of the high-rung thinker. But even when high-rung thinkers do agree about What Should Be, they often completely disagree about the best way to bridge the gap from What Is to their vision of something better. No one is an expert at how to run a country, and there’s rarely a consensus about the most effective way to fix an identified flaw in the system. Two people who agree that the middle class should be larger than it is can completely disagree about which tax structure or government structures will best achieve the goal. Two people who feel the same exact way about the history of race in the U.S. can hold opposite viewpoints about the efficacy of affirmative action. Two people who both hate the current healthcare system can come up with entirely different government healthcare programs as their proposed solution.</p> \n<p>Parsing political arguments using these three questions can help us isolate what the arguments are really about. Sometimes thinkers who agree philosophically will disagree strategically. Some who seem to agree strategically may actually be aiming for different outcomes. Some will disagree on all fronts.</p> \n<p>Other times, disagreements may be more fundamental. Here, it may be appropriate to *cautiously* apply what have become two of the most unpleasant words in American English: Progressivism and Conservatism.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/8.1-PC-bags.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8443 size-medium\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/8.1-PC-bags-600x206.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"206\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/8.1-PC-bags-600x206.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/8.1-PC-bags-768x264.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/8.1-PC-bags-750x258.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/8.1-PC-bags.png 1138w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a></p> \n<p>If we’re going to discuss these words—and the core concept behind each—the first thing we’ll need to do is put aside the baggage.</p> \n<p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/8.2-PC-no-bags.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8444 size-medium\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/8.2-PC-no-bags-600x206.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"206\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/8.2-PC-no-bags-600x206.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/8.2-PC-no-bags-768x264.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/8.2-PC-no-bags-750x258.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/8.2-PC-no-bags.png 1138w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a></p> \n<p>Well done. Now, anytime in this post we’re going to use politically charged words, we should make sure to agree on the definitions we’re using.</p> \n<p>If you want to confuse yourself, google around for a while reading about “Progressivism” and “Conservatism.” Each of the words has been the banner for a huge range of political, economic, social, and philosophical ideas—some of them overlapping, some that are unrelated to each other, and some that are totally contradictory with others.</p> \n<p>In the U.S., giant political Echo Chambers have appropriated these words as banners for themselves and for their enemies. And we’ll come back to what the words mean in that low-rung context, but let’s remind ourselves that the words <em>themselves</em> actually have pretty intuitive literal definitions, and I think those meanings provide an important and useful distinction in political thinking. At their most literal—and, because we’re dealing with Higher Minds at the moment, their most charitable:</p> \n<p><strong>Progressivism = </strong>concerned with helping society make forward <em>progress</em>—positive changes to the status quo. That progress can come from identifying what you deem to be a flaw in your nation’s systems or its culture and working to root it out, or by trying to make your nation’s strong points even stronger.</p> \n<p><strong>Conservatism =</strong> concerned with <em>conserving</em> what is already good about society—either by fighting against the erosion of what you deem to be your nation’s strong qualities, or by pushing back against well-intentioned attempts at positive progress that you believe, in reality, will prove to be changes for the worse, not for the better.</p> \n<p>Put more simply, if a nation is a boat, high-rung Progressivism tries to make improvements to flaws in the boat and build newer, better features, while high-rung Conservatism tries to protect the existing boat against damage and deterioration.</p> \n<p>Given that any nation, like any boat, has some things working well and others working poorly—along with the capacity to be both improved and damaged over time—Progressivism and Conservatism, the way we’re currently defining them, are simply the two sides of the “Let’s make this the best boat we can” coin. Two halves of a single noble quest for a more perfect nation.</p> \n<p>As high-rung thinkers trudge their way up the mountain into a foggy future, some of the most fundamental disagreements will be those between a progressive and conservative mindset—the “to change or not to change?” disagreements, and their underlying “how well is this part of the system accomplishing what it’s supposed to?” and “what does a more perfect nation even look like?” disputes.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#footnote-2-8422\" id=\"note-2-8422\" rel=\"footnote\">2</a> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/9-PC-Snake.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8445 size-full\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/9-PC-Snake.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1461\" height=\"841\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/9-PC-Snake.png 1461w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/9-PC-Snake-600x345.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/9-PC-Snake-768x442.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/9-PC-Snake-750x432.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1461px) 100vw, 1461px\" /></a></p> <p>It’s easy to see looking at this diagram why Progressivism is important. No country is perfect, and you can’t become a more perfect nation without making changes. Progressivism drives that change.</p> <p>But Conservatism is just as important. Firstly, there are some aspects of a country that are working beautifully—and in these cases, the conservative impulse to resist the inevitable calls for change will be wise. Further, a country like the U.S. is permanently tasked with figuring things out as they go, and when it comes to running and adjusting a massive country in a rapidly changing world, everyone is an amateur. Mistakes will be made, and some changes will prove with time to have been ineffective or detrimental. In these moments, the voice urging the country to press the undo key and go back to the way things used to be will be the wisest voice.</p> <p>Secondly, Progressivism is the collection of lots of different ideas—most of them untested—and inevitably, most of them will be bad ideas. Nations evolve the same way species do—through beneficial mutations. Coming up with mutations and pushing them into the national genome is the job of Progressivism. But for every beneficial mutation to a species, there are many more mutations which prove to be detrimental to survival. The conservative resistance to <em>all</em> progressive ideas provides a critical filter—a gauntlet that relentlessly tries to expose flaws in each progressive effort at mutation. Forcing progressive ideas to pass through intense conservative resistance in order to implement their desired change helps separate the wise ideas from the foolish or naive and protects the country from the latter kind.</p> <p>It’s worth noting that I’m using these <em>ism </em>terms and not “progressives” and “conservatives” because the latter implies that people are either one or the other, and high-rung culture doesn’t equate people with their ideas. High-rung thinkers may tend to think in a more progressive or conservative way—but they <em>are </em>no line of thought.</p> <p>Even using the words as adjectives for people—declaring yourself to <em>be </em>progressive or conservative, in general (as opposed to “holding a conservative viewpoint” or “tending to be progressive in a certain area of your thinking”) is an implicit presumption of uniform thinking across the board and through time. A single brash label for a person, or for their thinking, boxes in a person’s intellect and boxes in their evolution—and high-rung thinkers don’t like to be put in boxes, by themselves or by anyone else. This non-boxable phenomenon is apparent when I think about the high-rung political thinkers I know or know of, as it can often be frustratingly hard to figure out what their “deal” is politically.</p> <p>But while the individuals in high-rung politics may bounce back and forth between the two camps, what <em>is</em> consistent is a substantial group of people falling into each bucket on any given issue. If we bring things into 3D and venture upwards on <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/1.1AM-extended-emergence-tower-v2.png\">Emergence Tower</a>, we can visualize the two groups as a progressive giant and a conservative giant.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/10-high-rung-giants.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8446\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/10-high-rung-giants.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"450\" height=\"358\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/10-high-rung-giants.png 1942w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/10-high-rung-giants-600x477.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/10-high-rung-giants-768x610.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/10-high-rung-giants-750x596.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 450px) 100vw, 450px\" /></a></p> <p>If high-rung politics is a grand political courtroom, these giants are the two lawyers.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#footnote-3-8422\" id=\"note-3-8422\" rel=\"footnote\">3</a> When the “defendant” is the nation’s status quo or its traditional values, the progressive giant is the prosecutor and the conservative giant is the defense. In these cases, Progressivism will be the voice of negativity and criticism, while Conservatism will paint the rosier picture of the country as it stands, and its history.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/11-courtroom-v2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8709 size-large\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/11-courtroom-v2-750x651.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"651\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/11-courtroom-v2-750x651.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/11-courtroom-v2-600x521.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/11-courtroom-v2-768x666.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/11-courtroom-v2.png 1435w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> <p>But when it comes to how to change the country—when the defendant is the country’s evolution—the roles switch. Progressivism, now in the role of the defense, will tend to be a vocal proponent of change, while Conservatism, as prosecutor, will be critical of and resistant to change.</p> <p>In both cases, each giant acts as a counterforce against the other and helps keep it in check. When the conservative giant gets riled up, it can drift too far into “Our country is perfect just as it is” or “Our country used to be perfect” territory. When the progressive giant gets out of hand, it can fall too far down the “Our country is and always has been awful” hole. The presence of its rival giant restrains each giant from becoming a ridiculous caricature of itself.</p> <p>The clash of these two forces lies at the heart of the parts of society that evolve. I have a friend who’s a new mother and decided not to breastfeed her baby and use formula instead. She explained her reasoning to me and it made sense. I mentioned this to another friend, also a new mother, who thinks the first friend is crazy. Her reasoning made sense too.</p> <p>Another friend of mine makes a compelling case about how women who can afford to should consider using a surrogate for pregnancy instead of getting pregnant themselves.
