I found this interesting and have brought it up with a few other friends, to hugely negative reactions.</p> <p>I’m not sure who’s more right in either case, or if there even is a clear right and wrong side—but I know that some people having a progressive, “we should challenge the status quo” instinct in each area is important for our ability to evolve and improve, and some people having a knee-jerk conservative instinct to criticize and push back against progressive ideas is important for our ability to proceed prudently and effectively in our evolution. Together, they are the two lawyers that allow societal evolution to undergo “due process” in the marketplace of ideas.</p> <p>This same tension exists at the core of debates about nutrition, wellness, parenting, education, professional sports rules, holidays, company culture, employment practices, and 100 other things. In each area, evolution is driven by progressive ideas and policed by conservative sensibilities. In any of these situations, people with a progressive mindset feel like they’re dragging more conservative people upward to a better place, while people on the conservative side feel that the progressive effort is dragging things downward to a worse place.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#footnote-4-8422\" id=\"note-4-8422\" rel=\"footnote\">4</a> <p>Most of us will find ourselves on the progressive side in some of these “courtrooms” and on the conservative side of others. Even people who find themselves falling on the same side of most the debates I mentioned would hesitate to box themselves in by attaching their identities to that quality and letting that label automatically determine all of their viewpoints. High-rung political culture simply extends this way of thinking to politics as well.</p> <p>Some political debates aren’t about “to change or not to change.” Instead, they’re about a spectrum of possibility and the debates are about where exactly on the spectrum our policies should lie.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/12.1-spectrum-tug-of-war.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8448 size-large\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/12.1-spectrum-tug-of-war-750x278.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"278\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/12.1-spectrum-tug-of-war-750x278.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/12.1-spectrum-tug-of-war-600x222.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/12.1-spectrum-tug-of-war-768x285.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/12.1-spectrum-tug-of-war.png 1360w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> <p>In spectrum battles, which side ends up backed by the Left vs. the Right doesn’t always map on very well to “progressive” or “conservative,” but it doesn’t matter. The important thing is that each side of the spectrum has a group advocating for it. This allows the marketplace of ideas as a whole to home in on a point that represents a reasonable compromise. As the debates rage on and public opinion evolves, that point can evolve along with it. It’s democracy at its finest: everyone disagrees with each other in an unpleasant marketplace of ideas, and it results in a policy that represents a broad compromise that most people are somewhat unhappy with. There a lot of these types of issues in American politics:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/12.2-spectrum-tug-of-war.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8449\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/12.2-spectrum-tug-of-war.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1350\" height=\"911\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/12.2-spectrum-tug-of-war.png 2763w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/12.2-spectrum-tug-of-war-600x405.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/12.2-spectrum-tug-of-war-768x518.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/12.2-spectrum-tug-of-war-750x506.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/12.2-spectrum-tug-of-war-345x234.png 345w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/12.2-spectrum-tug-of-war-103x70.png 103w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1350px) 100vw, 1350px\" /></a></p> <p>Sometimes political issues revolve around priorities and where we should direct our attention. Here, again, high-rung politics usually organizes into a two-sided structure. A <a href=\"https://www.researchgate.net/publication/336076674_Ideological_differences_in_the_expanse_of_the_moral_circle\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">recent paper</a> explored how the two giants differ in which parts of Emergence Tower they focus on. Here are their results (they call progressives “liberals”):<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#footnote2-3-8422\" id=\"note2-3-8422\" rel=\"footnote2\">3</a> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/0-heatmap.jpg\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8450\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/0-heatmap.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1200\" height=\"691\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/0-heatmap.jpg 1200w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/0-heatmap-600x346.jpg 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/0-heatmap-768x442.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/0-heatmap-750x432.jpg 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1200px) 100vw, 1200px\" /></a></p> <p>In our language, that translates to:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/13-PC-Emergence.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8451 size-large\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/13-PC-Emergence-697x750.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"697\" height=\"750\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/13-PC-Emergence-697x750.png 697w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/13-PC-Emergence-558x600.png 558w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/13-PC-Emergence-768x826.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/13-PC-Emergence.png 1261w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 697px) 100vw, 697px\" /></a></p> <p>The Left sometimes seems overly focused on the global and the universal, and the Right can be a broken record about individualism and community and family values—but when you remember that each is half of a two-part system, it all makes sense. They’re both just doing their part of the job.</p> <p>It’s like a company having two founders, one who focuses more on operations and the other who thinks more about growth. Progressivism and Conservatism each worry about one half of every issue, and together, they make sure we’re paying enough attention to everything that matters.</p> <p>Every person involved in high-rung politics has a Primitive Mind in their head that wants to identify with political parties and treat politics like a tribal war. But up on the high rungs, the Higher Minds have the edge—one that they protect with a pervasive high-rung culture. The culture keeps everyone—even the more partisan people—aware that ultimately, they’re all on the same team. As fierce as the debates between the high-rung giants can be, they know deep down that what they’re really doing is working together to navigate their way up the mountain, towards a more perfect nation.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/13A-map.png\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8452\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/13A-map.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"551\" height=\"402\" /></a></p> <p>But politics is bottom-heavy. And even the high-rung-thinking grown-ups among us are prone to morph into childish low-rungers when it comes to politics.</p> <p>When our Primitive Minds get ahold of our political thinking, our political worldview, values, and general mentality jump in a time machine back to hunter-gatherer times. Politics ceases to be about figuring out the truth and building a more perfect nation and becomes geared toward ideological confirmation and triumphing over the bad guys. We forget how to do the <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/09/enlightenment-kids.html#value\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Value Games</a> and revert to the old human ritual—the <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/08/fire-light.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Power Games</a>. That’s why low-rung politics looks like this:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/0-political-2D-bottom-v2.jpg\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8657\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/0-political-2D-bottom-v2.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"850\" height=\"914\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/0-political-2D-bottom-v2.jpg 1412w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/0-political-2D-bottom-v2-558x600.jpg 558w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/0-political-2D-bottom-v2-768x826.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/0-political-2D-bottom-v2-697x750.jpg 697w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 850px) 100vw, 850px\" /></a></p> <p>Politics done the Primitive Mind way leaves us in a place that can really only be called one thing.<a id=\"disney-world\"></a></p> <p class=\"has-large-font-size\"><strong>Political Disney World</strong></p> <p>I’m pretty into most Disney movies. But especially <em>The Little Mermaid</em>, <em>Beauty and the Beast</em>, <em>Aladdin</em>, and <em>The Lion King</em>. I’ve never been sure if those are objectively the best four Disney movies or if everyone just thinks whichever Disney movies happened to come out when they were between the ages of 7 and 12 are the best Disney movies. Either way, clearly those are the four best Disney movies.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#footnote-5-8422\" id=\"note-5-8422\" rel=\"footnote\">5</a><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#footnote-6-8422\" id=\"note-6-8422\" rel=\"footnote\">6</a> <p>The thing about those movies, though, is that they’re definitely fake movies, and definitely not real life. Right?</p> <p>Like, kids might think Disney movies are the way the real world is, but everyone else knows that actually, the real world is not like Disney movies.</p> <p>Right?</p> <p>This is what I thought too—and then I started writing this post series.</p> <p>After spending most of the last three years thinking about hardcore political partisans and their hardcore political Echo Chambers, it hit me: like 80% of the U.S. thinks they live inside a Disney movie.</p> <p>I know it seems crazy.</p> <p>I know it seems crazy that like 280,000,000 adult humans in 2019 think they’re a beautiful Disney princess living inside a magical Disney castle perched on a sparkling Disney landscape on a fluffy Disney planet—</p> <p>But that’s the situation.</p> <p>Let’s discuss.</p> <p style=\"font-size:32px\"><strong>Analog and Digital</strong></p> <p>When I wrote about <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2017/04/neuralink.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Neuralink</a>, one of the concepts I got into was the difference between analog and digital information (brain waves are analog signals, but they need to be converted to digital information in order to be processed by a brain-machine interface).</p> <p>The thing is, ever since then, I can’t get analog and digital out of my head. I see it as a metaphor for all kinds of things in the world. Here’s what I mean:</p> <p>Analog is what actually goes on in the natural world. It’s a perfect representation of reality: information in its natural, messy state. Sound is a nice example.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#footnote-7-8422\" id=\"note-7-8422\" rel=\"footnote\">7</a> Sound is analog information that can be represented by a wave:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/14.1-analog-digital.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8454 size-large\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/14.1-analog-digital-750x500.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"500\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/14.1-analog-digital-750x500.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/14.1-analog-digital-600x400.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/14.1-analog-digital-768x512.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/14.1-analog-digital-103x70.png 103w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/14.1-analog-digital.png 1182w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> <p>Digitization is a way to approximate analog information using a set of exact values. Like this:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/14.2-analog-digital.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8455\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/14.2-analog-digital.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1182\" height=\"709\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/14.2-analog-digital.png 1182w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/14.2-analog-digital-600x360.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/14.2-analog-digital-768x461.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/14.2-analog-digital-750x450.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1182px) 100vw, 1182px\" /></a></p> <p>Information in digital format can be expressed as a series of 1s and 0s—an exact, binary format computers can process. When you listen to an mp3, you’re not listening to the true analog information made by the band’s instruments, you’re listening to a digitized version of the sounds—a big string of 1s and 0s that approximates the analog sound wave of the song.</p> <p>Above, the sound wave has been digitized to eight incremental values, by rounding all parts of the wave to the nearest value. Eight values can be expressed by three “bits” (a three-number string of 1s and 0s). You can compress an mp3 into a smaller file by making your approximations of the analog wave cruder—by making the digital “steps” <em>bigger</em>, using only four values. Now you only need two bits.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/14.3-analog-digital.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8456 size-large\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/14.3-analog-digital-750x451.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"451\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/14.3-analog-digital-750x451.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/14.3-analog-digital-600x360.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/14.3-analog-digital-768x461.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/14.3-analog-digital.png 1182w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> <p>The more you compress a sound file, the smaller the mp3 file gets, because bigger steps require fewer 1s and 0s to express the sound. But the song also sounds worse, because more “rounding” is happening to make cruder approximations—i.e. the sound has become lower-res. The size and sound quality of a digitized file all depend on how far down the <em>digitization spectrum</em> you go in your conversion.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/14.4-digitization-spectrum-v2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8707 size-full\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/14.4-digitization-spectrum-v2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1293\" height=\"324\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/14.4-digitization-spectrum-v2.png 1293w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/14.4-digitization-spectrum-v2-600x150.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/14.4-digitization-spectrum-v2-768x192.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/14.4-digitization-spectrum-v2-750x188.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1293px) 100vw, 1293px\" /></a></p> <p>At the far end of the digitization spectrum, you’d have only straight 1s and 0s—a tiny file that would sound almost nothing like the original song.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/14.5-analog-digital.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8458 size-large\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/14.5-analog-digital-750x454.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"454\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/14.5-analog-digital-750x454.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/14.5-analog-digital-600x363.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/14.5-analog-digital-768x465.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/14.5-analog-digital.png 1182w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> <p>The same concept applies to visual information. Each pixel is a datapoint. You can make a photograph file smaller, and worse-looking, by making the pixels bigger.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#footnote2-4-8422\" id=\"note2-4-8422\" rel=\"footnote2\">4</a> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/15-analog-digital-visual.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8459\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/15-analog-digital-visual-750x138.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"900\" height=\"165\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/15-analog-digital-visual-750x138.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/15-analog-digital-visual-600x110.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/15-analog-digital-visual-768x141.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/15-analog-digital-visual.png 1840w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px\" /></a></p> <p>Another way to make it smaller is by reducing the real-world’s infinite gradients of color to 10,000 gradients, or 100, or 15.</p> <p>The typical goal when we work with audio and visual information isn’t to try to go as high-res as possible—it’s to try to find the sweet spot: the crudest approximation you can get to while still accomplishing your goal. You want to weigh the costs of high file size alongside the costs of quality reduction and choose the optimal compromise for whatever you’re trying to do.</p> <p>I’ve been thinking about this a lot because the general concept behind the digitization spectrum and the compromise it represents is relevant in all kinds of places. If someone asks you a time-related question, without realizing you’re doing it, you’ll answer the question at what you believe to be the optimal point along the spectrum. If you didn’t do this, you’d be a weird person.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/16.1-time-digitization-v2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8698\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/16.1-time-digitization-v2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1355\" height=\"529\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/16.1-time-digitization-v2.png 1355w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/16.1-time-digitization-v2-600x234.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/16.1-time-digitization-v2-768x300.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/16.1-time-digitization-v2-750x293.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1355px) 100vw, 1355px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/16.2-time-digitization-v2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8699\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/16.2-time-digitization-v2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1355\" height=\"503\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/16.2-time-digitization-v2.png 1355w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/16.2-time-digitization-v2-600x223.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/16.2-time-digitization-v2-768x285.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/16.2-time-digitization-v2-750x278.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1355px) 100vw, 1355px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/16.3-time-digitization-v2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8700\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/16.3-time-digitization-v2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1355\" height=\"618\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/16.3-time-digitization-v2.png 1355w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/16.3-time-digitization-v2-600x274.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/16.3-time-digitization-v2-768x350.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/16.3-time-digitization-v2-750x342.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1355px) 100vw, 1355px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/16.4-time-digitization-v2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8701\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/16.4-time-digitization-v2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1706\" height=\"650\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/16.4-time-digitization-v2.png 1706w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/16.4-time-digitization-v2-600x229.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/16.4-time-digitization-v2-768x293.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/16.4-time-digitization-v2-750x286.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1706px) 100vw, 1706px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/16.5-time-digitization-v2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8702\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/16.5-time-digitization-v2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1706\" height=\"516\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/16.5-time-digitization-v2.png 1706w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/16.5-time-digitization-v2-600x181.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/16.5-time-digitization-v2-768x232.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/16.5-time-digitization-v2-750x227.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1706px) 100vw, 1706px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/16.6-time-digitization-v2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8703\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/16.6-time-digitization-v2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1628\" height=\"650\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/16.6-time-digitization-v2.png 1628w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/16.6-time-digitization-v2-600x240.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/16.6-time-digitization-v2-768x307.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/16.6-time-digitization-v2-750x299.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1628px) 100vw, 1628px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/16.7-time-digitization-v2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8704\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/16.7-time-digitization-v2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1628\" height=\"620\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/16.7-time-digitization-v2.png 1628w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/16.7-time-digitization-v2-600x229.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/16.7-time-digitization-v2-768x292.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/16.7-time-digitization-v2-750x286.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1628px) 100vw, 1628px\" /></a>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</p> <p>In our thoughts and our conversations about life, society, politics, or anything else, we’re always negotiating this same balance. Digitization/approximation, when used appropriately, is an incredibly handy efficiency tool that leverages the human mind’s talent for pattern recognition. But digitization is inherently lossy—it intentionally does away with nuance—and the appropriate amount of digitization is up to whatever point where the lost nuance isn’t important, meaningful information—or at least where the lost nuance is <em>less </em>important than the gained efficiency.</p> <p>Back to Disney movies.</p> <p>The real world is analog—gray, amorphous, and endlessly nuanced. What Disney movies do is they digitize the shit out of the real world. They go the full distance, converting all that gray into clean black-and-white 1s and 0s.</p> <p>Real people are complex and flawed, full of faults but almost always worthy of compassion. Disney characters, on the other hand, are either entirely good or entirely bad.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#footnote-8-8422\" id=\"note-8-8422\" rel=\"footnote\">8</a> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.1-digital-characters.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8467\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.1-digital-characters.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1200\" height=\"433\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.1-digital-characters.png 2337w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.1-digital-characters-600x217.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.1-digital-characters-768x277.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.1-digital-characters-750x271.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1200px) 100vw, 1200px\" /></a></p> <p>It goes beyond characters. In the real world, each turn of <em>events</em> is mired in potential positives and potential negatives, which is a mess to sort out. Disney movies get rid of that messiness. Something that happens is either clearly good, or it’s clearly bad. Disney even digitizes the weather.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.3-digital-weather.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8468\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.3-digital-weather.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1000\" height=\"494\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.3-digital-weather.png 2095w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.3-digital-weather-600x296.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.3-digital-weather-768x379.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.3-digital-weather-750x371.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px\" /></a></p> <p>Disney digitization spares no one. Not even the birds.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.4-digital-birds.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8469\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.4-digital-birds.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1000\" height=\"614\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.4-digital-birds.png 1721w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.4-digital-birds-600x369.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.4-digital-birds-768x472.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.4-digital-birds-750x461.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px\" /></a></p> <p>Going full digital is logical in Disney movies. Their core audience is little kids, who aren’t ready yet to sort through gray. Before a person learns to think in nuance, they first need to learn the basic concepts of good vs. bad, right vs. wrong, safe vs. dangerous, happy vs. sad. It’s the same way you wouldn’t teach a beginner poker player about the difference between how to slow play a big hand when you’re in early vs. late position—you’d start by making sure they understood what a pair is, what folding means, and how the betting works. Going straight to the higher-level strategy would only confuse them.</p> <p>If good Disney characters are shown to have deep character flaws, kids may misinterpret the message and think they’re supposed to mimic those qualities.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#footnote-9-8422\" id=\"note-9-8422\" rel=\"footnote\">9</a><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#footnote-10-8422\" id=\"note-10-8422\" rel=\"footnote\">10</a><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#footnote-11-8422\" id=\"note-11-8422\" rel=\"footnote\">11</a><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#footnote-12-8422\" id=\"note-12-8422\" rel=\"footnote\">12</a><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#footnote-13-8422\" id=\"note-13-8422\" rel=\"footnote\">13</a> And if bad guys are humanized, kids will get upset when things turn out badly for them in the end.</p> <p>Digitizing an analog world into perfect cartoon simplicity makes sense. In fictional Disney movies. Made for kids.</p> <p>But over-digitizing the <em>real</em> world is pretty bad idea—and unfortunately, that’s exactly what the Primitive Mind likes to do. So low-rung politics ends up feeling, to its participants, just like a Disney movie.</p> <p>Up on the high rungs, people know the world is a mess of analog complexity. They look out at that world, with clear eyes, and see fog. They also know that people are little microcosms of the messy world—each person an evolving gray smattering of virtues and flaws.</p> <p>Political Disney World is much more fun. Everything is nice and crisp and perfectly digital. Good guys and bad guys, with good ideas and bad ideas, respectively. Good politicians and bad politicians with good policies and bad policies. Right and wrong. Smart and ignorant. Virtuous and evil. Safe and dangerous.</p> <p>1s and 0s.</p> <p>In the foggy minds of Political Disney World, it’s all quite clear.</p> <p>At the heart of every faction in Political Disney World (PDW) is a guiding narrative. PDW narratives are all-encompassing versions of reality—they come with their own worldview, their own telling of history, their own description of the present, and their own explanation for the causes behind all of it. A unique, customized Disney movie for the tribe, by the tribe.</p> <p>Every country has a Political Disney World, each with their own factions and their own narratives. I live inside “Political Disney World, U.S.,” where there are two major factions: the low-rung Democrats and the low-rung Republicans. Their narratives digitize both people and ideas.</p> <p style=\"font-size:28px\"><strong>How PDW Narratives Digitize People</strong></p> <p>Central to each narrative are the main characters. In some stories, the protagonists live here—</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.5-good-castle.jpg\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8470 \" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.5-good-castle-462x600.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"350\" height=\"455\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.5-good-castle-462x600.jpg 462w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.5-good-castle-768x998.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.5-good-castle-577x750.jpg 577w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.5-good-castle.jpg 1656w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 350px) 100vw, 350px\" /></a></p> <p>—while the bad guys are some version of these:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.6-hyenas.jpg\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8471\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.6-hyenas-750x493.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"500\" height=\"329\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.6-hyenas-750x493.jpg 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.6-hyenas-600x394.jpg 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.6-hyenas-768x505.jpg 768w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 500px) 100vw, 500px\" /></a></p> <p>In other stories, the protagonists have this vibe—</p> \n      <div id=\"eggNine\">\n       <div id=\"image-map-pro-4914\"></div>\n      </div> <p></p> <p>—while the bad guys are more doing this thing:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.8-Maleficentcastle-2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8472 \" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.8-Maleficentcastle-2-600x522.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"500\" height=\"435\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.8-Maleficentcastle-2-600x522.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.8-Maleficentcastle-2-768x668.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.8-Maleficentcastle-2-750x652.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.8-Maleficentcastle-2.png 865w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 500px) 100vw, 500px\" /></a></p> <p>The important thing is that the characters can be divided into clear digital 1s and 0s, because that’s the kind of story the Primitive Mind understands the best.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#footnote-14-8422\" id=\"note-14-8422\" rel=\"footnote\">14</a> <p>In the U.S., when the Democrats imagine their Republican opponents, they tend to see them as Mr. Mean Man. Mr. Mean Man takes a few forms, usually one of these:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.9-Mr-Mean-Man.jpg\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8473 size-large\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.9-Mr-Mean-Man-750x547.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"547\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.9-Mr-Mean-Man-750x547.jpg 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.9-Mr-Mean-Man-600x438.jpg 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.9-Mr-Mean-Man-768x561.jpg 768w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> <p>In the Democrat Disney kingdom, the traditional narrative tells the story of righteous Democrats in a continual struggle to pull the country upwards to a liberal utopia as mean, bigoted Mr. Mean Man uses all his weight to try to pull the country back down into an underwater Backwards Land of all-powerful corporations run by gun-swinging Nazi rapists.</p> <p>On the other side of things, the low-rung Republican narrative paints their Them group—the Democrats—as Miss Shitty Pants, who might be depicted like any number of these:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.10-Ms-Shitty-Pants-v2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8682 size-large\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.10-Ms-Shitty-Pants-v2-750x583.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"583\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.10-Ms-Shitty-Pants-v2-750x583.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.10-Ms-Shitty-Pants-v2-600x467.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/17.10-Ms-Shitty-Pants-v2-768x597.png 768w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> <p>In the Republican Disney kingdom, the standard story looks a little different. It’s about the honest, hard-working families doing their best to stand their ground as the stupid, lazy, morally defunct Miss Shitty Pants tries her hardest to pull the country down into a dystopian hell of a tyrannical government run by ivory tower elitists that gives endless handouts to hordes of gay, Muslim immigrant terrorists.</p> <p>In high-rung politics, it’s understood that people aren’t 1s and 0s—they’re all 0.5s, each in their own messy, complicated, unique way. And to people who see people as 0.5s, it’s clear that PDW narratives not only dehumanize their opponents, they dehumanize <em>everybody</em> into fake cartoon people.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/18-dehumanization-1.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8622\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/18-dehumanization-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"480\" height=\"318\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/18-dehumanization-1.png 1050w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/18-dehumanization-1-600x397.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/18-dehumanization-1-768x508.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/18-dehumanization-1-750x496.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 480px) 100vw, 480px\" /></a></p> <p>Digitizing people is a practice in <em>moral dualism</em>. The world of low-rung religion (Religious Disney World) does this all the time, with their gods and devils, their believers and infidels, their heaven and hell. Political Disney World does the same thing, just using different terms. A digital people mentality is why people in PDW rarely marry someone with opposing political views (something people in the high-rung political world do all the time). It’s why people in PDW tend to feel an endless well of compassion and understanding for bullies, blunderers, and criminals within the protagonist group, while dropping all semblance of empathy for bad actors on the evil side.</p> <p style=\"font-size:28px\"><strong>How PDW Narratives Digitize Ideas</strong></p> <p>Political Disney World is also big on digitizing ideas, using one of PDW’s defining features: the checklist. A narrative’s checklist allows its thinkers to trade in the gray mess of nuanced “What Is,” “What Should Be,” and “How to Get from A to B” debates for a perfectly digitized list of binary issues with a Good, Correct Stance and an Evil, Wrong Stance. In the U.S. narratives, the current checklist includes items like these:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/19-checklist.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8476 size-large\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/19-checklist-417x750.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"417\" height=\"750\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/19-checklist-417x750.png 417w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/19-checklist-333x600.png 333w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/19-checklist.png 601w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 417px) 100vw, 417px\" /></a></p> <p>In each case, what is treated as a complex debate up on the high rungs digitizes out to perfect cartoon simplicity down below.</p> <p>Some telltale signs that people are deriving their viewpoints from a checklist:</p> \n       <ul> \n        <li>They abide faithfully by the entire list of protagonist viewpoints, with no exceptions. They can scan down their side of the above checklist and, without hesitation, check off every box.</li> \n        <li>For each issue, they tend to see the Them stance as having 0% merit.</li> \n        <li>They have strong feelings about the <em>specific </em>issues highlighted by the checklist but have little to say about all the other issues that matter to their country. Issues played up in the media are like plotlines in the Disney movie narrative, which you’ll hear constant emotional discussion about, while other issues are like plotlines that didn’t make it into the movie’s final cut—and in PDW, you won’t hear people talking about them at all.</li> \n       </ul> <p>Anytime a bunch of adults are pretty sure that they live in a Disney movie, there can only be one explanation:</p> <p>They’ve been sucked into the Power Games.</p> <p class=\"has-large-font-size\"><strong>New World, Old Games</strong></p> <p>The Power Games, as you’ll recall, is what humans evolved to do a long, long time ago. They’re super simple, with the only rule being:</p> <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><strong><em>Everyone can do whatever they want, if they have the power to pull it off.</em></strong></p> <p>Our Primitive Minds only know how to make sense of the world through the Power Games lens—and when people in modern societies are playing the Power Games, it’s a sign that Primitive Minds have hijacked the culture. Primitive Mind smoke is like a virus, and when a culture becomes permeated with it, it spreads through minds like an epidemic. Soon, almost everyone is convinced that they live in a Disney movie, where everything is 1s and 0s, and they’re the good guys—allowing the Power Games to rule the day.</p> <p>In Chapter 4, <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/09/american-brain.html#equality\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">I laid out the American notion of fairness</a>&nbsp;using this graph:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/20.0-Fairness-Diagram.png\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8477\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/20.0-Fairness-Diagram.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1381\" height=\"1148\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/20.0-Fairness-Diagram.png 1381w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/20.0-Fairness-Diagram-600x499.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/20.0-Fairness-Diagram-768x638.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/20.0-Fairness-Diagram-750x623.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1381px) 100vw, 1381px\" /></a></p> <p>The graph is a bit complicated (<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/09/american-brain.html#equality\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">go here</a>&nbsp;for a full refresher), but the basic idea is that the U.S. is based on a freedom/equality compromise. The U.S. Zone represents the region of compromise that the country is supposed to stay in at all times. The areas outside the U.S. Zone are restricted because those areas would mean the Power Games has taken over.</p> <p>In theory, the two American political parties are somewhere around here:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/20.0.1-Fairness-Diagram.png\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8478\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/20.0.1-Fairness-Diagram.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1381\" height=\"1148\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/20.0.1-Fairness-Diagram.png 1381w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/20.0.1-Fairness-Diagram-600x499.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/20.0.1-Fairness-Diagram-768x638.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/20.0.1-Fairness-Diagram-750x623.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1381px) 100vw, 1381px\" /></a></p> <p>Inevitably, a lot of Americans who read this chapter will yell at me and say I’m committing a gross false equivalency. Their reasoning will be that while their party is indeed behaving themselves neatly inside the U.S. Zone, the <em>other </em>party is playing all kinds of Power Games in the restricted areas.</p> <p>People on the Left will say it’s like this:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/20.1-Fairness-Diagram.png\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8479\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/20.1-Fairness-Diagram.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1381\" height=\"1209\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/20.1-Fairness-Diagram.png 1381w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/20.1-Fairness-Diagram-600x525.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/20.1-Fairness-Diagram-768x672.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/20.1-Fairness-Diagram-750x657.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1381px) 100vw, 1381px\" /></a></p> <p>People on the Right will tell this story:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/20.2-Fairness-Diagram-v2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8681 size-full\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/20.2-Fairness-Diagram-v2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1381\" height=\"1209\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/20.2-Fairness-Diagram-v2.png 1381w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/20.2-Fairness-Diagram-v2-600x525.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/20.2-Fairness-Diagram-v2-768x672.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/20.2-Fairness-Diagram-v2-750x657.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1381px) 100vw, 1381px\" /></a></p> <p>The thing is though, there are ample studies that suggest both parties are pretty similarly <a href=\"https://www.researchgate.net/publication/256050159_The_Ideological-Conflict_Hypothesis\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">intolerant</a> and similarly <a href=\"https://www.researchgate.net/publication/316164633_At_Least_Bias_Is_Bipartisan_A_Meta-Analytic_Comparison_of_Partisan_Bias_in_Liberals_and_Conservatives\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">biased</a>. Whether one is a bit worse than the other in any given year or decade is less important to our discussion than the fact that both are bad.</p> <p>Both parties are a bit challenged on the adult vs. grown-up thing, buying fully into the middle-school-esque “in-group/out-group” social structure—a classic sign of the Power Games. And both are totally down with gross negative generalizations of the out-group (John Cleese <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HLNhPMQnWu4\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">explains further</a>).</p> <p>On both sides of PDW, people would struggle to name three policies they like of a president on the Them side of things and three legitimate areas where an Us president has gone wrong—even though every president does a lot of good and bad things. People on both sides tend to believe that if only everyone in the country shared their viewpoints and values, all national problems would be solved. All signs of simplistic, tribal thinking. All signs of the Power Games.</p> <p>Probably the clearest sign of the Power Games is rampant hypocrisy. High-rung thinking is all about values and principles, and there’s an effort to remain consistent about them in the face of the inevitable tug of tribal attachment. But the Power Games has only one principle: power. As George Orwell succinctly said it in <em>1984</em>: “The object of power is power.”</p> <p>Channeling more Orwell, writer Andrew Sullivan <a href=\"http://nymag.com/intelligencer/2017/09/can-democracy-survive-tribalism.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">sums it up nicely</a>:</p> <p><em>George Orwell famously defined this mind-set as identifying yourself with a movement, “placing it beyond good and evil and recognising no other duty than that of advancing its interests.” It’s typified, he noted, by self-contradiction and indifference to reality. And so many severe critics of George W. Bush’s surveillance policies became oddly muted when Obama adopted most of them; Democrats looked the other way as Obama ramped up deportations to levels higher than Trump’s rate so far. Republicans, in turn, were obsessed with the national debt when Obama was in office, despite the deepest recession in decades. But the minute Trump came to power, they couldn’t be more enthusiastic about a tax package that could add trillions of dollars to it. No tribe was more federalist when it came to marijuana laws than liberals; and no tribe was less federalist when it came to abortion. Reverse that for conservatives. For the right-tribe, everything is genetic except homosexuality; for the left-tribe, nothing is genetic except homosexuality. During the Bush years, liberals inveighed ceaselessly against executive overreach; under Obama, they cheered when he used his executive authority to alter immigration laws and impose new environmental regulations by fiat.</em></p> <p>In the Power Games, principles will lose to power every time. While people in high-rung politics are criticized for flip-flopping on their <em>principles</em> (as in the above paragraph), PDW flip-floppers are criticized for the opposite reason: you get in trouble on the low rungs for flip-flopping on <em>policy positions</em> in an effort to stay <em>consistent</em> with principles. Integrity matters up high, loyalty matters down below.</p> <p>Liberalism itself is a set of principles, and in Political Disney World, people won’t hesitate to go illiberal if it helps with tribal victory. Beyond common PDW illiberal practices like selective empathy or being selectively supportive of core liberal rights like free speech, there’s the illiberal way people in PDW view democracy. When people in low-rung politics lose an election, they scream that they’re disenfranchised, they insist that the system must be broken,<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#footnote-15-8422\" id=\"note-15-8422\" rel=\"footnote\">15</a> and they have an impulse to overthrow the opposition leader. When their candidate wins, they say things like, “faith in democracy restored!”—i.e. democracy is only working when my candidate wins. This isn’t the mindset of someone who believes in democracy—it’s the mindset of someone who believes in dictatorship but who is stuck in a democracy.</p> <p>This is why it’s bad that the U.S. has come to redefine the word “liberal” as a synonym for “progressive.” While “progressive” is an x-axis word, “liberal” is a <em>y-axis</em> concept.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/22-liberal-illiberal.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8482\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/22-liberal-illiberal.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1200\" height=\"950\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/22-liberal-illiberal.png 1951w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/22-liberal-illiberal-600x475.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/22-liberal-illiberal-768x608.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/22-liberal-illiberal-750x594.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1200px) 100vw, 1200px\" /></a></p> <p>When we do a “zoom-up” on Emergence Tower, we’re reminded that what feels to PDW members like being a protagonist in a Disney movie is actually just being a uniform cell in a big, dumb, Power Games giant.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/23-low-rung-giants.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8483\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/23-low-rung-giants.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1200\" height=\"950\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/23-low-rung-giants.png 1951w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/23-low-rung-giants-600x475.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/23-low-rung-giants-768x608.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/23-low-rung-giants-750x594.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1200px) 100vw, 1200px\" /></a></p> \n       <div class=\"wbwAside\"> \n        <h3><strong>Variations in the Us/Them Divide Blue Box</strong></h3> \n        <p>People with a Power Games mentality will almost always divide into the Us vs. Them format—the thing that varies is how big the giants in question are. This is what that Bedouin proverb is getting at (feel free to refresh yourself on <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/08/giants.html#bedouin\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">my cartoon depiction</a>):</p> \n        <p style=\"text-align: center;\"><em>Me against my brothers; my brothers and me against my cousins; my cousins, my brothers, and me against strangers.</em></p> \n        <p>During primary season of elections in the U.S. the Us/Them divides move down Emergence Tower to the “me against my brother” level, as factions within each side go at it.</p> \n        <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/23A.1-giants-on-globe.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8485\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/23A.1-giants-on-globe.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1000\" height=\"633\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/23A.1-giants-on-globe.png 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/23A.1-giants-on-globe-600x380.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/23A.1-giants-on-globe-768x486.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/23A.1-giants-on-globe-750x475.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px\" /></a></p> \n        <p>During a war, the Us/Them divide moves upward on Emergence Tower to the “whole family against strangers” level, temporarily uniting the country as one big Us.</p> \n        <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/23A.2-giants-on-globe.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8486\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/23A.2-giants-on-globe.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1000\" height=\"633\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/23A.2-giants-on-globe.png 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/23A.2-giants-on-globe-600x380.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/23A.2-giants-on-globe-768x486.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/23A.2-giants-on-globe-750x475.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px\" /></a></p> \n        <p>But those are special circumstances. In normal times, the U.S. likes to be at the “cousins” level in between, where one half of the U.S. is pitted against the other half.</p> \n        <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/23A.3-giants-on-globe.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8487\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/23A.3-giants-on-globe.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1000\" height=\"633\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/23A.3-giants-on-globe.png 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/23A.3-giants-on-globe-600x380.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/23A.3-giants-on-globe-768x486.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/23A.3-giants-on-globe-750x475.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px\" /></a></p> \n        <p>Since this is the norm, we’ll focus on these two big national factions.</p> \n       </div> <p style=\"font-size:32px\"><strong>Keeping the giants glued together</strong></p> <p>Each giant’s guiding narrative, which feels so much like reality to the people inside it, is just another <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/09/stories.html#superglue\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">superglue story</a>.</p> <p>If high-rung politics is micro-divided and macro-united (people disagree, giants work together), low-rung politics is the opposite: micro-united (people in a giant all agree) and macro-divided (giants are enemies with other giants). Keeping things this way is the critical objective of the superglue story:</p> <p style=\"font-size:28px\"><strong>Keeping things micro-united</strong></p> <p>A low-rung tribe is like an ant colony, and it needs all of the ants in solid agreement and working together. This isn’t always easy, given the motley crew that makes up a PDW faction. This crew includes a few classic types, each there for their own reasons.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/24-political-protest.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8484\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/24-political-protest.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"800\" height=\"307\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/24-political-protest.png 2011w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/24-political-protest-600x230.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/24-political-protest-768x294.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/24-political-protest-750x288.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px\" /></a></p> <p>Some prominent members of any PDW faction:</p> <p><strong>Zealots: </strong>People who believe every word of the narrative.</p> <p><strong>Tribalists: </strong>People who love being part of a big, powerful in-group and talking shit about the out-group. These people were usually either super popular in middle school and use politics to relive their glory days or super unpopular in middle school and use politics to revel in the other side of things.</p> <p><strong>Opportunists: </strong>People who use politics to gain social status or career advancement, to sell books, to get clicks, or any other number of ways politics can generate profit.</p> <p><strong>Soul-searchers: </strong>People who have been convinced that politics can be a get-rich-quick scheme for meaning, purpose, intellectual conviction, moral conviction, self-esteem boosting, or any other parts of life that are, in reality, far harder than that to achieve. These people are also great candidates to buy weight-loss pills guaranteed to make you skinny with no work and snake oil balm guaranteed to make your hair grow back or your money back.</p> <p><strong>Intellectual townies: </strong>A me-coined term I’m super proud of. People who never “move out of their childhood hometown,” intellectually or morally.</p> <p><strong>Undercover high-rung thinkers: </strong>These people’s minds are up on the high rungs, but the low-rung culture they’re immersed in has successfully intimidated them into keeping their mouths shut.</p> <p>As far as the giant is concerned, this odd coalition falls into two categories:&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/25.1-IS-OS.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8488\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/25.1-IS-OS.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1000\" height=\"535\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/25.1-IS-OS.png 2778w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/25.1-IS-OS-600x321.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/25.1-IS-OS-768x411.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/25.1-IS-OS-750x401.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/25.1-IS-OS-374x200.png 374w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px\" /></a></p> <p>And the important thing is making sure that on the outside, things stay like this:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/25.2-IS-OS.jpg\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8489\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/25.2-IS-OS.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1200\" height=\"679\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/25.2-IS-OS.jpg 5725w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/25.2-IS-OS-600x339.jpg 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/25.2-IS-OS-768x434.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/25.2-IS-OS-750x424.jpg 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1200px) 100vw, 1200px\" /></a></p> <p>That means making sure that everyone who believes the narrative continues to believe the narrative and everyone who doesn’t believe the narrative continues to pretend like they do (either out of fear or profiteering). The sacred narrative baby must always be said to be cute. This is what it means for a tribe to be micro-united.</p> <p style=\"font-size:28px\"><strong>Keeping things macro-divided</strong></p> <p>As the Bedouin proverb reminds us, in the Power Games, the best glue of all is a good common enemy. And the bigger a giant you want to build, the bigger the common enemy you’ll need to keep things glued together—because if the Them giant isn’t big enough, the Us giant will inevitably fracture into a new Us/Them structure. To serve this cause, low-rung political giants will typically frame politics as a zero-sum game—one in which the goals of the good guys can only come as a result of the bad guys losing (and vice versa). And they’ll focus a ton of energy on the part of the narrative that talks about how stupid, ignorant, evil, bigoted, opportunistic, sneaky, toxic, backward, selfish, and most importantly dangerous the bad guys are, making lots of memes like this:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#footnote2-5-8422\" id=\"note2-5-8422\" rel=\"footnote2\">5</a> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/26.1-republican-brain.jpg\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8490\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/26.1-republican-brain.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"570\" height=\"502\" /></a></p> <p>And this:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#footnote2-6-8422\" id=\"note2-6-8422\" rel=\"footnote2\">6</a> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/26.2-democrat-brain.png\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8491\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/26.2-democrat-brain.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"400\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/26.2-democrat-brain.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/26.2-democrat-brain-103x70.png 103w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a></p> <p>Citizens of Political Disney World will be even better trained to rattle off the narrative’s story about how bad the bad guys are than they are to rattle off why the good guys are good.</p> <p>The bad-guys-are-bad part of the narrative is especially important because on top of its common-enemy glue benefits, it is the critical foil the story’s protagonists need in order to feel like protagonists. Without Jafar, Aladdin is no longer a hero—he’s just some guy. That’s why Mr. Mean Man has to always be super mean and Miss Shitty Pants has to always stay shitty-pantsed.</p> <p style=\"font-size:32px\"><strong>Protecting the glue</strong></p> <p>Power Games giants glued together by belief in a certain story need a very specialized environment to survive. Unlike the inherent robustness of values-based high-rung giants, Power Games giants are brittle and vulnerable. When you rely on people fervently believing an all-encompassing, mostly fictional reality when real reality is all around them, you need to maintain a lot of control to keep things in order.</p> <p>The sacred narrative would be torn to shreds in the marketplace of ideas outside the kingdom’s walls, where high-rung thinkers roam and no idea is safe from criticism. Loyalists would be not only told but shown clear evidence that Disney World isn’t a real place, like when a shitty five-year-old bursts the kindergarten class’s bubble by spilling the truth about Santa Claus. Unacceptable.</p> <p>Traditionally, brittle Power Games giants have avoided having their bubble burst with strict laws that control the flow of information—like King Mustache’s laws in <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/09/mute-button.html#censorship\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Hypothetica</a>. But in a country with laws like the First Amendment, Echo Chambers are forced to police speech with culture. The right culture can serve as a filter system, which both enriches the giant with glue-strengthening narrative confirmation and protects the giant from every Power Games giant’s kryptonite—doubt.</p> <p style=\"font-size:28px\"><strong>The PDW Giant’s Filter System</strong></p> <p style=\"font-size:24px\"><strong>1) The Media Filter</strong></p> <p>In today’s world, every political Echo Chamber giant has its own media channels, which serve as the giant’s eyes and ears. These media channels are for the Echo Chamber, by the Echo Chamber, and they’re the first line of defense in upholding the giant’s belief in the sacred narrative. To keep the giant strong and well-fed, they sensationalize the stories that confirm the narrative, like an amplifier. To keep the giant free of intellectual contamination, they downplay stories that challenge the narrative or neglect to report them at all.</p> <p>On any given day, just do a side-by-side at <a href=\"http://foxnews.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">foxnews.com</a> and <a href=\"http://msnbc.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">msnbc.com</a>, or <a href=\"http://breitbart.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">breitbart.com</a> and <a href=\"https://www.huffpost.com/news/politics\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">huffpost.com/news/politics</a>, or <a href=\"http://townhall.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">townhall.com</a> and <a href=\"https://www.salon.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">salon.com</a>, and you’ll see the two major U.S. filters at work. One amplifies a story, the other muffles it. When they do report on the same story, their framings reverse who the protagonists and antagonists are, to mold the story to fit the narrative (Scott Alexander lays out some good examples <a href=\"https://slatestarcodex.com/2014/10/16/five-case-studies-on-politicization/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">here</a>—and <a href=\"https://pudding.cool/2018/01/chyrons/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">this</a> is kind of interesting).</p> <p style=\"font-size:24px\"><strong>2) The Sharing Filter</strong></p> <p>If the Media Filter determines what ends up in the PDW giant’s brain, the Sharing Filter sets the rules about how information circulates through the brain.</p> <p>A key safeguard against those in the tribe who don’t actually believe the narrative, the giant’s political culture provides powerful social incentives to keep everyone’s Outer Selves in line and saying the right things.</p> <p>Expressing narrative confirmation is socially rewarded while challenging the narrative is laden with taboo. Because remember how the Agreement-Decency thing works in an Echo Chamber:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/31.1-agreement-decency-v2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8710\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/31.1-agreement-decency-v2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1000\" height=\"702\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/31.1-agreement-decency-v2.png 1650w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/31.1-agreement-decency-v2-600x421.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/31.1-agreement-decency-v2-768x539.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/31.1-agreement-decency-v2-750x527.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px\" /></a></p> <p>The Media Filter will never be perfect, but the Sharing Filter can clean up the mess. When compelling alternative viewpoints make it into the giant’s brain, they have hard time making it very far, as every neuron in the brain is socially incentivized not to pass it along to other neurons. The same system works as a market for narrative confirmation. When people share narrative confirmation, the most snappily worded and convincingly argued receive the biggest rewards when they’re shared, which then incentivizes others to share them too (Twitter retweet numbers are a nice example). The best of the best pieces of confirmation go viral, spreading like wildfire through the Echo Chamber.</p> <p style=\"font-size:24px\"><strong>3) The Individual Bias Filter</strong></p> <p>Any scraps of compelling dissent not caught by the first two filters usually meet their doom at the gates of the final filter—the biases of the giant brain’s neurons: individual minds. Those who do believe the narrative are thinking from the low rungs, in <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/09/thinking-ladder.html#unfalsifiable\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Unfalsifiable Land</a>, where they’ll use all of those low-rung tricks from <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/09/thinking-ladder.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Chapter 7</a> to make sure to stay unconvinced by any dissent that manages to reach them.</p> <p>Low-rung political thinkers, <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/09/thinking-ladder.html#attorney\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Reasoning While Motivated</a>, will do the “Can I believe this?” / “Must I believe this?” <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/09/thinking-ladder.html#toggle\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">toggle</a>&nbsp;on their Skepticism Meter:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/28-Skepticism-Spectrum.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8492\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/28-Skepticism-Spectrum.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1200\" height=\"574\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/28-Skepticism-Spectrum.png 1665w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/28-Skepticism-Spectrum-600x287.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/28-Skepticism-Spectrum-768x367.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/28-Skepticism-Spectrum-750x359.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1200px) 100vw, 1200px\" /></a></p> <p>Like <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/09/thinking-ladder.html#trains\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">trains in biased motion</a>, they’ll see any skeptics of their beliefs as worse thinkers than they actually are, making it easy to disregard the info right off the bat.</p> \n         <div class=\"wbwAside\"> \n          <h3><strong>The Thanksgiving Dinner Table Hideous Political Conversations Blue Box</strong></h3> \n          <p>It’s this third filter that lies behind phenomena like the whole “Oh my god I’m dreading the political conversations at the Thanksgiving dinner table so much” thing. When I hear someone say this, I know one of three things is happening:</p> \n          <p>1) The person talking about their Thanksgiving dread is part of a low-rung political giant and they’re dreading the one day of the year when they’re with high-rung political family members who will challenge them.</p> \n          <p>2) Same as #1 except the dreaded family members are also low-rung political thinkers, from the opposite Disney kingdom.</p> \n          <p>3) The person is a high-rung political thinker who is dreading their annual interaction with low-rung political family members.</p> \n          <p>Low-rung dreading high-rung, low-rung dreading low-rung, or high-rung dreading low-rung. The one thing I know is <em>not </em>the case is a high-rung thinker dreading interaction with a high-rung thinker who disagrees with them, since high-rung thinkers don’t dread having political conversations with each other. At least one of the parties involved in a nightmarish Thanksgiving political conversation is from the low-rung political world. And they’re dreading it because it’s a moment when their usual info guardians—the Media Filter and the Sharing Filter—will not be able to shield them. They’ll be exposed to challenges to the sacred narrative they identify with, and they’ll have no tools to handle that interaction. So the third, final filter of individual unfalsifiability will be left to fend off the challenge, which tends to make for an unpleasant interaction.</p> \n         </div> <p>We can imagine these three filters looking something like this:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/29.1-filters-key.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8493 size-large\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/29.1-filters-key-750x571.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"571\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/29.1-filters-key-750x571.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/29.1-filters-key-600x457.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/29.1-filters-key-768x585.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/29.1-filters-key.png 1083w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> <p>While high-rung giants gauge their filters to expose the truth, we can see how PDW filters work hand-in-hand to keep the giant glue strong.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#footnote-16-8422\" id=\"note-16-8422\" rel=\"footnote\">16</a> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/29.2-filters-v2.jpg\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8685\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/29.2-filters-v2.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1100\" height=\"517\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/29.2-filters-v2.jpg 1892w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/29.2-filters-v2-600x282.jpg 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/29.2-filters-v2-768x361.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/29.2-filters-v2-750x352.jpg 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1100px) 100vw, 1100px\" /></a></p> <p>But Political Disney World doesn’t stop there. The filter system is great for managing the world’s real information, but when real information doesn’t cut it, a political giant has to take matters into its own hands.</p> <p style=\"font-size:28px\"><strong>Fallacies</strong></p> <p>If there’s one thing we’ve established in this series, it’s that humans aren’t good at reality. For us, trying to figure out what’s right and what’s real is like an obstacle course lined with cognitive pitfalls. The smartest people I know spend a <em>huge </em>amount of effort trying to become experts on their own irrational tendencies in order to become better thinkers, and they’re still pretty bad at reality. That’s why the high-rung Idea Lab culture is so important—it turns the reality obstacle course into a team effort.</p> <p>But what if reality isn’t your goal? What if reality is itself the obstacle?</p> <p>Political Disney World turns confirmation bias into its own team effort—it does confirmation bias on a systematic, industrial scale. And when the mission relies on people getting reality wrong, human cognitive deficiencies are invaluable tools.</p> <p>One such tool is the fallacy. If human reasoning is an outdated 1.0 software program, fallacies are the glitches and bugs.</p> <p>We fall victim to fallacies by mistake all the time. A classic example is the sunk cost fallacy. As an untalented illustrator, I learned long ago that it’s usually a terrible idea to draw elaborate backgrounds in my illustrations. Just draw the three stick figures talking over a white background—skip the street and the trees and the sky and the sidewalk they’re standing on.
