And yet—sometimes I forget that lesson and decide to get all Bob Ross, like “well what if…what if I just put a happy little tree over there next to the people…well that looks weird like a floating tree…so I’ll make some ground…how do you make ground again?…I’ll try drawing a line…that looks bad…ooh okay I’ll draw grass…” Suddenly it’s 18 minutes later and I’m drawing individual strands of grass and questioning my entire existence.</p> <p>At that point, a little part of my brain is like, “So you’re about halfway into finishing this background. The background doesn’t look good. It looks bad. The drawing would be better without it. It was a cute idea but it failed. So just delete the background and move on.”</p> <p>And then a much bigger, glitchier part of my brain is like, “Huh? No. Of course I’m not deleting this bad background I just spent 18 minutes doing half of. That would be a total waste of 18 minutes—which would be incredibly unsatisfying. I’m not allowing those 18 minutes to go to waste. I’m finishing the background. If it makes the drawing worse, then that’s just what’ll have to happen.”</p> <p>So I spend 18 more minutes finishing the background.</p> <p>Rationalist Julia Galef <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vpnxd31y0Fo\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">likens this situation</a> to walking to a store that’s 20 minutes away, only to learn 10 minutes into the walk that the store is closed… and then deciding to “finish the job” and walk all the way to the store anyway, since you already started. Obviously that would be deeply inane—but that’s exactly what I’m doing when I finish my bad background. To avoid having the 18 minutes I already spent go to waste, I’ll waste <em>another </em>18 minutes, even though the first 18 minutes is already gone and spent either way. It’s a sunk cost.</p> <p>We all commit the sunk cost fallacy. Sometimes it leads us to stick with jobs or relationships we know deep down are wrong for us. Sometimes we go the full distance with a long project even though, after having put some work into it, we’ve come to the realization that it wasn’t such a great idea. Sometimes we read the last 250 pages of a book we’re not liking very much because we’ve already read the first 100. In all cases, we do it because we simply can’t bear to acknowledge that some of our time has officially been wasted. So we double (or quadruple) down.</p> <p>It’s a reasoning error. It makes absolutely no sense—as Julia’s example illustrates—but we do it anyway. Because we’re bad at reality.</p> <p>The sunk cost is a famous one, but there are a <em>lot</em> of common fallacies. Wikipedia lists over 100 of them <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_fallacies\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">here</a>. Our reasoning software sucks.</p> <p>But fallacies aren’t always mistakes. If you’re trying to win an argument and you’re not doing so well, you might try pulling a fallacy out of your bag of dirty tricks. If your opponent doesn’t catch it, it’ll appear to be a beautiful point in your favor.</p> <p>Political Disney World is pretty big on both accidental and intentional fallacies. Let’s go through some of the most prevalent, in three categories:</p> <p style=\"font-size:24px\"><strong>Category 1: Fallacies that misrepresent reality</strong></p> <p>The practice of misrepresenting reality falls on a spectrum with “slight data nudging” on one end and “total fabrication” on the other. Low-rung politics has a long tradition of misrepresenting reality by concocting questionable studies and misleading statistics or by spinning real events in a way that best fits the narrative.</p> <p>A common type is what I call the <strong>Trend-Anecdote Swapper. </strong></p> <p>It’s simple: If you come across an anecdote that supports the narrative, you put it through the swapper and frame it as evidence of a larger <em>trend</em> to make it seem representative of broader reality. Meanwhile, if there’s an actual trend happening that really is representative of broader reality—but it’s a trend that makes your narrative look bad—you just put it through the swapper, and it’ll come out the other side framed as nothing more than a handful of freak anecdotes.</p> <p>For example, imagine your tribe’s narrative says that dogs are almost always good boys (and anyone who says otherwise is a bigot), while most raccoons are dangerous, vile creatures (and anyone who says otherwise is a bigot). Now imagine that one week, these six news stories happen:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.1-trend-anecdote-headlines-v2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8639 size-medium\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.1-trend-anecdote-headlines-v2-600x408.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"408\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.1-trend-anecdote-headlines-v2-600x408.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.1-trend-anecdote-headlines-v2-768x522.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.1-trend-anecdote-headlines-v2-750x510.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.1-trend-anecdote-headlines-v2-782x530.png 782w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.1-trend-anecdote-headlines-v2-345x234.png 345w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.1-trend-anecdote-headlines-v2-103x70.png 103w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.1-trend-anecdote-headlines-v2.png 1600w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a></p> <p>The actual reality here isn’t really your friend. Your narrative, like all PDW narratives, leaves no room for mixed messages. Dogs are good. Raccoons are bad. Period. Meanwhile, the actual information at hand here suggests that maybe both can be good sometimes and bad sometimes. So you pull out the Trend-Anecdote Swapper and get to work.</p> <p>You start by categorizing and color-coding the stories as they actually seem to be.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2-trend-anecdote-headlines-v2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8636\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2-trend-anecdote-headlines-v2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"850\" height=\"262\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2-trend-anecdote-headlines-v2.png 1660w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2-trend-anecdote-headlines-v2-600x185.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2-trend-anecdote-headlines-v2-768x237.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2-trend-anecdote-headlines-v2-750x231.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 850px) 100vw, 850px\" /></a></p> <p>Then, when there’s an inconvenient red trend, you use the Trend-Anecdote Swapper to reframe it as nothing more than an anecdote:&nbsp;<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2A.2-trend-anecdote-headlines-v3.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8690 size-full\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2A.2-trend-anecdote-headlines-v3.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1500\" height=\"414\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2A.2-trend-anecdote-headlines-v3.png 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2A.2-trend-anecdote-headlines-v3-600x166.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2A.2-trend-anecdote-headlines-v3-768x212.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2A.2-trend-anecdote-headlines-v3-750x207.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1500px) 100vw, 1500px\" /></a></p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2A.3-trend-anecdote-headlines.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8499 size-full\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2A.3-trend-anecdote-headlines.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1451\" height=\"484\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2A.3-trend-anecdote-headlines.png 1451w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2A.3-trend-anecdote-headlines-600x200.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2A.3-trend-anecdote-headlines-768x256.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2A.3-trend-anecdote-headlines-750x250.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1451px) 100vw, 1451px\" /></a></p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2A.4-trend-anecdote-headlines.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8500 size-full\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2A.4-trend-anecdote-headlines.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1425\" height=\"484\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2A.4-trend-anecdote-headlines.png 1425w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2A.4-trend-anecdote-headlines-600x204.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2A.4-trend-anecdote-headlines-768x261.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2A.4-trend-anecdote-headlines-750x255.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1425px) 100vw, 1425px\" /></a></p> <p>When there’s a helpful green anecdote, you use the Trend-Anecdote Swapper to make it seem like part of a larger trend.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2B.1-trend-anecdote-headlines-v2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8692 size-full\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2B.1-trend-anecdote-headlines-v2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1500\" height=\"415\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2B.1-trend-anecdote-headlines-v2.png 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2B.1-trend-anecdote-headlines-v2-600x166.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2B.1-trend-anecdote-headlines-v2-768x212.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2B.1-trend-anecdote-headlines-v2-750x208.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1500px) 100vw, 1500px\" /></a></p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2B.2-trend-anecdote-headlines.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8502 size-large\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2B.2-trend-anecdote-headlines-750x255.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"255\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2B.2-trend-anecdote-headlines-750x255.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2B.2-trend-anecdote-headlines-600x204.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2B.2-trend-anecdote-headlines-768x261.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2B.2-trend-anecdote-headlines.png 1426w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2B.3-trend-anecdote-headlines.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8503 size-large\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2B.3-trend-anecdote-headlines-750x250.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"250\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2B.3-trend-anecdote-headlines-750x250.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2B.3-trend-anecdote-headlines-600x200.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2B.3-trend-anecdote-headlines-768x256.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2B.3-trend-anecdote-headlines.png 1451w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2B.4-trend-anecdote-headlines.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8504 size-full\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2B.4-trend-anecdote-headlines.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1050\" height=\"484\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2B.4-trend-anecdote-headlines.png 1050w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2B.4-trend-anecdote-headlines-600x277.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2B.4-trend-anecdote-headlines-768x354.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.2B.4-trend-anecdote-headlines-750x346.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1050px) 100vw, 1050px\" /></a></p> <p>By the time you’re done, the colors have sorted themselves out nicely: red on the left, green on the right.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.3-trend-anecdote-headlines.png\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8648\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.3-trend-anecdote-headlines.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1745\" height=\"641\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.3-trend-anecdote-headlines.png 1745w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.3-trend-anecdote-headlines-600x220.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.3-trend-anecdote-headlines-768x282.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.3-trend-anecdote-headlines-750x276.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1745px) 100vw, 1745px\" /></a><a id=\"causation\"></a></p> <p>Another common fallacy uses what I call the <strong>Causation Arrow.</strong> The most 101 concept in Statistics 101 has to be: <em>correlation does not imply causation. </em></p> <p>A nice example, courtesy of <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Gatn5ameRr8\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Jonathan Haidt</a>: A <a href=\"https://www.iza.org/publications/dp/7529/the-effect-of-sexual-activity-on-wages\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">2013 study</a> found that <strong>people who have sex more often make more money.</strong> If you weren’t being cautious with your Causation Arrow, you might read a <a href=\"https://gawker.com/more-bang-for-your-buck-people-who-have-more-sex-make-1159315115?source=post_page---------------------------\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">headline</a> about the study and jump to the conclusion that having more sex <em>caused </em>people to make more money—or that making more money led people to have more sex. In reality, the study found that a third variable—<em>extraversion—</em>lies behind both the sex and money trends.</p> <p>Any correlation stat—”variable A is correlated with variable B”—actually leaves us with four possibilities:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/31.1-AB-correlation.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8505 \" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/31.1-AB-correlation-709x750.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"467\" height=\"494\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/31.1-AB-correlation-709x750.png 709w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/31.1-AB-correlation-567x600.png 567w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/31.1-AB-correlation-768x813.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/31.1-AB-correlation.png 1172w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 467px) 100vw, 467px\" /></a></p> <p>In high-rung politics, people assess every correlation and try to determine which of the above is actually going on. But in Political Disney World, people just go with whichever of the four possibilities best supports the narrative. They grab their Causation Arrow and point it in the most convenient direction.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/31.2.1-causation-arrow-1.jpg\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8506\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/31.2.1-causation-arrow-1.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"650\" height=\"1538\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/31.2.1-causation-arrow-1.jpg 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/31.2.1-causation-arrow-1-254x600.jpg 254w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/31.2.1-causation-arrow-1-768x1818.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/31.2.1-causation-arrow-1-317x750.jpg 317w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 650px) 100vw, 650px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/31.2.1-causation-arrow-2-v2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8649\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/31.2.1-causation-arrow-2-v2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"650\" height=\"1793\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/31.2.1-causation-arrow-2-v2.png 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/31.2.1-causation-arrow-2-v2-218x600.png 218w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/31.2.1-causation-arrow-2-v2-768x2118.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/31.2.1-causation-arrow-2-v2-272x750.png 272w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 650px) 100vw, 650px\" /></a>&nbsp;</p> <p>Of course, presidential debates are full of fighting over Causation Arrows. The incumbent candidate will claim that every positive trend during the past four years was caused by his presidency and every negative trend happened in spite of his great policies. The challenger candidate will say the opposite, in both cases.</p> <p>Returning to dog-raccoonville, imagine that this graph starts making the rounds on Twitter.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/31.3-graph-correlation-v2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8513 size-medium\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/31.3-graph-correlation-v2-600x505.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"505\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/31.3-graph-correlation-v2-600x505.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/31.3-graph-correlation-v2-768x647.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/31.3-graph-correlation-v2-750x632.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/31.3-graph-correlation-v2.png 876w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a></p> <p>If you’re in the “dogs good / raccoons bad” tribe, you won’t hesitate to pull out the Causation Arrow and use the graph as evidence that raccoons are hurting the city. If you’re in the pro-raccoons tribe, you’ll call the correlation a coincidence or ignore it altogether (and call anyone who shares the graph a bigot). In neither case will you actually be getting to the bottom of why unemployment is going up—which makes sense, because the goal in PDW isn’t a more perfect country, it’s political triumph.</p> <p>This is an example of how the Causation Arrow can also be used as a Blame Arrow. The pro-dog crowd could use the arrow to further nudge the day’s news in their favor by fiddling with blame in two of the stories:&nbsp;<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.4A-trend-anecdote-headlines.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8650\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.4A-trend-anecdote-headlines.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"850\" height=\"497\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.4A-trend-anecdote-headlines.png 2031w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.4A-trend-anecdote-headlines-600x351.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.4A-trend-anecdote-headlines-768x449.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.4A-trend-anecdote-headlines-750x438.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 850px) 100vw, 850px\" /></a></p> <p>Then, to top things off, the pro-dog media channels will add on their own twist:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.6-trend-anecdote-headlines.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8651\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.6-trend-anecdote-headlines.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"850\" height=\"541\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.6-trend-anecdote-headlines.png 1435w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.6-trend-anecdote-headlines-600x382.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.6-trend-anecdote-headlines-768x489.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.6-trend-anecdote-headlines-750x478.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 850px) 100vw, 850px\" /></a></p> <p>Of course, that’s just the pro-dog side of things. This whole time, the pro-raccoon tribe has been outraged about a whole different set of stories:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.7-trend-anecdote-headlines.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8652\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.7-trend-anecdote-headlines.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"850\" height=\"533\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.7-trend-anecdote-headlines.png 1371w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.7-trend-anecdote-headlines-600x376.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.7-trend-anecdote-headlines-768x481.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/30.7-trend-anecdote-headlines-750x470.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 850px) 100vw, 850px\" /></a></p> <p>One of the critical defining features of high-rung politics is a shared sense of reality—a shared understanding of <em>What Is</em>. In Political Disney World, the beliefs and viewpoints of people in different tribes are premised on entirely different conceptions of reality. Of <em>course</em> they can’t find any common ground.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#footnote-17-8422\" id=\"note-17-8422\" rel=\"footnote\">17</a> <p style=\"font-size:24px\"><strong>Category 2: Fallacies that misrepresent an argument</strong></p> <p>In <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/09/thinking-ladder.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Chapter 7</a>, we talked about how a viewpoint is nothing more than a hypothesis <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/09/thinking-ladder.html#testing\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">until it’s gone through testing</a>.</p> <p>The real test of any argument is how well it stands up in the face of rigorous criticism. When you’re confident in your viewpoint, you love a chance to throw it into the ring with other arguments and watch it show off its strength. Like real boxing, the stronger the opponents you’ve beaten, the better your ranking. That’s why a strong college paper always includes a strong counterargument—it lets the thesis “show off” in front of the professor.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.1.1-counter-argument.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8514\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.1.1-counter-argument-750x475.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"850\" height=\"538\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.1.1-counter-argument-750x475.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.1.1-counter-argument-600x380.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.1.1-counter-argument-768x486.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.1.1-counter-argument.png 1500w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 850px) 100vw, 850px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.1.2-counter-argument.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8515\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.1.2-counter-argument-750x475.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"850\" height=\"538\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.1.2-counter-argument-750x475.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.1.2-counter-argument-600x380.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.1.2-counter-argument-768x486.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.1.2-counter-argument.png 1500w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 850px) 100vw, 850px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.1.3-counter-argument-v2.jpg\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8612\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.1.3-counter-argument-v2.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"850\" height=\"505\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.1.3-counter-argument-v2.jpg 1912w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.1.3-counter-argument-v2-600x356.jpg 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.1.3-counter-argument-v2-768x456.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.1.3-counter-argument-v2-750x445.jpg 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 850px) 100vw, 850px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.1.4-counter-argument.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8517\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.1.4-counter-argument-750x450.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"850\" height=\"510\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.1.4-counter-argument-750x450.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.1.4-counter-argument-600x360.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.1.4-counter-argument-768x461.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.1.4-counter-argument.png 1500w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 850px) 100vw, 850px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.1.16-counter-argument.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8528 size-large\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.1.16-counter-argument-750x573.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"573\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.1.16-counter-argument-750x573.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.1.16-counter-argument-600x458.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.1.16-counter-argument-768x586.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.1.16-counter-argument.png 1496w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> <p>But what if you’re not so confident in your viewpoint? And you still want to make it seem like it can do well in the boxing ring? As a procrastinator who wrote a lot of hasty, shitty papers in college, I can tell you firsthand that one of the trademarks of a paper with a weak thesis is an even weaker counterargument.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.2.19-counter-argument.png\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8547\" href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.2.20-counter-argument.png\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8548\" href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.2.21-counter-argument.png\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8549\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.2.21-counter-argument.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1406\" height=\"779\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.2.21-counter-argument.png 1406w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.2.21-counter-argument-600x332.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.2.21-counter-argument-768x426.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.2.21-counter-argument-750x416.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1406px) 100vw, 1406px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.2.22-counter-argument.png\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8550\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.2.22-counter-argument.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"2365\" height=\"1227\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.2.22-counter-argument.png 2365w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.2.22-counter-argument-600x311.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.2.22-counter-argument-768x398.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.2.22-counter-argument-750x389.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 2365px) 100vw, 2365px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.2.23-counter-argument.png\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8551\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.2.23-counter-argument.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"2365\" height=\"1227\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.2.23-counter-argument.png 2365w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.2.23-counter-argument-600x311.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.2.23-counter-argument-768x398.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/32.2.23-counter-argument-750x389.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 2365px) 100vw, 2365px\" /></a></p> <p>When exposed to real opponents not afraid to tear apart bad arguments, oversimplified PDW narratives end up TKO’d in round 1. That’s why political Echo Chambers are so intent on making it taboo to criticize the narrative—it’s their way of banning anyone from landing a good hit on their sacred baby.</p> <p>But to generate the kind of intense conviction in its members that <em>of COURSE the narrative is correct</em>, political Echo Chambers need to make it <em>seem </em>like the narrative is a champion heavyweight boxer who demolishes anyone who tries to prove it wrong. So how can this happen when no actual living, breathing dissenters are allowed to fight the narrative?</p> <p>Here’s the trick: The Echo Chamber stages scripted fights that seem real to the Echo Chamber’s members, but where the narrative always comes out on top. To pull this off, they use one of the most tried and true tools of the low-rung intellectual world:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/33-man-machine.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8552 \" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/33-man-machine-413x600.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"275\" height=\"400\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/33-man-machine-413x600.png 413w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/33-man-machine.png 493w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 275px) 100vw, 275px\" /></a></p> <p>The man machine takes real criticism of the narrative and converts it into easy-to-beat opponents. Here are three of the most common:</p> <p class=\"has-medium-font-size\"><strong>The Straw Man</strong></p> <p>To make a Straw Man, the man machine reframes the wording of a strong dissenting argument, transforming it into a much weaker argument.</p> <p>To see how it works, let’s first watch a standard low-rung political narrative face off against real dissent from outside the Echo Chamber.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.1-straw-man.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8553\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.1-straw-man-498x750.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"450\" height=\"677\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.1-straw-man-498x750.png 498w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.1-straw-man-399x600.png 399w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.1-straw-man-768x1156.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.1-straw-man.png 934w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 450px) 100vw, 450px\" /></a></p> <p>As expected, that didn’t go very well. But the man machine can save the day.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.2-straw-man.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8554\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.2-straw-man.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"700\" height=\"1734\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.2-straw-man.png 1686w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.2-straw-man-242x600.png 242w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.2-straw-man-768x1902.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.2-straw-man-303x750.png 303w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px\" /></a></p> <p>We’ve all used this tactic.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.3a-straw-man.png\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8555\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.3a-straw-man.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"2204\" height=\"824\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.3a-straw-man.png 2204w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.3a-straw-man-600x224.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.3a-straw-man-768x287.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.3a-straw-man-750x280.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 2204px) 100vw, 2204px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.3b-straw-man.png\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8556\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.3b-straw-man.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"2204\" height=\"824\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.3b-straw-man.png 2204w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.3b-straw-man-600x224.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.3b-straw-man-768x287.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.3b-straw-man-750x280.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 2204px) 100vw, 2204px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.3c-straw-man.png\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8557\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.3c-straw-man.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"2204\" height=\"824\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.3c-straw-man.png 2204w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.3c-straw-man-600x224.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.3c-straw-man-768x287.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.3c-straw-man-750x280.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 2204px) 100vw, 2204px\" /></a></p> <p>When we create Straw Men, we sometimes do it knowingly, sometimes cluelessly. Most of the time, we probably do it with our subconscious knowing what we’re doing but our conscious mind in denial that we’re pulling a cheap trick.</p> <p>In <em>public</em> arguments, the goal of an arguer isn’t to change the opponent’s mind as much as it is to win over a viewing audience. Here, arguers will use Straw Men in hopes that the audience isn’t smart enough to notice the sleight of hand.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4a-straw-man-debate.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8558 size-large\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4a-straw-man-debate-750x362.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"362\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4a-straw-man-debate-750x362.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4a-straw-man-debate-600x289.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4a-straw-man-debate-768x370.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4a-straw-man-debate.png 1500w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4b-straw-man-debate.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8559 size-large\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4b-straw-man-debate-750x475.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"475\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4b-straw-man-debate-750x475.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4b-straw-man-debate-600x380.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4b-straw-man-debate-768x486.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4b-straw-man-debate.png 1500w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4c-straw-man-debate.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8560 size-large\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4c-straw-man-debate-750x475.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"475\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4c-straw-man-debate-750x475.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4c-straw-man-debate-600x380.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4c-straw-man-debate-768x486.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4c-straw-man-debate.png 1500w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4d-straw-man-debate.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8561 size-full\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4d-straw-man-debate.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1500\" height=\"950\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4d-straw-man-debate.png 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4d-straw-man-debate-600x380.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4d-straw-man-debate-768x486.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4d-straw-man-debate-750x475.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1500px) 100vw, 1500px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4e-straw-man-debate.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8562 size-large\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4e-straw-man-debate-750x475.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"475\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4e-straw-man-debate-750x475.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4e-straw-man-debate-600x380.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4e-straw-man-debate-768x486.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4e-straw-man-debate.png 1500w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4f-straw-man-debate.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8563 size-large\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4f-straw-man-debate-750x475.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"475\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4f-straw-man-debate-750x475.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4f-straw-man-debate-600x380.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4f-straw-man-debate-768x486.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4f-straw-man-debate.png 1500w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4g-straw-man-debate.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8564 size-large\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4g-straw-man-debate-750x475.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"475\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4g-straw-man-debate-750x475.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4g-straw-man-debate-600x380.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4g-straw-man-debate-768x486.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4g-straw-man-debate.png 1500w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4h-straw-man-debate.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8565 size-large\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4h-straw-man-debate-750x475.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"475\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4h-straw-man-debate-750x475.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4h-straw-man-debate-600x380.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4h-straw-man-debate-768x486.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.4h-straw-man-debate.png 1500w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> <p>Using a Straw Man can make you appear victorious to unwitting viewers, like a boxer who takes a swing at the balls mid-match and hopes the ref won’t see it. You wouldn’t think it could work, but humans are bad at reality, so straw-manning often goes unnoticed.</p> <p>In a courtroom or debate stage, the opposition at least has a chance to object to or refute a straw man attack. But usually, the opposition doesn’t get a voice at all.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#footnote2-7-8422\" id=\"note2-7-8422\" rel=\"footnote2\">7</a> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.5-obama.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8566\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.5-obama.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"1519\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.5-obama.png 1500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.5-obama-237x600.png 237w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.5-obama-768x1944.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/34.5-obama-296x750.png 296w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a></p> <p>In Political Disney World, when a cleverly worded Tweet or op-ed straw-mans the opposing side, it goes viral, and soon, the farce boxing match is played on loop throughout the Echo Chamber, ad nauseam.</p> <p class=\"has-medium-font-size\"><strong>The Weak Man</strong></p> <p>The Straw Man is a well-known fallacy. But in the past decade, people have begun talking about what political theorist Robert Talisse <a href=\"https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/getting-duped/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">calls</a> the Weak Man fallacy.</p> <p>Straw-manning takes a strong argument and distorts it into a weak one. Weak-manning takes a strong argument and hand-picks the weakest <em>part</em> of it, or the weakest <em>version</em> of it, and attacks that. When you handily defeat the weak argument, you then frame it as if you’ve defeated the argument, in general.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/35.A-full-mouse-comic.jpg\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8567\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/35.A-full-mouse-comic.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"700\" height=\"2486\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/35.A-full-mouse-comic.jpg 1762w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/35.A-full-mouse-comic-169x600.jpg 169w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/35.A-full-mouse-comic-768x2728.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/35.A-full-mouse-comic-211x750.jpg 211w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px\" /></a></p> <p>Partisan media are big fans of the Weak Man. People like Jon Stewart and Tucker Carlson have made entire careers out of weak-manning.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#footnote2-8-8422\" id=\"note2-8-8422\" rel=\"footnote2\">8</a> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/35.8-weak-politics.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8568 size-large\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/35.8-weak-politics-750x412.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"412\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/35.8-weak-politics-750x412.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/35.8-weak-politics-600x329.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/35.8-weak-politics-768x422.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/35.8-weak-politics-239x130.png 239w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/35.8-weak-politics.png 1517w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> <p>Weak-manning is why everyone in low-rung politics sees the other side as absolutely indefensible and unforgivable. They’ve been presented again and again with the worst of the other side’s low-rung giant, and they’ve come to believe that it’s representative of the other side as a whole.</p> <p class=\"has-medium-font-size\"><strong>The Hollow Man</strong></p> <p>The Hollow Man does away with the work of distorting or cherry-picking the dissenting argument and just fabricates one from scratch. Often framed by “some people say” or something else vague, the Hollow Man is the ideal opponent for the narrative—the easiest match possible.</p> <p>In 2004, in order to refute opponents of the Iraq War, George W. Bush <a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/2004/05/01/bush-cites-racism-in-remarks-on-iraq/96fd11ac-231f-4f41-9f94-ffe0d74028eb/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">said</a>:</p> <p>“There’s a lot of people in the world who don’t believe that people whose skin color may not be the same as ours can be free and self-govern…I reject that. I reject that strongly. I believe that people who practice the Muslim faith can self-govern. I believe that people whose skins aren’t necessarily—are a different color than white can self-govern.”</p> <p>In other words:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/36.A-hollow-man-1.jpg\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8569\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/36.A-hollow-man-1.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"700\" height=\"1685\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/36.A-hollow-man-1.jpg 1473w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/36.A-hollow-man-1-249x600.jpg 249w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/36.A-hollow-man-1-768x1849.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/36.A-hollow-man-1-312x750.jpg 312w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/36.A-hollow-man-2-v2.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8676\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/36.A-hollow-man-2-v2.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"700\" height=\"1696\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/36.A-hollow-man-2-v2.png 1473w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/36.A-hollow-man-2-v2-248x600.png 248w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/36.A-hollow-man-2-v2-768x1860.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/36.A-hollow-man-2-v2-310x750.png 310w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 700px) 100vw, 700px\" /></a></p> <p>The Hollow Man argument is a viewpoint held by no one at all, created just to make the opposition look as bad as possible. It seems like a ridiculous tactic—until you remember that Political Disney World is a ridiculous place. Today, in the enchanted castles of PDW, Hollow Men are roaming around everywhere.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/36.B-hollow-men.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8571 size-medium\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/36.B-hollow-men-600x451.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"451\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/36.B-hollow-men-600x451.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/36.B-hollow-men-768x577.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/36.B-hollow-men-750x563.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/36.B-hollow-men.png 1032w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a></p> <p>In PDW, the power of the man machine goes beyond winning individual arguments. In 1961, social psychologist William Maguire wrote about what he called the “inoculation effect.” Vaccines work by exposing a person’s immune system to a weak version of a dangerous virus. After the body defeats the weak version of the virus, it develops an immunity against all versions of the virus, including the strong ones. Maguire found that people’s beliefs worked in a similar way. He <a href=\"https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/027e/3e86960b86a59a552d8ed21bb9c4815b5a16.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">wrote</a>:</p> <p><em>[B]eliefs can be “inoculated” against persuasion in subsequent situations involving forced exposure to strong counterarguments by pre-exposing the person to the counterarguments in a weakened form that stimulates—without overcoming—his defenses.</em></p> <p>If Straw Man, Weak Man, and Hollow Man arguments are repeated enough inside a political Echo Chamber, they become people’s ubiquitous conception of what dissenters to the narrative think—eternal proof of how right the narrative is and how stupid anyone is who says otherwise. Soon, any version of dissenting arguments—even the strong ones—will be disregarded as nothing more than better-worded versions of the well-known absurd dissent. People will have become “immune” to changing their mind on the topic.</p> <p>This also makes it even less likely that anyone inside the Echo Chamber will dare challenge the narrative—because the second they do, people will hear it as a defense of all of those terrible arguments and evidence of the challenger’s own stupidity and awfulness. Social penalties will ensue.</p> <p>But argument-misrepresenting fallacies can do more than attack opponents. They can also be used for <em>defense</em>.</p> <p class=\"has-medium-font-size\"><strong>The Motte and Bailey</strong></p> <p>The “motte and bailey” fallacy is a recently named piece of age-old trickery (<a href=\"https://philpapers.org/rec/SHATVO-2\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">coined by</a> Nicholas Shackel and <a href=\"https://slatestarcodex.com/2014/11/03/all-in-all-another-brick-in-the-motte/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">further popularized by</a> Scott Alexander).</p> <p>The name comes from a type of two-part medieval fortification common in Northern Europe between the 10<sup>th</sup> and 13<sup>th</sup> centuries. It looked something like this:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.1-motte.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8572 size-large\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.1-motte-750x339.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"339\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.1-motte-750x339.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.1-motte-600x271.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.1-motte-768x347.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.1-motte.png 919w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> <p>The bailey is an area of land that was desirable and economically productive to live on but hard to defend. It would always be vulnerable to attack. That’s where the motte came in. A motte is a hill in or adjacent to the bailey with a wooden tower on top of it. When the bailey was threatened, inhabitants would run up the motte and into the tower. The motte, unlike the bailey, was easy to defend and nearly impossible to conquer—so invaders who captured the bailey would be unable to conquer the whole fortification. Eventually, with arrows raining down on them from the motte’s tower, the attackers would give up and leave, at which point the inhabitants could resume life in their pleasant and profitable bailey.</p> <p>Shackel used the motte and bailey as a metaphor for a cheap argument tactic, whereby someone holding a convenient but not-very-defensible “bailey” viewpoint could, when facing dissent to that viewpoint, quickly run up the motte and swap out the viewpoint with a far stronger “motte” position.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.2a-motte.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8573 size-full\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.2a-motte.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"973\" height=\"422\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.2a-motte.png 973w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.2a-motte-600x260.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.2a-motte-768x333.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.2a-motte-750x325.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 973px) 100vw, 973px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.2b-motte-1.png\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8609\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.2b-motte-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1252\" height=\"410\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.2b-motte-1.png 1252w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.2b-motte-1-600x196.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.2b-motte-1-768x252.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.2b-motte-1-750x246.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1252px) 100vw, 1252px\" /></a>&nbsp;<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.2c-motte.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8575 size-large\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.2c-motte-750x286.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"286\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.2c-motte-750x286.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.2c-motte-600x229.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.2c-motte-768x293.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.2c-motte.png 1155w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.2d-motte.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8576 size-large\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.2d-motte-750x277.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"277\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.2d-motte-750x277.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.2d-motte-600x222.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.2d-motte-768x284.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.2d-motte.png 1137w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a> <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.2e-motte.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8577 size-large\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.2e-motte-750x281.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"281\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.2e-motte-750x281.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.2e-motte-600x225.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.2e-motte-768x288.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.2e-motte.png 1175w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.2f-motte-1.png\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8608\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.2f-motte-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1470\" height=\"677\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.2f-motte-1.png 1470w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.2f-motte-1-600x276.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.2f-motte-1-768x354.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.2f-motte-1-750x345.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1470px) 100vw, 1470px\" /></a></p> <p>The motte and bailey is using the man machine reverse—instead of swapping an opponent’s strong argument for a weaker one, it swaps out your own questionable argument for an irrefutable one. The goal is to make it seem like the two arguments are essentially the same, and that anyone who agrees with the motte statement must also agree with the bailey argument. It’s an attempt to <em>stitch </em>one position to another and use it as armor.</p> <p>Political Disney World is a land of sprawling baileys, dotted with motte hills. And if you listen carefully, you’ll notice people darting up to their trusty mottes, using them as trump cards whenever their views come under fire.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.3-motte-examples.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8579\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.3-motte-examples.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"900\" height=\"1177\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.3-motte-examples.png 1818w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.3-motte-examples-459x600.png 459w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.3-motte-examples-768x1004.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/37.3-motte-examples-574x750.png 574w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 900px) 100vw, 900px\" /></a></p> <p>Fallacies that misrepresent arguments let people twist, mold, and fabricate arguments in order to engineer faux boxing matches. These tactics go a long way toward making the PDW giant nearly invincible to the outside world. But when all else fails, low-rung political thinkers can reach into their bag for the dirtiest trick of all:</p> <p style=\"font-size:24px\"><strong>Category 3: Fallacies that misrepresent people</strong></p> <p>Paul Graham once laid out what he calls his <a href=\"http://www.paulgraham.com/disagree.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">hierarchy of disagreement</a>, which can be summed up like this:<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#footnote2-9-8422\" id=\"note2-9-8422\" rel=\"footnote2\">9</a> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/38.1-hierarchy.png\"><img class=\"alignnone  wp-image-8582\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/38.1-hierarchy.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"632\" height=\"474\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/38.1-hierarchy.png 1200w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/38.1-hierarchy-600x450.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/38.1-hierarchy-768x576.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/38.1-hierarchy-750x563.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 632px) 100vw, 632px\" /></a></p> <p>According to Graham, the lowest forms of disagreement are attacks on the person arguing against you instead of the argument itself. On the very bottom level, name calling is the trashiest form of argumentation and the trademark of someone who knows they have little ability to win a real debate. Name-calling is also often a sign an argument’s substance isn’t really relevant because the disagreement is mostly a vehicle two people are using to vent anger onto each other. In any case, no one in human history has ever gotten to the bottom of anything while throwing insults. It can be fun though.</p> <p>One level up, you have the slightly more civilized ad hominem fallacy. People often use “ad hominem” as an umbrella term that includes name-calling, but here, we’re referring to the specific practice of discrediting dissent based on who the dissenter is instead of attacking the argument itself. Another form of ad hominem fallacy is bringing up your own authority on the matter as a way to add credibility to your argument.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/38.2-ad-hominem.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8583 \" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/38.2-ad-hominem-560x600.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"500\" height=\"536\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/38.2-ad-hominem-560x600.png 560w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/38.2-ad-hominem-768x823.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/38.2-ad-hominem-700x750.png 700w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/38.2-ad-hominem.png 887w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 500px) 100vw, 500px\" /></a></p> <p>In Political Disney World, ad hominem arguments happen constantly, partially because people on the low rungs are childish arguers—but also because on the low rungs, ad hominem arguments are incredibly effective. The reason they’re effective is that the less someone knows about the substance of an issue, <a href=\"https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-1-4612-4964-1_1\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">the more they’ll form their judgments</a> based on how much they trust the messenger. In low-rung politics, people who seem trustworthy also tend to <em>seem</em> correct and well-intentioned, regardless of the quality of their arguments. And vice versa.</p> <p>Standard tribalism takes care of most of the trust allotment. Earlier this year, professors Steven Sloman and Elke Weber compiled <a href=\"https://www.sciencedirect.com/journal/cognition/vol/188/suppl/C\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">a wide range of articles</a> exploring the science behind political polarization. Many of the <a href=\"https://behavioralscientist.org/the-cognitive-science-of-political-thought-practical-takeaways-for-political-discourse/\">findings</a> confirmed the intuitive: that people are highly uncharitable in their assumptions about those in their political out-group. For example, if an opposing candidate has mostly mainstream views but holds a few extreme positions, <a href=\"https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0010027718301240?via%3Dihub\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">people tend to make the assumption</a> that the candidate’s supporters voted for them <em>because of</em>, not <em>in spite of</em>, the candidate’s extreme positions. But there’s no evidence that this is true. Another study <a href=\"https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0010027718303196\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">found that</a> “constituents are likely to attribute the actions of in-group leaders as intended to benefit the country (national interests), and the actions of out-group leaders as intended to benefit the political leaders themselves (egoistic interests)”—even when the actions in question are identical.</p> <p>So people in PDW are already predisposed to not trust those who challenge the narrative—and therefore, to not believe their arguments, regardless of the substance. But a strong tradition of ad hominem reasoning helps cement this key stability mechanism.</p> <p>Enemies of a political Echo Chamber are regularly discredited based on their background, their religion, their race, their gender, their education, their profession, their friendships—none of which addresses whatever clearly-wrong, not-even-worth-listening-to argument they’re actually making.</p> <p>Dissenters are smeared by quotes pulled out of context, a tactic that can double up on misrepresenting the person <em>and </em>misrepresenting their argument. Often, a regrettable quote from a decade earlier is reason enough in PDW to rule out anything a dissenter ever says again—even if the dissenter swears they no longer believe that thing they said back then.</p> <p>If those don’t do the trick, there’s always mind-reading—where disciples of a narrative will assume the worst about the dissenter’s real, true, deep-down intentions (like people assuming that opposition candidates are motivated by selfishness while being more charitable with their preferred candidates). Political Disney World scales this up until everyone in the Echo Chamber is convinced that anyone who wants to curb immigration is racist, or everyone who opposes a war effort is unpatriotic, or everyone who supports tax cuts is greedy, or anything else that helps the Echo Chamber write off those who challenge the narrative.</p> <p>In the most extreme Echo Chambers, the discrediting of arguments and people form an interlocking chain of dismissal. Once a given position is branded as terrible and wrong, anyone holding that position is automatically branded as wrong-headed, which in turn leads people to write off all of their other positions as well. In other cases, once a well-known person is deemed by an Echo Chamber to be bad, their viewpoints become tarnished with the same reputation, which then extends to anyone else who happens to hold those same positions. It’s like a discredit disease that spreads.</p> <p>With a further step back, we can see how all of these fallacies work in tandem with the Echo Chamber’s information-filtering system. The filters let friendly info in, the fallacies twist it to make it even friendlier, then the filters further refine things by elevating the best-manipulated info into further prominence. This ongoing tag-team effort is so effective that not only will everyone in PDW have the same digitized viewpoint on every issue, they’ll be saying <em>the same exact sentences about it</em>, word for word.</p> <p>When everyone is saying the same thing, a feedback loop takes hold—the kind we talked about in Chapter 1 (when we were supposedly talking about our ancestors):</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/39-behavior-loop-with-cross-outs.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8584\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/39-behavior-loop-with-cross-outs.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1200\" height=\"1042\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/39-behavior-loop-with-cross-outs.png 3154w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/39-behavior-loop-with-cross-outs-600x521.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/39-behavior-loop-with-cross-outs-768x667.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/39-behavior-loop-with-cross-outs-750x652.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1200px) 100vw, 1200px\" /></a></p> <p>You can take humans out of the Power Games…</p> <p class=\"has-large-font-size\"><strong>Politics in 3D</strong></p> <p>Our Psych Spectrum has helped us see the usual left-center-right—</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/0-political-1D.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8439 size-large\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/0-political-1D-750x228.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"228\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/0-political-1D-750x228.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/0-political-1D-600x183.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/0-political-1D-768x234.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/0-political-1D.png 1479w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> <p>—in 2D, where it looks more like an arch.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/0-political-2D-arch-1.jpg\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8653\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/0-political-2D-arch-1.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1000\" height=\"831\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/0-political-2D-arch-1.jpg 2018w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/0-political-2D-arch-1-600x498.jpg 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/0-political-2D-arch-1-768x638.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/0-political-2D-arch-1-750x623.jpg 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px\" /></a></p> <p>Our third dimension—Emergence Tower—lets us see an even bigger picture. What looks like an arch of 300 million individuals on the lowest floor of Emergence Tower looks like four giants from higher up on the tower:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/40-arch-giants.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8585 size-full\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/40-arch-giants.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1449\" height=\"1418\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/40-arch-giants.png 1449w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/40-arch-giants-600x587.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/40-arch-giants-768x752.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/40-arch-giants-750x734.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1449px) 100vw, 1449px\" /></a></p> <p>The people who make up the high-rung giants aren’t that different from the people in the low-rung giants. But the giants themselves are nothing alike. Low-rung giants are the product of ancient human survival software—they’re the kinds of giants that the software builds when it’s able to run the show. In the high-rung giants, Higher Minds have managed to band together to define the culture and override the software’s usual output.</p> <p>In <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2019/09/enlightenment-kids.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Part 2</a>&nbsp;of this series, we kept things simple and imagined how a country like the U.S. might work in an ideal scenario. Under the First Amendment’s protection, the U.S. would become a grand marketplace of ideas where the minds of individual Americans would link up like neurons and form a giant superbrain. Individual thinking on most topics would yield a Thought Pile with a clean bell curve shape, and that shape would be lit up with activity by a Speech Curve that would sit right on top of it.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/41-SC-TP.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8586\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/41-SC-TP.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1000\" height=\"472\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/41-SC-TP.png 2100w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/41-SC-TP-600x283.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/41-SC-TP-768x363.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/41-SC-TP-750x354.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px\" /></a></p> <p>As people talked, the big brain would think, and over time, it would ooze its way along Thought Spectrums to ever wiser places.</p> <p>This is kind of what does happen in the U.S. today. Except there’s a big asterisk.</p> <p>What we didn’t talk about in Part 2 were the inevitable Echo Chambers that would resist Enlightenment Values and function culturally like mini dictatorships. Echo Chambers are like frozen spots in a free nation’s superbrain—dark regions of the brain where thinking can’t happen.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/42-frozen-spots.jpg\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8587\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/42-frozen-spots.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"1000\" height=\"757\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/42-frozen-spots.jpg 5855w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/42-frozen-spots-600x454.jpg 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/42-frozen-spots-768x581.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/42-frozen-spots-750x568.jpg 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px\" /></a></p> <p>If high-rung politics is a marketplace of ideas that yields bell curves along the Idea Spectrum, the frozen Echo Chambers of low-rung politics look more like tall vertical towers. Put together, they make most political topics look like a camel.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/43-camel.jpg\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8588\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/43-camel.jpg\" alt=\"\" width=\"2500\" height=\"1750\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/43-camel.jpg 2500w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/43-camel-600x420.jpg 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/43-camel-768x538.jpg 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/43-camel-750x525.jpg 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 2500px) 100vw, 2500px\" /></a></p> <p>A camel curve moves slower towards progress than a bell curve. The science and business worlds can advance quickly because bad ideas fail quickly. In the world of ideas, Echo Chambers, with their sacred and taboo viewpoints, keep bad ideas alive way longer they would in a normal marketplace. With so many voters locked up in the humps, politicians have to spend a lot of their energy catering to the low-rung ideas and speaking to the low-rung political mentality.
