The humps distort the shape of the Overton window, making the national brain less intelligent, less adaptable, less rational, and less wise.</p> <p>None of this means the system isn’t working. As we’ve discussed, the vision of the Enlightenment wasn’t to completely repress the human Primitive Mind—it was to ensure that unlike most societies in the past, the Primitive Mind wouldn’t be able to completely take over. It wasn’t meant to generate perfect bell curves of national thinking—it was meant to thaw out static frozen towers enough to end up with stubborn but movable camel humps. With a species like ours, this may be the best we can hope for.</p> <p>Let’s zoom out further. If we move another floor up Emergence Tower, we can see a country like the U.S. as two huge political giants.</p> <p>One way to do that is to slice our 2D political space down the middle vertically, leaving us with a Left giant and a Right giant.</p> <p>The real Left—the <em>complete </em>Left—is the combination of the high-minded, high-rung progressive giant up top and the primitive-minded, Power-Games-playing blue giant down below. Same deal for the Right.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/44.1-left-right.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8589 size-large\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/44.1-left-right-746x750.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"746\" height=\"750\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/44.1-left-right-746x750.png 746w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/44.1-left-right-150x150.png 150w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/44.1-left-right-597x600.png 597w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/44.1-left-right-768x772.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/44.1-left-right.png 945w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 746px) 100vw, 746px\" /></a></p> <p>Each of these giants is like a large-scale human being—the product of an internal struggle between fire and light.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/44.2-xray.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8590\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/44.2-xray.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1000\" height=\"1059\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/44.2-xray.png 1579w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/44.2-xray-567x600.png 567w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/44.2-xray-768x813.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/44.2-xray-708x750.png 708w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px\" /></a></p> <p>Each of us is on our own little mountain, ebbing and flowing in maturity and wisdom. We all have good days and bad days, good years and bad years. We’re each a mix of admirable qualities and character flaws, and we spend our lives trying to become a little better. We’re all human, and so is our society.</p> <p>Like each of us, the political Left and Right are in a constant struggle to grow up. Sometimes they’re childish. Sometimes they’re wise. Like each of us, they can grow up with age—and like each of us, they also sometimes revert and go backwards.</p> <p>Every person is working on two projects all the time: them against the world and them against themselves. High-rung political giants are in the same situation, fighting a two-front battle at all times: a horizontal battle against their high-rung counterpart, in the struggle to determine how the country changes and evolves; and a vertical battle against the low-rung giant that masquerades under the same political banner—a battle that, if lost, threatens to destroy their reputation, hijack its movements, and undermine its progress.</p> <p>There’s another way political parties are like people: in both cases, the individual struggle of one can influence the individual struggles of others nearby.</p> <p>When a couple gets into a fight, it’s often because their Primitive Minds have started going at it with each other. The Primitive Mind of one member of the couple doesn’t want to fight with the Higher Mind of the other—it wants to fight with its primitive little friend. When it’s worked up, it calls the other Primitive Mind out to play, and it usually gets a response. A vicious cycle takes hold as things quickly devolve into nastiness. When one of the Higher Minds in the couple manages to wrest control of their person for long enough to get a word in—something like, “I do see where you’re coming from, I’d feel frustrated in this situation too”—the fight pretty quickly winds down. Once the Higher Minds start communicating with each other, they can regain the edge and take control of the interaction.</p> <p>Between what I’ve observed about politics and what I’ve read about history, political giants seem to work the same way. If, instead of looking at the two-giant U.S. as Left versus Right, we slice our political region horizontally, we see two pairs that function as teams as much as they do as adversaries.</p> <p>The high-rung giants argue with each other constantly, but they know they’re ultimately on the same team with the same overarching goal. It’s harder to see it on the bottom, but the low-rung giants are a team too. Remember, without Jafar, Aladdin is just some guy. The low-rung giants <em>need </em>their counterpart. It’s the key villain in their narrative—the key uniting force that holds everything together. Nothing delights members of a low-rung giant more than the other low-rung giant behaving badly. It makes them furious, but in a super fun way. It lights their fires and injects meaning into their lives. And it justifies a wave of their own childish behavior, which in turn fires up their rival giant even more—like what happens to a couple as they descend into a nastier and nastier fight. When the low-rung giants really get each other riled up, the high-rung giants become increasingly helpless and muted.</p> <p>People in the high-rung political world think of politics as a positive-sum game, and the way they do politics, it is. The clash of the high-rung giants is a classic Value Games clash—it yields progress and wisdom.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/45.1-clash.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8591 \" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/45.1-clash-435x600.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"375\" height=\"517\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/45.1-clash-435x600.png 435w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/45.1-clash-544x750.png 544w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/45.1-clash.png 551w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 375px) 100vw, 375px\" /></a></p> <p>In the low-rung political world, politics is seen as a zero-sum game—when one side wins, the other loses, and that’s that. But the actual game they’re playing ends up being <em>negative</em>-sum. Their fighting pulls the country downward on the same mountain the high-rung giants are trying to climb.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/45.2-clash.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8592 \" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/45.2-clash-548x750.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"550\" height=\"753\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/45.2-clash-548x750.png 548w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/45.2-clash-438x600.png 438w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/45.2-clash-768x1051.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/45.2-clash.png 1139w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 550px) 100vw, 550px\" /></a></p> <p>I finished Part 2 with a depiction of the U.S., trudging up the mountain on its mission to become a more perfect nation:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/46.2-mountain.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8593 size-large\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/46.2-mountain-750x475.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"475\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/46.2-mountain-750x475.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/46.2-mountain-600x380.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/46.2-mountain-768x486.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/46.2-mountain.png 1500w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> <p>Back then, we could only see the nation as it looked on the surface. Now, with some more tools in our bag, we can look deeper into the image and see the situation for what I’ve come to believe it really is: an eternal tug-of-war between the nation’s collective Higher Mind and the nation’s collective Primitive Mind.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/46.1-mountain.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8594 size-large\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/46.1-mountain-750x475.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"750\" height=\"475\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/46.1-mountain-750x475.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/46.1-mountain-600x380.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/46.1-mountain-768x486.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/46.1-mountain.png 1500w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 750px) 100vw, 750px\" /></a></p> <p>This is the real political picture in the U.S. It’s not only Right vs. Left. It’s High vs. Low. Forward vs. Backward. Wise vs. Foolish. Value Games vs. Power Games. It’s not only wing politics—it’s also <em>rung </em>politics. Many of our political struggles are, in fact, horizontal. But that’s all in the shadow of the <em>big</em>&nbsp;political tug-of-war. Which is vertical.</p> <p style=\"text-align: center;\">___________</p> \n              <div style=\"height:38px\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"wp-block-spacer\"></div> <p>This was me, heading off to college:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/47.1-aladdin.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8595 size-medium\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/47.1-aladdin-600x329.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"329\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/47.1-aladdin-600x329.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/47.1-aladdin-768x421.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/47.1-aladdin-750x411.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/47.1-aladdin-239x130.png 239w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/47.1-aladdin.png 1253w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a></p> <p>The world was my oyster. It was exciting. But then the political conversations started.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/47.2-aladdin.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8596\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/47.2-aladdin.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"450\" height=\"3356\" /></a></p> <p>For the first time in my life, my political views were being challenged. It was like I was standing there living my life and these new friends were trying to shove me off a cliff:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/49-cliff.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8597 size-medium\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/49-cliff-600x596.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"596\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/49-cliff-600x596.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/49-cliff-150x150.png 150w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/49-cliff-768x762.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/49-cliff-750x744.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/49-cliff.png 813w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a></p> <p>I didn’t know it at the time, but I was standing on a very common intellectual path, commonly referenced as the <a href=\"https://www.verywellmind.com/an-overview-of-the-dunning-kruger-effect-4160740#:~:targetText=The%20Dunning%2DKruger%20effect%20is,to%20recognize%20their%20own%20incompetence.\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Dunning-Kruger effect</a>.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#footnote-18-8422\" id=\"note-18-8422\" rel=\"footnote\">18</a> Here’s how I think of it.</p> <p><strong><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/50.1-childs-hill.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8598 size-medium\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/50.1-childs-hill-600x596.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"596\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/50.1-childs-hill-600x596.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/50.1-childs-hill-150x150.png 150w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/50.1-childs-hill-768x762.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/50.1-childs-hill-750x744.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/50.1-childs-hill.png 813w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a></strong></p> <p>It’s a lot like a roller coaster. At the time, I had spent my life doing the roller coaster’s big first creeping uphill part. Suddenly, I was at that terrifying moment where the car levels out and starts to tilt downward…</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/50.2-childs-hill.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8599 size-medium\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/50.2-childs-hill-600x596.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"596\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/50.2-childs-hill-600x596.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/50.2-childs-hill-150x150.png 150w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/50.2-childs-hill-768x762.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/50.2-childs-hill-750x744.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/50.2-childs-hill.png 813w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a></p> <p>I was left with two options:</p> <p><strong>Option 1: Stay up on Child’s Hill.</strong> I could decide that I didn’t actually like these friends after all, that they were arrogant&nbsp;ignorant assholes, and distance myself from them. I could seek out new friends more like the people I was used to talking to and try to forget about this whole bad early college experience. Re-isolate myself from dissent, reconfirm my established beliefs, and restore my confidence (which the <a href=\"https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs11109-010-9112-2\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">backfire effect</a> suggests wouldn’t have taken long).</p> <p><strong>Option 2: Take the plunge.</strong> Let go of my comfortable conviction and embrace these new bad feelings of self-doubt and existential confusion.</p> <p>I went tumbling.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/50.3-childs-hill.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8677 size-medium\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/50.3-childs-hill-600x596.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"596\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/50.3-childs-hill-600x596.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/50.3-childs-hill-150x150.png 150w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/50.3-childs-hill-768x762.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/50.3-childs-hill-750x744.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/50.3-childs-hill.png 813w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a></p> <p>As I tumbled, it sunk in that to be as opinionated as I had been entering college, you either have to be an expert or full of shit—and I wasn’t an expert. I was a Democrat mostly for the same reason that I was a Red Sox fan. They were my team, and that was that.</p> <p>Pretty soon I had no idea what I thought or who I was or what was right or wrong. I didn’t feel like a proud Democrat anymore. Tim the Democrat was a fraud and I was determined not to be a fraud ever again. But a Republican? <em>Me?</em> A <em>Republican? </em>No way. I had been indoctrinated too hard for too long to fully switch teams. I started to dread political conversation because I wasn’t sure who I was supposed to <em>be</em> when these conversations happened. It was a bad situation. I was here:</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/50.4-childs-hill.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8601 size-medium\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/50.4-childs-hill-600x596.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"596\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/50.4-childs-hill-600x596.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/50.4-childs-hill-150x150.png 150w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/50.4-childs-hill-768x762.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/50.4-childs-hill-750x744.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/50.4-childs-hill.png 813w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a></p> <p>Insecure Canyon is where you are when you’re past the <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2015/11/the-cook-and-the-chef-musks-secret-sauce.html#epiphany1\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">“Wait I actually don’t know shit” epiphany</a>, but not yet past the <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2015/11/the-cook-and-the-chef-musks-secret-sauce.html#epiphany2\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">“Ohhhh no one <em>else</em> knows shit either” epiphany</a>. The two-part epiphany, when still incomplete, leaves a thinker self-aware enough to know what they don’t know but not yet wise enough to know that <em>not</em> knowing is a healthy, productive state. The unpleasant feeling of existential confusion and intellectual insecurity is the gateway drug to real intellectual growth—but when you haven’t had the complete epiphany, it doesn’t feel that way. It feels shameful and embarrassing. You feel stupid and wishy-washy, and you hope no one finds out how little you know. That’s where I was.</p> <p>And then it happened. I was in my freshman dorm room and one of my roommate’s friends was hanging out, and he said something like, “And really, all the reasonable people are centrist anyway.”</p> <p>It all clicked. I was a <em>Centrist</em>. It was the perfect new identity. Fuck all those political extremists. <em>I </em>was a thoughtful, nuanced, moderate thinker who acknowledged that both sides had some good points and some bad points.</p> <p>We all look back on our previous selves and cringe about certain things. We’ve each got a list. Right near the top of mine is me coming home for Thanksgiving during my freshman year of college and declaring to anyone who would listen about how I was a Centrist. Wincey as fuck.</p> <p>People in Insecure Canyon are super vulnerable. They’re perfect targets for indoctrination into a new dogma, because they’re still too hazy to understand how knowledge works, and they’re dying to feel smart again. That’s why many people in Insecure Canyon end up making the mistake Tim the Centrist Moderate Independent made—they jump onto another dogma boat. This feels like a step forward. But it’s the opposite. It’s a young chick flying for the first time, feeling the cold winds, and making a U-turn right back to the nest. This is what I did. I had tried to solve the bad feelings of Insecure Canyon by running back up to the top of Child’s Hill, just with a new identity cloak on. I went from a Fraud Democrat to a Fraud Centrist.</p> <p>The whole thing reminds me of a drawing from <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2014/01/the-great-perils-of-social-interaction.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">another post</a>.</p> <p><strong><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/48-concept-of-you.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8602 \" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/48-concept-of-you.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"330\" height=\"350\" /></a></strong></p> <p>Thankfully, some self-awareness eventually crept in. My brief foray into Centrism turned out to be like getting out of a long relationship with a crazy person only to immediately jump into a rebound fling with the next person I met. But the fling had taught me something. If I were ever going to really figure out who I was and get myself into a healthy future relationship, I’d have to be okay with being single for a while.</p> <p>So my identity shifted again, this time to a guy who was Still Asking Questions. I became a SAQist.</p> <p>Over the next few years, I started to look up for the first time and notice the y-axis of the political space. This whole time, I had been staring down at the ground, searching for the right spot along the What You Think axis—when the real answer was <em>above </em>me.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/50.4A-me-looking-up-1.png\"><img class=\"alignnone size-full wp-image-8697\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/50.4A-me-looking-up-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"1937\" height=\"1508\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/50.4A-me-looking-up-1.png 1937w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/50.4A-me-looking-up-1-600x467.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/50.4A-me-looking-up-1-768x598.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/50.4A-me-looking-up-1-750x584.png 750w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 1937px) 100vw, 1937px\" /></a></p> <p>Looking up at the vertical axis for the first time, I felt like <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9woRJ7-mD7Y\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">these monkeys</a>.</p> <p>On the roller coaster, I was now standing here, a born-again SAQist, ready to start a life of climbing:</p> <p><strong><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/50.5-childs-hill.png\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-8603 size-medium\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/50.5-childs-hill-600x596.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"600\" height=\"596\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/50.5-childs-hill-600x596.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/50.5-childs-hill-150x150.png 150w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/50.5-childs-hill-768x762.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/50.5-childs-hill-750x744.png 750w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/50.5-childs-hill.png 813w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 600px) 100vw, 600px\" /></a></strong></p> <p>I’d like to tell you that it’s been a straightforward trudge up Grown-Up Mountain since then.</p> <p>But old habits die hard, and it turns out it’s <em>really </em>hard to stay on Grown-Up Mountain. When I declared myself an unattached SAQist, I didn’t realize just how attached my Primitive Mind was to the color blue.</p> <p>I’d go through all the right motions—reading op-eds by the most convincing conservative writers and seeking out flaws in Democrat politicians or their platforms. I played the <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2015/11/the-cook-and-the-chef-musks-secret-sauce.html#why\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">“Why?” Game</a> with myself about my lingering instinct that the left’s policies were more logical and more reasonable and search for evidence that those instincts were no more than a bad habit. I genuinely began to feel conflicted and confused about whether the Right or the Left made more sense when it came to fiscal and foreign policy and the optimal size of government.</p> <p>But then election season would come around, and I’d feel like I was rooting for the Red Sox again. The Democrats still felt like “my people,” no matter how hard I tried to shake the feeling off. Were the Democrats actually just more in line with my values, or was it just my Primitive Mind doing this? Or was it a little of both?</p> <p>Whatever the cause of my attachment, the Republicans of the 2000s—with their Iraq War and their snowballs and their traditional marriage and their stem cell bans—weren’t helping the situation. As I tried to rid myself of the notion that the Democrats were “my people,” the Republicans—with their Sarah Palin and their Sean Hannity and their <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kxzONeK1OwQ\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Perry ad</a> and their <a href=\"https://youtu.be/2olwuAy3_og?t=814\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">just watch this for 30 seconds</a>—would continually make it crystal clear that they were <em>certainly </em>not my people.</p> <p>Well good news! Over the past decade, the Left finally did it. They regressed so far that they became as “not my people” as the Republicans. They actually went insane enough to free me from my tribal handcuffs. I spent a lot of years saying I was “an Independent” while not truly believing it. Today, I can say it with a straight face.</p> <p>It’s amazing how much clearer your vision gets when you really—<em>actually</em>—separate your identity from a tribe. I can see reality better now. The bad news is that I don’t like what I see with my new eyes. It’s…the situation is pretty scary.</p> <p>We’ve got a problem and we need to fix it.</p> <p>This whole series so far has been getting us ready to dive head first into that problem, with clearer eyes than normal. That’s where we’ll be headed in the final group of chapters.</p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2020/01/sick-giant.html\"><img class=\"alignnone wp-image-7661\" src=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/next-1.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"103\" height=\"56\" srcset=\"http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/next-1.png 1100w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/next-1-300x164.png 300w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/next-1-768x419.png 768w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/next-1-600x327.png 600w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/next-1-374x200.png 374w, http://28oa9i1t08037ue3m1l0i861.wpengine.netdna-cdn.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/next-1-239x130.png 239w\" sizes=\"(max-width: 103px) 100vw, 103px\" /></a></p> <p style=\"text-align:center\" class=\"wbwFont\">Chapter 10: <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2020/01/sick-giant.html\">A Sick Giant</a></p> \n              <div style=\"height:38px\" aria-hidden=\"true\" class=\"wp-block-spacer\"></div> <p style=\"text-align: center;\">___________</p> <p>If you like Wait But Why, sign up for the <strong><a class=\"ClickPico PicoRule\">email list</a></strong> and we’ll send you new posts right when they come out. It’s a super unannoying list I promise.</p> <p>Huge thanks to our Patreon supporters for making this series free for everyone. To support Wait But Why, <a href=\"https://www.patreon.com/waitbutwhy\"><strong>visit our Patreon page</strong></a>.</p> <p style=\"text-align: center;\">___________</p> <h3><strong>More vertical tugs-of-war:</strong></h3> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2013/10/why-procrastinators-procrastinate.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><strong>The productivity tug-of-war</strong></a></p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2014/06/taming-mammoth-let-peoples-opinions-run-life.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><strong>The social tug-of-war</strong></a></p> <p><a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2014/10/religion-for-the-nonreligious.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\"><strong>The awareness tug-of-war</strong></a></p> <p style=\"text-align: center;\">___________</p> <h3><strong>Sources and related reading</strong></h3> <p>At the heart of an effort to grow in our political lives has to be a continual effort to get better at thinking and communicating. There are a lot of great writers on the internet dedicating themselves to helping people think and argue more rationally. I’ve learned a lot from them. Some of my favorites: </p> <p>The mecca of rationalism, <a href=\"https://www.lesswrong.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Less Wrong</a>, run by Eliezer Yudkowsky and his ragtag gang of rationalists. Whenever there’s a cutting-edge new idea making the rounds, Eliezer was writing about it 5-10 years ago. A deep dive on Less Wrong will make you smarter. <a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Rationality-AI-Zombies-Eliezer-Yudkowsky-ebook/dp/B00ULP6EW2/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&amp;qid=1546042059&amp;sr=8-2&amp;keywords=rationality+from+ai+to+zombies&amp;pldnSite=1\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">This collection</a> is a nice place to start.</p> <p>A Less Wrong offspring, Scott Alexander’s blog <a href=\"https://slatestarcodex.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Slate Star Codex</a> is a giant pile of clarity. If you liked this post, you’ll really like SSC. Specific further reading on ideas in this post: Scott on <a href=\"https://slatestarcodex.com/2014/11/03/all-in-all-another-brick-in-the-motte/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">motte-and-baileying</a>, <a href=\"https://slatestarcodex.com/2014/05/12/weak-men-are-superweapons/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">weak-manning</a>, and <a href=\"https://slatestarcodex.com/2014/04/15/the-cowpox-of-doubt/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">the inoculation effect</a>.</p> <p>Another big pile of wisdom: <a href=\"http://www.paulgraham.com/articles.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Paul Graham’s essays</a>. You can read about his “hierarchy of disagreement” I referenced <a href=\"http://www.paulgraham.com/disagree.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">here</a>.</p> <p>Julia Galef, co-founder of the <a href=\"https://www.rationality.org/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Center for Applied Rationality</a>, is a great explainer of rational concepts. Go on a spiral through <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/user/measureofdoubt/videos\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">these</a> sometime.</p> <p><a href=\"https://www.adamgrant.net/?fbclid=IwAR2mf-A6-3LHUxfNRS2srsRpPYtwn492nmAByUT8xcSh-shbbmFVQ5Hajao\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Adam Grant</a> spends his life using <a href=\"https://mgmt.wharton.upenn.edu/profile/grantad/#research\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">research</a> to embarrass conventional wisdom. Exceptional communicator but very bald.</p> <p>Shane Snow <a href=\"https://www.shanesnow.com/articles\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">dives deep</a> on how we can think better, and he makes it fun. His awesome article on <a href=\"https://www.shanesnow.com/articles/intellectual-humility\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">intellectual humility</a> is especially relevant to this series.</p> <p><strong>Other resources:</strong></p> <p>A great collection of research that I referenced in the post: <a href=\"https://www.sciencedirect.com/journal/cognition/vol/188/suppl/C\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">The Cognitive Science of Political Thought</a>. And a <a href=\"https://behavioralscientist.org/the-cognitive-science-of-political-thought-practical-takeaways-for-political-discourse/\">summary</a> of some of the findings.</p> <p>The <a href=\"https://www.nature.com/articles/srep39589\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">study I referenced</a> about how we process challenges to our political and non-political beliefs with different parts of our brain. By Jonas T. Kaplan, Sarah I. Gimbel and Sam Harris. The article’s citation list is full of interesting research. Other studies I referenced about how politics makes us bad at thinking: <a href=\"https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0959378014000909\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">1</a>, <a href=\"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/14599246\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">2</a>, <a href=\"https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1111/j.1559-1816.2010.00588.x\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">3</a>, <a href=\"https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs11109-010-9112-2\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">4</a>, <a href=\"https://www.pnas.org/content/early/2017/08/15/1704882114.short\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">5</a></p> <p>Some <a href=\"https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/getting-duped/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">nice examples</a> of straw-manning and weak-manning in politics, by Yvonne Raley and Robert Talisse (who seems to have coined the term “weak man”). To go deeper, <a href=\"http://www.communicationcache.com/uploads/1/0/8/8/10887248/two_forms_of_the_straw_man.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">here’s their paper</a> on the topic.</p> <p><a href=\"https://www.researchgate.net/publication/336076674_Ideological_differences_in_the_expanse_of_the_moral_circle\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Research</a> on how progressives tend to be more concerned about the global and conservatives more about the local. By Adam Waytz, Liane Young, Ravi Iyer, and Jonathan Haidt.</p> <p><a href=\"https://pudding.cool/2018/01/chyrons/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Cool interactive</a> exploring how Fox, CNN, and MSNBC differ in what stories they cover and how they present them.</p> <p>Wikipedia has nice compilations of <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_cognitive_biases\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">cognitive biases</a> and <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_fallacies\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">fallacies</a>.</p> <p><a href=\"https://rationalwiki.org/wiki/Rapoport%27s_Rules\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Rapoport’s Rules</a> for how to be a great arguer by doing the opposite of straw-manning (sometimes called steel-manning).</p> <p>The <a href=\"https://philpapers.org/archive/SHATVO-2.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">original explanation</a> of the motte and bailey doctrine by Nicholas Shackel, who coined the term.</p> <p>The <a href=\"https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/027e/3e86960b86a59a552d8ed21bb9c4815b5a16.pdf\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">original explainer</a> on the inoculation effect.</p> <p><a href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2011-12-01/correlation-or-causation\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Fun reminder</a> of how idiotic it is to assume correlation implies causation.</p> <p>A book to remind you that <a href=\"https://www.penguinrandomhouse.com/books/533524/the-knowledge-illusion-by-steven-sloman-and-philip-fernbach/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">you don’t know shit</a>.</p>\n              <div class=\"footnotes\">\n               <hr />\n               <ol>\n                <li id=\"footnote-1-8422\" class=\"footnote\"><p>Sometimes more nuanced discussions will add a second dimension to the political spectrum—<a href=\"https://fee.org/media/9818/20131203_fulmer1a.png\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">something like this</a>, perhaps—but that’s not the kind of second dimension I’m talking about. That’s taking the 1D What You Think axis and turning it into a 2D What You Think square. That’s a good way to add clarity to the discussion, but it’s still lacking <em>our</em> second dimension: the Psych Spectrum. As far as we’re concerned, that’s still a 1D discussion—just a more nuanced one.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#note-1-8422\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n                <!--/#footnote-1.footnote-->\n                <li id=\"footnote-2-8422\" class=\"footnote\"><p>Many people who think of themselves as conservative would argue that there are plenty of areas where they also want to forge a new path forward, not a reversion to the past—but under the definitions we’re using here, that simply would define them as progressive on those issues.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#note-2-8422\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n                <!--/#footnote-2.footnote-->\n                <li id=\"footnote-3-8422\" class=\"footnote\"><p>The lawyers in this metaphor aren’t to be confused with the Attorney of our ladder. Damn coinciding metaphors.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#note-3-8422\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n                <!--/#footnote-3.footnote-->\n                <li id=\"footnote-4-8422\" class=\"footnote\"><p>It’s funny that one thing progressives and conservatives can agree on is that progressives are dragging conservatives <em>somewhere</em>.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#note-4-8422\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n                <!--/#footnote-4.footnote-->\n                <li id=\"footnote-5-8422\" class=\"footnote\"><p>Side shout-out to <em>Pinocchio</em>, which I watched 550 times as a child.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#note-5-8422\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n                <!--/#footnote-5.footnote-->\n                <li id=\"footnote-6-8422\" class=\"footnote\"><p>btw, Geppetto—classic <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2016/05/clueyness-a-weird-kind-of-sad.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">cluey</a> character.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#note-6-8422\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n                <!--/#footnote-6.footnote-->\n                <li id=\"footnote-7-8422\" class=\"footnote\"><p>I explained the shit out of sound once, <a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/2016/03/sound.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">here</a>.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#note-7-8422\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n                <!--/#footnote-7.footnote-->\n                <li id=\"footnote-8-8422\" class=\"footnote\"><p>The closest you’ll see Disney go to a middle ground is the character that seems kind of bad (and only in a cuddly way), and then by the end of the movie comes around to full 1-ness. An example might be Maui in <em>Moana</em>.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#note-8-8422\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n                <!--/#footnote-8.footnote-->\n                <li id=\"footnote-9-8422\" class=\"footnote\"><p>At the end of their respective movies, the Beast and Simba both have every justification to kill Gaston and Scar—but as perfect 1s, they can’t kill anyone, even the movies’ 0s. Instead, Gaston trips and falls to his death and the hyenas do away with Scar. Then there’s Jafar, who does himself in with his own insatiable thirst for power. Ursula is killed by the highly dreamy Prince Eric, but kind of indirectly with a boat, and like—she was about to turn his girlfriend into a little sad-faced sea plant. Pretty fair.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#note-9-8422\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n                <!--/#footnote-9.footnote-->\n                <li id=\"footnote-10-8422\" class=\"footnote\"><p>While we’re in the footnote zone, let’s discuss a few things. To get all of these images I actually went through these movies and took screenshots. Except Disney is so scary that you can’t even take screenshots of Disney movies playing on your computer. So I had to take pictures of the screen with my phone. Don’t tell Disney.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#note-10-8422\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n                <!--/#footnote-10.footnote-->\n                <li id=\"footnote-11-8422\" class=\"footnote\"><p>Alan Menken has been all up in my piece the last three days since I went through these movies, circulating in my head. He’s a delicious man.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#note-11-8422\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n                <!--/#footnote-11.footnote-->\n                <li id=\"footnote-12-8422\" class=\"footnote\"><p>I’m a little sad every day of my life that I’m not married to Belle.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#note-12-8422\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n                <!--/#footnote-12.footnote-->\n                <li id=\"footnote-13-8422\" class=\"footnote\"><p>k bye<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#note-13-8422\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n                <!--/#footnote-13.footnote-->\n                <li id=\"footnote-14-8422\" class=\"footnote\"><p>This is why there are so many more WWII movies than WWI movies. WWII is a nice digital-seeming story, with a clear good side and a clear evil one. WWI, on the other hand, is messy and complex and doesn’t lend itself nearly as well to simple black-and-white depictions.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#note-14-8422\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n                <!--/#footnote-14.footnote-->\n                <li id=\"footnote-15-8422\" class=\"footnote\"><p>Of course, sometimes the electoral system will actually be compromised in places, something people on the high rungs are always concerned about. But on the low rungs, they’re only concerned about instances that hurt their party and go into denial about possible corruption when it helps their party.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#note-15-8422\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n                <!--/#footnote-15.footnote-->\n                <li id=\"footnote-16-8422\" class=\"footnote\"><p>In Chapter 7, when we discussed how confirmation bias works in individuals, we identified three layers of defense in a person’s head: 1) the Attention Bouncer; 2) the Belief Bouncer; 3) the Puzzler. So dissent really has to pass five filters to change the mind of a person in PDW: the media filter, the sharing filter, and the three individual filters. That’s some intense friction.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#note-16-8422\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n                <!--/#footnote-16.footnote-->\n                <li id=\"footnote-17-8422\" class=\"footnote\"><p>It got me thinking. If current events—which are literally happening now, with video footage and living eye-witnesses—are able to be presented entirely differently to different groups, what does that say about our knowledge of history? On one hand, hindsight can help with clarity—but on the other, historical stories have endured decades and sometimes centuries of the game of telephone, with each step of the way having their own biases and incentives. When we think about what we’ve been taught about history, we should remember to stay skeptical.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#note-17-8422\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n                <!--/#footnote-17.footnote-->\n                <li id=\"footnote-18-8422\" class=\"footnote\"><p>Or, more accurately, the common misinterpretation of it. Here’s what the Dunning-Kruger effect <a href=\"https://www.talyarkoni.org/blog/2010/07/07/what-the-dunning-kruger-effect-is-and-isnt/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">actually is</a>.<a href=\"https://waitbutwhy.com/?p=8422#note-18-8422\" class=\"footnote-return\">↩</a></p></li>\n                <!--/#footnote-18.footnote-->\n               </ol>\n              </div>\n
